Since the LLM's interactions with the search engine are black-box, CORE targets the content returned by search engines as the primary means of influencing output rankings. Specifically, CORE optimizes retrieved content by appending strategically designed optimization content to steer the ranking of outputs. We introduce three types of optimization content: string-based, reasoning-based, and review-based, demonstrating their effectiveness in shaping output rankings. To evaluate CORE in realistic settings, we introduce ProductBench, a large-scale benchmark with 15 product categories and 200 products per category, where each product is associated with its top-10 recommendations collected from Amazon's search interface. Extensive experiments on four LLMs with search capabilities (GPT-4o, Gemini-2.5, Claude-4, and Grok-3) demonstrate that CORE achieves an average Promotion Success Rate of \textbf{91.4\% @Top-5}, \textbf{86.6\% @Top-3}, and \textbf{80.3\% @Top-1}, across 15 product categories, outperforming existing ranking manipulation methods while preserving the fluency of optimized content.

title: Lee-Yang tensors and Hamiltonian complexity
authors: Benjamin Wong, Sergey Bravyi, David Gosset, Yinchen Liu
abstract: A complex tensor with $n$ binary indices can be identified with a multilinear polynomial in $n$ complex variables. We say it is a Lee-Yang tensor with radius $r$ if the polynomial is nonzero whenever all variables lie in the open disk of radius $r$. In this work we study quantum states and observables which are Lee-Yang tensors when expressed in the computational basis. We first review their basic properties, including closure under tensor contraction and certain quantum operations. We show that quantum states with Lee-Yang radius $r > 1$ can be prepared by quasipolynomial-sized circuits. We also show that every Hermitian operator with Lee-Yang radius $r > 1$ has a unique principal eigenvector. These results suggest that $r = 1$ is a key threshold for quantum states and observables. Finally, we consider a family of two-local Hamiltonians where every interaction term energetically favors a deformed EPR state $|00\rangle + s|11\rangle$ for some $0 \leq s \leq 1$. We numerically investigate this model and find that on all graphs considered the Lee-Yang radius of the ground state is at least $r = 1/\sqrt{s}$ while the spectral gap between the two smallest eigenvalues is at least $1-s^2$. We conjecture that these lower bounds hold more generally; in particular, this would provide an efficient quantum adiabatic algorithm for the quantum Max-Cut problem on uniformly weighted bipartite graphs.

title: Human-in-the-Loop Failure Recovery with Adaptive Task Allocation
authors: Lorena Maria Genua, Nikita Boguslavskii, Zhi Li
abstract: Since the recent Covid-19 pandemic, mobile manipulators and humanoid assistive robots with higher levels of autonomy have increasingly been adopted for patient care and living assistance. Despite advancements in autonomy, these robots often struggle to perform reliably in dynamic and unstructured environments and require human intervention to recover from failures. Effective human-robot collaboration is essential to enable robots to receive assistance from the most competent operator, in order to reduce their workload and minimize disruptions in task execution. In this paper, we propose an adaptive method for allocating robotic failures to human operators (ARFA). Our proposed approach models the capabilities of human operators, and continuously updates these beliefs based on their actual performance for failure recovery. For every failure to be resolved, a reward function calculates expected outcomes based on operator capabilities and historical data, task urgency, and current workload distribution. The failure is then assigned to the operator with the highest expected reward. Our simulations and user studies show that ARFA outperforms random allocation, significantly reducing robot idle time, improving overall system performance, and leading to a more distributed workload among operators.

title: On enumeration of spanning trees of complete multipartite graphs containing a fixed spanning forest
authors: Wei Wang, Jun Ge
abstract: We present a determinantal formula for the number of spanning trees of a complete multipartite graph containing a given spanning forest $F$. Our approach relies on the Generalized Matrix Determinant Lemma and Jacobi's formula for the derivative of a determinant. This work generalizes known results for complete bipartite graphs and offers an algebraic perspective on the problem.

title: Efficient Estimation of Kernel Surrogate Models for Task Attribution
authors: Zhenshuo Zhang, Minxuan Duan, Hongyang R. Zhang
abstract: Modern AI agents such as large language models are trained on diverse tasks -- translation, code generation, mathematical reasoning, and text prediction -- simultaneously. A key question is to quantify how each individual training task influences performance on a target task, a problem we refer to as task attribution. The direct approach, leave-one-out retraining, measures the effect of removing each task, but is computationally infeasible at scale. An alternative approach that builds surrogate models to predict a target task's performance for any subset of training tasks has emerged in recent literature. Prior work focuses on linear surrogate models, which capture first-order relationships, but miss nonlinear interactions such as synergy, antagonism, or XOR-type effects. In this paper, we first consider a unified task weighting framework for analyzing task attribution methods, and show a new connection between linear surrogate models and influence functions through a second-order analysis. Then, we introduce kernel surrogate models, which more effectively represent second-order task interactions. To efficiently learn the kernel surrogate, we develop a gradient-based estimation procedure that leverages a first-order approximation of pretrained models; empirically, this yields accurate estimates with less than $2\%$ relative error without repeated retraining. Experiments across multiple domains -- including math reasoning in transformers, in-context learning, and multi-objective reinforcement learning -- demonstrate the effectiveness of kernel surrogate models. They achieve a $25\%$ higher correlation with the leave-one-out ground truth than linear surrogates and influence-function baselines. When used for downstream task selection, kernel surrogate models yield a $40\%$ improvement in demonstration selection for in-context learning and multi-objective reinforcement learning benchmarks.

title: ProAct: A Benchmark and Multimodal Framework for Structure-Aware Proactive Response
authors: Xiaomeng Zhu, Fengming Zhu, Weijie Zhou, Ye Tian, Zhenlin Hu, Yufei Huang, Yuchun Guo, Xinyu Wu, Zhengyou Zhang, Fangzhen Lin, Xuantang Xiong
abstract: While passive agents merely follow instructions, proactive agents align with higher-level objectives, such as assistance and safety by continuously monitoring the environment to determine when and how to act. However, developing proactive agents is hindered by the lack of specialized resources. To address this, we introduce ProAct-75, a benchmark designed to train and evaluate proactive agents across diverse domains, including assistance, maintenance, and safety monitoring. Spanning 75 tasks, our dataset features 91,581 step-level annotations enriched with explicit task graphs. These graphs encode step dependencies and parallel execution possibilities, providing the structural grounding necessary for complex decision-making. Building on this benchmark, we propose ProAct-Helper, a reference baseline powered by a Multimodal Large Language Model (MLLM) that grounds decision-making in state detection, and leveraging task graphs to enable entropy-driven heuristic search for action selection, allowing agents to execute parallel threads independently rather than mirroring the human's next step. Extensive experiments demonstrate that ProAct-Helper outperforms strong closed-source models, improving trigger detection mF1 by 6.21%, saving 0.25 more steps in online one-step decision, and increasing the rate of parallel actions by 15.58%.

title: Precision in Practice: Knowledge Guided Code Summarizing Grounded in Industrial Expectations
authors: Jintai Li, Songqiang Chen, Shuo Jin, Xiaoyuan Xie
abstract: Code summaries are essential for helping developers understand code functionality and reducing maintenance and collaboration costs. Although recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have significantly improved automatic code summarization, the practical usefulness of generated summaries in industrial settings remains insufficiently explored. In collaboration with documentation experts from the industrial HarmonyOS project, we conducted a questionnaire study showing that over 57.4% of code summaries produced by state-of-the-art approaches were rejected due to violations of developers' expectations for industrial documentation. Beyond semantic similarity to reference summaries, developers emphasize additional requirements, including the use of appropriate domain terminology, explicit function categorization, and the avoidance of redundant implementation details. To address these expectations, we propose ExpSum, an expectation-aware code summarization approach that integrates function metadata abstraction, informative metadata filtering, context-aware domain knowledge retrieval, and constraint-driven prompting to guide LLMs in generating structured, expectation-aligned summaries. We evaluate ExpSum on the HarmonyOS project and widely used code summarization benchmarks. Experimental results show that ExpSum consistently outperforms all baselines, achieving improvements of up to 26.71% in BLEU-4 and 20.10% in ROUGE-L on HarmonyOS. Furthermore, LLM-based evaluations indicate that ExpSum-generated summaries better align with developer expectations across other projects, demonstrating its effectiveness for industrial code documentation.

title: Efficient Training of Boltzmann Generators Using Off-Policy Log-Dispersion Regularization
authors: Henrik Schopmans, Christopher von Klitzing, Pascal Friederich
abstract: Sampling from unnormalized probability densities is a central challenge in computational science. Boltzmann generators are generative models that enable independent sampling from the Boltzmann distribution of physical systems at a given temperature. However, their practical success depends on data-efficient training, as both simulation data and target energy evaluations are costly. To this end, we propose off-policy log-dispersion regularization (LDR), a novel regularization framework that builds on a generalization of the log-variance objective. We apply LDR in the off-policy setting in combination with standard data-based training objectives, without requiring additional on-policy samples. LDR acts as a shape regularizer of the energy landscape by leveraging additional information in the form of target energy labels. The proposed regularization framework is broadly applicable, supporting unbiased or biased simulation datasets as well as purely variational training without access to target samples. Across all benchmarks, LDR improves both final performance and data efficiency, with sample efficiency gains of up to one order of magnitude.

title: Angles Between Intermediate Operator Subalgebras
authors: Ved Prakash Gupta, Deepika Sharma
abstract: Motivated by [2] and [5], the notions of interior and exterior angles between a pair of compatible intermediate W*-subalgebras of an inclusion of W*-algebras with a normal conditional expectation with finite probabilistic index are introduced. This is then employed effectively to define the interior angle between a pair of compatible intermediate C*-subalgebras of an inclusion of non-unital C*-algebras with a conditional expectation with finite Watatani index. It is also shown that the interior angle is stable under the minimal tensor product of unital C*-algebras.

title: Double integrals and transformation formulas for Appell--Lauricella hypergeometric functions $F_D$
authors: Shihao Wang, Chenglong Yu, Zhiwei Zheng
abstract: The monodromy of hypergeometric functions can govern the properties of the functions themselves. Previously, the second and third authors studied the commensurability relations among monodromy groups of the Appell--Lauricella hypergeometric functions using Deligne--Mostow theory and the geometric correspondence between curves and surfaces. In this paper, we apply the same construction to obtain transformation formulas among these hypergeometric functions. This also provides an alternative approach to some of Goursat's quadratic transformations via double integrals and Fubini's theorem.

title: MIRROR: A Multi-Agent Framework with Iterative Adaptive Revision and Hierarchical Retrieval for Optimization Modeling in Operations Research
authors: Yifan Shi, Jialong Shi, Jiayi Wang, Ye Fan, Jianyong Sun
abstract: Operations Research (OR) relies on expert-driven modeling-a slow and fragile process ill-suited to novel scenarios. While large language models (LLMs) can automatically translate natural language into optimization models, existing approaches either rely on costly post-training or employ multi-agent frameworks, yet most still lack reliable collaborative error correction and task-specific retrieval, often leading to incorrect outputs. We propose MIRROR, a fine-tuning-free, end-to-end multi-agent framework that directly translates natural language optimization problems into mathematical models and solver code. MIRROR integrates two core mechanisms: (1) execution-driven iterative adaptive revision for automatic error correction, and (2) hierarchical retrieval to fetch relevant modeling and coding exemplars from a carefully curated exemplar library. Experiments show that MIRROR outperforms existing methods on standard OR benchmarks, with notable results on complex industrial datasets such as IndustryOR and Mamo-ComplexLP. By combining precise external knowledge infusion with systematic error correction, MIRROR provides non-expert users with an efficient and reliable OR modeling solution, overcoming the fundamental limitations of general-purpose LLMs in expert optimization tasks.

title: Extraction of the pion-nucleon coupling constant using the effective-range expansion with the left-hand cut
authors: Bo-Yang Liu, Bing Wu, Ji-Wei Fu, Meng-Lin Du, Feng-Kun Guo, Ulf-G. Meißner
abstract: We apply the generalized effective-range expansion of Phys. Rev. Lett. 135, 011903(2025), which incorporates the left-hand cut from one-pion exchange, to low-energy neutron-proton scattering in the $^1S_0$ and $^3S_1$ channels. The amplitude zero for the center-of-mass momentum near 0.35 GeV in the $^1S_0$ channel is naturally accommodated within this framework. We extract the pole position, scattering length, effective range, and the pseudoscalar pion-nucleon coupling constant $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ at different expansion orders. The low-energy parameters are stable and consistent with established values, while $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ exhibits larger uncertainties. The extraction of $g_{πN}^2/(4π)$ is data-driven, relying on the analytic constraints from the left-hand cut and phase-shift data within the one-pion-exchange approximation. Despite larger uncertainties compared to high-precision extractions, the consistency with established values demonstrates that this framework can probe the left-hand-cut singularity.

title: Non-perturbative renormalization for lattice massive QED$_2$: the ultraviolet problem
authors: Simone Fabbri, Vieri Mastropietro, Bruno Renzi
abstract: We consider a lattice regularization, preserving Ward Identities (WI) and with a Wilson term, of the Massive QED$_2$, describing a fermion with mass $m$ and charge $\mathsf{e}$ interacting with a vector field with mass $M$, in the regime $m\ll M\ll a^{-1}$ ($a$ being the lattice spacing) which is the suitable one to mimic a realistic 4d massive gauge theory like the Electroweak sector. The presence of the lattice and of the mass $m$ breaks any solvability property. In this paper we prove that the effective action obtained after the integration of the ultraviolet degrees of freedom is expressed by expansions which are convergent for values of the coupling $|\mathsf{e}|\le \mathsf{e}_0$, with $\mathsf{e}_0$ independent on $a$ and $m$, and with cut-off-independent bare parameters. By combining this result with the analysis of the infrared part in previous papers we get a complete construction of the model and a number of properties whose analogous are expected to hold in 4d. The analysis is done by integrating out the bosons and reducing to a fermionic theory; however, with respect to the case with momentum regularizations (which break essential features like the WI), the resulting effective fermionic action has not a simple form and this requires the developments of new methods to get the necessary bounds.

title: Cholesky factorisation, and intrinsically sparse linear quadratic regulation
authors: Julia Adlercreutz, Richard Pates
abstract: We classify a family of matrices of shift operators that can be factorised in a computationally tractable manner with the Cholesky algorithm. Such matrices arise in the linear quadratic regulator problem, and related areas. We use the factorisation to uncover intrinsic sparsity properties in the control laws for transportation problems with an underlying tree structure. This reveals that the optimal control can be applied in a distributed manner that is obscured by standard solution methods.

title: Electrical Bioimpedance Sensing-based Proximity Distance Estimation for Needle Interventions: Two-Layer Model and Validation
authors: Yao Zhang, Zhuoqi Cheng, Mouloud Ourak, Thiusius Rajeeth Savarimuthu, Emmanuel Vander Poorten
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Needle-based interventions are routine in clinical practice, yet clinicians lack reliable, precise, real-time estimates of the tip-to-target distance—–a key determinant of safety and efficiency. To bridge this critical clinical gap, physics-based models that maps electrical bio-impedance (EBI) measurements to the absolute tip-to-target distance by leveraging tissue-intrinsic electrical properties encoded in EBI are presented in this work. A tripolar electrode configuration is adopted to ensure tool-independence and broad compatibility across instruments and anatomical sites. The optimal layout of electrode radius, inter-electrode spacing, and placement was identified through a systematic parametric study. The model was validated across finite-element simulations, saline solution experiments, and ex vivo layered tissue. In all settings, proximity distance estimates were accurate and robust across different insertion angles. In simulation, it achieved 0.55 mm RMSE/1.06 mm MAE when the target layer was less conductive than the first layer and 0.40 mm RMSE/1.21 mm MAE when it was more conductive. In saline, four insertion angles yielded millimeter errors with no angle dependence. In ex vivo layered tissue, accuracy remained near the millimeter level across angles (RMSE 1.00–1.13 mm and MAE 1.30–1.58 mm), which is slightly lower than saline yet consistent across orientations. Together, these results establish a general, instrument-agnostic framework for absolute proximity distance sensing during needle interventions with the potential to enhance safety and efficiency in minimally invasive procedures. Furthermore, by first focusing on a two-layer model, this work provides a clear pathway to multi-layer tissue modeling and broader anatomical generalization.

title: Self-Error Correcting Method for Magnetic-Array-Type Current Sensors in Multi-Core Cable Applications
authors: Xiaohu Liu, Keyu Hou, Kang Ma, Jian Liu, Angang Zheng, Zhengwei Qu, Wei Zhao, Lisha Peng, Songling Huang, Shisong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Data-driven methods enable online assessment of error states in magnetic-array-type current sensors, and long-term measurement stability can be enhanced through further self-error correction. However, when the magnetic-array-type current sensors are applied to multi-conductor systems such as multi-core cables, the time-varying correlations among conductor currents may degrade the performance of multi-latent-variable data-driven models for error evaluation. To address this issue, this paper proposes a robust self-error correcting method for magnetic-array-type current sensors even under significant variations in phase current correlations (e.g., large fluctuations in three-phase current imbalance). By incorporating phase current decoupling and principal component analysis (PCA), the correlation analysis of multi-latent variables (i.e., multi-conductor currents) is transformed into a single-latent-variable (corresponding to single phase current) modeling problem. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively detects error drifts of magnetic field sensors as low as 2×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup> in relative error and 2×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup> rad in phase error. Accurate evaluation and correction of each magnetic field sensor’s error drifts substantially eliminates the overall error drift in the magnetic-array-type current sensor, validating the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed self-error correcting method.

title: Proactive Handover Management in 6G Low-Altitude Economy Networks for Aerial Vehicles Using Artificial General Intelligence
authors: Shikhar Verma, Sayantan Bose, Mostafa M. Fouda, Zubair Md Fadlullah, Diptendu Sinha Roy
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: The rise of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and electric vertical take-off and landing (eVTOL) aircraft is accelerating the growth of the low-altitude economy (LAE), enabling mobility beyond conventional ground-based transport. However, aerial vehicles or flying vehicles (FVs) in LAE environments face significant communication challenges due to high mobility, frequent handovers between base stations (BSs), and the susceptibility of mmWave bands to blockage and path loss. Reactive handover mechanisms—triggered only after link degradation—often lead to disconnections and degraded service quality, particularly in dense urban areas. Moreover, uneven FV distribution can cause BS load imbalances, further compromising quality of service (QoS). To address these challenges, we propose a proactive BS association framework for intelligent handover management using artificial general intelligence (AGI). Our approach leverages deep learning to jointly predict future received signal strength indicator (RSSI) and BS load, enabling an autonomous decision algorithm to select optimal BSs for stable, high-throughput connectivity while minimizing unnecessary handovers. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed joint prediction-based strategy significantly reduces handover frequency and improves average throughput compared to reactive, single-metric base-lines and two additional benchmark predictors introduced for extended evaluation. These findings underscore the potential of predictive, AGI-driven mobility management to enhance the stability and performance of communication networks in the emerging LAE ecosystem.

title: Neuron Membership Inference Attack in Federated Learning for bit Scenarios
authors: Ruihong Xiu, Junqing Le, Di Zhang, Xiaofeng Liao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Federated learning (FL) is a secure approach to protecting client data privacy by remaining data local. However, semi-honest central servers expose clients to the risk of membership inference attacks (MIA). Differential privacy is often used to defend against MIA in FL, but the differential privacy-based federated learning (DP-FL) still faces the risk of privacy leakage for bit scenarios. This paper designs a novel neuron membership inference attack (NMIA) strategy under semi-honest central servers and bit scenarios, which can compromise DP-FL and obtain client privacy information. Specifically, NMIA generates an inference attack model with low computational overhead by training only in small-scale neurons. The attack model analyzes the gradient outputs of the FL clients and effectively infers information about specific client data. Sufficient conditions for the success of the NMIA have been theoretically proven. To comprehensively evaluate the performance of the NMIA strategy in bit scenarios, two differential privacy protection methods for randomized response encoding applicable to federated learning for bit scenarios (BDP-FL) are proposed. Experimental results show that NMIA can easily defeat traditional DP-FL, achieving an attack accuracy of over 99%, while NMIA’s attack accuracy in bit scenarios is about 20% higher than the existing attack strategies. In addition, NMIA can still defeat the optimized encoding BDP-FL with an attack accuracy of up to 90%, while the symmetric encoding BDP-FL can only mitigate NMIA at the cost of severe FL utility loss.

title: A Novel Wideband X-band Amplifying Metasurface
authors: Zi-An Chen, Kun Liao, Shao-Bin Liu, Zhi-Chao Sun, Zheng-Yu Huang, Zi-Kang Liang, Xiang-Hua Xie, Jian-Ping Chang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, a novel X-band amplifying metasurface with power amplifiers is proposed to enhance the reflected electromagnetic (EM) signals. The amplifying metasurface is designed based on a receiving, amplifying, and polarization-converted reradiating scheme. To ensure wideband performance, a cross-aperture coupled patch unit cell is meticulously designed. According to simulation results, the amplifying metasurface exhibits a gain variation between 0 and 14 dB within the 7.1-9.9 GHz. The designed amplifying metasurface is then fabricated as a prototype and experimentally measured. The experimental measurements demonstrate good agreement with the simulated results. With the increasing demand for the high-capacity network, the proposed amplifying metasurface aligns with the key requirements of future wireless systems, particularly in scenarios requiring dynamic coverage control and signal enhancement.

title: Electromechanical Simulation and 3D Visualization of a Solenoid-Powered V8 Engine
authors: Saptarshi Banerjee, Soumyajit Hazra, Pritam Aich, Samit Karmakar, Amitava Ghosh
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Internal combustion engines have long been the backbone of mechanical motion in automotive and industrial systems. However, increasing focus on sustainable alternatives and the need to reduce carbon emissions has driven innovation in electromagnetically driven systems. This paper presents a simulation-based design of a V8 solenoid engine — a system that replaces conventional fuel-based combustion with electromagnetic linear actuators (solenoids) to mimic piston-like motion. Unlike traditional electric motors, solenoids offer high instantaneous torque and direct electromagnetic force application, making them suitable for high-load, low-speed applications such as educational EV prototypes or automation systems. The primary aim of this research is to explore the feasibility, energy efficiency, and mechanical performance of such a system through simulation tools. We use Proteus to simulate solenoid activation via control circuitry and Fusion 360 to model the mechanical components, including the pistons and crankshaft. By integrating circuit-level control with realistic mechanical modeling, this project bridges the gap between electronics and mechanical motion, serving as a proof-of-concept for solenoid-based engine alternatives in future electromechanical systems.

title: Development of a High-Gain Ceramic Mimo Antenna for Mm Wave Communication Supporting Smart City and Rural Broadband Infrastructure
authors: Vijayashree G C, Harshitha E, Nandu S, Nagesh K N, Vivek Singh, Ajay Kumar Dwivedi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Circularly polarized dielectric resonator antennas (CP-DRAs) are recognized as efficient radiators for millimeter-wave (mmWave) 5G links, combining miniature dimensions, minimal dielectric loss, and strong polarization stability. In this work, a compact two-port CP-DRA is modelled and refined in ANSYS HFSS for operation near 28 GHz to support 5G MIMO deployments. Circular polarization is accomplished through geometric shaping of the resonator and an offset ground aperture that excites orthogonal modes with approximately 90° phase separation. The realized design provides excellent impedance matching at 27.36 GHz(|S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf> | ≈ - 38 dB), an axial ratio under 3 dB, and inter-port isolation close to -30dB. The antenna features a broadside gain of 5.5 dBi while exhibiting greater than 95 % radiation efficiency. The associated diversity analysis revealed an ECC of <0.02, diversity gain of ~ 10 dB, and CCL of <0.1 bits/s/Hz. The innovation lies in the compact dual-feed architecture that maintains high isolation and stable circular polarization without additional decoupling networks. The findings corroborate that the suggested Circularly Polarized Dielectric Resonator Antenna (CP-DRA) presents an efficient and dependable platform for 28 GHz 5 G MIMO systems.

title: DWT Domain Precinct-Wise Scrambling for Encryption-then-Compression with JPEG XS
authors: Takayuki Nakachi, Park Cheolhwan, Yasuhisa Kato, Mitsuru Maruyama
abstract: We propose a JPEG XS compatible Encryption-then-Compression (EtC) scheme whose scrambling primitive is precinct-wise permutations defined in the discrete wavelet transform (DWT) domain. In this work, we permute LL precincts in the DWT domain using line-order permutations within the precinct height and cross-precinct reordering. This choice yields strong perceptual obfuscation at low computational cost while keeping the encoder unmodified. By designing the scrambling in a precinct-wise manner aligned with the JPEG XS packetization, the impact on rate-distortion (RD) performance is minimized, preserving compression efficiency. On 8K content under Main444.12, the method provides visually effective obfuscation with negligible bit-rate overhead for within-precinct line permutations and small overhead for cross-precinct reordering.

title: Energy Efficiency Maximization for RIS-Aided Integrated Sensing and Communication
authors: Huy T. Nguyen, Tri-Hai Nguyen, Vo-Nguyen Quoc Bao, Van-Dinh Nguyen, Nhan Thanh Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: In this paper, we study the energy efficiency (EE) of integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems enhanced by a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS). The objective is to maximize the overall EE subject to constraints on the monostatic transmitter power budget, the minimum communication data rate, and the maximum allowable sensing Cramér-Rao bound (CRB). The resulting optimization problem is non-convex and challenging due to the fractional objective function and the unit-modulus constraints of the RIS coefficients. To overcome these challenges, we propose an efficient solution framework that combines Dinkelbach's method with error reformulation techniques to transform the problem into a more tractable form. We then apply the successive convex approximation approach within each iteration to handle the non-convex components, yielding a computationally efficient solution. Simulation results confirm the convergence and effectiveness of the proposed algorithms. Notably, doubling the number of RIS elements from 8 to 16 improves the performance of RIS-aided systems by approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7 \%-10.5 \%$</tex> compared to those without RIS.

title: Research on Anomaly Data Preprocessing Technology for Deep Learning Soft Sensor Models Facing Missing Data and Fault Data
authors: Jian Xue, Lei Feng, Wenlong Hu, Yuanzi Li, Wenbin Zheng, Bing Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Deep learning-based soft sensor technology plays an important role in industrial process monitoring, however anomalous data such as sensor faults and missing values can severely compromise the predictive performance and reliability of the models. Most existing approaches address only a single type of anomaly, making it difficult to cope with the complex scenarios of multiple coexisting anomalies in real industrial environments. To overcome this limitation, this paper proposes a unified two-stage data preprocessing strategy that integrates anomaly detection and isolation with data reconstruction. In the first stage, a parallel Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)Residual Network (ResNet) architecture is employed for fault detection and isolation to identify and separate abnormal data. In the second stage, an improved masked autoencoder model is applied to reconstruct the data at the detected anomaly positions, thereby leveraging the complementary strengths of fault detection and data reconstruction across different anomaly magnitudes. Experimental results on the Tennessee Eastman Process dataset demonstrate that the proposed method achieves an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 9 7 6 1}$</tex>, a MAPE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 0 6 3 6 \%}$</tex>, and an RMSE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3. 6 9 1 5}$</tex> in reconstructing anomalous data caused by both sensor faults and missing values.

title: SCED in India: The Duals Behind Dispatch
authors: Debasis De, Abishek R. S, Saumen Majumdar, S. K. Soonee, Deb Chattopadhyay
abstract: This paper examines the interpretation and application of constraint shadow prices, or dual variables, from Security Constrained Economic Dispatch (SCED) pilots at an SLDC in India. These values capture the marginal cost of system constraints and provide actionable insights for operation, planning, and regulation. The discussion covers their mathematical foundation in linear programming and duality, and shows how shadow prices on limits such as generation, ramping, transmission, reserves, and emissions reveal real-time and structural grid challenges. Practical uses include control room operations, flexibility procurement, planning, and carbon policy. The limitations and sensitivities of duals are outlined, and a roadmap is proposed for embedding them in India’s regulated SCED framework. Unlike traditional textbooks, which emphasize formulation, this paper highlights their practical relevance in power systems where linear programming underpins optimal dispatch.

title: Design and Implementation of Intelligent Traction Device for Aircraft Maintenance Ladder
authors: Chao Liu, Guanfeng Zhong, WeiYing Liang, Hongjun Qiu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: Aircraft maintenance work ladder is an important maintenance auxiliary equipment in aircraft maintenance operations. A smart traction device for aircraft maintenance work ladders is designed to address the drawbacks of relying mainly on manual movement, low movement efficiency, and high consumption of manpower and material resources. The device includes a drive system, a drive control system, an AGV walking/steering system, a power management system, a mechanical structure system, and a safety protection system. After system testing, the device can adapt to different sizes of work ladders, meet the straight and turning requirements of work ladders, reduce the probability of collision between work ladders and aircraft surfaces, and overall improve the mobility efficiency of aircraft maintenance work ladders, saving manpower and material resources. It has a good application market in the field of aircraft maintenance.

title: Interpolation Techniques for Cost-effective Channel Data Capturing and Restoration in Ultrasound Imaging
authors: Sai Konda, Hicham Chaoui
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Ultrasound is a well known imaging technique used in various areas such as medical, industrial etc., It’s high frame rate is generating large amount of raw data, creating problems related to data handling and storage. To address these issues, we proposed and implemented a few novel data acquisition and interpolation (i.e. reconstruction) techniques on Plane-Wave Imaging Challenge in Medical Ultrasound (PICMUS) carotid artery dataset and Acoustical Radiation Force Impulse (ARFI) imaging techniques, which will not only reduce the amount of data capturing, but will also focus on missing data restoration with the help of interpolation. Reconstructed data thus obtained is subjected to a few ultrasound image processing techniques to generate final output images. These resulting images are then compared with those obtained using ground truth technique (i.e. full data based Delay and Sum (DAS) beamforming). We also applied recently proposed Frequency Domain Beamforming (FDB) technique on ARFI dataset (instead of DAS) for comparison and evaluation purposes. From which, we noticed that data storage cost can be reduced up to 50%, by increasing operation time of software for only few seconds.

title: A Review and Comparative Analysis of Predictive Models for Supply Chain Demand Forecasting
authors: Rehab IbrahimAhmed Omer, Raini Hassan, Madihah Sheikh Abdul Aziz
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Accurate demand forecasting is critical to supply chain optimization, influence inventory management, production scheduling, and customer satisfaction. This paper presents a comparative analysis of traditional forecasting models and machine learning approaches for supply chain demand prediction. This study reviews key techniques, including statistical time-series models, supervised and unsupervised learning algorithms, ensemble methods, and deep learning architectures. Empirical evidence from retail, manufacturing, healthcare, and food sectors demonstrates their relative performance and practical applicability. Challenges such as data quality, model interpretability, and system integration are analysed, along with emerging trends in real-time adaptability, hybrid modelling, and explainable AI. By synthesizing current research and implementation insights, this work provides a comprehensive evaluation of existing methods, identifying their strengths, limitations, and future research directions to enhance data-driven demand forecasting in modern supply chains.

title: On-Route Passenger Weight Estimation in Electric Buses via Air Suspension and Tire Pressure
authors: Utz Spaeth, Alexander Popp, Heiko Fechtner, Benedikt Schmuelling
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Accurate, real-time knowledge of a vehicle’s mass is crucial for predicting energy consumption of electric buses, enabling smart grid interactions, and supporting a variety of safety and assistance systems. This paper presents an empirical investigation of a passenger weight detection system that uses air suspension and tire pressure sensors on an 18.75-meter articulated battery overhead bus. The focus is on measurements conducted at bus stops during typical operational cycles. Through static tests conducted in a workshop and on-route at-stop tests that simulated passenger events (20 kg to 80 kg), the performance of the system was evaluated under various conditions, including kneeling and vehicle pre-loading. The results demonstrate that the approach maintains a high level of accuracy for non-kneeling scenarios even on-route (e.g., 80 kg: MPE -0.24%, StdDev PE 1.02% for front entries). However, kneeling operations caused significant performance degradation, as initial events were obscured and measurement variability increased. While the tire pressure sensor showed a good averaged calibration fit, its single-event accuracy during on-route kneeling tests was limited (StdDev PE 8.32% for 80 kg). Pressure changes induced by passenger weight were notably modified in size by vehicle pre-loading, underscoring the necessity for adaptive calibration. While the research validates the potential of direct, pressure-based measurement systems for determining weight on-route, successfully deploying them in real-world conditions requires integrating advanced signal processing algorithms and self-adapting calibration protocols.

title: Fast Multi-Tau Correlators on FPGA with Context Switching From and to High- Bandwidth Memory
authors: Abdul Rehman Tareen, Christian Plessl, Tobias Kenter
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Various methods to measure the dynamic behavior of particles require the calculation of autocorrelation functions. For this purpose, fast multi-tau correlators have been developed in dedicated hardware, in software, and on FPGAs. However, for methods such as X-ray Photon Correlation Spectroscopy (XPCS), which requires to calculate the autocorrelation function independently for hundreds of thousands to millions of pixels from high-resolution detectors, current approaches rely on offline processing after data acquisition. Moreover, the internal pipeline state of so many independent correlators is far too large to keep it on-chip. In this work, we propose a design approach on FPGAs, where pipeline contexts are stored in off-chip HBM memory. Each compute unit iteratively loads the state for a single pixel, processes a short time series for this pixel, and afterwards writes back the context in a dataflow pipeline. We have implemented the required compute kernels with Vitis HLS and analyze resulting designs on an Alveo U280 card. The design achieves the expected performance and for the first time provides sufficient throughput for current high-end detectors used in XPCS.

title: A Method for Reducing Learning Time in ARVTDNN for NN-DPD Applications
authors: Yudai Shiota, Hiroto Sakaki, Kenjiro Nishikawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper investigates the impact of training data reduction in the Augmented Real-Valued Time-Delay Neural Network (ARVTDNN) on the performance of digital predistortion (DPD). The training data was reduced using two methods: one that removes samples based on a threshold applied to the envelope amplitude of the PA output signal, and another that employs random sampling. The resulting models were evaluated and compared in terms of Adjacent Channel Power Ratio (ACPR), Error Vector Magnitude (EVM), AM/AM and AM/PM characteristics, demodulated signal constellations, and ARVTDNN training time, in order to identify the most effective reduction method. To compress the training data while minimizing degradation in model performance, it is important to extract samples with a well-balanced amplitude distribution. In particular, when the random sampling method was applied, it was confirmed that a 50% reduction in data resulted in only a 2.6 dB degradation in ACPR, while the training time was reduced by approximately 57.5%. This level of performance degradation remains within the acceptable range defined by the 3GPP standard (TS 38.104), demonstrating that the proposed method satisfies current regulatory requirements.

title: EdgeFlame: A Physics-Inspired Framework for Zero-Shot Fire and Smoke Recognition
authors: HyeYoung Lee, Muhammad Nadeem
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: Wildfires and smoke pose serious threats that demand rapid and reliable detection, especially on autonomous platforms operating under limited resources. We present EdgeFlame, a physics-inspired cross-modal learning framework for zero-shot fire and smoke classification on drones and IoT devices. It combines 3D CWT features with a Stationary Action Principle–guided architecture to link physical signal dynamics with lightweight AI inference. The model is highly efficient, requiring only 0.12 MB of parameters and achieving 3,281 frames per second with a latency of just 0.30 milliseconds. It outperforms conventional baselines such as CLIP, YOLOv12, and ResNet50 in both speed and efficiency. Tested on three diverse datasets—Kaggle Fire, YouTube wildfire videos, and the RGBIR FLAME2 drone dataset—EdgeFlame consistently achieves 94–98% accuracy across different environments. Designed for onboard edge deployment, it enables real-time wildfire perception on autonomous UAVs without relying on large-scale retraining, offering a practical and scalable solution for disaster response robotics.

title: Integrated Decision Making and Planning for Autonomous Driving Based on the Prediction of Ego Vehicle
authors: Mingyang Luo, Fusheng Bai
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: Decision making and planning are critical components of Autonomous Driving (AD) systems. The integrated decision making and planning approach captures the coupling between these two modules, offering enhanced interpretability and intelligence. However, in highly dynamic complex driving environments, existing integrated modeling approaches suffer from high time complexity or poor applicability. In this article, we present a soluble and intelligent framework called Integrated Decision Making and Planning (IDMP), which decompose the AD decision making and planning problem into two layers: optimal trajectory selection layer and optimal trajectory tracking layer. The optimal trajectory selection layer leverages historical planning information to predict the ego vehicle’s trajectory and employs a fast decision making strategy based on the predicted trajectory to select the optimal path, which is subsequently tracked to achieve a tightly coupled decision making and planning module. Based on these, we designed a closed-loop structure composed of upper-layer decision guidance and lower layer planning feedback. Finally, we validated the proposed framework through comparative experiments using the CARLA-SUMO simulation. Experimental results demonstrated that the proposed method has advantages in a series of complex autonomous driving scenarios.

title: Design and Fabrication of Low-cost Force Sensing Resistor for Prevention of Bedsores
authors: Mariam, Sameen Ahmed Malik, Umaima Shakeel, Baha, Jahanzeb Sheikh
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Pressure ulcers, or bedsores, are a frequent and serious condition in bedridden or immobile patients, especially in hospitals and long-term care facilities. They are caused by sustained pressure, friction, and moisture on the skin, which causes tissue injury and infection if not treated promptly. Although different monitoring systems exist, most of them are expensive, do not provide real-time feedback, or monitor only specific parameters. All of them do not offer an all-around solution that incorporates motion, pressure, and environmental inputs, all of which are necessary in the early detection and prevention of pressure ulcers. In this study a sensor-based detection system for patient movement that uses Force Sensitive Resistors, a temperature and humidity sensor, and a motion sensor, all interfaced to an Arduino microcontroller and an LCD display for real-time monitoring is used. The system is designed to sound alarms in cases of prolonged pressure on body regions, prolonged inactivity in the patient's movements for some period, and when temperature and humidity levels rise beyond comfort zones. All the sensors operate cooperatively to determine quickly any factors that pose risk, with warning offered through buzzers and LEDs. The system effectively identified the high-risk condition and responded by sounding the alarm appropriately. The findings show the system to be capable of monitoring key changes in patient status so that caregivers can react in a timely manner. This project illustrates the potential of low-cost embedded systems to improve patient safety by preventing pressure ulcers through early intervention, thus enabling improved healthcare outcomes in clinical, elderly care, and home settings.

title: Passivity-based adaptive controller with the thrust direction control for quadrotor trajectory tracking
authors: Kunal Barwal, Padmini Singh, Tushar Jain
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper introduces a new control structure for quadrotor path following that robustly integrates passivity-based adaptive control with nearly globally stable direction of thrust control on the configuration manifold s<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. The new method uses an adaptive force generation mechanism that estimates uncertain system parameters like mass and inertia online to improve robustness to parametric uncertainties typically present in flight operations of aerial vehicles. Capitalizing on the unit sphere description for thrust direction, the approach formulates a backstepping-like nonlinear control law offering nearly global stability bounds for the interaction of translational and rotational dynamics. A composite Lyapunov function is devised to set the issue of convergence of tracking errors and estimation errors conclusively. Simulation and experimental verifications establish the controller’s better transient performance, disturbance rejection robustness, and lower energy consumption in comparison with traditional approaches. This union of passivity-based adaptive control with geometric thrust guidance control presents a theoretically sound and practically useful solution for accurate quadrotor navigation under uncertain and dynamic conditions

title: Synthetic Inertia in Small Inverters: A New Strategy Based on DC Link Current Control*
authors: Luiz Fernando Marquez Arruda, Guilherme Beck Lemos, Roberto Francisco Coelho, Denizar Cruz Martins
abstract: This paper presents a control strategy for small-scale photovoltaic (PV) inverters to introduce synthetic inertia into the power grid. As the participation of renewable sources increases and conventional synchronous generators decrease, grid stability may be affected since PV inverters lack inherent inertia. A current control model for the DC-Link is proposed to improve the inertia, integrating a two-stage single-phase inverter with a bidirectional boost converter and a battery bank. This system acts as a synthetic inertia source, using battery charge and discharge to smooth power transitions and enhance grid stability. Based on the Swing Equation of synchronous generators, the strategy implements a virtual inertia response, reducing oscillations and improving system dynamics. Simulations on a 3 kW inverter show improved response time and smoother transitions, indicating this approach is a promising solution to increase renewable energy integration while maintaining grid stability.

title: Dynamic Model of Rolling Bearings Considering Edge Softening Effects
authors: Yunqing Kan, Jiahao Dong, Bochao Zhang, Ling Xiang, Aijun Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: The establishment of an accurate dynamic model for rolling bearings is of great significance for fault diagnosis and the analysis of the dynamic characteristics of defective bearings. This paper proposes a rolling bearing dynamic model that incorporates edge softening. It suggests that contact stiffness changes as the rolling elements approach and exit the edges of the defect, where the Hertz contact elastic half-space theory is no longer applicable. Combining time-varying contact stiffness and contact deformation enables the investigation of the motion and force characteristics of faulty bearings. The proposed dynamic model is found to be in agreement with experimentally measured acceleration and strain signals in terms of both acceleration and outer race forces, thus validating its accuracy.

title: A 66-82 GHz VCO with Dual-Tuning and Phase Noise Reduction Techniques in 40 nm CMOS
authors: Yi-Cheng Liu, Pei-Hsuan Wang, Yu-Yuan Huang, Tsung-Hsien Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper proposes a 66-82 GHz voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) incorporating dual-tuning and phase-noise (PN) reduction techniques. The dual-tuning method enables both coarse and fine tuning, thereby expanding the frequency tuning ratio (FTR) compared to conventional single-band tuning methods. Moreover, both figure of merit (FoM) and the FTR-inclusive FoM (FoM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</inf>) are better improved by considering several PN reduction techniques during the design procedure. This chip is fabricated in 40 nm CMOS process, with the core area of 0.079 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and the P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DC</inf> of 7.8 mW. The FTR is 21.6 %, operating from 65.9 GHz to 81.8 GHz at a supply voltage of 0.8 V. After power calibration, the optimal output power (P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OUT</inf>) is -13.4 dBm, and the PN at the 10 MHz offset is -114.3 dBc/Hz. The FoM and the FoM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</inf> are -182.7 dBc/Hz and -189.4 dBc/Hz respectively.

title: The Effect of Rain Attenuation on the Efficiency of Wireless Communication Systems in Millimeter Wave Frequencies
authors: Mohamed Farag Abughalia, Olga Boiprav, Amer R. Zerek, Salah E A Abeid
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: The advent of millimeter wave (mmWave) frequencies in wireless communication systems has opened new frontiers for high-data-rate applications. However, mmWave signals are highly susceptible to atmospheric impairments, particularly rain attenuation, which significantly degrades system performance. This paper investigates the impact of rain attenuation on the efficiency of wireless communication systems operating in the mmWave band, focusing on frequencies ranging from 30 GHz to 300 GHz. A comprehensive analysis is conducted using empirical rain attenuation models, including the ITU-R P. 838 and P. 837 recommendations, to estimate the specific attenuation under various rainfall intensities. The study evaluates the effects of rain on signal degradation, link budget, and system availability. Simulation results demonstrate that rain attenuation introduces substantial signal loss, which can reduce link reliability and throughput in mmWave systems. Strategies such as adaptive modulation, power control, and site diversity are discussed to mitigate these effects. The findings underscore the critical need for robust design and planning of mmWave wireless links to ensure efficient and reliable communication in rain-prone environments.

title: Deep Learning-Based Emotion Recognition Using Electroencephalogram Signals
authors: Duy Nguyen, Anh Nguyen, Minh Tuan Nguyen, Kou Yamada
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Emotion recognition plays an important role in various aspects of daily life, including education, healthcare, and entertainment. Moreover, intelligent emotion prediction enhances adaptability and responsiveness in brain-computer interface systems, thereby improving the efficiency of human-computer interaction. In this paper, we propose an efficient hybrid deep learning model for emotion detection using electroencephalogram (EEG) signals. The framework first performs optimal channel selection, followed by the extraction of band power features from four EEG frequency bands. The resulting feature sets are then used to validate One-Dimension Convolutional Neural Network (1D-CNN), Long-Short Term Memories (LSTM), and a hybrid 1D CNN-LSTM model using 5-fold cross-validation. Among them, the 1D CNN-LSTM model achieves the best performance with an accuracy of 95.00 %, precision of 95.93 %, recall of 95.07 %, and an F1-score of 95.50 % for arousal classification. Similarly, this model achieves an accuracy of 94.85 %, precision of 95.12 %, recall of 95.02 %, and an F 1 -score of 94.95 % for valence classification. These results demonstrate that the proposed framework offers a robust and generalizable solution for emotion recognition, making it a promising approach for practical applications.

title: Smart Dynamic Wireless Charging Lane for Electric Vehicles Powered by Hybrid Renewable Systems
authors: Malath A. Almulla
abstract: Smart Dynamic Wireless Charging Lane for EVs Electric vehicles (EVs) are gaining global momentum; however, long-distance travel remains limited due to insufficient access to fast-charging infrastructure, particularly in highway and remote settings. Additionally, high ambient temperatures in regions like the GCC increase battery drain due to air conditioning loads, further exacerbating range anxiety. This research proposes a smart dynamic wireless charging lane that enables continuous inductive power transfer to EVs during motion, powered by a hybrid renewable system combining solar panels and hydrogen fuel cells. The embedded transmitter coils, designed with a switching frequency of 85–150 kHz, are capable of achieving up to ∼85% power transfer efficiency at standard highway speeds (60 km/h). The system architecture includes a mobile application for real-time energy monitoring and lane interaction, integrated with the vehicle via onboard receivers. The energy management strategy prioritizes solar input where available, with hydrogen storage units serving as backup to ensure reliability in low-radiation conditions. The system is capable of supplying a net SoC gain of 17–21% over a 2 km lane segment at 60 km/h, extending vehicle range by up to ∼120 km in emergency or off-grid environments. Safety measures include insulated coils and authenticated EV access control to ensure user protection and system integrity. This approach minimizes reliance on centralized grid infrastructure by decentralizing energy delivery and enhances EV usability in infrastructure-constrained regions. The proposed system aligns with national sustainability and smart mobility objectives, contributing to reduced emissions and increased renewable energy utilization.

title: Design of High-Resolution Inverse Photoemission Spectroscopy System
authors: Sichao Zhang, Yu Chen, Ao Tan, Tiansong Zhang, Siyu Tian, Xin Liu, Shuang Wang, Min Zhang, Jiamei Liu, Lingjie Meng, Lumei Gao, Hisao Ishii
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Inverse photoemission spectroscopy is an important method for studying the surface electronic structure of materials. It can reveal the conduction band structure of a material. Combined with photoemission spectroscopy, complete electronic structure information can be obtained. Therefore, it is a crucial scientific instrument for characterizing the detailed electronic structure of a material across energy bands. In recent years, with the continuous advancement of materials science and surface physics, the demand for high-resolution inverse photoemission spectroscopy has continued to increase. This thesis first introduces the basic theory of inverse spectroscopy. Then, a high-resolution inverse photoemission spectroscopy system based on a sector-shaped deflection energy analyzer and a monochromator was designed, and its theoretical energy resolution was calculated. Finally, future research priorities for inverse spectroscopy are outlined to provide a reference for subsequent related research.

title: Automated Grading of Scratch Card Based Immediate Feedback Assessment Technique (IFAT)
authors: Davian Todd, Sergei Chernitsyn, Jun Hoang, Ruth Nwankwo, Sindhuja Suresh, Omar Alam, Balaji Subramanian
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Immediate Feedback Assessment Technique® (IFAT®) provides opportunities for students to answer a multiple-choice question until the correct answer is revealed. This process is claimed to promote self-learning while testing, reduce test anxiety, and provide teachers with partial knowledge recognition. Scratch card-based IFAT® was developed by Epstein and made available to the teaching community through a commercial channel. Despite several advantages, grading using IFAT® cards for a final exam of a typical first-year course requires several manual hours. To ease this tedious process, this paper discusses an automated approach for grading exams conducted using scratch card-based IFAT. An algorithm that uses the OpenCV image processing library that can detect scratched, unscratched, and varying degrees of partially scratched boxes with high accuracy has been developed and implemented to create a logical representation of the IFAT® card. Our tool demonstrated a high degree of precision (>99%) for an assessment involving 39 cards of 10 questions, each with 5 scratch boxes.

title: From Discriminative Regions to Complete Masks: CAM-SAM Fusion for Weakly Supervised Semantic Segmentation
authors: Yen Nhi Huynh, Tran Khuong An Nguyen, Tien-Dung Mai
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Semantic segmentation requires costly pixel-level annotations, limiting the scalability of fully supervised models. Weakly Supervised Semantic Segmentation (WSSS) reduces this burden using image-level labels, but existing methods based on Class Activation Maps (CAM) often capture only small discriminative object regions, yielding incomplete pseudo masks. We introduce a CAM-SAM fusion framework that combines the semantic cues of CAM with the strong boundary localization capabilities of the Segment Anything Model (SAM). Specifically, we propose Semantic-Aware Prompting (SAP), where highresponse CAM peaks to guide SAM in generating detailed masks, and a Mask Fusion Algorithm that intelligently integrates CAM and SAM outputs to produce reliable pseudo labels. Evaluations on PASCAL VOC 2012 and MS COCO 2014 show that our method produces sharper and more complete masks, leading to significant improvements in segmentation accuracy over CAM-only baselines. These results highlight the effectiveness of integrating foundation models into WSSS for high-quality segmentation with minimal supervision.

title: Multivariate Time Series Anomaly Detection Based on Time-Frequency Combination
authors: Zeru Huang, Hao Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Time series anomaly detection is a core task for ensuring the stability of modern industrial, financial, and operational systems. However, most existing methods model data in the time domain, which presents challenges in capturing global periodic anomalies and subtle structural changes, and they are susceptible to local noise. To address these limitations, we propose a novel unsupervised learning framework for anomaly detection named Multivariate time frequency anomaly detection(MTFAD). The core idea of MTFAD is to shift the main analysis process from the traditional time domain to the frequency domain. Specifically, the framework first maps the input sequence to the frequency domain via Fourier Transform and innovatively introduces a Frequency Patching strategy to decompose the spectrum into multiple frequency patches representing different frequency bands. The model's training is jointly supervised by a time-frequency dual-loss function, ensuring consistency in both the waveform and spectral structure of the reconstructed signal. Our experiments on multiple public datasets show that MTFAD can effectively identify diverse anomaly patterns and surpasses current state-of-the-art methods on several key metrics, providing a new perspective for time series anomaly detection by combining time and frequency domains.

title: Artificial Intelligence in HRM: Linking Ethical Design, Digital Well-being, and Green HRM for Sustainable Performance
authors: Waseem Umer, Rakhshanda Furnaz, Burhan Sadiq, Ammara Naseem, Tayyeba Bashir
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: This study investigates how AI-ethical design factors influence organizational sustainable performance through the mediating roles of employee digital well-being and Green Human Resource Management (GHRM) outcomes. Drawing on AMO theory and socio-technical systems theory, a cross-sectional survey was conducted, with 550 responses collected and 509 valid samples analyzed using Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLSSEM). The results demonstrate that ethical AI design enhances employee digital well-being, which positively drives GHRM outcomes and, in turn, strengthens sustainable organizational performance. Mediation analyses further confirm sequential pathways linking AI ethics, well-being, and GHRM practices to sustainability. The findings extend existing HRM and AI ethics literature by integrating digital well-being into the GHRM–sustainability nexus, while providing practical guidance for managers to embed ethical AI principles, foster employee well-being, and institutionalize sustainability-focused HRM practices. Keywords: Artificial Intelligence, Ethical AI, Green HRM, Digital Well-being, Sustainability

title: A Unified Framework for Swarm Intelligence to Enhance Convergence and Reliability
authors: Saravanan G, Yuvaraj V, Ramasubramanian B, Lakshmi Devi R, Afsar Ali M, Akshaya TR
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This research focuses on creating and applying advanced meta heuristic algorithms for Optimization Problems. The primary goals are to improve the effectiveness and efficiency of nature-inspired algorithms and to solve complex optimization problems in multiple areas. The research describes a number of algorithms that utilize principles of swarm intelligence, such as Particle Swarm Optimization, to address problems in machine learning, robotics, and data analysis. The goal is to enable researchers and practitioners to use these algorithms on various real-life challenges to enhance the processes and outcomes of optimization. This study not only serves scholarly interests but also has real-world application value, catalyzing the use of advanced methods for solving optimization problems. It is shown that all algorithms are implemented in Python, which ensures that a large audience is able to use and access them easily. Each algorithm is accompanied by comprehensive documentation, which offers detailed explanations and illustrative examples, thus enabling users to easily understand and incorporate the algorithms into their projects. Application of these meta-heuristic algorithms is anticipated to improve not just the optimization processes but also the resultant performance across a wide spectrum of tasks. Such findings motivate practitioners and specialists to actively participate in fostering collaboration and further development within the research community, thereby further advancing methodologies in swarm intelligence. This study's findings are of considerable significance with respect to artificial intelligence and optimization, offering a basis for subsequent advancements. The ongoing refinement of these algorithms may provide, at some point, solutions for addressing more sophisticated issues, which will, in turn, promote breakthroughs in technology and engineering.

title: A Study on Dispersion Characteristics of a Gyrator-Loaded CRLH-TL with an Even Number of Unit Cells
authors: Kensuke Okubo, Mitsuyoshi Kishihara, Koichiro Sakaguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper investigates the dispersion characteristics of a gyrator-loaded composite right/left-handed transmission line (CRLH-TL) with an even number of unit cells, which we refer to as the E-CRLH-TL. This structure exhibits both high tunability of the operating frequency and reciprocal transmission behavior. In this paper, to facilitate circuit prototyping, a simplified configuration is considered, in which series capacitors are placed on both sides of the gyrators. The dispersion equation for this structure is derived, and numerical analysis shows that its characteristics closely match those of the original configuration over a wide frequency range, except near the higher cutoff frequency. Furthermore, since it has been confirmed that the dispersion diagrams of the E-CRLH-TL and the conventional CRLH-TL coincide under a specific structural condition, the simplified version is shown to maintain similar transmission performance while offering improved ease of implementation.

title: Design of Multi-Beam Intelligent Reflecting Surface for 6G Wireless Communications
authors: Ngoc Tung Phung, Thanh Nam Le, Phuong Linh Nguyen, Quang Tuan Le, Khac Kiem Nguyen, Son Xuat Ta
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) is expected to become a key enabling technology in the future wireless communication networks (beyond 5 G or 6 G) due to its ability to dynamically control the radio wave propagation environment. Despite rapid advancements, most of the existing IRS researches still focus on a single-beam reflection. In this paper, a multibeam configuration for IRS is proposed, which is established based on 2-bit PIN diode unit cells with high reflectivity. Its reflection phase configurations are optimized by using genetic algorithm. To achieve the multi-beam operation, the IRS is configured by dividing into smaller sub-arrays, and each is independently configured to steer the reflected beam toward the desired direction. For computational demonstration, an IRS prototype composed of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16 \times 16$</tex> unit cells is characterized, which can yield 2, 3, and 4-beam steering with low side-lobe level. This flexible approach enhances coverage performance and meets stringent communication requirements in complex scenarios such as the 6 G networks. Furthermore, the proposed architecture offers high scalability and can be easily adapted to the practical problems.

title: Research on the Unbalanced Response Characteristics of Turbocharger Rotor System Under Transient Conditions
authors: Yinan Li, Hao Zhang, Guojin Feng, Dong Zhen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Turbochargers are widely used in highperformance internal combustion engine systems such as automobiles, aerospace, and marine applications. The floating ring bearing (FRB)-rotor system, as the core component, directly dictates turbocharger performance and durability. Its defining dual-oil-film structure enhances vibration damping on one hand, but simultaneously gives rise to significant nonlinear dynamic challenges, such as oil whirl, subsynchronous vibration, and bifurcation. A lubrication model for the FRB is developed based on the Reynolds equation with JFO cavitation boundary conditions. This model is then integrated with a finite element rotor model to establish a comprehensive nonlinear dynamic model of the turbocharger FRB-rotor system. Based on this, speed-up simulations were conducted for the system under balanced conditions and under different unbalanced conditions, systematically analyzing oil film instability behavior. The research results indicate that unbalanced excitation has a significant regulatory effect on oil whirl shedding, and the system may enter a chaotic state under specific operating conditions. Additionally, through methods such as waterfall plots, Poincare maps, and bifurcation analysis, the evolutionary of the system's nonlinear response was revealed. The findings deepen the insight into the physical mechanisms governing oil film instability in turbochargers, thereby contributing to the theoretical foundation needed for enhanced system design and more accurate vibration fault diagnosis.

title: Integrating Multi-Spectral Image Fusion and Path Planning Strategies for Effective Drone-Based Search and Rescue
authors: Semaa Amin, Mitchell Lawson, Kaitlyn Lowen, John Maunder, Ian Yip, Michal Aibin
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the integration of computer vision (CV) methodologies and advanced path planning strategies to enhance Search and Rescue (SAR) missions employing Remotely Piloted Aircraft Systems (RPAS), commonly known as drones. Effective SAR operations require rapid and accurate identification of missing or endangered individuals, which requires timely medical assistance to mitigate long-term health consequences. Traditional imaging techniques, such as RGB (visual) and thermal imaging, each present unique strengths and limitations within SAR contexts. To determine the most effective approach, we evaluated RGB, thermal and multispectral image fusion image datasets using the YOLO algorithm and four distinct path planning algorithms to optimize SAR missions: Scanline Fill, Quadrant Scanline Fill, Geocentric Fill, and Random Fill. We define multi-spectral image fusion as overlaying RGB and thermal imagery, enabling a combined view that leverages both modalities. Through extensive simulations, we verified that the Quadrant Scanline Fill algorithm consistently outperforms others in speed and efficiency, making it the most suitable choice for directing RPAS in search operations.

title: Conversational Smart Assistant on a Microcontroller with Cloud-Based LLM Function Offloading
authors: Dang Quoc-Minh Do, Nguyen Hoang Nguyen, Quang Nho-Dang Nguyen, Tuan Anh Hoang, Khoa Quoc Nguyen, Thuan Huu Huynh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper presents a conversational smart assistant architecture that integrates a resource-constrained microcontroller frontend with a cloud-based large language model (LLM) backend. The device captures user query audio, compresses it, and streams it in real time to the server over a lightweight custom TCP protocol. On the server, Google Speech-to-Text (STT) transcribes the input, which is then processed by OpenAI's Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) model for natural language understanding. Depending on the query, the model either generates a direct response or issues structured function calls to access real-time information (e.g., breaking news) via public APIs or a headless browser, or to execute taskoriented functions such as reminder scheduling and voice note recording. The final response is synthesized into speech using Google Text-to-Speech (TTS), compressed and streamed back to the device for playback. Experimental results show low latency, efficient bandwidth usage, and cost-effective operation, demonstrating the practicality of the proposed architecture for embedded conversational interfaces and wearable IoT assistants.

title: Interpretable and Reliable Soft Sensor Development in Industry 5.0
authors: Liang Cao, Jianping Su, Fan Yang, Yankai Cao, Bhushan Gopaluni
abstract: Dear Editor, This letter presents a new approach to developing interpretable and reliable soft sensors for Industry 5.0 applications. Although sophisticated machine learning methods have made remarkable strides in soft-sensor predictive accuracy, ensuring interpretability and reliable performance across varying industrial operating conditions remains a challenge [1]–[4]. This is precisely what Industry 5.0, proposed by the European Commission in 2021, advocates [5], [6]. It integrates various cutting-edge technologies, such as human-machine interaction, digital twins, cybersecurity and artificial intelligence, to facilitate the development of better soft sensors.

title: Federated Learning with Controlled Descent under Fading: Convergence and Energy Implications
authors: Sayantan Adhikary, Neelesh B. Mehta
abstract: In over-the-air computation-assisted federated learning (OTA-FL), devices transmit their local models to a parameter server over a shared time-frequency resource. Model aggregation occurs automatically due to the superposition property of the wireless channel. We derive a novel upper bound on the convergence of the optimality gap of OTA-FL that applies to any choice of device transmit powers and receiver scaling. The bound is based on less restrictive assumptions compared to the literature. It leads to the insightful concept of an effective learning rate that captures the dependence of the convergence of OTA-FL on the gains of the channels between the devices and the parameter server. We jointly optimize the transmit powers and the receiver scaling to minimize the error floor implied by the bound while controlling the effective learning rate. This leads to a novel controlled descent algorithm (CDA) and a new variant that adapts the effective learning rate. CDA can be implemented using a low overhead protocol. We benchmark CDA against several transmit power, receiver scaling, and device selection schemes. For both linear regression and multi-class logistic regression, CDA requires fewer iterations and a lower sum energy to achieve a target optimality gap or testing accuracy.
