title: A Category-driven Depth-Scalable Inversion Framework for 3D GPR Data Inversion
authors: Xiujun Lin, Xiren Zhou, Xiangyu Wang, Huanhuan Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Inversion of three-dimensional Ground-Penetrating Radar (3D GPR) data risks nonlinear electromagnetic wave propagation and the structural diversity of subsurface targets. Existing deep learning methods typically adopt fixed-depth architectures for all inputs, disregarding variations in structural complexity among varying targets. This results in redundant computation in non-target background and limited accuracy for specific types of underground targets. In response, we propose the Category-driven Depth-Scalable Inversion (CDSI) framework that integrates target classification with category-driven inversion. CDSI simultaneously extracts dynamic features (i.e., the wave changing information) via specific reservoir computing and captures spatial features through a convolutional network. A cross-attention mechanism fuses these features to predict the target category. Guided by the predicted category, a depth-scalable inversion network further adjusts its depth to reconstruct permittivity maps. Experimental results on synthetic 3D GPR datasets demonstrate that CDSI consistently outperforms existing methods in both accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Multimodel Comparative Assessment and Optimal Geodetector-Driven Analysis of Aeolian Desertification in the Horqin Sandy Land
authors: Wanying Cao, Hanchen Duan, Beiying Huang, Xiaopeng Jia
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: The Horqin Sandy Land (HSL), a critical ecological barrier in northern China and core area of the Three-North Shelterbelt Project, requires precise monitoring of aeolian desertification (AD) dynamics to maintain ecological stability in densely populated northern and northeastern China. This study innovatively integrated multi-source remote sensing parameters via Google Earth Engine to systematically compare three feature space models (Albedo-NDVI, Albedo-MSAVI, Albedo-KNDVI) and five machine learning algorithms for AD monitoring, while applying the Optimal Parameter Geographic Detector (OPGD) to quantify natural-anthropogenic driving mechanisms. High-resolution AD classification (5-year intervals, 2000–2020) revealed spatiotemporal dynamics, with machine learning models consistently outperforming feature space models. Random Forest (RF) achieved the highest accuracy (97.7%) and Kappa coefficient (0.967), effectively distinguishing non-desertified areas from extreme desertification. Temporal analysis showed a significant AD reversal: total desertified area declined to 30,166.35 km² by 2020, driven by ecological policies and climate amelioration. OPGD analysis indicated soil texture as the strongest single driver (q > 0.48), but factor interactions (e.g., SD ∩︀ LU) exerted greater explanatory power, highlighting compound effects of natural and anthropogenic factors. This study provides a robust framework for high-precision AD monitoring in semi-arid agro-pastoral zones, supporting global efforts toward zero land degradation.

title: Experimental Characterization of Commercial Reduced Graphene Oxide Nanoplatelets for RF and Microwave Device Applications
authors: Luís Henrique Farias Schneider dos Santos, Candice Müller, Fernando César Comparsi de Castro, Ricardo Barreto da Silva
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents the electrical characterization of different samples of commercially available reduced graphene oxide (RGO) nanoplatelets with distinct physical characteristics. The electrical response was evaluated in terms of resistance and transmittance variation as a function of the applied DC voltage and frequency. The reproducibility of the results and the behavior of the sample over multiple measurement cycles were evaluated. The results show that RGO nanoplatelets present significant resistance variation <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta R$</tex> in the first measurement cycle. However, after the first cycle, RGO nanoplatelets undergo a resistance relaxation process, which significantly reduces the resistance and transmittance variation. The results also demonstrate that, over several measurement cycles, the resistive behavior tends to stabilize, but with a significantly reduced <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta R$</tex>. Results indicate that further research and development on graphene is needed before its application in dynamically tunable RF and microwave devices, in order to reduce the resistance relaxation process and keep the behavior of the first cycle in the cycles that follow.

title: Leveraging Artificial Intelligence to Decode Brand Awareness and Buying Behaviour
authors: Aarti Malik, Pracheta Tejasmayee, Jagjeevan Kanaujiya, Shailesh Rastogi, Aman Pushp, Asmita Dani
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: The following research paper examines the correlation between the levels of brand awareness with consumer purchase behaviors including the utilization of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to allow greater depth of marketing research analysis. Replicating a mixed- methods design, the proposed study explores the effects of the divergent degrees of brand awareness on the consumer buying behaviour, loyalty and repeat purchase behaviour. The machine learning analytical tools utilize the ability to analyze large amounts of data to identify minute trends and predictive indications that historic methods might miss. The focus is on the role of digital marketing channels, such as social media platforms, where AI-based analysis of the sentiment and the engagement will present fine-grained views of consumer-brand interaction. The paper continues to analyze cognitive and emotional aspects of brand perceptions discussing the ways and dynamics of building loyalty. The outcomes demonstrate that brand recognition plays a key role in the purchase process and that conversational analytics supported by AI can streamline the segmentation of the audience, predict the purchase patterns, and channelspecific actions. The findings reaffirm the tactical value of incorporating AI in brand management with the view of promoting specific outreach, enhancing customer retention, and the ability to gain competitive advantage sustainably in a dynamic market. These insights can be useful in business, marketing and policies that are aimed at understanding the volatile relationships between brand awareness and consumer behaviour in an age of digitalization.

title: A Deep Learning-Based Approach for Plant Disease Detection
authors: Santanu Basak, Angshuman Khan, Yashwant Vashisht, Yogendra Singh, Ravi Sharma
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Improvement in the detection of plant diseases can lead to an enhancement in plant-based farming. On the other hand, it would be beneficial for farmers when the cost of detection is minimized. To address this, a system is proposed to detect plant diseases, enabling decisions to be made at an early stage. The proposed method leverages a pre-trained ResNet-50 model fine-tuned on the new leaf images dataset. The proposed model achieved an accuracy of 99.54%, an F1 score of 99%, a sensitivity of 99%, and a specificity of 99%. The testing outcomes indicate that the proposed system achieves a very high efficiency.

title: Opt360: QoE Optimization for 360° Video Streaming
authors: Reza Hedayati, Mea Wang, Logan Rakai
abstract: 360° video streaming is central to immersive applications such as virtual reality, education, and telepresence, yet delivering stall-free playback with high viewport quality remains difficult under fluctuating bandwidth and inaccurate viewport prediction. Prior solutions either fail to guarantee stall-free playback, introduce prohibitive overhead, or neglect prediction inaccuracies. We propose Opt360, a DASH-compliant optimization framework that generalizes tile assignment into multi-tier priority zones, incorporates prediction accuracy and window length directly into the optimization, and enforces hard constraints on stalls and quality switches. The resulting mixedinteger formulation, coupled with a segment-internal tile scheduler, adapts to diverse viewport models while remaining real-time feasible. Extensive evaluations demonstrate that Opt360 ensures smooth playback, remains resilient to viewport variations, and effectively utilizes bandwidth for improved video quality, even under challenging network conditions.

title: Convolutional Autoencoder Framework for Anomaly Detection in Cloud Data Centers
authors: K. Kannan, Vishalini J A, Sanjai M, Shruthi D, Rogith G
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Critical workloads are stored in cloud data centers and require a continuous availability of the service; however, these telemetry streams are highly dimensional and complex, and it is difficult to perform timely anomaly detection. Old thresholding and linear statistical models are not always good at modeling non-linear dependencies and dynamic multitenant behavior, resulting in delayed or inaccurate alerts. To counteract these problems, a Convolutional Autoencoder (CAE) model is used to estimate heterogeneous cloud measurements in the form of hierarchical tensors and train compact latent images of normal operations. The CAE is that which makes use of dualpath convolutional encoding to make use of spatial-temporal correlations and probabilistic reconstruction-error modelling of adaptive thresholding. The framework was tested on large-scale datasets of Google Cluster Trace and Alibaba Cloud, scoring 97.4 % precision, 96.1 % recall, 96.7 % F1-score, and 0.985 AUC while maintaining an average inference latency of 180 ms and 2.1GB GPU memory. The results indicate the effectiveness of the method in real-time and scalable detection of anomalies and its possible impact on improving reliability and resilience in cloud data centers.

title: Characterization of Graphene Films Deposited on Glass and Their Application in Patch Antennas
authors: Daniel Augusto Da Costa Oliveira, Igor Oliveira Souza, Lucas Silva Lima, Ursula Resende, Rúbia Fernandes De Andrade, Camilla Caroline Moro Carmo
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Antennas are fundamental elements in rectenna systems, as they receive radiofrequency electromagnetic energy and enable its conversion into direct current for powering low-power electronic devices. Their performance directly affects system efficiency, depending on parameters such as gain and input impedance matching with the rectifier circuit, which are essential for maximizing power transfer. The physical configuration of antennas must often be adapted to different environments and installation constraints. In this context, integrating antennas into window structures in buildings or vehicles presents a promising approach, offering a large surface area for energy collection without compromising usable space. To enable this integration while maintaining the optical properties of the window, this work investigates the use of glass as the dielectric substrate and a graphene-based film as the conductive element. Various deposition techniques for applying graphene onto glass substrates are evaluated, with emphasis on measuring electrical conductivity, and scattering parameters. These experimental results support the design of a patch antenna, optimized for operation at 5,8 GHz using CST Studio Suite software. A prototype is fabricated based on the selected graphene film, and its scattering parameters are measured and compared to both simulation results and to those obtained from a reference antenna of identical geometry using copper as the conductive material. This comparative analysis assesses the viability of graphene as a conductor in antenna applications.

title: High-Performance Circular Phased Array Microstrip Antenna for WiFi, Bluetooth, and Ultra-Wideband Applications
authors: Henry Mayorga Perez, Maria Diaz Gonzalez, Ronny Toctaquiza Piedra
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: In this work, a high-performance circular phased array microstrip antenna is designed and presented. The proposed antenna would be printed on an Epoxy FR4 substrate, with a permittivity of 4.3. By using a fractal patch antenna array with phase shift, impedance matching has been achieved for Wifi and Bluetooth frequencies, in addition to generating a continuous bandwidth from 5 to 19 GHz with low VSWR and good radiation characteristics, useful for next generation 5 G applications. These features together allow this prototype to be a promising solution for modern wireless communication systems, enabling efficient integration in a wide range of applications.

title: Adaptive Model Predictive Current Control Using EKF-Based Online Inductance Estimation for Totem-Pole PFC Converters
authors: Hee-Jeong Seon, Hyun-Gyu Koh, Yeong-Jun Choi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper proposes an adaptive model predictive current control (MPCC) method for totem-pole power factor correction (TPPFC) converters that maintains prediction accuracy under inductance variations. In practice, the effective boost inductance deviates from its nominal value due to tolerances, temperature, aging, and operating condition dependence. This degrades the MPCC current prediction and increases input current distortion, especially near the voltage zero crossing point. The proposed controller incorporates an extended Kalman filter (EKF) that estimates the inductance online at every sampling instant and injects it into the MPCC prediction model. A 2 kW FPGA-based TPPFC converter experimental setup is used to evaluate the method for two inductors (2.5/5.0 mH) and two load conditions (1/2 kW). Experimental results demonstrate that EKF-based inductance adaptation improves current prediction and sinusoidal current shaping without compromising power factor (PF) or efficiency. These results indicate that the proposed approach provides a practical solution for accurate MPCC implementation in TPPFC converters.

title: Health Monitoring System Development for Shielding Pumps in CSNS Target Station Cooling System
authors: Yu Liu, Ning He, Qiao Liang, Zhe Yang, Chuan Li, Huihong Liang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: To address the challenge of effective condition monitoring of shielded pumps in the water cooling system of the China Spallation Neutron Source (CSNS) target station under high radiation environments, this paper develops an intelligent fault diagnosis system based on multi-parameter fusion. The system integrates vibration sensors and current sensors to achieve multi-parameter monitoring, and establishes an integrated monitoring platform incorporating hardware system, software analysis, and database management. The system employs a threshold-based condition assessment method to realize real-time monitoring and fault warning, transforming the passive maintenance mode into a predictive maintenance strategy by replacing traditional offline inspection with online continuous monitoring. This system not only provides technical assurance for the safe and stable operation of the CSNS target station water cooling system, but also serves as a practical platform for health monitoring and fault diagnosis research of high-reliability equipment, demonstrating significant engineering application value.

title: ASDMD-GMM-UT Transfer-Driven RUL Probabilistic Prediction for Lithium-Ion Battery Packs
authors: Yihe Guo, Xipeng Wang, Jinzhen Kong, Dong Zhen, Guojin Feng, Hao Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Accurate remaining useful life (RUL) prediction of lithium-ion battery packs is essential for ensuring the reliability and safety of energy storage systems. However, the cross-domain transfer health prognosis from single cells to packs faces two major challenges: nonlinear and asynchronous degradation behaviors, and multimodal noises that violate the single-Gaussian assumption commonly used in traditional models. To address these issues, this study proposes an integrated framework for lithium-ion battery packs RUL prediction, synergistically combining an adaptive step-size differential model decomposition based on local curvature (ASDMD), and a Gaussian mixture model-based Unscented Transformation (GMM-UT). ASDMD adaptively regulates differential step sizes by local curvature estimation, ensuring the reduction of noise interference in smooth degradation phases and accurate capture of inflection points in steep degradation phases. GMM is employed to simultaneously model the statistical distributions of measurement noise and differential noise, while the UT realizes probabilistic propagation across domains. Three comparison methods are conducted to verify the accuracy and robustness of the proposed method. Experimental results show that the proposed method significantly improved prognostics performance for battery packs. In the migration prediction from battery cells to battery packs, the root mean square error for RUL prediction is less than 4 %, providing reliable guidance for maintenance scheduling and second-life utilization of battery systems.

title: Exploring Privacy and Security Risks in LLMs: Data Leakage, Prompt Injection, and Membership Inference
authors: Giancarlo Sperlí
abstract: In this paper, we present an analysis of the dual role of Large Language Models (LLMs) in the context of multimedia security, examining how these models can both strengthen defensive capabilities and introduce new vulnerabilities within modern content ecosystems. As LLMs increasingly interface with multimedia workflows-ranging from text-image generation pipelines to cross-modal retrieval and content moderation-their susceptibility to attacks such as data leakage, prompt injection, and jailbreaks raises critical concerns for the integrity and trustworthiness of multimedia platforms. We focus our analysis on privacy-oriented threats, including model inversion and membership inference, and discuss their implications for systems that process or generate multimedia content. Building on this risk landscape, we outline principles for improving the robustness and resilience of LLM-driven multimedia applications, highlighting strategies suited to in-the-wild threat scenarios. Indeed, we explore the constructive application of LLMs within cybersecurity frameworks, such as the Cyber Kill Chain, demonstrating how these models can be leveraged for threat detection, risk assessment, and automated defensive operations.

title: Performance Evaluation of Inverter-Fed Autonomous Microgrids under Uniform and Non-Uniform Delays Using Internal Model Control
authors: Sneha Goneguntla, Gnana Saisree Boppudi, Naresh Kumar Vemula, Pratikanta Mishra, Kiran Kumar N
abstract: This paper presents an internal model control (IMC) strategy for an inverter-based autonomous microgrid (MG) considering time delay. The system is modeled with two parallel inverters connected with multiple linear loads and incorporates communication delay associated with measurement blocks. The IMC controller is properly tuned with the help of a filter. parameter and utilized to control active and reactive power sharing. Furthermore, the time delay is modeled using Pade. approximation and the test system is investigated with uniform and non-uniform delay. The key performance indicators, like Overshoot, steady-state accuracy, and settling time demonstrate that the IMC controller provides better mitigation of high-frequency oscillations under both uniform and non-uniform delay. The proposed model efficacy is compared with a conventional controller, and the results indicate that IMC application in distributed energy systems mitigates high-frequency oscillations associated with inherent time-delays.

title: Development of YOLO-Based Fall Detection with Real-Time Monitoring System on Raspberry Pi 5
authors: Ngoc Anh Tran, Hoang Phuc Nguyen, Hoang-Loc Tran, Dinh-Duy Phan
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Falls are a leading cause of serious injuries, particularly among the elderly, children, and workers in hazardous environments. To enhance safety and real-time monitoring, this study develops a YOLO-based fall detection system, deployed on the Raspberry Pi 5 platform. At its core, the system utilizes a YOLOv9 model retrained on an extensive dataset of over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 7, 0 0 0}$</tex> images from various public sources. To address class imbalance and reduce false alarms, an additional 6,000 images of normal activities (Not_Fallen) were incorporated. After fine-tuning hyperparameters, the model achieved a high accuracy of 99.1 %, surpassing the reference study's mAP@0.5 score of 98.1 %. Experimental results demonstrate that the system operates efficiently, detecting falls with exceptional precision across diverse scenarios while maintaining realtime processing capability. This research establishes a strong foundation for future advancements, enabling the development of more sophisticated monitoring systems and expanding applications in safety and healthcare domains.

title: AgroFog+: Integrated IoT and AI System for Smart Greenhouse Management
authors: Shibagni Bhattacharjee, Raj Krish, Debajyoti Chatterjee, Suchanda Chatterjee
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Protective growing in greenhouses requires precise environmental control, effective water usage, hazard management, and immediate monitoring of plant health. AgroFog+ is a low-cost, integrated IoT-based system that addresses these challenges through microclimate control, adaptive fogging, fire and gas hazard monitoring, and an AI-based assessment of plant stress. The system achieves optimal humidity and CO levels with soil-moisture responsive fogging, and it detects hazards in real time. The farmers can upload images of the plants, which are then analyzed with AI. The AI identifies diseases such as powdery mildew, recommends treatment, and automatically generates a detailed report sent via email. Experimental validation shows AgroFog+ stabilizes humidity, on-farm consumption of water, fast hazard detection, and detection of diseases for example, powdery mildew. AgroFog+ integrates environmental control, safety or hazard detection, and AI analysis of plant health into a single web-based system that is scalable, practical, and low- cost for smaller and mid-scale greenhouse growing opportunities, which promotes crop yield, efficient resource use, and potential preventative management of plants.

title: Technology-Based Ergonomic Interventions for Preventing Musculoskeletal Disorders
authors: Anggi Paola Ricaldi-Esteban, Pablo César Gutiérrez-Falcón
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This study aimed to identify ergonomic interventions that incorporate technology to prevent or reduce musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs). A systematic review was carried out using databases such as Scopus, ScienceDirect, ALICIA, CONCYTEC, and Google Scholar, covering publications from 2012 to 2025. Selection criteria included articles and theses focused on technological interventions. The PRISMA technique was used, resulting in a final review of 28 articles selected for the topic. The results indicate that the identified technological interventions include exoskeletons, wearable sensors and devices, and motion capture systems. However, identified limitations included the high cost of devices, poor ergonomic design, and a lack of long-term studies. In conclusion, technological ergonomic interventions represent effective strategies for MSD prevention, although the identified limitations need to be addressed to enhance their effectiveness in occupational settings.

title: Joint Unicast and Multicast Transmission in RSMA-Aided Clustered Cell-Free Systems: Clustering and Power Allocation
authors: Xiaowu Ou, Yin Xu, Ruomeng Wang, Cixiao Zhang, De Mi, Dazhi He, Zhen Gao, Yiyan Wu
abstract: In this article, we design a joint unicast and multicast transmission system based on rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) and cell-free (CF) architectures. To enhance multicast efficiency and system scalability, we propose a large-scale fading coefficients-based clustering scheme that partitions users and access points (APs) into disjoint clusters, achieving dual benefits: significant precoding complexity reduction and enhanced multicast transmission efficiency. Unlike conventional methods, our approach enforces a critical constraint ensuring the number of cluster transmit antennas exceeds user antennas, thereby guaranteeing sufficient independent spatial streams. Subsequent to cluster formation, we implement fully distributed power allocation, substantially reducing system overhead compared to centralized alternatives. We derive closed-form expressions for the average sum rate (ASR) and ergodic sum rate (ESR) lower bounds under distributed operation, and develop a graph convolutional network (GCN) power allocation algorithm. Simulation results validate the superiority of our approach.

title: Transforming Crop Disease Classification with Hybrid Quantum Deep Learning
authors: Muhammad Shoaib Sarwar, Komal Batool
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to crop disease classification through the integration of quantum computing principles with deep learning techniques. We introduce a hybrid quantum neural network architecture that leverages quantum mechanical phenomena, including superposition and entanglement, to enhance crop disease detection capabilities. Using a comprehensive dataset of 23,265 images spanning 19 disease classes across five major crop species, our model achieved a test accuracy of 0.7958 with a weighted average F1-score of 0.85. The architecture combines classical convolutional layers for initial feature extraction with quantum processing units for advanced pattern recognition, demonstrating significant potential in the diagnosis of agricultural diseases. Our findings establish the viability of quantum-enhanced neural networks in agricultural applications, while highlighting pathways for future development in quantum machine learning systems.

title: Contrastive Semantic Reinforced Summarization: A Hybrid Framework for Arabic Abstractive Text Summarization
authors: Karim Dabbabi, Ahlem Kehili, Adnen Cherif
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Arabic abstractive text summarization remains a challenging task due to the language’s morphological richness, syntactic variability, and limited availability of highquality annotated corpora. This paper introduces the Contrastive and Reinforcement-enhanced Summarization System (CSRS), a novel hybrid framework that integrates contrastive semantic pretraining with reinforcement learning optimization to enhance summary fidelity and factual consistency. The model first employs a contrastive alignment module to maximize semantic coherence between the source and target summaries, followed by a reinforcement learning stage that optimizes task-specific rewards based on ROUGE-L, factual consistency, and coherence metrics. Experiments conducted on ArSumNews and Arabic Gigaword datasets demonstrate that CSRS achieves a ROUGE-L score of 43.12, outperforming AraBART and AraT5 by 3.6% and 2.8%, respectively, while improving BERTScore (F1) to 88.4. Furthermore, contrastive pretraining reduces semantic drift by 15% compared with conventional cross-entropy training. These results confirm the effectiveness of integrating semantic representation learning with reward-based optimization, offering a robust, contextually faithful, and human-oriented summarization framework for Arabic. The proposed CSRS sets a new benchmark in Arabic abstractive summarization and provides a foundation for future multimodal and crosslingual extensions.

title: Localization of OFDM Sources Using a Single Hydrophone in Rician Fading Channels
authors: Xinghao Qu, Zhigang Shang, Gang Qiao, Yiwen Zhou
abstract: This paper investigates range-depth localization of an orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) source using a single hydrophone, which serves as a portable scheme suitable for small underwater platforms. We consider a typical shallow-water propagation model, where the rich position information embedded in multipath delays and amplitudes offers the potential to achieve the above purpose. Specifically, we exploit the frequency-domain input-output relationship of pilot subcarriers to construct a measurement model and incorporate joint processing of multiple OFDM symbols to enhance localization performance. To characterize random fluctuations in path gains caused by scattering from the rough surface and bottom, we introduce the Rician fading model. Under this assumption, each complex path amplitude comprises a deterministic component associated with the source position and a random perturbation. To fully leverage the parametric model, we adopt the stochastic maximum likelihood principle. The resulting high-dimensional optimization problem is iteratively solved by the developed expectation-maximization-type algorithm. In addition, a stable initialization scheme is designed to strive for convergence to the global optimum. To quantitatively evaluate the sensing capability of the integrated system, we derive the Cramér-Rao bound on the mean square error of the localization result and elucidate the performance gain from the joint processing. For completeness, we also present a tailored communication processing chain for symbol detection. Simulations and laboratory experiments demonstrate the superiority of the proposed algorithm over existing matched field processing-based positioning techniques.

title: Bridging Service Quality and Architecture in Digital Banking: A Usability Framework Based on TOGAF ADM and E-Servqual
authors: Muharman Lubis, Fadhil Rozi Hendrawan, Alif Noorachmad Muttaqin, Dini Oktarina Dwi Handayani
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: This study proposes a usability framework that bridges service quality and enterprise architecture in digital banking, focusing on PT Bank XYZ—one of Indonesia’s leading banks. The research aims to address customer dissatisfaction with the PT XYZ Online application by aligning IT architecture with customer expectations. The study adopts TOGAF ADM (The Open Group Architecture Framework – Architecture Development Method) as the foundation for enterprise architecture design, customized through the integration of a satisfaction matrix derived from E-Servqual analysis. A mixed-method approach was applied, combining quantitative data from 100 customer questionnaires with qualitative insights from observation and literature review. The resulting satisfaction matrix corresponds to the business, information system, and technology architecture phases of TOGAF ADM, providing a structured mapping of user experience factors to architectural domains. The findings indicate that PT XYZ’s business and technology architectures demonstrate higher maturity (level 4), while data and application architectures remain at level 3. The study concludes with an enterprise architecture blueprint that guides future IT development, emphasizing continuous improvement of usability, system integration, and customer satisfaction in digital banking services.

title: Fuzzy Neural Dynamics for Kinematic Learning and Simultaneous Control of Redundant Robots
authors: Liuyi Wen, Jianfeng Lv, Yongji Guan, Long Jin
abstract: The accuracy of the kinematic information of a redundant robot directly influences the control performance of its end-effector. However, in practical applications, kinematic parameters may change. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a robust learning and fuzzy control (RLFC) model that possesses kinematic learning and simultaneous control capabilities, enabling the estimation of unknown kinematic parameters and achieving adaptive control for redundant robots. Specifically, the RLFC model comprises two components: an integral-enhanced recurrent neural dynamics (IERND) and a fuzzy-enhanced recurrent neural dynamics (FERND). The IERND is designed to enhance the noise tolerance in kinematic parameter learning. Based on the learned kinematic parameters, the FERND, which incorporates a fuzzy logic system for dynamically adjusting convergence parameters, achieves effective position and orientation tracking of the end-effector in the redundant robot. Theoretical analyses are provided to demonstrate the convergence of the RLFC model. Simulations and experiments validate the effectiveness of the RLFC model in parameter learning, noise tolerance, and kinematic control. The accompanying video can be accessed at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://youtu.be/DS6k7Cu19sU</uri>.

title: Suppressing the Capacitive Coupling by Adjusting the Precharge Biasing Scheme in a Two-Transistor Dynamic Random-Access Memory Operation
authors: Ju Hong Min, Jihun Kang, Jang Hyun Kim, Seongjae Cho
abstract: In this study, the impact of capacitive coupling (CC) caused by the parasitic capacitance components of metal-oxide semiconductor field effect transistors (MOSFETs) on the data stored in a two-transistor dynamic random-access memory (2T DRAM), is investigated, and a method to suppress CC is proposed. Recently, processing-in-memory (PIM) has been getting increasing popularity as one of the emerging technologies for future computing with a focus on data-centric operations due to increasing applications which deal with large amounts of data. 2T DRAM has advantages at high-speed inference operations, cell scalability with truncation of the bulky capacitor, and full Si processing-capability, which makes the 2T DRAM PIM more favorable in chip implementation. However, the 2T DRAM cell has a weakness in that it is highly susceptible to coupling, because the storage node (SN), where data is stored, exists between the two transistors at floating state. This work investigates the cause of the CC and explains how to the precharge voltage is used to reduce the effect of CC in 2T DRAM. Furthermore, the disturbance based on the data stored in each cell of a 32 × 32 array is analyzed to determine its impact on read operations. The overall circuit simulations are based on the 65-nm standard process and the effects of parameters in its model library are examined.

title: Design of the First Optimal Sliding Mode Control of Uncertain Linear Systems Based on Metaheuristics
authors: Wafa Boukadida, Awatef Yahyaoui, Anouar Benamor, Hassani Messaoud
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: The paper focuses on designing an optimal controller to stabilize linear uncertain discrete systems. The novel control method employs First Order Sliding Mode Control (FOSMC), Linear Quadratic Regulation (LQR), and metaheuristics. First, the optimal controller for the non-perturbed system is presented. Then, to compensate for unknown disturbances, the LQR method is combined with the sliding mode controller. To address issues associated with LQR synthesis, a metaheuristic-based optimization problem with conflicting objectives is solved. A novel aggregated dynamic objective function is proposed. The obtained results demonstrate the effectiveness and usefulness of the control strategy.

title: YOLOv5-Powered Smart Parking System with IoT-Based Real-Time Slot Monitoring
authors: Phuong Lam Nguyen, Duc Tai Phan, Thanh Trung Nguyen, Nhut Minh Nguyen, Duc Ngoc Minh Dang
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Finding a parking space has become a daily struggle in an era of rapid urbanization and increasing car ownership, contributing to traffic congestion, lost time, and environmental stress. To transform urban parking management, this study presents a novel Smart Parking System (SPS) that seamlessly integrates deep learning and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies. Our SPS delivers a streamlined workflow, featuring real-time slot occupancy detection via a fine-tuned YOLOv5 model analyzing camera feeds, automated entry/exit handling triggered by IoT sensors, and a specialized License Plate Recognition (LPR) model. Additionally, it includes secure cloud-based data logging for effortless tracking and billing. The web dashboard provides real-time, color-coded visualizations of slot availability, supporting efficient parking management. Experimental evaluation demonstrates an accuracy of 90% in license plate recognition and over 99.5% in slot occupancy detection, highlighting the system's reliability and practical applicability for smart city deployment.

title: Beyond Appearance: Dual-Graph Object Encoding with Learnable Graph Structure
authors: Cuiyun Fang, Fan Wang, Xirun Cheng, Wen Zhang, Zhenyu Gao, Yingwei Xia, Guoqing Deng, Chaofan Zhang
abstract: Object encoding is essential for enabling robots to efficiently perform tasks such as recognition and autonomous exploration. Existing object encoding approaches typically rely on appearance-based representations, leading to poor performance in environments with multiple visually similar objects, which can compromise downstream task accuracy. Inspired by human perception of objects through both appearance and structure, we introduce DGOE, a novel object encoding method, which adopts a dual-graph embedding scheme. Rather than treating object representation as a single-level appearance encoding problem, DGOE explicitly models object discriminability through a dual-level structural formulation, decomposing it into intrinsic inner-object structure and cross-object relational context. DGOE leverages graph structures as the carrier to integrate object intrinsic appearance and cross-object spatial features. This unified framework leads to more distinctive and reliable object representations. Additionally, we use multi-head self-attention to learn cross-object graph structures for extracting cross-object spatial features. Experimental evaluations on multiple publicly available datasets demonstrate the superior performance of our method in object-level matching tasks, underscoring its effectiveness and robustness.

title: An AC Charging Pile Current Regulation System Based on LoRa-Modbus
authors: Wenbin Zheng, Han Yang, Zheng Shi, Ping Fu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This study presents a LoRa-Modbus heterogeneous integrated CP line PWM intelligent control center based on STM32F103C8T6 for new energy vehicle charging piles. The system regulates CP line PWM signals and integrates LoRa-Modbus communication. A “programmable voltage division and buffer isolation” architecture enables accurate detection of multi-state signals <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(12 ~\mathrm{V} / 9 ~\mathrm{V} / 6 ~\mathrm{V})$</tex>. Highfrequency ADC sampling (10 kHz) with threshold statistics achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leqslant 1 \%$</tex> duty cycle error. A novel “LoRa physical layer + Modbus application layer” scheme, using the SX1268 chip, supports long-distance transmission and protocol mapping between Modbus registers <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0 \times 003 \mathrm{C}-0 \times 0276)$</tex> and PWM duty cycles <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(10 \%-89.2 \%)$</tex>, corresponding to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.0-63.0 ~\mathrm{A}$</tex> current with 0.1 A resolution. Experiments verify duty cycle tracking error <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leqslant 1 \%$</tex> without LoRa signals, offering a cost-effective, robust solution for charging pile upgrades.

title: A Dual-Band Circularly Polarized Slot Antenna with EBG Structure for Wi-Fi Applications
authors: Hien Doan Thi Ngoc, Hoai Vu Ngoc
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper introduces a high-gain dual-band circularly polarized (CP) microstrip slot antenna operating in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.4 \text{GHz}(2.4-2.484 \text{GHz})$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.5 \text{GHz}(5.150-5.825 \text{GHz})$</tex> Wi-Fi bands. An EBG surface composed of an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8$</tex> array of unit cells is positioned beneath the antenna, accompanied by two symmetrical rows of EBG elements placed on either side of the radiating element to enhance the overall antenna gain. Simulated results demonstrate good CP performance, with 3 dB axial ratio bandwidths (ARBW) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.6 \%(2.35-2.51 \text{GHz})$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$18.72 \%(5.00-6.03 \text{GHz})$</tex>, and high realized gains of 7.76 dBic and 8.84 dBic at 2.4 GHz and 5.5 GHz, respectively.

title: Exploratory Analysis and Temporal Dynamics of Air pollution in Bengaluru
authors: A Suresh, M N Saroja, S Kannan, A Sindhu, A Esakkiammal
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: The Indian cities have established air pollution as a critical environmental and health concern which affects the entire nation. The study evaluates Bengaluru’s Air Quality Index (AQI) data from 2017 to 2024 through detailed timebased and statistical methods. The research demonstrates that air pollution levels reach their peak during winter months from December to February but decrease substantially during the monsoon period from June to August. The 2020 COVID-19 lockdown resulted in substantial reductions of AQI values because of reduced human activity. The highest pollution levels occurred in 2019, but the AQI readings stayed mostly between 75 and 135 which falls under the ‘Moderate’ category. The pollution levels show a pattern of higher readings on weekdays because of vehicle and industrial emissions. The research demonstrates how urban growth interacts with weather conditions and human-made pollution sources to produce air quality changes. The research findings establish a data-based framework which enables urban planners to create effective sustainable air-quality management strategies for Bengaluru
