title: Study of Energy Flow in a Standalone Hybrid PV/Fuel Cell System
authors: Tawfik Soltani, Monia Ben Khader Bouzid
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: As part of the global energy transition, ensuring the autonomy of isolated sites is a major challenge, particularly in sunny regions such as Tunisia. Photovoltaic (PV) and hydrogen-based technologies are recognized as renewable sources for efficient and sustainable electricity generation. This paper presents a detailed analysis of a hybrid system that integrates a PV array with a proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) to supply a constant 6 kW load. Furthermore, simulations were performed in MATLAB/Simulink to investigate the dynamic behavior of the system under various solar irradiation conditions. The outcomes of this study provide valuable insights into the overall performance of the hybrid PV/PEMFC system and contribute to advancing sustainable solutions for isolated energy applications.

title: Second-Order Filtering for Internal Model Control Tuned PID Controllers
authors: Atilla Uygur
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Proportional-Integral-Derivative (PID) control has long been the backbone of many industrial control systems due to its cost-effectiveness, simplicity of design, and robustness. Internal Model Control (IMC) is one of the most effective approaches for tuning PID controller parameters. Typically, first-order low-pass filters are employed in the IMC-based process control, where the filter has only one tuning parameter, namely closed-loop time constant, $\lambda$. Even when a second-order filter is used, it still has only one tuning parameter. This study investigates the effect of second-order filtering with two userdefined parameters and employs analog filter denominator polynomials to determine the initial controller parameters. A novel second-order filtering model is proposed for first-order plus time delay (FOPTD) processes, and second-order low-pass Butterworth and Bessel polynomials are utilized to derive initial PID tuning parameters. The performance of the resulting controllers is evaluated through simulations in terms of setpoint tracking, load disturbance rejection, and robustness to model uncertainties for two FOPTD processes.

title: Long-Range Active Acoustic Sensing Based on Microwave Vibration Measurement
authors: Zhiqiang Kang, Haibin Meng, Yuyong Xiong, Xiangyi Tang, Wendi Tian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This paper presents a long-range active acoustic sensing method based on microwave vibration measurement. Conventional microphones suffer from severe performance degradation in long-distance sound acquisition due to acoustic energy attenuation and environmental interference, while laser-based solutions are limited by high cost and sensitivity to ambient conditions. To address these challenges, we propose an approach that employs a frequency-modulated continuous-wave (FMCW) radar system to measure the phase variations of reflected microwave signals, thereby estimating the minute vibrations of sound-producing objects and reconstructing the corresponding acoustic signals. The vibration measurement principle is derived in detail, and multiple experiments are conducted with sound sources placed up to 10 meters away. The results verify that the proposed method effectively acquires various types of sound signals at long range while maintaining robustness against environmental noise. This work demonstrates the feasibility of microwave-based acoustic sensing as a promising alternative to conventional methods for remote sound acquisition.

title: KUL-BPS: A Bearing Testing Platform in Addressing Data Scarcity in Condition Monitoring
authors: Junyu Qi, Zhen Li, Alexandre Mauricio, Konstantinos Gryllias
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Condition monitoring (CM) is vital for ensuring the reliability and safety of rotating machinery in industrial applications. Despite significant advances in signal processing and machine learning techniques, progress in CM research remains constrained by the scarcity of high-quality degradation datasets. Acquiring such data, particularly for fault prognostics, faces multiple challenges. First, constructing an experimental test rig requires substantial investment and multidisciplinary expertise in mechanical design, control systems, and measurement technologies. Second, generating meaningful prognostic datasets demands large numbers of bearing failures under diverse operating conditions to adequately represent different degradation patterns. Third, the degradation process often takes several days to months, making it both time- and resource-intensive. As a result, few comprehensive datasets are publicly available due to commercial confidentiality and limited test capacities. To address these challenges and contribute to the CM community, we present the KU Leuven Bearing Prognostics Setup (KUL-BPS), a novel, modular, and cost-effective Accelerated Lifetime Testing (ALT) platform designed for systematic bearing degradation testing. Unlike existing ALT setups, which are often limited to low loads <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(<10 \text{kN})$</tex>, low speeds (<3000 RPM), or artificially induced faults, KUL-BPS offers several key advantages: (a) It supports high loads up to 35 kN and speeds up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$18,000 \text{RPM}$</tex>, enabling realistic wear and fatigue processes; (b) It utilizes a robust self-aligning bearing, which is easy to install, inspect, and replace; (c) It allows experiments under both constant and time-varying load-speed profiles to reflect real-world operating conditions. Furthermore, KUL-BPS enables synchronized acquisition of multiple sensing modalities, including vibration, torque, speed, force, acoustics, displacement, and temperature, facilitating comprehensive CM studies. The platform also supports virtual sensing research, such as estimating internal forces or torques from indirect measurements.

title: Reflective Photoplethysmography Sensing Interface Designs on Chest for Improved Signal Quality*
authors: Zifei He, Yutong Zhang, Yiqing Yao, Zhipeng Cai, Lulu Zhao, Yongxin Chou, Qun Wei, Jianqing Li, Chengyu Liu, Chenxi Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: To accommodate multi-modal measurements, photoplethysmography (PPG) sensors have to be placed at nonstandard body sites, such as the chest, where unstable sensorskin contact commonly degrades signal quality. In this case, this paper presented a low-cost consideration of sensing interface that improves the signal quality of reflective PPG. Major designs were raised sensing surface and all-in-one electrode. The raised sensing surface helps the light-emitting diode (LED) and photodiode (PD) maintain flexible, close attachment to the skin. The all-in-one electrode with an open window and double-sided tape provides stable mechanical support. In this paper, two prototypes - one baseline (flat surface, separate electrodes) and one improved (raised surface, all-in-one electrode) - were tested simultaneously in 15 healthy subjects. Signal quality was compared using the PQR signal-quality indexes (rSQI) and SNR. The improved device outperformed the conventional one, with an average rSQI increase of +4.01 (infrared) and +2.08 (red), and an SNR improvement of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{+ 7. 8 6 d B}$</tex> (infrared) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{+} \mathbf{1 6. 7 5 d B}$</tex> (red). Using off-the-shelf parts and simple processes, the proposed designs effectively suppress low-frequency noise and enhance reflectance PPG quality at low cost.

title: Next-Gen Offshore Wind Year Ahead Forecasting Aided Modelling for Techno-Economic Feasibility
authors: Nidhi Gummaraju, C Shri Varshini, Mamilla Sree Vyshnavi, Greeshma Potnuru, K. Shanti Swarup
abstract: Offshore wind power development entails high uncertainty in the form of fluctuating resources, intricate grid integration, and finance risk. This paper proposes an integrated solution that unites wind resource evaluation, machine learning–based predictions, physics-constrained simulation, and techno-economic optimization to enhance the reliability and profitability of offshore wind farms. The model integrates high-resolution spatiotemporal information with a prediction module using the Extra Trees regressor, having a determination coefficient of R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.999. The simulation of physics-based turbine dynamics and high-voltage direct current (HVDC) transmission is used to calculate the operational stability and transmission loss. In addition, Monte Carlo-based measures of risk including De-Risked Wind Power Availability (DWPA) and Weighted Annual Revenue Reliability (WARR) are employed to quantify the impact of uncertainty in the market returns. A case study of a 1 GW offshore installation off the coast of Tamil Nadu illustrates a mean capacity factor of about 48% and a levelized cost of energy of 65–75 USD/MWh. These results indicate that the combined framework can substantially reduce techno-economic risk while supporting data-driven decision-making for large-scale offshore wind deployment.

title: Advancing Transmission Use of System (TUoS) Pricing in Saudi Arabia: A Technical Exploration
authors: M. S. Almajed, E. Q. Novenario, B. K. Al-Gthami
abstract: The structuring of Transmission Use of System (TUoS) pricing represents a pivotal technical and economic challenge within modern electricity market design, directly influencing investment signals, operational efficiency, and the integration of renewable energy sources. This paper presents a rigorous technical analysis of the evolutionary pathway for TUoS charges, drawing upon well-established international benchmarks. Utilizing a comprehensive phased modeling approach—progressing from a simple postage stamp model to the current peak-coincident framework and finally to an advanced zonal pricing methodology—this study applies a simplified DC load flow analysis, executed in a Python environment, to a representative model of the Saudi national grid. The modeling results provide quantifiable evidence of significant locational disparities in network costs, demonstrating that a strategic transition to a zonal model would substantially enhance economic efficiency by providing transparent, cost-reflective signals to guide optimal generation siting and demand-side management. Furthermore, this analysis establishes a technically robust and defensible foundation for calculating precise wheeling charges between zones—an important institutional enabler for third-party market access and competition, in line with broader liberalization goals. This study also offers practical insights into how Saudi Arabia's tariff structures could align with global technical practices, helping to support the Kingdom's Vision 2030 objectives for economic and energy diversification. The analysis is conducted with full respect for the significant progress already achieved by the national utility and regulator, and is intended solely as a technical contribution to the ongoing dialogue on strengthening the Kingdom's energy sector governance for a sustainable and efficient future [1].

title: Vaku: Web Application for the Management of Child Vaccination at the Emiro Quintero CañIzares Hospital in Ocaña
authors: Nelson Mauricio Navarro Zaraza, Noemi Collantes Reyes, Duvan Andrey Marquez Pinzón, Mauricio Alfredo Zafra Aycardi, Dewar Rico-Bautista
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: Childhood vaccination coverage has declined alarmingly in several regions of Latin America, especially in areas such as Ocaña, Norte de Santander (Colombia), which has generated public health concern. Socioeconomic, cultural, and structural factors, and particularly the deterioration or loss of the physical card, have interrupted the adequate follow-up of the vaccination schedule. This article presents a technological solution centered on a web application that allows health personnel to efficiently manage child immunization records and parents to consult their children's immunization status. The proposed solution strengthens digital capabilities in local health centers, through a user-friendly interface that improves traceability in the vaccination schedule, which seeks to ensure constant access to immunization data, contributing to an increase in the vaccination rate in the population.

title: Knowledge-Based Behavioral Biometrics for Secure Authentication in Virtual Reality
authors: Numan Zafar, Priyo Ranjan Kundu Prosun, Shafique Ahmad Chaudhry
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) transforms daily activities into immersive experiences, bridging the gap between physical and virtual environments. The growing use of VR applications to handle sensitive personal data necessitates the development of authentication methods that are both secure and practical. Traditional PIN-based systems remain susceptible to theft, spoofing, and credential sharing, while previous behavior-based biometrics often restrict trajectories to fixed lengths and overlook device heterogeneity. This study presents the first VR authentication framework that integrates knowledge-based PIN entry with behavioral biometrics derived from cross-device input modalities, incorporating both controller and hand-tracking trajectories to enhance the security. We evaluate a Siamese network designed to process variable-length motion data using a pilot dataset of 26 participants performing four distinct PIN-entry tasks. The proposed approach achieves authentication accuracies up to 96%, with Equal Error Rates (EERs) as low as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2. 9 5 \%}$</tex>. By preserving natural temporal variability and generating match scores, this method enables authentication to generalize across devices and users, thereby establishing a foundation for secure and deployable VR access control systems.

title: Soft Actor-Critic-Based Early Warning Method for Quench Risk in High-Temperature Superconducting Cables
authors: Jiawei Hao, Sixiang Xue, Chang Li, Jixiang Liu, Rui Wang, Menghua Deng, Pengyu You
abstract: To address the challenge of predicting quench risks in high-temperature superconducting (HTS) cables under multiple-source disturbances, this paper proposes an intelligent early-warning method based on the Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) algorithm. At first, a multi-index evaluation system covering electrical and cooling characteristics is constructed, and the entropy weight method is adopted to determine the weights for comprehensive risk quantification. Secondly, a deep reinforcement learning model based on SAC is established to achieve dynamic risk prediction under continuous operating conditions. Finally, multi-scenario experiments and comparative analysis with other mainstream early-warning methods demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves effective early quench warning, with prediction errors consistently maintained within acceptable ranges.

title: Automatic Generation of Open Data-Based Traffic Simulation Model
authors: Hyunyoung Ryu, Jitaek Lim, Minseok Song
abstract: Open transportation data is becoming more accessible, creating new opportunities for data-driven traffic simulation. However, transforming this data into a simulation-ready model is complex and time-consuming. This study introduces an automated framework to generate city-scale traffic simulation models using open data, including road networks, traffic signals, and vehicle volumes. Built on the Simulation of Urban Mobility (SUMO), the pipeline streamlines data processing and integrates real-world inputs into simulation components. The framework combines multiple open datasets through hybrid data synthesis, ensuring consistent road–signal coordination and enhancing traffic-flow realism and spatial resolution. Applied to a real urban center, the resulting models showed strong alignment with observed traffic patterns, supporting validity. As data collection, real-time monitoring, and spatial resolution advance, the framework’s applicability and precision will improve. By enabling efficient and reproducible model generation, this approach contributes to scalable traffic simulation and lays the groundwork for urban digital twin applications.

title: Self-Recovery and Fault-Tolerant Control of Distributed Piezoelectric Stack Actuators Under Temperature Perturbation and Layer Breakdown
authors: Jie Ling, Yunzhi Zhang, Congan Xie, Micky Rakotondrabe, Yuchuan Zhu
abstract: Aerospace actuators must deliver high-speed, high-precision performance while withstanding extreme temperatures and environmental variations, which pose significant challenges to their positioning accuracy and reliability. To address these issues, this article proposes a fault decoupling and fault-tolerant control (FTC) scheme for distributed piezoelectric stack actuators (PSAs), enabling self-diagnosis and self-recovery. A temperature perturbation observer (TPO) is designed to estimate temperature-induced disturbances, and a fault decoupling sliding mode observer (FDeSMO) is developed to decouple layer breakdown faults from lumped disturbances. The coordination between the two observers allows accurate detection of broken layers under temperature variations. Subsequently, a fault-tolerant controller is integrated to reallocate control signals and ensure system stability. Experimental results validate the proposed scheme, demonstrating its ability to detect fault and maintain reliability under the fault occurrence and temperature variation (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\textbf{19}\!\boldsymbol{\sim}\!\textbf{60}\,{}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}\textbf{C}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>). Furthermore, the error convergence time after fault detection can be controlled within 8.7 ms. The root mean square error (RMSe) remains below 0.536 <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol{\mu}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>m, accounting for 5.36% of the sinusoidal reference (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\textbf{1}\!\boldsymbol{\sim}\!\textbf{100}\,\textbf{Hz}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\textbf{1}\!\boldsymbol{\sim}\!\textbf{10}\,\boldsymbol{\mu}\textbf{m}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>).

title: Secure Acceleration of Aggregation Queries over Homomorphically Encrypted Databases
authors: Jinjiang Yang, Chunyi Zhang, Feng Liu, Yingjie Xue, Feng Wang, Kaiping Xue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Recent advancements in Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) have significantly impacted encrypted database management, particularly in secure data querying. However, FHE poses notable performance challenges, especially in processing aggregation queries. These challenges stem from the need to homomorphically evaluate selection predicates via a linear scan over encrypted rows and from the resultant accumulation of redundant data. Overcoming these limitations necessitates innovative solutions that transcend traditional FHE optimizations. We propose a scheme, named Accelerated Homomorphically Encrypted DataBase (AHEDB), to enhance the efficiency of aggregation queries in homomorphically encrypted databases. In the scheme, we employ Encrypted Multiple Maps (EMM) to reduce the computational load inherent in homomorphic operations, thereby achieving significant improvements over existing encryption schemes. We further introduce Single Range Cover (SRC) algorithm for range and equality indexing to address potential security vulnerabilities. We implement our scheme and conduct comparative analyses with FHE-based database system. Our experiments demonstrate that our scheme offers significant advantages in querying overheads, striking a balance between security and efficiency.

title: Feasibility of Quantum Cryptography with AES for Secure Communication
authors: Nurul Muzfirah Binti Mustaffa, Nurulain Balqis Binti Mat Daud, Takumi Sase
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Traditional encryption techniques face serious threats from the rapid development of quantum computing, which could soon compromise many classical algorithms. To address this, new quantum-resistant security methods are needed to protect private data and communications. This paper proposes a hybrid encryption approach that integrates quantum key distribution (QKD) with a simplified 3×3 advanced encryption standard (AES) key matrix, creating a lightweight system. The objective is to provide an efficient encryption method suitable for devices with limited processing power, such as IoT devices. The model was simulated using Qiskit, achieving an average quantum bit error rate of 0.00%, protocol efficiency of 49.72 %, and quantum fidelity of 1.000 under certain conditions. During eavesdropping scenarios, the error rate increased to 16.90 %. The simplified AES achieved a 50.14 % avalanche effect and an encryption time of 0.3073 ms, reducing latency by 17 % compared to standard AES. These results suggest that combining QKD with lightweight AES can provide quantum resilience and computational efficiency, offering a practical solution for secure communication in the post-quantum era.

title: Active Disturbance Rejection Controller Applied to Speed Control of Electromagnetic Frequency Regulator
authors: Gabriel P. de Oliveira, Aziz O-S. Bissiriou, José R. D. Neto, Tadeu F. dos Santos, Ricardo F. Pinheiro, Andrés O. Salazar
abstract: This study presents a novel control strategy for regulating the rotor speed of the Electromagnetic Frequency Regulator (EFR) in Hybrid Renewable Energy Systems (HRESs), based on Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ADRC). The EFR, which couples wind and photovoltaic sources through a single-stage power conversion system, requires accurate speed control to ensure stable output frequency in the synchronous generator. Unlike conventional Proportional - Integral (PI) controllers, which are sensitive to parameter uncertainties and external disturbances, ADRC actively estimates and compensates both internal and external perturbations, thus improving overall system robustness. Simulation results show that ADRC reduces speed oscillations by up to 80% during load variations and maintains frequency deviations within 2% of the nominal value, without overshoot. These results underscore ADRC's effectiveness in enhancing stability and power quality in hybrid renewable energy applications.

title: Modeling and Validation of a Two-Stage Degradation and Reliability Estimation Model in an Actuator
authors: Nabila Mabrouk, Ali Ben Brahim, Fayçal Ben Hmida
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents a two-stage actuator degradation model combining gradual wear and shock-induced damage. The first stage describes normal wear, while the second captures mixed progressive and random deterioration. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed model, a comparative analysis is conducted with existing degradation models reported in the literature. Applied to a two-tank level control system, the model provides a realistic representation of actuator behavior and highlights the impact of degradation on system performance.

title: Grounded CPW with a longitudinal slot at the bottom ground for loss reduction at the sub-THz band on glass IPD
authors: Ruei-Ze Lin, Zhi-Ting Yang, Hsin-Chia Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: Grounded CPW with a longitudinal slot at the bottom ground under the signal trace is proposed to reduce the loss of the transmission line at the sub-THz band. Adding a slot under the signal trace redistributes the E-field to the gaps between the signal trace and the two side-grounds. With a larger area for E-field distribution, the loss can be reduced. The wider the slot, the lower the loss in simulation and measurement. At slot widths of 40 μm and 50 μm, the losses are reduced by 37% and 40% at 140 GHz as compared with the traditional GCPW. At 300 GHz, the losses are reduced by 27% and 34%.

title: A Nonlinear Transformation-Based Defense Against Data Leakage in Federated Learning
authors: Trung-Hai Ha, Chi-Thanh Nguyen, Thi-Thu-Hang Truong, Quang-Kien Trinh, Thi-Nga Dao
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) allows multiple clients to train a global model without sharing raw data, but recent studies reveal that transmitted gradients still leak sensitive information through gradient inversion attacks. Such attacks exploit gradient magnitude, direction, sign, and BatchNorm statistics to reconstruct private inputs with high fidelity. In this paper, we introduce a lightweight defense mechanism based on parametric nonlinear gradient transformations. By applying tunable nonlinear mappings to selected gradients before transmission, our approach obfuscates exploitable geometric patterns while preserving convergence. Unlike noise injection or compression, the transformation directly targets the structural cues that enable inversion, thereby providing protection with minimal overhead. Comprehensive experiments on MNIST, CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and LFW confirm that the proposed defense significantly reduces reconstruction quality, achieving higher MSE and lower PSNR/SSIM, while maintaining competitive accuracy compared to baseline FL models. These results highlight the practicality of nonlinear transformations as an effective and composable privacy-preserving technique for federated learning.

title: Too Good to Be Human: AI Turing Test in Incomplete Information-Competitive Games
authors: Wancheng Ni, Xiaoqi Wang, Kaiqi Huang, Xiaonan Zhao, Shixian Wang, Jian Hu, Xin Li
abstract: Recent advances in artificial intelligence (AI) have significantly improved our ability to address complicated problems. However, concerns about human-like AI are also growing. This article investigates when humans consider AI agents to be human-like in competitive board games based on their game performance.

title: Voltage Deviation Feedforward Adaptive Design for VSG Oriented to Transient Stability Boundary Optimization
authors: Pingjuan Ge, Ming Yang, Hailiang Xu, Na Liu, Ruitong Mao
abstract: Virtual synchronous generators (VSGs) mimic the output characteristics of traditional synchronous generators, which can effectively address the challenges of low inertia and weak damping in modern power systems. However, under fault conditions, VSGs exhibit prominent transient instability, and the unclear transient stability boundary significantly impair their voltage/frequency support capability. To this end, this paper proposes a voltage deviation adaptive feedforward method, aiming to optimize the transient stability operating boundary of VSG. First, coupling relationship between reactive power-voltage droop characteristics and transient power angle characteristics is analyzed. Based on this, the coupling characteristics are harnessed to propose a transient stability control architecture incorporating voltage deviation feedforward. Furthermore, with the objective of optimizing the transient stability boundary of VSG, the voltage deviation feedforward coefficient is adaptively designed to enhance its transient stability performance. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed strategy in this paper is verified through simulations and experiments.

title: Physiologically Consistent Postural Control via EHGO-Augmented Nonlinear Compensation
authors: Nadia Sultan, Talha Shakil, Muhammad Najam ul Islam, Beenish Ayaz
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Accurate modeling and control of human postural stability remain central challenges in biomechanics, robotics, and rehabilitation engineering. Traditional approaches based on High-Gain Observers (HGOs) enhance state estimation but are highly sensitive to sensor noise, limiting their reliability in practical scenarios. This paper presents an Extended High-Gain Observer (EHGO)-assisted feedback linearization controller for a single inverted pendulum (SIP) model of human standing posture subject to actuator noise. By explicitly incorporating noise as an augmented state, the EHGO achieves robust state estimation while ensuring disturbance compensation. The controller simulates central nervous system (CNS) regulation by shaping nonlinear dynamics into a double-integrator form regulated via Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR). Simulation results under three perturbation magnitudes (1.27, 1.37, and 1.47 rad) demonstrate fast recovery (<1.7 s), minimal overshoot, negligible steady-state error, and smooth torque transients free of high-frequency chatter, even in noisy conditions. Compared with existing observer-based approaches such as Linear Extended State Observer–Sliding Mode Control (LESO-SMC) exoskeleton control, the proposed design provides equally strong disturbance rejection while preserving continuous, physiologically consistent torque outputs. These results confirm that the SIP model, when augmented with EHGO-based control, remains a valid and powerful framework for analyzing postural stability and developing robust, human-inspired controllers for assistive and rehabilitation technologies.

title: A Multi-Channel CNN for Global Empirical Ionospheric Modeling
authors: Weitang Wang, Yibin Yao, Qi Zhang, Rong Wang, Liang Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Conventional empirical global ionospheric models, such as the Klobuchar model and the International Reference Ionosphere (IRI), utilize a limited set of parameters to represent global ionospheric Total Electron Content (TEC). These models are extensively employed in Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) positioning. However, the accuracy of these models is inherently restricted by their reliance on predefined mathematical functions, particularly during periods of intense space weather activity. While Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) offer significant advantages in modeling nonlinear relationships and have demonstrated promising results for ionospheric prediction, their efficacy specifically for the domain of empirical ionospheric modeling remains largely unexplored. This study aims to fill this gap by proposing a multi-channel Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) method for empirical ionospheric modeling. The base architecture, CEIMv1, integrates fundamental solar-geometric parameters. Building upon this foundation, CEIMv2 incorporates the solar-geomagnetic indices as additional inputs, while CEIMv3 further extends the input data by including Mean Global Electron Content (MGEC) data. Validation against reference products shows that CEIMv2 and CEIMv3 achieve root-mean-square errors (RMSEs) of 6.40 TECU and 4.06 TECU, corresponding to accuracy gains of 26.0% and 17.1% over IRI-2020 and 46.6% and 49.9% compared to the Klobuchar model. Notably, CEIMv3 exhibits a minimal variation in precision of merely 3.66 TECU between high- and low-activity solar years, significantly outperforming conventional models. These results demonstrate a shift from traditional function-based methods toward a data-driven, multi-channel machine learning strategy, offering significantly improved ionospheric delay correction for single-frequency GNSS users.

title: Smart-to-Compress: A Predictive and Game-Theoretic Framework for Data Reduction Decisions
authors: Zhenrui He, Wenlong Tian, Zhixiong Xie, Dewen Zeng, Jianfeng Lu, Zhiyong Xu, Weijun Xiao, Yaping Wan
abstract: With the rapid growth of data, redundancy among different users in cloud environments has become increasingly prominent. Detecting and removing these redundant parts can effectively improve storage efficiency. But these processes may dramatically degrade the system performance, especially when dealing with similar data. Although deduplication and delta compression are common data reduction techniques, their high overhead can outweigh the benefits. As a result, users often cannot determine in advance whether compression is worthwhile for their datasets. Some approaches have attempted to solve this, but each has important limitations. Danny Harnik et al. proposed a sampling-based deduplication estimation method using linear programming, which efficiently estimates redundancy from exact duplicates. However, it fails to capture redundancy arising from similar data, thus underestimating the full compression potential. To address this limitation, we propose Smart-to-Compress, a predictive compression decision framework. We introduce the Super Feature Frequency Histogram (SFH) to capture redundancy among similar data. Combined with the Duplication Frequency Histogram (DFH), our method estimates the overall Data Reduction Ratio (DRR) without scanning the entire dataset. Furthermore, we design a game-theoretic decision model to weigh compression benefits against predicted costs, providing users with guidance on whether compression should be applied. Experiments on real-world datasets show that our method accurately predicts compression value, reduces unnecessary overhead, and offers reliable decision-making support for users.

title: Sampling-Based Imbalance Handling for Ensemble Models in Electricity Payment Fraud Detection
authors: Phung Do, Dinh-Phat Nguyen, Van-Hien Nguyen, Thang Cap, Tuong Le
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Electricity fraud detection remains a critical challenge for utility providers, especially in developing countries where data is large-scale and highly imbalanced. This paper introduces an adaptive resampling framework called the Hybrid Sampling Ratio Selection Algorithm (HSRSA), designed to enhance fraud detection performance in smart grid systems. The method systematically explores combinations of random undersampling and SMOTE-based oversampling ratios to optimize classifier sensitivity under low false positive rate (FPR) constraints. We evaluate the effectiveness of HSRSA across four ensemble-based models—CatBoost, LightGBM, XGBoost, and Decision Tree—using a real-world dataset from Vietnam Electricity comprising over 22 million smart meter records. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly improves partial AUC (pAUC) scores compared to baseline resampling, particularly in the critical <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$FPR \leqslant 0.2$</tex> region. The CatBoost model, when combined with the optimal sampling ratio identified by HSRSA, achieves a pAUC of 0.1992, outperforming its baseline counterpart. This study highlights the importance of ratio tuning in hybrid resampling and contributes a scalable, model-agnostic solution for electricity theft detection in imbalanced and large-scale settings.

title: Robust and Diversified Image Steganography Without Embedding Through a Disentanglement Autoencoder
authors: Xiyao Liu, Ziping Ma, Jian Zhang, Gerald Schaefer, Kehua Guo, Yuesheng Zhu, Shichao Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Image Steganography without Embedding (SWE) is an emerging data hiding paradigm. Instead of embedding a secret message into a container image, SWE synthesises a novel image by using the secret message as a latent code. Current SWE methods have achieved high synthesis quality and strong resistance to steganalysis tools. However, it remains challenging to apply the SWE due to two reasons: (i) lack of synthesis diversity and (ii) recovery of secret messages under malicious image attacks. In this paper, we present a novel SWE framework with a disentanglement autoencoder to tackle the above challenges. Specifically, the autoencoder disentangles an image into a structure and texture representation. Then, we exploit the stability of the structure representation to improve secret message recovery reliability, while increasing synthesis diversity by randomising texture representations and employing a chaotic system for structure randomisation to enhance its security. To further achieve a robust message recovery under malicious attacks, an adversarial learning strategy is introduced into our framework, which guarantees high recovery accuracy. Our method outperforms other state-of-the-art SWE methods in terms of synthesis quality, synthesis diversity and secret message recovery accuracy under various image attacks. The source code is publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Lemok00/RDI-SWE</uri>.

title: Taming Multi-Dimensional Analytics Costs: An Empirical Study of HLL and KLL Sketches in Cloud Data Warehouses
authors: Gurmeet Singh, Kushal Thakkar
abstract: Analytics dashboards that track unique users and percentiles across multiple dimensions create a costly problem for data teams: each query requires scanning the entire dataset, leading to spiraling costs and slow performance. We present an empirical study of a novel architectural pattern that stores compact probabilistic summaries (HyperLogLog (HLL) and Karnin-Lang-Liberty (KLL) sketches) once, then merges them to answer any dimensional query without rescanning data. Testing six configurations on Stack Overflow data (12.46 GB), we achieve 93-96% reduction in data scanning with less than 1% error. Our data-driven guidelines recommend HLL precision 20 and KLL precision 10,000 for production deployments. This approach transforms expensive multi-dimensional analytics into cost-effective operations suitable for real-time dashboards across cloud data warehouses including BigQuery, Snowflake, Redshift, and Presto.

title: Comparison of Random Forest and Gradient Boosting for Predicting Electric Vehicle Charging Time
authors: Rachid Benbey, Youssef Dhieb, Moez Ghariani
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Efficient management of electric vehicle (EV) charging is crucial for promoting the adoption of sustainable mobility. The main objective of this study is to compare two machine learning algorithms—Random Forest (RF) and Gradient Boosting (GB)—for predicting EV charging time using data collected from real charging stations. After rigorous preprocessing of input variables such as voltage, current, and energy, their performance is evaluated using MAE, RMSE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> metrics. Results obtained on public and industrial datasets consistently show the superior accuracy of Gradient Boosting, particularly XGBoost. Future work includes extending the study to other advanced models and exploring real-time implementation.

title: PDF-Reshape: Adversarial Attack on Probabilistic Wind Power Forecasting
authors: Yan Chen, Boli Chen, Mingyang Sun
abstract: Probabilistic wind power forecasting (PWPF) is a critical tool to manage the inherent uncertainty of wind power generation, providing probability predictions essential for economic dispatch and stability assessment. However, the increasing threat of cyberattacks necessitates a comprehensive investigation of the vulnerabilities of PWPFs. This letter introduces a novel adversarial attack framework, termed PDF-Reshape Attack, which targets to manipulate the statistical measures of the probability density functions (PDFs) while maintaining stealthiness by minimizing changes to the expectations. We evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed attack on mainstream PDF distributions (e.g., Gaussian, Beta, Gamma, Weibull) and assess its economic impact on downstream economic dispatch.

title: Experimental Assessment of a Cascaded Path-Following Controller for ASVs Using Extended State Estimation_supp3-3647840.mp4
authors: Manuel Gantiva Osorio
abstract: This work presents a cascaded control strategy for underactuated autonomous surface vehicles, integrating an extended state estimator within a path-following controller. Although path-following control has been extensively addressed in the literature, its experimental implementation continues to face significant challenges, particularly in real-world environments characterized by dynamic uncertainties, unmodeled disturbances, and measurement noise. The proposed architecture preserves the classical structure of cascade control, applying a surge-guided line-of-sight-based guidance law at the kinematic layer and a modified robust-adaptive backstepping controller at the dynamic layer. Both controllers take advantage of a nonlinear set-membership extended state observer, reformulated to incorporate a recently identified kinetic model that accounts for uncertainties in both the inertial dynamics and the propulsion system. The main contributions of this work include the reformulation of the observer to incorporate the identified model and the integration of angular velocity measurements, as well as the demonstration of the input-to-state stability of the low-level tracking errors with respect to estimation errors. Another significant contribution is the experimental validation of the complete strategy on a catamaran-type autonomous surface vehicle, operating under real-world conditions with unmeasured disturbances. The experimental results demonstrate robust and accurate performance in both estimation and control across various circuit exercises.

title: Dynamic Eccentricity Fault Diagnosis in PMSMs of EVs Using Data-Driven Learning
authors: Manel Krichen, Naourez Ben Hadj, Dorra Abdeljalil, Rafik Neji
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motors (PMSMs), commonly used in electric vehicles, are susceptible to dynamic eccentricity (DE) faults. This study compares four machine learning methods: Decision Tree (DT), Random Forest (RF), XGBoost and Support Vector Machine (SVM) to detect DE fault. Three-phase current signals are collected for both healthy motors and motors with a $\mathbf{4 0 \% D E}$ fault. The signals are preprocessed to extract frequency domain features, which are used as inputs for the ML models. The results show that RF achieves the highest accuracy (95.2%) in detecting eccentricity faults.

title: ECTFormer: Efficient CNN-Transformer Network for Uncalibrated Multi-view 3D Human Pose Estimation
authors: Jucheng Song, Xu Yang, Yapeng Wang, Jie Zhang, Sio-Kei Im
abstract: Single-view camera sensors suffer from inherent depth blurring issues that hinder progress in 3D human pose estimation (HPE), sparking widespread research interest in multi-view camera sensor systems. However, existing methods typically rely on complex camera calibration processes and are sensitive to dynamic environments. To address these limitations, we propose ECTFormer, an innovative calibration-free multi-view 3D HPE framework that seamlessly combines Transformer-based spatiotemporal modeling with CNN-based local feature extraction. The primary contents of this paper are: Firstly, we introduce a hierarchical multi-view spatio-temporal feature extraction network. This network avoids interference between noise from different viewpoints through hierarchical learning and employs a transformer to capture spatio-temporal features within views for subsequent fusion. And then, we design a CNN-Transformer fusion module (CTFM) that efficiently aggregates multi-view features, enabling accurate 3D pose regression. Extensive experiments on a public 3D human pose benchmark demonstrate that our approach attains superior performance without relying on calibration. For real-world environments equipped with dynamic camera sensors, ECTFormer can efficiently perform human pose estimation.

title: Solid-State Transformer Framework for FIDVR Mitigation and LVRT Capability Enhancement in PV-Integrated Transmission Systems
authors: Khaled Esamil Sh Ghambirlou, Adel Ali Abosnina, J. Khodabakhsh, Gerry Moschopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Critical motors in power systems are particularly vulnerable to voltage disturbances such as Fault-Induced Delayed Voltage Recovery (FIDVR), which is characterized by voltage dips and extended recovery periods. These issues can lead to motor stalling, industrial disruptions, and costly interruptions. This paper proposes a novel solid-state transformer (SST) control strategy to mitigate FIDVR, enhance motor stability, and improve low-voltage ride-through (LVRT) capability in systems with largescale photovoltaic (PV) integration. The SST employs advanced control techniques to dynamically manage active and reactive power, ensuring voltage stabilization, preventing motor stalling during faults, and maintaining system reliability. Unlike conventional solutions such as STATCOMs or SVCs, the SST integrates seamlessly with PV systems, offering superior fault mitigation and performance in renewable energy integration. Furthermore, the SST approach adheres to LVRT grid codes, ensuring compliance with voltage stability standards during fault events. MATLAB/Simulink simulations in a realistic gridconnected PV system validate the proposed approach, demonstrating its effectiveness in stabilizing voltage, maintaining critical motor operation, and addressing FIDVR. The results highlight significant improvements in system reliability, reduced downtime, and enhanced adaptability to increasing renewable penetration, establishing the SST as a transformative solution for modern power systems.

title: Improved Multi-Sensor Fusion by Federated Invariant Kalman Filtering for Underwater Vehicle State Estimation
authors: Atiya Azmi, Nabil Shaukat, Pablo Otero
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) operating in GPS-denied environments depend on Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs) and Doppler Velocity Logs (DVL) to estimate position, velocity, and orientation. This study presents a novel Federated Invariant Extended Kalman Filter designed to enhance the accuracy of these estimates through effective fusion of IMU and DVL data. Our approach employs a right-invariant error formulation to ensure robustness against navigation-frame transformations and compatibility with body-frame sensor measurements.A federated architecture divides the estimation process into an IMU local filter, which tracks the full state, and a DVL local filter, which focuses on body-frame velocity. A master filter integrates estimates using information-based weighting, with feedback ensuring consistency. Monte Carlo simulations reveal reductions in the position and velocity RMSE compared to centralized and baseline methods. The proposed method advances AUV navigation and facilitates the integration of additional sensors.

title: A D-Band Down-Conversion Mixer Using Transformer-Coupling Cascode Topology in 40-nm CMOS
authors: Jin-Hui Li, Chung-Yao Lu, Yi-Qi Lin, Yu-Hsiang Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: A D-band high-linearity double-balanced down-conversion mixer implemented in 40-nm CMOS technology for 6G applications is presented in this paper. The mixer employs a transformer inserted between the transconductance stage and the switching stage to achieve independent biasing and provide a higher lateral voltage swing for the switching stage, resulting in improved linearity. Additionally, an active load is incorporated to enhance both linearity and conversion gain. For the mixer output, an active balun is utilized to reduce chip area while preserving linearity and achieving better conversion gain. Measurement results show that the conversion gain is -6.8 dB, with a 3 dB bandwidth ranging from 116 GHz to 154 GHz. The local oscillator input signal is -3 dBm, the total power consumption is 15 mW, and the chip area, including pads, is 0.38 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title: Measuring the ROI of AI Implementation in Enterprise Systems: A Managerial Perspective on MIS and Analytics Integration
authors: Urmi Haldar, Md Mohibur Rahman, Md Alamgir Miah, Mukther Uddin, Sharjil Bin Yousuf
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) integration into Management Information Systems (MIS) has emerged as a crucial business strategy at a time when the digital revolution is changing businesses' competitive edge. The study examines the ROI of AI in business divisions, utilizing machine learning algorithms to identify predictive information and key factors influencing financial performance. Key performance factors, including installation cost, revenue before and after AI adoption, cost reduction, and management rating, were analyzed using real-world statistics from 20 businesses across various departments, including marketing, finance, human resources, IT, and operations. To enhance the conventional cost-benefit analysis, the ROI was estimated, and feature significance was measured using supervised learning models, including random forest and linear regression. Research indicates that the use of AI significantly improves operations and revenue, particularly in businesses with marketing and IT divisions, and that ROIs are often more than 300 percent. The features analysis's significance revealed that the department type, implementation cost, and managers' satisfaction with the outcomes were all reliable predictors of return on investment. The study not only calculates the financial cost or benefit of integrating AI, but it also suggests a data-structure-based decision-making process to direct their activities. By incorporating historical performance patterns into proactive investment strategies, machine learning elevates the degree of analysis. The study offers a forward-looking perspective on AI-based corporate transformation via the use of predictive modeling in conjunction with empirical performance data. In conclusion, well-thought-out, objective AI investments in MIS systems will provide significant and quantifiable benefits, ensuring the value of data intelligence in corporate systems.

title: Semantic Memory Synthesis: Hierarchical Knowledge Integration and Temporal Reasoning for Autonomous Agents
authors: Raghavendra Kamat
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Large Language Model (LLM) agents require memory architectures that transcend static data repositories, enabling continuous learning and dynamic adaptation. Current memory systems suffer from structural inflexibility, insufficient temporal reasoning capabilities, and inability to synthesize higher-order insights from experiential data. We present Semantic Memory Synthesis, a novel memory framework built around a multilayered Spatio-Temporal Resonance Graph (STRG) that manages semantically enriched Insight Particles (IPs) and autonomously synthesizes Insight Aggregates (IAs) through a Semantic Oracle Interface (SOI). The system interconnects information via typed Relational Strands and employs Cognitive Refinement processes orchestrated by the Nexus Weaver (NW). Experimental evaluation demonstrates Semantic Memory Synthesis’s superiority over existing approaches, achieving a $34 \%$ improvement in task completion rates for long-horizon planning and a $\mathbf{4 2} \boldsymbol{\%}$ reduction in query latency compared to state-of-the-art baselines, while maintaining enhanced coherence in multi-session dialogues.

title: Spatial Knowledge Graph Creation and Action Prediction with Neuro Symbolic AI
authors: Debamrita Paul, Akash Bhakat, Saikat Panda, Kousik Dasgupta
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Accurate perception and reasoning in driving environments remain critical challenges for autonomous vehicles. Traditional deep learning based perception systems, while powerful at detecting objects, often lack interpretability and fail to generalize in ambiguous or unseen conditions. To address these limitations, we propose a Neuro-Symbolic Spatial Graph architecture that integrates neural perception with symbolic reasoning for context aware scene understanding. The system employs a convolutional vision model to perform object detection, distance estimation from raw driving footage. The extracted spatial information is then structured into a symbolic scene graph, where nodes represent entities such as vehicles, lanes and the camera mounted car. Edges in the graph encode spatial and semantic relations, including distance, lane occupancy and proximity warnings. This hybrid representation enables the system to infer high level contextual insights such as collision risk and optimal maneuver zones. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach supports interpretability, logical reasoning about spatial interactions.

title: Optimizing RIS-Assisted D2D Networks with Energy Constrained Nodes Using Differentiable Projection-Based Approaches
authors: Nikita Egorov, Joel Algera, Omer Waqar
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper investigates sum-rate maximization for reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted device-to-device (D2D) networks with energy constrained nodes. Given the highdimensional and non-convex nature of the underlying optimization problem, obtaining a global optimal solution presents a significant challenge. To this end, we propose two novel differentiable projection-based approaches that provide high-quality sub-optimal solutions while guaranteeing to satisfy the energy harvesting constraints, i.e., achieve zero constraint violation. Numerical results are provided that show superiority of our proposed approaches over the benchmark schemes in achieving higher sum-rates. In particular, it is demonstrated that one of our proposed approaches achieves up to 3.68 times higher sum-rate when compared to the benchmark schemes.

title: Region-Aware and Stacked Ensembles for GNSS Forecasting:Outperforming Transformers, GRUs, and GP
authors: Prantik Roy
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Reliable GNSS forecasting under short histories, strong diurnal cycles, and sensor noise is vital for navigation, construction monitoring, and timing, yet day-ahead planning remains challenging. This paper introduces a lightweight, laptop-friendly ensemble that combines complementary strengths: a GRU to capture recent, fast dynamics; a compact Transformer to model long-range structure and daily periodicity; and a Gaussian Process with periodic+RBF kernels to provide calibrated, decision-ready uncertainty. The system produces 24-hour, minute-cadence forecasts with 15 predictive bands $(\mathbf{1 0 - 9 0 \%})$ and ships with a simple CSV-in/PNG-out interface for immediate use. Residual bootstrapping, integrated with GP variance, improves empirical coverage without operational overhead. Across multi-day back-tests, the ensemble consistently lowers MAE relative to the strongest single model and reduces large-error frequency, offering clearer risk signals for scheduling in mission-critical, ISRO/NASA-adjacent contexts. Reproducibility is ensured via deterministic seeds, portable checkpoints, and a scheduled prediction script that runs in seconds on commodity laptops. Code artifacts include predictions.csv, uncertainty plots, and human-readable configuration files to support explainability and plug-and-play integration with dashboards and APIs.

title: Energy-Efficient Resource Allocation in O-RAN Using Soft Actor-Critic
authors: Tri-Hai Nguyen, Huy T. Nguyen, Vo Nguyen Quoc Bao, Thanh-Dat Le, Luong Vuong Nguyen, O-Joun Lee
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) has recently become a powerful tool for addressing complex optimization problems in mobile networks. Among DRL methods, Soft Actor-Critic (SAC), an off-policy algorithm, stands out due to its sample efficiency and ability to learn stable and resilient policies. This work explores the application of SAC to the resource allocation problem in Open Radio Access Networks (O-RAN) with stringent Quality of Service (QoS) requirements. The performance of SAC is benchmarked against Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO), a strong on-policy DRL algorithm, and a greedy baseline. Experimental results show that while both DRL methods outperform the greedy strategy, SAC consistently achieves faster convergence and better long-term stability compared to PPO, making it highly suitable for dynamic O-RAN environments.

title: Personalized Adaptive Magnification in Gaze-Based Interaction
authors: Florian Eggenkemper, Jana Swerew, Teresa Rehers, Manuel Hanhoff, Constantin A. Rothkopf, Robert Mertens
abstract: Magnification has become the standard approach to tackle accuracy problems in eye-tracking based interaction systems, but suffers many problems itself. Magnification can be inefficient and oftentimes occludes contents in direct proximity to the magnifier, which is especially problematic when dealing with inaccuracies. While some of these problems can be tackled with special magnifying shapes, like hybrid linear-fisheye lenses, most approaches are rather limited one-size-fits-all approaches agnostic to user characteristics and content semantics. This limits the ability of magnification approaches to help users in scenarios where they encounter a below average accuracy or interact with targets that are especially small or crammed together. This paper presents Adaptive Magnification: a novel approach that is personalized to user-specific parameters and also context-aware by utilizing and mapping the screen content's semantic information to choose a magnification factor and size to optimally support interaction. The approach was evaluated against the use of no magnification and the use of hybrid linearfisheye magnification in a user study (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{n}=20$</tex>). Task effectivity was evaluated by measuring the misclick count, while task efficiency wasn't measured as the approach is not focused on speed increase but on functionality and usability improvements. The user study revealed a 95.7% lower misclick count when compared to the use of no magnification and 13.1% fewer misclicks compared to hybrid linear-fisheye magnification.

title: Adaptive Cardiac Pacing using Deep Learning Model
authors: Sindhu Rajendran, Aparna S Jagadeesan, Indulekha Anoop, Nidhi Andhavarapu, Shravani Rangarajan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Cardiac pacemakers are a type of medical device that have been developed to control abnormal cardiac rhythms by administering electrical stimuli. Globally, more than 1.5 million pacemakers are being implanted each year. This highlights the critical role of these devices in modern medical practice. However, available studies have found that traditional pacemaker implants provide unnecessary stimulation in some 30 to 40 percent of patients, thus hastening battery depletion, increasing the frequency of replacement implantation, and raising health risks and costs. These shortcomings highlight the urgency of more complex and flexible pacing agents in the field of cardiovascular medicine and biomedical engineering. Addressing these deficits is necessary to improve patient safety and reduce complications and long-term healthcare spending. A customized pacing paradigm is suggested to overcome these difficulties by means of deep learning. The current approach uses a hybrid ResNet-BiLSTM system as a way to properly label the individual heartbeats by using labeled data of the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Database. The results of the classification support a decision pipeline that takes into consideration heart rate variability, beat classification weights, deviation of resting heart rate, and non-regular RR intervals to assess the need for pacing. Unlike traditional pacemakers, which are activated only once heart rates drop below a set limit, this new method evaluates both the intensity and progression of arrhythmic conditions. As a result, the decisions made about the pace become more accurate, clinically relevant, and specific to a particular patient.

title: Design and Analysis of Compact Antenna Array for Advanced 5G, V2X Wireless Telemetry Satellite Applications
authors: Nabankita Majumder, Arun Raj, Durbadal Mandal
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Modern communication systems require antennas with wide bandwidth, high gain, and compact dimensions to deliver superior performance across the advanced mm Wave 5G frequency spectrum. This study presents a compact antenna design achieved through a three-step process involving strategically placed rectangular slots to enhance current density. The antenna is designed on a Rogers substrate with dimensions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 7. 2 5}$</tex> mm × <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 7. 2 5}$</tex> mm, a thickness of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 6}$</tex> mm, and a patch size of element antenna <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \text{mm} \times 5 \text{mm}$</tex>, respectively. The design accommodates multiple bands, featuring notched responses at approximately 35.32 GHz and 38.70 GHz, with reflection coefficients dropping to -34.8 dB and -22.72 dB, and achieving a peak gain of 8.6 dBi, respectively. The design effectively supports <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> applications within the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$24-40 \text{GHz}$</tex> range, functioning as a wideband antenna with an operational bandwidth spanning 0.9 to 1.6 GHz. Moreover, the antenna facilitates coverage of critical 5G mmWave bands (n259, n260), supports V2X telemetry and satellite applications, and operates throughout terrestrial navigation frequency ranges. The antenna's performance was validated through CST Microwave Studio simulations, confirming its suitability for next-generation communication systems.

title: Analysis of a Thermo-Optic Phase Shifter for Photonic Switching Applications
authors: F. F. de Lima, Í. A. Araújo, M. A. Romero, A. F. Herbster
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents a study of a thermo-optic phase shifter (TOPS) developed using silicon photonic integrated circuit technology, based on the fabrication platform from Applied Nanotools. Designed for use in optical switch schemes targeting programmable photonic circuits, the device was analyzed through numerical simulations with Ansys Lumerical tools. The study covers steady-state and transient behavior, as well as thermal crosstalk between adjacent components. The addition of thermal isolation trenches around the heaters improved energy efficiency and reduced thermal crosstalk by approximately 15%. Integrated into a Mach-Zehnder Interferometer (MZI), the TOPS demonstrated a switching power of 25.30 mW and a rise time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$60.43 \mu s$</tex>.

title: Mitigating LLM Hallucinations in Quranic Content: An Agentic Approach Using Deployable Language Models
authors: Muhammad Fahreza Alghifari, Mira Kartiwi, Muntaha Bin Artalim Zaim, Dini Oktarina Dwi Handayani
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) suffer from hallucinations - fabricating false information with high confidence - which poses critical risks in religious contexts where accuracy is paramount. When applied to Quranic content, these hallucinations can manifest as fabricated verses, incorrect diacritical marks, or misattributed sources, potentially leading to unacceptable distortion of sacred text. This paper addresses LLM hallucinations in Quranic text retrieval through an agentic framework that leverages external knowledge tools rather than relying on potentially flawed model memorization. We present two primary contributions: First, a benchmark quantifying hallucination rates across various LLMs on Quranic verse generation, revealing exact match rates below 1% for most open-source small language models and up to 69% for the best commercial models. Second, the preliminary result of our novel Islamic agentic approach that enables smaller, deployable models to achieve over 95% accuracy through SQL-based retrieval tools, providing a cost-effective, transparent, and locally deployable solution for accurate Islamic text retrieval.

title: Naval Radar Co-Site EMI Mitigation with a Novel Absorber Metamaterial
authors: Mário D. A. Tavares, Roberto B. Di Renna, Maurício Weber, Vinicius N. H. Silva
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: In this study, the reduction of electromagnetic interference (EMI) in naval radar frequencies is analyzed. Thus, the radar cross section (RCS) from antennas used for naval navigation frequencies is modified by an absorber based on periodically arranged metallic square spirals and FSS based ground plane. The EMI mitigation (reduction of susceptibility) with the optimized metasurface was investigated by CST Microwave Studio in a setup that simulates the real operational environment of the sensors installed in a ship. The proposed structure integrates three distinct functionalities as an absorber and spatial filter that block adjacent frequencies and transmit the frequency of 9.41 GHz with a wide bandwidth.
