title: SynthMed: Generating and Detecting Multimodal Deepfakes for Healthcare Communication
authors: Mariano Barone, Francesco Di Serio, Vincenzo Moscato, Marco Postiglione, Giuseppe Riccio, Antonio Romano
abstract: The rapid rise of deep generative models has enabled realistic synthetic media, posing severe risks to healthcare communication where trust and accuracy are essential. Existing deepfake detectors, mostly trained on entertainment-oriented datasets, degrade sharply in medical contexts, where domainspecific terminology and evidence-based discourse are critical. Moreover, post-hoc moderation is often too slow to mitigate the spread of health-related disinformation, underscoring the need for timely, domain-adapted solutions. We address these gaps by (i) curating a multimodal healthcare-oriented corpus of in-the wild and synthetically generated deepfakes, (ii) benchmarking state-of-the-art monomodal detectors for video, audio, and text, and (iii) introducing a late-fusion framework that integrates their predictions via ensemble methods. Our experiments show that late fusion consistently outperforms individual detectors, yielding notable gains in macro-F1 and AUC (+0.159 and +0.131, respectively), particularly under domain-shift and lowresource conditions. These findings demonstrate the importance of multimodal integration for robust detection of health-related deepfakes and contribute toward building trustworthy AI systems to safeguard medical communication. Code and data will be released for transparency and reproducibility: https://github.com/PRAISELab-PicusLab/Deepfake-Detection-in-Healthcare

title: PCGFormer: Power Control for Device-to-Device Communications With Graph Transformer
authors: Chengzhong Wang, Zhiwei Shan, Xinping Yi
abstract: Power control in Device-to-Device networks is still a challenging learn-to-optimize problem, although recent AI-empowered approaches (e.g., PCGNN/GRLinQ/UFPLinQ) have made remarkable progress regarding effectiveness and in-domain generalization. There is still some concern about whether or not purely data-driven approaches are generalizable across domains with diverse interference patterns. To clear such a concern, we propose a powerful data-driven approach, PCGFormer, enabled by a novel graph transformer architecture with fast attention mechanisms, answering the question in the affirmative. By extensive experiments in both strong and weak interference regimes, PCGFormer exhibits excellent sum rate performance comparable to the state-of-the-art model-based/driven methods, e.g., FPLinQ and UFPLinQ, with substantially reduced computational complexity. More impressively, PCGFormer demonstrates excellent cross-domain generalization across diverse interference patterns – scaling law still rocks – breaking through a key bottleneck of small-scale data-driven approaches, e.g, PCGNN. These findings establish PCGFormer as a practical and powerful candidate for large-scale wireless resource allocation.

title: Distributed Prescribed-Time Adaptive Secondary Control for DC Microgrid: A Dynamic Average Consensus Protocol
authors: Xuening Xu, Zhiyong Yu, Haijun Jiang, Chunxia Zhu
abstract: Due to the widespread development of microgrid (MG) systems, this paper mainly focuses on the edge-based prescribed-time adaptive secondary control problem for direct current (DC) MG systems. Firstly, a new voltage regulator is designed by the time-varying scaling function and the dynamic average consensus protocol of multi-agent systems. Meanwhile, in order to avoid the dependence of the algorithm on the global network information, an edge-based adaptive control update rate is proposed. Secondly, by applying the prescribed-time stability theory, it is rigorously proven that the bus voltage can be restored to its desired value under the presented voltage regulator within a prescribed time, and the current is allocated according to the droop coefficient ratio. Finally, the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed algorithm are verified through Matlab/Simulink simulation under different working conditions, and it is compared with the existing asymptotic consensus algorithm to demonstrate the superiority of the algorithm presented in this paper.

title: A Triple-Branch Architecture with Multi-Scale Attention for Spatiotemporal Remote Sensing Fusion
authors: Yawen Bai, Weisheng Li, Yidong Peng, Yusha Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Existing remote sensing spatiotemporal fusion methods often suffer from excessive smoothing at object boundaries, insufficient modeling of global contextual information, and underutilization of temporal change features. To improve these issues, a triple-branch convolutional neural network is proposed, consisting of a dual-stream spatial network and a temporal difference network.Within the spatial branches, a spatiotemporal adaptive modulation (STAM) module is integrated, in which spatial attention is combined with squeeze-and-excitation (SE) channel attention to enhance feature discrimination. In the temporal branch, lightweight depthwise separable convolutions are employed to efficiently refine temporal difference features. Furthermore, a composite loss function is designed to simultaneously optimize pixel-level accuracy, structural fidelity, and edge detail restoration. Experiments on the CIA, LGC, and AHB datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves marked improvements over current models in reconstructing high-frequency edges and low-frequency structures, maintaining global semantic consistency, and suppressing dynamic change noise, with an average increase of 1.46 dB in PSNR and an average decrease of 0.15 in ERGAS.

title: ViRefSAM: Visual Reference-Guided Segment Anything Model for Remote Sensing Segmentation
authors: Hanbo Bi, Yulong Xu, Ya Li, Yongqiang Mao, Boyuan Tong, Chongyang Li, Chunbo Lang, Wenhui Diao, Hongqi Wang, Yingchao Feng, Xian Sun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The Segment Anything Model (SAM), with its prompt-driven paradigm, exhibits strong generalization in generic segmentation tasks. However, applying SAM to remote sensing (RS) images still faces two major challenges. First, manually constructing precise prompts for each image (e.g., points or boxes) is labor-intensive and inefficient, especially in RS scenarios with dense small objects or spatially fragmented distributions. Second, SAM lacks domain adaptability, as it is pre-trained primarily on natural images and struggles to capture RS-specific semantics and spatial characteristics, especially when segmenting novel or unseen classes. To address these issues, inspired by few-shot learning, we propose ViRefSAM, a novel framework that guides SAM utilizing only a few annotated reference images that contain class-specific objects. Without requiring manual prompts, ViRefSAM enables automatic segmentation of class-consistent objects across RS images. Specifically, ViRefSAM introduces two key components while keeping SAM’s original architecture intact: (1) a Visual Contextual Prompt Encoder that extracts class-specific semantic clues from reference images and generates object-aware prompts via contextual interaction with target images; and (2) a Dynamic Target Alignment Adapter, integrated into SAM’s image encoder, which mitigates the domain gap by injecting class-specific semantics into target image features, enabling SAM to dynamically focus on task-relevant regions. Extensive experiments on three few-shot segmentation benchmarks, including iSAID-5i, LoveDA-2i, and COCO-20i, demonstrate that ViRefSAM enables accurate and automatic segmentation of unseen classes by leveraging only a few reference images, and consistently outperforms existing few-shot segmentation methods across diverse datasets.

title: End-to-End Multimodal Broadcast Fusion: 3D MRI–Clinical Network for Volumetric Tumor Delineation and Survival Prediction
authors: Fathia Ghribi, Fayçal Hamdaoui
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Accurate and efficient brain tumor segmentation and survival prediction are crucial tasks in medical image analysis, providing essential information for early diagnosis, treatment planning, and improved clinical decision-making. Motivated by these challenges, we propose a multimodal deep learning framework that integrates 3D MRI scans with tabular clinical data to simultaneously perform brain tumor segmentation and patient survival prediction. The proposed multitask model combines a 3D U-Net and a 3D Vision Transformer (3DViT) for volumetric segmentation, along with a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) branch that processes clinical data for survival estimation. The features extracted from both imaging and tabular modalities are fused through a broadcasting mechanism, enabling effective interaction between spatial and non-spatial representations. The integrated feature space is trained in an end-to-end fashion using a dual-task objective that simultaneously optimizes voxel-wise segmentation and survival prediction. Experimental results on the BraTS 2020 dataset demonstrate that the proposed framework achieved a mean Dice score of 0.78, an IoU of 0.72 for tumor segmentation, and a mean squared error (MSE) of 0.022 with a C-index of 0.88 for survival prediction. These results demonstrate strong segmentation performance and clinically relevant survival predictions.

title: Comparative Performance and Enhancement of Water pH Microwave Sensor
authors: Leonardo O. de Sousa, Lucas A. Sarmento, Mirelli S. da Silva, Samanta M. de Holanda, Jorge A. I. de Araujo, Gabriel G. Machado, Isaac B. T. da Silva
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work presents a proposal of enhancement of pH sensor only by changing the CSRR topology. A comparative analysis is performed using a reference work, where square loop CSRR topology is applied as DGS structure. Circular and octagonal topologies are proposed using the same DGS structure. Different water pH levels were characterized and inserted as input data for the simulations. Resonance shift and attenuation difference were evaluated individually and used as parameter for PRFSE and SE calculations. The results showed an excellent response for the proposed topologies, with a sensitivity parameter greater than 300 times for both topologies in the frequency variation, and a greater sensitivity of up to 50 times for the circular topology when analyzing the amplitude variation. highlighting the performance enhancement.

title: Anomaly Detection in Digital Payment Transactions
authors: Tuyen Nguyen Quoc-Khanh, Huyen Le Thao, Tien Dinh Ba
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: The rapid growth in credit card transaction volume and value has heightened the risk of fraudulent activity, yet public research leveraging real-world transaction data remains scarce. In this work, we propose a novel anomaly detection system based on a variational autoencoder (VAE) augmented with entity embedding layers, specifically designed to address the challenges of high-cardinality categorical variables and mixed-type features in digital payment data. Our system was trained and evaluated on a large-scale Vietnamese credit card transaction dataset comprising over 6.2 million records collected over three months. The preprocessing pipeline systematically compared encoding strategies (ordinal, one-hot, entity embedding, graph-based) and scaling methods to optimize feature representation. In semi-automatic evaluation, the model flagged the top 20 anomalous transactions per week for four weeks, with human reviewers confirming that 25 % of these required further investigation, demonstrating the system's practical utility. The results are presented via a Streamlit-based operator interface, serving as a proof-of-concept for integration into existing manual detection workflows. While the approach shows promise, further work is needed to enhance robustness and scalability for production deployment.

title: Balancing Defence and Operational Stability: Resilience-Oriented Reinforcement Learning for Autonomous Critical Infrastructure Cyber Defence
authors: Minh Tuan Tran, Ryan K L Ko
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Critical infrastructure such as power grids, manufacturing and water treatment plants are increasingly targeted by cyberattacks that can disrupt physical processes and cause service outages. While honeypots are useful for misleading attackers, the frequent use of high-quality deception can consume network and computing resources, slowing legitimate control operations and affecting system stability. This paper proposes a resilience-oriented reward function for reinforcement learning (RL) agents that defend critical infrastructure networks. The reward aims to maintain process uptime and stability while controlling the operational cost of deception. The RL agent assesses current system conditions—such as bandwidth use, computing load, and service health—before selecting a defensive action. This enables more selective use of both high-fidelity and lower-cost honeypots. The method is implemented and trained in a detailed critical infrastructure simulation environment, and compared with a baseline RL agent using a conventional cyber-focused reward. The evaluation covers both normal operations and scenarios where deception approaches introduce operational stress. Results show that while both agents maintained high availability in basic settings, the resilience-oriented model achieved steadier performance under resource constraints, highlighting the trade-offs between strong deception and system stability.

title: Cross-Lingual Transfer for Low-Resource Translation: Fine-Tuning mBART50 on Indonesian to Aid Atayal—Chinese Tasks
authors: Po Cheng Chan, Manh-Quan Bui, Di Tam Luu, Ching-Ting Hsin, Jia Ching Wang
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: In this paper, we address the challenge of lowresource machine translation for the Atayal-Chinese language pair by leveraging Indonesian as a pivot language for cross-lingual transfer. Specifically, we fine-tuned the mBART50 model using Indonesian-Chinese parallel data to adapt the model to a typologically related language. This adapted model was then further fine-tuned on a small set of Atayal-Chinese parallel data. Our experiments demonstrate that this two-stage fine-tuning approach significantly improves translation performance. We achieved a BLEU score of 14.00 in the Atayal-to-Chinese direction and 21.39 in the Chinese-to-Atayal direction, showing the effectiveness of pivot-based transfer for low-resource scenarios.

title: GA-Based Optimization of Visible and Infrared Decision-Level Data Fusion for UAV Detection
authors: Ana Pereira, Afzal Suleman
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a framework for the detection of small non-cooperative Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) using Electro-optical (EO) and Infrared (IR) sensors, in the context of Counter-Unmanned Aerial Systems (C-UAS). First, the hyperparameter tuning procedures for the training of the YOLOv7 object detector using spatial and temporally aligned datasets of EO and IR images of UAVs are described. The optimization is performed using a Genetic Algorithm (GA), and elitism and the use of a reduced number of images are implemented to improve the rate of convergence. Using the optimized EO and IR models, a decision-level data fusion approach for UAV detection is implemented and tested using the spatial and temporally aligned test sets and inference videos. Results show notable improvements in metrics, with maximum precision and recall increases of $10.9 \%$ and $5.1 \%$, respectively, with a minor compromise on frame rate.

title: A Review of Index Systems and Evaluation Methods for the Performance of Typical Mission Systems
authors: Shenghua Xiang, Wenjing Mo, Bowen Song
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: With the continuous evolution of mission requirements and system complexity, establishing a scientific and standardized evaluation framework to guide the design and optimization of typical mission systems has become particularly important. This paper first classifies mainstream methods for constructing indicator systems, including requirement analysisbased methods, systems engineering-based methods, multidisciplinary integration methods, and simulation feedback methods. Subsequently, common performance evaluation methods are summarized, such as the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), fuzzy comprehensive evaluation method, and multi-attribute decisionmaking method. By comparing these methods in terms of applicability, accuracy, and adaptability, this paper reveals the current challenges faced by indicator systems in terms of standardization and dynamic adaptability. Finally, future research directions are proposed, emphasizing the integration of intelligent evaluation algorithms and the construction of mission-oriented indicator systems. This review aims to provide theoretical guidance and technical support for the performance evaluation of modern mission systems.

title: Interaction Method with Virtual Environments for 3D Visualization of Molecules Using Smartwatches and Continuous Gesture Recognition
authors: Eduardo Amorim, Thamer Nascimento, Ana Valdo, Juliana Felix, Luciana Cardoso, Fabrizzio Soares
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Three-dimensional visualization of molecules is essential for understanding chemical concepts, but access to immersive technologies is still limited due to the high cost of specialized hardware. This paper presents the development and evaluation of a low-cost virtual environment for molecule visualization using Google Cardboard, with continuous gesture recognition on smartwatches for interaction. The aim is to provide an interactive and accessible experience for teaching chemistry, allowing users to manipulate molecular models intuitively. Usability and user experience were evaluated using the System Usability Scale (SUS) and the User Experience Questionnaire - Short Version (UEQS). The results indicated high acceptance of the system, with the SUS classified as “Good” and the overall UEQ-S evaluation as “Excellent”, demonstrating that the approach is efficient and well-received by users. The results emphasize that the solution can contribute to the democratization of immersive technologies in education. As next steps, we plan to expand testing to other contexts and disciplines, as well as enhance interaction and explore new features to enrich the learning experience.

title: A Self-Attention-Integrated Deep Learning Approach for Non-Invasive Hemoglobin Estimation from Palm Pallor Video
authors: Sumana Naskar, Dakshina Ranjan Kisku, Mamata Dalui
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Anaemia, a prevalent and often under diagnosed condition, presents a significant global healthcare challenge, requiring efficient and early detection for improved patient outcomes. Although deep learning has enhanced diagnostic capabilities, challenges persist due to variability in patient data, class imbalance, and subtle hematological differences. Artifacts like inconsistent sample quality can further hinder accurate diagnosis. This research tackles these challenges by introducing a novel deep learning approach for anaemia detection that combines the strengths of CNN model and Self-Attention architecture. Our proposed architecture utilizes the unique feature extraction capabilities of these networks and integrates self attention mechanism to dynamically focus on relevant features, improving model interpretability and boosting overall performance. This ensemble approach achieves superior results, outperforming state-of-theart models with remarkable accuracy, sensitivity and specificity metrics. Notably, this work demonstrates better accuracy for haemoglobin prediction ($94.44 \%$ accuracy with $90.91 \%$ recall) showcasing its robustness across the model.

title: Asymmetric Vocal Fold Oscillation Model Inversion via Time-Preference Residual Optimization
authors: Liu Zhenyu, Cao Laiyuan, Yang Xinqi, Zhang Yiting, Jiang Le, Tao Zhi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: To date, numerous physical models have been proposed to investigate vocal fold oscillations during phonation. The parameters of these models are typically obtained through direct measurement. Although this approach offers high accuracy, its applicability is limited by equipment constraints, highlighting the need for more scalable methods. To address this issue, this study employs a parameter estimation method based on an asymmetric vocal fold oscillation model, enabling the direct inference of vocal fold parameters from speech signals for dynamic modeling and source characterization. Meanwhile, we propose a time-preference residual-weighted optimization strategy that assigns monotonically increasing weights to residuals over time, thereby reinforcing phase consistency and amplitude constraints of the steady-state cycles and effectively suppressing large local residuals at model onset. In glottal flow simulations of healthy speech, this strategy reduces RMSE by 0.031 (a 12.8 % decrease). We further validate the method in more complex speech scenarios. The results show robust performance across diverse conditions, which provides a feasible solution for vocal fold dynamic modeling based on speech signals and enabling high-accuracy classification with inverted-parameter features.

title: ConvTimeNet: Hierarchical Fully Convolutional Model for Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cells Degradation Prediction
authors: Dengliang Zhu, Rui Yuan, Yong Lv, Hongan Wu, Wenzhe Sun, Feng Yuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: The superior environmental performance of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) has led to their widespread application in transportation, distributed power generation, and other fields. Accurate degradation prediction of PEMFCs is crucial for reducing costs and enhancing the reliability of equipment operation. However, capturing the degradation details of PEMFCs from measurement data with high-frequency noise is a challenging task. To address this, this paper proposes a hierarchical pure convolution data-driven model, ConvTimeNet, which focuses on local degradation modeling while capturing the multi-scale dependencies between degradation data. Specifically, this study introduces a deformable patch layer to perceive the local patterns of temporal dependence units. The extracted local patterns undergo multi-scale dependency analysis on the designed hierarchical pure convolution blocks. Consequently, both local patterns and multi-scale dependencies are effectively modeled, thereby enabling health status monitoring of PEMFCs. The proposed method is also validated in multi-step forecasting scenarios; for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 4}$</tex>-step horizon, the MAPE is only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 2 0 3 \%}$</tex>.

title: Design and Exploration of a Parameterized Hybrid Routing Architecture for FPGAs
authors: Yuanqi Wang, Yunfei Dai, Xianfeng Cao, Eric Ren, Xifan Tang, Weijun Qin, Tao Li, Lingli Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: As modern FPGAs continue to scale, the routing architecture increasingly dominates both area and delay. However, traditional homogeneous routing architectures struggle to efficiently accommodate spatially varying routing demands, often resulting in imbalanced routing resource utilization across different regions. This inefficiency contributes to increased routing area and critical path delay (CPD). To address this limitation, this paper proposes a hybrid FPGA routing architecture that introduces spatial heterogeneity into interconnect block configurations. The proposed architecture is fully parameterized, allowing different regions of the FPGA fabric to adopt distinct routing topologies tailored to local connectivity requirements. To support this architecture within the Verilog-to-Routing (VTR) toolchain, we extend the architecture description file format and enhance the routing resource graph (RRG) generator to support region-specific interconnect features. Furthermore, to efficiently search the vast parameter space, we employ a parallel Bayesian optimization (BO)-based design space exploration (DSE) framework for automated identification of optimal architecture configurations. Experimental results on the VTR benchmark suite demonstrate that the proposed hybrid routing architecture achieves up to 7.9% reduction in routing area, 2.5% improvement in CPD, and 10.1 % improvement in area-delay product (ADP) compared to the state-of-the-art VIB architecture. Additional analysis also shows a 38.09 % reduction in routing detour, confirming the effectiveness of the hybrid architecture in improving routing compactness and reducing wire overhead.

title: E-Invoicing Implementation in a Malaysian Bank: A Case Study Using SWOT Analysis
authors: Siti ‘Aisyah Binti Abd Rahim, Noor Azura Zakaria, Muhammad Haziq Bin Hayazi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Electronic invoicing (e-invoicing) is a key part of Malaysia’s digital transformation agenda to modernize tax systems, improve operational efficiency, and promote transparency. Although the benefits of e-invoicing are widely recognized, Malaysian banks face challenges such as compliance requirements, system integration, high initial costs, and staff resistance to change. This paper presents a qualitative case study on a Malaysian bank’s experience in implementing e-invoicing, analyzed through SWOT (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats) analysis. Data were collected via interviews with three staff members directly involved in the e-invoicing initiative. Findings show that while e-invoicing improves efficiency and compliance, challenges remain in system integration, training and change management. Practical strategies are suggested to support smoother adoption.

title: Stability Studies in Power Systems with IBR Plants. Part 2: Improvement of the Dot Product Criterion
authors: Christopher E. Reyes-Valencia, Mauricio Calderón-Gómez, Mohamed Badaoui, Daniel Ruiz-Vega
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This paper analyzes the basics of the Dot Product criteria, and proposes some improvements to correctly use it, when analyzing power systems with detailed modeling, including an Inverter Based Renewable energy resource (IBR) plant. It verifies the performance of the dot product criteria in the original IEEE 9-bus, 3-machine test power system, and in the same system, when generator at bus 3 is replaced by an IBR power plant of an equivalent capacity. This has a twofold objective: verifying the effect of an IBR in the stability assessment of electric power systems, and explaining the performance of the dot product with the Equal Area Criterion (EAC). Results show that the IBR power plant affects, indeed, system stability, but it does not interfere with stability assessment, while the point at which dot product detects instability, in which the dynamic trajectory of the system crosses the potential energy boundary surface of the unstable cases, is precisely the same at which the EAC detects instability.

title: Hand Gesture Recognition via GNN Attention-Keypoint Features Fusion and Geometric Encoding
authors: Esha-Tur-Razia, Shaheryar Najam, Ahmad Jalal
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: This paper describes a framework for recognizing real-time Arabic Sign Language (ArSL) gestures, which combines classical computer vision techniques and only uses an RGB input. The framework begins with Gaussian smoothing and normalization of the inputs and face detection and removal, creating regions of interest for gesture recognition. Both hands are segmented through HSV thresholding followed by instance-level separation. Key points of interest are extracted from the hand using ORB, Shi-Tomasi corner detection, and morphological thinning, skeletal endpoints and branch points of the hand provide further structural information. Geometric descriptors are computed and are concatenated into an overall feature vector. A Graph Neural Network (GNN) classifier is applied to model spatial dependencies and Salp Swarm Optimization strategies are applied to improve training overall. During evaluation, this method achieves 69.2% accuracy of gestures from the KARSL-190 dataset and demonstrates that interpretable features, graph-based learning, and gesture recognition that leverage precision provide a not only robust but essential method for any RGB-based approach to accurate gesture recognition.

title: Vehicle Segmentation Using YOLOv8n-seg: Advancements in Real-Time Detection
authors: Safa Teboulbi, Seifeddine Messaoud, Mohamed Ali Hajjaji, Mohamed Atri, Abdellatif Mtibaa
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Accurate object segmentation is a critical component for ensuring safe and reliable operation in autonomous vehicles. This paper explores the application of YOLOv8nseg, a lightweight deep learning model, to the task of realtime vehicle segmentation in dynamic driving environments. Building upon the architectural strengths of previous YOLO versions, YOLOv8n-seg introduces modular improvements aimed at balancing inference speed with segmentation precision. Our proposed framework leverages this architecture to segment five vehicle categories-car, bus, motorcycle, truck, and truck3-with a focus on robustness in complex urban scenarios. The methodology includes training on a curated vehicle re-annotation dataset representative of diverse driving conditions, followed by extensive evaluation of classification accuracy, precision-recall trade-offs, and qualitative segmentation results. The experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv8n-seg achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP${\$}$0.5) of 0.936 across all categories, with particularly strong performance for cars $(0.973)$ and buses $(0.952)$. The model further maintains high stability in training and validation losses, confirming robust convergence and generalization capabilities.

title: Building an Omnidirectional Maze-Solving Robot Using Position Offset and Alignment Angle Control with Mecanum Kinematics
authors: Arut Saengcharoenwanakul, Watchara Thitayanuwat, Puthyrom Tep
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Unlike the conventional differential drive method, which struggles to maintain both position and orientation at the same time, this study surveyed an omnidirectional movement system based on Mecanum kinematics to enhance navigation accuracy and adaptability. This research aims to build an autonomous maze-solving robot that utilizes position offset from the walls and alignment angle as key control factors. The robot is developed with ultrasonic sensors to measure perpendicular distance from the wall to itself and calculate alignment, allowing an adjustment of velocity and movement direction accordingly. A wall-following algorithm navigation and curvature-based turning enable the robot to efficiently explore maze environments. Experimental results demonstrate that the robot is able to maintain position during straight-line movement, execute smooth turns based on real-time position offset calculations, and successfully navigate both orthogonal and curvilinear mazes. The finding suggests that integrating omnidirectional control with position offset and wall alignment-based navigation can improve maze-solving efficiency and may have applications in certain robotic exploration tasks.

title: Crop Growth Stage Identification and Mapping using Time Series Multispectral Data
authors: Pavan Kumar Meka, Radhesyam Vaddi, Yesu Raju Parusu, Raja Sravan Kumar Kovvali
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Asian countries exhibit an extensive range of crop biodiversity due to varying climates and agricultural practices. This situation can make it challenging to develop automated mapping systems that accurately classify numerous crop types. To prevent these complexities, an automated method such as dynamic time warping with time series multispectral data is used for crop Growth identification and mapping. This paper presents a dynamic method for the identification of crop growth stages and their patterns for four years (2019-2022) in the Kanigiri region of Prakasam district, India, with the help of Sentinel-2 Time series multispectral data and Dynamic method of time Warping. The tools used for this project are GEE, and QGIS for downloading remote sensing images and preprocessing respectively. The dataset mainly contains a series of 12 TIFF files for each year, taken from Sentinel-2 satellite data, and a reference CSV file containing crucial reference & ground data, including longitude, latitude, crop type, and crop duration. The TWDTW technique used in this project is to find the best similarity alignment between the two-time series data and also to align and compare NDVI time series, which enables the identification of particular crop growth patterns and their temporal evolution. The resulting crop type maps provide important insights into the dynamics of agricultural land use in the study area. This approach demonstrates the standards of remote sensing and time-series analysis to automate the different crop type classification, mapping and monitor landuse changes for multiple years.

title: Low Profile Antenna Flexible Meander Line Antenna Array for Wearable Technology Applications
authors: Arthur Mendes da Silva, Elison Wediley dos Reis Silva, Humberto Dionisio de Andrade, Caiky Breno Santiago Chaves, Pedro Arthur Freitas da Silva, Carlos Albert Maia Filgueira
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents the design, fabrication, and experimental validation of a low-profile meander line antenna array operating in the Industrial, Scientific, and Medical (ISM) band for Wireless Body Area Network (WBAN) applications. Built on a flexible substrate, the objective was to develop a compact, efficient, and safe device for on-body use. The performance analysis included the reflection coefficient (S11), gain, radiation pattern, and Specific Absorption Rate (SAR). The experimental results confirmed the remarkable stability of its electromagnetic parameters under mechanical deformation, as evidenced by good impedance matching and minimal gain variations. The SAR analysis demonstrated that the power absorption levels are significantly below the limits established by the International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection (ICNIRP), ensuring full compliance with safety standards. The proposed array is concluded to be a technically viable, safe, and effective solution, validating its potential for integration into wearable health monitoring systems.

title: Impact Analysis of Zero-Sum False Data Injection Attacks on Peer-to-Peer Energy Trading
authors: V.V.N Prasad Thota, Kiran Teeparthi, Sri Phani Krishna Karri
abstract: Peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading frameworks are mostly implemented for decentralized energy trading among participants in a residential community. While economically effective, these platforms are susceptible to cyber-physical threats such as false data injection attacks (FDIAs). This paper proposes a novel class of zero-sum FDIAs especially designed to disrupt supply-demand ratio-based P2P energy trading markets without modifying the daily net energy consumption of individual prosumers. The objective of these attacks is to economically alter the local electricity market, decreasing the profitability of legitimate energy trading and undermining trust in the system. By injecting tactically crafted false demand data during the P2P trading period, the attacker exploits the supply-demand balance within the community, thereby impacting internal selling and buying prices to shift market outcomes. FDIAs are simulated at various attack percentages of targeted prosumers, analyzing both operational and economic effects at both the community and prosumer levels. Results indicate that even low-intensity FDIAs affecting a large portion of prosumers can significantly degrade prosumer utility and alter market prices while remaining stealthy. The results highlight the vulnerability of P2P energy trading frameworks to undetectable injections, reinforcing the need for robust anomaly detection and attack mitigation techniques in P2P energy trading systems.

title: Monitoring and Localization of Hole Defects in Plate Structures Using the Inverse Finite Element Method
authors: Xiao Xiao, Jianping Xuan, Tielin Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: The inverse finite element method (iFEM), owing to its unique advantages in structural health monitoring and defect identification, has received extensive attention and application in recent years. However, the monitoring of defects in plate structures with multiple holes or multiple types of holes remains insufficiently investigated. In this study, a novel mixed interpolation inverse element is introduced within the iFEM framework to achieve the monitoring and localization of multiple hole defects in plate structures. The effectiveness and applicability of the proposed method are validated through case studies involving cantilever plates with multiple hole defects. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach exhibits promising application prospects in monitoring hole defects in plate structures and provides new insights for the further development of iFEM in the field of structural health monitoring.

title: Many-Objective Distance Optimization under Polygonal Constraints: An Evolutionary and Swarm Intelligence Perspective
authors: Aishwarya Kayal, Sourab Mandal, Kakali Datta, Paramartha Dutta
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Many-objective optimization problems become increasingly difficult a st he n umber of o bjectives g rows, making it challenging to achieve both convergence and diversity. This paper addresses the task of selecting k points within a polygonal domain and maximizing all pairwise distances. The exponential increase in objectives with larger k makes this formulation computationally demanding, with applications in sensor placement, facility location, and wireless network deployment. To address this challenge, we apply two state-of-the-art metaheuristics: the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm III (NSGA-III), representing evolutionary optimization, and Multi-Objective Particle Swarm Optimization (MOPSO), representing swarm intelligence. Both algorithms were tested on convex and concave polygon-constrained domains and evaluated using hypervolume, spread, and convergence metrics. Results show that MOPSO achieves superior convergence and diversity of Pareto fronts, while NSGA-III provides competitive performance with reduced runtime, making it effective for time-sensitive applications. These findings highlight the suitability of multi-objective metaheuristics for solving many-objective geometric optimization problems under spatial constraints.

title: Application of OCR and NLP Technology in Text Summary and Vietnamese Handwriting Recognition
authors: Chau Ly Thi Huyen, Thanh Tran Cong, Duc Vo Chi, Tran Van Kha
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Nowadays, in an era where information is abundant, processing and using information effectively has become one of the indispensable skills for users. In addition, having to search and classify important information yourself can lead to missing key ideas or focusing too much on unnecessary details. Not only that, analyzing, summarizing, and preparing documents often requires a lot of time and effort. At the same time, with the strong development of artificial intelligence AI, more and more studies focus on applying AI to analyze and summarize documents. In particular, optical character recognition (OCR) and natural language processing (NLP) are considered two pioneering technologies, playing an important role in extracting data and processing information effectively. Therefore, the research team decided to combine these two technologies into text summarization and Vietnamese handwriting recognition. In particular, the combination of OCR and NLP not only opens up great potential in education but is also expected to change the way information is accessed and processed in today's strong digital age.

title: Analytical Extraction of Thermal Resistance in Power Semiconductors Using Structural Function Derivatives and Series Resistance Modeling
authors: Kwangsun Lee, Hojoon Lee, Jihyun Lee, Hyunchul Sagong
abstract: Junction-to-case thermal resistance (R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">thJC</sub>) is a critical parameter for assessing the reliability and thermal performance of power semiconductor devices. Conventional JEDEC-based extraction relies on detecting the divergence of thermal capacitance curves measured with and without grease, but this criterion is highly sensitive to interface variability and capacitance-delta noise, often leading to inconsistent or overestimated R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">thJC</sub> values. To address these limitations, we present an analytical extraction method that applies derivative and curvature analyses to the structural function, enabling clear identification of thermal boundaries and quantitative separation of chip-, die attach-, and lead frame-level thermal resistances. A series-resistance model is used to validate internal consistency by reconstructing the total R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">thJC</sub> from the extracted layer components. Experiments on silicon (Si) and silicon carbide (SiC) power devices confirm the method’s reproducibility and reveal material-dependent thermal behavior. In particular, the SiC chip exhibits intrinsically lower thermal resistance than Si, while the dominant contribution to total R<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">thJC</sub> originates from the lead-frame region—indicating that package-level optimization, rather than chip-level modification, offers the most effective path to reducing overall thermal resistance. The proposed method provides a grease-insensitive and analytically defined, physically grounded framework for thermal characterization, offering improved robustness and internal consistency, and design insight for next-generation power semiconductor packages.

title: Joint Representation Learning and Clustering for IoT Network Anomaly Detection
authors: Huu Noi Nguyen, Pavel Obukhov, Nguyen Ngoc Tran
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Anomaly detection is a crucial task for ensuring the security and reliability of Internet of Things (IoT) systems, where massive volumes of heterogeneous, high-dimensional, and noisy data are continuously generated. Existing methods often struggle with scalability, limited labeled data, and ineffective latent representations. To address these challenges, we propose a Joint Clustering-based Autoencoder (JCAE) framework that integrates deep embedded clustering with autoencoder-based representation learning in a joint optimization process. Unlike conventional approaches that separate feature extraction and clustering, JCAE simultaneously optimizes reconstruction and clustering objectives, leading to more discriminative latent representations. The learned encoder is further combined with multiple anomaly detectors to identify anomalous behaviors in IoT traffic. We conduct extensive experiments on five widely used IoT datasets (N-BaIoT, Edge-IIoT, CIC-Ton-IoT, IoT-23, and IoT-NID). Results demonstrate that JCAE consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models in terms of detection accuracy, false alarm rate, and missed detection rate, while maintaining feasible execution time. These findings highlight JCAE as a robust and scalable solution for IoT anomaly detection.

title: Fast Jacobian Evaluation for Islanded Microgrid Load Flow Using Compact Matrix Operations for Composite Load Models
authors: Rasmita Muduli, Debapriya Das
abstract: This paper presents a simplified technique for evaluating the Jacobian matrix for islanded microgrid load flow using compact matrix operations for composite load models. In conventional load flow algorithms, the Jacobian matrix is derived from nonlinear trigonometric power flow equations, which vary significantly between grid-connected and islanded operational modes. With the increase in size and complexity of such networks, the computational complexities of the traditional Jacobian evaluation increase, which leads to an increase in load flow computational time. The proposed approach streamlines the Jacobian computation process by employing matrix-based operations that reduce computational steps while maintaining accuracy. This method applies to grid-connected and islanded configurations and incorporates a frequency-dependent exponential load model to enhance realism. The effectiveness and scalability of the technique are validated through simulations on a modified 10-bus system and standard 33-bus, 38-bus, 69-bus, 118-bus, and 136-bus microgrids under both modes of operation.

title: Frequency Analysis of Hybrid (AC-DC) Corona Discharge Emissions in a Rod-Plane Arrangement
authors: Jorge Miguel Martinez Ramos, Roberto Linares y Miranda, Fermín Pascual Espino Cortés
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This work proposes a methodology for studying the behavior of corona discharge currents using a laboratory scale hybrid AC-DC rod-plane experimental arrangement operating at reduced voltage levels. This methodology enables emulation of surface electric field gradients encountered on high voltage conductors without applying high voltage. A rod-plane system was designed and constructed to measure conducted emissions via a shunt resistor and radiated emissions in the frequency range of 0.1 to 1,000 MHz.

title: Tuning Method of A Current Controller Through Pole Placement and Equivalent Impedance
authors: Ronaldo Ribeiro da Costa Neto, Jean Filipe Santana de Melo, Camila Seibel Gerhke
abstract: This work proposes a practical tuning method for the Proportional–Integral (PI) current controller in three-phase grid-connected inverters, based on pole placement using the system's equivalent impedance. The approach simplifies the controller design by linking dynamic specifications, such as the damping factor and natural frequency, to the pole locations, thereby avoiding complex techniques such as root locus analysis and Linear Quadratic Regulators (LQR). The study focuses on the application of Grid-Following (GFL) and Grid-Forming (GFM) control strategies, comparing the performance of the PI controller in these two architectures under strong and weak grid conditions, with X/R ratios of 10 and 3, respectively. Simulations carried out in Matlab/Simulink demonstrated robust control performance, ensuring stable and high-quality current injection even under load variations and different grid characteristics. This research emphasizes the importance of grid impedance in controller tuning and suggests future work involving more realistic DCLink modeling and the adoption of advanced control schemes.

title: Prescribed Performance Event-Triggered Control for Nonlinear Multi-Quadrotor Slung-Load Transportation
authors: Xinyu Chen, Yunsheng Fan, Guofeng Wang, Dongdong Mu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This paper presents an event-triggered control strategy that integrates a relative threshold mechanism with prescribed performance constraints for multi-quadrotor slung-load transportation systems. The proposed approach addresses the challenges posed by strong nonlinearities and limited onboard computational resources. A dynamic model that explicitly considers load geometry and cable tension constraints for a multi-quadrotor slung-load transportation system is obtained through the application of the Udwadia-Kalaba equation. This model effectively captures the coupled nonlinear dynamics between the slung-load and the quadrotors during transportation maneuvers. Based on consensus theory, a cooperative control architecture is designed for the multi-quadrotor formation. Leveraging an adaptive backstepping control framework, a prescribed performance function is implemented to map the tracking error into a constrained domain. This mapped error signal is further integrated into a relative threshold event-triggered mechanism that dynamically adjusts the control signal update frequency based on the current error state, thereby reducing computational resource consumption while ensuring precise tracking. Simulation experiments, including complex scenarios like load landing and unloading, were conducted. The results demonstrate that the proposed control method significantly reduces the number of control updates and computational burden, while also improving tracking accuracy and dynamic response.

title: Tracking Cell Phones for 5G mmWave Beam Placement Using Advanced Kalman Filtering
authors: Erfan Jalali, Raman Paranjape
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Achieving more reliable communication necessitates precise beam management, a process often challenged by the dynamic and unpredictable nature of mobile environments. This study proposes an advanced prediction methodology that integrates a beam sweeping technique to acquire user prototype trajectory information. The method leverages received signal strength (RSS) and interference signal to noise ratio (SINR) metrics collected over a defined period to construct a prototype trajectory that reflects the behavior of user equipment (UE) over time. To enhance the accuracy of user movement predictions, two distinct Kalman filter approaches-the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and the Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF) are applied to the prototype trajectory and data from proximity sensors. These filters are used to predict the user’s position and derive an average path representing the movement from one point to another. This comparative analysis enables the evaluation of prediction accuracy and its implications for adaptive beam steering in future. The findings demonstrate the potential of this approach that enable us to dynamically direct beams toward the user, thereby enhancing connectivity and overall network performance in mmWave-based systems. Such advancements are instrumental in addressing the challenges posed by high mobility and intermittent connectivity in nextgeneration wireless communication networks.

title: Volume-Based Lower Bounds to the Capacity of the Gaussian Channel Under Pointwise Additive Input Constraints
authors: Neri Merhav, Shlomo Shamai
abstract: We present a family of relatively simple and unified lower bounds on the capacity of the Gaussian channel under a set of pointwise additive input constraints. Specifically, the admissible channel input vectors x = (x1, . . . , xn) must satisfy k additive cost constraints of the form ∑n i=1 ∅j(xi) ≤ nΓj, j = 1, 2, . . . , k, which are enforced pointwise for every x, rather than merely in expectation. More generally, we also consider cost functions that depend on a sliding window of fixed length m, namely,∑n i=m ϕj (xi, xi−1, . . . , xi−m+1) ≤ nΓj, j = 1, 2, . . . , k, a formulation that naturally accommodates correlation constraints as well as a broad range of other constraints of practical relevance. We propose two classes of lower bounds, derived by two methodologies that both rely on the exact evaluation of the volume exponent associated with the set of input vectors satisfying the given constraints. This evaluation exploits extensions of the method of types to continuous alphabets, the saddle-point method of integration, and basic tools from large deviations theory. The first class of bounds is obtained via the entropy power inequality (EPI), and therefore applies exclusively to continuous-valued inputs. The second class, by contrast, is more general, and it applies to discrete input alphabets as well. It is based on a direct manipulation of mutual information, and it yields stronger and tighter bounds, though at the cost of greater technical complexity. Numerical examples illustrating both types of bounds are provided, and several extensions and refinements are also discussed.

title: Real-Time Object Detection and Multi-Object Tracking in Dynamic Environments
authors: Asha Kurian, Madire Sathwik, Yashodha Chouhan, Tejaswi S, Tina Babu, Rekha R Nair

title: Enhanced FIR Filter Architecture for Fast and Efficient DSP Implementation
authors: B Bharatha, S Hemanth, Manjunath Umesh Kudalagi, Vighnesh Udupi, N Shylashree
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: A high-performance arithmetic architecture is introduced for digital signal processing systems in biomedical, imaging, and embedded domains. The architecture combines Booth’s algorithm, Wallace Tree multiplication, modified carry logic, and a square root carry select adder, with parallel FIR filtering to reduce latency and improve throughput. Static timing analysis shows improvement in worst negative slack from minus $\mathbf{- 0. 7 0 6 ~ n s}$ to $\mathbf{+ 3. 6 5 1 ~ n s}$. Total negative slack was eliminated, and pulse width slack increased by 52.9%. The design achieves up to 40% reduction in computation time, with improved power and area efficiency under timing constraints.
