title: Advanced Mediapipe Enabled Sitting Posture Detection and Correction Model
authors: S Vaibhav Krishna, Biplab Das, R Deepak Kumar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Poor sitting posture over long period has become a major contributor to musculoskeletal disorders, which creates long-term spinal issues due to the rise of remote work, digital learning, and sedentary lifestyle. Through this paper we present “Slouchometer,” a real-time, vision-based posture monitoring system to address this challenge. Our system uses computer vision and AI to extract 33 body landmarks from a standard webcam feed using the MediaPipe model. It measures ergonomic angles between major joints to detect slouching and sends both notifications-visual and aural style notifications to raise awareness for correction in our posture behavior. Slouchometer is a non-intrusive and it is easy to deploy on ordinary computers with webcams or mobile devices, unlike existing intrusive wearable-based solutions. The proposed system also offers a session wise insights through an integrated dashboard. An experiment conducted with over 15 participants resulted in significantly improved user posture awareness and behavior over time, with excellent classification accuracy of 93.2% with less than 0.2 seconds of feedback latency. Through this study we aim to demonstrate how affordable, scalable, AI-powered ergonomic interventions can be designed and deployed to improve overall digital wellness across learning, work, and personal life.

title: 3D Point Cloud Segmentation of LiDAR-Scanned Eucalyptus Trees: a Deep Learning Analysis
authors: Welington G. Rodrigues, Gabriel Vieira, Afonso U. Fonseca, Juliana P. Felix, Deborah S. A. Fernandes, Fabrizzio Soares
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of 3D point clouds is essential for advancing precision forestry, particularly in eucalyptus plantations, where precise tree measurements underpin resource management and yield estimation. This study evaluates some state-of-the-art deep learning architectures, including point-based, voxel-based, and attention-based models, for segmenting LiDARscanned eucalyptus trees. A dataset comprising 55 clonal eucalyptus trees was constructed using an iPhone 12 Pro Max LiDAR sensor, with diameter measurements taken at four key heights. The performance of PointNet, PointNet++, DGCNN, PointMLP, PointNeXt-S, Point Transformer, and Point Voxel Transformer (PVT) was assessed using the mean $\mathrm{mIoU} \%$ metric. Results indicate that transformer-based models achieved superior segmentation accuracy, while classical point-based networks demonstrated competitive performance with lower computational costs. Despite dataset limitations, the models effectively delineated key tree structures, demonstrating their applicability to forestry tasks. This research highlights the potential of deep learning in forestry point cloud analysis and suggests avenues for enhancing segmentation performance through larger datasets and advanced augmentation techniques.

title: Design of All Digital Spiking Neuron Network Based on Izhikevich Model for Handwritten Digit Recognition on 180nm CMOS Process
authors: The-Hung Pham, Van-Nam Cao, Minh-Anh Nguyen, Duc-Hung Le
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper presents a hardware design of a Spiking Neural Network (SNN) based on the Izhikevich neuron model for handwritten digit recognition. The proposed architecture comprises three main layers (including input, hidden, and output), integrated with unsupervised learning through Spike-Timing Dependent Plasticity (STDP) and a Winner-Take-All (WTA) mechanism for effective feature extraction and classification. An Address-Event Representation (AER) bus is employed to optimize spike communication and mitigate connectivity bottlenecks within the network. The MNIST dataset is adopted for network training and performance evaluation. The physical implementation achieves a final layout area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$11.87 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex> with a power consumption of 4.5 W, operating at a maximum frequency of 100 MHz. Experimental evaluation demonstrates recognition accuracy ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 5 \%}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex> across different digit classes for input images of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12 \times 12$</tex> pixels, confirming the effectiveness of the proposed SNN hardware design. Each input image requires 5.6 ms for processing before producing the corresponding network output. This work demonstrates the capability of the SNN to serve as a powerful framework for neuromorphic computing while offering high efficiency in pattern recognition tasks.

title: Terahertz Wave Sensing Technology for Visualizing Hidden Objects
authors: Akinori Taira, Michiya Hayama, Kazuaki Ishioka, Satoshi Yoshima, Ichiro Somada, Akihito Hirai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: When sensing the shape and movement of objects in the near field, light waves and radio waves have been used as the medium so far. Methods using light waves include sensors such as cameras and ToF (Time of Flight) sensors, which can achieve high-resolution sensing. However, light waves are weak to shielding and greatly affected by obstacles, making it difficult to sense hidden objects. On the other hand, radio waves have superior transmission performance compared to light waves, but due to their long wavelength, it is difficult to secure resolution. Therefore, in recent years, terahertz waves have been attracting attention as a sensing medium that combines the features of both light waves and radio waves. Terahertz waves are electromagnetic waves with a frequency located between light waves and radio waves, from 100 GHz to 10 THz. They can sense targets behind obstacles with high accuracy and high resolution, and are particularly expected to be applied in fields related to safety and security, such as body scanners and infrastructure inspections. Also, a feature of the terahertz band is that it can achieve high-precision tomographic imaging using wideband radar signals. In this paper, we describe the configuration of the proposed terahertz wave tomographic imaging system, show the results of principle verification experiments using the 300 GHz band, and discuss high-precision design techniques for 300 GHz band integrated circuits and their application examples.

title: Wear Prediction and Remaining Useful Life Estimation in CNC Milling Using Deep Learning-Based PHM Framework
authors: Sahbi Wannes, Lotfi Chaouech, Jaouher Ben Ali, Eric Bechhoefer, Mohamed Benbouzid
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: The accurate prediction of cutting tool wear and Remaining Useful Life (RUL) is critical to improving the efficiency, reliability, and cost-effectiveness of Computer Numerical Control (CNC) machining operations. Traditional empirical approaches, such as Taylor’s tool life equation, often fail to capture the complex nonlinear relationships between machining parameters, material properties, and tool degradation, particularly under dynamic industrial conditions. To overcome these limitations, this study proposes a data-driven Prognostics and Health Management (PHM) framework for tool wear prediction based on Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network architecture. The proposed model leverages multisensory signals—including vibration, spindle current, and temperature-collected from industrial CNC milling processes conducted under variable cutting conditions and high-speed operations. Comprehensive pre—processing and data normalization techniques are applied to enhance model convergence and predictive accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed stacked BiLSTM model achieves superior performance, with a Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) of 0.0353 and a Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of 0.0307, validating its robustness and suitability for real-world PHM applications. Overall, the developed approach offers an effective and flexible solution for predictive maintenance, enabling optimized tool utilization and reduced unplanned downtime in modern manufacturing environments.

title: An Indoor Positioning Method Based on Distributed Single-Frequency Continuous Wave Radars
authors: Ruoxi Cai, Yue Yu, Lixin Ran
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper proposes an indoor positioning and tracking method based on distributed single-frequency continuous wave radars. Each radar node transmits an ultra-narrowband signal, allowing for convenient frequency-division multiplexing to separate signals from different sources. A dedicated 2D positioning algorithm is designed, which fuses displacement data observed by multiple nodes to achieve accurate positioning. The proposed system does not require synchronization between nodes and is capable of operating in complex indoor environments with occlusions, making it highly suitable for indoor applications. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Design of Reconfigurable Beam Scanning Array Antenna with CNN-Based Machine Learning for mmWave 5G/6G Applications
authors: Truong Khang Nguyen, Huu Quan Do, Thi Thanh Kieu Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper proposes a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> circular patch array antenna integrated with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \times 2$</tex> beamforming matrix (BM) for dynamic beam scanning in millimeter-wave (mmWave) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> applications. The radiation characteristics of the array are reconfigurable in terms of the number of beams, scanning angle, and beam direction, achieved through the incorporation of PIN diodes on each branch of the hybrid couplers. Simulation results demonstrate that the antenna operates in three distinct configurations: (i) all PIN diodes OFF, (ii) two outer PIN diodes OFF, and (iii) two inner PIN diodes OFF. These states enable flexible beamforming and scanning scenarios. The proposed antenna exhibits acceptable reflection coefficients (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left\vert \mathrm{S}_{\text{ij}}\right\vert <$</tex> - 10 dB) and high directivity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 2-6 \text{dB}$</tex>) across all reconfigurable modes for the desired frequency band of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$26.8-27.5 \text{GHz}$</tex>, confirming its suitability for adaptive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G} / \mathbf{6 G}$</tex> mmWave communication systems.

title: Remaining Useful Life Prediction of Circuit Breakers via Comprehensive Condition Assessment
authors: Jingyi Lin, Jianwen Wu, Shangwen Xia, Qihao Hu, Ruang Chen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: The performance of DC circuit breakers is critical to the safety and stability of power systems. At the same time, contact degradation during repeated breaking operations significantly affects their reliability and service life. This paper proposes a remaining useful life (RUL) prediction method for circuit breakers based on comprehensive condition assessment to address the progressive deterioration of contact performance with increasing breaking cycles. A finite element simulation model of the contact system is developed to analyze the arcing erosion characteristics under various breaking conditions. Experimental measurements of the contact surface morphology after breaking operations are conducted to validate the accuracy and reliability of the simulation model. Based on this, a mapping relationship between contact performance degradation and the operational state of the circuit breaker is established by incorporating arc energy. This framework enables predictive analysis of the circuit breaker’s remaining useful life, providing a robust reliability assessment and lifecycle management approach.

title: pFedKD: Personalized Federated Learning meet Knowledge Distillation
authors: Tonghui Liang, Enchang Sun
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Traditional Federated Learning (FL) ensures privacy and security by letting clients jointly learn a model without sharing data with other clients. However, statistical heterogeneity caused each client to have an unsatisfactory personalization ability. To mitigate the problem, we propose pFedKD in this paper, a personalized Federated Learning algorithm with knowledge distillation. During FL training, pFedKD identifies the optimal round with the best local accuracy for each client as the teacher model for knowledge distillation while treating the final round as the student model. Then, the knowledge distillation module extracts desired information for each client’s local model, ensuring the accuracy and efficiency of pFedKD. Finally, our extensive experiments on Cifar10 outperform vanilla FedAvg, FedProx, and other SOTA personalized FL algorithms by at least 1.2%, underscoring the superiority of pFedKD.

title: An approach to improve the selection of Single Nucleotide Polymorphism Associated with Trypanotolerant in cattle
authors: Ozias Bombiri, Pasteur Poda, Tounwendyam Frédéric Ouedraogo
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Genome-Wide Association Study (gwas) is a common approach for exploring relationship between observed phenotypes and genomics variations. The aim of gwas is to discover the genomic regions controlling a given trait. Gwas methods are facing analysis of high-dimensional data in which the number of variables is too large than the number individuals, known as curse of dimensionality. Research is turning to machine-learning approaches as they are well suited for this king of data. In this study, we proposed an approach for selecting significant snps. This approach is a two-stage process, in which, we remove non-informative snps using Kruskal-Wallis test and then select the significant snps based on a predictive model variable importance measure. In the second stage, we used XGBoost algorithm to train and assess a model. We applied this approach to cattle resistance to trypanosomiasis. The results show that our model based on XGBoost is more stable and robust selection of significant snps than previous work.

title: Evaluation and Comparative Study of Performance Metrics for Hydrogen Energy Systems
authors: Hichem Mabrouki, Mohamed Ali Zdiri, Mohsen Ben Ammar, Hsan Hadj Abdallah
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Hydrogen Energy Systems (HES) are growing more and more important for long-term energy security. The addition of Artificial Intelligence (AI) to these systems has been a game-changer, leading to better working efficiency, lower costs, and the ability to grow as needed. This study takes a close look at how AI can be used in hydrogen-based energy systems, focused on key performance indicators like how well the systems convert energy, how cost-effective they are, how environmentally friendly they are, and how well they work together. It looks into the role of AI in all parts of the hydrogen process, from making and storing hydrogen to distributing and using it. There is also a detailed evaluation method shown for finding the benefits of AI-enhanced HES. At the end of the study, the main problems and interesting research directions for future work in this multidisciplinary topic are listed.

title: A Sub-THz Inductive Source Degeneration Harmonic Oscillator Using 0.12-μm GaN HEMT Technology
authors: Jiayou Wang, Yin-Cheng Chang, Da-Chiang Chang, Shawn S. H. Hsu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper presents a sub-THz oscillator based on 0.12-μm GaN HEMT technology on a 50-μm SiC substrate. Different push-push topologies are investigated for 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">nd</sup> harmonic output, and the inductive source degeneration with capacitive gate termination is proposed to realize sufficient negative resistance at the fundamental frequency. In addition, harmonic balance simulations are performed to achieve an optimum design under large signal operation. The 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">nd</sup> harmonic output is extracted at the middle of the tank inductor, and a pair of balanced 3/4 λ transmission lines are employed as RF choke to provide a clean dc supply voltage. The GaN oscillator can operate from 149 to 152.1 GHz with a frequency tuning range of 2.1 %. The peak output power is -7.3 dBm, and the phase noise (PN) is -90.7 and -120.3 dBc/Hz at the 1 and 10 MHz offset, respectively. The proposed design achieves the highest oscillation frequency using 0.12-μm GaN HEMTs, demonstrating PN and FoM among the best compared with the published mm Wave/sub-THz GaN oscillators.

title: Robust Routing in Highly Dynamic FANETs via Predictive Multi-Metric Design
authors: Phuoc Van Dang, Chan Dai Truyen Thai, Nhu Tran Quang, Hien Bich Vo, Khoi Quang Tran
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: High node mobility in Flying Ad-Hoc Networks (FANETs) poses significant challenges to routing stability and efficiency. To address this, the Local Time-Distance-Velocity (Local TDV) protocol was introduced as a predictive routing scheme designed to maintain robust communication in highly dynamic environments. Local TDV integrated a multi-metric cost function that combines link latency with predictive kinematic indicators, including relative velocity, directional alignment, and projected future proximity. A custom MATLAB simulation framework was used to benchmark Local TDV against both an idealized global-state reactive protocol and a static baseline. Results demonstrated that Local TDV improves path stability by nearly 80 % in high-velocity scenarios while avoiding latency penalties, underscoring the effectiveness of predictive, mobility-aware routing for next-generation FANETs.

title: Techno-Economic Analysis of Roof Top Solar Power System Design
authors: Ulfat Zarin, Abdullah Al Nayem, Rubell Sen Goopta, Shubhajit Pal
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: The increasing demand for renewable energy integration in academic institutions, as well as any other sector, makes the potential of rooftop solar photovoltaic (PV) systems a sustainable solution. This paper presents the detailed design and techno-economic analysis of an on-grid solar photovoltaic (PV) system for Chittagong Independent University (CIU), Jamal Khan campus. This design proposes the detailed calculation of the rooftop solar PV system of the CIU campus according to the area provided by the authority. The design incorporates optimised solar panel placement based on rooftop area, local solar irradiance data, and institutional load demand.

title: AgriSure: AI and Blockchain Powered Crop Insurance Platform
authors: Atul Kumar Singh, Rishav Gupta, Kriti Raj, Asghar Hussain, Subhamita Mukherjee
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Crop insurance systems are designed with the aim of reducing financial burden from farmers. Although, in real life claim settlement and other hefty processes trap the farmers in a loop of huge paperwork and wasted time. Farmers have to rely on intermediaries to get updates on their policy status or claim guarantees, which decreases confidence in existing systems. AgriSure is a prototype crop insurance platform that integrates blockchainbased record management with AI-assisted claim verification. Insurance-related transactions are stored on a distributed ledger, while smart contracts are used to execute predefined claim conditions. AI components support verification tasks to reduce manual effort rather than fully automate decisions.By limiting intermediary involvement and partial automation of the workflow, the system seeks to improve traceability and operational efficiency. This paper discuss how the system was designed, implemented and evaluated during prototype development.

title: Detection and Localization of Low-Frequency Oscillations in North Eastern Region of India in the Presence of Inverter Based Resources
authors: Karan Vasudev Katariya, Subhash Kumar, Palash Jyoti Borah, Kishore Kalita, Sajan George, Deepak Reddy Pullaguram, Ashok Kumar Pradhan
abstract: Low-frequency oscillations (LFOs) are a growing concern for power system stability, as they can degrade power quality, damage equipment, and even trigger blackouts. These oscillations, typically in the 0.01–4 Hz range, are becoming more unstable with increasing integration of inverter-based resources (IBRs) and the prevalence of weak grid conditions. This paper analyzes three recent LFO events observed in the North-Eastern Region (NER) grid of India. Using the matrix pencil method for mode identification and the dissipating energy flow method for source localization, the study examines oscillation characteristics, damping behavior, and origin. The results show that IBR control actions, STATCOM reactive-power regulation, generator control responses, and inter-regional tie-line interactions all influence the observed oscillations. A key factor worsening stability is the high impedance of the NER grid. Grid strength assessment, based on short-circuit capacity relative to the ±800 kV HVDC system rating at Biswanath Chariali, gives a ratio of about 2.34 in the Assam system, indicating weak conditions. With around 4.6% solar penetration by installed capacity, the study highlights the need for enhanced monitoring, advanced analytical techniques, and coordinated mitigation strategies to ensure secure operation of future renewable-rich grids.

title: A Knowledge Distillation Approach for Diffusion-Based Generative Skin Lesion Segmentation
authors: Viet-Hoang Doan, Thanh-Danh Nguyen, Tuan-Kiet Ngo, Vinh-Tiep Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Accurate skin lesion segmentation is crucial for early melanoma detection and reliable medical diagnosis. Recently, such generative diffusion-based segmentation models have achieved state-of-the-art performance in this task. However, their large number of parameters hinders the deployment in real-world clinical and mobile settings. A key challenge is how to compress these models while preserving their reliability in diagnosis. To this end, we propose an edge-focused knowledge distillation (EFKD) strategy for the generative diffusion-based skin lesion segmentation, prioritizing contour information transfer from teacher to student. Accordingly, we introduce LiteDermoSegDiff, a lightweight diffusion-based lesion segmentation model that integrates knowledge distillation with boundary-aware supervision. This design ensures that the student network maintains sharp lesion boundaries while significantly reducing model parameters. Extensive experiments on the common ISIC2018 and HAM10000 dermoscopic benchmarks demonstrate that our method achieves up to 88.9% parameter reduction while maintaining competitive segmentation accuracy. These results show that diffusion-based segmentation models can be substantially compressed without compromising boundary awareness, paving the way for efficient and clinically deployable solutions in resource-constrained environments. Code can be found at https://github.com/hoangdv05/EFKD.

title: Remote Sensing-Based Human Detection Using a Custom-Built Coaxial UAV System
authors: Viet Q. Phan, Kien D. Vu, Tuan M. Le, Hieu M. Tran, Bao Q. Vuong, Minh N. T. Nguyen, Son V. T. Dao
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: As drones become increasingly integrated into search and rescue operations, understanding the barriers that impact effectiveness and optimizing humandrone interaction is critical. This research presents the design and implementation of a remote sensing-based human detection system utilizing a custom-built coaxial unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) to support search and rescue (SAR) operations in post-disaster environments. Integrating autonomous flight control, RF signal-based localization, and deep learning-based visual recognition, the system enhances victim detection in complex and constrained terrains. This design offers superior aerodynamic efficiency, enhanced mechanical resilience, and stable flight performance in various environments. A lightweight MobileNet-SSD model is deployed and optimized for edge inference using a Jetson Nano device, enabling low-latency, real-time human detection (40 FPS) from aerial imagery. Specifically, the system is designed to operate from a UAV at an altitude of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0}$</tex> meters, where human subjects typically occupy less than 3 % of the image area, presenting a significant challenge for standard object detectors due to the tiny object size. Experimental validation demonstrates that combining coaxial aerial mobility with intelligent onboard sensing significantly improves situational awareness and victim localization efficiency. The proposed system represents a scalable, reliable, and high-performance aerial solution tailored for modern disaster response operations under extreme environmental and infrastructural constraints.

title: From Data To Grid Stability: A Neural Network Approach For Long-Term EV Energy Demand Prediction
authors: Karumanchi Haribabu, R Sahith, P Venkata Bala Annapurna, Tejesh ReddySingasani, Sriharsha Vikruthi, V S R K Raju Dandu
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The rapid growth of electric vehicle (EV) adoption introduces significant challenges for power grid planning, longterm energy demand forecasting, and charging infrastructure optimization. Conventional forecasting models often achieve high accuracy for short-term predictions but exhibit limited performance in long-term scenarios, while also lacking transparency and data privacy guarantees. To address these challenges, this paper presents a hybrid deep learning framework that integrates Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, temporal attention mechanisms, and federated learning for longterm EV energy demand prediction. The LSTM module captures temporal charging patterns, the attention mechanism enhances interpretability by identifying influential time steps, and federated learning enables collaborative model training across geographically distributed regions without sharing raw data. The proposed framework is evaluated using multi-regional datasets covering Denmark, Greece, Portugal, Slovenia, Europe, and global projections. Experimental results demonstrate a reduction of $22-35 \%$ in long-term mean absolute error compared to conventional LSTM and CNN-RNN models. Furthermore, federated training achieves comparable performance to centralized learning with less than a $3 \%$ accuracy reduction, ensuring privacy preservation. The proposed approach offers a scalable and interpretable solution for EV demand forecasting to support grid stability and infrastructure planning.

title: A Cyclic-Buffered Architecture FPGA Accelerator for ORB Feature Extraction in Stereo Visual SLAM
authors: Te Han, Cheng Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Visual SLAM algorithms impose significant computational burdens, often limiting real-time performance in latency-sensitive autonomous systems. To address these bottlenecks, this paper presents an FPGA-based hardware acceleration scheme specifically designed for the ORB feature extraction frontend of Stereo ORB-SLAM3 by Cyclic Buffered Architecture. The proposed architecture is implemented and validated on the Xilinx KV260 platform and the speed has increased by nearly 1.2 times, demonstrating significant improvements in computational efficiency and system throughput for embedded visual SLAM applications. The code is available at: https://github.com/hankute.

title: Force Feedback-Based Adaptive Sensor Fusion Algorithm for Precision Enhancement in VR-Based Medical Training Systems
authors: Kyung Won Cho, Sungkwan Youm, Kwang-Seong Shin
abstract: Sub-millimeter tracking accuracy is an important requirement for high-fidelity simulation in Virtual Reality (VR)-based medical training systems. Conventional optical tracking systems suffer from significant errors during occlusion, while standalone Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) usage leads to severe drift accumulation. This study proposes an Adaptive Extended Kalman Filter (AEKF)-based sensor fusion algorithm that integrates optical tracking, IMU, and force/torque sensors. The key technical contributions are: (1) a force feedback-based position drift correction mechanism, (2) innovation-based adaptive process noise adjustment, and (3) real-time tissue stiffness estimation through a 21-dimensional state vector. To evaluate the proposed algorithm’s performance, we generated simulation datasets for three standard medical scenarios (laparoscopic suturing, catheter insertion, and needle biopsy) and quantitatively compared five sensor fusion algorithms: (A) optical-only, (B) IMU-only, (C) standard EKF (optical+IMU), (D) Unscented KF (optical+IMU), and (E) proposed method (optical+IMU+force). Simulation-based experiments show that the proposed algorithm achieves an average position tracking error of 0.75mm (±0.19mm) in controlled simulation conditions, representing 95.5% improvement over optical-only (P < 0.05) and 85.4% improvement over standard EKF (p < 0.01) within the simulation environment. Furthermore, it maintains stable performance below 1.2mm even during simulated optical occlusion and achieves computational latency of 2.1ms on the tested hardware platform. This research focuses on algorithmic development and simulation-based validation, and does not include hardware prototype implementation, user studies with medical professionals, or clinical validation. The results demonstrate algorithmic feasibility under idealized simulation conditions rather than validated performance in real clinical environments.

title: Twin-Timescale Traffic Signal Timing Method with Joint Communication Resource Allocation
authors: Tong Wang, Guangxin Yang, Lu Wang, P. Takis Mathiopoulos, Tomoaki Ohtsuki, Min Ouyang
abstract: In multi-intersection traffic signal timing (TST) the use of a uniform cycle time reduces efficiency at low-volume intersections and signal changes which can alter vehicle flows and degrade communication quality. This paper presents a solution to this problem introducing a Twin-Timescale model whereby a multi-intersection TST method is jointly considered with communication resource allocation (CRA) strategies. For each intersection, a Twin-Timescale Reinforcement Learning (RL) algorithm is proposed, by considering both CRA and TST as the Short- and the Long- Timescale models, respectively, and jointly formulating their rewards. Based on the characteristics of this Twin-Timescale model, the reward function is constructed as a singularly perturbed model (SPM), and a state feedback controller that can ensure asymptotic stability is designed. Furthermore, a novel asynchronous time Multi-Agent Coordinated RL algorithm is proposed, which allows each intersection to generate each own joint parameters for its decision strategy which are based upon information obtained from neighboring intersections at asynchronous time. In addition, the use of Federated Learning (FL) in conjunction with the proposed algorithms is investigated, and its advantages in enhancing the resistance to malicious attacks are discussed. Using real traffic data, various performance evaluation results obtained by means of extensive computer simulation experiments have confirmed that the proposed TST-CRA joint optimization approach significantly improves traffic indicators and maintains the quality of the overall communication performance. Through numerical calculations, the state feedback controller coefficients have been determined.

title: Data-driven Microgrid Operation Towards Optimized Battery Energy Storage Lifetime Degradation
authors: Xizhen Xue, Yan Xu
abstract: This paper proposes a new data-driven approach for two-stage operation of a microgrid (MG) towards optimized battery energy storage (BES) lifetime degradation. At the first stage (day-ahead), the BES degradation range over the scheduled day is optimally allocated under day-ahead forecast of random variables. To accurately quantify BES degradation under temperature impact, a convex BES electrothermal-aging model is constructed. Then, a dynamic model constraint coefficient determination method is proposed for optimizing BES lifetime degradation using the historical operation and updated current information. At the second stage (real-time), an approximate dynamic programming method is developed to real-time optimize the MG operation after multiple uncertainties are realized. Considering the temperature dependent constraints of BES, a sequential decomposed value function slope update method is designed for enhanced optimization feasibility, BES aging quantification accuracy, and training efficacy, which can deliver high-quality solutions under uncertainties. Case studies on a MG system demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

authors: N/A

title: YOLD: You Only Look Denseness for Tiny Object Detection in Aerial Images
authors: Guangshuai Gao, Yunqi Shang, Junyu Gao, Haojie Guo, Yan Dong, Chunlei Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Aerial image object detection has gained increasing attention recently. Compared to natural scenes, this task is more challenging due to two main factors: 1) a large number of densely packed tiny objects with blurred appearances that hinder detection accuracy, and 2) non-uniform data distributions that limit detection efficiency. To address these challenges, we present YOLD (You Only Look Denseness), a simple yet efficient detection framework. Specifically, for dense small objects, we propose an end-to-end anchor-free detector guided solely by point supervision, improved from the classical CenterNet, the key difference of which lies in using localization-based distance transform maps instead of heatmaps. To tackle non-uniformly data distribution, a straightforward and effective Dense Region Extraction (DRE) module is designed to identify clustered regions containing challenging instances such as dense tiny objects, thereby improving detection efficiency. Additionally, we design the regression loss by incorporating the Generalized Euclidean Distance (GED) with an adaptive weighted mechanism based on objects’ areas, which improves the detection accuracy of tiny object detection. Finally, extensive experiments are carried out on three publicly available large-scale aerial image object detection datasets, namely VisDrone, UAVDT, and DTOD. The results confirm both the effectiveness of the proposed approach and its superiority over state-of-the-art methods.

title: Inverse Dynamic Games With Process Noise and Unknown Target States: A Linear Estimation Approach
authors: Yao Li, Chengpu Yu, Renshuo Cheng, Fang Deng, Jie Chen
abstract: The inverse dynamic games problem is to model expert demonstrations by identifying the underlying cost functions of multiple agents from observed trajectories of their dynamic game interactions. This article investigates discrete-time, finite-horizon linear-quadratic (LQ) problems where both the state weight matrix and input weight matrix are unknown, with the presence of both process noise and observation noise. In addition, each player’s cost function incorporates a player-specific, unknown linear term with respect to the state. Under this framework, first, sufficient conditions are established for the solvability of the weight matrices. Subsequently, it is proved that the inverse dynamic games problem involving heterogeneous unknown target states is structurally identifiable, unaffected by process noise. Building on the necessary conditions for Nash equilibrium solutions in forward problems, the estimation of the cost function parameters is formulated as a nontrivial solution to a homogeneous linear estimation problem, which can be implemented in a distributed manner. Furthermore, the proposed estimator achieves statistical consistency under the influence of observation noise. The effectiveness is illustrated through a multivehicle spring-coupled dynamic game and an interactive steering control scenario.

title: Integrated Feedback Loop for Ancillary Services Optimization of Economic Dispatch and Automatic Generation Control
authors: Hassan A. Alsobaie
abstract: This study focuses on enhancing Automatic Generation Control (AGC) by integrating ancillary services into economic dispatch optimization, aiding system operators in determining the most efficient bidding strategies to strengthen power system operational effectiveness. The primary objective is to develop an optimization strategy for economic dispatch that accounts for the need for reserve power to support system operators. This approach will modify the traditional economic dispatch model into an integrated system with a feedback control loop that includes crucial ancillary services. Moreover, an analysis will be conducted to contrast the conventional AGC framework with the new integrated model, which provides for ancillary services, presenting their connections and the effects on its functionality. The proposed approach uses MATLAB Simulink to model both classical and integrated AGC configurations, allowing for a comprehensive assessment of their operational dynamics and optimal market price. The anticipated study results highlight the benefits of incorporating an ancillary services system into AGC, which may lead to improved economic efficiency and greater stability in power system management. This holistic approach will yield a crucial understanding for advancing more refined and cost-effective AGC systems.

title: Data Stories and Cognitive Load: A Systematic Review of the Picture Superiority Effect
authors: Mohammed Rakibul Hassan, Madihah Sheikh Abdul Aziz, Raini Hassan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: This study investigates the Picture Superiority Effect (PSE) as a mechanism for enhancing data storytelling and reducing cognitive load. A systematic literature review (SLR) of 16 peer-reviewed studies published between January 2022 and June 2025 was conducted following PRISMA 2020 and CASP guidelines. Results show that visual formats such as infographics, dashboards, and data comics outperform text-only approaches, particularly when tailored to audience expertise and domain context. Relevant, well-integrated visuals improve memory retention, engagement, and comprehension, whereas irrelevant or overly complex visuals can increase cognitive load. The synthesis draws on Dual Coding Theory, Cognitive Load Theory, and Cognitive Semiotics to explain these effects. Despite growing adoption of PSE-based approaches, challenges persist in developing standardized design guidelines, accurately measuring cognitive load, and adapting visuals for diverse audiences. This review consolidates empirical evidence, identifies key research gaps, and offers design recommendations for adaptive, user-centered visual storytelling applicable to domains including education, healthcare, and governance.

title: An EEG Controlled Artificial Hand Based on α Wave
authors: Wenlong Liu, Chong Liu, Zijian Zhao, Lin Hu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: Artificial hands controlled by electroencephalograph (EEG) can bring a lot of help to the disabled. However, most of the EEG sampling equipments are expensive and the system design is always very complicated. All these bring limitations in the application of EEG controlled equipment in practice. This work has designed a low cost EEG controlled artificial hand that the control commands were generated by an α based brain-computer interface (BCI). The BCI designed in this work sampled EEG through an inexpensive wireless EEG device EMOTIV EPOC+. The system can output control commands to grasp and release objects by detecting α wave generated by users. The local controller can not only receive the control commands from BCI but also can control the detail movements of artificial hand based on current feedback, which makes the artificial hand can grasp objects of any shapes. By combining these two parts, the artificial hand can control and grasp things well according to the user's will by EEG. The experiment results show that the success rate of each subject finishing the experiments reached greater than or equal to 90%. This verifies that the artificial hand can be controlled well by the system designed in this work.

title: Design and Implementation of a Keystroke Capture System for Malware Behavior Analysis
authors: Km Meenaskhi, Shashi Saurabh Kumar, Deepshikha Bhargava
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Keyloggers are applications which spy on you and captures all that you type to save it to some hidden files. By intercepting your keystrokes before they are even displayed on your screen, cybercriminals use them to steal passwords, banking information and other sensitive information. Their heightened danger is that they operate silently in the background, and thus they are almost undetected. Nevertheless, keyloggers are not always malicious, they might be used by IT administrators, security researchers, and forensic investigators as a part of legal monitoring of the system, research work, or evidence collection. It is this duality that makes keyloggers interesting to research on their lethal weapons being in the wrong hands but also useful tools in the hands of security agencies that strive to keep us safe. The top overall accuracy was 98% with Random Forest, and 97 and 95 with Decision tree and SVM respectively. Their operations are known to develop better protection against cyber threats.

title: Forecasting of Solar Photovoltaic Power Generation Using Advanced Machine Learning: A Case Study of Saudi Arabia
authors: Saida Makhloufi, Abdelaziz Salah Saidi, Mohamed Mohana, Ashraf Ali Mohammad, F. Bargaan
abstract: The variability of solar and wind resources creates fluctuations in power generation outputs, which might threaten power system security and stability. In this context, developing an accurate prediction tool is essential with a high share of variable renewable energies and in the electricity market. This study applies advanced machine learning (ML) and long short-term memory (LSTM) networks to predict the expected power production of variable renewable generation in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The work considers several forecasting models, such as K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Gradient Boosting-and Long Short-Term Memory. To do so, meteorological variables such as solar irradiation, ambient and cell temperatures, relative humidity, and wind speed, are introduced into models for predicting power outputs. To ensure the fairness of our results, we adopted the parameter as a setting in the baseline models. Performance evaluation of the results was conducted using MSE, RMSE, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, and MAE metrics.

title: Simulation and Experiment of a SMF-NCF-SMF Hetero-Core Fiber Refractive Index Sensor with Discrete Interrogation
authors: Leonardo S. C. de Miranda, Thales H. Castro de Barros, Adler de S. Moura, Joaquim F. Martins-Filho
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents the characterization of a heterocore fiber optic refractive index (RI) sensor for discrete interrogation as a function of wavelength. The structure consists of a single-mode, no-core fiber, single-mode fiber (SNS) configuration, demonstrated both experimentally and through simulations. The sensor, with a no-core fiber section of 14.4 mm, achieved a sensitivity of 226.2 dB/RIU in the RI range of 1.3154 to 1.4237 at 1550 nm.

title: Designing a Testbed for Neural Network Operations on an FPGA Using VHDL
authors: Kwadwo Ansong Annor, Nathan Amanquah, Kojo Nyarku Baidoo, Oracking Amenreynolds
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Neural network inference in embedded systems often faces computational and memory constraints, making hardware acceleration an essential optimization strategy. A primary feature of neural network operations is the use of matrix computations, particularly repeated multiplications and additions. If these repetitive steps can be optimized, the inference time can be shorted. This paper presents the design of an FPGA-based testbed for exploring neural network operations in hardware, with a focus on fixed-point arithmetic, matrix multiplication, and activation functions. The testbed enables detailed examination of data flow and performance characteristics of neural network inference in constrained environments. This work aims to make the implementation details available to support future research and education in embedded machine learning, offering a practical reference for deploying neural networks for real-time, resource-constrained applications. The results from implementing a feedforward deep neural network, initially trained in MATLAB, and implemented on an Artix-7 FPGA using an 8.8 fixed-point format to reflect real-world resource limitations are also provided.

title: Morph-RAG-SAM: Few-Shot Medical Image Segmentation via Hybrid Semantic–Morphological Re-Ranking and Prompt-Guided Refinement
authors: Lan-Phuong Nguyen Ngoc, Thanh-Danh Nguyen, Vinh-Tiep Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Recent few-shot medical image segmentation models have demonstrated remarkable capabilities to generate precise masks given minimal user guidance. However, this reliance on user-provided precise prompts for optimal performance represents a limitation in their applicability to automate high-throughput clinical workflows where manual intervention is impractical. Currently, retrieval-augmented approaches address this process by finding similar examples in a support set. Nonetheless, they face a critical challenge that the best semantic matching is often not the best morphological matching, leading to inaccurate prompt generation and poor segmentation. In this work, we propose Morph-RAG-SAM, a trainingfree retrieval-based framework for few-shot medical image segmentation. Our key contribution is a hybrid re-ranking module fusing a robust semantic similarity metric, i.e., Mahalanobis distance, with a morphological similarity score, i.e., dice coefficient, to select superior support exemplary samples. This exemplar is then used to generate a multi-point positive prompt for an initial coarse mask prediction. Then, this initial mask is analyzed to create a prompt constructed from positive and negative points to guide the final refinement step. We successfully demonstrate our contributions through extensive experiments on three public medical datasets: PH2, HAM10000, and ISIC2018. Our proposal significantly improves upon a strong semantic-only retrieval baseline, achieving an increase in Dice score of 15.64% on PH2, 13.42% on HAM10000, and 16.95% on ISIC2018. Code can be found at https://github.com/danhntd/Morph-RAG-SAM.

title: Intelligent AI-Based Reinforcement-Learning Energy Management System
authors: Rahaf Aljohani, Doaa Alghamdi, Atheer Babeer, Haneen Bawayan
abstract: The increasing variability of renewable generation and rising demand pose significant challenges for multi-micro grid operation. This paper proposes an Adaptive Intelligent Renewable Energy Management System (AIREMS), a hierarchical EMS framework that employs a trigger-based load management strategy implemented via reinforcement learning (RL). When a load peak is detected, the system engages the Adaptive Peak Shaving and Coordination (APSC) algorithm to dynamically adjust load shifting, peak shaving, and energy storage dispatch. In the absence of peak events, AIREMS feeds system data into a reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm to refine forecasts and load profiles. Simulation results demonstrate the superiority of AIREMS in both performance and efficiency, achieving a 30% reduction in total power consumption, improving the system-wide load factor to 0.72, and reducing operating costs and peak demand by 23.8% and 26%, respectively, compared with alternative systems. These results underscore the potential of AIREMS as a scalable and intelligent solution for next-generation energy systems, offering a robust framework for real-time, adaptive, and cost-effective multi-micro grid management.

title: Wind Power Forecasting using Auto-Regressive QRF for Operational Reserve Management
authors: Girraj Raigar, Naveen Kumar Thokala, Swathi Battula, Abheejeet Mohapatra
abstract: With the increasing penetration of Renewable Energy Sources (RESs) into power systems, maintaining the balance between supply and demand has become more challenging due to the inherent variability and uncertainty of these sources. Wind power, in particular, exhibits significantly higher stochasticity and volatility, necessitating reliable forecasting methods for the Independent System Operator (ISO), ensuring supply and demand balance. Traditional point forecasts, such as median-based predictions, are inadequate for capturing the nonstationary and heteroskedastic nature of wind generation. In contrast, quantile forecasts provide upper and lower bounds on expected generation, offering a more robust foundation for operational decision-making. In this work, we propose an Auto-Regressive Quantile Random Forest (ARQRF) regression model for multi-horizon wind power forecasting, covering lead times from day-ahead up to three hours ahead. The model captures temporal dependencies using auto-regressive features, in conjunction with weather-based predictors, to generate quantile-based probabilistic forecasts. These forecasts are intended to assist ISOs in optimal reserve procurement and ramp management. The performance of ARQRF is evaluated using publicly available wind generation data from the California ISO (CAISO) and benchmarked against several state-of-the-art forecasting methods. Results demonstrate that ARQRF delivers superior predictive accuracy while maintaining high computational efficiency.

title: On many-to-one mappings over finite fields
authors: Yanbin Zheng, Yanjin Ding, Meiying Zhang, Pingzhi Yuan, Qiang Wang
abstract: We introduce the definition of m-to-1 mappings between two finite sets, which unifies and generalizes the definitions of 2-to-1 and n-to-1 mappings in recent literature. We also characterize these m-to-1 mappings in terms of the generalized local criterion and thus provide three generic constructions of m-to-1 mappings, which unify and generalize the previous known constructions. Using these constructions, the problem whether xrh(xs) is m-to-1 on the multiplicative group F∗q is converted into that whether an associated polynomial xr1h(x)s1 is m2-to-1 on the order ℓ subgroup Uℓ of F∗q, where m2 = m/(r, s) and ℓ = (q − 1)/s. Furthermore, the m2-to-1 property of xr1h(x)s1 on Uℓ is studied in detail in five different cases. In addition, a recursive construction of m-to-1 mappings from m-to-1 mappings is proposed.

title: Nyx: An Extractive Text Summarization Framework Using TF-ISF and Graph-Based Sentence Ranking
authors: Pulkit Dwivedi, Preet Kamal, Mansi Kajal, Nikita Rattan, Namit Chawla
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: With the continuous rise of digital text everywhere, it has become increasingly difficult to find real and useful information within large volumes of documents. This paper proposes a hybrid extractive summarization model named <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N y x$</tex>. It combines a graph-based ranking module, TextRank, with a neural scoring layer based on a simple single-layer perceptron. The main idea is to let the graph component handle the global structure, how sentences are connected, while the neural component focuses on capturing the semantic importance of each sentence. The two scores are then combined using an adaptive fusion rule that maintains a balanced trade-off between coverage and precision. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that Nyx produces concise yet meaningful and readable summaries. It outperforms or matches several well-known extractive systems in terms of relevance and clarity. Moreover, the method remains computationally lightweight and interpretable, making it suitable for real-world applications such as news summarization, research paper screening, and business content analysis.

title: Syntax-Aware Transformer for Sentiment Analysis of Japanese SNS Text
authors: Sotaro Shiozawa, Akira Kubota
abstract: Japanese SNS sentiment analysis has broad applications in marketing, public opinion surveys, and mental health support. However, because posts are often short, colloquial, and elliptical, they tend to be misclassified. To address this issue, we propose three methods that incorporate syntactic information into a Japanese BERT classifier. Using the GiNZA dependency parser, we extract four types of syntactic features—POS tags, dependency labels, parent position, and tree depth—and encode them via: (1) an embedding-based method that adds syntactic embeddings, (2) a syntactic positional encoding method that applies sinusoidal encodings to positional information, and (3) a hybrid method that combines these two methods. Experiments on the WRIME ver. 2 dataset show that the embedding variant utilizing POS tags and parent position achieves the best performance in 5-class polarity classification, while the hybrid method combining all syntactic features yields the best results in 8-class emotion classification. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first systematic study demonstrating the effectiveness of syntactic integration for Japanese SNS sentiment analysis and identifying optimal combinations of syntactic features.

title: Deep Learning Based Video Conferencing Application with Facial Emotion Detection
authors: Shivam Singh, Jyoti Khandelwal, Akanksha Chaturvedi, Sanjog Arora, Ankur Kumar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: More than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1 0, 0 0 0}$</tex> users worldwide have turned to our chat server platform over the last five years as a reliable way to stay in touch, no matter where they are. A robust server-side system and an easy-to-use client application that runs directly in your web browser are its two primary components. Whether it's a large group discussion or a one-on-one chat, the platform facilitates over 500 meetings every day, so keeping a steady connection is crucial for effective communication. Secure login, meeting scheduling, real-time messaging, screen sharing, session recording, and breakout rooms are just a few of the useful features that our video conferencing tool offers. It can easily handle events with up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1, 0 0 0}$</tex> participants. To keep our users safe, we've added strong privacy protections like end-to-end encryption and two-factor authentication. As more people turn to digital tools for work, learning, and staying in touch, we're proud to offer a secure and reliable platform — one that's expected to keep growing by 20 % in the next two years. At its core, our goal is simple: to make virtual connections easier and more meaningful in today's fast-moving world.

title: DetTrack: Detect Target from Local Region for 3D Single Object Tracking in Point Clouds
authors: Hande Yin, Wei Liu, Jason Gu
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: D single object tracking (3D SOT) is an essential task in computer vision, widely applied in autonomous driving and robotics. Existing Siamese-based and motion-centric methods often require additional parameters and specialized architectures, resulting in high computational demands and failing to fully utilize advancements in 3D object detection. In this paper, we believe that if the search region is sufficiently localized, 3D SOT can be reformulated as a sequential detection problem within these regions. Based on this insight, we propose a novel 3D SOT framework, DetTrack, which comprises two core components: a search region estimator to predict the potential region including tracking target, and a modular 3D detector switcher to integrate pretrained 3D detectors for object localization. Our framework simplifies the tracking pipeline, eliminates the need for specialized 3D SOT models, and significantly reduces computational costs. Furthermore, the 3D detector switcher enables DetTrack to seamlessly integrate various state-of-the-art 3D detectors, making the framework highly adaptable and future-proof. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves performance comparable to state-of-the-art 3D SOT methods on multiple datasets while enabling real-time inference speed.

title: Bankruptcy Risk in Other Transportation Equipment Manufacturing in Ecuador: Analysis with Altman Z1 and Springate
authors: Jorge Luis Garcia Bacuilima, Lourdes Valeria Damián Tepán, Noelia Lucía Barbecho Beltrán
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: In Ecuador, the manufacturing sector plays an important role in the country's economy. Within this area, the manufacture of other types of transportation equipment is a strategic axis for industrial and technological progress, complementing and strengthening the growth of other productive sectors. However, despite its relevance, a lack of accurate and timely financial information has been identified for companies in this sector, leading to inadequate investment decisions, poor analysis and ineffective planning. This study analyzes the financial risk of 35 companies engaged in this activity, using information corresponding to the year 2023, obtained from the Superintendency of Companies, Securities and Insurance. For the analysis, the Z 1 and Springate models were used for this analysis. The results show that 26 % of the companies are at high risk of bankruptcy according to Altman Z1, while 23 % represent a critical risk according to the Springate model. It is concluded that a significant proportion of the sector faces worrying levels of financial fragility and faces important risks, so urgent measures must be taken to avoid the insolvency of these companies.

title: A Maintenance-Based Approach to Increase Equipment Availability in the Plastic Bag Industry
authors: Stephanie A. Montalvan-Moreno, Paula C. Huerta-Mori, Claudia C. Leon-Chavarri, Rafael Chavez-Ugaz
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This study addresses the problem of low equipment availability in plastic manufacturing industries, which limits productivity and efficiency. A technical diagnosis identified critical failure modes in the extrusion screw, bearings, and control panel. Validation through Arena simulation showed a 128.60% increase in MTBF and a 2.07% improvement in availability, while MTTR remained at 59.67 hours. To solve this problem, the research proposes a hybrid maintenance approach that integrates Preventive Maintenance based on optimal intervention intervals calculated using the Weibull distribution, and Predictive Maintenance using a system based on a neural network with persistent memory for temperature data. According to the results, integrating preventive and predictive maintenance reduces unplanned downtimes and improves equipment availability in industrial operations.

title: Investigation of Graphene as a Shielding Material for Space Environments
authors: Abdelrahman M. BaniHani, D. Hill, V. Pan, J. Vohradsky, D. Bennett, D. Bolst, S. Peracchi, M. Povoli, A. Kok, S. Lee, H. Mizuno, T. Nakaji, S. Matsuba, A. Ishikawa, S. Tanaka, M. Muramatsu, D. Sakata, T. Inaniwa, Timothy Squire, Gregory Ryder, David Officer, Gordon Wallace, L. T. Tran, A. B. Rosenfeld
abstract: This work investigates the radiation shielding efficiency of High-Density Polyethylene (HDPE)/Graphene, carbon fibre, and polyethylene materials. The composite HDPE Graphene was studied both as a substitute layer in the ISS wall/Columbus shielding configuration and as an additional layer serving as intravehicular spacesuits for astronauts. The average quality factors (Q) for 12C, 40Ar, and 56Fe ion beams were evaluated using the Silicon-On-Insulator (SOI) Mushroom microdosimeter behind various realistic ISS Columbus wall configurations at the Heavy Ion Medical Accelerator in Chiba (HIMAC), Japan. Moreover, the individual dose equivalent, Hp(10), was calculated for astronaut personal monitoring. The SOI microdosimeter’s response to the monoenergetic ion beams behind these shielding configurations enabled comparison of the shielding efficiencies for the tested materials. The results indicate that the shielding efficiency of HDPE Graphene is similar to that of carbon fibre and Kevlar.

title: An Algebraic Geometry Approach to Viewing Graph Solvability
authors: Federica Arrigoni, Kathlén Kohn, Andrea Fusiello, Tomas Pajdla
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: The concept of viewing graph solvability has gained significant interest in the context of structure-from-motion. A viewing graph is a mathematical structure where nodes are associated with cameras and edges represent the epipolar geometry connecting overlapping views. Solvability studies under which conditions the cameras are uniquely determined by the graph. In this paper we propose a novel framework for analyzing solvability problems based on algebraic geometry, demonstrating its potential in understanding structure-from-motion graphs and proving a conjecture that was previously proposed.

title: In Memoriam of Jeffrey L. Hesler
authors: Thomas W. Crowe, Stephen H. Jones, Jan Stake, Imran Mehdi, Nuria Llombart
