title: Energy-Aware Structured Pruning Strategy for Scalable Federated Learning in IoT Networks
authors: Fazal Muhammad Ali Khan, Omer Waqar, Syed Ali Hassan
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: The rapid growth of the Internet of Things (IoT) has led to a significant increase in connected devices, necessitating efficient and scalable solutions for data processing and analysis. Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising approach that enables collaborative training of machine learning (ML) models while preserving data privacy. However, the iterative nature of FL and the resource-constrained environment of edge devices present challenges in terms of energy efficiency, computational overhead, and communication noise. To address these issues, this work proposes an adaptive structured pruning strategy that dynamically prunes and regrows model filters based on the clients’ local accuracy thresholds. By adapting to client-specific communication conditions, such as channel noise and varying signal-to-noise ratios (SNR), the proposed method ensures robust performance and enhanced energy efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate significant energy savings of up to $30 \%$ and notable model size reductions while maintaining competitive accuracy. These findings validate the efficacy of the approach in optimizing FL for resource-constrained IoT ecosystems.

title: Design and Simulation of a Banana Bunch Grabbing and Transporting Device Based on Unmanned Aerial Vehicle
authors: Guo J., Chen P.Z., Qiu J.G., Liu Z.F., Zhang X.R.
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization has recognized bananas as the fourth-largest food crop in developing countries, with 500 million people worldwide depending on them as a staple food. However, in mountainous and hilly areas where vehicle deployment is challenging, banana transportation from plantations to processing sites mainly relies on manual labor. This transportation method often leads to bruising of the banana fruits, and labor costs are high. Establishing cableways or laying tracks entails significant investment, long construction periods, and low utilization rates. While unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV s) are increasingly used in agricultural production, there is still a lack of practical devices for grabbing and transporting banana bunches with UAVs. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a UAV-based banana bunch grabbing and transporting device, capable of operating in hilly and mountainous banana plantations by relying solely on the UAV platform and its vision system. The design and material selection of the device are discussed, incorporating principles from mechanics, material science, and fluid dynamics to perform relevant calculations. Kinematic simulations were carried out using SolidWorks Motion. Results indicate that the device can grip banana bunches with diameters ranging from 40mm to 172mm, exhibiting smooth movement and uniform speed. Static finite element analysis, conducted using SolidWorks Simulation, demonstrates that the device can stably carry a 30-kg banana bunch even in wind speeds of 20 m/s. Additionally, the paper identifies areas of high stress in the gripping section and proposes optimization solutions. A damage analysis of the gripped banana bunch stalk is also included, showing that the device does not cause destructive damage. Furthermore, modal analysis is conducted to determine the suitable frequency range for the UAV motor. This paper offers potential solutions for UAV -based banana bunch transportation and serves as a reference for the UAV transportation of other fruits, timber, or goods.

title: Regional Distributed Photovoltaic Power Forecasting Method Based on Two-stage Clustering and Hierarchical Graph Network Modeling
authors: Zinuo Su, Zhao Zhen, Fei Wang, Fei Xu, Xizai Yang, Yu Zhu, Le Yang
abstract: Accurate regional distributed Photovoltaic (PV) power forecasting provides data support for power grid management and optimal operation. Existing graph structures are unable to effectively mine spatio-temporal correlation information or lose a lot of valid information in the modeling process. For this reason, this paper proposes an ultra-short-term regional distributed PV power forecasting method based on two stage clustering and Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Neural network. First, a two-stage clustering method is used to optimize the clustering results on the basis of the existing K-means clustering method to maximize the use of PV power data to mine the deep similarity between PV power stations; then, based on the optimal clustering results, sub-graph and global graph are constructed by taking into account the hierarchical structure of distributed PV systems; finally, a Hierarchical Graph Convolutional Neural network forecasting model is constructed to further mine deep spatio-temporal correlation between PV power stations to achieve ultra-short-term regional distributed PV power forecasting. The superiority of the proposed method is verified by a real dataset in China.

title: Beamforming and Beam Steering Optimization for a Yagi-Uda Three-Antenna Array by Genetic Algorithm
authors: Renan G. M. dos Santos, Lauro R. G. S. Lourenço Novo, Marcos T. de Melo, Flávio de P. Lopes, Bruno G. M. de Oliveira, Elias M. F. de Oliveira
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This study focuses on optimizing of an antenna array composed of three Yagi-Uda antennas for 5G service customization using the Genetic Algorithm (GA). The proposed array's electromagnetic excitation parameters (amplitudes and phases) were iteratively adjusted by coupling the GA with Ansys High Frequency Structure Simulator (HFSS) to minimize a defined objective function. A population of 20 individuals and 200 iterations resulted in 4,000 simulations per objective direction. Convergence analysis considering four beam steering scenarios (0°, 30°, 60°, and 90°) demonstrated the GA's robust capability, achieving significant objective function error reductions ranging from 71% to 81%, with a lower final error of 0.78 for the 0° case. The optimized radiation patterns confirmed effective beam steering and beam forming. This work validates the GA as an efficient tool for complex antenna array optimization, providing reliable setups for practical implementation and contributing to advancements in 5G connectivity and mobile service quality.

title: Measurements of Dielectric Properties of Biological Phantoms and Tissues for Biomedical Imaging
authors: Abid Raza, Ghulam Nabi, Sunble Yousaf, Muhmmad Yasir, Maryam Liaqat, M. T. de Melo
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Microwave imaging stands as a promising early cancer detection technique which uses the dielectric tissue contrast between cancerous and normal tissue types with nonionising radiation. The research develops normal breast phantom and tumour constructs from agarose-NaCl-corn oil composites to fulfil the important requirement of realistic phantom development. In this work, dielectric properties of the phantoms were measured through a Keysight N9952A vector network analyser alongside the Keysight N1501 open-ended coaxial probe over the 2-3 GHz frequency range. At 2.5 GHz, clear numerical differences in electromagnetic properties were observed between the phantom, the phantom with tumour content, and the tumour tissue, highlighting their potential for cancer detection. The conductivity of the phantom is 0.45 S/m, while the phantom with tumour content shows a significant increase to about 2.6 S/m. The tumour tissue exhibits the highest conductivity, reaching 3.3 S/m. Similarly, permittivity values follow a comparable trend: the phantom registers 5, the phantom with tumour content 35, and the tumour tissue 55. These substantial differences - up to 7 times higher conductivity and over 10 times higher permittivity in tumour tissue compared to normal phantom - demonstrate a strong dielectric contrast. This quantifiable distinction supports the application of microwave imaging and electromagnetic-based diagnostic techniques for reliable, non-invasive cancer detection and characterisation.

title: Multi-part Innovative Tariff Framework for the Renewables for ambitious Net Zero targets
authors: Sushil Kumar Soonee, Amit Kumar Singh Parihar, Ghanshyam Thakkar, Himanshu Mishra
abstract: This paper aims to explore the potential of a multipart tariff framework to address the rising risk of curtailment in renewable energy (RE) systems, amidst growing integration challenges due to increasing RE capacity. The paper draws the lessons from the historical transition of single-part to multi part tariffs in thermal and hydro generation, we highlight how such frameworks have facilitated greater adoption and eased financing challenges for conventional power plants. We propose a multi-part tariff model for renewables, incorporating the capacity value concept, to enhance grid reliability, ensure revenue stability, and incentivize RE contributions during critical demand periods. This approach aims to align economic incentives with grid needs, reducing curtailment risks and supporting India’s ambitious RE targets.

title: Physics-Guided Exposure Parameter Estimation for Image Metadata Verification
authors: Sharmilee Rajkumar Rajan, Ming-Ching Chang, Pradeep K. Atrey
abstract: The rapid rise of AI-generated and edited images has made it increasingly difficult to distinguish authentic photographs from manipulated content. Digital image forensics addresses this challenge by detecting inconsistencies between image content and metadata. Among various forensic cues, the exposure triangle parameters namely ISO Speed Ratings (ISO), aperture (F-number), and shutter speed offer a physically grounded reference for verifying authenticity. We propose a physics-guided latent triad regression framework that predicts these parameters directly from image pixel content while enforcing exposure value (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E V$</tex>) consistency through the exposure equation. Our model predicts <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I S O, F$</tex>-number, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E V$</tex> in log space, deriving shutter speed to ensure physically coherent and non-redundant predictions. Trained on RAISE-2K, it achieves strong correlations with ground-truth parameters (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2} \approx 0.32$</tex> to 0.35) and high <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{E V}$</tex> consistency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}=0.69$</tex>). By embedding physical exposure laws into learning, the framework produces interpretable, exposure-consistent predictions that enhance metadata verification, camera provenance analysis, and image authenticity assessment.

title: Synthetic Point Cloud Generation for Autonomous Driving: A Survey and Taxonomy
authors: Aitor Iglesias, Nerea Aranjuelo, Ignacio Arganda-Carreras, Marcos Nieto
abstract: Autonomous driving is advancing rapidly, fueled by improvements in sensor technology and artificial intelligence (AI). Lidar-captured point clouds are crucial for these systems, offering precise spatial data and detailed environmental representations. Data are essential for developing and validating robust AI-based systems. However, obtaining real-world data is costly, and capturing specific scenarios, especially dangerous or rare cases, is impractical. As a result, synthetic point cloud generation is emerging as a promising alternative. Despite increasing interest and techniques, there is no comprehensive survey on synthetic point cloud generation for autonomous driving. This article addresses this gap by exploring the challenges in generating synthetic point clouds, outlining the methods used, and cataloging available datasets. This survey aims to provide a foundational understanding of the state of the art in synthetic point cloud generation, promoting further research in this critical area of autonomous driving technology.

title: Multi-Scale Transformer–CNN Fusion with Metric Learning for Medicinal Plant Identification
authors: Nagagopiraju Vullam, Jayadeep Pakala, Dara Vikram, Vunnava Dinesh Babu, Naladi Ram Babu, P.Chandra Sekhar Reddy
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Accurate identification of medicinal plants is essential for botanical research, biodiversity conservation, and drug discovery. Traditional manual identification is slow, errorprone, and dependent on expert knowledge, motivating the need for automated and reliable image-based classification systems. This paper proposes a Multi-Scale Transformer-CNN Fusion framework with Metric Learning for robust medicinal plant identification using the publicly available Kaggle dataset comprising twenty plant species. The model integrates a Swin Transformer to extract global contextual representations and an EfficientNetV2 branch to capture fine-grained local texture information. The outputs from both branches are fused through an attention-based module (CBAM) to emphasize discriminative regions. To enhance class separability, an ArcFace metric-learning layer is incorporated during training. Dimensionality reduction through Principal Component Analysis is applied to reduce redundancy and improve convergence. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the proposed hybrid model achieved higher accuracy and F1-score than conventional CNNs and transfer-learning approaches, confirming its effectiveness in identifying visually similar medicinal plant species.

title: High-Efficiency Tunable Terahertz Metamaterial Absorber Based on Dumbbell-Shaped Vanadium Dioxide Resonator
authors: Ashish Kumar Sarangi, Sraddhanjali Mohapatra, Sudhansu Sekhar Singh, Bikash Ratan Sahoo, Dinesh Kumar Dash
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This paper introduces an innovative design for a high-efficiency metamaterial absorber in the terahertz (THz) frequency band, which employs dumbbell-shaped Vanadium Dioxide (VO2) resonators. The absorber is composed of an array of VO2 resonators, arranged in a periodic pattern on a 50 μ m thick silicon substrate, which is then backed by a thin gold ground plane of 0.2 μ m, Vanadium Dioxide is a classic phase-change material and was chosen for its natural ability to provide a mechanism for actively tunable absorption of the absorber's overall electromagnetic response. However, this study focuses on the device operating in the metallic phase. The underlying electromagnetic characteristics of the design were numerically investigated using the Finite Element Method (FEM) in ANSYS HFSS. Sharply peaked resonances were observed that exhibit a high absorption efficiency of 97.6% for unpolarized light at a resonant frequency of 440 GHz. This strong absorption occurs due to the excitation of coupled electric and magnetic resonances within the VO2 resonator, which results in large ohmic losses within each resonator. The design shows considerable promise as a highly compact, high-performance, and dynamically controllable THz absorption device suitable for different applications.

title: Multivariate Graphical Analysis of Transformer FRA Signatures: An Integrated Amplitude-Phase Approach for Automated Winding Fault Diagnosis
authors: Abdoallah Hosseini, Ali Abbasi, Ali Reza Abbasi, Mohammad Reza Mahmoudi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Power transformers serve as critical components in electrical transmission networks, continuously exposed to severe electromechanical stresses that lead to winding faults including Axial Displacement (AD), Radial Deformation (RD), and inter-disk Short Circuit (SC). Early detection of these faults is crucial for preventing catastrophic failures and ensuring grid reliability. While Frequency Response Analysis (FRA) has gained global acceptance as a sensitive diagnostic tool, its primary challenge lies in the subjective interpretation of complex frequency responses. This paper presents an automated, quantitative framework that leverages two parallel visualization methodologies: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for optimal feature compression and noise reduction within hybrid amplitude-phase feature space, and Fuzzy Clustering Analysis (FCA) for managing uncertainties in transitional and combined fault conditions. The proposed approach implements a structured two-stage identification process: initially distinguishing healthy from faulty states, followed by specific fault classification. Experimental validation on a 1 MVA transformer under various fault severity levels demonstrates outstanding performance, with PCA and FCA achieving accuracies of 98.9% and 99.0%, respectively. The dual visualization system independently presents results from both methods, significantly reducing dependency on specialized expertise and enabling clearer, more objective interpretation. This research represents a significant step toward standardizing FRA interpretation and offers a practical, reliable solution for transformer condition assessment in industrial applications.

title: Distance Correlation-Enhanced Collaborative Filtering for Tag Recommendation
authors: Dao Xuan Thi Nguyen, Khoi Nguyen-Tan, Hiep Xuan Huynh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Tag recommendation systems (TRS) are a crucial component of social and academic platforms, assisting users in efficiently organizing and exploring information. Traditional Collaborative Filtering (CF) methods rely mainly on linear similarity measures such as Cosine or Pearson, which cannot fully capture the complex nonlinear dependencies among users, resources, and tags. This paper proposes a novel model that integrates Distance Correlation (dCor) into CF to detect nonlinear relationships, thereby improving tag recommendation accuracy. dCor, derived from energy statistics, is a powerful measure capable of identifying both linear and nonlinear dependence, with a value of zero if and only if the variables are independent. Unlike traditional similarity measures (Cosine, Pearson) that only capture linear dependencies, dCor is the only measure that satisfies: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$d \operatorname{Cor}(X, Y)=0$</tex> if and only if <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Y$</tex> are independent. This property is critical for tag recommendation systems, where user-tag and item-tag relationships exhibit complex nonlinear patterns that linear measures completely fail to detect. The proposed model follows a pipeline consisting of data preprocessing, distance correlation computation, neighbor selection, and tag recommendation. Experimental results on the MovieLens-20M dataset with a 5-fold cross-validation setup demonstrate that the proposed EnDist-Tag model achieves Precision =0.4502, Recall =0.2443, F1=0.2458, outperforming baseline methods including UserCF, ItemCF, and Matrix Factorization. These findings confirm that integrating distance correlation significantly enhances tag recommendation quality compared to traditional CF approaches.

title: A 40.8% FBW Full D-Band Receiver Front-End Fabricated in 40 nm CMOS
authors: Yi-Wen Wang, Shih-Chun Yeh, Kai-Jie Chuang, Tian-Wei Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper presents a design for a broadband receiver front-end implemented in a 40nm CMOS process. The proposed receiver front-end includes a five-stage differential common-source Low Noise Amplifier (LNA) and a passive ring mixer with an IF buffer. Simulation results show that the system offers a 3dB bandwidth from 111 GHz to 168 GHz, reaching the highest fractional bandwidth (FBW) of 40.8%, a peak gain of 4.7 dB at 163 GHz, and a minimum noise figure (NF) of 10.1 dB at 145 GHz. This Receiver front-end demonstrates -18 dBm input 1 dB compression point (P1dB), which is suitable for frequency communication and radar systems in D-band.

title: A 96-GHz 15.9-dB Gain 20.7 dBm PSAT Power Amplifier in 60-nm GaN-on-Si HEMT
authors: Tsai-Rung Hu, Hsin-Chieh Lin, Yin-Cheng Chang, Sih-Han Li, Da-Chiang Chang, Shawn S. H. Hsu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: A W-band three-stage power amplifier (PA) is demonstrated using 60-nm GaN-on-Si HEMT technology. The PA topology comprises one transistor for the first stage and two transistors for the following stages. A transistor size of 2×25 μm transistor is employed in all three stages, which offers cut-off frequency f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</inf> and maximum oscillating frequency f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf> of 95 and 213 GHz, respectively. Using the proposed circuit configuration and taking advantage of the superior characteristics of GaN-on-Si HEMT devices, a W-band PA with a maximum output power of 20.7 dBm, a peak power gain of 15.9 dB, and a peak power-added-efficiency (PAE) of 7.2% at 96 GHz has been achieved. Compared to the published GaN-on-Si PAs, this work demonstrates the highest operating frequencies with high gain and comparable power density. Also, the PA only occupies an area of 1.45 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, which is also among the smallest compared to other W-band GaN PAs.

title: Pedagogical Prototype for Teaching Automatic Control Using a DC Motor
authors: Luis R. Rivera-Goitia, Luis E. González-Jiménez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Traditional methods of teaching automatic control often lack practical involvement, making it difficult for undergraduate engineering students to connect theory with real-world applications. This work presents the development of a low-cost pedagogical prototype aimed at teaching automatic control principles through hands-on experimentation. The prototype integrates a direct current (DC) motor, an encoder, a current sensor, a DC motor driver, and an embedded system. In addition, a Graphical User Interface (GUI) was developed in the MATLAB environment. The GUI communicates through the serial port of the PC and allows students to define the experimental parameters and monitor responses in real time. The system enables students to design and apply open-loop and closed-loop controllers in a practical environment, enhancing their understanding of control theory. The low-cost and user-friendly design of this prototype makes it accessible for educational purposes, bridging the gap between theoretical concepts and practical applications.

title: Simulation-Based Design of a PI-Controller System for Superficial Thermal Therapy
authors: Juan M. Núñez-Leyva, Saúl R. Méndez-Elizondo, Iván A. Reyes-Portillo, Diomar E. Rodríguez-Obregón, Lizeth Lopez-Lopez, Dora L. Castro-López
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This study presents the simulation-based design of a closed-loop thermal regulation system for localized superficial thermal therapy. A simplified First-Order Plus Time Delay (FOPTD) model derived from the bioheat equation is used to emulate tissue response. A PI controller is synthesized with root locus techniques using MATLAB’s interactive tools and evaluated under a family of physiological conditons. The simulation shows that the controller drives tissue temperature into the therapeutic window in the range of 40 to 42<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">◦</sup> C with a rise time 3 min, a thermal overshoot below 1<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">◦</sup> C, and a safety threshold≤ of T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf> ≤ 43<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">◦</sup>C. The results demonstrate compliance with clinical requirements and validate the proposed approach for future experimental implementation.

title: VILOD: Combining Visual Interactive Labeling With Active Learning for Object Detection
authors: Isac Holm, Rafael M. Martins, Claudio D. G. Linhares, Amilcar Soares
abstract: The need for large, high-quality annotated datasets continues to represent a primary limitation in training Object Detection (OD) models. To mitigate this challenge, we present VILOD, a Visual Interactive Labeling tool that integrates Active Learning (AL) with a suite of interactive visualizations to create an effective Human-in-the-Loop (HITL) workflow for OD annotation and training. VILOD is designed to make the AL process more transparent and steerable, empowering expert users to implement diverse, strategically guided labeling strategies that extend beyond algorithmic query strategies. Through comparative case studies, we evaluate three visually guided labeling strategies against a conventional automated AL baseline. The results show that a balanced, human-guided strategy—leveraging VILOD's visual cues to synthesize information about data structure and model uncertainty—not only outperforms the automated baseline but also achieves the highest overall model performance. These findings emphasize the potential of visually guided, interactive annotation to enhance both the efficiency and effectiveness of dataset creation for OD.

title: Interpreting Ganymede’s Microwave Emission: Modeling Emission and Scattering from Bright Terrain
authors: Wenchao Zheng, Yi Leng, Hailiang Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: An advanced microwave radiative transfer model is developed for Ganymede by enhancing the Microwave Emission Model of Layered Snowpacks (MEMLS). It integrates topographic effects into the heat conduction equation for temperature profiles and treats ice as Rayleigh scatterers to address volume scattering. Channels 4–6 of Juno Microwave Radiometer data, sensitive to the surface diurnal layer, are applied to investigate the microwave emission of bright terrains of Ganymede. Comparisons between observed and simulated brightness temperatures (TBs) reveal no significant Rayleigh volume scattering across 5-22 GHz in either Xibalba Sulcus (XS) or Tros crater. To reconcile the discrepancy between observed and modeled TBs, a surface dust layer is introduced into the model. This addition successfully explains the suppressed TBs observed in bright terrains, suggesting the presence of materials with a higher dielectric constant (such as silicates or salts) than pure water ice. For the XS region, the real part of the dielectric constant of the dust layer must be at least 5 to achieve approximate agreement between the modeled and observed TB. While For Tros crater, with lower TB, requires an exceptionally high value (real part > 15). The impact of antenna patterns at 5 GHz and 22 GHz on observed TBs is quantified. An anomalous 5 GHz TB depression relative to 22 GHz TB in XS is attributed to antenna pattern variations between frequencies. Topographic effects are negligible at Tros crater due to its large diameter-to-depth ratio, unlike smaller craters like Achelous, where topography significantly influences thermal behavior.

title: A Robust Region-Aware Framework for Audio Forgery Localization
authors: Jiale Luo, Hongxia Wang, Hanqing Liu, Xiao Huang, Kaile Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: The localization of partially forged audio containing multiple fine-grained forged segments poses a significant challenge to audio forgery localization countermeasures. This challenge is further exacerbated when such audio is affected by compression-induced noise and may also include content generated by unknown models. To address this challenge, we propose a novel framework to enhance audio forgery localization by capturing the differences across different forged audio regions and applying distinct strategies to each region. Specifically, we introduce a Cluster-Based Mixture of Experts (CMoE) framework designed to dynamically allocate specialized experts to distinct regions of forged audio. Furthermore, we introduce a learnable masking module to effectively extract robust and generalizable features from large-scale pre-trained models. We also design a group contrastive loss function to enhance the ability to distinguish differences between different audio regions. Experimental results demonstrate that our model achieves superior performance on generalization and robustness while also effectively localizing forgeries across diverse compression formats and unknown generative models.

title: Towards Maintenance-Free IoT Sensor Nodes: An Energy Harvesting Wireless Platform Based on STM32WL55 with Sub-GHz LoRaWAN Connectivity
authors: Balmukund Prasad, Filippo Colaianni, Stefano Spaziani, Roberto La Rosa
abstract: The rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) applications increases the need for wireless sensor nodes that support maintenance-free long-term operation. This article describes a fully energy-autonomous wireless sensor platform based on the STM32WL55 microcontroller unit (MCU), featuring integrated sub-GHz LoRaWAN connectivity and power management. The system uses a photovoltaic cell for energy harvesting and ambient light sensing. An embedded finite state machine manages and optimizes sensing and communication tasks. A 1.2 F supercapacitor provides energy backup, enabling up to 12 hours of autonomous operation with 15-minute transmission intervals. Experimental results demonstrate continuous environmental sensing and long-range communication powered exclusively by harvested energy. The average power consumption is below 50 μW, and the communication range is approximately 1 km. This platform provides a scalable, environmentally friendly, and maintenance-free solution for sustainable IoT deployments.

title: TinySE-OSFD: Tiny Squeeze-and-Excitation for Open-Set Anomaly Detection
authors: Haiyang Wan, Zhuyun Chen, Fen Liu, Wenbing Sun, Bowen Peng, Weihua Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Industrial rotating machinery often cannot collect all possible fault data at once. This paper presents an open-set anomaly detection network, TinyCNN-SE (Tiny Squeeze-and-Excitation blocks(SE)), which appends a Cross-Entropy Softmax layer after SE-ResBlocks. Experiments on the Automobile Transmission (AT) Dataset show that when only one unknown fault class is present, the proposed method achieves over 90 % accuracy, and when multiple unknown classes appear, it still maintains over 80 % accuracy.

title: A Deep and Efficient Analysis Method for Satellite Bus Data Based on a Three-Dimensional Framework
authors: Tao Chen, Xinxin Zhang, Wenbin Sa, Kun Zhao, Si Guo, Yi Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: The next-generation satellite bus data shows significant advances in type, volume, and format, whereas traditional analytical methods—relying on manual work and single indicators—suffer from low efficiency and inadequate anomaly detection, making them unfit for tackling challenges of large-scale data and complex communication architectures; to resolve these, this study innovates a “Time-Space-Type” 3D analytical framework for satellite bus data, transforming conventional 1D sequences into a “Remote Terminal (RT) Address-Message Category-Timestamp” data cube. It uses statistical thresholding to quickly identify single-dimensional anomalies, autocorrelation analysis to quantify sequence periodicity (detecting cyclical irregularities like missing or unstable cycles), and Density Peak Clustering (DPC) integrated with Mahalanobis distance to identify high-dimensional coupled composite faults, while establishing a “local detection-global validation-root cause localization” closed-loop mechanism for single/multi-dimensional features to boost anomaly accuracy. Software based on this method significantly improves satellite-wide bus data processing efficiency, and deployed in satellite models, it provides critical support for satellite fault diagnosis and prognostics and health management.

title: Design of a Virtual Binocular Photogrammetry Sensoring System Based on Reflective Optical Paths
authors: Chengfei Li, Jianliang Liu, Hao Wang, Jianfeng Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: The observation of butterflies has always been an important link in the field of bionic aircraft design and research and development. This paper designs a binocular vision sensoring system based on single-camera specular reflection. This design ensures high reflectivity and no ghosting or distortion of the image, while also simplifying the design of the reflective light path. We perform single-object calibration on the camera to obtain the internal parameter matrix and distortion coefficient of the single camera. It is a single-camera virtual binocular sensoring vision sensoring system based on reflection, subsequent binocular determination only needs to obtain the rotation matrix and translation vector. The intrinsic parameter matrix and distortion coefficient of the binocular camera should be the parameters of the single camera. We use the rotation matrix and translation vector to perform stereo correction and triangulation to obtain the three-dimensional information of the two-dimensional point, and to verify the results, the error is required to be less than 0.1 mm. The design is verified by experiment.

title: Graph-Based Evaluation of Visual Brain Decoding from fMRI Data
authors: Mohammad Moradi, Morteza Moradi, Marco Grassia, Giuseppe Mangioni
abstract: Despite progress in visual reconstruction from fMRI signals, evaluating reconstruction quality remains challenging due to noisy, low-resolution data and semantic ambiguity. Conventional metrics often overlook perceptual and structural alignment with the original stimuli. To address this, we propose Graph-based Semantic and Structural Similarity (GSS), a novel evaluation approach that represents both stimuli and reconstructions as patch-wise graphs using CLIP-derived features. By applying graph matching, GSS captures spatial and semantic relationships beyond pixel-level similarities. Our approach aligns with neuroscientific models of visual processing and demonstrates robust, interpretable results that complement existing metrics.

title: Experimental Evaluation of a Low-Power Radio-over-Fiber System for IoT Sensing with LoRaWAN Transmission
authors: Hugo V. Sousa, Victhor F. F. Silva, Leonardo Didier Coelho, Joaquim Ferreira Martins Filho, Vladimir Diego Rojas Albuquerque
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work proposes and experimentally investigates a Radio over Fiber (RoF) transmission system using LoRaWAN signals over a single-mode fiber (SMF) link, targeting low-power IoT sensing applications in harsh environments. The system establishes an optical link between a Central Station and a Remote Sensor, which includes a LoRaWAN module, a Distributed Feedback Laser (DFB), and a passive photodetector. The LoRa signal, operating in the AU915 band, modulates a 1550 nm optical carrier to transmit sensing data back to the Central Station. Experimental results demonstrate successful bidirectional RoF communication using LoRaWAN with received optical power as low as −55 dBm at both photodetectors. This allows for LoRaWAN transmission over distances exceeding 100 km, significantly greater than the typical 10 km range of wireless-only links. The system was designed to operate with reduced power consumption at the Remote Sensor, enabling an integration with Power-over-Fiber (PoF) technology. Overall, the proposed setup is a reliable and energy-efficient solution for IoT sensing in harsh industrial environments, using a secure optical link that is immune to interference and protected against unauthorized access.

title: LQR-based Optimal Controller Design for LVAD
authors: Subhodip Goswami, Sumit Kumar Pandey, Anindita Ganguly
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: A vital life-supporting tool for patients with stage IV heart failure is the Left Ventricular Assist Device (LVAD). Effective circulatory support requires that the LVAD be regulated in order to preserve hemodynamic stability and react suitably to changing physiological circumstances. The Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) architecture is used in this study to design an optimal control method for LVAD operation. The control design is based on a thorough six-state dynamic model that incorporates the important relationships between pump dynamics, the heart, and the vasculature. In spite of limitations such actuator saturation, simulation findings show that the LQR controller maintains system stability while providing faster and more precise monitoring of physiological reference signals, including step, square, triangle, and sinusoidal waveforms. The results demonstrate that LQR-based control, which strikes a compromise between computing economy, resilience, and performance, is a viable and promising approach for real-time LVAD regulation

title: Dynamic Multi-Objective Economic Load and Emission Dispatch Incorporating Renewable Energy Uncertainty Using an Enhanced Particle Swarm Optimization Framework
authors: AbdolRasool Khorram Dabiri
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: due to increasing integration of renewable energy sources and the need for cost-effective, environmentally compliant operation. This paper develops a comprehensive formulation for the 24-hour dynamic dispatch problem by incorporating probabilistic models of wind and solar generation to properly capture their inherent uncertainties. The proposed model considers practical nonlinear operational constraints of conventional generating units, including valve-point effects, ramp-rate limits, and prohibited operating zones. To efficiently solve the resulting multi-objective optimization problem, an improved particle swarm optimization algorithm with enhanced local–global search capabilities and entropy-based Pareto sorting is introduced. The algorithm aims to simultaneously minimize fuel cost and pollutant emissions while ensuring system reliability. Benchmark tests on standard 6-unit, 10-unit, and 30-unit systems demonstrate that the enhanced PSO achieves fast convergence and superior solution quality compared to conventional evolutionary techniques. The results further highlight the significant impact of renewable energy penetration on optimal dispatch schedules and overall generation cost, validating the effectiveness of the proposed optimization framework for next-generation power system operation.

title: CNN-Based Surrogate Model for Rapid Prediction of Flow Fields in Early-Stage Urban Design and Planning
authors: Gulzar Ali, Hadia Khan, Bazla Tariq, Eemaan Khalid, Ammar Mushtaq
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) is a cornerstone in analyzing airflow behavior around buildings, playing a vital role in optimizing urban layouts for wind comfort, ventilation, and pollutant dispersion. However, the high computational cost and time required for traditional CFD methods make it impractical for iterative and large-scale design evaluations. This study proposes a deep learning-based surrogate model using a convolutional neural network (CNN) to enable rapid aerodynamic analysis of building layouts from a top-view (2D) perspective. The model is trained on a dataset comprising pressure and velocity fields generated from high-fidelity CFD simulations across a variety of building designs and wind parameters like velocity and direction, including some building layouts from the NUST campus. Geometry is encoded using signed distance functions, and inlet flow conditions are explicitly conditioned to allow generalization across varying scenarios. The trained model accurately predicts flow fields around unseen geometries with MAE 0.032 and MSE 0.002, demonstrating its potential as a fast surrogate for early-stage urban design and building aerodynamic assessments.

title: Dynamic Arithmetic Optimization Algorithm for renewable DG placement considering load uncertainty
authors: Indrajit Dey, Provas Kumar Roy, Falguni Chakraborty
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The photovoltaic (PV) and wind turbine (WT) based renewable distributed generation (DG) placement in radial distribution network (RDN) using dynamic arithmetic optimization algorithm (DAOA) under load uncertainty is the prime objective of this paper. The suggested DAOA is an enhanced version of the original AOA technique. For improving network efficiency, an objective function, active power loss minimization is considered. The suggested DAOA technique reduces the real power loss by allocating PV and WT DG in the optimal place with optimal sizes. The nominal load and $60 \%$ increase in nominal load are considered as a load variation scenario for this study. The test system, Portuguese 94-bus system is considered and potency of the recommended DAOA algorithm is tested on this system. The results of DAOA have been contrasted with primary AOA and other algorithms found in the literature.

title: REXpanded-LSTM: A Recurrent Expansion Framework for Milling Machine Degradation Prognostics
authors: Tarek Berghout, Sahbi Wannes, Jaouher Ben Ali
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Accurate prediction of complex, nonlinear degradation processes is critical for prognostics and health monitoring applications. In this work, we propose Recurrent Expansion eXpanded Long Short-Term Memory (REXpanded-LSTM), a novel recurrent neural network framework that recursively expands hidden states via Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and incorporates previous predictions into augmented input sequences. This iterative procedure allows the network to progressively refine temporal representations and capture higherorder dependencies in highly non-stationary and noisy signals. The method is evaluated on a challenging synthetic dataset designed to mimic the degradation of milling machines, capturing phenomena such as exponential amplitude growth, nonlinear frequency drift, impulsive tool impacts, and strong stochastic noise. Experimental results demonstrate that the REXpandedLSTM outperforms conventional LSTM models, achieving a root mean squared error of 0.201 compared to 0.253, a mean absolute error of 0.185 compared to 0.236, and an $R^{2}$ of −4.43 compared to −7.61. The predictions closely follow the true Health Index (HI) trajectories and exhibit stable convergence across training rounds. The framework achieves these improvements without requiring extensive preprocessing or manual feature engineering, offering a robust and generalizable approach for sequential time-series prediction in milling machine prognostics, condition monitoring, and other data-driven modeling applications.

title: Use of Vanadium Redox Flow Batteries in Electric Grid
authors: Oumayma Hadj Salem, Ghada Boukettaya, Rafik Cherni
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Faced with the rapid growth of electric mobility and the deployment of charging infrastructures, which can impose additional stress on the electric grid, there is an increasing need for storage systems capable of delivering energy over extended periods to accommodate the long charging times of electric vehicles (EVs). Therefore, long-duration energy storage becomes essential to ensure stable and reliable grid operation. In Tunisia, where the grid is already showing signs of saturation, particularly during summer peak periods, this paper examines the vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB) as a long-term storage solution, emphasizing its role in power system operation, its operational flexibility, and its ability to provide auxiliary services, as well as its potential for combined electricity and heat production, offering opportunities to support electric mobility while alleviating stress on the electric grid.

title: Research on Scoring Mechanism and Rehabilitation Application of Metaverse 3-D Virtual Reality Technology in Social Adaptation System for Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder
authors: Xuanlin Li, Sergey Gorbachev, Ashish Mani
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Children with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) face challenges in social adaptation and emotional regulation due to developmental deficits in psychological and social abilities. Uneven resource allocation and insufficient immersive experiences limit the effectiveness of traditional rehabilitation approaches, resulting in low engagement and poor skill transfer among children with autism. To address this issue, we developed the Metaverse Interactive Social Adaptation System (MISAS) for children with ASD. Based on Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales, Second Edition (VABS-II), it includes 12 thematic scenarios and 31 tasks. Using a quasi-experimental pre-test/post-test design, 8 ASD children ($4-8$ years old, mean 5.5) received 3-week intervention. Paired-samples t-test showed significant score improvement (mean increase: 18.36, Cohen’s $\mathrm{d}=6.28$, 95% CI [10.52,26.20], $\mathrm{p}=0.006$). VABS-II domain weights (daily living skills: 0.41, communication: 0.25, socialization: 0.21, motor skills: $\mathbf{0. 1 2}$) were determined by normative standards and clinical practice.

title: Estimation-Based Protection of Shunt Reactors Against Cyberattacks Using Dynamic State Estimation
authors: Jumana I. Alarfaji, Latifah M. Alessa, Mohamed A. Abdulgalil, Abdulaziz Qwbaiban
abstract: This paper analyzes cyberattacks on shunt reactors in transmission systems using estimation-based protection (EBP) built on Dynamic State Estimation (DSE). Unlike conventional protective relays that are vulnerable to cyberattacks and measurement errors, the proposed EBP integrates real-time measurements with a reactor-bank dynamic model. It targets attacks such as current-transformer (CT) and potential-transformer (PT) ratio tampering and GPS spoofing. Detection uses residual-based hypothesis testing, where the residual is the difference between measured and model-predicted quantities. We model a 115-kV reactor-bank test system, generate COMTRADE data under multiple attack scenarios, and assess secure operation. The COMTRADE files were analyzed to identify the attack type and to validate secure decision logic. The scheme detected attacks within one cycle and avoided mis-tripping by excluding compromised data.

title: A Bayesian Network-Based Approach for Fault Diagnosis in Natural Gas TEG Dehydration System
authors: Lijun Huang, Shangfei Song, Daqian Liu, Mingzhe Xu, Keyu Wu, Bohui Shi, Kai Wen, Jing Gong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: The triethylene glycol (TEG) dehydration system is an integral component of the natural gas processing flow, and its proper functioning is essential for maintaining the efficiency and stability of the overall process. Any failure within this system can have substantial and detrimental effects on the entire natural gas processing operation. To overcome the limitations of traditional diagnostic methods, such as incomplete fault identification, lack of probabilistic quantification, and difficulty in tracing causal factors, this study proposes an advanced fault diagnosis approach based on fault tree analysis (FTA) and fuzzy Bayesian networks (FBN). Initially, a fault tree model is constructed utilizing process knowledge and expert insights to identify potential failure modes. Subsequently, the mapping relationship between the fault tree model and the Bayesian network is established to define the network's structure. To address the uncertainty inherent in expert judgments, fuzzy set theory is employed to derive the prior probabilities for basic events. The conditional probability tables of the Bayesian network are then determined through logic gates, completing the parameter learning phase. Forward inference of the Bayesian network reveals a current fault probability of 0.79, indicating a high likelihood of system failure, which necessitates enhanced operational and maintenance efforts. Additionally, backward inference pinpoints TEG foaming and improper human operations as the primary contributors to the elevated risk. Sensitivity analysis further identifies the most probable causal chains of events. In conclusion, the proposed fuzzy Bayesian network-based fault diagnosis approach provides a robust and accurate methodology for identifying critical fault factors and causal relationships, offering valuable support for accident prevention and informed maintenance decisionmaking. This approach holds significant practical implications for engineering operations and maintenance management.

title: Real-Time Fault Analysis and System Optimization in EV Controllers with Field-Oriented Control: A Practical Investigation on Monitoring Diagnostics and Enhancements
authors: R. Suganya, L.M.I. Leo Joseph, Sreedhar Kollem
abstract: This paper examines the Field-Oriented Control (FOC) for EV controllers monitoring in the LingBo ECU Gen5 GUI environment. Advanced analysis and fault diagnosis tools are employed in real-time in the system to monitor important parameters, including bus voltage, current, speed, and motor temperature. Based on this analysis, it is found that undervoltage faults, as well as thermal management issues, present some of the most significant problems during operation. Recommendations, such as fault prioritization and enhanced cooling systems, are also presented to promote both safety and efficiency within the EV controller. The article also presents ideas on how machine learning and adaptive thermal management can be integrated to improve fault diagnosis and predictive maintenance. This concept would ensure high performance, reliability, and scalability for FOC-based systems on EV applications. These results provide crucial information that can accelerate the development of sustainable and efficient electric transportation systems.

title: FIRE: A Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Rule-Based Interpretability in Diabetic Patient Analysis
authors: Tasawar Abbas Khan, Majid Iqbal Khan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Diabetes is a chronic disease that affects millions worldwide due to the inability of the body to produce or utilize insulin effectively, leading to elevated blood glucose levels. Although deep learning and other machine learning models have significantly improved diabetes diagnosis and prediction accuracy, their black-box nature limits interpretability and trust among healthcare professionals. This study introduces a Feature Interaction and Rule-based Explainability (FIRE) framework that combines the predictive accuracy of a Deep Neural Network (DNN) with the interpretability of an XGBoost surrogate model. The proposed approach uses polynomial feature transformations and attention mechanisms to capture nonlinear interactions among features. The surrogate XGBoost model provides transparent rule-based explanations using SHAP values, translating complex DNN predictions into human-readable "if-then" rules. Experimental results demonstrate high precision (86.46%) and near-perfect fidelity (99.61%) between DNN and XGBoost predictions, achieving an optimal balance between interpretability and accuracy. FIRE framework enables interpretable, accurate, and clinically meaningful AI findings for the treatment of diabetic patients to enhance trust and understanding among clinicians.To improve interpretability for medical professionals, the extracted rules are transformed back from normalized feature space into their original clinical units (e.g., mg/dL, mmHg, kg/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>).

title: SPLAM-Based Destination Optimization in Unmapped Environments Using LiDAR for Autonomous Logistics
authors: MSA Khan, Anjum Naeem Malik, Anas Bin Aqeel, Hassan Elahi, Faraz Kunwar
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Accurate and optimized localization of the target position in an unknown environment remains a challenging problem, particularly when considering cost-effectiveness and computational efficiency in large environments. Although optimized localization can be achieved using a multi-sensor mobile robot, it increases both system cost and computational complexity. To address these challenges, a mobile robot is developed to determine destination positions using only LiDAR sensors reliably. A robust approach is proposed to build the map and navigate the mobile robot in unknown environments. This approach employs a combination of Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) and a path planning technique, known as Simultaneous Path Planning, Localization, and Mapping (SPLAM), which integrates Graph-SLAM as the SLAM method with the D* (improved A* for dynamic environments) path planning algorithm. A ROS-based system and a real-time embedded system are developed to achieve the desired results. Simulated results are implemented in Robotic Operating system (ROS) with Noetic version, and successfully integrating mapping and target localization within an unknown environment. It effectively combines map construction and goal-reaching using LiDAR data. In parallel, a real-time robotic platform is also designed to implement the SPLAM framework in a real environment with an area of 25×40 feet, enabling simultaneous path planning, localization, and mapping in dynamic and real-world conditions.

title: Statistical Analysis of Vibration Signals for Monitoring Blade Cracks in Low-Power Wind Turbines
authors: J. Jesus de Santiago-Perez, Jesus R. Rivera-Guillen, Juan P. Amezquita-Sanchez, Martin Valtierra-Rodriguez, Jesus Jeronimo-Castro, Francisco Gerardo Jimenez-Lopez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Nowadays, there are various proposals to promote the use of alternative energies globally. In this regard, wind turbines present a prominent option because they are a clean and renewable energy source, which contributes to reducing environmental impact. Wind turbines are systems that convert the wind's kinetic energy into electrical energy; however, for efficient performance, the system must be in healthy condition. Therefore, it is important to have monitoring and diagnostic strategies in place to detect wind turbine failures. This paper presents a proposal for the characterization of blade fracture failures in low-power wind turbines. The proposal is based on the use of Hjorth parameters (HPs) to analyze triaxial vibration signals. A multivariate analysis of variance (MANOVA) and comparison of means are performed to statistically validate the HPs' ability to characterize the signals. An experimental validation of the proposal was performed with a low-power wind turbine in a controlled environment with a wind tunnel, where different levels of failure severity were analyzed (healthy, light, intermediate and severe). The results show the effectiveness of HPs as indicators capable of characterizing vibration signals according to the case studies considered.

title: Fault diagnosis scheme design using convex Takagi-Sugeno observer for boost converter
authors: T.L. Pérez Campos, J.R. Santoyo Anzures, J. Anzurez Marín, R. Tapia Sánchez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of fault diagnosis in boost converters through the design and simulation of observers based on convex Takagi-Sugeno (T-S) models. This type of converters are used in power systems, making them susceptible to faults that can compromise system stability and efficiency. A fault diagnosis scheme is proposed that utilizes the convex Takagi-Sugeno model to represent the nonlinear behavior of the converter, as well as a convex T-S observer to generate the residuals, which function as fault indicators. The simulation results show that the proposed approach enables early and accurate fault detection, which contributes to improving the operational reliability of the system.

title: Intelligent Transportation Framework for Vehicle Detection and Tracking in Urban Scenes
authors: Muhammad Adeel Ahmed Tahir, Adnan Ahmed Rafique, Ahmad Jalal
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: The accurate detection and tracking of vehicles are important part of intelligent traffic management and urban surveillance systems. In this paper, we have presented robust integrated pipeline which is capable of detecting, tracking and counting vehicles within difficult urban scenes taking advantage of the Cityscapes dataset. This pipeline grows with image enhancement techniques via contrast equalization and noise reducing methods to improve visibility under different lighting conditions and environmental contexts. For object detection, we have employed hybrid fusion method using SSD and modified RetinaNet with frozen ResNet-50 base layers to detect vehicles with a high degree of confidence. To implement object tracking, we have incorporated ByteTrack to associate vehicle locations across frames, while preserving unique IDs and temporal layer. We have utilized HOG features that are classified using support vector machine), for vehicle counting, ensuring an accurate level of verification based on instance identification at the vehicle level. An experimental evaluation is conducted to assess the performance, where the results show competitive accuracy of 95.8% for counting, along with profound results for detection and tracking metrics noted. The combination of classical machine learning components with advanced object detection techniques present a pipeline able to efficiently process video data for subsequent visualization and/or analysis in real-time for smart city deployments.

title: Power Flow Algorithm Optimization: A New Method to Reduce Active Losses in Offshore Wind Farms
authors: Guilherme Beck Lemos, Matheus Schramm Dall'Asta, Romero Leandro Andersen, Lenon Schmitz, Jéssika Melo de Andrade, Telles Brunelli Lazzarin
abstract: As offshore wind energy becomes a major contributor to renewable generation, enhancing electrical efficiency is crucial. This paper proposes an optimization-based power flow control strategy for offshore wind farms to minimize active transmission losses. The approach integrates the New-ton-Raphson power flow algorithm with an optimization function, adjusting reactive power outputs of individual turbines. Two topologies, star and radial, were assessed under varying loading conditions. Results show that the method shifts reactive power support from the onshore grid to the turbines, decreasing reactive power at the connection point by about 30% in both topologies without increasing overall system consumption. This internal compensation improves voltage profiles and operational security. Additionally, active power losses were reduced by up to 29.84% in the star topology and 28.03% in the radial topology under low-load scenarios, with higher relative savings at lower generation levels.

title: A three-dimensional model reconstruction method for two measurement planes of electrical impedance tomography for breast cancer simulation
authors: Luis Gerardo Zamudio Ibarra, Jose Antonio Gutierrez Gnecchi, Marcos Gutierrez Lopez, Enrique Reyes Archundia, Javier Alejandro Rodriguez Herrejon
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Electrical impedance tomography is a non-invasive measurement technique that allows the generation of a graphic reconstruction of a section of a body or surface and from there visualize its impedance profile graphically, in the medical area it has different applications such as the visualization of cancerous tissue in the breast, various strategies have been proposed not only to improve its greatest limitation: its low spatial resolution, but also to be able to visualize the location of the carcinoma in different layers or levels. As a contribution to the development of image reconstruction systems with a greater scope, the use of a three-dimensional model generated from two bidimensional layers, built by linear interpolation, is proposed. By using this model, it is possible to visualize not only the position of the object, but also the depth at which it is located.

title: HMM-Based Reservation Plans of Cloud Resources
authors: Louis-Marie Péan, Omar Abdelaaziz Kabbaj, Jean-Baptiste Masson, Bruno Marhic, Laurent Delahoche
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: The use of cloud resources, such as virtual machines or containers, has been rapidly increasing. Consequently, the environmental impact of cloud data centres is becoming a major issue. On the enterprises’ side, the massive use of cloud services induces high financial costs. One way to reduce both the environmental and financial costs of cloud services is to optimize reserved resources. Major cloud providers propose autoscaling methods that automatically add or remove resources based on the current or predicted load, but these might cause issues when the workload varies rapidly. Other approaches make long-term resource reservation plans, often based on forecasting. However, long-term forecasting is a difficult task. Moreover, sporadic usage spikes might be observed, yet models are unable to predict them. The proposed approach handles this issue by giving a description of the different states of the workload based on HMM clustering. The use of periodic time variables such as the hour of the day or the day of the week allows the model to recommend weekly resource reservation plans. Experiments on simulated data show that the method is able to describe periodic and aperiodic behaviours in an accurate yet understandable way.

title: The Simplest Side-Channel Protection of AES-Dedicated Circuit for Last-Round Attack by CPA
authors: Tomoaki Ukezono, Saishi Taira
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Cryptography constitutes a critically important technology for virtually establishing dedicated channels in Internet. However, widely standardized and continuously used ciphers such as AES have been reported to possess vulnerabilities to side-channel attacks for over two decades, and decisive countermeasures to address these vulnerabilities have yet to be established. This paper targets Correlation Power Analysis (CPA) [7], a type of side-channel attacks, and proposes a dedicated hardware design for AES that is effective against attacks on the last-round. The paper demonstrates that the proposed approach is highly effective against CPA-based last-round attacks while achieving implementation with significantly lower overhead compared to the WDDL [9] countermeasure. In the evaluation presented in this paper, it was demonstrated that the proposed design method, when applied to a dedicated AES hardware design without countermeasures, incurs virtually no overhead in combinational logic, introduces approximately 12 % overhead in register utilization, and is capable of almost completely preventing secret key leakage through side-channels against CPA-based last-round attacks.

title: Comparative Analysis of Power-line Denoising Techniques in Electromiographic Signals
authors: José Felipe Escobedo-Magallán, Adriana del Carmen Téllez Anguiano, William Alberto Rojas, Lorenzo García
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Electromyographic (EMG) signals are frequently contaminated by powerline interference (60 Hz and harmonics), compromising diagnostic accuracy. This paper compares three denoising techniques: 1) a cascaded IIR filter (60 Hz notch), 2) spectral subtraction of harmonics via Fourier Transform, and 3) wavelet denoising (db4 wavelet, universal threshold, level 7). All methods include a 10–500 Hz bandpass prefilter. These techniques are compared using experimental superficial electromyographic (sEMG) data. The results show that wavelet achieves optimal harmonic suppression (- 60.4684 dB), while spectral substraction best preserves temporal features (RMSE = 0.013) with the lowest computational load. The IIR approach remains suitable for real-time applications. Noise suppression, feature preservation, and computational load are quantified using SNR, RMSE, and spectral metrics.

title: Multiobjective Tuning of RBF Neural Network for MPPT Control of Standalone PV System
authors: Mohand Akli Kacimi, Celia Aoughlis, Amine Abadi, Toufik Bakir
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper proposes a methodology for designing a Radial Basis Function Neural Network (RBFNN) aimed at enhancing the performance of Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) control in standalone photovoltaic (PV) systems. The proposed methodology concurrently addresses two critical challenges: improving the efficiency of power extraction from the PV system and mitigating the structural complexity of the RBFNN. To this end, the NSGA-II algorithm is employed to optimize both the network architecture—namely, the number of radial basis functions—and the corresponding network parameters. By leveraging a tailored chromosome encoding strategy in conjunction with a rigorously formulated objective function, the algorithm effectively determines the optimal number of basis functions and their associated parameters, thereby improving MPPT efficiency. The case study focuses on a standalone PV system comprising a Kyocera KC200GT PV module supplying a resistive load through a boost converter. The simulation results, obtained using the MATLAB/Simulink environment, demonstrate the proposed approach’s potential to achieve superior tracking performance and significant efficiency improvements.

title: Gain Drop Analysis of Electrically Long Gate Finger FETs and Its Improving Method
authors: Shinji Hara, Keiichi Sakuno
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: Gate length is dominant for high-frequency characteristics of FETs. In addition, even for short gate length FETs, a large unit gate width, that is, a long gate finger, will degrade the high-frequency characteristics. This study analytically explains the cause of gain degradation and presents a method to increase gain by describing the gate electrode as a transmission line. The proposed structure, standing-wave controlled gate, can increase not only gain but also fmax, which cannot be increased under the conventional theory based on the three-terminal device.

title: A Mixed-Signal I-D-TIA with Direct Digitization
authors: David-Peter Wiens, Ahmed Abdelaal, Bjoern Driemeyer, Joachim Becker, John G. Kauffman, Maurits Ortmanns
abstract: Emerging sensing techniques impose strict requirements on the analog frontend regarding noise, bandwidth (BW), scalability, etc. For example, in nanopore-based DNA sequencing, two buffer solutions are separated by a membrane with a nanometer-sized pore. As molecules pass through the pore, they change the ionic current, producing a very small signal (<1 nA). Since translocation events are very short, a large BW(>MHz) is required in the sensing circuit [1]. Another example is scanning ion conductance microscopy, where a pipettewith an opening of a fewhundred nanometers is scanned over a small object (e.g., a cell or bacterium). The ionic current (hundres of pA) through the pipette varies with the object’s distance, thus a topographical image can be generated. To achieve high scan rates, a large BW(>100kHz) is required in the analog sensing front-end [2].
