title: Directional Emission Enhancement of NV Centers in Diamond via Bullseye Nanoantenna Design
authors: Leonardo R. Ramos, Henrique W. Moscoso, Vinicius M. Pepino, Ben-Hur V. Borges, Achiles F. Da Mota
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers in diamond have emerged in recent years as a leading platform for high-sensitivity microwave sensing, due to their spin-dependent optical response and stability at room temperature. In this work, we propose a hybrid modeling approach that combines Lindblad-based quantum dynamics with classical electromagnetic simulations to study and improve the emission behavior of NV centers under coherent optical excitation. A three-level open quantum system is used to describe the NV dynamics under green laser excitation, with a Rabi frequency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Omega_{12}=7.24\Gamma_{13}$</tex>. To enhance photon extraction, we design a dielectric bullseye nanoantenna that reshapes the emission pattern and increases the radiated power by over 100 times. This combined approach offers a practical route for optimizing NV-based emitters in microwave quantum sensing for telecommunications application.

title: Microwave-Based Device for Detecting Ethanol Content in Gasoline
authors: Julia S. Neves, Alexandre J. R. Serres, Marcus M. Bezerra, Pedro R. Maia
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Gasoline adulteration occurs intermittently during transportation and commercialization, leading to socioeconomic losses, engine damage, and increased pollutant emissions. Although there are precise laboratory techniques for fuel quality analysis, they are invasive, require specialized personnel, and are not easily applicable in the field. This article addresses the non-destructive detection of the ethanol content in gasoline using a microwave sensor. The system consists of a complementary split ring resonator (CSRR) etched on the ground plane that is designed to be sensitive to changes in the dielectric parameters of the fuel mixture. The variation in the transmission coefficient (S21) is used as an indicator of ethanol concentration, allowing a practical and efficient assessment of gasoline quality.

title: Designing a Low-Latency Data Transmission System for Mobile Wireless Sensor Controls Using Optimized Communication Protocols
authors: G. Ramkumar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Mobile wireless sensor control systems demand low-latency and energy-efficient data transmission to ensure timely decision-making in dynamic environments such as industrial automation, healthcare monitoring, and intelligent transportation. The conventional communication protocols, such as ZigBee offer energy efficiency but is not always effective in supporting tight latency constraints in high mobility and traffic congestion. The work introduces the architecture and analysis of a low-latency data transmission system with an optimized MQTT-SN protocol, augmented with the packet aggregation and priority-based scheduling, dynamic channel allocation and cross-layer optimization. The proposed system is verified by extensive MATLAB simulations and testbed experiments on ESP32. Findings show that the reduction in latency is up to 60% over that of ZigBee with an average delay of 18.6 ms at 10 nodes and 69.1 ms at 100 nodes. Throughput is increased by 10-15, and MQTT-SN with optimization attains 430.7 kbps at 500 kbps load or less. A packet delivery ratio (PDR) of over 97% is ensured at low mobility and 86.9% even at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 ~\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> mobility speeds. Consumption of energy per packet is cut by 25 to 30% and jitter is less than 15 ms, guaranteeing predictable performance of control. The general accuracy of the system expressed as the percentage of successful and timely packet transmissions had an average of 96.4% which was higher than the 89.5% observed in the ZigBee system. The solution proposed has better control of latency, reliability and efficiency, which has made it very appropriate to use in applications of mobile sensors that require latency control. Such results indicate its capability to be applied in actual smart environments.

title: Reconstruction of High-Resolution Magnetic Field from Sparse Measurements Based on a Super-Resolution Neural Network
authors: Jiawei Xu, Xiaoxian Wang, Siliang Lu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This paper proposes a super-resolution reconstruction network designed to recover complete magnetic field distributions from sparse magnetic field measurements. The network incorporates two down-sampling convolutional modules after the input layer, enabling it to directly process sparse high-resolution magnetic field data and reconstruct comprehensive magnetic field maps. To evaluate the model's performance, a training dataset was generated using simulated magnetic field images, while real magnetic field images were collected through a custom-built experimental setup for testing. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves effective reconstruction in both simulated and real-world scenarios, validating its accuracy and practical applicability.

title: DDSAM-CD: Dense Feature Fusion and Difference Enhancement for the Segment Anything Model in Remote Sensing Change Detection
authors: Lida Xu, Zongze Zhao, Fenglei Wang, Cheng Wang, Leiku Yang, Chao Ma, Hongtao Wang, Shusong Huang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing Change Detection (RSCD) is a critical research direction in the field. Recently, Vision foundation models (VFMs) (such as Fast Segment Anything Model, FastSAM) have demonstrated remarkable effectiveness in image segmentation tasks. SAM-CD employs a FastSAM-based encoder (pre-trained on large-scale vision datasets) to extract multi-scale features from bi-temporal images independently, followed by feature fusion prior to final interpretation, generating high-precision change detection results. However, current research in change detection has not adequately explored the utilization of features extracted from VFMs. Therefore, this study proposes the DDSAM-CD model, which primarily consists of a dense feature aggregation network (DFAN) and a differential enhancement network (DEN). The DFAN comprehensively fuses multi-scale features derived from FastSAM. In the DEN, bi-temporal features are first differentially fused to capture temporal change information. Subsequently, low-scale features extracted by FastSAM are incorporated and fused with the differential features through multi-scale feature integration. The optimized differential enhancement module significantly improves edge-region accuracy while resolving scale discrepancies, thereby delivering more reliable results for change detection tasks. The quantitative and qualitative analyses demonstrate that the proposed DDSAM model outperforms state-of-the-art RSCD methods on both the LEVIR-CD and WHU-CD datasets. Specifically, DDSAM achieved Precision, Recall, F1-score, and mIoU values of 93.79%, 90.97%, 92.38%, and 92.37% on LEVIR-CD, respectively; corresponding metrics on WHU-CD were 92.93%, 88.72%, 90.79%, and 91.24%. Additionally, the DDSAM model has achieved significant improvements in the accurate identification of edge regions.

title: Predictive Maintenance of Industrial Pumps in Manufacturing Systems using Hybrid Wiener–Hammerstein Ensemble Model
authors: T Rajesh, Anju S Pillai
abstract: Centrifugal pumps are essential assets in industrial installation, where they support continuous dynamic operation in manufacturing processes, power plant, water distribution system facilities. In a small and medium scale industries, pump failure/faults are often detected only after noticeable performance deterioration, resulting in increased unplanned down time, energy consumption and higher operational risks. Traditional fault predictive maintenance strategies typically rely on single-sensor vibration analysis or standalone statistical indicators, which tend to lose reliability when nonlinear behaviour arises from coupled hydraulic and electrical interactions. To overcome this limitations, this study proposes a Hybrid Wiener–Hammerstein ensemble method for predictive maintenance (HWE–PM) that integrate physical system dynamics with data driven learning approach. The primary premise is that incipient faults are reflected not only in conventional signal features but also in structured residual patterns that signify deviation from normal operating conditions. A nonlinear-linear-Wiener-Hammerstein representation is employed to organize time and frequency domain information while an ensemble of heterogeneous classifiers–Random Forest (RF), XGBoost and k-Nearest Neighbours (kNN) is used to learn fault specific decision boundaries. The probabilistic output of these base learners is subsequently combined through a logistic regression meta learner using cross validated stacking, maximizing prediction stability under various operating conditions. The proposed work is evaluated using synthetic multimodal dataset developed to emulate the operating characteristics of a Crompton Greaves CG-IPM-15, three phase centrifugal pump and instrumented with 26 sensing channels. The HWE-PM model achieves an overall classification accuracy of 97.6% with a low false alarm rate of 2.3%, outperforming all individual base classifiers. The results demonstrate effective discrimination among multiple degradation modes, including bearing wear, aging of insulation, impeller imbalance and cavitation. Further implementation and model deployment on Jetson Nano and ESP32 edge devices confirms the feasibility of real time fault monitoring environment. Overall, the proposed HWE-PM based framework offers an interpretable and scalable predictive maintenance solution aligned with the requirement of Industry 4.0 environments.

title: Interleaver design for parallel concatenated block codes with arbitrary lengths
authors: Vijayasri Sundarapuram Soundayan, Sina Vafi
abstract: Parallel Concatenated Block (PCB) codes are conventionally constituted by two identical linear systematic block codes, as component codes, linked by an interleaver. In general, the interleaver length of the PCB code (or message length) is the square of the message length of the constituent codes. This feature enables the interleaver to distribute bits from a message block across various interleaved blocks. Such a permutation process is not achievable from a PCB code whose interleaver length is shorter than the square of the message length of its component codes. As more than one bit of a message block is placed at an interleaved block, the minimum weight of the PCB code can be obtained from messages with weight greater than one. Such a structure will consequently deteriorate the PCB code's error-correcting performance. To overcome this problem, the paper presents a new scheme of interleavers for PCB codes, whose lengths are multiples but not squares of the message length of PCB's component codes. A permutation algorithm is implemented based on the low-weight distribution of component codes to ensure that the PCB code has an outstanding error-correcting capability. Indeed, the interleaver rearranges message bits such that the minimum weight of the PCB code is obtained from messages with weight one. The analysis and simulation results confirmed that the newly proposed interleaver outperforms the conventional interleavers for PCB codes. The improvement is achieved at medium to high signal-to-noise ratios, where the code's error floor is encountered. It is also concluded that PCB codes constructed using the proposed interleaver outperform the well-known Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC)-polar codes used in global standards. This is evident for long-length-based codes.

title: Development and Performance Investigation of 3D Printed Horn Antenna
authors: R. H. Oliveira, Miguel C Twardowski, E. S. Lima, Arismar Cerqueira Sodré Junior
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work presents a comparative electromagnetic analysis of two horn antennas designed for C-band operation, both sharing the same Computer-Aided Design (CAD) geometry but fabricated with different materials. The first antenna, serving as a reference, was machined from aluminum, while the second was manufactured from ABS thermoplastic using Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) 3D printing technology. Numerical simulations were conducted in ANSYS HFSS to evaluate key performance indicators, including reflection coefficient, gain across frequency, beamwidth, and operational bandwidth. Following simulation, the ABS antenna prototype was internally coated with a high-adhesion conductive silver-based paint to enable high-frequency operation. Practical measurements were then performed on the ABS prototype, including a 5G signal transmission test using the aluminum antenna as the transmitter and the ABS antenna as the receiver. The experimental setup ensured direct line-of-sight between antennas. The study assesses both simulated and measured results, highlighting the influence of the material on antenna performance. The findings demonstrate that, with proper internal coating, polymer-based antennas can approximate the electromagnetic behavior of metallic counter-parts, offering a viable alternative for rapid prototyping and testing in C-band communication scenarios.

title: Automatic Debugging and Testing Strategy for Power Equipment PCB Based on Multi-modal UAV Inspection Data
authors: Chao Li, Dong Zhang, Mingzhu Zhang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: Printed Circuit Boards (PCBs) are critical to power equipment, as faults like overheating, broken traces, or loose components can disrupt the entire power system. Traditional manual debugging and testing are inefficient, high-risk in harsh environments, and inaccurate in fault localization. To address these issues, this paper proposes an automatic debugging method for power equipment PCBs using multi-modal Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) inspection data. A UAV system with multiple sensors collects visible light, thermal imaging, and vibration data, which is processed via a fusion model integrating deep learning and classic computer vision. An automated workflow for fault detection, localization, and debugging is developed, verified through laboratory and on-site tests. This strategy enhances automation and fault detection accuracy, filling the gap of integrating UAV remote sensing, multi-modal data processing, and PCB-specific debugging.

title: Hybrid Boosted Stacking Model for Air Quality Index Prediction in Delhi
authors: K. Naveen Kumar, P. Samundiswary
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: In megacities like Delhi, accurate air pollution forecasting is crucial for public health and urban management. Previous research using Decision Trees with Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO), Support Vector Machines (SVM), LSTM and CNN-LSTM models and other regression techniques has reported moderate accuracy, with $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ usually below 0.95 and RMSE frequently above 25. While ensemble approaches are emphasized in more recent works, they encounter issues with scalability and robustness in dynamic urban environments. This paper suggests a Hybrid Boosted Stacking Ensemble Model with XGBoost as the meta-learner that integrates LightGBM, CatBoost, ExtraTrees, and XGBoost in order to overcome these drawbacks. Prediction is further improved by a preprocessing pipeline that includes polynomial feature expansion, YeoJohnson transformation and feature selection. The model significantly outperformed baseline Bi-LSTM, Bi-RNN and KRR models with $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{0. 9 8 2}$, $\mathbf{R M S E}=\mathbf{2. 6 0}$, MAE $=\mathbf{1. 8 8}$, and MAPE $=1.98 \%$ using Delhi AQI data (2019-2024). The results confirm the model’s robustness and practical utility for real-time AQI forecasting, supporting smart city planning and proactive public health interventions.

title: Polarization-Reconfigurable Loop Antenna for Remote Sensing Radar Systems
authors: Pedro A. B. Leao, Igor F. Da Costa, Arismar Cerqueira S.
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This article presents the development of a circularly polarized antenna for VHF (Very High Frequency) applications, enabling switching between RHCP (Right-Hand Circular Polarization) and LHCP (Left-Hand Circular Polarization) for radar systems. The numerical validation of the proposed antenna was performed using Ansys HFSS software based on the Finite Element Method. Simulated and measured results for impedance matching are presented, with particular emphasis on the influence of a ground plane on the antenna performance. Additionally, gain results for both RHCP and LHCP polarizations are discussed, as well as the impact of phase difference on the antenna's axial ratio.

title: A Data-Driven Framework of PV Hosting Capacity Assessment for a Military Garrison
authors: Lieutenant Colonel Ujjawal Srivastava, P Amritansh Naidu, Ankit Singhal
abstract: This paper investigates the dual challenge of accurate load forecasting and photovoltaic (PV) hosting capacity assessment in a mission-critical power distribution network—Indian Garrison Utility. A comprehensive data-driven framework is proposed, combining machine learning-based day-ahead load forecasting with OpenDSS-based PV hosting capacity analysis. The study leverages two years of high-resolution load data (15-minute intervals), meteorological parameters from Solcast API, and network topology details. Forecasting models including Random Forest, XGBoost, and LSTM were compared; Random Forest showed the best performance. Hosting capacity was evaluated using OpenDSS, considering voltage, reverse flow, and seasonal conditions. The results highlight how future PV integration potential is load-dependent and underscore the role of accurate forecasting in planning. This methodology enables reliable and scalable renewable integration for defense-oriented utilities.

title: Improvement in Picking Operations in Retail Product Warehouse Using Slotting, Multiproduct ABC Segmentation and Lean Warehousing
authors: Juan José Taquia Lora, Brayan Cardenas Ayona, Edilberto Avalos-Ortecho, Silvia Ponce Álvarez
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This study proposes an improvement in picking operations in a retail warehouse through the implementation of the multi-product ABC methodology, storage policies, and lean warehousing validated by the implementation of simulation tools. The initial diagnosis revealed low resource utilization, high order preparation times, and low compliance with the Fill Rate indicator. A simulation model was designed using Arena and Flexsim tools to analyze the current process and evaluate improvement scenarios. The proposed inventory reorganization based on product rotation reduced total preparation time by up to 22%, improved warehouse resource utilization, and increased productivity by 38%. The results demonstrate that the use of slotting and ABC classification techniques significantly contribute to the warehouse's operational efficiency.

title: Suppression of Higher-Order Harmonic Distortions in Rectangular Microstrip Antennas Through Optimized Single-Slot Design
authors: Srijita Chakraborty, Koushiki Ghosh, Srijan Bhattacharya, Malay Gangopadhyay, Anirban Chattopadhyay, Mrinmoy Chakraborty
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: The work presents a microstrip antenna resonating at 5.42 GHz with a single slot along with several features like bandwidth, radiation features, gain and impedance properties of the antenna. In the beginning a simple rectangular antenna was created and simulated in range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(1-15) \text{GHz}$</tex> which showed several higher harmonics. It has a patch which is created on plane of ground. To reduce higher harmonics a different type of cross shaped slot was created that showed reduction in higher harmonics up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 G H Z}$</tex>. The slot was adjusted with suitable dimensions and placed properly in the ground. The antenna showed reduced harmonics above -10dB and had same resonating frequency of 5.42 GHz with return loss of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 3 9} \boldsymbol{.} \mathbf{5 d B}$</tex>. The design method of antenna is described in the paper. Several features like reflection coefficient, impedance and gain properties of created antenna are analyzed and illustrated in paper. The design of antenna and several properties like reflection coefficient,gain,impedance, radiation features are elaborated defining its applications in different areas. The antenna which is created also has improved bandwidth and better isolation. The directivity of the antenna is observed, defining it's efficiency in functioning. The antenna proves to be efficient and effective for a wide range of applications and uses in wireless communications.

title: Virtual Power Generation Fosters the Increase in Customers Engagement with Decentralized Sources
authors: L.M. Daloub, I. H. Sassi
abstract: The accelerating global shift toward clean and sustainable energy has catalyzed the evolution of power systems from centralized architectures to decentralized energy models, particularly through the emergence of virtual power plants and small-scale embedded generation, including rooftop solar PV installations and distributed micro-generators. These decentralized systems play a pivotal role in reducing carbon emissions and enhancing flexibility, resilience, and responsiveness of modern power grids. The integration into legacy distribution networks originally built for one-way, centralized power delivery, presents series of technical and operational challenges. High penetration of distributed energy resources decentralized energy resources introduces bidirectional power flows, voltage instability, and grid management complexities, especially in systems not designed for such dynamic behavior. This paper conducts a comprehensive technical evaluation of decentralized generation integration within a distribution network using DIgSILENT PowerFactory application. The study focuses on critical performance metrics including power flow characteristics, and system reliability, comparing scenarios with and without the presence of small-scale embedded generation. The results underscore both the transformative potential and systemic limitations of decentralized energy resources integration, offering insights into practical strategies for modernizing distribution networks to accommodate a more virtual, sustainable, and smarter energy future.

title: Short-Term Load Forecasting for Energy and Cost Savings: A Case Study
authors: T. Praneeth, Gajangi Arun Kumar, P. Ram Kishore Kumar Reddy, Yemula Pradeep Kumar
abstract: Accurate load forecasting is essential for effective energy planning, operational reliability, and cost optimization. The study analyzes daily energy consumption patterns in an educational institute with a focus on power factor trends, peak demand variations, and phase-wise imbalances, while also evaluating correction strategies such as power factor improvement, load balancing, and peak shifting. The main contributors to electrical load include lighting, HVAC systems, IT equipment in classrooms, laboratory equipment, workshop machinery, pumps, and lifts. A hybrid short-term load forecasting model that combines autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) for capturing seasonal trends and gradient boosting (GB) for learning nonlinear patterns is applied to improve prediction accuracy. The results indicate measurable reductions in peak demand, savings in reactive power, and significant daily cost benefits. The integration of load forecasting with corrective strategies enhances both system efficiency and reliability while supporting data-driven energy management for long-term sustainability in campus environments.

title: An Improved Differential Admittance Based Fault Detection Algorithm for Low Voltage AC Microgrid
authors: Joy Narayan Das, Biswajit Sahoo, Sandeep Banik
abstract: Reliable fault detection in ac microgrids is challenging because of dynamic changes brought by distributed generations as well as varying grid/isolated modes. This paper proposes an enhanced differential admittance-based relaying scheme for fault detection in ac microgrids. Differential admittance (DA) is computed from positive-sequence voltage and current phasors retrieved from both line ends. The absolute value of the Derivative of the Differential Admittance Angle (DADA) is calculated using DA information. It captures sharp transients at fault inception and can be suitably incorporated as a fault indicator enabling fast and robust detection. In our proposed algorithm, a two-bus equivalent model establishes the mathematical framework and evaluates fault scenarios. The devised scheme is implemented and tested for a microgrid testbed integrated with the utility grid, wind farms, solar PV, transformers, and loads. Simulation results show that the DADA index improves sensitivity, enhances fault detection under high-resistance faults, and ensures reliable operation in both grid-connected and islanded modes with variable DG penetration. Compared to existing protection algorithms, our proposed technique demonstrates superior adaptability and robustness, making it a promising solution for microgrid fault detection.

title: A Variational Bayesian-Based Augmented State Joint Estimation Method for Heavy-Tailed Colored Noise
authors: Qianhui Ma, Huijuan Hao
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: The measurement of dynamic system is corrupted by colored noise and involved heavy-tailed characteristics simultaneously for target tracking in practice. Mostly existing work employs the the first-order measurement difference method to resolve the colored noise. In this paper, we augment the colored measurement noise onto the system state vector to whiten the colored noise. To handle the heavy-tailed noise in state model, we model it as the Student’s t distribution, and it is decomposed into a hierarchical Gaussian structure of Gaussian distribution and Gamma distribution. Subsequently, the variational Bayesian method combined with the inverse Wishart prior describing the uncertainty of the scale matrix, is used to achieve the joint posterior estimate of the system state. Then a variational Bayesian and augmented state (VB-AS) joint estimation algorithm is proposed for the state estimate of dynamic system with colored heavy-tailed noise. Illustrative examples verify the validness of the proposed algorithm.

title: Earthquake Energy Prediction Using Liquid Neural Networks
authors: Kavitha B, M Srinivas
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Earthquakes release tremendous amounts of energy, and accurately forecasting this release is crucial for early warning systems and disaster risk mitigation. In recent years, statistical methods have played a key role in analyzing time series data. This paper introduces a novel approach for predicting earthquake energy using a machine learning technique known as the Liquid Neural Network (LNN), applied to seismic datasets. TThe proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art machine learning algorithms, achieving an RMSE of 0.26, an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> score of 0.87, and a MAE of 0.22 on the test dataset.

title: An Intelligent Collaborative Metaheuristic Approach for Task Offloading in MEC Devices Under Cloud Synergy
authors: Santanu Dam, Soumyadeep De, Om Bhattarai, Harshit Agarwal, Kousik Dasgupta, Abir Chattopadhyay
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Cloud computing has grown due to internet advancements in recent years. The Internet, Cloud of Things (IoT, CoT), edge, and fog computing are integrated in modern cloud architecture. These devices generated a lot of client-requested data that must be handled quickly. Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) devices offloaded smartphone tasks to nearby edge servers to speed up execution. Task offloading has become increasingly crucial for accelerating execution, minimizing latency, and conserving energy. Task execution and efficient resource use enhance the Quality of Service (QoS). So, researchers have proposed heuristic and rule-based dynamic offloading policies. However, they typically fail to balance exploring multiple solution spaces and using high-quality solutions, resulting in imbalanced task allocation convergence. In this paper, a machine learningbased method is proposed that uses the Random Forest (RF) classifier to choose Differential Evolution (DE) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). The classifier was trained using several metrics derived from different job sizes. It used the best possible metaheuristic method for the incoming job size. The proposed methodology yielded promising results when compared to several current strategies.

title: Development of Distributed Secondary Control Based on Voltage-Shifting for Hybrid Microgrids
authors: Jhonathan Peowany Silveira, Waner Wodson A. G. Silva, Thiago Ribeiro de Oliveira
abstract: Microgrids emerge as local solutions to integrate distributed generation and storage, operating either connected to or isolated from the main grid. Hybrid microgrids extend this flexibility by integrating different types of sources and loads, while reducing conversion stages. In this context, this paper proposes a hybrid and distributed secondary control strategy based on the Voltage-Shifting method, applied to hybrid microgrids interconnected through a bidirectional interlinking converter. The technique requires the exchange of only one variable per converter through low-bandwidth communication. Each unit shares the variable <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex>, which incorporates output voltage and power quantities, and locally computes the average value from its neighbors. When the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> values converge to the average, the technique restores the dc bus voltage and achieves proportional power sharing among all converters in the microgrid, even across different buses (AC/DC). In addition, it avoids the communication of multiple variables and preserves plug-and-play operation. Simulations in PLECS software confirm its effectiveness under different operating conditions.

title: Investigation of Road Surface in Simulated Environmental Road using LiDAR
authors: MSA Khan, Shehar Yaar, Faisal Rehman, Hassan Elahi, Anas Bin Aqeel
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Road surface study is important for reducing accidents and improving road safety. It is critical for identifiying the road faults and properly localizing their locations for improving road quality and maintenance. The proposed methodology is integrating the sensor data using a sliding window technique to acquire 3D data of the road (similar to 3D LiDAR) and the location of the road using the 2D LiDAR and GPS sensors. Initially, a detailed road surface profile is created by combining five successive LiDAR scans within a sliding window. Building 3D point cloud data (PCD) is an efficient way to identify a road’s profile. The YOLO model is used to identify several types of road faults, including cracks, potholes, and ruts. The GPS sensor provides precise geographic coordinates in the form of latitude and longitude for the detected problems, which is useful for future maintenance and fixing. The Robot Operating System (ROS) environment serves as a simulation for verifying the methods with a differential drive mobile robot. Following simulation findings, it successfully detects ruts, potholes, and cracks. The findings demonstrate that the suggested methodology can successfully localize road problems across a variety of situations.

title: Exploring organisational challenges and enablers in the implementation of the integrated personnel and payroll information system (IPPIS) in Nigeria
authors: Ayesha Adeleye Dupe, Abd. Rahman Ahlan, Najhan Muhamad Ibrahim, Mahfooz Ahmed
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: The Integrated Personnel and Payroll Information System (IPPIS) was introduced by the Nigerian government to promote payroll transparency, reduce fraud, and enhance administrative efficiency. Despite these goals, its implementation faces persistent organizational, technical, and user-related challenges. This study employs a qualitative design using semi-structured interviews with ten key personnel from the Office of the Accountant-General of the Federation to explore the barriers and enablers affecting IPPIS adoption. Findings indicate that data delays, limited ICT skills, system rigidity, and resistance to change impede effective use, while leadership support, training, perceived usefulness, and accountability facilitate adoption. Participants also proposed strategies for improving system design, stakeholder engagement, and sustainability. The study provides ministry-level insights into digital transformation and offers policy recommendations for strengthening public payroll reforms in Nigeria.

title: A Computer Vision-Based Mobile System for Efficient Event Attendance Management Using Quick Response Codes and Facial Recognition
authors: Tri Nhut Do
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of information technology, the integration of digital solutions such as Quick Response codes and facial recognition into event attendance management has become an essential trend to enhance efficiency, security, and user experience. The combined system of Quick Response codes and facial recognition streamlines check-in procedures, minimizes fraud risks, optimizes resource utilization, and elevates the prestige and reputation of events. This research aims to develop a modern, practical system that fosters the application of cutting-edge technology in event organization and customer information management. In this paper, a design of a mobile system leveraging computer vision, incorporating key components such as a camera, a Quick Response code scanner, a Raspberry Pi embedded computer, an LCD, and a loudspeaker, is proposed. The system was tested in various real-world environments, achieving an average check-in time of 20 seconds per user and a false positive rate of approximately 7 %, based on over 88 experiments involving 20 real customers. These results demonstrate the promising potential of the proposed design for future development and implementation.

                    Control Design for Large-Scale Systems Based on Different Graphon Functions
authors: MohammadAli BeladiPour, Jafar Zarei, Mehrdad Saif
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper deals with the integration of graphonbased connectivity models with state-space representations to examine the dynamic behavior of systems as the number of nodes increases. A particular focus is placed on analyzing various graphon functions, such as constant, step, exponential, Gaussian, and periodic, to investigate their influence on system connectivity, scalability, and stability. Furthermore, robust control methodologies, specifically $H_{\infty}$ control, is employed to enhance system performance under disturbances and uncertainties in graphon-based networks. This study provides a comprehensive framework that combines theoretical insights and practical applications, offering new directions for the design and control of large-scale dynamic networks.

title: Resource Scheduling and Application Generalization for a Hybrid In-Memory Graph Mining Architecture
authors: Jiahe Zhu, Xueyan Wang, Jianlei Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Graph mining has become increasingly important in domains such as social network analysis and bioinformatics. Processing-in-memory (PIM) offers high parallelism and reduces costly data transfers by performing logical operations directly in memory. A hybrid architecture combining content-addressable memory (CAM) and PIM leverages the strengths of both, delivering improvements in performance and energy efficiency. However, real-world graphs are highly irregular, and mapping them onto fixed-size PIM arrays leads to underutilized computing resources, limiting overall efficiency. In this work, we remove the fixed-size constraint at the hardware level and propose two task scheduling strategies that adapt dynamically to varying PIM array sizes, significantly improving graph mining throughput. Furthermore, while prior implementations on this hybrid architecture were limited to k-clique counting, we extend its applicability by implementing an enumeration and counting algorithm for sub-graphs with a central node. Experimental results show that our scheduling strategies achieve an average speedup of 3.0 × over the baseline on k- clique counting, while our new algorithm broadens the range of supported graph mining tasks.

title: Transformer-Based Traffic Flow Forecasting: A Survey and Experimental Comparison of Time-Series Analysis
authors: San Van Tran, Viet Hang Duong
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper benchmarks Transformer-based traffic flow forecasting under a unified, leakage-safe protocol at two resolutions (hour and minute) on California PeMS Bay Area data (a limitation; future work will include diverse regions and data sources). Beyond MSE/MAE, we introduce deployment-oriented reporting—Promotion (% vs. a strong baseline), Efficiency (% parameter/latency savings), and estimated peak VRAM—within a shared hyperparameter optimization setup and multi-seed significance testing for fair, reproducible comparison. On hour-level horizons, iTransformer attains the best accuracy at moderate size, while TimeMixer offers the strongest parameter/latency efficiency with competitive error. On minute-level horizons, Crossformer leads beyond \~{}48-96 minutes, whereas iTransformer is strongest at 12-24 minutes. These results yield clear guidance for ITS deployment: choose models by horizon and resource budgets rather than scale alone.

title: A Machine Learning-Driven HVAC Optimization: Occupancy Prediction and Detection at Scale
authors: Justin Vaughan, Amir Ameli, Thangarajah Akilan
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Optimizing the operation of heating, ventilation, and air Conditioning (HVAC) systems is crucial for improving energy efficiency, enhancing user comfort, and maximizing system performance. This paper proposes a machine learning (ML)-based method that leverages environmental sensor data to predict high room occupancy, enabling more efficient HVAC operation. It integrates multiple ML techniques to enhance energy efficiency by minimizing HVAC operation in unoccupied spaces while maintaining occupant comfort. The methodology involves using sensor readings, such as temperature, humidity, light, and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> levels to improve occupancy detection accuracy. It exploits advanced techniques such as synthetic minority over-sampling technique (SMOTE)-Tomek for data balancing, eXtreme Gradient Boosting for robust classification, multi-layer artificial neural networks (ML-ANN) for capturing nonlinear relationships, and long short-term memory (LSTM) models for time-series forecasting. To further improve prediction accuracy, a probabilistic voting classifier is implemented by combining the predictions of the above individual models, leveraging a soft voting mechanism to generate more reliable occupancy forecasts. The results show that the proposed solution achieves highly competitive performance on a publicly available dataset. Index Terms-Ensemble learning, HVAC, machine learning, time series analysis.

title: Analysis and Simulation of ISAR Imaging Based on Parameters Affecting Surface Shape
authors: Abdulbasit Kareem Omran, Adel Saad Emhemmed, Abdulbast Kriama
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive simulationbased investigation of Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar (ISAR) imaging, addressing the critical challenge of achieving optimal image quality and accurate scatterer identification under varying target characteristics. A high-fidelity simulation framework is proposed and validated, which leverages the ANSYS High-Frequency Structure Simulator (HFSS) for electromagnetic scattering analysis, integrated with MATLAB for subsequent signal processing and image formation. The study systematically investigates the influence of five distinct geometric and material configurations using a detailed 3D F16 aircraft model. Results demonstrate that target geometry, surface shape, and material reflectivity are the primary determinants of image clarity and recognition capability. The analysis successfully quantifies dominant scattering centers, identifying the engine ducts as the source of the peak backscatter intensity of 14.591 kW/m<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at a range of 0.6 meters. The findings confirm that high-resolution ISAR imagery is contingent upon precise target design, with the final optimized model achieving superior performance through strategic manipulation of component size and surface structure. This work provides critical insights for applications in radar crosssection (RCS) signature management and automatic target recognition (ATR)

title: A Ku-Band GaN MMIC Power Amplifier with a 47.4% Large-Signal Fractional Bandwidth
authors: Tsai-Rung Hu, Hsin-Chieh Lin, Yin-Cheng Chang, Da-Chiang Chang, Shawn S. H. Hsu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This letter presents the design of a broadband high-power amplifier (PA) employing a novel approach for complex impedance transformation and the technique of de-embedding the output capacitor (C<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">out</inf>) for effective broadband matching network design. By utilizing transformers in the form of the low-pass filter (LPF) within the matching network, a PA fabricated using 0.25-μm GaN technology with a fractional bandwidth up to 47.4%, a maximum output power (P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">out</inf>) of 38.4 dBm, and a peak power-added efficiency (PAE) of 36% is demonstrated.

title: An On-Chip Spiking Neural Network Using Auto-Plasticity Synapses for Unsupervised Learning in Edge AI Applications
authors: Trung-Khanh Le, Trong-Tu Bui, Duc-Hung Le
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: On-chip learning is the most advantageous feature of spiking neural networks (SNNs) that allows realizing lowpower artificial intelligence (AI) systems, especially for the edge computing technique and edge AI devices. Although there is still no principal learning method for SNNs, the spike timingdependent plasticity (STDP) learning rule is the most popular. Most implementations of the method predominantly defined synapses as conductors. This approach results in common on-chip training designs for digital systems that typically require finite state machines (FSMs) and look-up tables (LUTs), which evaluate and update the values of all neurons and synapses within a neural network. This combination limits the responding time of an SNN. An auto-plasticity synapse, which defines plasticity based on spike-time delay and independently controls this property, offers a solution to address this limitation. In this work, we proposed a 4-layer fully-connected SNN that uses 96 auto-plasticity synapses to validate this new type of synapse. This network synthesized into a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 8}-\mathbf{n m}$</tex> field-programmable gate array (FPGA) Cyclone V with just 14.5 % of resources, allowing the making of an edge AI system on a chip (SoC). The SNN was trained unsupervised, totally on-chip, and could classify the 3-class Irish data set with accuracy up to 90 %.

title: BER Performance Evaluation of 8-PSK and 8-APSK in 2X3 MIMO System over Wireless Communication Channel
authors: Hajer F. Dougdoug, Amer R. Zerek
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of the Bit Error Rate (BER) performance of 8-Phase Shift Keying (8PSK) and 8-Amplitude Phase Shift Keying (8-APSK) modulation schemes in a $2 \times 3$ Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) wireless communication system. Simulations are carried out using MATLAB with Simulink over Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) and fading channels (Rician and Rayleigh) for different values of the Energy per Bit to Noise Power Spectral Density Ratio $\left(E_{b} / N_{0}\right)$. The system is analyzed under spatial multiplexing conditions to evaluate the impact of noise and fading on signal quality. Results show that 8-PSK achieves better BER performance than 8-APSK in all tested channel conditions, requiring $3.12-3.45 \mathrm{~dB}$ less $\mathrm{E}_{\mathrm{b}} / \mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{o}}$ to reach a BER of $10^{-6}$. This superior performance is attributed to the robustness of 8-PSK against amplitude variations, making it a more power-efficient and reliable option for wireless systems that demand stable connectivity and efficient data transmission.

title: Optimization of HTS coils for sustainable magnets applied to particles therapy
authors: R. Riccioli, C. Calzolaio, M. Grossmann, A. Louzguiti, D. Meer, G. Montenero, S. Sanfilippo
abstract: Particle therapy is a very promising radiation treatment capable to irradiate tumours with millimetres precision and therefore to spare the neighbouring healthy tissues. The proton therapy market size is expected to keep growing in the next decade, but the size and initial cost still need to face challenges. High Temperature Superconductors (HTS) could be a possible way to enable particle treatment with a reduction of the facility size and the operational costs. However, the extraction of Rare-Earth materials such as the ones used for the most commercialized HTS tapes is extremely pol luting if compared to copper. In that sense, when designing a mag net for an emerging technology, it is important to minimize the environment impact by minimizing the size of the coil. This paper, with the help of a case study, aims at showing how the CO<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>-eq emissions can change as a function of design parameters, such as the current margin and the operative temperature. These emissions are then compared to the ones due to the power consumption. The study is based on the energy selection dipoles of Gantry 1 beamline at the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI).

title: Robust Flood Area Segmentation through Federated Learning on Distributed Remote Sensing Data
authors: Muhammad Saif Ul Islam
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Floods are among the most devastating and frequent natural disasters, often resulting in severe humanitarian, ecological, and economic consequences. Accurate and timely flood mapping is critical for informed emergency response and disaster risk management. While deep learning has significantly advanced flood area segmentation using remote sensing imagery, traditional methods rely on centralized data aggregation, posing substantial challenges due to privacy restrictions, data heterogeneity, and data ownership concerns. This paper presents a federated learning (FL) framework for robust flood segmentation across distributed, multisource remote sensing data. By enabling multiple institutions to collaboratively train models without exchanging raw data, the proposed system preserves data privacy while leveraging the diversity of geographically and sensor-varied datasets. Experimental results show that our federated approach achieves segmentation performance comparable to centralized training and generalizes better across unseen domains. This framework lays the foundation for scalable, privacy-preserving, and operationally viable flood mapping, especially in data-sensitive environments.

title: Web Content Analysis of Malaysia’s Public Library Websites: An Evaluative Study
authors: Nur Leyni Nilam Putri Junurham, Nurhafizah Mahri
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: In the digital era, public libraries are expected to strengthen their online presence to support access, literacy, and community engagement. This study evaluates the websites of 14 Malaysian state public libraries using a checklist-based Web Content Analysis (WCA) under seven categories: accessibility, navigation and links, authority and currency, general information, user support and resource discovery tools, services, and Web 2.0 tools. The results show that overall performance is moderate, with Kuala Lumpur, Selangor, and Sabah achieving the highest compliance, while Perlis, Perak, Pulau Pinang, and Johor lag behind. Strengths include universal WebOPAC adoption, integration of social media platforms such as Facebook and Instagram, and consistent copyright/domain authority. Weaknesses include poor update practices, limited disability features, absence of fair use policies, and minimal adoption of interactive tools such as live chat and feedback systems. The findings highlight that while Malaysian public library websites provide basic access and visibility, they underutilize features essential for inclusivity, interactivity, and user education. This study recommends standardizing website development, enhancing accessibility, and integrating user-centered policies to optimize digital platforms and improve remote library services.

title: Enhancing Transparency in Humanitarian Crowdfunding: A Blockchain and MVC-Based Approach for Non-Profit Organizations in Pakistan
authors: Hanan Munir, Ayesha Rashid Khan, Aimen Qaiser, Touseef Tahir, Bilal Hassan, Hamid Jahankhani, Mohammad Noman
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Crowdfunding is a fundraising process by which money is raised from many people. Each person donates a relatively smaller amount. This is typically done through the online medium. Many crowdfunding sites support donation for humanitarian purposes. These face challenges due to lack of transparency, presence of intermediaries, and centralization. This problem in crowdfunding is solved through the combination of Blockchain Technology and the ‘Model View Controller’ architecture. We conducted a literature review to analyze the reported challenges of Nonprofit Organizations (NPOs). These challenges are validated through a survey among NPOs in Pakistan. The proposed solution overcomes majority of the problems identified in our survey. The smart contracts ensure that all the donations are received directly in NPOs. These Organizations can further use the donations for buying products from allocated ‘E-stores’. Each transaction would be stored in the decentralized ledger. The donors can track the spending of NPOs based on their donation. The ‘MVC architecture’ ensures that there is ‘maintainability’ and ‘separations of the concerns’ as the ‘Blockchain Technology’ is evolving continuously.

title: Towards scalable and low-cost WiFi sensing: preventing animal-vehicle collisions on rural roads
authors: Samuel Ducca, Jeferson Cotrim, Artur Jordão, Cintia Borges Margi
abstract: Rural roads are vital for the transportation of persons and goods, but are vulnerable to animal-vehicle collisions, which cause substantial environmental, economic and public health impacts every year. WiFi sensing has recently emerged as a cost-effective approach to detect hazardous situations on roads, overcoming some limitations of traditional monitoring systems. However, scaling WiFi sensing to cover long road sections introduces challenges, including interference between WiFi nodes and with other protocols operating in the same Industrial, Scientific, and Medical (ISM) bands, such as IEEE 802.15.4. In this work, we present a scalable, low-cost architecture for WiFi-based monitoring of rural roads. We develop and optimize machine learning models for real-time detection and classification of pedestrians, vehicles, and animals using low-cost IoT devices, achieving over 95% accuracy and a miss rate of only 0.7%. We evaluate the models under varied conditions, including different sensor distances, light rain, and previously unseen rural locations, demonstrating robustness across environmental variations. Additionally, we conduct network simulations to assess the coexistence of WiFi sensing with IEEE 802.15.4 communications and perform LoRaWAN experiments in rural environments to validate long-range data transmission. We also release an open dataset containing all evaluated scenarios to support reproducibility and further research. Our results confirm the feasibility of the proposed system in terms of sensing accuracy, network performance, and deployment cost.

title: Analyzing the Role of Mobile Applications and Loyalty Programs in Enhancing Customer Loyalty
authors: Sharon Glowdy Widarto, Iston Dwija Utama
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Due to the rapid digitalization in recent years, many businesses have focused on developing new marketing, service, and distribution methods to maintain business sustainability. Drawing upon the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) as the theoretical foundation, this study employs a quantitative approach to examine the influence of Starbucks mobile applications, loyalty programs, and brand image on customer loyalty. All data was acquired from 355 valid respondents and then used SEM-PLS for further examination. The findings demonstrate that loyalty programs significantly influence customer loyalty, while brand image does not have a significant effect on customer loyalty. Mobile applications, however, have a significant impact on brand image and customer loyalty, indicating an important role. These results highlight the theoretical contribution of extending TAM into the context of mobile applications and loyalty programs in the coffee shop industry, as well as providing practical insights for enhancing customer loyalty. The study suggests that coffee shops can strengthen business sustainability by mobile applications, offering excellent service, and implementing loyalty programs. This study provides both theoretical and practical implications, encouraging future strategies to improve competitive advantage and overall business performance.

title: Signal-Flow-Graph Representation of Weakly Nonlinear Networks and Its Applications
authors: Shuhei Amakawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: Signal flow graphs (SFGs) of linear networks are commonly used for design and measurement formulation. This paper discusses the SFG representation of weakly nonlinear networks based on the poly-harmonic distortion model. SFGs lucidly visualize the interaction between positive- and negative-frequency components and facilitate derivation of useful analytic equations. How to deal with signal sources is also discussed, which was missing in earlier studies.

title: Deadlock-free routing for Full-mesh networks without using Virtual Channels
authors: Alejandro Cano, Cristobal Camarero, Carmen Martinez, Ramon Beivide
abstract: High-radix, low-diameter networks like HyperX and Dragonfly rely on Full-mesh switch cliques and require multiple virtual channels (VCs) to avoid packet deadlocks in adaptive routing. However, VCs introduce significant overhead in terms of area, power, and design complexity, limiting switch scalability. This paper presents TERA (Topology-Embedded Routing Algorithm), a novel proposal that employs an embedded physical subnetwork to provide deadlock-free non-minimal paths without using VCs. In a Full-mesh network, compared to state of the art VC-based approaches, TERA eliminates VCs while maintaining similar latency and throughput. Moreover, TERA can be applied to networks based on Full-mesh such as Dragonfly, Dragonfly+, and HyperX.

title: Performance analysis of an n-channel HfS2 monolayer transistor
authors: Khairul Alam
abstract: We systematically investigate the orientation-dependent transport and device performance of monolayer HfS2 n-channel transistors using self-consistent NEGF-Poisson simulations incorporating electron-phonon scattering. The conduction band exhibits strong valley anisotropy at the high symmetry M-point, leading to significantly different effective masses along the Γ-K and Γ-M transport directions. Our results reveal that the drain current shows almost no directional dependence due to the degenerate contribution from the three equivalent M valleys. However, the low-field electron mobility exhibits a clear anisotropy, with a ratio of ≈ 1.27 between the Γ-K and Γ-M transport directions. A peak transconductance value of 11.2 mS/μm, a lowintrinsic switching delay of 1.5 ps, and an estimated power-delay product of 0.736 fJ/μmhighlight the potential of HfS2 for energy-efficient nanoelectronics. Analysis of phonon-limited power dissipation reveals that only 20% of the total on-state power is dissipated within channel region, while the remaining 80% is released in the leads to maintain thermal equilibrium. Position-resolved power dissipation shows lattice cooling in the channel up to the potential barrier under the gate, followed by lattice heating beyond the barrier.

title: Editorial
