title: Towards Generalist Neural Motion Planners for Robotic Manipulators: Challenges and Opportunities
authors: Davood Soleymanzadeh, Ivan Lopez-Sanchez, Hao Su, Yunzhu Li, Xiao Liang, Minghui Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: State-of-the-art generalist manipulation policies have enabled the deployment of robotic manipulators in unstructured human environments. However, these frameworks struggle in cluttered environments primarily because they utilize auxiliary modules for low-level motion planning and control. Motion planning remains challenging due to the high dimensionality of the robot’s configuration space and the presence of workspace obstacles. Neural motion planners have enhanced motion planning efficiency by offering fast inference and effectively handling the inherent multi-modality of the motion planning problem. Despite such benefits, current neural motion planners often struggle to generalize to unseen, out-of-distribution planning settings. This paper reviews and analyzes the state-of-the-art neural motion planners, highlighting both their benefits and limitations. It also outlines a path toward establishing generalist neural motion planners capable of handling domain-specific challenges. For a list of the reviewed papers, please refer to https://davoodsz.github.io/planning-manip-survey.github.io/.

title: Comparative Chemiluminescence Sensing of Hydrogen Peroxide Using a Miniaturized Chip using Cobalt Catalyst versus Electrogenerated Emission at a Graphite Electrode
authors: Kavita Manekar, Meghana A. Hasamnis
abstract: Hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂) is a critical biomarker involved in oxidative stress and enzymatic pathways, necessitating sensitive and portable detection strategies for biomedical and point-of-care (POC) applications. In this work, we present a comparative study of two chemiluminescence (CL) methodologies on a miniaturized 3D-printed microfluidic chip: catalyst-assisted CL using cobalt chloride hexahydrate and electrogenerated chemiluminescence (ECL) at a graphite electrode. The cobalt-catalyzed CL method provided higher signal output about 85–90 a.u. with a linear range of 0.1–0.9mM, a limit of detection (LOD) of 0.0131mM (13 μM), and a limit of quantification LOQ of 0.043mM (43μM). In contrast, graphite electrode–based ECL achieved linear detection range 0.4–0.9mM, an LOD of 0. 036mM (36 μM) and an LOQ of 0.120mM (120 μM). The time analysis further revealed rapid emission and falloff kinetics, necessary for accurate quantification. The experimental results highlight the tradeoff between catalyst driven CL and electrogenerated ECL, offering valuable insights for the design of compact and reliable biosensing platforms.

title: Pseudo-Label Similarity Graph-Driven Multi-View Contrastive Clustering
authors: Guojie Li, Zhiwen Yu, Kaixiang Yang, Jianming Lv, C. L. Philip Chen
abstract: Multi-view clustering has exhibited exceptional performance by harnessing complementary information and extracting shared semantics across diverse views. However, existing methods still encounter substantial obstacles in exploiting high-quality consensus representation: (i) they typically lack effective guidance mechanisms under unsupervised conditions, leading to suboptimal representation learning, and (ii) they overlook the intrinsic cluster structure when forming sample pairs to align representation across views, conflicting with clustering objectives. To address these issues, we propose a contrastive-based method called Pseudo-Label Similarity Graph-driven Multi-View Clustering (PSGVC). Specifically, to uncover the potential semantic relationships between samples, we construct a pseudo-label similarity graph based on the consensus representation. Then, we design a similarity graph-based contrastive loss, which utilizes the pseudo-label similarity graph as a global supervision signal to guide the optimization of cross-view embedded representation, thereby indirectly improving the quality of consensus representation. Additionally, we propose a weighted cluster-aware contrastive loss to align the consensus representation with view-specific representation. It leverages the cluster structure contained in the pseudo-label similarity graph to achieve cluster-level contrastive learning, further enhancing the quality of the consensus representation. Extensive experimental results show that our PSGVC achieves state-of-the-art clustering performance across multiple datasets.

title: An Adaptive Scoring Framework for Attention Assessment in NDD Children via Serious Games
authors: Abdul Rehman, Ilona Heldal, Cristina Costescu, Carmen David, Jerry Chun-Wei Lin
abstract: This paper introduces an innovative adaptive scoring framework for children with Neurodevelopmental Disorders (NDD) that integrates multiple metrics, such as spatial attention patterns, temporal engagement, and game performance data, to provide a comprehensive assessment of learning that extends beyond traditional game scoring. The framework employs a progressive difficulty adaptation method that focuses on specific stimuli at each level and dynamically adjusts weights to accommodate increasing cognitive load and learning complexity. Additionally, it includes capabilities for temporal analysis, such as detecting engagement periods, rewarding sustained attention, and implementing an adaptive multiplier framework based on performance levels. To avoid over-rewarding high performers while maximizing improvement potential for struggling students, the designed framework features an adaptive temporal impact framework that adjusts performance scales accordingly. We also established a multi-metric validation framework using Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Pearson correlation, and Spearman correlation, along with defined quality thresholds, to assess deployment readiness in educational settings. This research bridges the gap between technical eye-tracking metrics and educational insights by explicitly mapping attention patterns to learning behaviors, enabling actionable pedagogical interventions.

title: High-Efficiency Wideband GaN Power Amplifier MMICs for 6G and SATCOM
authors: Takuma Torii, Shintaro Shinjo, Chenhao Chu, Hua Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: The 7-24 GHz band is now considered as a new spectrum band in the sixth-generation (6G) communication. On the other hand, satellite communication has gained rapidly growing interest to extend the coverage and reliability of wireless communication. This paper reports two high-efficiency wideband GaN PA microwave monolithic integrated circuits (MMICs) for 6G and future satellite communication (SATCOM). The GaN PA MMIC demonstrates a saturated power-added efficiency (PAE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sat</inf>) of 34.6-45.9% with an output power (P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sat</inf>) of 35.1-36.7 dBm from 10 to 16 GHz. Another GaN PA MMIC is designed as a Doherty PA and demonstrates P<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sat</inf> of 34.5 to 37.7 dBm with PAE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sat</inf> of 35.6 to 43.4%, and PAE at 6dB back-off of 28.5 to 31.7% over frequency of 16.5 to 22.5GHz.

title: Blockchain for Decentralized Authentication in IoT Networks Using Digital Certificates
authors: Osama A. Khashan, Nour M. Khafajah, Nachaat Mohamed, Waleed Alomoush, Mohammed Alshinwan
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: With the rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices, securing their communication and authentication has become a critical challenge. Traditional authentication methods struggle in heterogeneous IoT systems due to incompatibility with diverse devices, reliance on centralized models, costly cryptographic operations, and issues with scalability, trust, and single points of failure. To address these challenges, this paper presents a decentralized authentication framework for IoT nodes based on blockchain technology and digital certificates. In this approach, each IoT device is equipped with a digital certificate that authenticates its identity, while the blockchain is used to securely validate these certificates in a decentralized manner. A lightweight blockchain architecture employing a Proof of Stake (PoS) consensus mechanism is proposed to validate nodes’ certificates. The consensus is conducted on these certificates, with blocks created and appended to the chain, reducing the computational and storage overhead of traditional blockchains. By leveraging blockchain’s immutability and transparency, the system enhances IoT node authentication security and integrity while minimizing resource consumption and delays. Designed for heterogeneous IoT systems, the architecture ensures seamless communication, security, scalability, and efficiency.

title: Voice-Controlled Drones for Emergency Response: AI at the Frontline
authors: Swarnamouli Majumdar, Anjali Awasthi, Sonny Kirkley, Biswadip Basu Mallik
abstract: Transformer-based U-Net architectures have demonstrated remarkable advantages in low-light image enhancement, where the long-range dependency modeling improves enhancement performance, yet the substantial computational complexity hinders real-time applications. To address this, we propose HaarReformer, a single-stage low-light enhancement network that integrates Haar wavelets with a lightweight Transformer architecture. To improve computational efficiency, an illumination-guided cross-channel context aggregation module is introduced, which fuses cross-channel context with expanded receptive fields to enhance self-attention, striking a balance between global modeling and computational overhead while achieving linear complexity. For high-frequency information preservation, we construct a Haar wavelet-based downsampling scheme with multi-scale invertible decomposition, enabling representative feature learning. Furthermore, an ultralightweight dynamic upsampling module is introduced for efficient feature reconstruction, leveraging a learnable point sampling mechanism within a plug-and-play framework. Experimental results validate that HaarReformer effectively enhances low-light images with low computational overhead, while demonstrating superior performance in preserving color fidelity, structural integrity, and textural details.

title: Visual Exploration of a Historical Vietnamese Corpus of Captioned Drawings: A Case Study_supp1-3660122.mp4
authors: Kailiang Fu
abstract: This paper presents a case study focusing on the exploratory visual analysis of a unique historical dataset consisting of approximately 4000 visual sketches and associated captions from an encyclopedic book published in 1909-1910. The book, which offers insight into Vietnamese crafts and social practices, poses the challenge of extracting cultural meaning and narrative structure from thousands of drawings and multilingual captions. Our research aims to explore and evaluate the effectiveness of multiple visualization techniques in uncovering meaningful relationships within the dataset while working closely with professional historians. The main contributions of this study include refining historical research questions through task and data abstraction, combining and validating visualization techniques for historical data interpretation, and involving a focus group of historians for further evaluation. These contributions offer generalizable insights for the development of domain-specific visualization tools and support interdisciplinary engagement in historical data visualization and critical digital humanities research.

title: Rethinking Adversarial Robustness: The Role of Input Transformations
authors: Hanh Thi-My Nguyen, Khoa Tran, Quan Minh Phan, Ngoc Hoang Luong
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Although deep neural networks (DNNs) have achieved remarkable success in computer vision, they remain vulnerable to adversarial examples. Numerous studies have evaluated the robustness of vision models, but most generate adversarial images by adding perturbations to transformed inputs (i.e., post-transformation). A recent study investigated a more realistic setting, where perturbations are applied to raw inputs before transformation and model prediction (i.e., pre-transformation). The results suggest that models are generally more robust in this setting, as attackers lack information about the transformation and can only access the raw image, making it more challenging to generate effective perturbations. However, prior work has not provided a comprehensive evaluation across diverse models and attack types. In this paper, we evaluate the robustness of vision models against diverse adversarial attacks under both posttransformation and pre-transformation settings. Experiments on various models and attack methods, including both white-box and black-box attacks, demonstrate that vision models are highly vulnerable to perturbations crafted by white-box attacks under any setting. In contrast, the effectiveness of black-box methods is significantly reduced when shifting from post-transformation to pre-transformation. Notably, vision models suffer no damage from frame-based attacks when perturbations are applied only to raw input images.

title: Design of a Tanned Leather Defect Recognition System Using Multi-Scale Training and Image Augmentation Technique
authors: Erika Justin Furigay, Raiña Isaiah D.V. Javier, Trisha Lenix Nora, Emiel Renz Faminiano, Ryann Alimuin
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Leather manufacturers lose a significant amount of revenue up to $65 \%$ due to the $50-60 \%$ percentage of produced leather hides containing defects. Currently, manual inspection is the fastest leather assessment method averaging 20 seconds but is inconsistent with a low accuracy rate of $65 \%$. Meanwhile, the current technology accuracy has an average of $90 \%$ detection rate. The designed leather defect recognition system is intended for cuts, folds, and stain imperfections. It can perform at an accuracy of $95.46 \%$ under bright and low light setups, $99 \%$ under normal light scenarios, and $97.50 \%$ under no-light with an overall accuracy of $97.73 \%$. The system is both accurate and fast and employs YoloV5s deep learning algorithm using CSPDarknet for image feature extraction, PANet for feature fusion, and Yolo Layer for result classification. The leather defect recognition system was able to achieve an accuracy of 0.9955, F1-Score, mAP, and AP of 0.9932, and a detection time of 5 seconds or less.

title: TIES: Topological Analysis of Literary Character Representations in BERT Through Dimensional Transposition
authors: Apurba Paul, Anupam Rana, Ishan Chattopadhaya, Dipankar Das
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: We propose TIES (Topological Inference for Embedding Spaces), applying topological data analysis to characterspecific BERT representations through dimensional transposition. Unlike traditional approaches treating sentences as points, TIES transposes data so embedding dimensions become points, enabling persistent homology to analyze how dimensions cluster across contexts. We provide a theoretical framework connecting topological features to narrative semantics: H1 loops encode semantic recursion (contradictory traits), H2 voids represent ambiguity spaces, H 0 clusters indicate semantic organization. Analyzing five Mahabharata characters across 12 BERT layers (10,577 instances), we demonstrate significant character differentiation $(\mathrm{F}(4,55)=4.457, \mathrm{p}=0.0034)$ and layer progression. Karna shows strongest hierarchical development (H1: $\mathrm{r}=0.813$, $\mathrm{p}=0.0013; \mathrm{H} 2: \mathrm{r}=0.820, \mathrm{p}=0.0011$), aligning with predictions for complex characters. Robustness validation confirms reliability ($90.1 / 100,95.6 \%$ non-significant differences).

title: Performance Evaluation Metrics Comparison Between Weka and Google Colab for Predicting Type1 and Type2 Diabetes Using Machine Learning Algorithms on Egyptian Dataset
authors: Saida O. Said, Nurul Liyana Binti Mohamad Zulkufli, Asmarani Binti Ahmad Puzi, Asadullah Shah
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Diabetes is the among the chronic diseases which is every year the number of deaths increases globally in diabetes patients. While Egypt had carried the 8<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> position in diabetes and the number is suggested to rise to approximately 13.1 million by 2035. Additionally, for the Type1 and Type2 diabetes patients has been high in Egypt, whereby the early prediction using Machine learning is needed. Therefore, the main aim of this study is to compare two software that are WEKA and Google Colab in prediction of Type1 and Type2 diabetes using different algorithms on Egyptian Dataset, whilst the dataset has been categorized using three different age groups such as Early adulthood, Middle age and Geriatric. Six algorithms were used, which were Naïve Bayes, Random Forest, Decision Tree, Random Tree, AdaBoost and Bagging and as a performance evaluation metrics, the accuracy, precision, recall, F1 measure and ROC were used. In the experimental results, it has been shown that the Random Forest had the highest accuracy of 0.936 on the Early Adulthood group, Decision Tree of Accuracy 0.930 and 0.794 for the Middle age and Geriatric age groups respectively using WEKA software. As for the google Colab, Random Forest had highest accuracy for all age groups of 0.9742, 0.9491 and 0.9043. In conclusion, Google Colab had the better overall evaluation performance than WEKA.

title: Energy Efficiency Maximization Based on Orthogonal Multiple Access Assisted Intelligent Reflecting Surfaces Enabled Unmanned Aerial Vehicle 6G Network
authors: Fariea Khalid, Umar Ghafoor
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Intelligent Reflecting Surfaces (IRS), is a promising technology which is energy efficient and provides high data rate. Therefore, it is considered a suitable candidate in Sixth Generation (6G) wireless communication system. In 6G systems, the widespread adoption of communication equipment necessitates line-of-sight (LoS) communication, especially in urban areas. Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) can serve as an aerial Base Station (BS) and provide coverage to locations where the Line of Sight (LoS) communication link between users and BS is hindered by obstacles. UAVs offer flexibility, and careful trajectory planning enhances their Energy Efficiency (EE). This work focuses on maximizing the EE of a UAV communication system incorporating IRS in a Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA) framework by jointly optimizing user power, phase shifts of IRS, and UAV trajectory using the Sequential Convex Approximation (SCA) method. Simulation results show that the proposed outperforms in terms of EE over conventional TDMA-enabled UAV system without IRS.

title: FingerWrap: A High-Density Finger-Enveloping Tactile Display
authors: Yusuke Ujitoko, Haruto Kurosawa, Koichi Hirota
abstract: Touch enables humans to recognize the location, motion, shape, and properties of contacted objects in the real world through mechanoreceptors distributed widely across the skin. However, existing tactile displays typically stimulate only the ventral surfaces of the fingers and hands, limiting the range and richness of touch-based interactions in interactive systems. Here, we present FingerWrap, a high-density pneumatic pin-array display that wraps around the finger and activates the widely distributed mechanoreceptors. FingerWrap uses 337 pins arranged at 13 pins/cm<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula>, which cover the ventral, dorsal, and lateral surfaces of the finger up to 45mm from the fingertip, enabling precise spatiotemporal stimulation across continuous regions of the finger skin. Across six perceptual experiments, we show that FingerWrap can provide tactile experiences that ventral-only displays cannot achieve. These include the discrimination of stimulus locations and motion trajectories across multiple regions of the finger skin, the recognition of three-dimensional shape features, and the perception of realistic resistance when the finger is immersed in virtual liquids. This display, which enables a rich and realistic touch experience, could serve as a platform for exploring novel tactile interactions and basic scientific research.

title: Adaptive Fractal Representation Learning for Data-Efficient Materials Property Prediction
authors: Xue Qiyang, Wei Jiang
abstract: Predicting material properties is a cornerstone of materials discovery but remains challenging for geometrically complex crystals (e.g., those with large unit cells or low symmetry), where conventional descriptors fail to capture multiscale structural irregularities and graph-based models incur high computational costs. Existing approaches often struggle to balance representational expressivity with data efficiency. In this study, we propose FractalNet-Plus, a dual-branch architecture that addresses this gap by combining domain-informed geometric features with multiscale fractal characterizations. Our method extracts six complementary fractal metrics—box-counting, mass, correlation, and information dimensions, lacunarity, and multiscale entropy—applying adaptive weighting to identify the most informative scales. Evaluations on complexity-filtered subsets of five Matbench tasks (thermodynamic stability, band gap, shear modulus, perovskite band gap, 2D exfoliation energy) demonstrate that our hybrid representation consistently improves accuracy, achieving MAE reductions of 17% for thermodynamic stability and 13% for band gaps compared to state-of-the-art baselines. For geometrically complex crystals, FractalNet-Plus achieves substantially lower prediction error while using fewer parameters and training more efficiently than graph neural networks, offering a computationally efficient and interpretable approach for materials property prediction.

title: Survey-Free Indoor Localization via Cooperative RSS and Learning-Based DOP Estimation
authors: Mohamed M. Atia, Soroush Sheikhpour
publish: IEEE Journal of Indoor and Seamless Positioning and Navigation
abstract: This paper presents an automated wireless indoor localization system that eliminates the need for site surveying and reduces the dependency on complete anchors' location knowledge. The proposed approach leverages cooperative Received Signal Strength (RSS) measurements and a hybrid logarithmic path-loss model to automatically localize network anchors and build radio maps that can be used to localize user nodes. Starting from a limited initial number of known anchor nodes, position estimates are propagated to the rest of the network using an iterative strategy guided by a learning-based Dilution of Precision (DOP) metric. To address the challenge of unknown anchor locations at initialization, a novel Gaussian Process Regression (GPR)-based method is introduced to estimate the DOP values without requiring ground-truth coordinates. This enables a self-organizing deployment process that adapts to varying indoor deployments. The system is validated through Cramér–Rao Lower Bound (CRLB) analysis, simulations, and real-world experiments in ZigBee-based networks. Results demonstrate a root-mean-square localization error of 3 meters in a typical indoor 15m x 30m office environment covered by seven partially known anchors without prior site survey using only RSS measurements, providing a balance between cost, deployment complexity, and localization accuracy. The code and data of the work has been made available on GitHub on the following link: https://github.com/SensorFusionBook/SensorFusionProjects/tree/ main/IndoorPositioningProject

title: Sharpe Based Portfolio Optimization Using Slime Mould Algorithm
authors: Abhishek Das, Soudipta De, Siddhartha Bhattacharyya, Jan Platos, Vaclav Snasel, Ivan Zelinka
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The bio-inspired metaheuristics have evolved as effective alternatives to handle portfolio optimization problems, which remain a key instrument in investment analysis. This study proposes the adoption of the Slime Mould Algorithm (SMA) to address the portfolio optimization problem with the objective of maximizing the Sharpe ratio under Lintner’s framework of short selling. The SMA-based portfolio optimization is performed on two distinct datasets from the NASDAQ and the NSE, with optimal parameter settings fine-tuned using Sobol’s sensitivity analysis and random and grid search methods. Rigorous benchmarking experimentation against three widely used metaheuristics, the Genetic Algorithm (GA), the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), and the Differential Evolution (DE), over multiple independent runs, demonstrates the performance superiority of SMA over others. Statistical tests like the KruskalWallis H test and the post-hoc Dunn’s test also confirm a significant performance difference among the four algorithms. The study concludes the reliability and effectiveness of SMA in Sharpe-based portfolio optimization.

title: Multi-Layer Stacking Ensemble AutoML Architecture for Social Media Bot Detection using AutoGluon Framework
authors: Adwitiya Sinha, Bhawna Saxena, Suruchi Sabherwa
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Social bots compromise the integrity of online platforms by automating content dissemination and manipulating public opinion. This paper presents a multi-layer stacking ensemble AutoML architecture for social bot detection, implemented using the AutoGluon framework. The proposed approach incorporates data pre-processing, feature selection, model deployment, hyper-parameter optimization, and ensemble generation, thus enabling efficient pipeline construction with minimal manual intervention. A publicly available Twitter dataset containing profile metadata and activity-based features is used for model training and evaluation. Experimental results demonstrate that the multilayer stacking ensemble achieves improved accuracy with better precision, recall, and F1-score compared to individual base learners, while significantly reducing development time. For experimentation a range of 14 machine learning and deep learning models were customized with multi-layer stacking and hyper parameterization. The result shows LightGBMXT model to perform the best with a validation accuracy of 99.2% and a balanced execution time of 0.0071 seconds. Also, we examined a feature-wise study using an incremental t-SNE evolution to justify the selection of features for bots identification. This work highlights the effectiveness and scalability of ensemble-based AutoML solutions for dynamic, large-scale social bot detection in evolving online social environments.

title: Convolutional Neural Network-Based Bird Sound Detection in a Forest Area with Reference to the Argumentation of Data
authors: Amritangshu Das, Murari Shaw
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This paper presents bird song detection using a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). The structure of CNN is vividly described, and the importance of CNN is highlighted in this paper. The amount and quality of bird songs that can be detected using CNN help to understand the ecological balance of the ecosystem. The data that has been used for training of machine and for proper prediction to get accurate results are collected from the kernel. The structure of CNN consists of an Input layer, a Convolutional Layer, a Pooling Layer, a fully connected Layer, and an Output Layer. This work aims to find the species of birds found in the American subcontinent by detecting the birds' songs. In this work, the data argumentation is done with the help of pitch shifting, volume adjustment, and masking of frequency, and the technologies used are Spectrograms and Mel-Frequency Cepstral Coefficient.

title: Adaptation of CDN at the Edge Using Cloud-Native Network Telemetry Across Media Scenarios
authors: Javier Iglesias, Felipe Mogollón, Iñigo Tamayo, Zaloa Fernández, Olov Danielsson, Ivan Pretel, Asier Lopez
abstract: This paper investigates the potential of Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC)-enabled architectures to expand Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) features by exploiting real-time telemetry across the radio access, core, and edge layers. We present experimental results from three representative use cases each posing distinct challenges in terms of mobility, traffic surges, and content pre-positioning. The proposed system leverages telemetry-informed decisions to orchestrate CDN resources dynamically, including a Proxy for Local Cache and Segment Prefetching to reduce latency and improve delivery predictability, a Multi-CDN Steering Proxy that selects optimal content paths based on live Quality of Service (QoS) metrics, and an Orchestrator for Proxy Scaling and Load Balancing that ensures elastic resource adaptation in response to demand fluctuations. These capabilities collectively enable low-latency, resilient media delivery even under network congestion conditions. The experimentation also conducts the identification of key operational challenges for MEC-based CDN deployments, including virtualization gaps, lack of telemetry standards, proxy discovery limitations, and cross-domain orchestration needs critical for scalable and interoperable 5G streaming solutions. This paper provides a practical evaluation of telemetry-driven MEC-based CDNs, offering insights to guide future designs and standardization for reliable, immersive streaming in next-generation cloud-native networks.

title: MaxMpox-Det: A Dual-Input Transformer-Based Model for Mpox Skin Lesion Detection
authors: Tran Nguyen Quynh Tram, Hoang The Vinh, Nguyen Thanh Binh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Early and accurate identification of mpox skin lesions is critical for clinical diagnosis, treatment planning, and outbreak containment. In this paper, we propose MaxMpox-Det, a dual-input object detection model designed for robust localization of mpox lesions in clinical and dermoscopic images. The model processes both raw RGB and CLAHE-enhanced images through parallel MaxViT-Tiny encoders to extract complementary color and contrast-aware features. These features are fused in a stage-wise manner and refined using multi-head self-attention, enabling the network to capture both fine-grained lesion details and global contextual patterns. A Feature Pyramid Network (FPN) and a Cascade R-CNN head further enhance multi-scale detection and bounding box precision. Evaluated on a custom mpox dataset, MaxMpox-Det achieved an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m A P {@} 0.5$</tex> of 0.852, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m A P {@}[0.5: 0.95]$</tex> of 0.472, and an F1-score of 0.850, outperforming several state-of-the-art baselines. These findings underscore the effectiveness of dual-stream input and attention-based feature fusion in advancing medical object detection tasks.

title: Innovative AI Agent with LLM: A Breakthrough Personalized News Aggregation System for the Vietnam Crypto Financial Market
authors: Hao Phu Phan, Khiem Vinh Tran
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Vietnam's rapid adoption of cryptocurrency and pioneering regulatory reforms have created a dynamic yet underserved market for personalized financial information. The need for reliable, up-todate news is critical for both policymakers and market participants, especially as digital technologies accelerate and regulatory demands grow. To address these challenges, we propose a novel AI Agent system powered by Large Language Models (LLMs) and RetrievalAugmented Generation (RAG), designed to deliver personalized news aggregation and address information overload for Vietnamese users. Our framework integrates OpenAI's GPT-4 with advanced recommendation algorithms such as MINER and Prompt4NR, and utilizes two specialized datasets-VOZ FINANCE and VOZ CRYPTO-sourced from the VOZ forum, covering over 4,000 articles and 130,000 user interactions. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that Prompt4NR significantly outperforms baseline models, achieving an AUC of 0.7990 on the cryptocurrency dataset and a 31.5 % improvement over MINER, while the Agentic RAG system achieves high context recall for real-time news synthesis. This research highlights the potential of scalable, AI-driven news recommendation systems to support informed decision-making and regulatory compliance in emerging digital economies, particularly in low-resource language settings.

title: Risk, Readiness, and Return: Rethinking the North American Connected Vehicle Deployment Strategy
authors: David G. Michelson, Ali Rastegar
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Successful adoption of a new technology often relies as much on effective policy as it does on technical contributions. Despite near universal agreement that mandatory deployment of connected vehicle (CV) technology and the exchange of vehicle position and status information through Basic Safety Messages (BSMs) could significantly improve road safety, reduce traffic congestion, and streamline commercial vehicle operations, North American lawmakers have not yet been persuaded that the benefits outweigh the deployment challenges. To date, proponents have focused on the possibility of using the technology to prevent road accidents and traffic fatalities by drawing a driver’s attention to hazardous situations and instigating corrective action. Here, we argue that extending the use of BSM data to road safety analysis and traffic management considerably enhances the value proposition and makes the case for mandatory deployment even more compelling. We further argue that a three-stage approach to connected vehicle technology deployment that prioritizes low-risk but high-readiness applications will maximize return to stakeholders, minimize operational risk, and increase confidence in the technology. Finally, we argue that conventional approaches to assessing technology readiness are not adequate here, and propose an alternative way to assess deployment readiness.

title: Natural Evolution Strategy for Camouflaged Adversarial Patches
authors: Duc Viet Bui, Chi Duc Luu
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Adversarial patch attacks pose a serious threat to deep learning systems, particularly in security-critical applications where patches can be physically deployed. Recent work such as CamoPatch has shown that camouflaged, visually inconspicuous patches can fool classifiers while remaining stealthy to human observers. However, CamoPatch relies on a fixed mutation stepsize in its evolutionary strategy, which limits efficiency and adaptability under black-box constraints. In this paper, we present NES-CamoPatch, an extension of CamoPatch that integrates antithetic gradient estimation from Natural Evolution Strategies (NES) with gradient-guided mutation in the patch parameter space. By periodically invoking NES, our method leverages queryefficient gradient information while retaining the robustness of mutation-based search. This hybrid design balances exploration and exploitation, reducing query costs without sacrificing visual stealthiness. Extensive experiments on ImageNet and CIFAR-10 demonstrate that NES-CamoPatch achieves equal or superior attack success rates compared to state-of-the-art baselines, while maintaining stealthiness. These results highlight the effectiveness of combining evolutionary search with NES guidance for blackbox adversarial patch optimization and point toward promising extensions to real-world physical attacks.

title: Operational Bottleneck Analysis for Sending-End Power Systems with High Renewable Penetration
authors: Renshun Wang, Yiqing Liao, Shilong Wang, Guangchao Geng, Quanyuan Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: With high proportion of renewable energy integration, challenges in power balance and renewable accommodation in sending-end power grids have become prominent, increasing the demand for flexible regulation resources. This work conducts a multi-dimensional operational bottleneck analysis for a sendingend power grid in Northwest China. Operational restriction indicators are introduced to quantitatively characterize multidimensional bottlenecks affecting power balance and system security. A bottleneck identification model is then developed, incorporating constraints such as power balance and spinning reserve capacity. Using current operational and long-term planning data, the identified bottleneck scenarios are categorized and analyzed based on restriction indicators. Sensitivity analysis examines the effects of wind-solar mix and demand response capacity on operational bottlenecks. The results indicate that renewable curtailment scenarios primarily occur during high power output periods, such as spring and autumn, while power supply shortages are concentrated in the heating season.

title: BiSRA: Binarized Super-resolution Accelerator with Hierarchical Design
authors: Jiaying Geng, Yongmeng Ye, Zhi Qi, Hao Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Real-time super-resolution (SR) on resource-constrained edge devices is hindered by the high computational and memory demands of deep SR networks. To address this, we propose BiSRA, a co-design of binary super-resolution algorithms and hardware accelerators optimized for end-side FPGA platforms. We propose BSRResNet, a hardware-friendly binarized network that reduces the computation by 40% with minimal loss of PSNR. A grouped layer-fusion dataflow minimizes off-chip memory access, and a LUT-based XNOR-POPCOUNT module eliminates DSP usage. The design achieves 40 FPS for ×4 FHD super-resolution on the Xilinx ZCU104 platform at 200 MHz, using only 10% of the DSP resources compared to previous work.

title: Conflict-Free Block Pipelining for FPGA-Accelerated Stochastic Simulated Bifurcation on Dense Ising Models
authors: Sijie Xu, Qifeng Liao, Honglan Jiang, Jie Han, Siting Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: The Ising model provides an efficient framework for solving combinatorial optimization problems. Stochastic simulated bifurcation (sSB) is a parallel numerical method that can rapidly find solutions to the Ising model. However, stochastic bit operations in sSB are not inherently supported by general-purpose CPU or G PU architectures. In contrast, the fine-grained reconfigurable structure of FPGAs makes it well suited for implementing stochastic bit operations and enabling large-scale parallel updates of spin states. This paper presents an FPGA-based sSB architecture that fully exploits the strengths of FPGAs through three innovations: bit-width-optimized stochastic arith-metic, symmetric matrix compression, and conflict-free block traversal. As a result, the proposed architecture achieves high performance on a single FPGA chip for a 2000-node max-cut problem, with reduced data movement and improved computational efficiency. On a Xilinx XC7Z020 FPGA operating at 71 MHz and 1.6 W, the solution reaches 99 % of the optimal cut value with >50% probability in 1.1 ms.

title: Hedonic Requirements Are Critical to Creative Computing Project Success
authors: Barry Hawkey, Marie Vans
abstract: Hedonic requirements, which specify a user’s intended emotional response, are critical to success in many types of software, games, and interactive experiences. By surveying over 300 IT project managers, we reveal a strong link between their perception of these requirements and project success, highlighting the need for better methods to manage emotional goals.

title: Stable-Hair v2: Real-World Hair Transfer via Multiple-View Diffusion Model
authors: Kuiyuan Sun, Yuxuan Zhang, Jichao Zhang, Jiaming Liu, Wei Wang, Nicu Sebe, Yao Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: While diffusion-based methods have shown impressive capabilities in capturing diverse and complex hairstyles, their ability to generate consistent and high-quality multi-view out puts—crucial for real-world applications such as digital humans and virtual avatars—remains underexplored. In this paper, we propose Stable-Hair v2, a novel diffusion-based multi-view hair transfer framework. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to leverage multiple-view diffusion models for robust, high-fidelity, and view-consistent hair transfer across multiple perspectives. We introduce a comprehensive multi-view training data generation pipeline to generate high-quality triplet data, including bald images, reference hairstyles, and view-aligned source-bald pairs. Our multi-view hair transfer model integrates polar-azimuth embeddings for pose conditioning and temporal attention layers to ensure smooth transitions between views. To optimize this model, we design a novel multi-stage training strategy consisting of Pose-Controllable Latent IdentityNet training, Hair Extractor training, and Temporal Attention training. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method accurately transfers detailed and realistic hairstyles to source subjects while achieving seamless and consistent results across views, significantly outperforming existing methods and establishing a new benchmark in multi-view hair transfer. Code is publicly available at https://github.com/sunkymepro/StableHairV2.

title: Joint Transmit Beamforming and Phase Shift Design for RIS and NOMA Assisted Wireless Caching Systems with Non-Linear Energy Harvesting
authors: Xuewei Zhang, Yapeng Zhang, Yuan Ren, Fan Jiang, Junxuan Wang, Jie Zeng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Green Communications and Networking
abstract: This paper studies a new reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) aided wireless caching system. The RIS is equipped with a smart controller, and the functions of content caching and energy harvesting (EH) are endowed to the controller. We design a two-phase transmission policy. In the first phase, the requested contents that are not cached are delivered by the base station (BS) to RIS, and the controller conducts EH from surrounding radio frequency signals. In the second phase, the controller distributes cached contents utilizing non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) transmission with harvested energy, while the RIS forwards fetched contents sent from the BS to users. The beamforming vectors of the BS, RIS phase shifts, and NOMA power allocation factors are jointly optimized to maximize the achievable sum rate. The problem is intractable owing to coupled variables. After using the methods of fractional programming and quadratic transformation, we divide it into three sub-problems. The first sub-problem is solved by introducing auxiliary variables; the second one is addressed using the Riemannian manifold optimization; and the third one is converted to be convex by transforming the quality of service constraint. The sub-optimal solutions are achieved by alternatively solving the sub-problems. Simulation results reveal that the problem converges quickly, and the proposed algorithm outperforms benchmarks in terms of the sum rate.

title:
Conductor and Winding Pack Design for DEMO LAR TF Coil Based on React&Wind Nb
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Sn Flat Cable
authors: Kamil Sedlak, Pierluigi Bruzzone, Jack Greenwood, Xabier Sarasola, Valentina Corato
abstract: A new EUROfusion DEMO baseline, defining the size and main parameters for the possible future European tokamak, has been released in 2024. Compared to the previous DEMO baseline from 2018, the machine size and performance have been slightly reduced, relaxing the requirements on the magnet design. This gives us an opportunity to review the design of the DEMO toroidal-field coils, to optimize the cross-sections of all winding-pack components, and to investigate the impact of the reduced performance requirements on the TF coil radial build and manufacturing costs. Two main coil designs are under investigation by the DEMO magnet team. One of them is ITER-like, applying the existing technology to the scaled-up DEMO coils. In our contribution we explore the second option of the coil design based on flat rectangular react&wind Nb3Sn cable enclosed in a steel jacket. The winding pack is graded, layer wound and without radial plates, leading to a cost-efficient design both in the required amount of material, as well as in the simplifications in the conductor and coil assembly.

title: Identification and Exploitation of Critical Lines through Targeted LR Attacks
authors: V. Bharat Kumar, Satish Sharma
abstract: The power grid is a crucial infrastructure susceptible to multiple cyber threats, notably false data injection attacks (FDIA). These attacks manipulate sender data, causing the System Operator (SO) to receive and operate based on falsified information. This can lead to erroneous dispatch decisions, posing a risk to the power grid. Hence, there is an imperative need for enhanced study of cyber threats in smart grids to establish the appropriate countermeasures. This paper introduces a novel problem formulation to identify the power grid system’s critical lines under a Load Redistribution (LR) attack. Additionally, a bi-level attack model is developed to target these identified lines and evaluate system vulnerability. The approach is validated on the IEEE 14-bus test system, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proposed method in identifying critical line and quantifying the operational impact of LR attacks.

title: Directional Overcurrent Relay Coordination in a Microgrid Environment by using Genetic Algorithm, and Breeder Genetic Algorithm
authors: Ravindra Mankar, Pranav Darji
abstract: Optimal relay settings are crucial to guarantee fast fault clearance in the shortest possible operation time with optimal relay coordination. Traditional optimization techniques, namely LP and NLP, have slow convergence, difficulty in constraints handling, and the requirement of algorithm-specific control parameters during relay coordination. However, their performance is often limited by the highly nonlinear nature of the problem in the DG-penetrated system. This paper proposed a BGA to improve the optimal coordination of DOCRs with a system penetrated with DGs. The effectiveness of both GA and BGA is assessed on the IEEE 14-bus system operating with DGs that have been modeled and simulated using ETAP, and a MATLAB program has been developed to achieve optimal coordination of DOCRs. The objective is to reduce the overall operational time of primary relays and to optimize relay coordination under defined constraints. Mean simulation time per run, without DGs, becomes 34.0739 sec and 8.0647 sec, and with DGs, 21.8931 sec and 7.8175 sec, respectively, by implementing GA and BGA. Hence BGA gives a lower total CTI between P/B relay pairs compared to GA.

title: “Use of Horsehair Fibers to Control Plastic Shrinkage Cracking in Concrete”
authors: Lucía Mercedes Guerra Lagos, Carlos Omar Lizárraga Robles, Ana Victoria Torre Carrillo
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This study evaluates the effect of incorporating natural horsehair fibers into concrete mixtures as a strategy to mitigate plastic shrinkage and reduce crack formation in the fresh state. The fibers were preconditioned by cutting, washing, and drying, using a standard length of 2.5 cm. Four concrete mixtures were designed with varying fiber contents (0 %, 0.5 %, 1.0 %, and 2.0 %), maintaining a constant water-to-cement ratio of 0.50. Workability, temperature, and density were assessed in the fresh state, and prismatic specimens were prepared and subjected to accelerated drying conditions according to ASTM C1579-13. Additionally, cylindrical specimens and standard beams were fabricated to evaluate the mechanical properties of hardened concrete at 7, 14, and 28 days. The results showed a 37.5% reduction in the surface crack width with a 2.0 % fiber content, without significantly affecting compressive strength, while flexural strength improved. It is concluded that the use of horsehair fibers represents a viable, accessible, and sustainable alternative to control plastic shrinkage and enhance the early durability of concrete, while promoting the use of low-impact natural materials.
