title: Privacy-preserving Sentiment Analysis using Federated Deep Learning
authors: Ramesh Wadawadagi, Parutagouda Khanagoudar, Shrikant Tiwari
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) offers an efficient framework for local devices to train a global model collaboratively, while authorizing users to control their data locally. In this research work, an efficient Federated Deep Learning (FDL) framework is proposed for estimating users’ sentiments toward a specific topic, product, or service. More precisely, we employed Deep Learning (DL) models to train decentralized devices using FL that maintains data locally without transferring the raw data during training. Nevertheless, the non-IID genre of the data when distributed among multiple clients renders FL a challenging task. To address this, we employed an efficient Quantity-level Dirichlet Allocation strategy for data distribution among multiple clients. Two DL models have been trained, namely, LSTM and BERT, using the proposed FDL framework on local datasets. For model aggregation, a robust aggregation strategy called FedMedian is used, which efficiently handles non-IID data. The efficiency of the proposed framework is estimated using two distinct sentiment datasets: (i) Sentiment140 dataset and (ii) Yelp reviews dataset. The experimental outcomes illustrate that the proposed model surpass centralized learning on both coarse (two-class) and fine-grained (five-class) sentiment classification tasks. Further, the models are evaluated on a secure aggregation environment integrated with the proposed FL framework. The study reports that the model’s performance is consistent with secured aggregation, ensuring data privacy.

title: Key Insights from Security-Constrained Economic Dispatch: A Case Study for Uttar Pradesh
authors: Nishant Kumar, Abheejeet Mohapatra, Prabodh Bajpai, Swathi Battula, Sushil Kumar Soonee, Arun Kumar Mishra, Sangeeta Sangeeta
abstract: Security-Constrained Economic Dispatch (SCED) ensures secure and economic supply of electricity from the set of committed generators to the aggregated forecasted load. In India, each state is equipped with State Load Dispatch Center (SLDC) to handle the intra-state loads from available generators. Uttar Pradesh uses the merit-order approach to schedule the available set of committed generators for the predicted load. A related case study for Uttar Pradesh is presented in this paper to understand the SCED benefits. This case study retroactively does Linear Programming (LP)-based SCED. Also, the classical SCED has been modified to include the commitment status of the generators, which aids in considering related administrative decisions. This analysis includes the marginal prices of load-generation balance, generators’ minimum, maximum, and ramp limits. Compared to the merit-order approach, LP-based SCED provides key insights regarding compensation or tariffs to be charged by Uttar Pradesh to individual generators, if needed, for altering the limits of the related generation constraints, including ramp limits. Lastly, the LP-based SCED analysis automatically considers each generator’s economics and provides a global optimal solution owing to the linear SCED model.

title: Design and Performance Study of Transformer Oil Moisture Content Detection Sensor Based on Metamaterial
authors: Shuang Wang, Liuyu He, Yue Chen, Qian Cao, Lingjun Zeng, Boyu Han, Siyu Du, Jiale Mao, Yu Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Transformer oil plays a vital role in oil-immersed transformers, with its condition and performance directly impacting the operational efficiency and service life of the transformer. This paper proposes a metamaterial-based sensor for detecting water content in transformer oil. By measuring the resonance frequency difference at varying water concentrations, the sensor enables detection at low moisture levels. The sensor comprises a microstrip transmission line and metamaterial resonator unit. Simulation of different resonator structures determined that a four-arm resonator configuration yields optimal sensor performance. Physical testing of the designed sensor using a network analyzer revealed that as water content increased from 0 ppm to 300 ppm, the sensor's resonant frequency decreased from 5.876 GHz to 5.8 GHz, exhibiting a linear relationship. The sensor designed in this paper is capable of detecting the moisture content of transformer oil with an accuracy of 50 ppm. This verifies the feasibility of using this sensor for the detection of transformer oil moisture content, providing a new solution for the condition monitoring of transformer oil.

title: Class-Incremental Transfer Learning Method for Cross Domain Lifelong Intelligent Diagnosis
authors: Cuiying Lin, Leijun Shi, Kangkang Zhao, Junhui Qi, Haiqiang Wang, Yun Kong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: In the long-term operation and service of machinery, new fault modes continuously emerge, placing higher demands on the continual learning and intelligent diagnostic capabilities of fault diagnosis models. Intelligent diagnosis driven by class-incremental learning offers a promising approach to ensuring safe operation throughout the equipment lifecycle. However, existing class-incremental learning methods fall short in addressing the challenge of efficient incremental transfer diagnosis under cross operating conditions. To overcome this limitation, this paper proposes a cross domain intelligent diagnostic method driven by class-incremental transfer diagnostic (CITD). Firstly, a novel knowledge distillation strategy is developed to mitigate catastrophic forgetting in incremental transfer diagnostic scenarios. Then, a generalization training and fast adaptation strategy is introduced to improve the generalization ability of the model for incremental transfer diagnosis. Experimental validation on a subway train transmission system dataset demonstrates that the proposed CITD method effectively adapts to cross-domain incremental transfer diagnosis tasks, delivering superior performance and outperforming several state-of-the-art class-incremental learning methods.

title: Cryogenic CMOS RF AWGs for qubit control
authors: S. Chakraborty, M. Kossel, M. Brändli, P.A. Francese, M. Prathapan, P. Rosno, M. Yeck, J. Bulzacchelli, D. Frolov, D. Frank, R. Richetta, T. Schmerbeck, D. Ramirez, C. Baks, K. Inoue, C. Zota, B. Snell, D. Underwood, K. Tien, B. Sadhu, D. Friedman
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Solid-State Circuits Society
abstract: This paper presents design approaches for two radio frequency (RF) arbitrary waveform generators (AWGs) operating at cryogenic temperatures using FinFET CMOS technologies. The paper presents power, performance, and area trade-offs for highly scaled quantum computing systems using different types of qubits (spin and transmons). The first considered design uses a direct digital synthesis (DDS) approach to provide a wide bandwidth (1−18 GHz) control solution for spin qubits. As this design point was implemented in two technology nodes (14 nm and 7 nm CMOS), it offers a window into the benefits for this application arising from technology scaling. Furthermore, the DDS architecture offers flexibility to meet the requirements of the rapidly evolving requirements of spin qubits and naturally supports a high degree of programmability of the amplitude, phase, duration, frequency and spacing of control waveforms. The DDS-based wideband radio frequency digital to analog converter (DAC) was demonstrated operational over the full 1 to 18 GHz target operating range, providing sufficient bandwidth for control signals for state-of-the-art spin qubit platforms. The second design approach uses various techniques for highly reconfigurable, low power control waveform generation for transmon qubits using current mode analog design. This second approach, implemented using two 14nm FinFET CMOS designs, has enabled the investigation of design-driven power scaling techniques. The DDS-based single spin qubit controller consumes 40−140 mW, occupying 0.5 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> in a 14 nm FinFET node implementation, and 30−68 mW, occupying 0.1 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> in a 7 nm FinFET node. The current mode transmon qubit controller designs, both implemented in 14 nm FinFET, consume 23 mW and 12.8 mW, respectively, occupying 1.61 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and 1.32 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> per qubit controller, respectively.

title: Audio Recognition-based Method for RF Transmitters Classification using CNN-LSTM model
authors: Nordine Quadar, Abdelah Chehri, Benoit Debaque
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to Radio Frequency transmitter classification that adapts audio recognition techniques to enhance device identification accuracy. By leveraging Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs) and spectral characteristics traditionally used in audio processing, combined with a hybrid CNN-LSTM deep learning architecture, our method achieves $93.6 \%$ classification accuracy across 8 devices in same-scenario testing. The approach demonstrates strong initial performance comparable to state-of-the-art RF fingerprinting methods, while also providing insights into cross-scenario challenges under varying operational conditions. Our experimental results, conducted using a dataset of commercial RF transmitters, highlight both the potential of audio-inspired features for RF fingerprinting and the persistent challenge of maintaining classification reliability across different operational conditions. This work contributes to the growing field of physicallayer security by demonstrating how cross-domain adaptation of proven audio processing techniques can enhance RF device identification.

title: Dynamic Resource Allocation Using Quantum Algorithm and Game Theoretic Approach
authors: Anjan Bandyopadhyay, Priyanshi Kumari, Debolina Ghosh, Mahendra Kumar Gourisaria, Parthasarathi Pattnayak, Sayan Ghosh
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The assignment of resources dynamically is a decisive issue in the new paradigms of computations including cloud, edge, fog computing, and the Internet of Things (IoT). These are heterogeneous resource environments, decentralized control environments, and overload environments that vary at a rapid pace and require adaptive and intelligent allocation schemes. The paper suggests a hybrid quantum-game-theoretic model, which combines quantum optimization approaches and multi-agent game theory to solve the problems of multi-agent resource allocation in dynamic systems. Using the quantum concept of superposition and entanglement, the framework can explore the solution spaces in parallel and therefore increase convergence speed and allocation efficiency.A quantum game-theoretic model is developed, which entails price-motivated system to control the strategic interaction of rational agents, in addition to maintaining stability, autonomy and equilibrium. The resource allocation problem is formulated as a Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization (QUBO) problem and solved with the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) algorithm. The proposed approach is proved to be useful as simulation results show significant gains to classical baselines in terms of utility gain, fairness, and system throughput. The results highlight the possibilities of the quantum-game-theoretic paradigm as a fundamental engine of next-generation computing infrastructures, including networked cloud, edge and IoT with networked computing nodes in VPN-enabled networks.

title: Digital Calibration of Analog-to-Digital Converter Based on an Improved Volterra Model
authors: Runze Yu, Shengwei Meng, Xiyuan Peng, Benkuan Wang, Datong Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: High-speed Pipeline Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADCs) often suffer from nonlinear distortion and structural mismatch, significantly limiting dynamic performance. Volterra-based behavioral modeling can uniformly characterize memory effects and nonlinear interactions, but their parameters grow exponentially with order and memory length, which causes redundancy, unstable identification and excessive complexity. Existing simplification methods, relying mostly on post-hoc pruning or sparsification, lack unified structural constraints and struggle to balance performance and complexity. This paper proposes a calibration method based on OrderDependent Volterra and Dynamic Deviation Reduction (ODVDDR). By introducing order-dependent memory allocation and dynamic deviation control in the structure generation stage, it systematically reduces parameter scale, improves the matrix condition number, and maintains the model's ability to represent nonlinear distortions. Compared with existing methods, ODV-DDR achieves a better balance between calibration accuracy and model complexity, providing a generalizable modeling approach for efficient and stable nonlinear calibration. Verification results on a behavioral-level simulation platform show that ODV-DDR significantly improves the SFDR and SNDR under the condition of coexisting typical non-ideal errors. Its performance is close to that of the full Volterra model, while the parameter scale is significantly reduced. Therefore, this method demonstrates good practical value in balancing implementation complexity and performance, and provides a new approach for the digital calibration of highspeed ADC systems.

title: BOAMLS: Bayesian Optimization with Attention Mechanism for FPGA Logic Synthesis (PhD Forum Paper)
authors: Xijun Cheng, Zhongyan Xu, Jicong Fan, Yun Qian, Xiaofeng Gu, Zhiguo Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: The continuous scaling of integrated circuits causes excessive growth in both area and delay, underscoring the critical need for logic synthesis to reduce redundancies. Nevertheless, prevailing methods for FPGA logic optimization exhibit limited efficiency and are susceptible to convergence into local optima. To address these challenges, this paper proposes BOAMLS, a Bayesian optimization framework with an attention mechanism for FPGA logic synthesis, enhancing high-dimensional design space exploration efficiency. Furthermore, an adaptive acquisition function is designed to prevent the Bayesian optimization process from getting trapped in local optima, thereby strengthening the overall robustness and global search performance. Experimental results on the EPFL benchmark show that, compared with RESYN2, the proposed framework achieves a geometric mean reduction of 11.44% in LUT-6 count under timing constraints.

title: Insights and Analysis from Black Start Mock Drill Case Studies using Synchrophasor Technology
authors: Praveen Tripathy, Subhash Kumar, Sachin Kumar Singh, Kishore Kalita, Saksham Rithe, Sharmistha Dutta
abstract: History has demonstrated the critical importance of initiating power generation units independently of the external grid, a capability known as a "Black start". This capability is essential for recovering power systems from instabilities and disasters. To ensure equipment reliability, maintain system health, and provide operators with valuable restoration experience, regular black-start mock drills are conducted, including those performed prior to the commercial operation of new units.This paper presents insights from black start mock drill case studies conducted in the North East region of India and the use of Synchrophasor technology to analyze such cases at load despatch centers. The exercise involves initiating the black start of a unit, charging a dead bus, energizing a transmission line, and synchronizing with the grid at a remote end. During such exercises, synchronized phasor measurements are leveraged to monitor real-time conditions, including frequency and phase angles, in both the islanded system and the power grid. The paper explores the use of synchrophasor data to analyze both successful and unsuccessful attempts at synchronizing the incoming generator with the grid. The findings provide valuable lessons and data that can improve future black-start procedures and enhance the resilience of power systems.

title: Design and implementation of a unidirectional isolated charger applied to electromobility with a 310 Whr lithium battery bank
authors: Sebastián Cruz Murillo, Jorge Ortiz Marín, Vicente Venegas Rebollar, Edgar Lenymirko Moreno Goytia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This paper presents the design and experimental development of a high-efficiency lithium-ion battery charger, which includes a pack of 24 INR18650-35E cells arranged in 4 branches of 6 cells in series each, intended for electric mobility and energy storage applications. The proposed charger incorporates a power conversion stage based on a medium-frequency isolated topology, enabling a compact and lightweight design with enhanced performance. The system employs state-of-the-art silicon carbide (SiC) power electronics components, allowing high switching frequencies and improved thermal behavior. Experimental validation of a 300 W, 22.2 V nominal prototype demonstrates a peak efficiency of 92.3% at full load and 98.14% efficiency at the transformer terminals. The proposed solution addresses the growing demand for efficient, reliable, and scalable charging systems for modern lithium-ion battery applications.

title: A Modified U-Net with Focal Modulation for Robust Breast Lesion Segmentation
authors: Khadija Arshad, Imran Arshad Choudhry, Gulshan Saleem
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of breast lesions is a crucial step in computer-aided diagnosis systems for breast cancer screening. While U-Net and its variants have achieved success in medical image segmentation, conventional skip connections often transmit modality-specific noise, limiting robustness across different imaging domains. In this study, we propose a Focal-Gated Skip Connection U-Net (FGSC-U-Net) that integrates focal modulation and context-aware gating into skip connections and the bottleneck layer. This design suppresses irrelevant background features such as dense tissue textures in mammography and speckle noise in ultrasound, while enhancing salient lesion boundaries. The model was evaluated independently on three public datasets spanning both mammography and ultrasound: DMID mammography, UDIAT ultrasound, and BUSI ultrasound. The proposed approach achieved Dice scores of 74.28%, 88.38%, and 95.60%, respectively, outperforming standard U-Net and several state-of-the-art models. Qualitative visualizations further confirm improved lesion coverage and reduced false positives.

title: Construction-D’ Lattices Based on Raptor Codes for Unconstrained AWGN Channels
authors: Pegah Sharifi, Khadijeh Bagheri, Hassan Khodaiemehr, Chen Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Raptor codes provide low encoding and decoding complexity, making them effective in unreliable networks. This paper introduces a novel framework for constructing multilevel lattices using Raptor codes, integrating Construction-D’ to enhance joint coding and modulation. We employ a multilevel decoder with Belief Propagation (BP) and concatenate Luby Transform (LT) codes with quasi-cyclic low-density parity-check (QC-LDPC) pre-codes, streamlining the construction process. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed Raptor lattices significantly outperform traditional counterparts in Frame Error Rate (FER) over additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channels.

title: Fast Gradient-Based Distributed NMPC with Event-Driven Communication
authors: Dine El Houda Hammami, Saber Maraoui, Kais Bouzrara
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents a communication-efficient framework for Distributed Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (DNMPC) based on event-triggered coordination and fast gradient optimization. The proposed method decomposes the global control problem into local subproblems solved by individual agents, while minimizing communication through an eventtriggering mechanism that exchanges information only when significant deviations occur. A fast gradient method is employed within each local MPC to accelerate convergence and enable real-time implementation. The stability and performance of the approach are analyzed, and its effectiveness is demonstrated on a multi-agent system. Simulation results show that the proposed strategy achieves control performance comparable to periodic (time-triggered) implementations, while significantly reducing the communication load between agents.

title: A Contextual Approach to Modeling Activity-Related Electricity Consumption in Instrumented Dwellings
authors: Ly-Huynh Phan, Hong Anh Tan Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Occupants' activities strongly influence electricity use in residential buildings. Modeling and evaluating the relationships between occupants and the electricity consumed by appliances is essential for improving energy-efficient occupant behavior in dwellings. This paper examines activity-related electricity consumption of domestic appliances. Because appliance operation differs across household activities, activity contexts produce distinct electricity-use patterns. To capture these effects, we propose a contextual approach to model the electricity consumption associated with activities in houses. Specifically, Bayesian Networks are used to infer predefined consumption levels for studied appliances (e.g., microwave, toaster, washing machine). A case study with activities was used to evaluate the performance of the proposed approach. The results show the variation in appliance electricity levels both within a given activity and across activities. To evaluate the approach, simulated electricity from the proposed model was compared with sensorbased observations for multiple appliances. The results indicate that, when activity labels were available, the model effectively characterized the electricity levels linked to occupants' activities and effectively reproduced the activity-related consumption of appliances across multiple activities. It was also shown that even for the same activities, occupants may operate appliances in different ways and that their usage patterns change over time, a dynamic the current model only partially captures.

title: A Robust Two-Tier Computer Vision System for Energy-Efficient Fire Detection
authors: Tianyi Chen, Lin Li, Rui Wang, Pan Wang, Yu Gao, Michal Aibin
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce a framework for energyefficient fire detection by combining a simple color-based approach with a deep-learning-based model. We show how the two detectors can complement each other, achieving strong accuracy with reduced computational load. The experiments and results illustrate the performance in terms of detection speed, accuracy, and the feasibility of running multiple instances on shared hardware.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Modern CNN Architectures: EfficientNetV2 vs. ConvNeXt for Plant Disease Classification
authors: Thi Kim Anh Vo, Ngoc Vo Chau, Thi Nho Vo
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Accurate and early diagnosis of plant diseases is critical for global food security and for minimizing economic losses in agriculture. Deep learning, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), has emerged as a powerful tool for automating this process. This study presents a direct comparative analysis between two state-of-the-art CNN architectures, EfficientNetV2 and ConvNeXt, for the task of multi-class plant disease classification. Both models were trained using a transfer learning approach on a public dataset of 20,639 images across 15 distinct classes of plant leaves. While this dataset is extensive, it is primarily composed of images taken in controlled, uniform settings, which presents a known limitation for real-world generalization. This work provides a direct, up-to-date benchmark of two leading modern CNNs, revealing not only their performance and efficiency but also their distinct failure modes through a qualitative error analysis. Our evaluation demonstrates that EfficientNetV2 achieves a significantly higher overall test accuracy (84.72%) compared to ConvNeXt (74.71%). Furthermore, with approximately 4.6 times fewer parameters, EfficientNetV2 is a more efficient and effective architecture. The error analysis revealed that EfficientNetV2 correctly classified 292 images that ConvNeXt misclassified, whereas the reverse was true for only 87 images, confirming its superior robustness. These findings highlight the architectural superiority of EfficientNetV2 for this application and suggest key areas for future research.

title: Distribution Network Reconfiguration Considering Distributed Generation and Shunt Reactive Compensation
authors: J. E. Munguia Tapia, Héctor F. Ruiz Paredes, A. Vázquez Mendoza, J. H. Tovar Hernández
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This article addresses one of the most important problems faced in modern electrical distribution systems: The optimal reconfiguration of primary feeders that contain distributed generation systems and Reactive compensation systems. Both aspects require optimal strategies for opening and closing switches, as well as adjusting reactive compensation. The problem is solved by using efficient power flow techniques for radial systems that allow calculating different operating scenarios with the aim of minimizing the number of switch operations and also establishing the optimal level of reactive compensation through linear sensitivities. The proposed algorithm takes into account the hourly variation of the load and thus the variation in renewable energy sources. Case studies are presented.

title: Brain Tumor Segmentation and Classification Using Multi-Scale SAM and VGG16
authors: Tayyab Raza, Muhammad Arslan Ul Haq, Syeda Qanitah Naqvi, Hafiz Arslan Ramzan, Abdul Rehman, Sadia Ramzan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: The precise delineation and consistent categorization of brain tumors are essential for informed therapeutic decisions and the provision of optimal patient care. The article gives one model that incorporates heavy segmentation and that of the state of the art classification to improve the degree of diagnostic accuracy in detecting intracranial abnormalities. The segmentation part applies a Multi-Scale, Detail-Refined Segment Anything Model (SAM) that is guided to achieve Salient Object Detection and the capability to extract the features with caution at various resolutions with a ability to refine boundaries in the structures. According to the BraTS2020 benchmark, the accuracy rate of the method is 97%.A VGG16 model is trained in the classification step on a selected set of brain tumor MRI images with 98 percent accuracy. The two elements together make up a single pipeline which greatly enhances reliability of diagnosing and presents a high likelihood of altering the full automated tumor detection systems. The impossible task of the future work is to achieve a more significant level of segmentation and classification to the level of 99 percent and advance the threshold of computational diagnostics even more.Abstract-Tumor segmentation is an important procedure in the brain, the type of tumor, medical imaging, and deep learning, vision transformer.

title: A Cluster Head Election Mechanism for Industrial IoT Based on the Integration of Association Rules and Decision Trees
authors: Fang Jiang, Gewen Mi, Yanjun Hu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: In recent years, the rapid growth of the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) has placed increasing demands on Low-Power and Lossy Networks (LLNs) for data collection and communication in complex environments. As key nodes in clustered architectures, Cluster Heads (CHs) directly influence network lifetime and transmission efficiency. This paper proposes a lightweight rule-based two-stage CH selection mechanism that integrates association-rule filtering with a decision-tree–style logical evaluator that combines association rule mining with a decision tree, jointly evaluating features such as neighbor density, residual energy, and communication cost to improve candidate filtering and final election accuracy. The mechanism is implemented in Contiki and evaluated through Cooja simulations. Results show that the proposed approach significantly enhances energy efficiency and extends network lifetime, offering a promising direction for intelligent CH election and adaptive communication protocols in LLNs.

title: Identification and Nonlinear Modeling of Synchronous Reluctance Motor (SynRM)
authors: Yutthasat Chaemkan, Paisak Poolphaka, Pairote Thongprasri, Ehsan Jamshidpour, Thierry Lubin, Noureddine Takorabet
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This research proposes a comparative study of developed models for a Synchronous Reluctance Motor (SynRM). The study involves simulations based on two prototype models: one is a conventional, linear SynRM model that assumes fixed values for the direct-axis inductance (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</inf>) and quadrature-axis inductance (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</inf>), and the other is a developed SynRM model designed to closely mimic the physical device by utilizing a mathematical framework that allows L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</inf> and L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">q</inf> values to vary based on the motor's equations. The simulation results obtained from both models are then compared against experimental test results from an actual SynRM motor.

title: Reduced-Complexity Transfer Learning Based BiLSTM Network for Multi-Amplifier Behavioral Modelling
authors: Marwan Emira, Majid Ahmed, Oualid Hammi
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Neural network-based behavioral models for radio frequency power amplifiers (PAs) face scalability challenges, as device-specific variations typically necessitate independent training procedures across production units. This work showcases how transfer learning can enable a lowcomplexity bidirectional long short-term memory (BiLSTM) behavioral model to be adapted between power amplifier lineups built using two identical PA prototypes. The novelty of this work lies in the utilization of a fine-tuning transfer learning based dense layer which is trained to adapt to PAs manufacturing variations and aging, with virtually no accuracy loss. The findings suggest that most PA-specific behavior can be captured by the proposed low complexity approach. In the experimental validation, the model accuracy was maintained while updating as little as 332 parameters which represents less than 15 % of the number of parameters needed using a conventional full retraining approach. These results pave the way for lightweight, device-agnostic behavioral models in multivendor <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G} / \mathbf{6 G}$</tex> front-ends.

title: Automatic SystemVerilog Assertion Generation: Challenges and Opportunities
authors: Raheel Afsharmazayejani, Hammond Pearce, Benjamin Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: As modern semiconductor devices have become increasingly complex, guaranteeing their functional correctness and security assurance has become more challenging. Assertion-based verification (ABV) is a typical method to detect functional and security issues at the RTL stage of the design process. Properties - often expressed as SystemVerilog Assertions (SVAs) - are constructed to formally specify a design’s expected behavior by enabling automatic checks during simulation and formal verification. Although writing assertions enhances semiconductor assurance before fabrication, it requires expertise and is a time-consuming process, motivating the development of automated methods to facilitate the entire procedure. This article explores the various methodologies and best practices to enhance the automation of the SVA generation and presents insights into the challenges and opportunities in this area.

title: Introducing Multi-Level Modulation for Improving Spectral Efficiency in Modified Walsh-Hadamard Code Division Multiplexing
authors: Shinya Sotome, Toshiharu Kojima
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: In helicopter satellite communications, the periodic blockage (PB) due to rotor blades severely degrades the bit error rate (BER) performance. While modified Walsh-Hadamard code division multiplexing (MWHCDM) is effective against the PB, its primary modulation is binary phase-shift keying, limiting spectral efficiency. This paper addresses introducing multi-level modulation for improving spectral efficiency in MWHCDM. The analysis shows that pulse amplitude modulation (PAM) is suitable for the multi-level primary modulation. Although multi-level phase-shift keying also improves spectral efficiency, it impairs the anti-PB capability of MWHCDM. Computer simulation demonstrates that, in the PB channel, MWHCDM with 4-level PAM outperforms that with quaternary phase-shift keying.

title: Knowledge Graphs And Explainable AI For Transparent, Accurate Employee Turnover Prediction
authors: Prudvinadh Kopparapu, V T Ram Pavan Kumar, Paramati Chandini, Bhinaram Soundarya, Pathan. Hussain Basha, Gopala Varma Kosuri
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Employee turnover poses a critical challenge for organizations by increasing operational costs, disrupting team productivity, and affecting long-term workforce stability. Although machine learning techniques have shown promising results in predicting employee attrition, most existing approaches suffer from limited transparency and fail to incorporate relational organizational knowledge. Explainable AI (XAI) techniques improve interpretability but often operate on flat feature representations, overlooking hierarchical and collaborative workforce structures. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a hybrid framework that integrates knowledge graphs (KGs) with explainable machine learning models for transparent and fair employee turnover prediction. The proposed approach embeds organizational relationships such as reporting hierarchies and team interactions into KG-derived features, which are combined with interpretable classifiers. Post-hoc explanation techniques, including SHAP and LIME, are employed to provide actionable insights, while fairness-aware optimization reduces bias across protected attributes. Experimental evaluation on realworld HR data demonstrates that the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 88.7% and a fairness score of 0.78, outperforming baseline methods such as Random Forests and graph neural networks. The results highlight the effectiveness of combining structured organizational knowledge with explainable AI to support ethical and data-driven human resource decision-making.

title: Hall Effect Sensor Network Simulation Over SDN for Detecting Corona Discharge in High-Voltage Transmission Lines
authors: Luis Timaná, Óscar Penagos, Andrés Rodríguez
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: The safe and efficient operation of high-voltage power lines requires constant monitoring, especially in the presence of events such as corona discharges and electromagnetic transients. These phenomena can degrade critical infrastructure and lead to significant financial losses. Hall-effect sensors offer notable advantages due to their compact size, sensitivity to magnetic fields, and adaptability to diverse environments. This study explores the integration of a wireless sensor network based on Hall-effect sensors, managed through Software-Defined Networking (SDN), and simulated using the Mininet-WiFi platform. Preliminary results suggest that the proposed approach enables fast and accurate detection of critical conditions, supporting timely preventive interventions in non-uniform highvoltage transmission systems.

title: HIBA-Siamese BiLSTM: A Deep Learning-Based Intrusion Detection System for Enhancing IoT Cybersecurity
authors: J Poornimha, P R Pameela Rani
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: The exponential rise of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has significantly extended attack surface of new networks, making intrusion detection a critical element of IoT cybersecurity. Conventional Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) and shallow ML approaches struggle to cope with evolving threats, class imbalance, and the computational limitations of resource-constrained IoT environments. To address these issues, this paper develops a novel DL-based IDS using Hitchcock Bird-Inspired Algorithm optimized Siamese Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (HIBASiamese BiLSTM). This model integrates a Siamese BiLSTM network with HIBA for hyperparameter optimization. The Siamese BiLSTM architecture learns discriminative temporal embeddings of IoT traffic and leverages contrastive learning to effectively differentiate between benign and malicious patterns, including zero-day attacks. HIBA is employed to optimize critical hyperparameters, including learning rate, dropout, and BiLSTM units, thereby enhancing accuracy and decreasing false positives. The proposed framework is evaluated on benchmark IoT cybersecurity datasets, namely IoT-23, UNSW-NB15, and TON_IoT, and achieves 99.91%, 99.99%, and 99.99% accuracies, respectively, while maintaining lightweight computational requirements suitable for IoT edge deployment. This work establishes a foundation for adaptive, efficient, and generalizable IoT intrusion detection, paving the way toward robust cybersecurity in smart and connected environments.

title: Explainable CNN & Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Health Risk PCOS Prediction & Diagnosis
authors: Priyanka Nalawade, Vishal Borate, Rajlakshmi Narsinha Shindalkar, Snehal Subhash Bansode, Shreya Dilip More, Cynthia Pachal
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS), a predominant hormonal disorder causes various reproductive issues in women starting from their early reproductive period and prevailing for a lifelong period of time. It can be critical when left undiagnosed, causing life threatening cardio vascular diseases. So early prediction of the syndrome can prove to be an essential step in the diagnosis of PCOS. Manual prediction of this hormonal disorder is quite challenging as the exact cause is still unknown and the prediction can be erroneous. For such a situation deep learning models can employ as a aiding means by the medical adepts in analyzing the presence of PCOS. Ultrasonographic images being the most important factor in the prediction is labelled into two categories as infected and non-infected. This image dataset with 2 classes is used to train different models for prediction. This work focuses on training various pre- trained models and a separate deep learning Convolutional Neural Network model (CNN) doing a comparative analysis on the accuracy of prediction. Out of all the pretrained models and the built CNN model, then latter gave high accuracy prediction where training time is less. With high accuracy of 99% CNN is employed by Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanation (LIME) explainable model to assist the medical adepts in giving error free precise predictions at the earliest.

title: Super-Wideband Cardioid Printed Monopole Antenna
authors: Stéfano A. V. Rezende, Fatima S. Correra, Murilo H. Seko, Guilherme N. Kawassaki
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This study introduces the development of a super-wideband printed monopole antenna using a cardioid resonator. The antenna design approach uses equations for the radius of the circular printed monopole antenna to estimate the initial dimensions of the cardioid radiator. The proposed antenna was designed for operation from 2.45 to 26.5 GHz, with potential applications in contemporary communication and RF energy harvesting systems. Using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 5 2 4}-\mathbf{m m}$</tex> thick Kappa® <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 3 8}$</tex> laminate as a substrate, the antenna area resulted in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{4 2} \text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. Experimental results validated the antenna performance, which demonstrated gains ranging from 1.6 to 3.0 dBi in the frequency band between 3.0 and 26.5 GHz.

title: Improving Heart Disease Risk Prediction using Stacking Classifier
authors: S N Netra, N N Srinidhi, E Naresh
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: In the medical field, early cardiac disease prediction is extremely difficult, yet precise models can greatly enhance patient outcomes. An enhanced stacking ensemble classifier for the prediction of heart disease is proposed in this paper. Three Level 0 base learners XGBoost, Random Forest, and LightGBM are integrated into the model to identify various patterns and connections in clinical data. A Level 1 meta-classifier then combines and processes their probabilistic outputs, learning the best weighting for each base model to get the final prediction. The dataset used in this study include important clinical characteristics like cholesterol, blood pressure, and age. The Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) was used to combat class imbalance, while RandomizedSearchCV was used to optimize hyperparameters and improve model performance. The suggested ensemble outperforms individual classifiers, according to experimental results, with an accuracy of 0.9783 and a ROC-AUC score of 0.9897. The proposed method provides a better solution in early detection of heart disease and overall healthcare outcomes.

title: DC Performance Benchmarking of Core-Insulator Embedded Junctionless NSFETS for Low-Power Logic Applications
authors: K. Mamota Devi, Anisha Samanta, Arun Kumar, Ashraf Maniyar, Pukhrambam Puspa Devi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This work presents a comprehensive DC performance evaluation of two-stacked silicon-based Core-Insulator Embedded Junctionless Nanosheet FETs (CI-JLNSFETs) using a fully calibrated 3D TCAD simulator. To enhance electrostatic control, a silicon dioxide <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{SiO}_{2}\right)$</tex> layer has been embedded at the center of the nanosheet channel. The proposed device exhibited a threshold voltage (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{V}_{\text {th }}$</tex>) of 0.37 V, subthreshold swing (SS) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$70.548 \text{mV} / \text{dec}$</tex>, drain-induced barrier lowering (DIBL) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$92.75 \text{mV} / \mathrm{V}$</tex>, an I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</inf> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.231 \times 10^{-5} ~\mathrm{A}$</tex>, an I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OFF</inf> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.805 \times 10^{-13} ~\mathrm{A}$</tex>, and an I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</inf>/I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OFF</inf> ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.863 \times 10^{7}$</tex>. Additionally, the effects of varying gate length (Lg), core insulator thickness (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{T}_{\mathbf{C}}$</tex>), split nanosheet thickness (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{T}_{\text{Ns}\_\text{Split }}$</tex>), and Source/Drain (S/D) and channel doping concentration were analyzed to study their impact on key DC parameters such as Vth, SS, I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ON</inf>/I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">OFF</inf>, and DIBL.

title: Design and Implementation of Low-Latency Five-Port NoC Router for Embedded Systems
authors: Surya Pratap, Chhagan Charan
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: In the era of high-performance embedded systems where embedded processors are designed to perform complex operations and the feature size is continuously decreasing so that many IP cores can be integrated into a single silicon chip to serve multiple functions, interconnections have become a major factor. Therefore, the communication of intellectual property cores via NoCs is immensely important. The router is basic building block of a NoC. In this paper, a low latency NoC router has been proposed that employs deterministic X-Y routing unified with look ahead routing to reduce the latency of packets by calculating the optimum at the input stage. The elements of the proposed router are FIFO, arbitrator, scheduler, and registers. The architecture of the proposed router is simulated in Xilinx Vivado. The source code is authored in a Verilog Hardware Description Language.

title: Research on Sensitivity Enhancement of Acetylene Photoacoustic Sensor Based on Cross-Correlation Technique
authors: Yuhang Chen, Shihong Lu, Min Huang, Yang Wang, Feng Zhang, Runhao Zhang, Haoyu Yu, Jiuan Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This paper presents a photoacoustic signal enhancement method based on cross-correlation operation for the application scenario of dissolved gas analysis in transformer oil, which improves the sensitivity of photoacoustic spectroscopy gas detection systems and effectively suppresses noise. The technique correlates deterministic signals acquired at high concentrations with measurement signals from target gases, leading to higher measurement sensitivity and a lower detection limit. We describe the principle and implementation of the method and experimentally validate its effectiveness for trace acetylene detection. The low detection limit of sensing system is improved from 0.447 ppm to 0.152 ppm and reliable detection of acetylene at 0.2 ppm was achieved. These findings offer both theoretical and practical value for achieving high-sensitivity trace gas detection.

title: Design and Analysis of Vertical Cavity Surface Emitting Laser (VCSEL) for High-Power and Thermally Stable Operation
authors: Swastik Kumar Sahu, Kaushik Mazumdar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: In this paper, a vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser (VCSEL) was designed and analyzed to investigate its electrical, thermal, and optical performance. The study focused on device structure optimization, threshold characteristics, output power, and transverse mode behavior under varying bias conditions. The investigated device exhibited a well-defined threshold around 0.95 V, followed by a rapid increase in output power with increasing anode voltage. The maximum fundamental-mode output reached approximately 38 mW at 3.0 V, while higher-order modes were significantly suppressed, demonstrating favorable single-mode operation at elevated bias. Thermal analysis revealed minimal self-heating, with the device temperature increasing by 7 K under high-bias conditions, thereby confirming stable operation and efficient heat dissipation. The results establish the capability of the proposed VCSEL design to achieve high power with controlled mode confinement, making it suitable for applications in optical interconnects, sensing, and integrated photonic systems.

title: Power Quality Optimization using d-q and Fuzzy Logic Control for SSSC based Voltage Sag Mitigation in a Power System Network
authors: Roqayya Aimun, M. Manjula
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Power Quality optimization is a burgeoning methodology aimed at enhancing performance of power system networks, particularly during events such as voltage sags, that significantly impact nonlinear loads. The Synchronous Series Compensator (SSSC), one of the FACTS devices, enables series injection of synchronous and controllable AC voltages to adjust line impedance, improve stability, regulate voltage, and damp oscillations. During voltage sags, SSSC is operated using an intelligent control strategy. In this context, combined d-q control with Fuzzy logic control is employed to achieve a highly adaptive, optimized and comprehensive approach for power quality enhancement. Simulation results obtained demonstrate that Fuzzy Logic Control offers a rapid and robust response to voltage disturbances. Furthermore, a THD of 2.64% confirms the system’s performance in compliance with IEEE Std 519-2022 guidelines. This optimized technique is particularly vital for increased system efficiency that leads to lower carbon footprint, and a power system that supports eligibility for green energy incentives for interconnection with microgrids even under unstable conditions.

title: Rover-71: An Indigenous Multi-purpose Rover Featuring Autonomous Navigation and Control
authors: Md Ehsanur Rahman, Tyseer Ninad, Md Tariqul Islam, Tajikur Rahman Turjo, Shoaeb Akter, Mohammad Samiul Islam, Mubin Azam, S. M. Sadakatul Bari
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a cost-effective and modular rover featuring autonomous navigation. Developed for human-assisted applications in both terrestrial and extraterrestrial environments, the system supports missions such as scientific exploration, disaster response, and environmental monitoring. The system integrates a robust mechanical framework, an energy-efficient power architecture, and a long-range communication to ensure reliable performance. The core novelty lies in its modular design, a five-degree-of-freedom robotic manipulator, and a custom navigation system combining depth camera, GPS, SLAM, and real-time perception. The onboard software, powered by Jetson Orin NX and ROS2, enables the rover to perceive its surroundings, make real-time decisions and execute using a fused sensor framework. The autonomous path planning system leverages sensor fusion and priority-based control switching to safely operate in partially structured environments. Field test results confirm successful mission execution across diverse terrains, validating the rover’s effectiveness and adaptability.

title: Experimental Investigation of Underwater Wireless Power Transmission System
authors: Mamiko Inamori, Sora Anzai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: In recent years, wireless power transmission has become a familiar technology, particularly with its widespread adoption in smartphones. At the same time, it is expected to be applied in high-power applications, such as supplying electricity to electric vehicles and underwater robots. The magnetic resonance method has been actively studied as a promising approach for enabling wireless power transmission over medium to long distances. However, its power transmission efficiency tends to decrease in seawater environments. This paper presents experimental results on power output, power transmission efficiency, and power loss measured in air, pure water, and saline water. In addition, measurement results are provided to clarify the loss factors that affect wireless power transmission in seawater.

title: Engineering and Development of a Plantar Device Featuring an Auxetic Structure Sole
authors: Mariam Barkaat, Ali Imran Khwaja, Shifa Maryum, Faisal Amin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive exploration of the design, development, and analysis of a foot pressure distribution device aimed at enhancing our understanding of human gait biomechanics and providing valuable insights into comfort and foot-related conditions such as plantar fasciitis. The study commences with an extensive literature review encompassing foot pressure measurement techniques, auxetic structures, and the significance of foot pressure distribution in diagnosing foot problems. By critically reviewing existing methods, the review identifies their inherent challenges and limitations, thus emphasizing the pressing need for an accurate and innovative foot pressure distribution and measurement device. The research methodology entails the design and construction of a novel foot pressure measurement and distribution device capable of capturing and analyzing pressure distribution patterns during various stages of gait. The device leverages state-of-the-art sensor technology and data acquisition systems to precisely measure and record the pressure exerted by the foot at distinct key points. To ensure the utmost reliability and validity, the device undergoes meticulous calibration procedures. The results unequivocally demonstrate the effectiveness and dependability of the proposed device in accurately capturing foot pressure patterns and promoting pressure equalization across the foot through the integration of auxetic structures. By providing valuable quantitative data to clinicians and researchers, the device significantly contributes to the diagnosis, treatment, and monitoring of foot-related disorders. Furthermore, it serves as a practical tool for designing customized footwear, thereby enhancing foot comfort and alleviating discomfort caused by pressure-related issues.

title: Soft-Switched GaN-Based Current Source Converter
authors: Christos Leontaris, Gean J. M. de Sousa, Marcelo Lobo Heldwein
abstract: Recently introduced bidirectional GaN switch technologies can potentially revive Current Source Converters (CSCs), since the conduction losses for a given chip area are approximately halved. However, our vision in this work is that the highest potential of CSCs lies in implementing converters with reduced material usage and low overall losses to minimize environmental impacts. To this end, the size of the passive components (l, Cs, and EMC filter components) is reduced by operating at higher switching frequencies. Although GaN transistors reduce switching losses, these remain a fundamental limitation. The solution pursued here is the implementation of novel modulation strategies that achieve Zero Voltage Switching (ZVS) in all devices. The main challenge is enabling ZVS without a significant increase in the circulating currents, which requires accurate knowledge of the current waveforms during switching transitions. Mathematical models are therefore derived and used to define advanced modulation strategies that fulfill this goal. Two modulation schemes are proposed: Trapezoidal Current Modulation (TrCM) and Advanced Trapezoidal Current Modulation (A-TrCM). Preliminary results predict a semiconductor efficiency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\eta \approx 99.55 \%$</tex> at the nominal operation point of 6.75 kW. The required DC-link inductance is only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L=8 \mu \mathrm{H}$</tex>, which is at least one order of magnitude smaller than that of traditional continuous conduction mode CSC modulation, potentially enabling a substantial reduction in overall system volume.
