title: Research on the Method of Accurately Measuring the Angular Speed of Rotating Machinery based on Angular Point Transformation
authors: Jie Ren, Kaisong Wang, Kuosheng Jiang, Yuanyuan Zhou, Biao Hu, Chang Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This paper proposes a method for accurately measuring the angular speed of rotating machinery based on corner transformation and designs a corresponding sensor system. The system primarily consists of a grating and a highspeed camera. By attaching a specific rectangular pattern to the shaft surface, a phase-modulated signal is generated during the shaft's rotation. The instantaneous angular speed (IAS) is then extracted using image feature tracking and corner detection algorithms. Unlike traditional encoders, which rely on resolution, this method theoretically enables angular speed detection with infinite resolution, making it particularly suitable for condition monitoring at low speeds or even near-zero speed. This paper first establishes a rotating shaft model in a simulation platform to simulate the sensor imaging process and validate the method's feasibility through corner detection. An experimental testbed is then constructed to test the sensor under constant and variable speed conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that this method maintains high detection accuracy at extremely low speeds and during dynamic acceleration and deceleration, with the measurement results highly consistent with the motor's setpoints. Further error analysis reveals that the grating attachment accuracy, lighting conditions, and mechanical vibration have some influence on the measurement results, but image preprocessing and feature normalization methods can effectively reduce these errors. Research shows that this method not only has high accuracy and stability, but also has the advantages of simplicity, low cost, and a wide application range. It can provide a new technical approach for condition monitoring, process control, and predictive maintenance of rotating machinery.

title: An Interpretable Multimodal Attention and Stacking Framework for Intelligent Wind Turbine Fault Diagnosis
authors: Nawel Said, Atef Khedher, Majdi Mansouri, Rami Al-Hmouz
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Accurate fault diagnosis in wind turbines is essential for maximizing operational efficiency and minimizing costly downtime. This paper introduces a novel Multimodal Attention and Stacking Framework that incorporates DomainDriven Feature Extraction (DDFE), Global Fusion Integration (GFI), and an Improved Attention Optimization with Hybrid Stacking (IAO-HS) mechanism for intelligent wind turbine fault classification. Initially, the framework extracts discriminative features from mechanical, electrical, and environmental signals using DDFE. These features are subsequently fused globally to capture both intra- and inter-modal relationships, followed by an attention-based hybrid stacking ensemble that dynamically weights each modality and aggregates predictions from multiple classifiers. Extensive evaluations on simulated and real-world datasets show that the proposed framework substantially outperforms traditional single-modality and early-fusion methods, achieving accuracy up to 99.98% while maintaining robustness under diverse operating conditions. The findings demonstrate the effectiveness of combining physically interpretable features with data-driven multimodal learning for highly reliable wind turbine fault diagnosis.

title: Comprehensive Analysis of Object Detection using RGB Camera for Autonomous Vehicles under Adverse Weather Conditions
authors: Hasan Abbasi, Marzieh Amini, F. Richard Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: In recent years, object detection and recognition algorithms have achieved acceptable performance in normal weather conditions. However, these algorithms fail to provide the same results in adverse weather conditions which hampers autonomous vehicles widespread utilization. As a result, analyzing the performance of autonomous vehicle sensors in severe environments is very important. This paper evaluates the performance of camera sensors under diverse weather scenarios using the BDD100k dataset. Specifically, we compare the detection accuracy of models trained and tested on individual weather conditions, such as rain, snow, and clear weather including different times like day and night. In addition, a general model is trained on aggregated data to compare the performance of models specifically trained for a weather condition with a generalized model. Metrics such as mean Average Precision, Recall, and Precision are calculated and assessed for 3 types of object groups categorized as small, medium, and large objects. The results demonstrate that weather-specific models perform better in their respective weather conditions, particularly for small and medium objects. However, the general model provides consistent and robust performance across all weather scenarios, making it suitable for general-purpose applications. Additionally, the paper highlights the trade-offs between model generalization and specialization, time of the day, and the impact of object size on detection accuracy. These findings contribute to the development of more reliable and adaptable object detection systems for adverse weather environments.

title: AI-Assisted System Design: Improving Sequence Diagrams Through Use Case Scenarios
authors: Harsh Sarvaiya, Munima Jahan
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper explores two AI-driven approaches for transforming user stories (USs) into sequence diagrams (SDs). Pipeline A directly converts USs into SDs, while Pipeline B introduces an intermediate step of generating use case scenarios. Both pipelines leverage OpenAI’s GPT-4 model to automate these tasks. Ten user stories were processed through both pipelines and evaluated for accuracy, clarity, efficiency, and scalability. Pipeline B’s use of intermediate use case scenarios significantly improved the quality and detail of SDs while maintaining logical consistency and reducing ambiguity. These findings demonstrate the potential of AI-assisted tools to streamline software development, enhance collaboration, and make technical workflows accessible to non-technical stakeholders. While promising, challenges such as computational overhead and reliance on language models require further research. This study lays the groundwork for integrating AI into model-driven engineering, advancing efficiency and collaboration in software design.

title: A Hybrid Algorithm for Loop Closure Detection in LiDAR SLAM Using Global Point Cloud Density and Local Triangular Features
authors: Yixiao Chen, Xuefen Zhu, Gangyi Tu, Chuan Zhang, Ang Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: In Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) systems, LiDAR odometry inevitably accumulates drift in pose estimates, leading to significant trajectory deviations and inconsistencies in the global map. Loop closure detection plays a crucial role in mitigating this cumulative error through closedloop optimization strategies. In this paper, we propose a hybrid algorithm for loop closure detection in LiDAR SLAM that leverages both global point cloud density and local triangular features. Specifically, the algorithm first filters candidate keyframes using a ring descriptor based on global point cloud density, followed by fine-grained triangle matching and geometric verification within each candidate frame to identify the optimal loop closure frame. The proposed method was evaluated on the publicly available Park dataset, with experimental results demonstrating a reduction in the RMSE of trajectory error to 0.051 m, representing a 59 % improvement over the original odometry results, and outperforming other benchmark algorithms in terms of trajectory error reduction. Additionally, the precision-recall (PR) curve of the proposed algorithm exhibited the widest coverage, achieving a maximum F1 score of 0.92, thereby outperforming existing mainstream loop closure detection algorithms.

title: Dispersion Suppression and Compensation Strategy of Terahertz Wave in Single and Multiple Layer Structures Based on U-Net with Residual Blocks
authors: Peihan Li, Datong Liu, Hua Zhang, Yafei Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) technology, as a novel nondestructive testing (NDT) approach, has shown great potential in thickness measurement and damage location of various non-metallic materials due to its superior detection accuracy and safety. However, when THz wave penetrates the material, the inherent physical properties of the electromagnetic wave will cause it to exhibit different degrees of dispersion, which will limit the temporal-spatial resolution performance of THz NDT. Thus, in this work, a dispersion suppression and compensation method of THz waves is proposed based on U-Net with residual blocks. Firstly, the transmission characteristic of the THz wave is analyzed. The key to dispersion compensation is to obtain the sparse pulse sequence related to the time-of-flight of the structure. Then, the U-Net with residual blocks network is proposed to capture the sparse pulse sequence from dispersive THz signals. Specifically, during the training process, the Dynamic Focus Sparse Regression Loss (DFSR Loss) and Impulse Localization Overall Score (ILOS) are proposed to enhance the network's attention to sparse pulses. Finally, a series of numerical experiments on single-layer and multi-layer structures verifies the effectiveness of the proposed method in suppressing and compensating for complex dispersive THz signals.

title: Adversial Prompt Injection in Large Language Models: Taxonomy, Exploits, and Mitigation Frameworks
authors: Hritesh Yadav, Varun Singh, Kshitij Sharma
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Adversarial prompt injection attacks pose a critical security threat to Large Language Models (LLMs) by manipulating model instructions through malicious inputs. In this paper, we present a comprehensive analysis of prompt injection vulnerabilities in LLMs. We develop a taxonomy encompassing direct, indirect, and multi-stage (chained) prompt injection attacks, detailing various exploits from simple “ignore previous instructions” overrides to covert multi-turn schemes. Through case studies and experimental evidence from recent literature, we demonstrate that even state-of-the-art models (e.g. GPT-4) can be consistently coerced into producing disallowed content, leaking confidential data, or executing unintended actions. We evaluate real-world risks via documented incidents (such as system prompt leaks and compromised LLM-integrated applications) and quantitative benchmarks, finding adversarial success rates exceeding $80 \%$ in many scenarios. To address these threats, we propose a defense-in-depth mitigation framework. Our framework combines prompt sanitization (input filtering and normalization), context isolation (segregating user input from system instructions and external data), and model hardening (enhanced alignment tuning and adversarial training) to substantially reduce injection success. We also outline practical defensive strategies including role-based privilege restriction, output validation, and continuous red-teaming. Finally, we discuss the broader implications of prompt injection for AI safety, ethics, and policy, and highlight directions for future work in building robust, secure LLM systems.

title: Relationship Between Physiological Parameters Monitored by Wearable Devices and the Prevention of Occupational Accidents: A Systematic Review
authors: Junior Raul Soto Sanchez, Pablo César Gutiérrez Falcón
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This study explores, through a systematic review, how certain physiological indicators collected using smart wristbands can contribute to predicting occupational accidents. Seventeen studies were analyzed from databases such as Scopus, ScienceDirect, Wiley, and Google Scholar, published between 2020 and 2025, in both Spanish and English. The process was governed by the PRISMA methodology, ensuring a rigorous and structured approach to source selection. The findings reveal that variables such as heart rate, degree of fatigue, and level of physical activity can provide valuable signals about potential risks in the workplace. However, further development is required, particularly regarding validation in real-world settings. This overview highlights the potential of wearable technologies as preventive tools and the urgent need to further explore their application in different productive sectors. Keywords: Wearable devices, accident prediction, occupational safety, physiological data.

title: Improving Operational Availability with a TPM-Integrated AI-Based Supply Management System in a Metalworking Company
authors: Pedro Enciso-Ortiz, Ronny Leon-Zegarra, Pablo César Gutiérrez-Falcón
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This study addresses the problem of low equipment availability at a metalworking company located in Callao, Peru, dedicated to the manufacture of air suspensions for heavy vehicles. In 2024, equipment availability was 82%, below the industry standard (90%), due to an increase in unplanned downtime and deficiencies in material supply management, a critical situation given that semi-trailer suspensions represent the main sales line. To address this problem, an intelligent supply management system was proposed and implemented, based on limited-memory artificial intelligence and integrated with the Total Productive Maintenance (TPM) methodology. This solution allowed realtime monitoring of machine status, improved forecasting of material requirements, and synchronized logistics activities, thus reducing operational downtime. As a result, availability was increased to 88%, stockout-related downtime was reduced from six to three days, and key maintenance indicators and key indicators such as Mean Time to Repair (MTTR) and Mean Time Between Failures (MTBF) showed marked improvement. The proposal was validated through a TPM pilot test and a simulation of the supply system using Arena software, version 16.

title: Optimising Power Despatch: Security Constrained Economic Despatch Initiative in Gujarat
authors: Divya Sharma, Vatsalkumar Bhatt, Pandya Darshan Dilipkumar, Naran M. Pindoriya, Utpal Patel, Chetan Darji, A B Rathod, Kanti Bhuva, Sushil Kumar Soonee, Debasis De
abstract: The efficient, economic, and reliable operation of power systems is crucial for ensuring reliable electricity supply to the end users. As power system is evolving with increasing renewable energy integration, network complexity, and the need for real-time operational security, there is growing interest in upgrading existing despatch practices such as merit order despatch through advanced optimization techniques. Security constrained economic despatch (SCED) for state load despatch centres (SLDCs) is a complementary approach to support the transition towards smart, secure, and optimized power system operations. SCED incorporates all types of constraints like transmission constraints, generating unit constraints- declared capacity, technical minimum, ramp-up and ramp-down limits, etc. This work describes the SCED implementation for SLDC Gujarat from 15.06.2025-15.07.2025, for day-ahead and first window of real-time generation scheduling to take decision about the amount and price of power to be acquired from the electricity market. The optimization problem is formulated as linear programming to minimize the operational cost, respecting generating unit constraints (declared capacity, technical minimum, ramp-up, and ramp-down). The simulation study is carried out using the CPLEX solver in the GAMS software.

title: Hydrogen-Based Offshore Wind Farm Energy Storage: Simulation and Sensitivity Analysis
authors: Sree Vyshnavi Mamilla, K Shanti Swarup
abstract: Seasonal changes in offshore wind energy complicate continuous electricity supply to coastal grids. This study models using hydrogen as a seasonal storage medium to capture excess offshore wind energy during high-wind months while delivering electricity during low-wind months. An hourly, full-year model based on ERA5 wind data for the Gulf of Mannar and a 50 MW peak microgrid demand profile is used. The system simulates electrolysis, compression, gaseous storage, and reconversion using fuel cells while accounting for conversion efficiency, compression losses, and storage leakage. The results reveal that hydrogen permits seasonal energy shifting with a round-trip efficiency of 30% to 40%, depending on component efficiencies and storage losses. Sensitivity analysis shows that tank capacity and leakage are the most important factors influencing supply reliability. These findings evaluate hydrogen’s potential for long-term offshore wind balance and offer practical recommendations for coastal grid development.

title: Trust, but Verify
authors: Michael J. Yuan, Carlos Lospoy, Sydney Lai, James Snewin, Ju Long
abstract: We demonstrate that in a cluster of mostly honest nodes, we can detect nodes that run unauthorized or incorrect large language models (LLMs) through the social consensus of their peers. We discuss an intersubjective validation system to encourage honest behavior from LLM nodes.

title: AD-HKFCM: A Robust Nonlinear Spectral Variability-Aware Unmixing Via Intra/Inter-Class Affinity Cohesion
authors: Jie Yu, Xin Chen, Yi Lin, Yu Rong, Junbo Lv, Yuxuan Yang, Daiqi Zhong, Yiyuan Tian, Yi Jing, Xiaonan Yang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Spectral variability and nonlinear mixing interactions critically degrade spectral unmixing accuracy, especially in heterogeneous environments. To address these challenges, this study proposes a robust nonlinear spectral variability-aware unmixing model, AD-HKFCM, which integrates fuzzy clustering, kernel-driven nonlinear mapping, and intra-class/inter-class affinity cohesion. The model introduces a hybrid kernel function combining polynomial and radial basis kernels to enhance linear separability in high-dimensional space. By replacing conventional FCM prototypes with SVDD-derived hypersphere centers, the model reduces dependency on pure pixels and adaptively suppresses outliers through adaptive penalty weight optimization. A physics-informed affinity distance metric is designed to explicitly quantify spectral variability by penalizing intra-class dispersion and amplifying inter-class separation, thereby enabling the precise inference of “virtual pure endmembers” from intimately mixed data. Experiments on simulated (including Orchard 2EM/3EM benchmarks and synthetic hyperspectral) and real satellite datasets demonstrate that AD-HKFCM achieves 5–26% lower abundance estimation errors compared to the best-performing comparative methods, particularly in densely mixed regions with seasonal vegetation variability. This work unifies spectral variability compensation and nonlinear unmixing into a cohesive architecture, offering a generalizable solution for robust unmixing in complex environments.

title: Microbubble Backscattering Intensity Improves the Sensitivity of Three-dimensional (3D) Functional Ultrasound Localization Microscopy (fULM)
authors: YiRang Shin, Qi You, Yike Wang, Matthew R. Lowerison, Bing-Ze Lin, Pengfei Song
abstract: Functional ultrasound localization microscopy (fULM) enables brain-wide mapping of neural activity at micron-scale resolution but suffers from limited sensitivity due to sparse and noisy microbubble (MB) detections. Extending fULM into three dimensions (3D) further exacerbates these challenges because of low-frequency matrix arrays, reduced localization efficiency, and severe data sparsity. To address these limitations, we developed a statistical framework that models MB arrivals in 3D as a Poisson process accounting for localization efficiency, detection probability, and backscattered amplitude. This analysis predicts that integrating amplitude with count-based fULM improves functional sensitivity, particularly under high MB concentrations where localization saturates. Three-dimensional MB advection simulations confirmed these predictions, showing that backscattering fULM (B-fULM) maintains sensitivity at higher MB concentrations where conventional fULM fails. In rat brain experiments, B-fULM yielded stronger and more robust stimulus-evoked responses, with SNR gains of 18% in the somatosensory cortex and 61% in the thalamus, while preserving super-resolved spatial detail (33.4 μm for B-fULM vs 35.7 μm for fULM). These results establish B-fULM as a practical and sensitive approach for super-resolved 3D functional neuroimaging

title: Lightweight KAN Convolution Spectral-Spatial Network with Purification Window for Hyperspectral Anomaly Detection
authors: Shufang Xu, Yifan Liu, Yiyan Zhang, Hongmin Gao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: In recent years, deep learning-based methods have been increasingly applied to hyperspectral image (HSI) anomaly detection (HAD). Due to the unique nature of the HAD task, which lacks prior supervisory information, existing methods often reconstruct both background and anomalous pixels to some extent. Moreover, the neglect of spatial information in HSI creates difficulties in separating anomalous pixels from background pixels during detection. To address these issues, we propose a novel purification window spectral-spatial self-supervised network that trains a network to reconstruct only background pixels while fully leveraging HSI spatial information. The Purification Window module first cleanses the dataset, significantly mitigating the problem of insufficient supervisory information in HAD. Inputting the processed dataset into the network shortens the training time while enhancing the model performance. The processed image data is then input into a lightweight reconstruction network based on KAN convolution and depthwise separable convolution, which ensures strong feature representation capabilities with low computational complexity. We summarize and improve upon previous guided image filtering methods, introducing a new approach to incorporate spatial information that further suppresses the reconstruction of anomalous pixels. The proposed network focuses on spectral information, and its combination with the guided filtering method further improves the accuracy of HAD. Extensive comparative experiments on three datasets demonstrate that Lightweight KAN Convolution Spectral-Spatial Network with Purification Window(KSSN) outperforms other popular detectors in terms of effectiveness and superiority.

title: Strong Baselines for PlantCity: Multi-Crop Leaf-Disease Classification
authors: Syed Usama Rehan, Muhammad Farrukh Shahid Syed, Sohail Ahmed, Muhammad Hassan Tanveer
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Field performance of leaf-disease classifiers still lags behind lab-curated results because many studies optimize PlantVillage-like lab imagery and do not validate on cluttered, in-field data, where illumination, backgrounds, and poses vary substantially. We study this by building strong, reproducible baselines on PlantCity, a Pakistan-collected, in-field dataset spanning 12 crops and 52 classes with 10,667 original images (the authors also provide an augmented release), which better matches deployment conditions than studio datasets. We adopt a transparent protocol (held-out test set; stratified 80/20 train/validation from the official train split), prioritize macro-F1 for class imbalance, and report results for classic CNNs (AlexNet, GoogLeNet with aux), Transformers (ViT-B/16, Swin-T), and compact custom CNNs. Using a simple, Kaggle-ready recipe (AdamW + cosine decay, early stopping, AMP, robust DataLoader), we obtain competitive, field-grade baselines; e.g., AlexNet, GoogLeNet with aux, and Swin-T lead among pretrained models, while a small residual CNN reaches within ≈ 2% of their performance along with per-class reports to surface hard categories (e.g., fine-grained grape and tomato diseases). Despite high scores, few crop-disease interactions remain systematically difficult (as in grape, fig, and cherry). Hence, errors concentrate in a small, long-tail subset.

title: Machine Learning based Predictive Analytics of Student Retention Using Transcript Data
authors: Faiza Tahir, Maha Saddal, Mamoona Mumtaz, Rabia Anwar, Saher Nazir, Maida Gulfam
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: The high dropout rates in Computer Science programs pose a major challenge to higher education institutions, especially in developing nations like Pakistan, where economic constraints and limited academic support exacerbate the situation. Early identification of vulnerable students and intervention tailored to their needs are crucial in enhancing retention and academic performance. This paper proposes a data-informed predictive framework utilizing official transcript data to assess student performance and identify dropout risks. A total dataset of 200 CS undergraduate students was gathered from the University of Management and Technology, Sialkot campus, covering several semesters with regular as well as repeating students. The most important variables were GPA, credit hours, course grades, attendance, and student status. Using the preprocessed and encoded dataset, clustering algorithms were used to discover performance-based clusters. Later, Gradient Boosting Regression predicted grades, and the Random Forest Classifier was used to classify at-risk students. The results indicated that clustering distinguished between student groups clearly, whereas regression analysis predicted grade advancement moderately with better accuracy upon hyperparameter tuning. The classification model differentiated between regular and repeating students with more than 97% accuracy, successfully identifying students at risk of academic failure. These results emphasize the promise of predictive analytics to make available timely, individualized academic assistance and inform institutional policy in an effort to decrease dropout rates. Although limited to one institution and omitting qualitative factors related to teaching, the research exhibits a scalable model for enhancing student retention by using data-driven decision-making.

title: Learning to Prompt with Refining Text Knowledge for Zero-shot Video Action Recognition
authors: Hao Wang, Fang Liu, Licheng Jiao, Jiahao Wang, Shuo Li, Lingling Li, Puhua Chen, Xu Liu
abstract: Foundational vision-language models (VLMs) like CLIP are redefining the vision domain with their exceptional generalization capabilities. Prompt-based learning methods adapt pre-trained VLMs to video action recognition tasks using task-specific learnable text tokens. However, these tokens often struggle to generalize to unseen categories, as they tend to forget general textual knowledge. To address this, we construct knowledge prompts composed of handcrafted and descriptive prompts and introduce a novel knowledge-guided context mapping to enhance the generalization of learnable prompts to unseen categories. This approach mitigates the forgetting of fundamental knowledge by reducing the discrepancy between learnable prompts and knowledge prompts while simultaneously allowing the prompts to extract rich contextual knowledge from LLM data. Then, incorporating the knowledge-guided context mapping into the contrastive loss enables zero-shot transfer of prompts to new categories and data, providing discriminative prompts for both seen and unseen tasks. In addition, we propose an advanced temporal aggregation method that refines uniform mean pooling by incorporating frame-level textual relevance scoring. Extensive evaluations on multiple benchmarks demonstrate that learning to prompt with refining text knowledge is an effective quick-tuning method, achieving superior sample generalization performance without increasing training parameters.

title: Reduction of current consumption in servomotors through the analysis of jerk profile of the motion dynamics
authors: Gonzalez Villagomez Esau, Rodriguez Donate Carlos, Gonzalez Villagomez Jacob, Calderon Uribe Uriel
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Energy consumption in industrial machines has become a significant factor in the reduction of production costs. The design of trajectories and the manipulation of motion dynamics have proven to be a viable solution for reducing energy consumption in industrial machinery. In this study, an analysis of the current consumption of a servomotor using two motion dynamics was conducted, which demonstrated a 30% reduction in current consumption of the profile with reduced jerk levels.

title: Multimodal Fusion for Physical Telerehabilitation using YoLov8 and Machine Learning Classifier
authors: Aqsa Fazal, Shaheryar Najam, Ahmad Jalal
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Recognizing actions made by humans in rehabilitation faces challenges associated with differences in font, speed of movement, strength and variability of execution. To examine this phenomenon, we outline a multi-stream feature fusion framework designed to classify each exercise using RGB images by leveraging both binary silhouettes of the human participant and RGB frames of the exercising individual. For silhouettes, a DeepLabV3 model is used to extract the human's form, a model path that we found to be the most accurate and useful, to analyze movement in relation to a static position of the participant's body. For RGB frames, we extract body joint keypoints from YOLOv8 and use Gray Level Co-occurrence Matrix (GLCM) statistics assessing texture measures including contrast, correlation, entropy, energy, and homogeneity. To quantify the human movement from binary silhouettes, we extract Fourier descriptors, Radon transforms, and distance transforms that also describe contour and spatial geometry. Features are fused into a single feature vector that is optimized using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO). We use a Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) for the classification model. When applying the framework to the UCO Rehab dataset, we achieved a 96.1% recognition accuracy, demonstrating that complementary uses of visual cues can improve rehabilitation-based action recognition.

title: Sentiment Analysis of COVID-19 Posts on the X Platform Using Machine Learning
authors: Mohammed Saeed Alhaweti, Yasamiyan Abdullah Aljadani
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: This study analyzes the sentiments of Saudi users toward the COVID-19 pandemic using posts from the X platform (formerly Twitter). We adopt a descriptive design and employ natural language processing (NLP) techniques—particularly machine learning (ML)—to build and evaluate a sentence-level sentiment classifier. After manually annotating posts with contextual, sentence-level labels (positive, negative, neutral) rather than relying on word-level lexicons, we detect emotional expressions such as anger, sadness, and disgust using a pre-trained Arabic emotion model partially aligned with Robert Plutchik’s Wheel of Emotions. We implement two ML algorithms—Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Naïve Bayes (NB)—and assess their performance using accuracy and confusion matrices. Data analysis was conducted in Google Colab using Python. Results show that sentiment among Saudi users varied across the three polarity classes, with the largest share being positive (42.1%). The NB classifier achieved the best overall accuracy (78.1%) with balanced predictions across the three classes, indicating robust performance for sentence-level Arabic social-media sentiment classification.

title: Predicting Stroke Risk: A Comparison of ML and DL Approaches
authors: Awais Arif, Maliha Fajar
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Stroke is a major cause of death and long-term disability globally. Early stroke risk prediction is crucial for timely intervention and enhanced patient outcomes. This paper offers a comparative study of machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models for stroke risk prediction based on a publicly available dataset [1]. Two widely adopted ML models, Random Forest (RF) and LightGBM (LGBM), are benchmarked against two DL models, Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) and TabNet (TN). To address class imbalance, the SMOTE–Tomek hybrid resampling technique is applied [2]–[4], and median imputation is used for missing values. Results demonstrate that ML models achieved the highest overall accuracy and calibration (Random Forest: Accuracy = 96.34%, AUC = 0.9949), while DL models, particularly MLP, achieved superior sensitivity (Recall = 99.68%). These findings highlight a trade-off: ML models provide robust and balanced predictions, while DL models reduce the risk of false negatives, making them suitable in safety-critical healthcare settings.

title: Prediction of Service Performance of Angular Contact Ball Bearings Using a Back Propagation Neural Network Model
authors: Yicong Wang, Lingli Jiang, Wenjun Shu, Yi Zeng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: As critical fundamental components in high-end equipment, angular contact ball bearings undergo service performance degradation that directly impacts the operational accuracy and reliability of the entire system. Traditional numerical methods suffer from low computational efficiency, whereas simplified theoretical frameworks cannot accurately capture the dynamic coupling mechanisms between bearing assembly parameters and service performance. This limitation leads to an inevitable trade-off between efficiency and accuracy in predicting dynamic responses. To address this issue, we propose a Backpro Pagation (BP) neural network-finite element modeling framework. First, a dynamic model of the angular contact ball bearing is constructed. Second, representative assembly process parameters are selected as inputs, and performance indicators are defined as outputs, with the dataset generated via finite element simulations. Third, a surrogate model is developed to predict bearing service performance. Finally, the effectiveness and accuracy of the surrogate model are validated experimentally, thereby providing a solid theoretical foundation and technical support for condition-based maintenance and intelligent health management of bearings.

title: On-Device Inference and Training Acceleration of Graph Neural Networks with Quantized Arithmetic
authors: Jose Nunez-Yanez, Olle Hansson
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the hardware accel-eration of the forward and backward passes with quantized arithmetic in graph convolutional (GCN) and attention networks (GAT). The proposed architecture uses adaptive fixed-point numeric precisions down to 1-bit in the forward pass and 4-bit in the backward pass. The accelerator is mapped to a Zynq UltraScale+ MPSOC and integrated within the PyTorch framework, delivering scalable performance with multiple configuration options that include varying the number of hardware threads and compute units available in each thread. Each hard-ware thread uses a hierarchical dataflow with fine and coarse-grained components. The coarse-grained dataflow is composed of aggregation, combination, and attention stages. Hardware-aware quantization is used to optimize the parameter width of weights, features, attention coefficients, and graph connectivity expressed in the normalized adjacency matrix. Performance evaluation using popular Planetoid graph datasets shows acceleration factors higher than 2 orders of magnitude for GCN and GAT compared with on-device CPU execution. The experimental measurements compared with other FPGA, mobile GPU, and CPU hardware show up to 50x better performance per Joule.

title: Visual Inspection of CNC Milling Tool Defects: A Study with Few-Shot Learning
authors: Thanh Huy Phung, Quang-Huy Nguyen, Due-Trung Ho, Thinh Nguyen Duc, Xuan Van Tran, Quoc-Chi Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This study investigates the application of few-shot learning to detect defects and fractures in mechanical parts-a critical task for inspection of machining tools, machine part evaluation, and manufacturing quality control. Specifically, the fractures and defects on the Computer Numerical Control (CNC) milling tool were examined. For this purpose, experimental datasets were collected using an in-house imaging system integrated into a CNC machine, enabling efficient capture and processing of cutting tool images. First, the few-shot classification was evaluated for tool damage identification using standard algorithms, with Grad-CAM providing deeper insights into the results. The object detection methods were then applied for precise defect localization. The results show that defect detection achieves a accuracy of more than 96 % under a 5 shot configuration. For specific defect types, the mean Average Precision at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 \%}$</tex> IoU (mAP@50) reaches <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 7 \%}$</tex> with both Fewshot Faster R-CNN and YOLOv11 on side-view images, while bottom-view detection yields <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 4 \%}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex> mAP@50 for FSFRCNN and YOLOv11, respectively, and can improve further with relaxed IoU constraints. The promising results indicate significant potential for industrial implementation.

title: An Asymmetric Dual Swin Transformer for High-Resolution Aerial Segmentation
authors: Ham-Thuat Vo, Thien Huynh The
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Semantic segmentation of aerial and satellite imagery is fundamental for various remote sensing applications, including urban planning, environmental monitoring, and transportation management. Recent advances in deep learning have leveraged convolutional neural networks and multi-head self-attention (MSA) mechanisms to achieve substantial improvements over traditional machine learning approaches. Furthermore, several studies have demonstrated that dual-branch architectures can markedly enhance performance in aerial image segmentation. In this work, we propose the Dual Swin Transformer DeepLabV3+ (DSTD) network. This hybrid architecture combines Swin Transformers with a dual-branch design to enhance contextual and spatial feature understanding. This design improves feature fusion, achieving high segmentation performance while maintaining computational efficiency. Experimental results show that DSTD outperforms state-of-the-art methods such as BiSeNet, ST-UNet, and SwinCNN, achieving up to 91.94 % global accuracy, 82.79 % mean Intersection-over-Union, and 90.13 % mean Boundary F1-Score on the ISPRS Vaihingen dataset. These results demonstrate that the proposed architecture is a robust and efficient solution for high-resolution remote sensing image segmentation.

title: A 1-Bit Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface: Design, Theory and Beam Steering in S and C Band
authors: K R Jaganbharathi, G Boopalan, Truong Khang Nguyen, K Senthilnathan
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: In this work, we propose a square loop-based unit cell to realize a 1-bit reconfigurable intelligent surface. The proposed unit cell operates at two sub 6 GHz frequencies, namely, 3.5 GHz and 4.2 GHz. By integrating a PIN diode into the unit cell, two distinct reflection phase states are achieved, which are encoded as digital states '0' and '1'. The beam forming of the proposed design, which works as a reflective RIS, is analyzed by tailoring a distinct unit cell array configuration. In this paper, uniform, striped and checkerboard array configurations are explored under plane wave incidence to achieve multiple beams forming. Through the full wave simulations, a single, twin and four beam are achieved for uniform, striped and checkerboard array configurations, respectively. Additionally, the beam forming of the given array configuration is validated by employing theoretical modelling. Further, the single beam forming of the proposed RIS is theoretically investigated for a spherical wave source at elevation angles of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0}^{\circ}, \mathbf{1 0}^{\circ}, \mathbf{2 0}^{\circ}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0}^{\circ}$</tex>. The various phase profiles of an array are generated, which result in single beamforming for the specified angles. This study confirms the accuracy and effectiveness of the proposed RIS design for beamforming applications.

title: RVO-GAT-MARl for Scalable Multi-Agent Formation Navigation
authors: Yujie Luo, Hongyun Xiong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: We address the problem of multi-agent formation navigation, where multiple agents must reach their goals safely while maintaining coordinated formations in dynamic environments. The main challenges lie in effectively modeling inter-agent interactions and ensuring scalability to large teams. To this end, we propose a hybrid approach that integrates the Velocity Obstacle (VO) and Reciprocal Velocity Obstacle (RVO) models for obstacle representation, and employs a Graph Attention Network (GAT) to aggregate neighboring agents' state information. The GAT-based policy enhances scalability and alleviates the curse of dimensionality, while parameter sharing across agents further improves adaptability in large-scale environments. In addition, a multi-objective reward function based on goal distance and expected collision time encourages smooth, safe, and efficient trajectories. Extensive experiments in an extended Multi-Agent Particle Environment (MPE) demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior robustness, safety, and scalability compared with state-of-the-art baselines, particularly in complex dynamic environments.

title: Grid-Feeding to a Grid-Forming Converter with Photovoltaic Energy in an Islanded AC Microgrid
authors: A. Valle L. Obed, Perez R. Javier, D. Flores N. Darcy, A. Beristain J. Jose, de J. Teran Gonzalez G. Raul A., L. Gonzalez S. Ana
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This paper presents the development and validation of a control strategy for converters in an alternating current (AC) microgrid (MG), focusing on the reconfiguration capability between Grid-Forming (GFR) and Grid-Feeding (GFD) converter. A cascaded control scheme is proposed for the GFR and a current control loop for the GFD, enabling stable operation under load variations and compatibility with nonlinear loads. The microgrid is modeled using averaged equations that describe the system’s electrical behavior. Simulation results demonstrate that, in the event of a GFR failure, the GFD can dynamically reconfigure itself as a GFR, ensuring uninterrupted operation. This functionality enhances the system's flexibility, resilience, and autonomy, particularly in distributed generation scenarios powered by renewable energy sources such as photovoltaic (PV) systems.

title: Statistical Analysis and Probability Distributions of Solar and Wind Resources for the La Rumorosa Region, Mexico
authors: Alberto Gutiérrez Martínez, Carlos Rubio Maya, Gilberto Gonzalez Avalos, Víctor Manuel Ambriz Díaz, Hugo C. Gutiérrez Sanchez de
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This study presents a systematic review and detailed probabilistic analysis of hourly wind speed and solar irradiance data for the La Rumorosa region, Baja California, Mexico. A total of 87,360 hourly wind speed data points were analyzed over a 10-year period to identify the probability distribution function (PDF) that best characterizes the monthly statistical behavior of the wind resource. While the literature indicates that the Weibull distribution is most suitable for wind resource studies, it does not always provide the optimal fit, demanding exploration of alternative PDFs. Five commonly employed probability distributions were evaluated: Weibull, Log-normal, Gamma, Rayleigh, and Normal; using statistical metrics including root mean square error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), mean absolute percentage error (MAPE), and the coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), complemented by the Kolmogorov–Smirnov (K-S) goodness-of-fit test. For wind data, results confirmed that the Weibull distribution demonstrated optimal performance in most months (RMSE: 0.0069, MAE: 0.0042, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.984, K-S: 0.027), although the Normal distribution yielded better results in some cases (RMSE: 0.0035, MAE: 0.0025, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>: 0.996, K-S: 0.010). For solar resource assessment, 51,100 hourly data points were analyzed, focusing on the 14 most representative daylight hours. Initial application of unimodal forms of the aforementioned PDFs yielded unsatisfactory results. Consequently, a bimodal approach—combining two probability distributions—was implemented, enabling adequate representation of intra-daily variability under mixed atmospheric conditions. For solar irradiance data, results indicated that bimodal analysis more effectively captured the variability and intermittency inherent in solar data. The primary contribution of this work lies in the development and application of a robust methodology based on comprehensive statistical analysis and validation through multiple error metrics, designed for precise sizing of solar–wind hybrid systems. This approach provides enhanced characterization of regional renewable resources and supports the design of more efficient energy storage and operational strategies to address intermittency challenges.

title: XAI-Enhanced Physics-Informed Neural Networks for State Estimation of Li-ion Batteries
authors: Sheroz Shahid Tabassum, Muhammad Saeed, Hafiz Muhammad Jawaad, Hassan Elahi, Arash Khalatbarsoltani, Ayesha Zeb, Hamid Jabbar, Umar Shahbaz Khan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Data-driven state of charge (SOC) estimation for Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), though highly promising, suffers from opacity, overfitting, and lack of trustworthiness in safety-critical applications like electric vehicles and grid storage. To address this issue, this paper proposes an explainable physics-informed neural network (PINN) approach tailored for SOC estimation in dynamic scenarios, integrating battery internal features with attention mechanism for precise state prediction and SHAP for interpretability and framework optimization. The main goal is to enhance reliability and robustness across dynamic operations, while maintaining low complexity through model reduction per SHAP’s recommendations. Using a light observer, PINN-based SOC is first realized and validated. The framework is then optimized using SHAP analysis to retain only the most influential features that ensure similar performance. Experimental results against dynamical scenarios and critical temperatures demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed XAI -enhanced framework with RMSE<1.4% and high explanation fidelity, showcasing its potential to meet the accuracy, safety, and deployment requirements of next-generation BMS.

title: Secure Steganography with Encryption for Uncompressed YUV Video Frames
authors: Md. Mushfiqur Rahman
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Ensuring sensitive information remains protected during transmission has become a primary concern, particularly when transmitted with various media, such as video frames. Traditional steganographic techniques have had difficulties merging adequate security with low visibility, resulting in secure video storage data becoming unembeddable while losing essential video quality. This study implements a two-tiered security system to combat these concerns by integrating the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) encryption with a more sophisticated steganography technique. The AES with the use of 128-bit encryption in the first tier encrypts the secret data, whereas the second tier is an enhanced steganographic process with the Least Significant Bit (LSB) encoding that utilizes an 8-directional pixel selecting process for conveying the encryption data within the video frame without sacrificing the visual fidelity. The proposed Model surpassed current techniques, as indicated by the excellent PSNR of 74.082 and SSIM of 0.999992913 obtained for the Daffodil Varsity (DV) frame. These outcomes reflect the suitability of the proposed Model in ensuring maximum security with imperceptibility and demonstrating its potential for secure video steganography.

title: Automated Analysis and Summarization System By using CNN for JWST Images
authors: Aditya Kale, Swaraj Pawar, Yogesh Dongare, Shashwati Kale, Nilesh Sable, Anuradha Yenkikar
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: In this work, we introduce an automated tool based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for the analysis and classification of James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) galaxy images. We built and assessed four deep learning models: VGG16, InceptionV3, EfficientNet-B0, and ResNet-50 in order to classify galaxies into eight different classes. The approach employs several data preprocessing methods, including data augmentation and normalizing, in order to raise model stability. Our results reveal that various architectures perform differently; InceptionV3 exhibits high overfitting with a 98% training accuracy but a 63% validation accuracy. ResNet-50 shown the best generalizing ability with a validation accuracy of $\mathbf{9 2 \%}$. We observed class-dependent variations when models showed almost perfect accuracy and recall for some galaxy types (NGC3256 nuc1, NGC 1365) but not others.

title: A Multi-Objective Genetic Algorithm for Large-Scale Integrated Berth Allocation and Quay Crane Assignment Problem With Maintenance Activities
authors: Xiangyi Teng, Zhengyu Zhang, Tao Ma, Jing Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: In the current era of globalization, with increasing vessel cargo and limited port resources, the operational efficiency of container terminals is of paramount importance. Berth allocation and quay crane allocation problems (BACAPs) emerge as pivotal focal points, especially in large-scale container terminals. Although preventive maintenance for quay cranes is crucial for reducing equipment failures and widely implemented in real-world operations, it is often overlooked in existing studies. Lately, few methods are proposed considering maintenance activities. However, their performance are unsatisfied in terms of large-scale problems and hard to meet the requirement of efficiency. To deal with this challenge, in this paper, we present a mixed integer bi-objective optimization model and further propose a novel algorithm to address the large-scale BACAP with quay crane maintenance activities. This model aims to minimize vessel turnaround durations and the penalty of unscheduled maintenance. Meanwhile, based on NSGA-II, the model called RTAA utilizes a novel decoding method with Recurrent Temporal berth Allocation and quay crane Assignment, which can greatly reduce the probability of generating infeasible solutions in a heuristic way. Moreover, the island model is involved to improve the efficiency and parallelism of the model and enhance the diversity of the Pareto-front solutions. Compared to the existing methods in both small and large instances, the RTAA demonstrates its efficacy in discovering superior and more diverse solutions. In particular, for large-scale problems involving 100 vessels, as well as more berths and quay cranes, our model still delivers superior performance with a significant reduction in computation time. Additionally, our approach shows excellent scalability, as it can be easily adapted to scenarios that do not consider maintenance activities.

title: Service Capacity Maximization in Multi-UAV MEC: Deployment, Offloading, and Resource Allocation
authors: Xuan Liu, Shumei Liu, Jiawei Zhu, Yisheng An, Chen Mu, Lei Guo, Yonghui Li
abstract: To address the increasing computation-intensive tasks, we consider a multi-unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-enabled computing offloading system and aim to explore its maximum service capacity. The existing solutions aim to optimize user service experience in terms of delay or energy efficiency, but this fundamentally assumes that all tasks are completable. We highlight that all computational tasks in practical application environments have specific delay constraints. As such, it is unrealistic to consider that all tasks can always be completed on schedule when resources fall short of demand. To this end, we propose a service-maximized bilevel (SMax-bilevel) optimization scheme, and formulate a task completion rate maximization problem. Due to its non-convex complexity, we decompose the original problem into a tractable bilevel structure. At the upper level, an encoding mechanism-enhanced adaptive differential evolution algorithm (ADEEM) is developed to determine UAV deployment locations that maximize service coverage. At the lower level, a theorem is presented to guide user selection, task offloading, and resource allocation, aiming to maximize the number of completed tasks within their delay constraints. The two levels iteratively interact to produce an optimal solution. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed SMax-bilevel scheme significantly enhances system service capacity while reducing algorithmic complexity, outperforming existing benchmark solutions.

title: M-WAD: Self-Supervised Multimodal undergain Anomaly Detection for Wafer Probing
authors: Hyekyung Yoon, Minhyuk Lee, Dahyun Won, Kiljae Lee, Kyungja Park, Jaehoon Joo, Jangwon Seo, Yonghoon Kwon, Youngsoo Ha, Myungjoo Kang
abstract: Wafer probing is a critical inspection stage in semiconductor manufacturing, where the electrical behavior of on-wafer circuits is evaluated prior to packaging. Most existing wafer anomaly detection approaches have primarily relied on image-based inspection, while recent time-series–based models such as SwinProbeFormer have focused on detecting over-gain anomalies in probing signals. In contrast, undergain anomalies have received relatively little attention due to their subtle deviation from normal probing behavior, despite their significant impact on probing efficiency and test-cell throughput. In this paper, we propose M-WAD, a multimodal wafer anomaly detection framework that jointly leverages time-series signals, data-specific visual representations, and textual prompts to effectively detect undergain anomalies during wafer probing. M-WAD introduces a domain-aware residual image generation strategy that amplifies subtle motion degradations and enables robust multimodal representation learning. Extensive experimental results on real-world wafer probing datasets demonstrate that the proposed approach achieves state-of-the-art performance in undergain anomaly detection and consistently outperforms existing methods, including models tailored for wafer probing. These results highlight the effectiveness of multimodal learning for capturing subtle probing anomalies and its potential for practical deployment in industrial wafer testing environments.

title: High Speed Processing Using a Complex Photonic Perceptron Based on Tunable MZIs
authors: C. R. Oliveira, Í. A. Araújo, M. A. Romero, A. F. Herbster
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Photonic Neural Networks (PNN) are attractive as high-throughput, energy-efficient accelerators for a wide range of data-intensive tasks. In this work, we evaluate a photonic complex-valued perceptron based on tunable Mach-Zehnder Interferometers (MZI) designed to be used as a building block in a Field Programmable Photonic Gate Array (FPPGA). The final goal is to develop a photonic circuit which can overcome fiber linearities and nonlinearities effects and process data while operating at a high data rate, while remaining fully reconfigurable by the FPPGA architecture. The simulation results show error rates in the order of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−5</sup> in the XOR delayed application for trained binary rates between 5 and 16 Gbps, demonstrating the design effectiveness for potential application on an FPPGA.

title: A Persuasive Design Framework for Waste Management Application based on Maqasid al-Shari’ah: A Fuzzy Delphi Study
authors: Zohora Azmin Shompa, Hazwani Mohd Mohadis, Aznan Zuhid Saidin, Evi Indriasari Mansor, Nazlena Mohamad Ali, Mahfuzah Muhamad Tarmidi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) management remains a critical challenge affecting environmental sustainability and public health. Existing technological interventions, however, often overlook the integration of Islamic ethical perspectives, particularly Maqasid al-Shari’ah (Objectives of Islamic Law), which provides a holistic foundation for responsible human behaviour. This study proposes a Persuasive Design Framework for waste management applications grounded in the five essential principles of Maqasid Al-Shari’ah i.e. preservation of religion, life, intellect, progeny, and wealth, aimed at promoting sustainable waste management practices among Muslim communities. Validation of the framework was conducted using the Fuzzy Delphi Method (FDM) with twelve domain experts representing Islamic jurisprudence, Islamic economics, ICT and Islam, Human-Computer Interaction (HCI), and waste management. Two rounds of expert review identified 12 core persuasive elements comprising of reduction, tunneling, tailoring, personalization, self-monitoring, simulation, rewards, reminders, suggestion, liking, authority and verifiability. The findings demonstrate the potential of embedding Islamic ethical values within persuasive system design to strengthen intrinsic motivation, and behavioural compliance in waste management practices and provides actionable guidance for designing ethical and culturally relevant waste management solutions.

title: Ethical Intelligence by Design: Bias Mitigation through Nature-Inspired Machine Learning
authors: Yuvaraj V, Saravanan G, Paramanathan E, Subramanian C, Subbarayan Poornavel, Balakrishnan Senthil
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: AI and data mining methods have become the focus of quite a few industries, however, the issue of ethical responsibility, especially in terms of algorithmic biases has come to the fore. This paper seeks to investigate the severe ramifications of the biased data which causes applications in areas like recruitment, law enforcement or healthcare to be biased. However, some existing literature addresses the issues in a rather shallow manner when it comes to methodologies of identifying or addressing bias and its instances. This puts the public trust at risk and limits the advancements of AI technologies.As a solution to this urgent problem, this research proposes a rigorous framework for the detection, response and prevention of bias in all stages of the data mining process, and explores a range of algorithms and metrics for the identification and control of bias in machine learning models. Several case studies allow us to investigate the applicability of the proposed solutions and evaluate their effectiveness in practice, thus increasing the level of fairness and the result of the research demonstrated relationships in order to reduce bias not only in anticipation of legal requirements but as part of ethical practice of AI. This research is concerned with the discussion of ethics of algorithm use in regards to AI applications to equity and inclusion among the stakeholders of AI allowing for actionable insights into how different actors will interact with the technology.

title: Data Augmentation Pipeline for Text Recognition of Laser-Etched Serial Number Images
authors: Theerapat Niamhom, Worarat Krathu, Pornchai Mongkolnam
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenging task of recognizing severely degraded laser-etched serial numbers on copper surfaces, where conventional OCR and scene text recognition models struggle due to noise, incomplete characters, and limited training data. To overcome these challenges, we proposed a data augmentation pipeline leveraging generative adversarial networks (GAN) for finetuning a transformer-based text recognition model. The pipeline consists of 3 three main modules: (1) character-free background generation module using a LaMa inpainting model to remove existing characters from real images, (2) Character Generation module using four CycleGAN models trained on different appearance groups to synthesize diverse textured characters to create character images, and (3) a text insertion module combines these synthesized characters onto the generated backgrounds. Fine-tuning the pretrained TrOCR model with our augmented dataset achieved an absolute accuracy of 88.5 %, representing a 72.79 % improvement over the baseline. This highlights the effectiveness of our approach for extreme degradation and its potential for broader industrial serial number recognition applications.

title: Agentic AI Framework for Adaptive Clinical Workflow Orchestration
authors: Quy Minh Le, Duc-Trong Le, Hoang D. Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Healthcare systems in resource-constrained settings face systemic challenges, including workflow inefficiencies and clinician overload, which directly threaten patient safety and quality of care. Although Artificial Intelligence (AI) has shown substantial promise, current approaches predominantly emphasize isolated analytic models, leaving unaddressed the central challenge of optimizing the clinical workflow itself. This gap between singlepoint predictions and end-to-end workflow optimization remains a critical barrier to impact. To address this, this paper introduces the Vietnam Health-Agent System (VHAS), a system-theoretic framework to build agentic healthcare ecosystems. Its core component, the Clinical Workflow Orchestrator, functions as a meta-agent that coordinates specialized tool-using agents and employs Reinforcement Learning to dynamically compose, execute and adapt workflows in real time. We argue that medical AI must shift from building standalone tools to orchestrating coordinated, adaptive workflows. VHAS provides a scalable architectural blueprint for this transition, enabling efficient, reliable, interpretable, and equitable healthcare systems.

title: Decentralized Smart EV Charging with Multi-Agent System Communication and Energy Coordination
authors: Priyansh Dwivedi, Himanshu Tiwari, Pradhyumna Yadav, Murari Kumar, K Shanthi Swarup
abstract: This paper presents a decentralized smart electric vehicle (EV) charging framework that integrates Raspberry Pi and Arduino-based controllers with multi-agent coordination for efficient and scalable operation. The system leverages IoT-enabled edge computing to support adaptive load balancing, real-time monitoring, and cloud synchronization. Unlike centralized approaches, the proposed architecture employs a Raspberry Pi server to manage distributed charging nodes through MQTT-based communication, ensuring resilience in bandwidth-constrained environments. Hardware prototyping and MATLAB/Simulink simulations validate the feasibility of the design, demonstrating improvements in load management and fault handling. Experimental results show balanced power allocation among multiple EVs with reduced grid stress and reliable user interaction through a local dashboard. While future extensions such as bidirectional Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) and Demand Response (DR) integration are envisioned, the present work provides a cost-effective and modular prototype suitable for urban, semi-urban, and rural deployments.

title: Physics-Guided Indicators with PSO-Tuned Regression for EV Battery SOH Estimation
authors: V. Yashwanth, Y. Likhith, B. Nikhil, C. Priyanka, K. H. Phanishree
abstract: Lithium-ion battery state of health (SOH) estimation is a core enabler of predictive maintenance in electric vehicles (EVs). This paper develops a reproducible pipeline for SOH prediction using the NASA Prognostics Center of Excellence (PCoE) aging datasets (cells B0005–B0007) and compares three learning models whose hyperparameters are tuned via particle swarm optimization (PSO): long short-term memory (LSTM), a 1D convolutional neural network (CNN), and support vector regression (SVR). From charge–discharge time series (voltage, current, and temperature under constant-current/constant-voltage (CC–CV) charging), sixteen physics-guided health indicators (HIs) are engineered and twelve are retained via Pearson-correlation screening. Models are trained on sequential cycles and evaluated on held-out cycles with MAE, RMSE, MAPE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Across all cells, the PSO-SVR consistently achieves the lowest error and the highest R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (around 0.92–0.93), outperforming PSO-CNN and PSO-LSTM, while preserving the physically consistent monotonic SOH decline. We also outline a lightweight deployment sketch (Flask REST API and React UI) for real-time inference in maintenance dashboards. The results indicate that a compact HI set, coupled with PSO-tuned models, enables accurate and deployment-ready SOH estimation for EV battery maintenance.

title: Radio- and Power-Over-Fiber Transmission Using a Hybrid Optical Cable for Scalable B5G Networks
authors: Paulo Kiohara, Felipe B. F. Pinto, Eduardo. S. Lima, Arismar Cerqueira Sodré
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents the conception and evaluation of an integrated Radio- and Power-over-Fiber (RPoF) system that supports scalable and energy-efficient solutions for beyond 5G (B5G) networks. The proposed architecture supports two remote units (RUs), referred to as midhaul and fronthaul, employing a single hybrid optical cable composed of single-mode fibers (SMFs) and multimode fibers (MMFs). Digitally modulated RoF signals at 3.5 GHz and 700 MHz are transmitted simultaneously over the same SMF to the midhaul and fronthaul stations, respectively. Optical power is delivered throughout the MMF using a high-power laser diode (HPLD) at 808 nm to supply a receiver module (Rx) with a 20 dB amplifier at 200 m. Additionally, a laser diode (LD) at 1550 nm is coupled to a second SMF to power a photodetector (PD) located at 5.2 km. The system achieved optical power transmission efficiencies (OPTE) of 74.3% and 66.8%, and power transmission efficiencies (PTE) of 33.9% and 17.7% for the midhaul and fronthaul links, respectively. Error vector magnitude (EVMRMs) values remained within 3GPP limits for 64-QAM and 256-QAM modulations, confirming the feasibility of simultaneous photonic power delivery and high-quality RF signal transmission in a unified RPoF link for B5G applications.

title: Design and Implementation of 4-bit ALU Using 90nm CMOS Technology
authors: Vishal Sanjay Raju, Karthi Pradeep
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This paper presents a 4-bit Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) design and implementation using 90 nm CMOS (Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor) technology. The ALU is a fundamental building block of any central processing unit (CPU), microcontroller unit (MCU), GPU's, DSP's etc. and is responsible for performing arithmetic and logical operations. The design process involves the schematic design of adder, subtractor, comparator, 1 's complement and decoder for the development of the ALU architecture followed by simulation of the design using Cadence Virtuoso EDA (Electronic Design Automation) tools. The implementation phase focuses on layout design to ensure the functionality and manufacturability of the ALU. The performance metrics such as power consumption, area, and speed are analyzed to validate the efficiency of the design. The successful realization of the 4-bit ALU showcases the potential for advancements in integrated circuit design and the practical application of CMOS technology in modern computing systems.

title: AttNetVLAD and AttNetVLAD++: Capturing Frame Feature Correlations with Self-Attention for Event Spotting in Football Videos
authors: Anh Pham Hong, Khoan Le Duc, Hoang Pham Minh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Football is a global industry with significant commercial potential, yet analyzing long matches to extract key events remains challenging. Event spotting in football videos focuses on detecting predefined events and localizing their temporal boundaries within a match. This task faces two main challenges. First, feature aggregation methods such as NetVLAD and NetVLAD++ operate on frame-level features without adequately capturing correlations across neighboring frames. Second, the dataset is highly imbalanced, where frequent events dominate rare ones. To model inter-frame dependencies more effectively, we propose AttNetVLAD and AttNetVLAD++, which integrate self-attention before NetVLAD and NetVLAD++. In addition, we replace binary cross-entropy with Focal Loss and introduce a novel resampling strategy to mitigate the class imbalance. Experiments on the SoccerNet-v2 dataset show that AttNetVLAD and AttNetVLAD++ with Focal Loss achieve the best performance when evaluated using a-mAP under the Loose criterion within the Visible group, with average precision of 49.12 and 50.81, respectively. These results represent improvements of 13.59 and 8.22 over the baseline NetVLAD and NetVLAD++ trained with binary cross-entropy. Overall, the results demonstrate the effectiveness of integrating self-attention with imbalance-aware learning for football event spotting.

title: Optimizing AES Encryption Algorithm on Resource-Constrained Devices in IoT Systems
authors: Tram K. T. Nguyen, Khoa D. Vu, Anh Q. Ngo
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: In the rapidly expanding Internet of Things (IoT), ensuring secure communication among numerous resource-constrained devices remains a major challenge. The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) is widely adopted for its strong security, yet its deployment on devices with limited processing power, memory, and energy demands careful optimization. This study explores the core mechanisms of AES and evaluates its performance on typical IoT platforms, analyzing trade-offs between encryption strength, computational efficiency, and system overhead. The results highlight practical optimization strategies that enhance AES performance in constrained environments without compromising security, offering valuable insights for the design of secure and efficient IoT applications.

title: ECC-EXONUM-eVOTING: Enhancing Secure E-Voting with AI-Based Fraud Detection and Offline Voting Support
authors: A.K. SarveshKrishna, M. Anbarasan, M. Suguna
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: As the world transitions toward digital-first governance and civic participation, ensuring the security and integrity of voting systems has become a critical concern. Traditional evoting mechanisms, although convenient, suffer from a range of vulnerabilities - including voter impersonation, double voting, identity leaks, and tampering by insiders or external adversaries. ECC-EXONUM-eVOTING was previously proposed to mitigate many of these issues through elliptic curve cryptography (ECC), Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKP), and Exonum private blockchain. In this paper, we extend the capabilities of ECC-EXONUMeVOTING by integrating two novel modules aimed at enhancing both system intelligence and accessibility. First, we implement an AI-based fraud detection system using unsupervised anomaly detection techniques that proactively identify and block fraudulent voting behaviors in real time. Second, we introduce a secure offline voting architecture designed for voters in remote or lowconnectivity regions, using QR-based tokenization and Merkle-root-based integrity proofs for delayed blockchain synchronization. Through simulations, algorithmic validation, and comparative analysis, we demonstrate how these enhancements significantly increase the robustness, scalability, and real-world applicability of blockchain-based voting systems.
