title: Assessment of Unbalance in Tata Power Mumbai Network due to Single-Phase Railway Loads
authors: Santosh V. Singh, P. V. Navalkar, A. M. Kulkarni, G. T. Jawale
abstract: This study is motivated by the concern that there may be significant levels of voltage unbalance in the Tata Power (Mumbai) system due to the presence of single-phase traction (railway) loads. The available measurements are analyzed to assess the extent of the unbalance problem. The distribution of the negative sequence current injections obtained from the measurements is then used to perform Monte-Carlo simulations to estimate the negative sequence voltages under contingency and emergency conditions. The studies indicate that while unbalance is not significant under normal conditions, it could be so under certain contingency conditions. The worst-case scenario occurs under black start conditions, when large thermal stations have not started up, and high-priority railway loads are among the first to be energized. The variable nature of unbalanced loads and their spatial distribution necessitate flexible compensation devices, such as STATCOMs. A methodology is proposed and applied to assess the effect of compensation at multiple locations in this system.

title: Incorporating Uncertainty-Guided and Top-k Codebook Matching for Real-World Blind Image Super-Resolution
authors: Weilei Wen, Tianyi Zhang, Qianqian Zhao, Zhaohui Zheng, Chunle Guo, Xiuli Shao, Chongyi Li
abstract: Recent advancements in codebook-based real image super-resolution (SR) have shown promising results in real-world applications. The core idea involves matching high-quality image features from a codebook based on low-resolution (LR) image features. However, existing methods face two major challenges: inaccurate feature matching with the codebook and poor texture detail reconstruction. To address these issues, we propose a novel Uncertainty-Guided and Top-k Codebook Matching SR (UGTSR) framework, which incorporates three key components: (1) an uncertainty learning mechanism that guides the model to focus on texture-rich regions, (2) a Top-k feature matching strategy that enhances feature matching accuracy by fusing multiple candidate features, and (3) an Align-Attention module that enhances the alignment of information between LR and HR features. Experimental results demonstrate significant improvements in texture realism and reconstruction fidelity compared to existing methods. The source code can be found at https://github.com/wwlCape/UGTSR-main.

title: HaarReformer: Haar Wavelet-based Transformer for Low-Light Image Enhancement
authors: Shiyan Wang, Jun Chen, Heping Zhong, Jiawei Zhao, Chi Zhang
abstract: Transformer-based U-Net architectures have demonstrated remarkable advantages in low-light image enhancement, where the long-range dependency modeling improves enhancement performance, yet the substantial computational complexity hinders real-time applications. To address this, we propose HaarReformer, a single-stage low-light enhancement network that integrates Haar wavelets with a lightweight Transformer architecture. To improve computational efficiency, an illumination-guided cross-channel context aggregation module is introduced, which fuses cross-channel context with expanded receptive fields to enhance self-attention, striking a balance between global modeling and computational overhead while achieving linear complexity. For high-frequency information preservation, we construct a Haar wavelet-based downsampling scheme with multi-scale invertible decomposition, enabling representative feature learning. Furthermore, an ultralightweight dynamic upsampling module is introduced for efficient feature reconstruction, leveraging a learnable point sampling mechanism within a plug-and-play framework. Experimental results validate that HaarReformer effectively enhances low-light images with low computational overhead, while demonstrating superior performance in preserving color fidelity, structural integrity, and textural details.

title: CompoVis: Is Cross-modal Semantic Alignment of CLIP Optimal? A Visual Analysis Attempt_supp1-3660158.pdf
authors: Guodao Sun
abstract: Vision-language pre-trained models (VLMs) have shown impressive cross-modal understanding, yet their “compositional understanding” ability remains under investigation. We introduce CompoVis, a framework for visually probing cross-modal gaps in VLMs. CompoVis optimizes the grid layout to highlight alignment clusters and boundaries, visually interprets multi-head attention and semantic drift, and enables interactive fine-tuning unconstrained by closed datasets or offline models. Quantitative experiments and case studies explore key insights: VLMs rely on entity shortcuts rather than comprehension-driven; stubborn global modality isolation and suboptimal fine-grained alignment remain; fine-tuning with negative samples does not fundamentally alleviate the gaps. Approximately 89% of participants (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$n=27$</tex-math></inline-formula>) found that, compared to methods relying solely on data metrics, CompoVis offers a more innovative and effective approach for investigating modality gaps in VLMs.

title: Toward Practical Onboard Impedance Spectroscopy: Multi-Frequency, Self-Powered Measurement of Lithium-Ion Cells
authors: Amin Fischer, Hamza Boughanmi, Lukas Thierfelder, Ahmed Yahia Kallel, Olfa Kanoun
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) provides detailed insights into battery end of useful life (EUL) estimations and state of charge (SoC), but its application in real systems remains limited due to the need for external instrumentation, long measurement times, and inefficiencies in signal generation. This work presents an embedded, self-supplied EIS system based on a cell-to-cell inverter topology that enables one cell to provide the excitation energy required to measure its neighbor. The proposed design employs a synchronous buck-boost inverter for bidirectional energy transfer, avoiding DC offsets and maintaining cell charge balance during measurement. Excitation signals are generated by a microcontroller, and both single-sinusoidal and multi-sinusoidal excitations are supported. The multi-sinusoidal approach significantly reduces measurement time by simultaneously probing multiple frequencies. A hardware demonstrator was developed and validated on commercial lithium-ion cells. Results show that the proposed system reproduces the key features of impedance spectra when compared with a commercial reference instrument, with good accuracy across the low- and mid-frequency range. The method demonstrated high energy efficiency and preserved the state of charge during measurement. Overall, the approach represents a practical step toward integrating EIS directly into battery management systems for real-world applications.

title: Safe Search and Rescue Operations Based on Autonomous Robots: A Systematic Review of the General System Architecture
authors: Abbas Aqeel Kareem, Ahmed Jabbar Abid, Dalal Abdulmohsin Hammood, Ali Al-Naji, Javaan Chahl
abstract: Over the past few years, remarkable progress has been made in Autonomous Robotic Systems (ARSs) due to their multidisciplinary nature and applications. Among the most in-demand applications is the Search and Rescue (SAR) task, particularly in high-risk environments where human entry is unsafe. Specifically, teleoperated SAR platforms deploy dedicated sensors and control algorithms to optimize search effectiveness and mitigate risks incurred by human responders. This systematic review analyzes 74 research papers published between 2016 and 2024, with a focus on the role of robots in SAR operations (sensor integration), the types of robots employed, and the control algorithms used. The work classifies robotic systems in the context of SAR as either aerial, ground, or marine platforms and analyzes their sensor technologies, autonomous navigation functions, and human-robot interaction capabilities. A major contribution of this survey is the proposal and design of a five-layered architecture for robotic SAR systems, which categorizes system functions into clearly differentiated layers; namely, the HRI Layer, Perception Layer, Navigation Layer, Control Layer, and Robot Layer. Such a structured method enables modular, scalable, and real-time decision-making under dynamic disaster conditions. Moreover, this paper identifies several research challenges, including multi-robot coordination, AI-based real-time decision-making, and energy efficiency, providing a related analysis for the future development of robotic SAR systems.

title: SIM-assisted Secure Mobile Communications via Enhanced Proximal Policy Optimization Algorithm
authors: Wenxuan Ma, Bin Lin, Hongyang Pan, Geng Sun, Enyu Shi, Jiancheng An, Chau Yuen
abstract: With the development of sixth-generation (6G) wire-less communication networks, the security challenges are becoming increasingly prominent, especially for mobile users (MUs). As a promising solution, physical layer security (PLS) technology leverages the inherent characteristics of wireless channels to provide security assurance. Particularly, stacked intelligent metasurface (SIM) directly manipulates electromagnetic waves through their multilayer structures, offering significant potential for enhancing PLS performance in an energy efficient manner. Thus, in this work, we investigate an SIM-assisted secure communication system for MUs under the threat of an eavesdropper, addressing practical challenges such as channel uncertainty in mobile environments, multiple MU interference, and residual hardware impairments. Consequently, we formulate a joint power and phase shift optimization problem (JPPSOP), aiming at maximizing the achievable secrecy rate (ASR) of all MUs. Given the non-convexity and dynamic nature of this optimization problem, we propose an enhanced proximal policy optimization algorithm with a bidirectional long short-term memory mechanism, an offpolicy data utilization mechanism, and a policy feedback mechanism (PPO-BOP). Through these mechanisms, the proposed algorithm can effectively capture short-term channel fading and long-term MU mobility, improve sample utilization efficiency, and enhance exploration capabilities. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that PPO-BOP significantly outperforms benchmark strategies and other deep reinforcement learning algorithms in terms of ASR.

title: Unknown Input Observer design for Detecting Stator Inter-Turn Short-Circuit Faults in DFIG-Based Wind Turbines
authors: Ghada Amami, Moez Allouche, Mariem Ghamgui, Sandrine Moreau, Driss Mehdi, Mohamed Chaabane
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: The reliability of wind energy conversion systems is critically influenced by electrical faults in the generator, particularly Stator Inter-Turn Short-Circuits (ITSC). If undetected in their early stages, these faults can cause severe equipment damage and significant downtime. The aim of this paper is to use an Unknown Input Observer (UIO) to detect faults in a wind turbine system equipped with a Doubly-Fed Induction Generator. The system’s non-linear dynamics are accurately described under different operating conditions using a multi-model representation. The observer that is being suggested is assessed on its sensitivity to ITSC faults and its ability to handle external disturbances. Simulation results demonstrate that the UIO can efficiently detect and isolate stator ITSC faults while maintaining high robustness to wind speed variations. Based to the findings, confirm that the suggested UIO based fault recognition design is effective and reliable to improve the dependability of wind turbine systems.

title: Lightweight Statistical Model for Bash Command Recommendation
authors: Cuong Tran Manh, Duy Ngo Hoang, Hieu Dinh Vo
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Command-line interfaces like Bash are essential tools for developers and system administrators, enabling efficient interaction with operating systems. However, existing support tools, such as auto-completion, still rely on simple solutions based on history lookups or pre-defined, static rules, failing to learn from individual user workflows and adapt to personalized patterns. This paper presents a lightweight, data-driven approach for Bash command recommendation using a statistical n-gram model designed to run efficiently on typical hardware without NPUs/GPUs or cloud-based services, thereby ensuring data privacy and low latency. This paper also introduces a novel sessionized dataset constructed from GitHub user histories and Q&A forums. Our model handles two key tasks, which are are intra-command completion and inter-command prediction. Experiments show high effectiveness and efficiency: key results include <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 0 \%}$</tex> Top-1 accuracy for intra-command completion, over <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7 1 \%}$</tex> Top-3 accuracy for inter-command, and latencies under 50 ms on a mid-range CPU. This work confirms that a lightweight approach can provide a more personalized and practical command line experience, outperforming rule-based tools like bash-completion in adaptability while avoiding the computational overhead and data privacy risks of cloud-based LLMs.

title: Comparative Study of Clustering Algorithms for Geospatial Legal Data Analysis
authors: Chaitanya P. Desai, Navya Raj, Asher Mustafa, Gouthaman P, Preethiya T
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The digitization of India’s judicial system has produced a substantially large unstructured, repository of legal data and documents. It becomes difficult to analyze the data and the documents holding information systematically, which leads to a Big Data challenge. A successful methodology to unfold this complex digital data holds considerable potential for aiding legal scholars and providing a foundation for data-driven policies. This work introduces and evaluates a computational framework which is specifically designed to identify both thematic and geospatial patterns within this legal data. Utilizing a pipeline constructed on Apache Spark, the framework comparatively analyzes four distinct clustering algorithms: K-Means, Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM), Density - Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN), and Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA). The main objective is to determine which of these unsupervised machine learning methods is most effective for the complex domain of processing and clustering based on the legal text. The later findings reveal a dilemma between the statistical cluster quality and practical, thematic interpretability. GMM produced the most mathematically cohesive partitions, while LDA proved substantially more effective at generating clusters that aligns more with the human understandable legal concepts.

title: RCTNet: A Wavelet-Enhanced CNN-Transformer for sEMG Gesture Recognition
authors: Ye Sun, Ke-xiang Li, Chuang Li, Jian-Hua Zhang, Li Wang, Yong-bin Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: Surface electromyography (sEMG) signals impede gesture recognition for non-stationarity and inter-subject variability. This paper proposes RCTNet, a hybrid framework with discrete wavelet transform db4 3-level for multi-scale features, enhanced occlusion-based channel selection reducing 50% channels, and residual CNN-Transformer. The model captures local temporal patterns via CNNs and global dependencies via self-attention, with attention visualization for interpretability. Using 5-fold stratified cross-validation on Ninapro DB2 with 7 able-bodied and DB3 with 3 amputees, RCTNet achieves 96.11% and 98.34% accuracy, showing strong generalization. It balances accuracy, efficiency and interpretability, offering a practical solution for sEMG-based gesture recognition in prosthetic control and rehabilitation.

title: The New AI Asymmetry: How the Global South Is Rewriting the Rules of Technological Power
authors: Nir Kshetri
abstract: This article examines how strategic asymmetries enable emerging economies to challenge established artificial intelligence hierarchies. It analyzes how cost innovation, open source models, and culturally grounded development in the Global South are reshaping competition and asserting technological sovereignty.

title: Power Control of a Capacitively-isolated Bidirectional DC-DC Converter with Auxiliary Converters
authors: Trong Nhan Ngo, Makoto Hagiwara
abstract: This paper verifies an improved control method of a capacitively isolated bidirectional DC-DC converter with auxiliary converters, designed for electric railway systems. The converter consists of four unidirectional power devices, two capacitors for galvanic isolation, two inductors, and two auxiliary converters. Each auxiliary converter comprises three full-bridge cells connected in cascade. To downsize the isolated capacitors, as well as the filter capacitors and inductors on the primary and secondary sides, the switching frequency of the main converter should be set higher than 500 Hz, as used in [1]. However, it leads increased losses in the auxiliary converters because the sinusoidal inductor currents used for archiving power balance between the auxiliary converters. To address the above issue, this paper proposes an inner power control method based on triangular inductor currents, allowing the switching frequency of the main converter to be set higher. The operating principles of this inner power control method are validated experimentally using a 1.2-kW, 120-V down-scaled model, in which the switching frequency of the main converter can be set at 4 kHz.

title: Feasibility of a Hybrid FMG-sEMG Sensor for Prosthetic Training in a Serious Game Environment
authors: Felipe Ramirez Cortes, Laura V. De Arco Barraza, Gustavo Nunes Lopes, Carlos A. Cifuentes, Marcelo E. V. Segatto, Camilo A. R. Díaz
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: The control of active prostheses presents challenges for upper-limb amputees, impacting their rehabilitation and the performance of activities of daily living (ADLs). To handle this, current research explores more intuitive and engaging training methods to improve user performance and acceptance. This paper presents a proof-of-concept for a rehabilitation system that integrates a hybrid force myography (FMG) and surface electromyography (sEMG) interface with a prosthetic digital twin in a virtual reality (VR) serious game. The system architecture incorporates an FMG sensor based on fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors, a commercial sEMG device, and Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs) to capture muscle activity and arm motion. Participants interacted with a modified Virtual Reality Southampton Hand Assessment Procedure (VR-SHAP) to evaluate the system's performance. A comparative analysis of six machine learning algorithms was conducted in order to classify user gesture intentions from sensor data. The results from the machine learning evaluation identified the K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) classifier as an optimal model, achieving a mean accuracy of 99.63% across all subjects. The experimental protocol confirmed that all users could successfully operate the system to complete a series of complex virtual tasks. This study demonstrates the feasibility of the proposed hybrid FMG-sEMG system as an accurate, engaging, and promising platform for the rehabilitation and training of prosthesis users.

title: Radiation Performance of Circular Patch Antenna Modified by Double-Layered Firat Fractal
authors: Mirelli S. da Silva, Alyson Leite M. de Araújo, Leonardo O. de Sousa, Samanta M. de Holanda, Lucas A. Sarmento, Jorge A. I. de Araujo, Ignácio Llamas-Garro, Isaac B. T. da Silva
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This article investigates the radiation performance of a circular patch antenna modified by Firat-based fractal modeling. The pattern modeling was modified from two to four quadrants, where two frequencies were chosen for analysis, 2 GHz and 4 GHz, with four iterations applied to both antennas. Next, an appropriate mathematical description for the model is presented, based on previous studies and adding the necessary updates for the new application. The simulated performance of each antenna was verified by the axial ratio, radiation pattern, and efficiency. The best results were observed in the 4 GHz antenna, with a maximum efficiency of 65.21% (k=2) and a gain difference of only 1.45 dB between the reference and the first iteration, maintaining the broadside pattern.

title: Analytical Determination of Phase Weights in a Time-Delayed Photonic Neural Network for Dispersion Compensation
authors: Arnaldo Paterline Togneri, Marcelo E. Vieira Segatto, Reginaldo Barbosa Nunes
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: An analytical methodology is proposed for determining the phase weights of a time-delayed PNN configured to operate as a chromatic dispersion compensator in optical communication systems. Unlike traditional approaches that rely on iterative optimization algorithms, the proposed method establishes a direct correspondence between the PNN structure and an FIR filter model, allowing the weight calculation through a closed-form expression. Simulations were performed using Ansys Lumerical INTERCONNECT to evaluate the system's performance over 100 km of standard single-mode fiber, with data rates ranging from 6.25 Gbps to 12.5 Gbps. The analytically derived weights enable effective CDC at higher rates, with BER remaining below 0.001 in relevant scenarios. The proposed technique eliminates training or reconfiguration, offering a lowcomplexity and scalable solution compatible with integrated photonics platforms.

title: Computationally Efficient Optimal Millimeter Wave Base Station Deployment
authors: Hang Qi, Lefu Xiao, Qiyue Li, Jingjin Wu, Eric W. M. Wong
abstract: Millimeter wave (mmWave) communication is a key technology to provide ultra-fast data rates and massive connectivity in wireless networks. This paper introduces a computationaland cost-efficient approach for deploying mmWave base stations (BSs) in urban environments. In addition to the physical blockage constraints that have been considered in various existing studies, we also account for the capacity constraints of mmWave BSs, which limit the maximum number of concurrent user requests. To address the inherently stochastic nature of mobile user traffic, we utilize teletraffic theory and specifically apply the Erlang Fixed-Point Approximation to accurately and efficiently estimate blocking probabilities. Then, we propose a low-complexity algorithm by identifying the submodularity structure of the deployment problem to determine the optimal deployment strategy that minimizes the number of BSs. Extensive numerical results demonstrate that our method outperforms existing approaches in both solution accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: HIPCAM: Data Stream-Driven Group Key Management for In-Vehicle Network with Seamless Key Updates
authors: Yufeng Li, Yingjie Xu, Guiqi Zhang, Jiangtao Li, Ke Sun, Qi Liu
abstract: The vehicular network primarily relies on the Controller Area Network (CAN) because it meets the requirements of vehicular networks in terms of high reliability and real-time performance. However, the absence of robust security measures on the CAN bus exposes vulnerabilities, enabling attackers to potentially compromise vehicles remotely. Many cryptography based methods are proposed to enhance the security of CAN bus, but they rarely involve key management issues. In this paper, we propose a lightweight group key management scheme that innovatively utilizes the residual part of the Message Authentication Code (MAC) of data stream to maintain a synchronized fields between Electronic Control Units (ECUs), which is called hippocampus. Each ECU executes the refresh process by applying the XOR operation between hippocampus and old key. Moreover, we provide formal security proofs and informal analyses for the robustness of the proposed scheme. Afterwards, a series of evaluations on three typical hardware platforms are detailed. The results demonstrate that the additional time overhead introduced by our scheme remains within acceptable limits and validate its advantage, efficiency, and flexibility by comparing it with other methods.

title: Alerting Tsunamis: A Fuzzy Logic Model
authors: Eduard Fabian Cañón, Julián Andrés León, John Velandia Vega, Holman Diego Bolivar
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This research aims to strengthen the tsunami model of the Navega Seguro application, which, with the integration of the wind speed variable, reached a maturity level of 6.75 out of 10 according to the AIMM evaluation, demonstrating a significant improvement in its accuracy. This application alerts its users about meteorological and oceanographic conditions that could be dangerous for navigation in the coastal areas of Colombia. The research focused on integrating a new variable, wind speed, which, along with the already existing variables within the application, such as the magnitude and depth of earthquakes, allows for the analysis of maritime phenomena. To achieve these objectives, both generative and traditional artificial intelligence were incorporated into the project. Taking advantage of the fact that the application already had fuzzy logic integrated into its prediction model, it was possible to interpret data from multiple meteorological sources, such as the OpenWeatherMap API and DIMAR, improving the application's ability to generate early and accurate alerts. The project followed the SCRUM and Participatory Action Research (PAR) methodologies. The SCRUM methodology helped organize the work into short sprints, allowing for continuous corrections and prioritizing feedback among developers, while the PAR methodology engaged coastal communities and local experts in the process, ensuring that the improvements reflected their specific needs, which are now incorporated into the application. Functional, unit, and automated tests demonstrated the correct operation of the adjusted model, validating the incorporation of the new variable in different scenarios. With this improvement, the application is useful for commercial, tourism, and fishing activities by providing a reliable, real-time tool that aids in decision-making and, at the same time, protects users' safety at sea.

title: Information Disclosure Risk of Thumbnail-Preserving Encryption
authors: Xin Li, Guopu Zhu, Hongli Zhang, Tao Xiang, Xiangyang Luo, Sam Kwong
abstract: With the rapid growth of cloud services, the storage of images in cloud environments requires secure and effective data encryption methods. Many thumbnail-preserving encryption (TPE) methods have thus been proposed to balance privacy and usability of image data. However, the exposure of thumbnail information in TPE methods may introduce privacy leakage risk, and a systematic evaluation of their security has not yet been conducted. In this paper, we propose a new Mamba-Transformer cooperation Network (MTNet) to recover the original images from the limited exposed thumbnail information, highlighting the information disclosure problem in TPE. Specifically, the core model component integrates a Mamba block and a Transformer block, which employ the powerful capabilities of the Mamba for wide field dependency modeling and the Transformer for effective channel interaction. Besides, the cascade architecture incorporates an intermediate output that provides supplementary information and achieves multilevel supervision, thereby improving the quality of the final output. Finally, to better utilize the subtle details in different levels, we propose a multi-scale fusion module that adaptively integrates features from various stages of the encoding process. The experimental results achieved by our proposed MTNet reveal that the privacy risk associated with TPE is significantly underestimated and more robust defense mechanisms are required. Source code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/HITLiXincodes/MTNet</uri>.

title: Task-Generalized Adaptive Cross-Domain Learning for Multimodal Image Fusion
authors: Mengyu Wang, Zhenyu Liu, Kun Li, Yu Wang, Yuwei Wang, Yanyan Wei, Fei Wang
abstract: Multimodal Image Fusion (MMIF) aims to integrate complementary information from different imaging modalities to overcome the limitations of individual sensors. It enhances image quality and facilitates downstream applications such as remote sensing, medical diagnostics, and robotics. Despite significant advancements, current MMIF methods still face challenges such as modality misalignment, high-frequency detail destruction, and task-specific limitations. To address these challenges, we propose AdaSFFuse, a novel framework for task-generalized MMIF through adaptive cross-domain co-fusion learning. AdaSFFuse introduces two key innovations: the Adaptive Approximate Wavelet Transform (AdaWAT) for frequency decoupling, and the Spatial-Frequency Mamba Blocks for efficient multimodal fusion. AdaWAT adaptively separates the high- and low-frequency components of multimodal images from different scenes, enabling fine-grained extraction and alignment of distinct frequency characteristics for each modality. The Spatial-Frequency Mamba Blocks facilitate cross-domain fusion in both spatial and frequency domains, enhancing this process. These blocks dynamically adjust through learnable mappings to ensure robust fusion across diverse modalities. By combining these components, AdaSFFuse improves the alignment and integration of multimodal features, reduces frequency loss, and preserves critical details. Extensive experiments on four MMIF tasks-Infrared-Visible Image Fusion (IVF), Multi-Focus Image Fusion (MFF), Multi-Exposure Image Fusion (MEF), and Medical Image Fusion (MIF)-demonstrate AdaSFFuse's superior fusion performance, ensuring both low computational cost and a compact network, offering a strong balance between performance and efficiency. The code will be publicly available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Zhen-yu-Liu/AdaSFFuse</uri>.

title: Smart Irrigation System for Roses: Enhancing Sustainable Production in Greenhouses Through Industry 4.0 and Digital Technologies
authors: Luz Calle-Quispe, Andrea Mori-Novoa, José Velásquez-Costa, Javier Torres-Zavala, Cristina Losada-Gutiérrez
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: Greenhouse rose production is often affected by inefficient manual irrigation systems, resulting in excessive water consumption and inconsistent flower quality. This research presents the design and validation of a smart irrigation system that integrates Industry 4.0 digital technologies such as IoT sensors, cloud computing, and adaptive control algorithms. The system monitors soil moisture and environmental variables in real time, enabling precise and efficient water application only when necessary. Implemented in a prototype greenhouse, the solution achieved a 32% reduction in water use while maintaining optimal plant growth. The study highlights the potential of data-driven rule-based control (with AI planned), data driven irrigation automation to improve sustainability, reduce human error, and increase productivity in ornamental horticulture, especially for rose growers in developing countries. This approach can be replicated for other ornamental crops and greenhouse settings in water scarce environments.

title: Comparison of Mechanical Properties of a Cold Dense Mix with Recycled Asphalt Pavement (RAP) with Additions of Hydrated Lime and Portland Cement
authors: Diana Carolina Fuquene Santana, Cristian Leonardo Rojas Villamil, Jefferson Arles Ayala Bohorquez
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: The recycled asphalt pavement RAP involves incorporating recycled asphalt materials into new pavement structures, which not only reduces costs but also contributes to the conservation of natural resources. In Colombia, its use has been implemented at the departmental level by INVIAS in various projects, demonstrating its viability on tertiary roads. Furthermore, in the city of Bogotá, its use and study have been adopted by entities such as the IDU and the UAERMV. Various research projects have been conducted analyzing the physical characteristics of the material, with the aim of promoting the reuse of discarded material. To improve the properties of recycled pavement, tests have been conducted with additions of materials such as rubber, lime, cement, and fibers. This project aims to evaluate how the addition of lime and cement influences the physical and mechanical properties of asphalt mixtures containing 100% recycled asphalt. Through laboratory tests, the strength characteristics of different mixtures will be compared, seeking to identify the combination that optimizes pavement durability and reduces maintenance costs, while meeting the technical requirements established for roads in Colombia.

title: Influence of Seismic Source Azimuth on the Dispersion Curve Using Optical Distributed Acoustic Sensing
authors: Beatriz Brusamarello, João P. Bazzo, Guilherme H. Weber, Gustavo Macioski, Larissa W. Kulik, Daniel R. Pipa, Gilson A. Brunetto, Luis F. P. Melegari, Jean Carlos Cardozo da Silva, Cicero Martelli, Uilian J. Dreyer
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper analyzes data acquired using Distributed Acoustic Sensing (DAS) to investigate directivity effects and their influence on dispersion curves that relate frequency and shear wave velocities. Field tests were carried out by burying the optical cable and excitation of the soil at azimuthal angles ranging from 0° to 90° in 15° increments with a sledgehammer. The results indicate that the optical fiber detects a mixture of seismic wave types—specifically S-waves, P-waves, Rayleigh waves, and Love waves—based on comparisons between the measured directivity and simulations from the literature. Furthermore, DAS was found to exhibit sensitivity to apparent seismic velocities higher than the actual values, consistent with observations from conventional geophone-based methods. This study highlights the potential of DAS for seismic applications, showing that its response can be corrected with appropriate algorithms for accurate seismic analysis, despite the mixed nature of the detected waves.

title: A Mapping Study of Artificial Intelligence Application for Assisting Dyslexia Children in Education
authors: Siti Husna Mohd Zubair, Farhana Sukiman, Norsaremah Salleh, Siti NoorJannah Ibrahim, Samer Zein
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is becoming more and more a part of our everyday lives. It facilitates us in decision making, work planning, learning new skills and many other tasks. One of the applications of AI is to assist children with Dyslexia to learn better. Dyslexia is a learning disability that affects reading, writing, and speaking ability. This study aims to discover the learning tools that have utilized AI in helping Dyslexia children to learn. We used the systematic mapping study approach to provide evidence about the use of AI-based tools and characterize the studies based on the learning difficulties. Based on the 20 included studies, we found that most of the studies focused on implementing AI features but lack in addressing the limitations that Dyslexia children are facing. We discussed the findings on this topic and highlight the future direction of this work.

title: Stability Enhancement of Hybrid Fuel Cell-Battery-Supercapacitor Systems Using a Hamiltonian Control Approach
authors: Phatiphat Thounthong, Pongsiri Mungporn, Nicu Bizon, Gianpaolo Vitale, Serge Pierfederici, Babak Nahid-Mobarakeh, Burin Yodwong
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper presents a Hamiltonian control law to enhance the stability and performance of a hybrid energy storage system (HESS) composed of a proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell, lithium-ion battery, and supercapacitor. The control design is based on port-Hamiltonian system theory, enabling dynamic energy management among sources while maintaining global system stability. A nonlinear control law is developed using damping-injection techniques to regulate the DC bus voltage, ensure optimal power sharing, and respect power and energy constraints of each component. The strategy allocates fast dynamics to the supercapacitor, medium response to the battery, and slow dynamics to the fuel cell, achieving efficient energy coordination. Experimental validation is performed using a dSPACE controlled test bench with real-time monitoring. Results confirm that the proposed method ensures fast transient response, smooth voltage regulation, and robust operation under sudden load variations.

title: Energy-Efficient Wireless Systems for Biomedical Applications
authors: Minyoung Song
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: By virtue of the rapid evolution of integrated circuit technologies in recent decades, the quality of services and equipment for biomedicine and healthcare has been dramatically improved. As a clear example, wireless medical implants are transforming conventional medical treatment and diagnosis by enhancing patient comfort, safety, and flexibility. In this context, energy-efficient wireless systems play a pivotal role in reducing device volume while ensuring sufficient implant lifetime. Moreover, they enable the maximization of data transmission rates, which are essential for supporting advanced medical sensing, such as high-resolution neural sensing. This paper explores key technical challenges in achieving high energy efficiency and introduces state-of-the-art wireless systems for biomedical applications.

title: Digital Biomarkers for Depression Monitoring Using Multi-Sensing Wearable Wristband
authors: Daili Yang, Yunge Li, Yi Lei, Bin Gao, Lizhu Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Depression has become one of the most prevalent mental disorders among adolescents. However, its clinical etiology remains unclear, and unlike many other diseases, it lacks objective biochemical or medical imaging indicators for assessment and severity evaluation. To address this gap, this study presents a multi-sensing wearable wristband that integrates audio, activity, and heart rate sensors. Furthermore, this system is used to capture physiological and behavioral data for investigating how these parameters evolve in depressed adolescents during hospitalization. To identify meaningful digital biomarkers from the collected data, a multi-step analytical method has been constructed. Firstly, statistical methods such as correlation analysis, variance analysis, and non-parametric tests are employed to eliminate redundant, unrelated, and non-differential features, thereby narrowing the feature space. Moreover, a variational autoencoder is applied to address class imbalance, and focal loss is incorporated to enhance model sensitivity to difficult samples. Secondly, an XGBoost-based framework is developed to classify depression improvement levels and the model achieve a validation accuracy of 0.8. Finally, feature contribution analysis based on the proposed model is conducted using Shapley values and linear model coefficients, providing both individualized and global interpretations of differential feature sets before and after treatment. By integrating insights from these analyses, a set of objective digital biomarkers has been identified that may aid in screening and diagnosing adolescent depression.

title: Equilibrium Optimizer for Multi-Objective Reconfiguration of Distribution Networks Considering Hourly Demand Variations
authors: Samir Bouslimani, Anes Bouhanik, Salhi Ahmed, Djemai Naimi, Said Drid, Younes Zahraoui
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This study proposes a multi-objective approach for the reconfiguration of radial electrical distribution networks. It considers the hourly demand fluctuations across several consumer groups according to the actual 24-hour load profiles. The methodology concurrently reduces daily technical energy losses $J_{1}$ and estimated risk-weighted interruption costs $J_{2}$. The latter assesses the economic effects of outages via line failure rates, repair durations, and the Value of Lost Load (VOLL). An aggregated satisfaction degree (DS), obtained by sigmoid-based fuzzy normalization with weights of 0.6 for ${J}_{1}$ and 0.4 for $J_{2}$, serves to equilibrate efficiency and reliability while guaranteeing consistent convergence. The methodology is validated on a modified IEEE 33-bus test system, employing three metaheuristic algorithms: Equilibrium Optimizer (EO), Gorilla Troops Optimizer (GTO), and Geometric Mean Optimizer (GMO). Results indicate that EO regularly attains the highest DS (0.3), diminishing daily energy losses by 17.79% and enhancing minimum bus voltage from 0.9045 pu to 0.9678 pu, surpassing the other methods for all evaluation criteria.

title: EVIU-link: Composite Collaborative Perception Framework for Enhanced Indoor Localization
authors: Yu-An Liu, Li Zhang, Yuqi Fan, Zheng Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Visual-inertial odometry (VIO) is widely used for mobile robot localization in indoor areas. Recent studies show that integrating global sensors such as ultra-wideband (UWB) into VIO can improve long-term robustness, but existing multi-sensor fusion schemes still face challenges. First, visual feature tracking, a core component of VIO, is easily degraded under low-texture, low-light, or fast-motion conditions, where current visual enhancement methods remain ineffective. Second, most fusion strategies are constrained to a single coupling paradigm (loose/tight) and a single estimation scheme (filter/optimization), which makes it difficult to jointly balance accuracy, efficiency, and robustness. To address these issues, we propose EVIU-link, an event-based VIO-UWB fusion framework. The key innovations are twofold: (1) an event-enhanced vision module, where feature-density monitoring dynamically triggers event-flow tracking to maintain robust feature matching under challenging visual conditions; and (2) a hierarchical fusion strategy that performs local pose estimation within a VIO-UWB constrained factor graph, while simultaneously applying UWB ranging constraints at the global level to correct accumulated drift. Experiments on public datasets and real-world indoor scenarios demonstrate that EVIU-link achieves superior performance in challenging environments, indicating its promising application potential.

title: BDSA: Remote Sensing Image Dehazing via Fusing Brightness Decomposition and Saturation Adjustment
authors: Weidong Zhang, Kaijie Jin, Ling Zhou, Kangjia Qiao, Qiang Zhang, Peixian Zhuang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing imagery is often degraded by atmospheric scattering and suspended particles, which suppress brightness, distort colors, and obscure fine details. To mitigate these degradations, we introduce a dehazing approach termed BDSA that integrates brightness decomposition with saturation adjustment to restore visual clarity and fidelity. Specifically, our first performs a nonlinear transformation on the luminance channel of the YCbCr color space, wherein a logarithmic modulation scheme is applied to strengthen the visibility of dark regions while an exponential modulation strategy is simultaneously adopted to retain the fidelity of bright structures, thereby ensuring balanced enhancement across the entire dynamic range of the image. Meanwhile, we employ a multi-scale gamma correction strategy in the RGB space to generate image sequences with varying exposure levels, and calculate a saturation adjustment factor combining luminance and color difference information to restore color. Finally, we employ a multi-scale feature fusion strategy to extract structural features and texture details at different resolution levels, progressively guiding the reconstruction of high-quality remote sensing images. Extensive experimental results clearly demonstrate that our BDSA method consistently achieves superior dehazing performance across a wide range of remote sensing scenarios, empirically validating its advantage over state-of-the-art approaches in terms of contrast enhancement, detail restoration, and color fidelity.

title: Development of a Novel 2-DoF Wearable Ankle Angle Sensor with an Adjustable Rotation Center
authors: Chaoyang Shi, Yupeng Hao, Aofei Tian, Yinan Zhao, Bo Zhang, Kaifeng Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper presents a novel fiber Bragg grating (FBG)-based sensor for precise 2-degree-of-freedom (DoF) ankle angle monitoring. The proposed sensor primarily comprises two symmetric torsion springs, a planar spring, and three FBG-embedded optical fibers. Symmetric torsion springs are employed to measure plantarflexion/dorsiflexion (PF/DF) rotation, while a planar spring targets inversion/eversion (INV/EVE) motion, effectively minimizing cross-axis interference due to their distinct stiffness characteristics. Crucially, the sensor's high in-plane compliance accommodates the physiological shift of the ankle’s rotation center, enabling enhanced wearing comfort. Moreover, a symmetric differential fiber configuration compensates for rotation-axis variations and ensures high measurement accuracy. Structural optimization was conducted to maximize sensitivity and minimize crosstalk. Experimental results demonstrate high sensitivities of 37.09 pm/° (PF/DF) and 224.70 pm/° (INV/EVE) over ±55° and ±23°, respectively. The structural decoupling is validated by a low maximum crosstalk of 3.56%. Furthermore, the sensor maintains accuracy against rotation center offsets, with sensitivity deviations kept below 2.8% under a 2-mm misalignment. Dynamic tests at 50°/s and 300°/s yielded maximum root-mean-square errors (RMSEs) of 2.47° and 1.27° for PF/DF and INV/EVE, respectively. Finally, on-body validation, including seated range-of-motion tests, squat-to-stand exercises, and level walking, confirmed the sensor's ability to capture high-fidelity kinematic profiles for rehabilitation applications.

title: FRoCL: Robust Continual Defense against Deepfakes in Facial Identification Systems
authors: Fatima Khalid, Usman Haider, Muhammad Hanif, Saeed Mian Qaisar, Ahmar Rashid, Yasser D. Al-Otaibi
abstract: Facial identification in consumer electronics is increasingly threatened by deepfakes, requiring robust and adaptive defenses. Modern generative adversarial networks (GANs) and diffusion models generate highly realistic forgeries that bypass conventional verification, particularly in resource-constrained and compressed-input settings. Current deepfake detectors face two critical challenges: i) they suffer from catastrophic forgetting when learning sequential forgery types, and ii) they remain vulnerable to adversarial perturbations. These issues are addressed in isolation with continual learning that reduces forgetting but neglects robustness. Conversely, adversarial defenses improve resilience but fail to retain prior knowledge. This paper proposes a novel framework, Forgery-Robust Continual Learning (FRoCL), a unified approach that balances plasticity, stability, and robustness. FRoCL integrates supervised learning with knowledge distillation, feature alignment, contrastive objectives, and adversarial consistency, supported by an uncertainty-driven replay buffer under strict memory constraints. Extensive experiments on FaceForensics++, Celeb-DF, and DFDC under sequential clean and adversarial task protocols show that FRoCL consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving less than or equal to 5% forgetting and up to 40% improvements in adversarial robustness, while preserving efficiency at inference. These findings confirm the potential of FRoCL as a practical and future-proof solution for integrating forgery detection into consumer electronics.

title: AQUA-SENSE: Integrated Environmental and Acoustic Sensing for Underwater Vehicle Surveillance
authors: Rajat Amat, Anurag Sahoo, Mourina Ghosh, Amitava Nag, Robin Pathak
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This paper presents AQUA-SENSE, an integrated framework for underwater vehicle surveillance using combined environmental and acoustic sensing. The system incorporates ultrasonic range finders, LiDAR modules, pH, and dissolved oxygen sensors along with acoustic detection to track underwater vehicles while monitoring water quality. Data acquisition and visualization are implemented in LabVIEW, ensuring real-time processing and reliable monitoring. Experimental results show accurate range estimation, robust target tracking, and stable environmental measurements, making AQUA-SENSE a scalable and cost-effective solution for maritime security and ecological monitoring.

title: GaN Power Devices for Electrified Transportation: Status, Challenges, and Perspectives
authors: Hengbo Zhang, Yifei Huang, Hongchang Cui, Xin Yang, Zineng Yang, Jian Guo, Haozhe Jin, Daohui Li, Yu Zhang, Quanliang Yang, Xuyang Liu, Taozhe Liu, Florin Udrea, Han Wang, Yuhao Zhang
abstract: Gallium nitride (GaN) power devices are gaining traction in electrified transportation due to their low switching losses, high-frequency capability, and compact footprint, enabling higher efficiency and power density than conventional silicon (Si) and silicon carbide (SiC) technologies. However, their large-scale adoption, especially in main powertrains, remains limited by insufficient voltage and current ratings as well as an incomplete understanding of device reliability under stressful operating conditions. Here, we review recent advances in GaN devices for transportation electrification. We first examine the industrial multilevel framework of device reliability qualification for automotive applications, aiming to better inform device researchers of application requirements. We then survey recent GaN device innovations targeting higher voltages and improved robustness. We also discuss monolithic bidirectional switches (MBDSs) and their enabling advantages in ac power conversion. The review outlines key technological pathways toward broader deployment of GaN devices in electrified transportation.

title: Effective Deterministic WiFi Handover Mechanism with Fuzzy-Inspired Stability Checks
authors: Phan Binh Nguyen Lam, Nguyen Thai Anh, Ngo Hoang Tu
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Seamless WiFi connectivity in mobile environments is essential for latency-sensitive applications such as video streaming and voice-over-internet-protocol. However, conventional received signal strength indicator (RSSI)-based handover mechanisms often lead to high latency, frequent handover, and ping-pong effects in dynamic settings. This paper proposes a novel two-stage handover strategy to optimize WiFi transitions in mobile environments. In the first stage, a deterministic access-point nomination is performed based on instantaneous throughput. The second stage integrates fuzzy-inspired stability checks to mitigate frequent handover and ping-pong affects. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed framework addresses a trade-off between responsiveness and stability. In terms of throughput and latency, the proposed scheme outperforms traditional fuzzy-based policies under competitive handover and ping-pong conditions, while maintaining performance comparable to the deterministic RSSI-based approach, with significantly reduced handovers and ping-pong events.

title: Design and FPGA Implementation of an Optimized 4×4 Reversible Multiplier with Balanced Design Parameters
authors: Mihir Lal Saha, Anamitra Roy, Anushmita Das, Ahana Talukder, Agnik Maity, Antarik Sinha
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Reversible logic plays a crucial role in advancing future VLSI and quantum computing, where the optimization of design parameters like quantum cost, garbage outputs, and circuit complexity is essential. This paper introduces the design and implementation of an efficient 4×4 reversible multiplier on FPGA using Peres and TSG gates. The proposed architecture results in a 31.7 % reduction in quantum cost and enhances TRLIC by up to 30.6% compared to previous designs, while also decreasing garbage outputs and constant inputs. The design has been modeled, simulated, and validated on FPGA to verify its practical viability. Findings indicate that the proposed multiplier strikes a good balance among important parameters, surpassing traditional reversible multipliers in terms of efficiency and scalability. This positions it as a promising option for incorporation into low-power VLSI circuits and quantum arithmetic systems.

title: Robust High-Gain Control for Maximum Power Point Tracking of Variable-Speed Wind Turbines
authors: Naveed Mazhar, Abdullah Abushokor, Syed Muhammad Amrr, Mohamed Zaery, S. M. Suhail Hussain, Mohammad Ali, Mohammad A. Abido
abstract: Wind turbines are a key technology in sustainable energy generation, but their performance is often challenged by strong aerodynamic disturbances, parameter uncertainties, and rapidly varying operating conditions. Achieving reliable maximum power point tracking (MPPT) under such conditions requires control strategies with fast dynamic response and strong robustness. This paper proposes a robust high-gain control scheme for MPPT of variable-speed wind turbines. The method uses high-gain feedback to enforce accurate rotor speed tracking while attenuating the effects of unmodeled dynamics and external disturbances. By appropriately tuning the gain parameters, the controller achieves rapid error convergence without sacrificing robustness or stability. A rigorous Lyapunov-based analysis establishes closed-loop stability under model uncertainties. Simulation studies, conducted under both smooth and highly turbulent wind profiles, demonstrate that the proposed high-gain control achieves faster tracking, improved disturbance rejection, and higher energy capture efficiency, while maintaining smooth control actions suitable for practical implementation.

title: A Taxonomy of CPU Scheduling Problems
authors: Binh T. Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: The scheduling problem in service systems has been widely classified and studied. However, the CPU scheduling problem—the fundamental issue that an operating system's scheduler must address—has not been systematically classified or clearly defined. This lack of clarity has led to difficulties and misunderstandings in studying the problem and its related algorithms. In this study, we propose a classification for CPU scheduling problems and clarify their relationships with the associated algorithms.

title: A Quantum-inspired Hybrid Swarm Intelligence and Decision-Making for Multi-Criteria ADAS Calibration
authors: Sanjai Pathak, Ashish Mani, Amlan Chatterjee
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The tuning of Advanced Driver Assistance Systems (ADAS) involves resolving trade-offs among several competing objectives, including operational safety, system responsiveness, energy usage, and passenger comfort. This work introduces a novel optimization framework based on Quantum-Inspired Hybrid Swarm Intelligence (QiHSI), in which quantum-inspired mechanisms are embedded within a multi-objective salp swarm optimization process to strengthen global search capability and preserve population diversity in complex, high-dimensional decision spaces. In addition, a decision-maker-in-the-loop strategy is incorporated to incorporate adaptive expert guidance, enabling the optimization process to respond dynamically to changing design priorities and system constraints. The effectiveness of QiHSI is assessed using established multi-objective benchmark problems as well as a practical ADAS calibration scenario. Experimental comparisons with several state-of-the-art evolutionary and swarm-based algorithms, including MSSA, MOPSO, MOEA/D, SPEA2, NSGA-III, and RVEA, show that the proposed method consistently produces well-distributed Pareto-optimal solutions with faster convergence and improved adaptability. These findings demonstrate that QiHSI offers a reliable and scalable approach for intelligent ADAS calibration, supporting the development of more responsive, efficient, and safety-oriented autonomous driving technologies.

title: Characterization of Power-Domain NOMA Versus MIMO in 6G OFDM Networks
authors: Fabbryccio Akkazzha Chaves Machado Cardoso, Francisco Raimundo Albuquerque Parente, Maykon Renan Pereira da Silva
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: The evolution towards Sixth-Generation (6G) systems requires strategies to increase spatial capacity beyond conventional methods. This paper analyzes the feasibility of Power-Domain Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access (PD-NOMA) as a complement to Multiple-Input Multiple-Output Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiplexing (MIMO-OFDM) in dense 6G cellular networks. Using an open-source simulation framework developed on Sionna 0.16, we model MIMO systems with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1\times 2,\ 2 \times 2$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> antenna configurations. We incorporate PD-NOMA by superimposing two non-orthogonal streams per MIMO layer under clustered delay line channel models from 3GPP Technical Report 38.901, while preserving the same spectral efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that PD-NOMA can double the number of streams (or users) with minimal Eb/N0 overhead. In non-line-of-sight environments, reception diversity helps mitigate the resulting interference, whereas line-of-sight scenarios benefit from stronger channel eigenvalues, which reduce error propagation. We further quantify the influence of power allocation ratios and MIMO order on the block error rate, providing practical guidelines for system parameter tuning under diverse channel conditions. Finally, we analyze limitations due to interstream interference remaining after minimum mean square error detection and propose residual leakage metrics, highlighting open research challenges in advanced interference cancellation. Overall, the results support PD-NOMA as a low-complexity and costeffective strategy for enhancing spatial capacity in 6 G networks, assuming sufficiently accurate channel state information and feasible iterative decoding at the receiver.

title: Numerical Simulation of the Inverse Photoemission Based on Three-Step Model
authors: Ao Tan, Yu Chen, Sichao Zhang, Tiansong Zhang, Zhenxuan Li, Siyu Tian, Shuang Wang, Xin Liu, Hisao Ishii
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: As the inverse process of the photoelectric effect, inverse Photoemission is a crucial physical process for analyzing the unoccupied electronic structure of materials. Based on the reverse deduction of the three-step theory of photoemission, this paper systematically elaborates on the basic principles of Inverse Photoemission, constructs a three-step physical model that includes photon generation by electron incidence, photon transport, and photon escape at the interface, and employs the Monte Carlo numerical simulation method to conduct quantitative analysis of each stage. The probability of photon excitation by electrons is calculated using the bremsstrahlung differential cross-section. Combined with random sampling, the photon transport trajectory and energy loss are simulated. The Fresnel equations and critical angle criterion are applied to analyze the laws of interface reflection and refraction. Simulation results of 100,000 electrons show that the probability of emitted photons is stable and consistent with the data reported in existing literature, which verifies the reliability of the proposed model. This study provides a theoretical and simulation framework for the research on the unoccupied electronic structure of materials.

title: LTQU-Net: Learnable TQWT-Enhanced Unrolling Net for Interpretable Cross-Domain Fault Diagnosis
authors: Yiyue Zhang, Gang Chen, Zhenpeng Lao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Trustworthiness is paramount for fault diagnosis in safety-critical industrial applications, particularly when dealing with domain shifts. However, standard deep learning models often struggle with opacity, failing to explicitly learn interpretable and invariant features across different domains. To overcome this limitation, we present a novel framework: the Learnable TQWTEnhanced Unrolling Net (LTQU-Net). This method synergizes signal processing with deep learning through two key mechanisms. First, we introduce a differentiable TQWT Subband Alignment and Fusion module, which allows for the end-to-end extraction of physically interpretable time-frequency signatures. Second, by leveraging the deep unfolding paradigm, we map the iterative sparse coding optimization into a fixed-depth neural network, thereby inheriting the theoretical transparency of dictionary learning. Coupled with tailored objective functions, LTQU-Net is optimized for robust cross-domain performance. Experiments on public benchmark confirm that our approach not only outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in accuracy but also offers a transparent solution suitable for intelligent industrial monitoring.

title: A Smart Approach For Implementing Load Based Traffic Control System
authors: Mahua Raha Patra, Poulomi Ghosh, Sudip Ghosh
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Nowadays, traffic congestion is a serious problem that people face every day in their daily life. Normally, at every junction, traffic is controlled by either traffic police or an automatic traffic light. An automatic traffic light is a timer- based device that operates on a fixed time, and it is a static system. The traffic congestion problem can be solved to some extent if it is possible to design a dynamic traffic controller system. In this paper, a traffic controller system is designed which work on the basis of traffic density of the lane. Nowadays due to advancement of technology Internet of Things (IoT), Cloud Technology, Artificial Intelligence and Information Technology are used to tackle our daily life problems. In this paper, a system is proposed that uses an ATMEGA 328 microcontroller (Arduino) and an IR sensor, which detects the density of traffic in the lane and sends a corresponding signal to the microcontroller, which controls the traffic light based on the sensor output.

title: Deep Learning For Dark Web Text Analysis: A Convolutional Approach To Content Categorization
authors: Sasidhar Reddy Gaddam, Pathan HussainBasha, Mohana Prasad Mendu, Purimitla Ramalingamma, Buddaraju Revathi, V T Ram Pavan Kumar M
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The rapid expansion of dark web platforms has intensified the need for efficient and automated text analysis systems capable of identifying illicit and high-risk activities. Traditional deep learning models for dark web content classification often suffer from high computational complexity, limited robustness to adversarial manipulation, and reduced effectiveness in multilingual environments. This paper proposes an Enhanced Text Convolutional Neural Network (ET-CNN) framework designed to address these challenges. The proposed model integrates adaptive word embeddings, adversarial training based on gradient perturbation, and cross-lingual embedding alignment to improve classification reliability and generalization. Experiments conducted on a large-scale dataset consisting of 100,000 labeled dark web forum posts demonstrate that the ETCNN achieves an accuracy of 94.2% and an F1-score of 92.5%, while maintaining significantly lower computational overhead compared to transformer-based architectures. The results indicate that the proposed approach provides an effective balance between performance, robustness, and efficiency, making it suitable for real-time dark web monitoring and analysis.
