title: Real-Time Identification of Jerk Peaks from Triaxial Acceleration Data in a Cartesian Robot
authors: Edgar Eliseo Franco-Ortiz, Carlos Rodriguez-Donate, Jacob Gonzalez-Villagomez, Ruth Ivonne Mata-Chávez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Vibration regulation is essential to improve the accuracy and prolong the lifetime of mechanical components. In this sense, jerk plays a key role due to its direct association with the system’s residual vibrations. This work presents an efficient methodology for the real-time detection of jerk peaks from the analysis of vibration signals obtained from a triaxial accelerometer. Unlike previous approaches that require complex dynamic models, this study introduces a scheme based on the numerical derivative of acceleration and an adaptive threshold computed using moving statistics. This accurate approach enables precise identification of relevant events, even in noisy conditions. The proposed methodology was experimentally validated using trapezoidal profiles in velocity designed to present jerk pulses at known time instants. The results of these experiments demonstrate a high temporal correspondence between the theoretical pulses and the detected peaks, thereby validating the approach as a valuable tool for experimental analysis of motion profiles.

title: An Efficient FPGA Accelerator for Learning Image Compression
authors: Shengtao Zhao, Yingchang Mao, Zhaohui Guo, Zhaoqing Pan, Qiang Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Image compression methods based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have been extensively investigated. A just noticeable difference (JND)-based learned image compression (JND- LI C) method demonstrates competitive performance among learning-based image compression methods. However, the CNN model of this method involves different types of convolutional and residual blocks and is computationally in-tensive, restricting its deployment in environments constrained by power consumption. This paper proposes a high-efficiency FPGA accelerator designed for the JND-LIC method. To improve throughput, multiple parallel strategies are adopted for different types of convolution operations. With respect to residual block structures, the accelerator is optimized to enhance data transfer efficiency. In addition, uniform quantization is applied to further improve efficiency. The proposed accelerator, implemented on the Xilinx Virtex-7 FPGA, achieves a measured performance of 346.65 GOPS and an energy efficiency of 30.68 GOPSIW. It delivers a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.55\times$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.422\times$</tex> energy efficiency improvement over implementations on the Intel i7-10875H CPU and the NVIDIA RTX 2060 GPU, respectively.

title: A Hybrid Machine Learning Approach to IT Salary Prediction: Insights from Academic, Demographic, and Socio-Economic Factors
authors: Caesar Jude Clemente
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: IT professional’s first job after graduation is a significant milestone, marking the first step to financial independence. To explore the factors influencing compensation for IT graduates, a binary classification model using an ensemble machine learning approach that integrates Random Forest (RF), Neural Networks (NN), and LightGBM was developed. A multilevel strategy was adopted, beginning with training the data using RF and subsequently feeding the output leaf indices and the feature set into NN, culminating with LightGBM functioning as a meta-classifier. A cross-validation approach was employed to assess the model’s accuracy rigorously. The model achieved an 88% accuracy rate and an F1 score exceeding 80% across all categories. Utilizing SHAP analysis, key features per model were extracted and analyzed. Notable features highlighted by the two models are the mother’s educational level, IT experience, degree concentration, study frequency, accommodation, siblings and grades. Features such as holding a degree in cybersecurity and residing on dorms emerged as significant predictors of higher starting salaries. The model offers valuable insights for students, enabling them to enhance their qualifications and improve their compensation prospects after graduation

title: Innovative Microgrid Planning for Grid Restoration and Support Using Distributed BESS Systems
authors: Mohammad Alnaeem, Gavin Anderson, Ricardo Parata, Rimnesh Shah
abstract: Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESSs) are playing an increasingly important role in maintaining the stability and resilience of renewable-focused power grids. Deploying distributed BESSs (D-BESSs) at the distribution level enhances overall system reliability. This paper explores how D-BESSs function within microgrid configurations, with emphasis on their impact on system restoration, voltage and frequency regulation, and blackout recovery. The study presents a planning framework focused on network design, and control strategies specifically developed for microgrids. Results from simulations illustrate the tangible advantages of D-BESSs in supporting restoration and ancillary services, further emphasizing their growing significance as conventional restoration plants are retired.

title: High Precision and High Stability Satellite Platform for Atmospheric Infrared Laser Occultation Detection
authors: Yang Liu, Zhijie Ma, Wenxin Zhang, Yibo Hong, Xun Zhang, Jiahe Cui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: The reliable laser transmission and reception requirements for spaceborne atmospheric infrared laser occultation detection were analyzed, with a focus on the control requirements of the satellite platform. Factor decomposition was performed on the pointing accuracy and stability indicators required for the satellite. Through design of the control system and various influencing factors, a highly stable platform implementation method that meets the requirements of laser stable transmission and reception has been achieved. Simulation results show that the design results of the control system and satellite platform can meet the requirements of the indicators.

title: Impact of DER and Mrteo Demand on Relastic Distribution Network
authors: Abdullah A. Almehizia
abstract: The paper is concerned with the technical impact of distributed renewable energy resources and high-intensity demand, such as metro systems, on the distribution network. The study is conducted on an actual distribution network in Saudi Arabia, to identify and investigate the voltage harmonics issues and its severity arising from such integrated systems, as these systems represent inverter-based resources and demands, which are commonly known to affect the power quality of the supply. The study is modeled and simulated in MATLAB Simulink.

title: Real Time Prediction of Signal Strength for 4G and 5G Communication
authors: Tanisa Mallick, Dalia Nandi, Sanjay Chatterji
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The mobile network needs accurate and reliable signal strength prediction to provide seamless connectivity and superior network performance. However, predicting 4 G or 5 G mobile signal strength is difficult due to the real-world scenario, which includes dynamic and environmental variations. The present study develops a real-time prediction system that uses machine-learning approaches to predict signal strength from direct measurement. The proposed system can accurately predict signal strength for both 4 G and 5 G networks. To capture complex non-linear interactions, different machine learning models are trained on large datasets. The result shows a significant improvement in prediction accuracy while using Long ShortTerm Memory (LSTM) model compared to other models. This research provides a flexible and efficient solution for modern communication systems by increasing the reliability and quality of mobile networks.

title: Lightweight Hybrid Model Based on Compact Convolutional Transformers (CCTs) for Efficient Skin Lesions Classification
authors: Khouloud Elbedoui, Hiba Mzoughi, Mohamed Ben Slima
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Melanoma, the most dangerous form of skin cancer, requires early and accurate automated diagnosis to improve patient prognosis. While state-of-the-art deep learning models, particularly Vision Transformers (ViT), achieve high diagnostic accuracy, their inherent computational complexity and excessive parameter count (often exceeding 80 million parameters) create significant barriers to practical deployment in resource-constrained clinical settings. To specifically address this critical efficiency challenge in dermoscopic image diagnosis, we introduce the Compact CNN-Transformer (CCT), an optimized hybrid architecture. The CCT ingeniously combines the local feature extraction capabilities of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with the powerful global dependency modeling strengths of standard Transformers, all within a highly efficient framework. Evaluated on a comprehensive skin lesion dataset, the CCT achieves competitive diagnostic performance with 0.85 accuracy and F1-score, demonstrating strong generalization. Our comparative analysis reveals a critical balance: the CCT achieves this high performance with only 4 million parameters, representing a parameter reduction of over 95% compared to the standard ViT while incurring a marginal performance loss of only 1-2%. Furthermore, the CCT exhibits superior deployment efficiency, requiring low FLOPs and low inference latency. This optimal balance between diagnostic performance and model complexity makes the CCT a highly viable and efficient solution for automated skin lesion classification in low-resource clinical environments.

title: Study on MOSFET’s Operating Region for Fully-Integrated Sub-1-GHz LNA under Scaling
authors: Nobuyuki Itoh, Kiyotaka Komoku, Jun Furuta, Yasunori Suzuki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper presents the optimum operation region of MOSFET for a fully-integrated sub-1-GHz cascode LNA. Results show that subthreshold operation is suitable for fully integrated cascode LNA using scaled CMOS by calculation and comparison with other circuits, and we designed, fabricated, and measured a 920-MHz cascode LNA operated under the moderate inversion region. The measurement results exhibit |s21| of 16.9 dB, NF of 2.30 dB for W =1,000 μm with 1.6-mA current consumption by a 0.8 V power supply.

title: Reduced effective voltage control by shunt reactors in renewable rich grid – Experience of Western Region of India
authors: Naresh Kumar Mhalas, Vishal Balram Puppala, Raj Shailendra Mudaliar, Satyendra Singh Raghuwanshi, Mahesh M Mehendale, Ganji Aravind, Aman Gautam
abstract: This paper highlights the experience of Indian power system operator in managing reactive power in transmission grid near renewable energy complex. States of Western, North-Western and Southern India have concentrated renewable generation complexes. In recent time, significant decrease in voltage control is observed during switching-in of 765kV shunt reactors at the nodes located in close proximity to Renewable Energy Source Generating (RES) plants. During these switching-in operations, the shape of voltage curve in the time series (observed by using phasor measurement unit) is also found different from other nodes directly connected with load or thermal generation. This paper aims to establish the relation between reduction of effective voltage control gained by switching-in a shunt reactor with the reactive resources installed at RES plants connected to same or surrounding nodes. Authors have also shared observations of real-time / live system trial operation that confirm the reactive resources installed at RES plants as a source of additional reactive power supply that is causing reduction of voltage control.

title: Evaluating the Socioeconomic Impacts of the Construction of the Bogotá Metro: A Case Study Focused on the Marly Transmilenio Station Area
authors: Fabio Enrique Londoño-Galindo, Ivanhoe Rozo-Rojas, Jaime Díaz-Ortiz, Johann Nicolás Perilla-Pérez, María Fernanda Ramírez-Amarillo, Andrés Felipe Suárez-Chacón, Litzy Andrea Roncancio-González, Bryan Camilo Chavarro-Flórez, Samuel Murte Tarazona, Clara Pereira Da Silva
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This article presents the results of the socioeconomic effects on businesses resulting from the construction of the Bogotá Metro in the vicinity of the Marly TransMilenio Station, considering preliminary studies and news regarding subsequent stages of the project. Construction projects identify and monitor risks that may impact them; some of these risks in the specified context have been acknowledged. However, literature indicates that significant effects are not adequately addressed as the project progresses. The study adopts a mixed-methods approach, integrating quantitative surveys, structured interviews, and data analysis from a representative sample of 239 business establishments in the Marly neighborhood (N = 636, 95% confidence). The results reveal significant financial pressures due to reduced sales and disrupted pedestrian flow during the construction process, predominantly affecting small and medium-sized enterprises. Furthermore, the study shows a deterioration in community safety, an increase in financial vulnerability, and additional operational costs for many business owners. Nevertheless, the majority of businesses remain resilient and continue their operations by employing strategies to cope with financial stress while retaining employment and preserving their services. This case underscores the necessity for policymakers, stakeholders, and city planners to account for the social and economic impacts of major infrastructure projects. Implementing mitigation mechanisms, fostering community participation, and employing a holistic framework can contribute to reducing adverse effects and strengthening the resilience of local businesses and communities. The study's findings provide valuable empirical insight and may guide future mass transportation initiatives toward socially responsible, environmentally sustainable, and broadly beneficial outcomes for all stakeholders.

title: Fusion of Liquid Neural Networks and Multi-Head Attention for State of Health Estimation of Lithium-ion Battery Packs
authors: Xinyi Zhang, Feiran Xu, Mingxuan Ge, Pengchao Zou, Yuchen Song, Datong Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel fusion architecture that combines Liquid Neural Networks (LNN) with multi-head attention mechanisms for accurate State of Health (SOH) estimation of lithium-ion battery packs. The method employs learnable liquid time constants (LTC) that enable dynamic adjustment of memory characteristics based on input temporal patterns, while the multi-head attention mechanism identifies critical time steps that contribute most to SOH prediction. Additionally, we introduce an innovative coverage-averaging mapping strategy that transforms overlapping window predictions into smooth, cycle-level SOH estimates, eliminating the boundary discontinuities commonly observed in traditional sliding window approaches. Experimental evaluation on real battery data demonstrates competitive performance with an RMSE of 0.0072 and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.9248. The results demonstrate that the proposed method successfully establishes a mapping relationship between individual cells and the battery pack, and accurately estimates the SOH of the pack.

title: Design and Implementation of Blockchain-Enabled P2P Energy Trading Testbed
authors: Shweta Kadam, Debasmita Panda, Ashutosh Yadav
abstract: The paper proposes the combination of Smart Energy Management Systems (SEMS) with Blockchain technology to enable secure, transparent, and decentralized peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading. Substantial emphasis is placed on understanding blockchain fundamentals, including decentralization, immutability, smart contracts, and distributed transaction validation. A 3-layered energy trading system is proposed using smart contracts to manage the trading logic, and a Solidity compiler is used. In this, we have shown the creation of the blockchain account and explained the details of the trading process enabled with the Ethereum blockchain. The proposed 3-layered architecture is demonstrated through a hardware testbed for integrating peer-to-peer energy trading with blockchain technology.

title: Application of an Improved Bandwidth Model in the Design of a 3-Pole Feedback Amplifier
authors: Venkatnarayan Hariharan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: A novel, closed-form analytical model for the −3 dB bandwidth of a 3-pole negative feedback amplifier is presented. The derivation of the model is described, including the approximations made therein. A validation of the model against an exact numerical solution is shown, as also its improvement over prior works. Finally, a sample application of the model is illustrated in calculating the design-space for the poles of the underlying basic amplifier, which otherwise generally needs brute-force techniques in the absence of a closed-form model.

title: Cooperative Prescribed Performance Control for the UAV-USV System With Considering the Dynamic Landing Manoeuvring
authors: Guoqing Zhang, Li Wang, Zehua Jia, Weidong Zhang, Ruonan Liu
abstract: Cooperative systems involving an unmanned aerial vehicle and an unmanned surface vehicle (UAV-USV) are pivotal components of modern autonomous vehicle networks. This paper develops a novel dynamic landing control framework for the UAVUSV to carry out high-precision path-following mission. The main features of the developed scheme are threefolds: (a) The logic virtual aircraft and the logic virtual ship (LVA-LVS) guidance principle is constructed to generate reference route and signals for the UAV-USV system. A triggered rule is designed based on the distance boundary to reduce the continuous update for the attitude signals to the controller. (b) The prescribed performance control (PPC) method is introduced to ensure the convergence of position errors to the prescribed region even the initial condition is inconsistent. The output errors of the UAV will be transformed by using the transformation function to be stabilized. Moreover, the L-function is used to approximate the external disturbances and the nonlinearity terms. (c) Semi-Globally Uniformly Ultimate Boundness (SGUUB) stabilities of the closed-loop control system are guaranteed via the Lyapunov theory. Finally, the advantages and validity of the proposed algorithm are evaluated through the simulation experiments.

title: Uncertainty-guided Iterative Contrastive Fusion for Reliable Survival Prediction in Rectal Cancer
authors: Qingsen Bao, Lei Chen, Ling Dai, Kaicong Sun, Yiqun Sun, Xin Xia, Fu Xiao, Dinggang Shen
abstract: Integrating multimodal radiological images and clinical data is critical for survival prediction in rectal cancer. However, existing methods often lack sufficient consideration of 1) modality heterogeneity (caused by rectal peristalsis, noise artifacts, and missing modalities) and 2) site heterogeneity (caused by different imaging protocols and patient populations). These factors hinder the model from capturing reliable cross-modal relationships and adapting to distribution shifts across clinical sites. In this work, we propose UICSurv, a novel multimodal Survival prediction framework highlighted by Uncertainty-guided Iterative Contrastive fusion, to capture robust cross-site multimodal interactions while leveraging sample-level uncertainty to enhance fusion reliability. Specifically, UICSurv initializes a shared multimodal embedding and iteratively refines it by fusing each heterogeneous modality via the cross-attention mechanism. In each iteration, a novel Survival Contrastive Learning (SCL) strategy is designed to progressively enhance both cross-site alignment and survival discriminability of the multimodal embedding space. Moreover, we design an EvidenceHit module, which employs temporally consistent evidential learning to jointly estimate survival probabilities and uncertainty. The estimated uncertainty further guides the embedding alignment by reducing the interference of unreliable samples. All components operate synergistically within UICSurv to reinforce reliable survival prediction in rectal cancer. Extensive experiments on multimodal datasets of rectal cancer (collected from three sites) demonstrate the superiority of our method both in survival prediction and uncertainty estimation. The code is available open-source: https://github.com/ScorpioBao/UICSurv.

title: FedLoDrop: Federated LoRA with Dropout for Generalized LLM Fine-tuning
authors: Sijing Xie, Dingzhu Wen, Changsheng You, Qimei Chen, Mehdi Bennis, Kaibin Huang
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Fine-tuning (FT) large language models (LLMs) is crucial for adapting general-purpose models to specific tasks, enhancing accuracy and relevance with minimal resources. To further enhance generalization ability while reducing training costs, this paper proposes Federated LoRA with Dropout (FedLoDrop), a new framework that applies dropout to the rows and columns of the trainable matrix in Federated LoRA. A generalization error bound and convergence analysis under sparsity regularization are obtained, which elucidate the fundamental trade-off between underfitting and overfitting. The error bound reveals that a higher dropout rate increases model sparsity, thereby lowering the upper bound of pointwise hypothesis stability (PHS). While this reduces the gap between empirical and generalization errors, it also incurs a higher empirical error, which, together with the gap, determines the overall generalization error. On the other hand, though dropout reduces communication costs, deploying FedLoDrop at the network edge still faces challenges due to limited network resources. To address this issue, an optimization problem is formulated to minimize the upper bound of the generalization error, by jointly optimizing the dropout rate and resource allocation subject to the latency and per-device energy consumption constraints. To solve this problem, a branch-and-bound (B&B)-based method is proposed to obtain its globally optimal solution. Moreover, to reduce the high computational complexity of the B&B-based method, a penalized successive convex approximation (P-SCA)-based algorithm is proposed to efficiently obtain its high-quality suboptimal solution. Finally, numerical results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in mitigating overfitting and improving the generalization capability.

title: The Role of Strategic Entrepreneurship To Develop Sustainable Competitive Advantage (A case study on Umrah and Hajj Travel agencies)
authors: Rianto Nurcahyo, Richael Alfasha, Matthew Avrellio, Damar Aji Irawan, Natalia, Arif Zulkarnain
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: This study aims to analyses the marketing strategies implemented by PT. XYZ Branch in enhancing its competitiveness as a specialized Hajj travel agency. The focus of this study is on the application of the 7P marketing mix (Product, Price, Place, Promotion, Process, People, Physical Evidence) and the effectiveness of each strategy in attracting pilgrims. Using a qualitative approach, data was collected through in-depth interviews, participatory observation, and documentation studies. The results of the study show that promotional strategies through social media and collaboration with religious leaders are the most effective marketing tools. However, the company also faces challenges such as intense industry competition and limited use of digital technology. This study provides recommendations for strengthening digital marketing strategies and improving service quality so that PT. XYZ Branch can compete sustainably.

title: JEDI-Linear: Fast and Efficient Graph Neural Networks for Jet Tagging on FPGAs
authors: Zhiqiang Que, Chang Sun, Sudarshan Paramesvaran, Emyr Clement, Katerina Karakoulaki, Christopher Brown, Lauri Laatu, Arianna Cox, Alexander Tapper, Wayne Luk, Maria Spiropulu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), particularly Interaction Networks (INs), have shown exceptional performance for jet tagging at the CERN High-Luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC). However, their computational complexity and irregular memory access patterns pose significant challenges for deployment on FPGAs in hardware trigger systems, where strict latency and resource constraints apply. In this work, we propose JEDI-linear, a novel GNN architecture with linear computational complexity that eliminates explicit pairwise interactions by leveraging shared transformations and global aggregation. To further enhance hardware efficiency, we introduce fine-grained quantization-aware training with per-parameter bitwidth optimization and employ multiplier-free multiply-accumulate operations via distributed arithmetic. Evaluation results show that our FPGA-based JEDI-linear achieves 3.7 to 11.5 times lower latency, up to 150 times lower initiation interval, and up to 6.2 times lower LUT usage compared to state-of-the-art GNN designs while also delivering higher model accuracy and eliminating the need for DSP blocks entirely. This is the first interaction-based GNN to achieve less than 60 ns latency and currently meets the requirements for use in the HL-LHC CMS Level-1 trigger system. This work advances the next-generation trigger systems by enabling accurate, scalable, and resource-efficient GNN inference in real-time environments. Our open-sourced templates will further support reproducibility and broader adoption across scientific applications.

title: Evaluation of Tree-based Machine Learning Models for Chronic Kidney Disease: Interpretability with SHAP
authors: Valeria Maeda-Gutiérrez, Luis C. Reveles-Gómez, Fabian Navarrete-Rocha, Luis Alberto Flores-Chaires, Karina Trejo Vázquez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Chronic kidney disease represents a significant global health challenge, characterized by the progressive deterioration of renal function associated with elevated morbidity and mortality. Early identification is essential for preventing adverse outcomes and improving clinical management. This study aimed to evaluate and compare tree-based machine learning models for classifying of chronic kidney disease, with an emphasis on predictive performance and model interpretability. Four decision tree-based classifiers were implemented and evaluated using stratified train-test splits. Missing values were imputed using the k-nearest neighbors algorithm, and class imbalance was addressed through the application of the synthetic minority over-sampling technique. Among the models, CatBoost achieved the highest performance, reaching an area under the curve of 0.952, along with a sensitivity of 0.824 and specificity of 0.902, indicating a robust ability to classify both positive and negative cases correctly. SHapley Additive exPlanations analysis was conducted to interpret model predictions, identifying time to event months, HgbA1C, and eGRF baseline as the most influential features. These findings support the utility of CatBoost for severity classification in chronic kidney disease, particularly due to its effective handling of categorical variables and reliable predictive capabilities.

title: A Compact K/Ka-Band Dual-CP Shared-Aperture Phased Array with Wide-Angle Scanning Capability
authors: Chunxu Mao, Tao Wang, Xudong Cai, Yanzhao Niu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter presents a compact shared-aperture phased array operating in the K/Ka bands with wide-angle beam steering capability. The K- and Ka-band antenna elements are staggered, featuring a compact size. Specifically, the Ka-band antenna has the left-handed circular polarization (LHCP) and the K-band antenna has the right-handed circular polarization (RHCP). Both antennas are fed by stripline-based Wilkinson power dividers to improve the CP radiations. To improve the beamwidths and therefore the beam-scanning performance, a back-cavity structure is employed in the design. In addition, a quarter-wavelength opened stubs are integrated into the feeds of the elements, which is functioned as band-stop filters to suppress out-of-band radiation, and hence, the cross-band isolation can be improved. The phased array is prototyped and characterized experimentally, demonstrating the phased array antenna has a beam-scanning range of ±65° in both the K and Ka bands, respectively, with an average scanning loss of less than 4 dB.

title: Sb-Doped Substrates for Low-Noise Silicon Photomultipliers
authors: Shifeng Zhang, Jiangteng Xia, Yanling Ren, Fudexuan Huang, Jiacheng Lai, Ming Zhang, Anqi Hu, Xia Guo
publish: IEEE Journal of the Electron Devices Society
abstract: Suppressing dark noise in silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs) remains highly challenging because Geiger-mode operation inherently leads to high dark count rates (DCR). Although epitaxial silicon layers grown on heavily doped substrates are widely employed, high-temperature epitaxial processing often induces dopant autodoping and the formation of interface states, which significantly exacerbate noise. In this work, we demonstrate that SiPMs fabricated on antimony (Sb)-doped substrates exhibit approximately 20% lower DCR, up to 40% higher photon detection efficiency, and about 15% improvement in single-photon timing resolution at an excess bias of 8 V, compared with their arsenic (As)-doped counterparts. These performance enhancements are attributed to the larger covalent radius and higher diffusion activation energy of Sb, which effectively suppress autodoping and minimize interface-state formation at the epitaxial–substrate boundary, thereby enabling low-noise, high-precision SiPM operation.

title: QUIDS: Quality-informed Incentive-driven Multi-agent Dispatching System for Mobile Crowdsensing
authors: Nan Zhou, Zuxin Li, Fanhang Man, Xuecheng Chen, Susu Xu, Fan Dang, Chaopeng Hong, Yunhao Liu, Xiao-Ping Zhang, Xinlei Chen
abstract: This paper addresses the challenges of achieving optimal quality of information (QoI) in non-dedicated vehicular mobile crowdsensing (NVMCS) system, where vehicles not originally designed for sensing are leveraged to collect real-time data as they traverse urban environments. These challenges are exacerbated by the interrelated issues of sensing coverage, sensing reliability, and the inherently dynamic nature of participating vehicles. To tackle these challenges, we propose QUIDS, a QUality-informed Incentive-driven multi-agent Dispatching System, which ensures high sensing coverage and sensing reliability under budget constraints in NVMCS systems. QUIDS improves QoI by introducing a novel metric, Aggregated Sensing Quality (ASQ), designed to quantitatively capture the concept of QoI by integrating both sensing coverage and sensing reliability. Moreover, we develop a Mutually Assisted Belief-aware Vehicle Dispatching algorithm that estimates sensing reliability and allocates monetary incentives under uncertain vehicle conditions, thereby further improving ASQ. Evaluation using real-world data collected from a deployed NVMCS system in a metropolitan area demonstrates the effectiveness of QUIDS. The ASQ metric shows a 38% improvement over non-dispatching scenarios and a 10% enhancement over state-of-the-art methods. Additionally, QUIDS reduces reconstruction map errors by 39–74% across various reconstruction algorithms, validating its efficacy in improving QoI within NVMCS systems. Addressing the often-overlooked issue of sensing reliability in existing studies, the QUIDS system leverages non-dedicated vehicles and incorporates a quality-informed incentive-driven dispatching system to jointly optimize sensing coverage and sensing reliability. This enables low-cost, high-quality, and scalable urban environmental monitoring without the need for dedicated sensing infrastructure, and makes the system applicable to diverse smart-city scenarios such as traffic monitoring and environmental sensing.

title: NutriRec: Multimodal Large Language Models Enhanced Personalized Dietary Recommendation
authors: Xiwen Deng, Wenzhe Tu
abstract: Poor diet quality is a major modifiable risk factor for obesity, cardiovascular disease, and metabolic disorders, motivating a growing ecosystem of diet-tracking apps and recipe platforms that promise personalized guidance. However, most of these systems still rely on simple scoring rules or ID-based collaborative filtering that ignore rich multimodal food information (ingredients, cooking methods, images, nutrient profiles) and lack explicit nutritional reasoning. To address this gap, we propose NutriRec, a multimodal LLM-based framework for personalized dietary recommendation that links nutritional reasoning with collaborative dietary patterns.We uses a multimodal LLM to generate unified representations of meals and food items from textual descriptions, ingredient lists, nutrient profiles, and images, capturing both sensory and nutritional attributes. On top of these content-based embeddings, NutriRec incorporates collaborative filtering signals through a post-alignment mechanism that aligns user representations from an ID-based sequential model with those from the multimodal LLM. This design enables explainable dietary reasoning by grounding each recommendation in concrete nutritional evidence (e.g., lower sodium, higher fiber, heart-healthy tags) while still reflecting behavioral patterns learned from large-scale consumption logs. We evaluate NutriRec on realistic dietary recommendation scenarios with long-term, multimodal food interaction histories. Across these settings, NutriRec not only yields stronger recommendations than sequential and LLM-based baselines, but also provides more explainable dietary reasoning by explicitly linking suggestions to nutrient profiles, meal composition, and simple guideline-based constraints.

title: SLAPE: Secure Lightweight Authentication for Privacy Enhanced Federated Learning in Industrial Internet of Things
authors: Shanyao Ren, Jianwei Liu, Chip-Hong Chang, Hanzhou Wang, Dongyu Li
abstract: Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising technique in the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) by enabling distributed devices to collaboratively train models without sharing raw data. In FL, ensuring data privacy and secure authentication becomes essential due to the sensitivity of industrial data and the potential for adversarial attacks. This paper highlights a security flaw in a recently proposed FL authentication protocol designed for IIoT environments. Specifically, the scheme is analyzed to be susceptible to public-key replacement attacks. We propose a secure, lightweight authentication scheme for privacy-enhanced federated learning (SLAPE) to address vulnerabilities in participant registration, group key distribution, local data training, and aggregation processes. SLAPE leverages the Elliptic Curve Cryptography with the Chinese Remainder Theorem to support malicious group member traceability, revocation of compromised identities, and efficient batch verification of multiple messages. It effectively resists Type-I attacks that previous schemes could not, while also incorporating forward and backward security essential for IIoT applications. We rigorously demonstrate SLAPE’s resilience against prevalent threats through both formal and informal analyses. Our evaluation results indicate that SLAPE demonstrably enhances the security and privacy of existing schemes, with improvements in computational efficiency for both proof generation and verification, while keeping communication overhead relatively low.

title: Statistical Moment or Cumulative Distribution? Evaluations and Improvements on Side-channel Analysis
authors: Jiangshan Long, Changhai Ou, Yukun Cheng, Kexin Qiao, Wei Cheng, Fan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: Side-channel techniques, such as Distance-of-Means and Kolmogorov-Smirnov analysis, provide valuable insights about leakages from the indirect perspectives of statistical moment and cumulative distribution function (CDF), circumventing the direct and costly estimation of leakage probability densities and thus enabling broad application. Though both the perspectives are informative, their relationship remains unclear – the question of ”which one is better and under what circumstances?” is left open. In this paper, we introduce the probability-probability (PP) plot as a common framework for explaining the mathematical foundations of the CDF-based techniques, facilitating an intuitive understanding of different variant strategies. Then, we propose a novel distinguisher based on the Mann-Kendall test, where the key identification task is reformulated as a goodness-of-fit test checking whether a key-dependent sequence originates from a random binomial distribution. Compared to the existing methods, it delivers substantial gains within the CDF-based family. Finally, we explore the symmetry and dual counterpart of CDF in mathematics, developing an interesting technique based on the inverse cumulative distribution function (ICDF). We present a general discussion of its bridging role and, on this basis, establish the relationships among moment-based, ICDF-based, and CDF-based techniques, thereby enabling the evaluation of CDF-based techniques using metrics originally proposed for the moment-based family. Our theoretical analysis accounts for the empirical observations in practice, and further shows that the improvement achieved by the Mann–Kendall distinguisher is near-optimal.

title: UR-CP-ABE: CP-ABE with Flexible Construction Mechanism and Efficient User Revocation Capability for Access Control in the Cloud
authors: Zhen Guo, Jiangkai Gao, Shuainan Liu, Rong Wang, Chaosheng Feng, Keping Yu, Kim Kwang Raymong Choo, Mohsen Guizani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Ciphertext-Policy Attribute-Based Encryption (CP-ABE) schemes with user revocation allow for dynamic updates to users' access rights. However, existing schemes often encounter issues such as low re-encryption efficiency, inflexible access control, and susceptibility to collusion attacks. To address these challenges, we propose UR-CP-ABE, an efficient user revocation scheme built upon a double encryption method. Specifically, UR-CP-ABE stores both valid and revoked users' identity information in a binary tree. This design enables flexible user authority revocation by modifying only the binary tree's relevant secret sub-items. Moreover, the scheme limits the scope of revocation-induced binary tree updates to a single sub-item. This key optimization resolves the critical issue where re-encryption overhead scales linearly with the number of attributes of revoked users. In addition, we eliminate the possibility of attackers constructing secret sub-keys, preventing the collusion attacks. UR-CP-ABE also supports bidirectional revocation, allowing for the revocation and restoration of user rights, which is not available in other related schemes. Our theoretical analysis and experiments demonstrate that UR-CP-ABE has better performance than other schemes, especially in the re-encryption stages. Moreover, UR-CP-ABE has been proved to be secure based on the decisional q-parallel BDHE hardness assumption in the standard model.

title: Identifying Fault-related Deformation in Large InSAR Datasets Using Transfer Learning
authors: Xu Liu, Yingfeng Zhang, Juliet Biggs, Zhenjie Wang, Xinjian Shan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The rapid expansion of SAR archives (e.g., Sentinel-1) offers new opportunities to detect fault-related deformation signals, such as weak coseismic-like patterns and interseismic shallow fault creep. However, their low signal-to-noise ratio and coherence variability pose challenges for large-scale screening. To address this, we develop a transfer learning–based convolutional neural network for automatic recognition of fault-related deformation in single wrapped interferograms. Built on SarNet and fine-tuned with globally curated Sentinel-1 data, the model achieves 92.25% validation accuracy (AUC 0.9689) with a low false-alarm rate. Cross-mission tests on ALOS-2 (L-band) and ENVISAT (C-band) confirm strong portability (accuracy 87.24%, precision 95.54%, recall 78.13%, F1 85.96%, AUC 0.9686), though recall decreases due to sensor-specific domain shifts. Grad-CAM visualizations indicate that the classifier relies on meaningful interferometric fringes rather than noise artifacts, supporting physical interpretability. These results show that transfer learning enables robust and scalable automated recognition of fault-related deformation, thereby supporting systematic, large-scale mining of multi-sensor InSAR archives.

title: Study on Ignition Performance of TaN/CuO Thin Films
authors: Xiaoming Ren, Yuanyuan Xue, Yanxiang Luo, Yi Mei, Ruizhen Xie, Lan Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: To improve the ignition reliability of film-based initiators, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TaN} / \text{CuO}$</tex> composite thin films with varying compositional ratios were fabricated via a micro-electromechanical systems (MEMS) process. The structural and electrical properties of the films were examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), and fourpoint probe measurements. Ignition sensitivity was assessed according to the Langley statistical procedure specified in GJB/Z377B-2022. Performance tests were conducted under a constant ignition voltage of 27 V and a discharge capacitance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 3} \boldsymbol{\mu} \mathbf{F}$</tex>. Results indicate that the deposited <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{T a N} / \mathbf{C u O}$</tex> films exhibit a dense, uniform morphology with a smooth surface. The composite films show a negative temperature coefficient of resistance. Among the tested configurations, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TaN}_{0.6} \text{CuO}_{0.3}$</tex> film demonstrated the lowest average ignition voltage and produced the most intense plasma emission during operation.

title: Augmented Audio Video Encoding Compression for Secured Optimal Cloud Storage Mechanism
authors: Amruta Gadad, A Devi
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Storing large multimedia data in the cloud demands efficient and secure handling, yet existing methods often apply uniform compression and encryption to both audio and video, causing inefficiencies. The proposed Augmented Audio Video Encoding Compression for Secured Optimal Cloud Storage Mechanism (AAVEC) addresses this by employing separate, optimized pipelines for audio and video processing. AAECE focuses on adaptive preprocessing, smart compression, and lightweight encryption for audio, while AVECE applies scene-aware encoding, content-driven compression, and selective encryption for video. Supported by chunk-based storage and metadata management, performance evaluation shows that AAVEC improves compression efficiency, reduces energy and processing overhead, and enhances security for cloud-based multimedia storage.

title: Feasibility of the Choosing by Advantages Tool in the Strategic Selection of the Structural Supervisor in Multi-Family Buildings to Ensure Quality Compliance
authors: Raúl Huamán Crispín, Maksumi Yulissa Pérez Quispe, Jorge De la Torre Salazar
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: The construction industry currently faces recurring quality issues in multifamily building projects, reflected in structural defects such as cracks and fissures. These deficiencies stem from inadequate selection processes for the structural supervising specialist, which are often focused solely on the lowest cost and lack objective technical criteria. In response to this problem, the application of the tabular mathematical model of Lean Construction-CBA is proposed as an objective, transparent, and collaborative multi-criteria tool that enables the strategic selection of the most suitable professional and ensures quality compliance. Through expert judgment and the use of collaborative tools such as Power BI, Miro, and Paramount Decisions, five candidates were evaluated based on factors such as experience, BIM knowledge, certifications, decision-making skills, and soft skills. The results show a significant reduction in the Rework Problem Estimation Index (RPEI) to 18 % and an increase in Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) to 95%. This research demonstrates the feasibility of the CBA as an effective tool for improving strategic decision-making in consulting firms, reducing rework, and increasing customer satisfaction in housing projects.

title: Occluded Face Recognition Through Enhanced Self-Attention and Cross-Attention Mechanisms
authors: Elhamsadat Hejazi, Majid Ahmadi, Arash Ahmadi
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Occluded face recognition remains a critical challenge in biometric systems and real-world applications, where obscured facial features can significantly hinder identification accuracy. To address this issue, we present an approach that enhances the ResNet18 architecture by integrating positional encoding (PE) with multi-head self-attention (MHSA) and crossattention (CAM) mechanisms. This hybrid design enables the model to selectively focus on critical facial regions while mitigating the effects of occlusions. Evaluated on the Extended Yale B dataset with synthetic occlusions and the AR dataset with real-world occlusions, the proposed model demonstrates remarkable improvements in accuracy and robustness. Our method surpasses state-of-the-art techniques, particularly in scenarios with partial facial occlusions. This work improves occluded face recognition and supports the development of reliable next-generation biometric systems.

title: The Role of Islamic Mobile Apps in Enhancing Religious Practices among Gen Z in Jakarta
authors: Tiurida Lily Anita, Athea Sarastiani, Lianna Wijaya, Muhammad Zilal Hazah, Hainnuraqma Rahim
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: The rapid growth of digital technology has transformed religious practices among Generation Z (Gen Z), particularly in Muslim-majority contexts such as Indonesia. This study investigates the role of Islamic mobile applications in enhancing religious engagement among Gen Z Muslims in Jakarta. Utilizing a framework based on the Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology (UTAUT/UTAUT2) and an extended Technology Acceptance Model (TAM), the study investigates how attitudes, behavioral intentions, and actual usage of Islamic apps are influenced by perceived utility, perceived ease of use, trust, privacy concerns, social influence, and habit, as well as how these elements affect religious engagement. An online survey was used to gather data from 210 Gen Z respondents, and Structural Equation Modeling with Partial Least Squares (SEM-PLS) was used to analyze the model. The results show that attitudes are considerably shaped by perceived ease of use, while attitudes and intentions are not much impacted by perceived usefulness. Actual usage is a powerful indicator of religious engagement, while social influence and habit are important determinants of behavioral intention. It's interesting to see that attitudes are positively impacted by privacy worries, indicating a privacy paradox among Gen Z consumers. By expanding technology acceptance models into the field of digital religion, this study advances both theory and practice by providing guidance to developers, educators, and legislators on how Islamic apps can encourage young people to engage in faith-based activities.

title: Extremely Low Power Consumption of Linear Power Amplifier for Base Station
authors: Yasunori Suzuki
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper presents a linearizer for power amplifier achieving extremely low power consumption. In general, linearizer consists of digital signal processing for compensating complicated intermodulation distortion components, but that consumes huge electric power at the digital signal processing. The proposed linearizer provides extremely low power consumption using an analog circuit in front of power amplifier. This paper shows the configuration of proposed linearizer, while that estimates the compensated performance and efficiency performance around 1-dB gain compression point. This paper discusses the validity of the proposed linearizer.

title: Feasibility Analysis and Design of Off-shore Wind Energy Systems in the Gulf of Tehuantepec, México
authors: Herlinda Tututi-Guillén, Aurelio Medina-Rios, Julio Cesar Godinez-Delgado
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This article presents the feasibility, design, configuration, and dynamic and transient operation analysis of offshore wind farms for the efficient supply of electrical energy. The proposed location is in region of México, in the Gulf of Tehuantepec in Oaxaca, México, which presents great potential and ideal characteristics for its installation and operation. This region offers significant advantages compared to others, according to data and studies provided by Mexican public sector institutions in charge of energy regulation and complementarity studies. It should be noted that this research represents an initiative for the installation of renewable energy generation systems in México (wind power), taking advantage of the strong and constant wind currents in the area. The region is characterized by its favorable climate, its proximity to the ocean, and its strategic location for the installation of off-shore wind farms. This document analyzes the environmental, operational advantages and the technical challenges, in the simulation of different case studies, using the PSCAD/EMTDC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">®</sup> simulator to verify its application.

title:
Development of a Smart Hybrid Heating System with Intelligent Energy Management
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Noor-Ul-Huda, Muhammad Muneeb Khan, Abd Ur Rehman, Mumajjed Ul Mudassir
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: This study presents the development of a Smart cloud based Hybrid Heating System capable of optimizing domestic energy consumption by intelligently switching between natural gas and electric heating sources. The system is connected to the cloud based platform Firebase which allows real-time data exchange with a mobile application built using React Native. ESP32 acts as the main embedded computing unit for the system and manages the DS18B20 and DHT22 temperature sensors, solenoid valve, gas burner, electric heating element, IR flame sen-sor and pressure sensor BMP180. The system uses a lightweight Multi-task MultiLayer Perceptron (MLP) for predictive energy management. Based on the predictions the system selects energy sources and schedules operation, otherwise a decision making pipeline is used to select the energy source and schedule operation based on user preference. The study demonstrates how a compact ML model integrated with a cloud based mobile application can improve automation.

title: Understanding Forward and Reverse Overcurrent Induced Electrical Parameter Degradations of Cascode GaN HEMTs
authors: Weihao Lu, Sheng Li, Yanfeng Ma, Mingfei Li, Jie Ma, Ran Ye, Jiaxing Wei, Long Zhang, Leke Wu, Yiheng Li, Tinggang Zhu, Siyang Liu, Weifeng Sun
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: In this work, the degradations of electrical parameters of GaN-based high electron mobility transistors in Cascode structure (Cascode GaN HEMTs) induced by forward and reverse overcurrent stress are comparatively investigated. Based on an innovative test platform, on-state resistance degradations have been in-situ observed immediately after overcurrent stresses in both forward and reverse directions simultaneously. Furthermore, the similarities and distinctions in degradation effects caused by stresses have been demonstrated through the repetitive on-board test strategy. More severe degradation of on-state resistance has been observed under overcurrent stress in reverse conduction compared to forward conduction. With the help of TCAD simulations, the positive substrate voltage induced by reverse overcurrent has been verified to cause partial channel electrons to inject into the buffer layer. The injected electrons are subsequently captured by intrinsic traps leading to more pronounced on-resistance degradation, which is validated by C-V characterizations.

title: GaN HEMT Low Noise Amplifier with an 8-shaped Inductor for 5G Application
authors: Sheng-Lyang Jang, Te-Lun Fan, Wen-Cheng Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This letter proposes a low-noise amplifier (LNA) for 5G millimeter-wave (mm-wave) applications in the WIN 0.12-nm GaN process. The LNA utilizes three-stage common-source (CS) topologies. The fabricated LNA includes HEMTs, inductors, and input/output pads. The LNA is fabricated in a GaN on silicon carbide technology, and it attains small signal gains greater than 19.52 dB, noise figures of 4.6 dB, 1-dB compression points greater than -12 dBm, and an output third-order intercept point significantly larger than 1.8 dBm. The implemented design consumes a power of approximately 264 mW. The three sub-amplifiers use the drain load with a 1-turn 8-shaped inductor for noise suppression. The sub-amplifier is designed based on a common-source topology with an RC feedback network.

title: CLMPO-EC: A Lightweight Multi-UAV Multi-Area Coverage Path Planning Method Using Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zhichao Qian, Yong Feng, Nianbo Liu, Qian Qian
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs), as an aerial extension of the Internet of Things (IoT) sensing layer, have played an increasingly important role in applications such as environmental monitoring, disaster assessment, and precision agriculture. These tasks can be uniformly abstracted as Coverage Path Planning (CPP), which aims to achieve efficient scanning and surveying while ensuring complete coverage of single or multiple disconnected regions. While single-region CPP has been extensively studied, in multi-region settings existing methods often rely on predefined coverage patterns to guarantee completeness, which to some extent limits their flexibility. Meanwhile, constraints on UAV energy and onboard computation impose higher performance requirements on planning methods. To address these challenges, this paper targets an energy-constrained multi-UAV cooperative scenario and proposes a cross-layer, energy-constrained path optimization framework based on multi-agent reinforcement learning (CLMPO-EC). Specifically, the framework organizes the overall task into two layers—CPP and multi-agent path planning—and, on this basis, integrates Back-and-Forth Planning (BFP) with multi-agent reinforcement learning under a centralized training and distributed execution paradigm to construct a unified, interactive, and structured environmental model. CLMPO-EC further introduces a lightweight cross-layer connection network that propagates raw state information to higher layers to enhance learning efficiency. In addition, building on BFP, an entrance–exit exploration factor is proposed to dynamically adjust the exploration probability of regional entrances and exits in CPP according to the training phase and batch, thereby improving the efficiency of searching for optimal solutions. Theoretical analysis and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior performance in terms of optimality and efficiency.

title: Attribute-Based Credentials with Verifiable Human Binding: towards Compactness and Revocability_supp1-3658312.pdf
authors: Debiao He
abstract: Digital and physical identity authentications are often implemented concurrently to meet strict access control for online services. Although privacy-preserving digital credentials provide strong guarantees such as anonymity and minimal disclosure, these benefits are compromised if holders must simultaneously present physical identification (e.g., government issued IDs) to establish ownership. To securely bind digital credentials to their physical holders while preserving privacy, a new protocol called card-based anonymous credentials (cbAC) was proposed by Hesse et al. (USENIX Security'23). However, this approach faces two significant drawbacks: the size of the communication during credential presentation scales linearly with the number of disclosed attributes, and it lacks revocability, which is essential for internal governance, including identity management and accountability. In this paper, we bridge the above gap by first introducing a constant-size two-party proof of knowledge protocol in asymmetry settings, where there exists a disparity in storage and computational resources between the two parties. Furthermore, building upon this two-party proof of knowledge protocol and utilizing signatures with randomizable keys, we meticulously design a cbAC scheme that is both efficient and capable of supporting revocation. We formalize all notions and conduct a rigorous security proof of the proposed construction. Finally, we present benchmarks from our implementation to illustrate the better than-state-of-the-art performance and features of our solutions.

title: Traceable and Revocable Attribute-Based Conjunctive Keyword Search
authors: Jinguo Li, Chunlin Li, Kai Zhang, Yin He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computing
abstract: The Attribute-Based Keyword Search (ABKS) scheme provides a secure, efficient, and expressive method for data outsourcing to the cloud, offering fine-grained access control to prevent unauthorized data usage. However, existing ABKS schemes primarily cater to the single-owner model and lack effective mechanisms to trace or revoke access from malicious users who leak decryption keys. In this paper, we introduce TR-ABCKS, a traceable and revocable attribute-based conjunctive keyword search scheme. Designed for the multi-to- multi model, TR-ABCKS supports conjunctive keyword search and features an efficient revocation mechanism utilizing binary trees with multilinear maps to revoke access permissions from malicious users. Additionally, TR-ABCKS achieves white-box traceability, preventing malicious users from leaking decryption keys for economic gain. Our comprehensive security analysis confirms TR-ABCKS's semantic security, validated by experimental simulations, showcasing its effectiveness.

title: Privacy-Utility Trade-off in Federated LLM Fine-Tuning: A Dynamic Game Approach_supp1-3658317.pdf
authors: zhou Su
abstract: Fine-tuning large language models (LLMs) is critical for adapting pretrained models to specialized downstream tasks. Federated LLM fine-tuning enables privacy-aware model updates by allowing data owners (DOs) to contribute a global LLM without exposing local data. However, full-parameter fine-tuning in federated settings incurs significant computational and communication overhead, while frequent gradient exchanges increase the risk of privacy leakage, such as memorized data inference. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) with differential privacy (DP) offers a low-overhead alternative with formal privacy guarantees, but fails to strike privacy-utility tradeoff under heterogeneous privacy preferences: individual DOs may inject excessive DP noise to maximize privacy, whereas the curator aims to minimize noise to preserve model quality. In this paper, we present an innovative game-theoretical framework that enables dynamic privacy trading within differentially private federated LLM fine-tuning. In the game, DOs strategically adjust their local DP noise levels in exchange for customized incentives from the curator, thereby balancing privacy and utility. We begin by establishing a theoretical convergence bound that quantifies the influence of locally injected noise on the global model utility. Under this bound, we analytically characterize the pure-strategy Nash equilibrium of the game, accounting for DO heterogeneity, curator budget constraints, and noise estimation errors. For mixed-strategy settings with incomplete information, we design a hierarchical reinforcement learning algorithm that jointly learns DOs’ optimal noise-saving strategies and the curator’s optimal pricing policy without presupposing their private information. Experiments on real-world datasets demonstrate that the proposed scheme improves DO utility, reduces curator cost, mitigates free-riding, and accelerates convergence compared to existing methods.

title: Deep Learning-Enhanced Multiparametric MRI for Prostate Cancer: Reducing Overdiagnosis and Improving Risk Stratification
authors: Daniyal Ahmed, Muhammad Ammar Hassan, Hassan Gilani, Mehwish Afshan, Muhammad Sheraz Khan
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Prostate cancer is one of the most prevalent causes of cancer in men in terms of cancer morbidity and mortality. Multiparametric MRI (mpMRI) has become more effective in tumor detection and characterization of lesions, yet it still has a significant problem of inter-reader variation and overdiagnosis, resulting in unnecessary biopsies. New developments in deep learning (DL) have proven to be able to complement or even substitute PI-RADS assessment, avoiding up to 49 percent of biopsies with high diagnostic accuracy. This paper models and tests an ensemble DL model with ResNet, EfficientNet, and Vision Transformer models, and trained on harmonized large-scale mpMRI data such as PI-CAI (10,207 cases of patients) and PROSTATEx (346 participants). The system was sensitive and specific at over 90 percent and AUC at more than 0.90 in the detection of clinically significant prostate cancer (csPCa). Notably, the model decreased the number of unnecessary recommended biopsy by 25-30 percent and enhanced risk stratification accuracy in low, intermediate, and high risk groups. AI assistance when incorporated into the workflows of radiologists, enhanced diagnostic confidence, inter-reader agreement, and decreased the time of interpretation. The findings highlight the promise of DL-enhanced mpMRI to reduce overdiagnosis, improve treatment planning, and standardize of diagnosis of prostate cancer. The future research will be aimed at potential multi-center validation and the smooth incorporation of AI-assisted mpMRI into clinical workflows.

title: A Constant Switching Controller based DTC Scheme for Speed Control of Five-Phase Open End Winding Induction Motor
authors: C. Venkata Subba Reddy, Sabavath Akhila, Nalla Akshitha, Gunji Poojitha, Yadlapalli Ragini
abstract: the hysteresis based DTC is a simple and yet efficient control technique for control of industrial motors. Even though the direct torque control exhibits first-rate dynamics, it has drawbacks like higher ripple content in torque and flux profiles and variable switching frequencies. The 5-phase induction motors have several benefits over conventional induction motor like additional fault tolerant capability, higher power/torque density, less weight. In this paper, a carrier based constant switching controller based DTC is proposed for open ended winding five phase induction motor. The proposed method reduces ripple content of torque and flux, current distortion by restricting the torque controller to follow triangular carrier wave without disturbing the general structure or simplicity of direct torque control method. The proposed method enhances the use of 5-phase induction motor in electrical vehicles and marine applications. The effectiveness of proposed method for ripple content of torque, flux and current distortion over traditional method is tested with the Simulation software.

title: Intelligent Hybrid MPPT Strategy for Photovoltaic Systems Using PSO-ROA: A Simulation- Comparative Study
authors: Bouloukza Ibtissam, Lekhchine Salima, Ladaycia Hania, Rahab Abderezak, Senani Fawzi, Lekhchine Salima
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid optimization strategy that combines Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) with Red Kite Optimization (ROA) for Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) of photovoltaic systems. The objective is to improve power extraction under dynamic irradiance and temperature. We compare classical and intelligent MPPT methods in MATLAB/Simulink: INC, PSO, ACO, ANN, HORS, and PSO+ROA. The hybrid PSO+ROA shows improved tracking accuracy, faster convergence, and lower steady-state ripple in the simulated test cases. The strategy achieved the highest measured efficiency of 98.8%, surpassing all other met

title: A Simplified Reference Sensor-Embedded Low-Noise Fiber-Optic Hydrophone for Improving Deep Learning-Based Underwater Acoustic Perception
authors: Yuanzhi Zhai, Long Zhang, Dongye Xie, Yuan Xie, Ji Xu
abstract: Underwater environment denoising and target recognition are vital tasks in underwater acoustic perception. Recent advances in deep learning have greatly improved these tasks, but their performance remains limited by the quality of sensor-acquired data. Fiber-optic hydrophones (FOHs) which are widely used in underwater acoustic data collection suffer from inherent phase noise. This noise introduces random perturbations to the captured data and hence reduces the effectiveness of learning-based methods. Embedding a reference sensor in FOH is a promising solution to reduce FOH phase noise, but is complex to be implemented. To address this challenge, this study proposes a simplified method for implementing a reference sensor-embedded FOH. In the proposed architecture, the signal and reference sensors are made all-passive and share a common input and output via time-division multiplexing. To reduce computational complexity in the demodulation, the conventional ellipse fitting algorithm is replaced with a self-orthogonal component superposition method for nonlinear distortion compensation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed FOH can suppress phase noise by up to 9.33 dB compared to conventional FOH, and achieves a Total Harmonic Distortion (THD) of -33.71 dB. Using the proposed FOH, deep learning-based environment denoising is improved by 3.73 dB and underwater target recognition accuracy is enhanced by 6.96%. These findings validate the effectiveness of the proposed FOH and highlight the significance of phase noise reduction in enhancing deep learning-based underwater acoustic perception.

title: Modeling and Optimization of 5G NR - Cellular IoT Coexistence Through Dynamic Spectrum Sharing
authors: Nicholas Accurso, Hariharan Venkatraman, Filippo Malandra
abstract: Due to the growing number of interconnected Internet of Things (IoT) devices along with a greater prevalence of data-intensive 5G applications, it has become increasingly clear that we need efficient methods to share a finite bandwidth among our growing needs. In this work, we examine the coexistence of these two types of applications and propose a method through which to improve its efficiency. To this end, we model the performance of NarrowBand IoT (NB-IoT) latency and 5G New Radio (NR) throughput for IoT and 5G applications performance respectively. Using these models, we formulate two methods through which to statically divide bandwidth between the two networks. Further, we provide a Dynamic Spectrum Sharing (DSS) scheme, allowing NB-IoT users to opportunistically utilize unused 5G spectrum, minimizing unused spectrum. Finally, we reconsider the static bandwidth division methods with our DSS scheme enabled, showing that the addition of our scheme allows more bandwidth to be allocated to the 5G network, resulting in a higher tolerance for variance in the notoriously volatile 5G traffic distributions.

title: Disentangled Multimodal Spatiotemporal Learning for Hybrid EEG-fNIRS Brain-Computer Interface
authors: Yun Xu, Chi-Man Vong, Zihao Xu, Jianlin Fu, Junhua Li, Chuangquan Chen
abstract: The hybrid EEG-fNIRS Brain-computer interface (BCI) combines the high temporal resolution of electroencephalography (EEG) with the high spatial resolution of functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) to enable comprehensive brain activity detection. However, integrating these modalities to obtain highly discriminative features remains challenging. Most existing methods fail to effectively capture the spatiotemporal coupling features and correlations between EEG and fNIRS signals. Furthermore, these methods adopt a holistic learning paradigm for the representation of each modality, leading to unrefined and redundant multimodal representations. To address these challenges, we propose a disentangled multimodal spatiotemporal learning (DMSL) method for hybrid EEG-fNIRS BCI systems, which simultaneously performs multimodal spatiotemporal coupling and disentangled representation learning within a unified framework. Specifically, DMSL utilizes a compact convolutional module with one-dimensional temporal and spatial convolution layers to extract complex spatiotemporal patterns from each modality and introduces a multimodal attention interaction module to comprehensively capture the inter-modality correlations, enhancing the representations for each modality. Subsequently, DMSL designs an adaptive multi-branch graph convolutional module based on reconstructed channels to effectively capture the spatiotemporal coupling features, incorporating modality consistency and disparity constraints to disentangle common and modality-specific representations for each modality. These disentangled representations are finally adaptively fused to perform different task predictions. The proposed DMSL demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on publicly available datasets for mental arithmetic, motor imagery, and emotion recognition tasks, exceeding the best baselines by 2.34%, 0.59%, and 1.47%, respectively. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of DMSL in improving EEG-fNIRS decoding and its strong generalization ability in BCI applications.

title: Smart Cardiac Output Prediction Using AI and IoT
authors: Manel Souaf, Ibtihel Nouira, Mohamed Salman
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents a smart and adaptive system designed to predict and optimize cardiac output in patients suffering from heart failure by combining the internet of thing (IoT) technology with Artificial Intelligence (AI). This work relies on a rich dataset of varied physiological signals, ensuring both the integrity and diversity of the data. The collected data are preprocessing and analyzed through a predictive model based on Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural networks. The model’s accuracy is evaluated using standard metrics performences such as Mean Squared Error (MSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE). The system features a control module embedded in a smartwatch that communicates with the power unit using the ESPNOW protocol. This power unit contain a brushless motor, an ESP32 controller, and a cardiac assist pump. The pump speed is automatically adjusted in real time according to the patient’s physiological needs, maintaining both stable blood oxygenation and responsive cardiac support. The experimental results confirm the reliability and efficiency of the proposed design, suggesting strong potential for further refinement and integration into next-generation cardiac assistance devices

title: A Deep Learning-Enabled BCI Framework for Autonomous Wheelchair Navigation in ROS2-Simulated Environments
authors: Aya Abdallah, Walid Benayed, Omar Trigui, Amal Bouabid, Mohamed Ghorbel
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Despite advances in modern medicine, restoring autonomy for individuals with severe motor impairments remains a major challenge. This work proposes an SSVEP-SLAM hybrid framework that integrates Steady-State Visual Evoked Potentials (SSVEPs) with simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) for autonomous robotics in a ROS2-simulated domestic environment. EEG signals were preprocessed and classified using two deep learning models: EEGNet and CCNN. Experimental results on a 12-class SSVEP dataset show that CCNN outperforms the other, achieving 90.28% accuracy versus 88,56% for EEGNet. The decoded intentions were integrated into ROS2 through a graphical interface, enabling real-time control of a TurtleBot3 platform acting as a simulated intelligent wheelchair. Using the Nav2 stack, the robot successfully navigated toward predefined targets in Gazebo with obstacle avoidance and trajectory visualization in RViz. This study demonstrates the feasibility of SSVEP-SLAM hybrid frameworks for autonomous wheelchair navigation, paving the way toward practical assistive mobility solutions.

title: Development of an Enhanced Control Approach for Compressed Air Supply System
authors: Valentin Vister, Tomaž Požrl, Primož Podržaj
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: The research presented in this paper addresses the issue of energy inefficiency of conventional compressor station control methods. A centralized control system was developed based on a Beckhoff PLC and HMI interface, incorporating fuzzy logic for the dynamic adjustment of compressor operation according to pressure, pressure change trend, and available power. The system was tested on a real industrial compressed air installation with two compressor stations. Measurements were taken before and after implementing the optimized control system. The results demonstrated stabilization of system pressure, a reduction in the number of load/unload cycles, improved utilization of variable-speed compressors, and a significant reduction in specific energy consumption.

title: Experimental Study of a Rotational Piezoelectric Energy Harvester Based Dual Frequency Up-Conversion Utilizing Stoppers and Magnets
authors: Zixuan Xia, Jiawen Xu, Ruqiang Yan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This study proposes a novel piezoelectric energy harvesting (PEH) system achieving dual frequency up-conversion (FUC) for rotational motion. The system integrates a piezoelectric cantilever beam, two stoppers, and three magnets, all mounted on a rotation plate. Under centrifugal forces and magnetic repulsion, impact between the beam and stoppers excites high-order vibration modes, inducing FUC mechanism. A piecewise mathematical model is presented to describe the proposed PEH dynamic model. In addition, the influence of stoppers at different positions on the output voltage results is compared and discussed experimentally. The results demonstrate that the system exhibits significant dual FUC capability within the rotational speed range of 260 to 320 rpm, achieving a maximum peak output voltage of 4.754 V at a constant speed of 314 rpm.

title: A Data Construction and Fine-Tuning Framework for LLM-Based Vietnamese Mental Health Assessment
authors: Xuan Hieu Tran, Thi Kim Trang Vo, Duc Thinh Nguyen, Hai Linh Chu, Thanh Nguyen Tran, Thai Son Le, Minh Chi Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have advanced rapidly in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and show strong promise for mental-health assessment in underserved languages such as Vietnamese. We introduce Mindful Companion, a compact, culturally adaptive Vietnamese LLM. Our pipeline comprises three stages: (i) translating IMHI dialogues [1] into Vietnamese with GPT-4 [2] while preserving linguistic and cultural fidelity; (ii) refining the corpus with perplexity-based filters to retain semantic diversity; and (iii) adapting the Qwen2.5-1.5B backbone using parameter-efficient LoRA/QLoRA fine-tuning. On held-out evaluation, the model achieves 79.9% accuracy and 0.81% macro-F1, indicating readiness for real-world Vietnamese mental-health research and digital-empathy applications under limited compute. The system supports early linguistic screening and empathetic dialogue understanding, not clinical diagnosis or therapeutic decision-making. Our code implementation is available at: https://github.com/ai4li/mainproject/tree/main/MindfulBot

title: YOLO-trash: A Light-weight Detector for Waste Identification in Underwater Marine Images
authors: Bhavika Gandham, Rushik Tangudu, Rimjhim Padam Singh
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Marine pollution poses a serious threat to ocean ecosystems, as underwater debris, including plastics, metals, and rubber materials, causes considerable damage to aquatic life and deteriorates water quality. Existing monitoring methods are time-consuming and insufficient for large-scale detection needs due to computational and performance inefficiencies.
