Hence, this paper presents YOLO-trash, a light-weight detection system for identifying underwater trash through the strategic integration of YOLOv11n model and RepNCSPELAN blocks. The work also examined other advanced strategies like attention and residual connection integration into the YOLOv11 model for performance enhancements. Finally, the paper comprehensively analyzed and compared the proposed method against five state-of-art YOLO techniques on “Marine Pollution” dataset, an annotated collection of underwater images containing eight different categories that include both natural marine elements and various pollution types. Results showed that the YOLO-trash outperformed with a high $F 1=75 \%$ and $m A P=77 \%$ approximately, thereby contributing to SDG-6: Clean water and sanitation, SDG-14: Life below water and SDG-11:sustainable cities and communities.

title: Exploration on Mobility Extraction Anomalies in Pentacene Organic Transistors via Silvaco TCAD Based Simulation
authors: Indranil Maity, Arijit Mondal, Ankit Biswas, Malay Gangopadhyay
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This work presents a practical Technology Computer-Aided Design (TCAD) based simulation framework for pentacene Organic Field-Effect Transistors (OFETs), aimed at addressing the present need for dependable predictive models in flexible electronic devices. The study applies the Poole-Frenkel model to describe how carrier mobility changes with electric field, together with a trap density of states (DOS) model that combines exponential band-tail states and Gaussian deep traps, which usually occur in disordered organic semiconductors. The model is implemented for a bottom-gate, top-contact p-type pentacene OFET using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{HfO}_{2}$</tex> as a high-k gate dielectric. The simulated device shows good electrical performance, with a saturation mobility of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.38\ \text{cm}^{2} / \mathrm{V}. \mathrm{s}$</tex>, a subthreshold swing of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$81.9 \text{mV} /$</tex> decade, and an ON/OFF current ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.37 \times 10^{12}$</tex>. A major outcome is that the model reproduces a numerical breakdown in the usual transconductance-based mobility extraction, producing a non-numerical (NaN) result. This behaviour comes from the actual interaction of field-dependent transport and gate-modulated contact effects, not from numerical error, proving the need for realistic physical models in device analysis.

title: UniVerseChat: An AI-Enabled Conversation Bridge for Inclusive Communication
authors: K. Rajalakshmi, Medha Harini Dravidamani, D Nivetha Ruvah, S Sreeja
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Communication barriers continue to impact interaction for individuals who are deaf, mute, and visually impaired. Although technologies have advanced in recent years, including sign language into digital systems remain a complex challenge. This project addresses these gaps by developing a Video and Audio Chatbot that includes sign language recognition and dual-mode communication. The system interprets sign gestures into text and generates responses in both text and audio formats, enabling access for users with diverse requirements. Using Computer Vision for gesture detection, deep learning techniques for translation, and Natural Language Processing (NLP) for generating responses, the chatbot ensures adaptive interaction. Text-to-Speech (TTS) technology further improves usability for visually impaired users. Designed with an emphasis on inclusivity, this system supports smooth communication and reduces dependence on intermediaries. By addressing varied communication needs, the project promotes empathy in technology-driven solutions.

title: An Inspection on Paraphrase in Healthcare Using Natural Language Processing Approaches
authors: Moupriya Kundu, Mohua Mukherjee, Anupam Mondal
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Paraphrase is a process where rewriting of sentences occur which have the same meaning but different set of words. There are huge data files in healthcare containing the reports of the people, prescriptions or enquiries. Paraphrase can use electronic healthcare records and simplify them into small data where are easy to use and consume less time. This makes the patient and healthcare workers interaction more efficient. The two tasks here are identification and generation of paraphrase. Here the survey identifies techniques like Variational Autoencoders with Long short-term memory model (VAEs-LSTMs), adversarial learnings, Advanced EncoderDecoder architectures, Knowledge Driven and safety focused Methods, Data Augmentations and other deep learning approaches. Other than this LLMs are also used here in medical fields for patients, education and research. This research paper mainly focuses on the generation of multiple paraphrases for an input, additionally in also identifies the paraphrase. There is a brief context where the generation of report is also taken in account using visual data like images. Various deep learning approaches like (CNN) and RNN are also used. Thus, this survey paper explores a detailed topography about the personal scenario of paraphrase in the domain of healthcare using different frameworks and deep learning processes.

title: Generative Artificial Intelligence Enabled Smart Metering Framework For Predictive Energy Sharing
authors: Monisha M, Gayathri S, Anant Kumar, Shanti Swarup K
abstract: The growing complexity of modern energy systems necessitates intelligent and adaptive solutions to ensure efficient power distribution and improved grid resilience. This work proposes a generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) framework for predictive energy sharing in smart power grids. The system integrates smart meters, embedded sensors, and edge-computing controllers to monitor real-time energy flows and facilitate peer-to-peer (P2P) surplus redistribution. A hybrid simulation approach implemented using MATLAB/Simulink, LabVIEW, and hardware prototyping validates real-time demand-supply behaviour. Generative models-Variational Autoencoder (VAE), Generative Adversarial Network (GAN), and Transformer were evaluated for classifying energy-sharing events using consumption data. For future forecasting of energy sharing sequences, a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network was employed, capturing temporal dependencies in consumption patterns. Comparative analysis showed that VAE and Transformer achieved high classification performance (accuracy > 90%), LSTM demonstrated superior capability in predicting actual energy sharing (kWh) with reduced RMSE and improved temporal stability. A Raspberry Pi 5- based prototype, communicated with smart meters via RS-485, MQTT, and dashboard for real-time visualization. Results validate effectiveness of the AI framework for predictive decision-making in decentralized energy distribution, offering a scalable and resilient energy-sharing solution for future smart grid applications.

title: Development of an Integrated Tax Management System Through an Agile Framework to Optimize Ceta's Technological Infrastructure
authors: John Edisson Martinez Garcia, Nelson Vladimir Yepes Gonzalez
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: The Centro de Estudios Tributarios (CETA) confronts significant operational challenges stemming from obsolete technological infrastructure characterized by legacy information systems, fragmented data silos, manual processes, and critical security vulnerabilities. This research presents a comprehen- sive digital transformation initiative leveraging the Scrum agile framework to systematically modernize CETA's technological infrastructure, enhance operational efficiency, ensure organizational sustainability, and catalyze strategic growth. The proposed methodology addresses the fundamental technological obsolescence affecting over 20 independent databases while serving 19,315 active users. Key contributions include the development of a tailored agile framework for tax management systems, implementation of centralized data architecture, deployment of secure transactional portals, and creation of integrated mobile applications. The transformation initiative demonstrates measurable improvements in system reliability, operational efficiency, and strategic decision-making capabilities, positioning CETA as a benchmark for digital tax management excellence in Colombia's public sector.

title: Investigation of Higher Order Sectorization Techniques for Enhancing Spatial Reuse and Network Capacity in 6G mmWave Environments
authors: Mridul Gupta, Alankrita Aggarwal, Pardeep Singh, Stuti Bhatt, Javed Wasim, Karuna Kumari
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: In this paper, we had investigated how higher order sectorization can improve network performance in 6G mmWave environments. We had divided the area into more sectors and tested how it affects throughput, interference, and energy efficiency. The simulations showed that using more sectors helps to handle more users and keeps the signal strong even with obstacles like buildings blocking the way. We had used beamforming and power optimization to make the network work better. The results looked very much like real-world situations and showed how these techniques help in keeping connection stable and fast. This work gives a good way to make future wireless networks more efficient, reliable, and capable of serving many users in tough conditions. It's useful for next generation communication systems.

title: Mitigating HTLC Griefing Attacks with Commitment Bonds: A Game-Theoretic and Empirical Analysis
authors: Tuan-Dung Tran, Quoc-Khoi Le, Uyen Do, Van-Hau Pham
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Hashed Timelock Contracts (HTLCs) underpin atomic swaps and payment channel networks by combining a hashlock with a timelock, yet their economic soundness remains fragile under rational adversarial behavior. We analyze the griefing attack, in which an adversary withholds the preimage until expiry to immobilize an honest counterparty's liquidity at negligible cost, thereby imposing material opportunity loss without risking principal. To formalize this asymmetry, we develop a game-theoretic model together with a Python-based, discrete-time simulation framework that quantifies both the attacker's cost and the victim's lock duration under realistic protocol timelines. Building on this foundation, we propose the Commitment Bond HTLC (CB-HTLC), a lightweight mitigation that requires the initiator to post a small, non-refundable bond prior to lock creation. This bond introduces an unavoidable, upfront cost that converts strategic delay into a strictly loss-making action, restoring incentive alignment for rational participants. Empirical evaluation demonstrates that, whereas the classic HTLC permits zero-cost griefing with full-duration liquidity lock, CB-HTLC reshapes the payoff landscape: the attacker's inaction becomes economically irrational while atomicity and liveness for honest participants remain intact. Crucially, the mechanism is lightweight, protocol-agnostic, and immediately deployable, offering a rare example of a security enhancement that is both effective and practical without disruptive network-wide upgrades. Our contri-butions-formalization of griefing as a strategic game, development of an open simulation tool, and empirical evidence that commitment bonds realign incentives-advance HTLC-based systems toward genuine economic robustness rather than cryptographic sufficiency alone.

title: Seasonal Dynamics and Long-Term Trends of Aerosol Optical Depth and Particulate Matter Using Multi-Source Analysis: A Case Study of Jaipur, Rajasthan
authors: Aman Yadav, Ajay Singh Jethoo, Shivam Chauhan, Kaushlandra Bairwa, Sheikh Abbas Muhammad
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Aerosols and particulate matter (PM) play a significant role in altering atmospheric composition and radiative balance through complex physical and chemical processes. Understanding their optical and mass characteristics is essential for evaluating both climate forcing and air quality. In the present study, ground-based measurements of particulate matter (PM 2.5 and PM 10) obtained from the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) were compared with satellite-retrieved Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD) at 500 nm from the AErosol RObotic NETwork (AERONET) over Jaipur, India. The analysis covers the period from April 2018 to November 2024 and aims to examine the interrelationship between AOD and PM concentrations under varying seasonal conditions. Results indicate that both AOD and PM levels reach their maximum during the pre-monsoon season, while relatively high values are also recorded in winter months due to stagnant meteorological conditions. The lowest AOD values occur during spring, corresponding to cleaner atmospheric conditions. A gradual decline in AOD and PM levels during successive winters suggests a possible reduction in biomass burning and industrial emissions. The observed strong correlation between AOD and PM underscores the reliability of AOD as a proxy for surface aerosol loading.

title: Bayesian Analysis of Tuberculosis Patients: Their Knowledge and Awareness
authors: Achinta Saikia, Manash Pratim Barman, Bipin Gogoi, Monjit Protim Changmai
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This study employs Bayesian methods to analyze the level of knowledge and awareness about tuberculosis (TB) among patients. Using survey data, we estimate posterior distributions of awareness levels and examine associations with demographic factors, treatment adherence, and outcomes. The Bayesian framework allows for robust inference even with small or uncertain samples, integrating prior knowledge with observed data to yield credible intervals and probabilistic interpretations. Objectives: To study the effect of different demographic and socio-economic factors on awareness of tuberculosis (TB). Methods: The study was conducted from January, 2021 to March 2021, employing a expressive, observational research design with a quantitative approach to explore the awareness of tuberculosis (TB) patients in the Dhemaji district of Assam, India. Results: Results indicate that age, occupation, and alcohol consumption are significant predictors, as their 95 % credible intervals do not include zero, suggesting a reliable positive association with the outcome variable. Specifically, older individuals, those in certain occupations, and those who consume alcohol tend to have higher predicted values on the outcome. In contrast, variables such as sex, caste, educational level, and smoking status do not show statistically significant effects, as their credible intervals span zero, indicating considerable uncertainty in their influence. Overall, the model suggests that demographic and behavioral factors like age and alcohol use play more consistent roles in shaping the outcome than socio-cultural indicators like caste or education. Conclusion: This analysis demonstrates that age, occupation, and alcohol consumption are robust and statistically significant predictors of the outcome, each exhibiting a clear positive association. In contrast, variables such as sex, caste, educational attainment, and smoking status show no meaningful or consistent effects, suggesting their limited relevance within the current model. These results highlight the critical influence of demographic and behavioral factors-particularly age and lifestyle choices-on the outcome of interest. Moreover, model comparison metrics (DIC, Log Marginal Likelihood, and log Bayes Factor) strongly and consistently favor Prior1, indicating that its underlying assumptions provide a markedly better fit for the data. Together, these findings offer valuable insights for targeting interventions and refining predictive models.

title: Practicing Advanced Technology Implementation For the Indian Transmission Grid
authors: Amit R. Kulkarni
abstract: Today's transmission utilities are adopting multiple smart grid technologies to fulfill "Carbon Neutrality" obligations and make transmission grids more resilient. The paper enumerates several of these technologies, including synchrophasors, drones, Distributed Energy Resources (DER), and offshore wind energy, to enhance the transmission grid's adaptability and achieve sustainable energy objectives for the future. The use of machine learning-based data analytics, combined with data from smart grid devices, is demonstrated through a real-world example to extract value from large datasets. The utilization of Drone technology for faster actions to patrol transmission assets spread over a more expansive geography, along with remedial measures needed to achieve better operational performance, is explained. This paper highlights the seamless integration of Renewable Energy (RE), including Offshore Wind technologies, and elaborates on the key factors that require attention during project implementation. Thus, this paper lays down the pathway for working in coexistence with all such smart grid technologies, thereby broadening the horizon of adaptability and sustainability in electric transmission grids.

title: Dynamic Offloading Strategy in Vehicular Networks via Federated Continuous Reinforcement Learning
authors: Xiaoming Yuan, Kunda Huang, Boxuan Cao, Jiaqi Zhao, Changle Li, Qingxu Deng
abstract: The dynamic nature of vehicular ad-hoc networks (VANETs) presents significant challenges, including computational constraints, decision conflicts, and performance degradation under environmental dynamics. Traditional offloading strategies often struggle to balance real-time responsiveness, energy efficiency, and knowledge retention in heterogeneous vehicle clusters. To address these issues, this paper proposes a federated continual reinforcement learning framework with asynchronous updates and spatiotemporal knowledge fusion. An optimized multi-agent deep deterministic policy gradient algorithm with lazy agent updates (OMADDPG-LA) is introduced to reduce policy conflicts while improving communication efficiency. Additionally, a spatiotemporally decoupled knowledge retention mechanism adjusts parameter importance weights based on vehicle-specific behaviors and incorporates generative replay to alleviate storage constraints. A federated aggregation paradigm with credibility-aware weighting further enhances adaptability to dynamic tasks. Experimental results show that the proposed framework significantly improves information freshness, energy efficiency, and communication overhead compared to existing methods. It also achieves better convergence stability under dynamic conditions, providing a privacy-preserving and scalable solution for collaborative intelligence in large-scale VANETs.

title: Empirical Evaluation of Evolutionary NAS with Training-Free Metrics for Discovering Robust Networks Under Adversarial Training
authors: Can Do, Ngoc Hoang Luong, Quan Minh Phan
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Using training-free (TF) metrics as proxies for network performance is an effective and efficient approach in neural architecture search (NAS). Recent studies have shown that TF metrics can outperform training-based metrics in identifying robust networks when integrated as search objectives in both single-objective and multi-objective evolutionary NAS (ENAS) methods. However, prior work has typically evaluated robustness without applying adversarial training. While adversarial training can improve the robustness of deep neural networks, it has the drawback of reducing performance on clean data. In this paper, we investigate the effectiveness of ENAS with two types of performance metrics (i.e., training-based and training-free) in discovering networks that simultaneously achieve high accuracy on both clean and adversarial data. Extensive experiments on NAS problems built upon the newly proposed adversarial NAS benchmark (i.e., NAS-RobBench-201) demonstrate that multiobjective ENAS with TF metrics as search objectives can efficiently identify networks with high performance on clean data and strong robustness against various adversarial attacks.

title: Over-the-Air Performance Evaluation of Real and Complex Neural Networks for Joint Channel Estimation and Equalization in QAM Systems
authors: Fábio D. L. Coutinho, Jonathan A. Soares, Kayol S. Mayer, Hugerles S. Silva, Arnaldo S. R. Oliveira, Dalton S. Arantes
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: With the advent of sixth-generation (6 G) communication networks, artificial intelligence (AI) is recognized as a promising technological enabler due to the paradigm shift it brings to various processing functions. Consequently, AIbased algorithms, including both real- and complex-valued neural networks (NNs), have been proposed in the literature, although they are typically evaluated using simulated data. In this work, an over-the-air (OTA) experimental setup is employed to gather real-world datasets to assess NNs applied to joint channel estimation and equalization in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$M$</tex>-ary quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) systems. A comparative analysis between real- and complex-valued NN architectures is also provided, carefully matched in terms of learnable parameters to ensure an unbiased evaluation. The channel environments consider both line-of-sight (LoS) and non-line-of-sight (nLoS) propagation scenarios, aiming to provide insights into the impact of realistic channel conditions on the performance of NN-driven physical layer functionalities.

title: A Federated Learning-Based Intrusion Detection Framework for Blockchain-Enabled IoT Supply Chains
authors: Rupesh Mishra, Yukta Vishnoi
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The newest Internet of Things (IoT) networks in supply chain operations not only provide massive amounts of realtime information but also present new cyber-physical security challenges. This study presents a multidisciplinary simulation framework that merges blockchain and machine learning (ML) to boost the security and efficiency of blockchainbased IoT supply chain networks. In this regard, we consider federated learning (FL)-trained deep neural networks for distributed anomaly detection on IoT device data collections and report anomalies on a permissioned blockchain database to achieve tamper-proof auditability measures. When we simulated the network (using NS3 and a blockchain simulator) under various trouble scenarios, the ML-enhanced system could detect cyber-attacks (e.g., data exfiltration, DDoS, and malicious device behavior) with $\mathbf{{\gt} 9 5 \%}$ accuracy and also considerably reduced the false alarms compared with the baseline methods. Blockchain only provides data visibility and traceability for supply chain events. The following are our contributions: (1) proposing a new federated ML framework for distributed anomaly detection in IoT supply chains, (2) designing a layer on the blockchain to store alerts and trained models, and (3) performing a comprehensive simulation study of the overall system, which demonstrates how combining both systems surpasses non-ML or non-blockchain configurations. The results indicate that a robust collaborative ML-based IDS improves incident response, and the blockchain guarantees the trust and auditability of IoT Data streams in supply chains. This study lays the groundwork for the future realworld deployment of secure, smart IoT supply chain networks.

title: Ultra-Fast and Accurate Estimation of Large-Scale & Multi-Level Mesh-Based On-chip Architectures using Machine Learning and Multiprocessing
authors: Anil Kumar, Basavaraj Talawar, S. Mahadevi
abstract: Packet Switching On-Chip Network technology has taken over conventional bus-based on-chips since it combines multiple cores into a single chip, enabling the implementation of numerous complicated applications. The evaluation of NoC design performance depends mainly on simulation, which becomes very slow with increasing architectural size and needs more information about how different design parameters affect the actual performance of the network. As a result, using simulation for optimization is exceedingly challenging, and these systems must be verified using distinct simulated traffic flows of various topological sizes. Thus, we present a Machine Learning (ML) framework to examine the design parameters of 2D and 3D NoC architectures paired with multiprocessing since these need to be evaluated on different configurations. The Multiprocessing Regression Framework (MRF) is the name of this framework. By utilizing different machine learning regression models, this approach forecasts NoC parameters while considering a range of various simulated traffic flows. The proposed approach can be tested on 2D and 3D NoC designs and may be used to analyze performance, area, and power architectures. The outcomes were compared with those produced by the popular cycle-accurate Booksim NoC simulator. Topology sizes ranging from 2×2 to 50×50 were tested alongside varying injection rates, virtual channels, and various network traffic behaviors. The proposed design put forward achieved a speedup between 1000× and 1500×, while the prediction error was approximately 8% to 10%.

title: Unified Model Framework for Electrified Propulsion Systems Based on Equivalent Circuit Models
authors: Yeojin Hyun, Mehdi Zadeh, Hae Seong Ahn
abstract: This paper introduces a unified and physically grounded modeling framework for electric propulsion systems, formulated using active Equivalent Circuit Models (ECMs). The proposed framework integrates the coupled dynamics of the propulsion system, hierarchical control architecture, and hull surge motion within a single circuit-theoretic structure, enabling a consistent representation of electrical, mechanical, and hydrodynamic interactions. Key dynamic phenomena including torque generation, inertial responses, and hydrodynamic loads are represented through electrical equivalents, enabling a computationally efficient yet physically interpretable simulation environment. The control system, from ship speed regulation to motor-drive control, is modeled as a hierarchical set of circuit-level submodels that retain domain-specific dynamics and their interdependencies. Model validation is performed via two complementary approaches. First, a switching-based simulation model is developed to verify dynamic motor behavior under no-load conditions, demonstrating consistency in predicted q-axis current, motor speed, and electromagnetic torque. Second, experimental validation focuses on steady-state propulsion characteristics, including thrust, propeller torque, effective power, and self-propulsion point. All ECM parameters are derived from scaled experimental measurements, including towing tank resistance and propeller open-water tests. The proposed model offers structural scalability and extensibility, positioning it as a foundation for real-time simulation, system-level co-design, and digital twin development in next-generation electric and hybrid-electric marine vessels.

title: Physics-based model for threshold voltage drift of Ovonic Threshold Switch (OTS)
authors: Paolo Fantini, Joe McCrate
abstract: This work investigates the cross time and temperature drift of the threshold voltage (V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"/>T ) of ovonic threshold switch (OTS) selector in the 3DXPoint<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TM</sup> technology. A physics-based model, accounting for the activation energy spectrum of structural relaxation (SR) phenomena at the basis of the V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</sub> drift, has been developed. The model has been validated by comparison with an extensive electrical characterization of 3DXPoint<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">TM</sup> chips.

title: A Fine-Tuned Resource-Limited Deep Learning Approach for Alzheimer’s Diagnosis
authors: Pradipta Chakrabarty, Tannistha Neogy, Arjya Banerjee, Shirsa Mondal, Sukanya Mitra, Deboleena Sadhukhan
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Automated Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) Diagnosis anticipates perfect and timely medical aid to Dementia affected patients. Nowadays, the AD diagnosis using the Deep Learning (DL) architecture leads to the early diagnosis of the disease. This paper proposes a thirteen-layer Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture that integrates five sets of convolutional layers with batch normalization to enable efficient hierarchical feature learning, followed by max pooling to reduce computational complexity. A dropout layer is employed to reduce overfitting in this model by dropping $50 \%$ of neurons during training, and finally, fully connected layers are incorporated for identifying multiple classes of dementia images. The Adam optimizer is used to expedite faster training, also yields stable convergence. The proposed model is validated on two popular databases, the OASIS and ADNI databases, to evaluate high diagnostic accuracy with limited resources. The proposed model reports diagnostic accuracy of $92 \%$ and $68 \%$, and computational time of 53 minutes and 62 minutes, respectively, for the OASIS and ADNI databases, which are found to be more promising and robust than other conventional pre-trained DL models, including DenseNet, EfficientNetB3, MobileNet, and ResNet152. Finally, the proposed approach has been ideated as a mobile application for easier usage by patients and pathologists.

title: Functional Prototype for Temperature Control in the Coffee Drying Process
authors: Johan Bohórquez, Juan Conde, Luis Timaná, Daniela Ávil
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a functional prototype for temperature control in the coffee drying process in the rural area of Pitalito, Huila, with the aim of improving bean quality and optimizing the production process. Since thermal variations can affect the coffee's organoleptic properties and reduce its commercial value, an automated system was implemented based on temperature and humidity sensors connected to an ESP8266 control unit with IoT connectivity. This technology enables real-time monitoring and adjustment of drying conditions, ensuring a more uniform and efficient process. By reducing losses due to heat overexposure and improving the consistency of the final product, this system not only enhances coffee quality but also strengthens the sustainability and competitiveness of small-scale producers in the market.

title: Modeling and Analysis of UAV Signal Propagation in Outdoor Environments Using Two-Ray Ground Reflection
authors: R Prkash Kumar, Ram Anjaneyulu Idapalapati, M.Chathar Singh, Pinjala N Malleswari, Ravindar Amgoth, V Leela Satyanarayana
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly utilized in applications such as surveillance, disaster management, and smart agriculture, where reliable wireless communication is essential. Accurate modeling of signal propagation is crucial to ensure consistent connectivity between the UAV and ground control stations. This paper presents a comprehensive performance analysis of UAV communication using the Two-Ray Ground Reflection (TRGR) model, which accounts for both direct and ground-reflected signal components. This research paper compares TRGR with the traditional Free-Space Path Loss (FSPL) model across varying UAV altitudes and distances. Simulation results demonstrate the influence of ground reflection coefficients, terrain types, and UAV height on signal behavior. Furthermore, Rayleigh and Rician fading models are integrated to simulate realistic smallscale fading effects. The findings provide valuable insights into optimal UAV deployment strategies for reliable communication in outdoor environments.

title: Control-Oriented Modeling for Thermal Management of Fuel Cell Vehicles in High-Temperature Environments Based on Physics-Informed Neural Network
authors: Haowen Shen, Fengxiang Chen, Yaowang Pei
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: To ensure the stable operation and passenger comfort of fuel cell vehicles, vehicle-level thermal management plays a vital role. Under high-temperature conditions, the control of air-conditioning compressor speed and chiller valve opening is particularly important, as these actuators directly affect both the cabin temperature for passenger comfort and the battery temperature for system safety and durability. Integrated thermal management systems can improve efficiency and thermal performance in such scenarios, yet the strong coupling among subsystems significantly increases the difficulty of accurate modeling and control design. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a control-oriented modeling framework based on a physics-informed neural network. First, conventional state-space models of the high-temperature thermal management system are obtained. Then, the Gated-Recurrent-Unit (GRU) based encoder-decoder neural network is trained in a physics-informed manner, allowing it to capture the underlying dynamics of the system. This hybrid approach improves modeling accuracy while preserving the interpretability. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed model achieves better input–output accuracy compared with both traditional neural networks and conventional state-space models. With a relatively small number of network parameters, the Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of the step-by-step prediction for the cabin and the battery are only 0.030 K and 0.023 K respectively, and the maximum errors are 0.916 K and 0.629 K respectively. The developed model therefore establishes a solid foundation for advanced thermal management strategies, such as neural network-based model predictive control, in the future development of fuel cell vehicles.

title: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Security: A Critical Review of Threat Landscape and Protective Mechanisms
authors: Tinku Adhikari, Samanway Bhattacharya, Subhronil Paul, Ashwini Sharma, Srija Jana, Ayantika Dhar
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: A decade has passed since Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) evolved from specialized military capabilities to commercially available platforms that are now commonplace in commercial, surveillance and delivery markets. With that evolution, the need to investigate UAV-related security threats has grown in importance, mitigation of these security threats occur next. This paper provides a critique of existing UAV threat landscape, and discusses a number of vulnerabilities at the physical, software and communications levels. To provide some context, we explore key systems (ground control and communications station, on-board flight systems, UAV-based communications networks) and make systemic comments regarding vulnerabilities at each layer to jamming, spoofing, false data injection, and unauthorized access. In addition, we investigate protective mechanisms (cryptography, AI based mechanisms, resilient architectures, etc.), and active avenues of research that must be addressed if secure deployments are to occur. By mapping the existing vulnerabilities and countermeasures in an organized fashion, we have provided a road forward for future research to enable a secure, resilient, and reliable UAV ecosystem.

title: A Ka-Band VGA and Its Application to Four-Element Beamforming IC for LEO Satellite Communication
authors: Hyeonwon Song, Wonseob Lee, Mingyu Lee, Hyungju Kim, Seunghun Wang, Hui-Dong Lee, Bonghyuk Park, Seungchan Lee, Jinseok Park
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: A Ka-band variable gain amplifier (VGA), fabricated using a 65 nm CMOS process, is presented for beamforming integrated circuits (ICs) supporting low earth orbit (LEO) satellite communication systems. The proposed VGA employs a two-stage architecture comprising a variable gain stage and a buffer stage. The variable gain stage utilizes a Gilbert-cell topology, chosen for its structural robustness against phase errors during gain control. The buffer stage is implemented using a common-source amplifier with neutralization capacitors, which ensures adequate gain and output power. The VGA is integrated into a common node of the four-element beamforming IC to provide additional gain control range and to correct offset gain errors between ICs in a multichip phased array module. The VGA achieves a 13 dB gain control range with a root mean square (RMS) phase error of less than 0.94° across the 26.5 to 30.5 GHz frequency range.

title: Beam Steering Characteristics of a 300 GHz Stretchable RIS with Dual-Polarization Capability
authors: Eiru Morimoto, Kento Seki, Yuto Kato, Yosuke Nakata, Atsushi Sanada
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: In this paper, we present stretchable RIS with cross-shaped metallic patterns on both sides of an elastic substrate to handle beam steering capability for both orthogonally polarized incident waves. The stretchable RIS is designed at 300 GHz band and its reflection beam steering characteristics are demonstrated numerically. The simulated reflection beam angle agrees well with the theoretical prediction for both the x- and y-polarized incident waves and the beam steering characteristics from 61.2 deg to 42.4 deg are confirmed with the stretch ratio from 100 % to 130 % with the reflection efficiencies of 34.8 % and 30.4 % for the y- and x-polarized incident waves.

title: Physics-Informed Reinforcement Learning with Euler-Lagrange Constraints for Robotic Manipulation Optimization
authors: Sanjay Kumar K J, Sachin Saravanan, Kuberan Shivashankara, Hrithick E, Parvathy Vinod K V, Ramesh Kumar K, Pushparajan M
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper proposes a physics-informed reinforcement learning framework that integrates Euler-Lagrange dynamics constraints into robotic manipulation control. To address the challenge of maintaining physical consistency in contact-rich environments, the approach introduces three core innovations: a composite loss function that blends Proximal Policy Optimization objectives with torque-based regularization, a neural architecture featuring shared feature extractors with Exponential Linear Unit activations, and the use of genetic algorithms for hyperparameter tuning under physical stability constraints. The framework is implemented on a simulated robotic manipulator using NVIDIA Isaac Lab and demonstrates significantly improved convergence speed, higher task rewards, and enhanced dynamic consistency. The method also ensures accurate motion execution and stable contact behavior during complex manipulation tasks. Experimental evaluations highlight strong sim-to-real transfer capabilities, showcasing the potential of incorporating physics-based constraints to improve learning performance and reliability in robotic reinforcement learning.

title: System Identification of a Novel Amphibious Cycloidal Propeller Unmanned Underwater Vehicle
authors: Jonathan Lephuoc, Chenliang Zhang, David Coleman, Casey Harwood, Moble Benedict
abstract: The littoral zone presents several operational challenges for most unmanned underwater vehicles (UUVs) due to strong breaking waves, obstacles in the surf zone, and close proximity to land. A novel amphibious vehicle, the cycloidal propeller unmanned underwater vehicle (Cyclo-UUV), was designed and developed to help overcome these challenges. The vehicle features two parallel tracks for ground locomotion and four retractable cycloidal propellers (cyclo-propellers) for better agility, disturbance rejection, and controllability underwater than vehicles that utilize conventional screw propellers. Due to the uniqueness of the design, little is known about its natural dynamics. As such, this article presents an experimentally derived linear state-space dynamics model of the Cyclo-UUV in forward level motion. Manual inputs were provided to perturb the vehicle from steady-state conditions to excite the system modes. System identification programs for aircraft were used to extract the bare airframe dynamics of the Cyclo-UUV using least squares parameter estimation between the inputs and outputs. The longitudinal and lateral dynamics were found to be coupled and featured two oscillatory modes, one stable and one unstable. These results further our understanding of cyclo-propeller UUV dynamics, and can help with the development of robust model-based controllers for autonomous undersea operations.

title: Design and Modeling of an Interleaved Boost Converter with Partial Power Processing
authors: Iván A. Reyes-Portillo, Jorge A. Morales-Saldaña, Saúl R. Méndez-Elizondo, Aurelio Hernández-Rodríguez, Julián A. Hernández-Gallardo, Claudia A. Rivera-Romero
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This paper presents the design and analysis of an interleaved boost converter with Partial Power Processing, applied to direct current microgrids supplied by photovoltaic systems. The main contribution of this work lies in the integration of PPP into an interleaved boost converter topology to improve efficiency and power density. The development of an averaged model that enables dynamic analysis under constant power load conditions, and the application of the Volt–Ampere (VA) area modeling technique to quantify the fraction of processed power. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate reduced ripple, higher efficiency, and improved performance at low input voltages compared to a conventional boost converter. These results confirm the feasibility of the proposed converter as an interface for PV systems, DC buses, and battery banks in microgrid applications.

title: Electrolyte Level Sensor Based on Plastic Optical Fiber for Lead-Acid Batteries Applications
authors: Pedro Siqueira Neto, Thales H. Castro De Barros, Joaquim F. Martins-Filho, Henrique Patriota Alves
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents a computational modeling of a level sensor based on plastic optical fiber with holes for electrolyte volume measurements in lead-acid batteries. The model was implemented in COMSOL Multiphysics and allowed the design of a multipoint device with 10 sensor elements inserted in a single plastic optical fiber. The results obtained describe a sensor with linear behavior, with each sensor element capable of distinguishing changes in the refractive index of the external environment that indicate a reduction in the liquid level of the electrolyte solution.

title: Claro Colombia Customer Experience Patterns: Sentiment Analysis
authors: Juan Pablo Acosta Vasquez, Francy Rocío Castellanos Oviedo, Laura Valentina Garzón Arismendy
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: During the second quarter of 2024, Claro Colombia positioned itself as the market leader in terms of user numbers, with more than 589,000 new ports. However, this growth has not been matched by an improvement in service perception. On social media, users continue to report high levels of dissatisfaction, with frequent complaints about service quality, customer service, and network stability. Today more than ever, social media is a direct reflection of the customer experience. Users not only share their experiences but also shape the opinions of others. Ignoring these voices can mean losing the public's trust; however, listening to them and analyzing them strategically can make a difference in customer relationships. This work seeks precisely that: to understand what Claro Colombia users feel and think through the analysis of their comments on platforms such as Facebook, Threads and X. Applying artificial intelligence and sentiment analysis techniques, patterns and trends will be identified that allow generating useful information to make decisions aimed at improving the service, strengthening the brand's reputation and, above all, better connecting with the real needs of users. During the second quarter of 2024, Claro Colombia positioned itself as the market leader in terms of the number of users, with more than 589,000 new portings. However, this growth has not been accompanied by an improvement in the perception of the service. On social media, users continue to report high levels of dissatisfaction, with frequent complaints about the quality of service, customer service, and network stability.

title: Ethical Use of the ESP8266 for Teaching Wireless Network Threats
authors: Pablo Ospina Rodriguez, Andres Sanguino, Juan Gutierrez, Santiago Valdiri
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This project proposes the use of the ESP8266 microcontroller as a didactic tool to raise awareness and educate users about wireless network threats. Through controlled demonstrations of foundational network reconnaissance techniques-such as local device discovery and host port scanning-the project demonstrates vulnerabilities often overlooked by users. The low-cost device, easily programmable via the Arduino IDE, enables the recreation of the initial phases of a cyberattack in a safe educational environment. Technical validations demonstrated the prototype's high efficacy, achieving a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 5 \%}$</tex> discovery rate in local device scans and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 0 \%}$</tex> accuracy in identifying open ports. Furthermore, educational assessments confirmed its pedagogical impact, as post-workshop surveys revealed a 75-percentage-point increase in participants' awareness of network visibility. The project contributes to developing more critical and informed users, emphasizing that cybersecurity is not solely a professional concern, but a shared responsibility.

title: Analysis of Multimodal LLMs in VQA in the Field of Radiology
authors: Cristovão Pessoa Cândido Neto, Claúdio de Souza Baptista, André Luiz F. Alves, Vivek Swarnakar, Anselmo Cardoso de Paiva
abstract: The exponential growth in medical imaging volumes necessitates scalable, reliable diagnostic support systems capable of augmenting clinical workflows. This paper presents a systematic quantitative evaluation of state-of-the-art Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) for radiology Visual Question Answering (VQA), a task requiring integrated visual perception and clinical reasoning. We benchmark five leading models-GPT4o, Gemini 2.5 Pro, Qwen 2.5-VL (72B), LLaVA 13B, and Llama 3.2 Vision (90B)-on the VQA-RAD dataset under a rigorous zero-shot protocol with standardized prompts and comprehensive precision-recall-F1 evaluation. Our empirical analysis reveals that Gemini 2.5 Pro achieves superior balanced performance (F1 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.77$</tex>, Accuracy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.76$</tex>, Recall <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.81$</tex>), while Qwen 2.5-VL attains the highest precision (0.87) at the cost of reduced recall, exhibiting conservative prediction characteristics. These outcomes demonstrate that general-purpose MLLMs can perform competitively with specialized medical models in tasks such as modality and organ recognition but still struggle with abnormality detection and complex clinical reasoning. The findings reinforce that MLLMs currently serve best as assistive decision-support tools rather than autonomous diagnostic agents and highlight the potential of retrieval-augmented and context-aware strategies for improving clinical reliability and interpretability.

title: A Dynamic GPF Scheduler for 5G Hetnets Aided by Neural Networks and Differential Evolution
authors: Getúlio M. Resende, Gabriel A. Queiroz, André L. A. da Costa, Éderson R. da Silva
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: To achieve the desired 5G goals, a network must be efficient and fair simultaneously, allowing high data rates for regular users while also equally serving low-power users. Static schedulers, as the name implies, don't change their scheduling policy regardless of the number of users, giving rise to the need for dynamic schedulers that can shift this paradigm by sensing the number of network users and other parameters and changing the scheduling policy accordingly, raising network efficiency and fairness. Thus, this work presents an optimization technique that uses the Differential Evolution (DE) algorithm and, later, trains a feedforward Neural Network (NN) to mimic the DE's decisionmaking to act as a dynamic Generalized Proportional Fair (GPF), adapting its two internal parameters assuring a threshold fairness while seeking a throughput maximization in a simulated 5 G Heterogeneous Network (HetNet). Results show that the method achieves a minimal 0.7 Jain's fairness index for most numbers of users, from 40 to 200 users, while having a better average throughput when compared to a related scheduler. It was also noted that using the created dynamic NN scheduler added only 0.03% to 0.57% in simulation runtime compared to GPF.

title: Leakage Power and PDP Reduction in NAND Gates Using Modified Feedback Sleeper Stack (MFSS) Technique
authors: Vaduguru Sai Venu Satya Ramlalith, Thampula Kartheek, Shashi Tiwari
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: The continuous scaling of CMOS technologies has intensified the problem of leakage power in digital circuits, making low-power design techniques essential for energy-efficient VLSI systems. This paper investigates the application of the Modified Feedback Sleeper Stack (MFSS) technique in three-input NAND gates to suppress leakage power while maintaining performance across advanced technology nodes. A detailed comparison between conventional NAND gates and MFSS-enhanced designs is carried out for 180nm, 90nm, and 45nm CMOS processes. The study is performed in two phases: first, the baseline performance difference between standard and MFSS-based NAND gates is evaluated, and second, the effect of threshold voltage engineering is analyzed using Low-V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf>, High-V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf>, and Dual-V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf> configurations. Simulation results demonstrate that while High-V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf> transistors effectively reduce leakage, they introduce delay penalties, whereas the Dual-V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf> configuration provides the most balanced trade-off with notable improvements in power-delay product (PDP). The findings confirm that MFSS, particularly in Dual-V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf> mode, offers a scalable and robust low-power design methodology suitable for nanoscale VLSI applications where minimizing standby leakage is a critical requirement.

title: Novel Graphical Method for Uncovering Multiple Harmonic Mitigation Solutions at Ultra-Low Switching in Multilevel Inverters
authors: Sayantika Mukherjee, Pratik Kalkal, A. V. Ravi Teja
abstract: This article proposes a novel graphical technique for identifying several sets of switching angle solutions with the same fundamental to mitigate different harmonics in a cascaded H-bridge (CHB) multilevel inverter with ultra-low switching frequency at fixed dc input. This technique is then applied on a three-phase seven-level CHB inverter for mitigating 50 lower-order harmonics with the limitation of three switching angles each quarter cycle. This ensures that the switching frequency is the same as the fundamental frequency. Using this technique, it is demonstrated that in more than 45% region of the available range of modulation indices, with just fundamental switching frequency, a seven-level inverter can mitigate all harmonics from its output line voltage up to the 50th order within the 5% range according to the IEEE 519-2022 standard. Apart from this, more than 20% region also provides a total harmonic distortion below the 8% value. The results obtained from the proposed graphical analysis are verified in simulation using MATLAB/Simulink software as well as hardware using an FPGA-based experimental prototype developed in the laboratory. Typical results are provided with three, four, and five switching angles in seven-level, nine-level, and three-level multilevel inverters respectively to validate the findings.

title: A Robot-Led Intervention for Emotion Regulation: from Expression to Reappraisal_supp3-3657604.pdf
authors: Guy Laban
abstract: Emotion regulation (ER) is a crucial skill for managing emotions in everyday life, yet finding a constructive and accessible method to practice ER remains challenging due to cognitive demands. In this study, we explore how regular interactions with a social robot, conducted in a structured yet familiar environment within university halls and departments, can provide effective support for practising ER via cognitive reappraisal. Twenty-one students participated in a five-session study at a university hall or department in the U.K., where the robot (QTrobot, LuxAI), powered by a large language model (GPT 3.5) facilitated structured conversations, encouraging the students to reinterpret emotionally charged situations that they shared with the robot. Quantitative and qualitative results indicate significant improvements in ER, with participants reporting better understanding and control of their emotions, significant changes in constructive ER tendencies and positive effects on mood and sentiment after each session. The findings also demonstrate that repeated interactions with the robot encouraged greater emotional expression, including longer speech disclosures, increased use of affective language, and heightened facial arousal. Notably, expression peaked during key reappraisal moments, particularly when participants were prompted to reinterpret negative experiences. The qualitative feedback further highlighted how the robot fostered introspection and provided a supportive space for discussing emotions, enabling participants to confront long-avoided emotional challenges. These findings demonstrate the potential of robots to effectively assist in ER in familiar environments, offering both emotional support and cognitive guidance

title: TK-Patch: Universal Top-K Adversarial Patches for Cross-Model Person Evasion
authors: Saad Imran, Syed M. Kazam Abbas Kazmi, M Umair Raza, Fahim Maan, Nayyer Aafaq
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Physical adversarial attacks have received increasing attention for their potential to deceive deep neural network–based perception systems. Among these, adversarial patches (printed perturbations) placed on clothing or objects have gained increasing attention, as they can modify person-detection models output while remaining visually inconspicuous. However, most existing methods target single models and often fail to maintain effectiveness across different detectors or physical transformations commonly encountered in surveillance settings. In our research, we introduced a universal adversarial Top-K Patch (TK-Patch), optimized to deceive multiple person detectors YOLOv3, YOLOv5, and YOLOv7 using a unified model-agnostic framework. Instead of relying on internal model access, TK-Patch leverages common objectness outputs and a Top-K loss strategy to guide optimization. The patch is trained using the labels from PASCAL-VOC and INRIA datasets and then made robust for handling varying lighting conditions, viewing distances and camera angles. To test the patches physically by printing it on a matte photo paper and to mimic real world deployment. The experiments shows a attack success of 85-90% across all the tested models, highlighting the success of our TK-patch and the feasibility of constructing a transferable physical adversarial patch attacks against the modern detectors.

title: Lipid profile, atherogenic index, and anthropometric-based models for detecting type 2 diabetes in Mexican adults: a non-glycemic diagnostic alternative
authors: M. Hazael Guerrero-Flores, Valeria Maeda-Gutiérrez, Miguel Cruz, Luis Alberto Flores-Chaires, Carlos E. Galván-Tejada, Jorge I. Galvan-Tejada
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Type 2 diabetes (T2D) represents a priority in Mexican public health due to its high prevalence and associated complications. Currently, diagnosis is primarily based on glycemic biomarkers such as plasma glucose, insulin, and the HOMA-IR index, which reflect metabolic alterations in advanced stages. This study aims to assess the capability of classifying individuals with T2D using lipid profiles and machine learning, while primarily excluding glucose-associated biomarkers. Anthropometric measurements are incorporated into the lipid profile to explore their potential contribution to diagnosis. Various classification algorithms were trained and validated, including Logistic Regression (LR), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), and XGBoost. Exploratory statistical analyses and feature selection techniques were performed, as well as the evaluation and calculation of derived atherogenic indices such as TG/HDL and AIP. The results showed that the SVM model achieved the best overall performance, with an accuracy of 85.2%, an F1-score of 0.853, a precision of 85.1%, and an AUC value of 0.916. The RF and XGBoost models achieved sensitivities above 88%, with AUC values of 0.934 and 0.930, respectively, indicating their ability to identify patients with T2D accurately. These findings demonstrate that lipid profiles, in combination with non-glycemic features, can serve as an accessible and low-cost alternative to support the automated diagnosis of T2D, particularly in resource-constrained settings.

title: Improving Stability of GFL Inverter in Weak Grid using Paralleled GFM Inverter: Hardware Validation
authors: H R Sai Kiran Pandit, Sarasij Das
abstract: The penetration of inverter-based renewable energy resources (IBRs), like solar and wind, into the power grid is rapidly increasing. The inverters that are used for connecting the IBRs to the power grid can be broadly classified as grid following (GFL) and grid forming (GFM) inverters. However, most of the existing inverters in the renewable energy plants are of GFL type. GFL inverters use phase-locked loops (PLLs) to synchronize to the power grid, whereas GFM inverters don’t need a PLL to stay synchronized to the grid. In the existing literature, it has been shown that the GFL inverters face stability issues in the weak grid, as the PLLs can go out of synchronization with the grid. In this paper, the authors provide power hardware-based experimental results on the stability improvement of a GFL inverter in a weak grid. The power hardware results show that the addition of a GFM inverter in parallel with the GFL inverter which is not stable in a weak grid, stabilizes the GFL after the addition. PSCAD simulation results also support the experimental observations.

title: Assessment of Traveling-Wave Fault Location in Non-Homogeneous Feeders Terminated in Multiple Cable-Fed Transformers
authors: W. Fernandes, T. Alhussain, A. Almutairi, W. Khardawi
abstract: This paper examines the single-ended and double-ended traveling wave fault location algorithms applied to 230 kV non-homogenous feeders that includes 90 km of submarine cable. A second feeder is connected in parallel, and both feed an offshore gas-insulated substation that further supplies nine short-length cable-fed power transformers. The system is modelled using an electromagnetic transient simulation software, which generates current and voltage waveforms with 1 MHz sampling rate in COMTRADE format. These waveforms are played back in fault locator devices, having built-in capability to replay the COMTRADE event file, eliminating the need for external test equipment. Results demonstrate that fault locations are accurately and reliably determined across all scenarios considered in the study.

title: An Analytical Review of Image Segmentation Techniques & Logo Detection
authors: Somnath Bhaskarrao Lavhate, Vishal Borate, Priyanka Nalawade, Sakshi Rajendra Gulhane, Kavyaa Jaiswal, Khushi Chouhan
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Image segmentation is a basic method that includes partitioning an image into meaningful components. Content-based image retrieval, robotics, medical imaging, and self-driving cars are just a few of the fields in which they find use. Over the past several years, numerous segmentation methods have been developed, each with its own set of benefits, drawbacks, and uses. Deep learning and traditional methods are two different types of image segmentation. Region-based techniques, thresholding, edge detection, and clustering fall under the traditional method. Deep learning has revolutionized the field with convolutional neural networks. Multilevel thresholding is among the strongest image segmentation techniques for grayscale and color images with complicated intensity distributions. By selecting many optimal threshold values, multilevel thresholding segments an image into several regions. To find optimal threshold values, optimization algorithms have been used. Otsu and Kapur methods are familiar methods for multilevel thresholding segments. The Kapur algorithm maximizes the entropy of each segmented area thus creating a more homogeneous distribution of pixel values in each category. The given paper gives an in-depth assessment and comparison of the various approaches to segmentation through the integration of optimization approaches into multilevel thresholding systems. We use related quantitative measures, such as PSNR, VOI, FSIM, SSIM and entropy, to compare the performance of multilevel thresholding by Kapurs criterion with other optimization methods including Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA) Moth Flame Optimization (MFO) Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) Jaya Algorithm (JA) Artificial Bee Colony Optimization (ABC) and other optimization methods and discuss results. The study reveals the improvement of the quality of segmentation and efficiency of computations using optimization techniques.

title: Optimization of User Distance in STAR-RIS-Assisted NOMA Random Networks Using Supervised Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Nguyen Thi Yen Linh, Pham Ngoc Son, Vo Nguyen Quoc Bao
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper investigates the downlink performance of non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) random networks empowered by simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (STAR-RIS), which allow wireless signals to be both reflected and transmitted concurrently. We first derive the outage probability (OP) for transmission and reflection users over Rician fading channels. To further improve network reliability, a supervised deep learning (SDL) framework is introduced to predict user distances and transmission power, thereby guaranteeing OP constraints and fulfilling the stringent requirements of ultra-reliable low-latency communications (uRLLCs). Analytical and simulation results show a strong consistency, demonstrating that the proposed SDL scheme achieves substantial reductions in computational complexity and execution time compared with conventional approaches.

title: The Sustainability Card: Measuring Sustainability of Multimedia AI Models
authors: Francesco Pistolesi, Michele Baldassini, Matteo Mugnai, Beatrice Lazzerini
abstract: Multimedia AI now characterizes multiple concurrent streams at high resolutions, spanning video, audio, language, and multimodal fusion. Energy, bandwidth, and even water for cooling have become first-order constraints for real deployments. Training a single large NLP model has been estimated to emit up to 284 tons of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>, while infrastructure and model choices can shift emissions by orders of magnitude; at the same time, data centers consume huge volumes of water for cooling (hundreds of thousands). In this position paper, we argue that we cannot continue to choose models based on accuracy and throughput alone. We propose a Sustainability Card for Multimedia AI—Correct Outputs per kWh, Joules per Sample, Bytes per Output, and optional Water per 1,000 Outputs —and outline a simple measurement protocol.

title: Cost-Optimal Design of Hybrid Broadcast—Unicast Video Delivery Systems
authors: Yuriy A. Reznik
abstract: This paper investigates the cost-optimal design of a hybrid video distribution system that includes broadcast and unicast delivery networks. Broadcast costs are modeled based on the total bandwidth of all broadcasted channels, while unicast costs are based on the total edge traffic generated by users accessing unicast-delivered content. Using these models, we derive an expression for the system's overall operating cost and formulate an optimization problem to minimize it. Subsequently, we derive an analytical solution that reveals the lowest achievable cost, enables comparisons between hybrid and purely broadcast or unicast architectures, and explains the effects of key system parameters on the attainable operating cost. To validate our approach, we perform a numerical study using real-world TV channel audience statistics and realistic cost metrics for both delivery modes. The results confirm our theoretical findings.

title: Convex-Hull of Locational Marginal Carbon Emission for Carbon Management Considering Emissions during Non-Steady-State Operation Hours
authors: Zelong Lu, Lei Yan, Zuyi Li, Yunpeng Xiao, Mohammad Shahidehpour, Xifan Wang
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy, while essential for decarbonization, can intensify thermal-unit cycling and ramping, aggravate network congestion, and increase emissions during non-steady-state operating periods (i.e., start-ups, shutdowns, and fast ramping). Research indicates that carbon emissions during such hours could increase to 2–6 times those of steady-state operation hours. However, conventional studies often ignore the impact of intertemporal constraints on carbon measurements, leading to significant underestimation of carbon emission. To address this gap, this paper extends the locational marginal carbon emission (LMCE) framework by incorporating non-steady-state hours emissions through a convex-hull-based variant of LMCE (i.e., LMCE2) model. This approach clarifies the endogenous link between nodal prices and carbon intensity and ensures theoretical consistency between electricity pricing and carbon emission calculation. The LMCE2 can be efficiently computed using the Dantzig–Wolfe decomposition. We further derive LACE2 that mitigates carbon over-allocation. Our case studies demonstrate that rapid emission assessment during non-steady-state operation hours using LMCE2/LACE2, enables more trustworthy carbon accounting. Compared with traditional LMCE/LACE, the use of LMCE2/LACE2 reduces carbon measurement error by 83.5%–90.1%. The proposed framework offers practical tools for carbon management in electricity markets with high renewable shares.

title: Low Area Overhead Modified Reconfigurable Duplication for Multi-Die FPGA-based Space Applications
authors: Yosof Maklad, Hassan M. Hassan, Ramez M. Daoud, Hassanein H. Amer, Gehad I. Alkady, Dina G. Mahmoud
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper focuses on SRAM-based Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) systems in space applications. These systems are vulnerable to Single Event Upsets (SEUs) which can lead to catastrophic failures. Fault tolerance is often used to mitigate these effects; however, this may require redundant components. If these components require relatively high FPGA resources, replicating them may not be feasible. Therefore, this paper proposes a fault-tolerant architecture based on the reconfigurable duplication one in the literature, which only requires one extra copy of the module. Using the multi-die technology, where the effect of SEUs is different on each die, a modified reconfigurable duplication architecture is proposed, requiring less area resources than the conventional one. Using Continuous Time Markov Chains (CTMCs), it is proven that, according to the system parameters, the proposed architecture may have a higher reliability than the conventional one. Furthermore, it is shown that the failure rate of one of the two redundant modules does not affect architecture reliability. The coverage of the error detection mechanism is also investigated, and it is shown that a small change in its value may have a significant effect on reliability.

title: DEGA: Dynamic Entropy Guided Adaptation
authors: Minh-Loi Duong, Minh-Duc Huynh, Thai-Son Tran, Thanh-Dat Truong, Khoa Luu
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Test-Time Adaptation (TTA) addresses the challenge of adapting a pre-trained model from a source distribution to a target distribution without requiring retraining, access to source data, or labeled target samples. Existing state-of-the-art TTA methods often rely on backward updates involving gradient computation, which incur additional training time and computational costs. Moreover, sample noise and the reality of micro-batch inference, where only a few images are available at a time, limit the model's ability to capture distributions. To overcome these obstacles, we propose a new backwardfree approach named Dynamic Entropy Guided Adaptation (DEGA). Our method combines two modules: the Distribution Adaptation Module prior Entropy (DAM-E), which updates batch normalization statistics using the mean entropy of initial predictions, and the Semantic Adaptation Module prior Entropy (SAM-E), which utilizes an entropy-based mask to select confident pixels for proto-type construction, guiding inference. We evaluate DEGA by adapting models pre-trained on GTA and SYNTHIA across five target domains, achieving strong performance without retraining or access to the source data. Source code is available at minhloi0901/DEGA.

title: Agent-Based Simulation of Tensile Testing of Metallic Materials: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Andres Camilo Pacheco Becerra, Cristian Fernando Romero Prada, Alexander Guerrero-Avendaño, Dewar Rico-Bautista
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: Digital simulation methods are transforming engineering education, offering accessible alternatives to practices traditionally dependent on physical resources. In the field of strength of materials, tensile testing—defined as a standardized method used to assess the response of materials under uniaxial tensile load—is essential for characterizing the mechanical behavior of metals, but its implementation in academic settings faces challenges such as excessive costs, equipment limitations, and irreversible sample destruction. Recent studies suggest that agent-based simulation models can mitigate these obstacles, although questions remain regarding their pedagogical effectiveness, technological evolution, and methodological rigor. Through a literature review, it is demonstrated that simulation models significantly improve the conceptual understanding of tensile testing by 35% compared to traditional methods, while reducing dependence on physical laboratories without compromising accuracy. These findings redefine the potential of simulations in engineering education, not only as logistical solutions but also as pedagogical tools that democratize access to experiential learning. The review proposes a framework for future research, highlighting the need to standardize quantitative assessments and evaluate socioaffective dimensions to integrate these types of simulations into academic curricula where infrastructure limit practical experiences.

title: Using Quantization Aware Training Technique to Enhance Performance of Deep Learning Model for ADAS System
authors: Dinh-Duy Phan, Anh-Tiep Bui, Thi-Thanh-Dung Tran, Van-Hoai Tran, Duc-Lung Vu
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper presents a real-time traffic monitoring system leveraging Quantization Aware Training (QAT) with INT8 precision for efficient deployment. The system integrates YOLOv8 for traffic sign recognition running on a single platform. It identifies traffic signs based on Vietnam's QCVN 41:2019/BGTVT standard, detects four categories of vehicles. Designed for on-vehicle installation, the system processes 2D images or video, offering a scalable solution for intelligent transportation applications with optimized performance and accuracy.

title: Impact of Different Current Limiting Strategies on Stable Power Swing Trajectories in Grid-Forming Converter–Integrated Power System
authors: Balabhaskar S. S., Sreenath B., Manas Kumar Jena
abstract: The extensive integration of inverter-based resources (IBRs) into the power grid challenges the traditional power sys-tem relaying philosophies. Grid-Forming Converters (GFMs), by emulating the dynamic characteristics of synchronous generators (SGs) and providing grid-support functionalities, have emerged as a promising solution for grid integration. GFMs are equipped with advanced control schemes that include current limiters that may impact how GFMs respond during grid disturbances. The study focuses on the impact of GFM current limiters on the impedance trajectory during power swing. Simulation tests conducted in PSCAD using the modified IEEE 9 bus system reveal that different current limiter methods have distinct impact on the impedance trajectory. Consequently, power swing detection may be affected depending on the type of current limiter used in the GFM control and whether the limiters are activated during a disturbance. These insights would be fruitful for future research in developing source-agnostic power-swing blocking or protection strategies.

title: Addressing Infeasibilities in SCED in India - Big M Penalty and System Marginal Price Distortion: A Practical Guide
authors: Debasis De, Abishek R. S, Saumen Majumdar, S. K. Soonee, Deb Chattopadhyay
abstract: Infeasibility is a persistent challenge in Security-Constrained Economic Dispatch (SCED), especially in systems with high renewable variability, tight ramping constraints, and operational complexities. This paper examines the mathematical basis, physical interpretation, and cost implications of infeasibility, drawing insights from India’s national SCED pilot. The Big M method, commonly used to maintain model feasibility through penalized constraint relaxation, is analyzed along with its impact on system marginal price (SMP), potential distortions, and calibration practices. Alternative approaches such as graded penalties and dual variable analysis are discussed as more robust methods to identify and manage constraint violations. Case studies demonstrate that infeasibilities often signal deeper structural gaps, limited ramping flexibility, congestion, or data errors. Pilot results show that even modest violations can escalate system costs and distort market signals. The paper recommends best practices in model design, penalty setting, and regulatory alignment to improve SCED outcomes, emphasizing its dual role as both an operational tool and investment diagnostic.

title: Simulink-Based Modeling of Regenerative Braking with Energy Recovery Optimization for Electric Vehicles
authors: Sadia Begum, Ujwala Gajula, Gouthami Eragamreddy, Remala Geshma Kumari
abstract: Every chance to increase the battery charging is essential to improve the battery charging; this research paper provides an exploration about regenerative braking systems (RBS) in electric vehicles. The motor used in an electric vehicle works as a motor and generator when the reversal of energy supply is made as per the fundamental principles of vehicle operations. In this paper regenerative braking is designed, and the same is developed using MATLAB/Simulink to show the energy restoration and recovery. Results after simulation show the improvement of battery SOC up to 25% due to the usage of regenerative braking. In the study in a real-world context, examples from leading manufacturers such as Tesla and Toyota are examined. Implementation of regenerative braking improves the efficiency of the system both economically and environmentally.

title: Advancing Coral Reef Bathymetry: A GAN-Augmented and Stratified CNN analysis of fused ICESat-2 and Sentinel-2 dataset
