authors: Ziyao Chen, Li Wang, Wei Feng, Yan Gu, Jin Li, Ya Ping Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: High-resolution bathymetry mapping of coral reef is essential to morphodynamical studies of reef habitats, assisting reef monitoring and conservation under global climate change. However, accuracy of conventional satellite-derived bathymetry is reduced at depth over 15 m with optical signal attenuation and training data insufficiency. To address this gap, here, we present an approach that synergizes ICESat-2 ATL24 photon-counting lidar data with Sentinel-2 multispectral imagery. A generative adversarial network (GAN) is implemented to offset dataset deficiency at deeper depths and a stratified convolutional neural network (CNN) is adapted to distinct optical-depth regimes. Bathymetry derived at Jiuzhang Atoll is in good agreement with the in-situ multibeam measurements with a mean absolute error of 0.75 m and a root-mean-square-error of 10% of the present maximum depth of 19 m, validating the effectiveness of GAN-driven sample synthesis to make up measurement inadequacy, and the enhancement of model generalizability across a wide depth range by stratified CNN. This approach could be applied to bathymetry mapping of coral reefs worldwide at depths of 15-30 m where biodiversity generally increases to the most with multi-source satellite observations.

title: Influence of Humidity Variation on Textile Substrates for Microstrip Antennas
authors: Alexandre Maia Gomes Chaves, Samanta M. de Holanda, Humberto D. de Andrade, Isaac B. T. da Silva, Idalmir de S. Q., Leonardo O. de Sousa
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: The growing demand for efficient wearable sensors drives the study of new materials and structures for applications in textile electronics. This work investigates how humidity impacts the electromagnetic properties of microstrip antennas with textile substrate. Aiming at its use as a humidity sensor in hospital environments, polyester fabric was chosen as the substrate, which is one of the most widely used in the area. The analysis is based on the variation of the electrical permittivity of the textile material at different humidity levels. Using the HFSS software, an antenna with the same textile substrate was simulated, but with electrical permittivity and loss tangent values changed according to three stages of the fabric: dry, intermediate and completely wet. The results showed that increasing humidity increases the electrical permittivity of the substrate, resulting in a reduction in the resonance frequency (from 3.5 GHz to 1.6 GHz) and antenna gain (from 7.4 dB to -25 dB). This confirms the potential of microstrip antennas with textile substrate as humidity sensors for applications in the medical field, with the possibility of integration into wearable systems. Furthermore, it highlights the importance of complementary studies on the dielectric behavior of textile materials and the optimization of antenna geometry for different applications.

title: Tensor-Based Ant Colony Optimization for Set Meal Design in Online-to-Offline Restaurants_supp1-3656946.pdf
authors: Wei-Jie Yu
abstract: Set meal design (SMD) for online-to-offline (O2O) restaurant services presents a complex optimization problem, requiring the simultaneous satisfaction of diverse customer preferences, operational constraints, and profit maximization objective. To address this challenge, this article proposes a comprehensive mathematical formulation for the O2O-SMD problem. This formulation integrates complex operational requirements, such as dish variety, pricing, nutritional balance, and profitability, into a unified optimization problem with well-defined objective and constraints. To efficiently solve the O2O-SMD problem, we propose a tensor-based ant colony optimization (TACO) algorithm. Distinct from traditional ant colony optimization (ACO) variants, the core of TACO lies in reformulating the fundamental ACO operations into a tensor computational structure, enabling parallel optimization over O2O-SMD tasks at the algorithmic level. Furthermore, a dedicated local search strategy is integrated to refine solutions and accelerate convergence of the algorithm. The performance of TACO is evaluated on real-world restaurant data and benchmark instances. The experimental results show that TACO significantly outperforms a wide range of comparison algorithms in terms of solution quality, scalability, and computational efficiency, confirming its effectiveness and practical value for real-world O2O-SMD problems.

title: An Optimized Machine Learning Approach to Robust and Scalable Face Recognition
authors: Duong T. T. Tran, Minh N. T. Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: In real-world settings, facial recognition systems frequently suffer reduced accuracy because of changes in lighting, the use of glasses, and obstructions such as protective masks. This study proposes a lightweight, interpretable framework that leverages geometric facial keypoints and support vector machine classification to enhance recognition robustness in such challenging conditions. Two specialized pipelines were developed: one optimized for clear, lowlight, and glasses scenarios, and another designed for mask-induced occlusion using upper-face landmarks. Evaluation on a six-participant dataset revealed that both models achieved accuracy rates approaching 90 %, confirming the practicality of SVM landmark techniques for robust face recognition across unconstrained and masked settings.

title: Contrastive Learning Enhanced Transfer Framework for Fault Diagnosis of Aerospace Electromechanical Systems
authors: Hejun Cheng, Diyin Tang, Danyang Han
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Fault diagnosis of aerospace electromechanical systems in orbit faces the dual challenges of data scarcity and domain discrepancy. To address this problem, a contrastive learning enhanced transfer framework is proposed. Large-scale general bearing data are employed for self-supervised pretraining to obtain transferable representations, which are then adapted with a limited number of labeled CMG samples. The model is subsequently validated on in-orbit CMG data under real operating conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method substantially improves diagnostic performance compared with traditional approaches, achieving a relative gain of about 24.1 %. These findings highlight the effectiveness of integrating contrastive learning with transfer learning to overcome small-sample and crossdomain challenges, and provide a feasible pathway for in-orbit health management of aerospace electromechanical systems.

title: How Data Quality Helps Marine Activities Using a Mobile App
authors: Sarita Rincon, Leyder Poveda, John Velandia Vega, Holman Diego Bolivar
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: In collaboration with the Dirección General Marítima (Dimar) and the Universidad Católica de Colombia, the Navega Seguro mobile application was developed to provide access to oceanographic and marine meteorology data in Colombia. Designed for navigators, maritime authorities, and tourists, it offers information on sea conditions, winds, sunlight, and atmospheric pressure to ensure safety in coastal activities. Issues with data quality, such as outdated meteorological bulletins and incomplete station information, were identified. To address these, improvements focusing on accuracy, integrity, and reliability were proposed. Using Participatory Action Research (PAR) methodology, the problems were thoroughly investigated, and twenty-three user stories were documented with prioritized enhancements. Eleven user stories were selected for a sixteen-week development period, focusing on station listing, station details, and user registration modules. Post-implementation, functional and usability tests confirmed the effectiveness of the adjustments, ensuring the precision and reliability of the application. These enhancements enable users to make informed and safe decisions for maritime activities, promoting trust and continuous use, thus contributing to a secure maritime environment in Colombia.

title: Towards the Implementation of a Quantum Internet in Recife
authors: Leonardo Didier Coelho, Joaquim F. Martins-Filho, Daniel Felinto
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: The Quantum Internet has emerged as a key technological frontier, promising to transform secure communications and distributed quantum computing. This paper presents ongoing efforts toward the implementation of a metropolitan quantum network in Recife, Brazil. We first introduce the conceptual framework of the Quantum Internet, highlighting the role of entanglement, quantum repeaters, and quantum memories in overcoming channel losses. The architecture of the Recife Quantum Network is then described, including optical fiber connections between multiple academic institutions and the integration of cold rubidium ensembles as photon-pair sources and quantum memories. Furthermore, we discuss the potential of hybrid photonic quantum processors to enable advanced functionalities such as quantum teleportation and cluster-state-based protocols for all-optical quantum repeaters. Finally, we outline immediate applications, with emphasis on quantum key distribution, and provide perspectives for scaling up toward a city-wide Quantum Internet.

title: Flexible and Multifunctional Graphene Based Ecoflex Sensor for Radial Artery Pulse Detection
authors: Rizwan Zahoor, Babar Ali, Ghulam Murtaza, Hafiz Muhammad Bilal, Muhammad Ishfaq, Faisal Tufail
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: In this work, a convenient, simple, scalable and portable sensor is designed and fabricated to detect the artery pulse for effective human health examination. The core sensing material consists of a Graphene Oxide Layer on a flexible substrate, ECOFLEX, which exhibits excellent sensitivity and performance against the tensile force. With this pulse detection sensor, the precise and accurate measurements of the periodic artery pulse signal and the fluctuations produced in the signal due to disease become repeatable. In conclusion, a single signal is obtained that approximately contains all the important parameters required in medical analysis, from which a cardiovascular risk factor can be detected for home health care, medication, and prevention of disease.

title: GLOFNet- A Multimodal Dataset for GLOF Monitoring and Prediction
authors: Zuha Fatima, Muhammad Anser Sohaib, Muhammad Talha, Sidra Sultana, Ayesha Kanwal, Nazia Perwaiz
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Glacial Lake Outburst Floods (GLOFs) are rare but destructive hazards in high mountain regions, yet predictive research is hindered by fragmented and unimodal data. Most prior efforts emphasize post-event mapping, whereas forecasting requires harmonized datasets that combine visual indicators with physical precursors. We present GLOFNet, a multimodal dataset for GLOF monitoring and prediction, focused on the Shisper Glacier in the Karakoram. It integrates three complementary sources: Sentinel-2 multispectral imagery for spatial monitoring, NASA ITS_LIVE velocity products for glacier kinematics, and MODIS Land Surface Temperature records spanning over two decades. Preprocessing included cloud masking, quality filtering, normalization, temporal interpolation, augmentation, and cyclical encoding, followed by harmonization across modalities. Exploratory analysis reveals seasonal glacier velocity cycles, long-term warming of ~0.8 K per decade, and spatial heterogeneity in cryospheric conditions. The resulting dataset, GLOFNet, is publicly available to support future research in glacial hazard prediction. By addressing challenges such as class imbalance, cloud contamination, and coarse resolution, GLOFNet provides a structured foundation for benchmarking multimodal deep learning approaches to rare hazard prediction.

title: Hybrid Convolutional–Bidirectional LSTM Model for Intrusion Detection in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Cyber-Physical Networks
authors: Tharunkumar E, Deepika G, Faseela M H, Manjith Baby Sarojam Chellam
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly deployed in applications ranging from surveillance to logistics, but their integration into cyber-physical systems exposes them to diverse cyber and physical intrusions. Traditional intrusion detection systems (IDS) often fail to capture both spatial and temporal dependencies in UAV telemetry, and they struggle with class imbalance and deployment constraints. To address these challenges, we propose a hybrid IDS based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) networks. The CNN layers extract low-level spatial representations from UAV communication data, while BiLSTM layers model long-range temporal dependencies. To mitigate class imbalance, Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) and a class-weighted cross-entropy loss were employed. Experimental evaluation on a multi-class UAV intrusion dataset demonstrates that the proposed model achieves a test accuracy of 94.09% and a macro-F1 score of 0.94, outperforming prior IDS architectures on minority attack classes. Furthermore, the model shows potential for edge deployment with low latency and a compact memory footprint, making it suitable for FPGA/SoC implementations. Future work will extend this framework to federated and swarm-based UAV intrusion detection systems, ensuring robust and scalable protection in dynamic UAV networks.

title: Sign Language Interpreter using Machine Learning
authors: Umar Nawaz, Moeez Amir, Hassaan Ahmad, Nabeel Khalid, Faiza Ghulam Nabi
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Communication barriers for the deaf community in Pakistan, where Pakistan Sign Language (PSL) lacks technological support, present a significant challenge. This paper introduces a real-time PSL Interpreter that translates five specific PSL sentences and invalid gestures using a Convolutional Neural Network-Long Short-Term Memory (CNN-LSTM) model. Utilizing TensorFlow and MediaPipe, the system achieves 94.27 percent training accuracy and 100 percent validation accuracy on a dataset of 150 samples. The methodology includes video capture, hand landmark extraction, preprocessing with smoothing and speed features, and temporal sequence modeling. Real-time inference provides text and speech output, demonstrating a cost-effective, accessible solution. The work contributes to inclusive communication, with future potential for expanded vocabulary and diverse signer datasets.

title: Physics Informed Deep Learning for Error Compensation of Vibration Signals
authors: Dmitrij Filenko, Alexander Hetznecker, Thomas Greiner
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: This paper presents a physics informed artificial intelligence approach for reducing the dynamic error of a sensor, which receives vibration signals. Therefore, a two-stage process is proposed, which employs in the first step a Deep Neural Network (DNN) as an autoencoder which is pre-trained to the sensor's physical forward dynamics. In the second step a deep learning algorithm iteratively reconstructs the vibration signal by adapting the previously defined underlying deep neural network weights. A case study is carried out by the analysis of a disturbed piezoelectric acceleration sensor signal. The validation results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly reduces dynamic error and outperforms the most common deep learning approach.

title: A Further Study on Terminal Sliding Mode Control for Nonlinear Systems
authors: Zhe Sun, Zhipeng Li, Bo Chen, Yuan Zhou, Jinchuan Zheng, Zhihong Man
abstract: In this paper, a unified terminal sliding mode (UTSM) control method is proposed for second-order nonlinear systems with uncertainties and disturbances. It is seen that the newly defined terminal sliding surface is integrated with both conventional and fast terminal sliding mode and exhibits design advantages such as a variable exponent, adjustable sliding mode parameters, and chattering-alleviation effect. The inherent dynamic properties of the closed-loop systems with the UTSM control are discussed in detail via the phase plane and Lyapunov stability theory. Both numerical simulations and experimental results show the flexible sliding manifold design, strong robustness against uncertain dynamics, and effective attenuation of chattering phenomenon.

title: A Novel Deep Learning Framework for Enhanced Multispectral Palm-Print Recognition
authors: Poonam Poonia
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This paper presents a novel deep learning framework designed for high-performance multispectral palm-print recognition. Our methodology leverages a multi-channel Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture to extract robust and highly discriminative features from distinct spectral bands, including Blue, Green, Red, and Near-Infrared. We then employ a weighted-sum score-level fusion technique to integrate the individual matching scores from each channel, capitalizing on the complementary strengths of both surface and subsurface palm characteristics. The proposed system is rigorously evaluated using the publicly available PolyU Contact-based and Multispectral Palm-print Databases. Our experimental results demonstrate a significant leap in performance, achieving a state-of-the-art Equal Error Rate (EER) of 0.01% on the contact-based dataset and an exceptional 0.005% on the multispectral dataset, which surpasses both conventional and prior deep learning-based methods.

title: Design of Wideband Multilayered Dielectric Resonator Antenna
authors: S.B. Vasconcellos, K. Z. Nobrega, Pei Xiao, Arismar Cerqueira S.
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents a wideband multilayered rectangular dielectric resonator antenna (RDRA) designed for millimeter-wave applications. The proposed structure employs a stacked configuration of ceramic and polymer dielectric materials to achieve broadband impedance matching and efficient excitation of multiple resonant modes. The antenna operates over a wide frequency range from 17 to 32 GHz, corresponding to a 61% fractional bandwidth centered at 24.7 GHz. At this frequency, a realized gain of 6.2 dBi is obtained, with a peak gain of 9.3 dBi observed at 26.2 GHz. Parametric optimization using ANSYS HFSS is focused on probe height, feed strip dimensions, and the air gap. The final design exhibits directive radiation patterns in the elevation plane, omnidirectional behavior in the azimuth plane, and negligible sidelobes. Simulated electric field distributions confirm the excitation of the TE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">121</inf> and TE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">131</inf> modes, with significant field confinement within the polymer layers attributed to the smooth dielectric transition. These findings highlight the potential of the proposed RDRA for integration into broadband, high-frequency communication systems.

title: Quantifying Panchakarma Therapy Efficacy through Cross Recurrence Quantification Analysis of Cardiorespiratory Dynamics
authors: Vivek Ranjan, Rohit Sane, Raghuwansh Singh, Anindita Ganguly, Suman Halder
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: This study investigates the effects of a 7-day Panchakarma therapy on cardiorespiratory coordination by applying Cross Recurrence Quantification Analysis (CRQA), a non-linear dynamical systems method. The objective was to quantitatively assess therapy-induced changes in the complex, high-dimensional dynamics of the cardiorespiratory system using a nonlinear computational framework. An observational study was conducted with 30 patients diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and hypertension. Electrocardiogram (ECG) and respiratory signals were acquired before (day 1) and after the therapy (day 7). After a rigorous preprocessing pipeline, state-space reconstruction was performed using time-delay embedding, with parameters optimized via Average Mutual Information and False Nearest Neighbors algorithms. Cross-recurrence plots were generated from the synchronized signals, and 6 CRQA metrics were computed to quantify the system’s dynamical properties. Statistical significance was assessed using Wilcoxon signed-rank tests on $\mathbf{1, 8 0 0}$ paired observations. CRQA revealed a significant restructuring of cardiorespiratory dynamics post-therapy. Key findings include a significant decrease in Recurrence Period Density Entropy (RPDE) ($\mathbf{p}\lt0.001$), indicating a reduction in complexity and an increase in regularity. Concurrently, significant increases in the longest diagonal (Lmax, $\mathrm{p}\lt0.001$) and vertical (Vmax, $\mathrm{p}\lt0.001$) line lengths were observed, signaling enhanced stability and longer periods of sustained coordination. The application of CRQA successfully decoded the subtle, positive impact of Panchakarma therapy on autonomic regulation. This work establishes a novel computational framework at the intersection of CRQA and integrative medicine, demonstrating how advanced nonlinear methods can objectively quantify the efficacy of complex therapeutic interventions, paving the way for data-driven personalized healthcare.

title: TriNetDerm:An Ensemble Deep Learning Framework for Robust Skin Cancer Classification
authors: Sayantani Das, Nitu Saha, Pranati Mondal, Sumit Mondal, Dwaipyan Ghosh, Sneha Pramanik, Swapnendu Biswas, Sohini Patra, Singhan Ganguly, Chinmoy Ghorai
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Skin cancer is one of the most prevalent and severe diseases worldwide, making early and accurate detection critical. Here, we present a deep learning-based approach for classifying skin cancer images with improved accuracy. We experimented with several well-known architectures, including ResNet50, EfficientNetB0, and InceptionV3, both individually and in various ensemble configurations. Our final model combines ResNet50, EfficientNetB0, and a custom Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) into a hybrid ensemble, leveraging pre-trained networks alongside task-specific features. Key metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score were used to evaluate the system. Findings indicate that the hybrid ensemble outperformed individual models and other ensemble combinations, achieving 92% accuracy while maintaining balanced performance across all metrics. These results demonstrate that ensemble deep learning can enhance diagnostic reliability and support automated systems that aid dermatologists in early skin cancer detection and treatment decisions.

title: Research on Spacecraft Temperature Measurement Deviation and its Suppression Methods
authors: Shuwen Yue, Xiaofeng Zhang, Jianchao Feng, Xiaofei Zhu, Xu Wu, Kangli Bao, Wenfeng Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: To meet the high-precision temperature measurement requirements for spacecraft, this study investigates the deviation mechanism and the deviation suppression methods for thermistor-based temperature sensing. A simulation model of the insulated wires was developed to determine its equivalent thermal resistance associated with heat leakage. Then, the thermal models of various temperature measuring scenarios were established. The influence of factors, including ambient temperature, insulated wire length, fixation method, and self-heating power, on the temperature measurement deviation was studied. The results indicate that within general engineering conditions, ambient temperature is the primary factor affecting the measurement deviation. Compared to the method of direct fixation using silicone rubber, covering the installation area with aluminum-coated film can reduce the temperature measurement deviation by approximately 10 %. Furthermore, an optimized method employing a high-thermal-conductivity holder can reduce the deviation caused by ambient temperature differences by nearly two orders of magnitude.

title: The Influence of Large Language Model-Based Decision-Making on Predator-Prey System Dynamics in Heterogeneous Niche Environment
authors: Linh Do Bui Khanh, Nghi Huynh-Quang, Doanh Nguyen-Ngoc
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Traditional ecological models often rely on a simplified set of deterministic or stochastic rules to govern individual agent behavior. This study investigates how the introduction of a more sophisticated, adaptive decision-making process, facilitated by a Large Language Model (LLM), impacts the dynamics of a predator-prey system within a heterogeneous niche patchy environment. Utilizing an agent-based modeling framework, we compare a baseline scenario (with fixed agent behaviors) against an experimental scenario where individuals' choices are guided by an LLM. Our findings reveal a profound shift in ecological outcomes. In the baseline model, the system exhibits rapid prey population growth, leading to resource over-exploitation and a subsequent population crash, ultimately resulting in prey dominance. In contrast, the LLM-driven system demonstrates a stable, co-existing population dynamic characterized by sustained oscillatory cycles. The analysis of mortality factors highlights this fundamental change: baseline individuals primarily succumbed to starvation, whereas in the LLM-driven system, predation became the dominant cause of prey mortality. Furthermore, the LLM's adaptive decision-making, which supports resource and predation feedback loops, prevented the over-exploitation of the heterogeneous environment, thereby promoting long-term ecological sustainability. These results suggest that LLM-based decision heuristics can introduce a novel, stabilizing regulatory mechanism into complex ecological systems.

title: DoraReviewer: Vietnamese Virtual Reviewer with GraphRAG and LLM
authors: Tin T. Trinh, Anh H. L. Ngo, Trinh H. T. Nguyen, Khanh D. D. Ly
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Online product reviews significantly influence consumer decisions, yet existing large language model (LLM) systems often generate ungrounded or inaccurate content, especially for low-resource languages like Vietnamese. This study introduces DoraReviewer, a Vietnamese-focused virtual reviewer system that integrates structured smartphone specifications and speech-to-text transcriptions from trusted video reviews into a multimodal knowledge graph. Using the Graph-based Retrieval-Augmented Generation (GraphRAG) method, DoraReviewer generates factually grounded product reviews and is evaluated across three LLM architectures: GPT-4 Turbo, Gemini 1.5 Flash, and DeepSeek Reasoner, using ROUGE metrics. DoraReviewer advances trustworthy, culturally relevant, and low-resource-friendly automated review generation, demonstrating how structured knowledge integration can overcome the hallucination challenges in multilingual LLMs while contributing to more reliable e-commerce ecosystems in Vietnam and similar emerging market.

title: Hybrid Quantum–Classical Models for Forecasting and Anomaly Detection on Edge IoT Devices
authors: Rayen Hajjem, Akramul Azim, Moncef Triki
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: The growing complexity of Internet of Things (IoT) networks has generated massive multivariate time-series data at the edge, challenging traditional forecasting and anomaly-detection models due to limited computation, memory, and energy on edge devices. Quantum machine learning (QML) provides a promising solution through expressive, parameter-efficient models that align with these constraints. This study proposes two distinct quantum-classical approaches for edge-based IoT analytics. The first combines a Quantum Neural Network (QNN) with a Quantum Autoencoder (QAE) to deliver lightweight forecasting and anomaly detection. The second employs Quantum Long Short-Term Memory (QLSTM) networks, exploring multiple variants and introducing optimization strategies to enable efficient deployment on a Raspberry Pi 5 using PennyLane simulators. Both approaches are evaluated on two real-world IoT datasets Bker (weather parameters) and ETTm1 (transformer temperature) and with a unified preprocessing pipeline incorporating normalization and PCA-based dimensionality reduction. Results show that QLSTM variants achieve superior forecasting accuracy, while QNN+QAE ensures robust anomaly detection with minimal resource overhead. A lightweight QLSTM variant strikes the best balance between accuracy and inference latency, enabling real-time edge deployment. To our knowledge, this is among the first practical demonstrations of QML-based forecasting and anomaly detection directly on edge hardware, highlighting a feasible pathway toward quantum-enhanced IoT intelligence.

title: Population Preservation in Autoencoder-Enhanced Optimization for Large-Scale Multi-Objective Problems
authors: Mayank Bajpai, Shishir Gaur, Kamal Singh, Adwitiya Roy
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Large-scale optimization involves numerous decision variables, creating significant computational challenges as the problem's complexity grows with increasing dimensions. Traditional approaches often struggle to handle vast search spaces efficiently, necessitating advanced techniques. Autoencoders, a key tool in dimensionality reduction, encode high-dimensional data into a lower-dimensional latent space, capturing essential features while discarding noise and redundancy. This study investigates the integration of autoencoder-assisted mechanisms within evolutionary multi-objective optimization algorithms across four standard benchmark problems (ZDT1–ZDT3, ZDT6). By varying the proportion of original to learned solutions for 12 trials each, we evaluate the impact on convergence and diversity using Hypervolume (HV), Inverted Generational Distance (IGD), Generational Distance (GD) and Spread (delta) metrics. Results show that hybrid configurations with low high original population (90% original or 10% autoencoder) consistently outperform other settings, demonstrating a balanced trade-off between exploration and exploitation. While autoencoder guidance improves search efficiency in continuous and discontinuous Pareto fronts, it shows limited effectiveness in deceptive landscapes. The findings emphasize the need for adaptive hybridization strategies tailored to problem complexity.

title: Detecting Mental Health Signals in Tweets: A Machine Learning and NLP Approach
authors: Aliza Sohail, Sibghat Ullah Bazai, Zoha Shahid, Isma Batool, Muhammad Imran Gafoor, Uzair Aslam Bhatti
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: Anxiety and depression are major global health challenges. Users’ tweets often reveal authentic emotional states, suggesting potential for early detection of mental distress. This study analyzes a public dataset of 20,000 labeled tweets (depression, anxiety, neutral) using four models— Logistic Regression, Random Forest, ANN, and CNN. CNN achieved the highest accuracy (89.2%, F1 = 88.5%), while Logistic Regression was fastest and most memory efficient. These results show that lightweight models can support mobile screening applications, while deeper architectures are suited for centralized monitoring systems. Identify mental health indicators from social media with high accuracy and real-time integration into social-media–based mental-health monitoring tools.

title: Early Detection of Supraventricular Tachycardia Events Using Machine Learning and Wearable Biosignals
authors: Mohana Krishna Munukutla, P. Karthikeyan, Lokesh Rajgopal, M.Dhanur Vishnu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Supraventricular Tachycardia (SVT) is a group of cardiac arrhythmia that result in abnormally fast heart rhythms originating above the ventricles. Early detection and prediction of SVT events are crucial for improving patient outcomes, especially given the often-intermittent nature of symptoms. This paper proposes a machine learning-based predictive model that leverages physiological signals gathered from wearable devices, including electrocardiogram (ECG), heart rate variability (HRV), oxygen saturation (SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), and respiration rate, identify early indicators of SVT events in real time, using synthetic wearable data derived from PhysioNet and Apple Watch signals, with SHAP-based explainability to support clinical interpretation.The research utilizes publicly available ECG data from the PhysioNet database, supplemented with synthetically generated wearable data to approximate real-world conditions such as noise, missingness, and low-frequency sampling. Feature engineering techniques were applied to extract biomarkers indicative of arrhythmic patterns, followed by training and validation of Random Forest and Logistic Regression models. Our Random forest model achived 88.7% in classifying SVT and non-SVT episodes, with HRV and SpO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> identified as the most significant predictive features.These outcomes indicate the feasibility of using consumer-grade wearable technology for early SVT prediction, laying the foundation for intelligent, AI-driven clinical decision support systems in cardiovascular healthcare. This work contributes to the growing field of eHealth and personalized medicine by integrating machine learning and wearable biosensing for proactive arrhythmia management. We trained Random Forest and SVM models on ECG and biosignal data, using synthetic wearable data derived from PhysioNet and Apple Watch recordings, with SHAP-based explainability to interpret model decisions.

title: SWiM3 : Solid Waste Mapping Dataset
authors: Muhammad Burhan Ahmed, Javeria Razzaq, Sajiah Razeen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: The exponential rise in population has also increased the amount of litter produced daily. The economic value of junk can come to light through proper waste segregation. This study aims to design a dataset that will allow computer vision techniques to identify and classify waste material into one of three classes: plastic, metal and paper. The SWiM3(Solid Waste Mapping) dataset is developed to accommodate the needs of the local environment. It comprises of 6,429 manually annotated images with a total of 25,234 instances. This to-and-fro process of manual annotation has elevated the quality of SWiM3 enough that it can be used as a new benchmark in the development of AI models for solid waste detection and classification. Machine Learning and Deep Learning strategies were integrated to rigorously evaluate the reliability and consistency of SWiM3 within the proposed framework. Optimal configurations for the model were identified via hyperparameter tuning to ensure stable and high-fidelity performance across all experiments.Overall, the proposed dataset provides a scalable foundation for deep learning-based architectures to build edge-cutting waste solutions that can be deployed into real-world scenarios.

title: A Method of NEAR-FIELD SIMULATION and Analysis with FDTD Algorithm
authors: Kaichun Zhang, Hongtao Zhang, Ji Yang
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: The Finite-Difference-in-Time-Domain (FDTD) method is a significant numerical analytical approach for electromagnetic field calculations, applicable across diverse scenarios. Some professional software has been developed to solve electromagnetic simulation question. However, some of aspects about the software should be considered. Software concentrates about shallow single-mediums by setting some simple parameters. The simulations may have other results cause of the properties’ differences between the interfaces of different kinds of medium such as complicated discrete media. When meeting some experiments designed for special conditions such as discrete medium area with many complicated reflective objects, parameters and environment of the software can’t be modified according to the experimental conditions either. It may need specific update packages, which will spend a large amount of cost. This paper proposes a method to simulate the propagation of electromagnetic wave in near-field area with some of experiments by digitizing necessary objects such as reflective objects and combination of medium. By comparing to some of results compiled by other codes, the experiments show fine results.

title: Geometric Position Tracking Control of Bicopter UAV
authors: Vijay Reddy Vundela, Vijay Muralidharan
publish: IEEE Journal on Miniaturization for Air and Space Systems
abstract: The Bicopter UAV belongs to a class of underactuated aerial vehicles with tilt thrusters. Unlike the co-planar underactuated and thrust-tilting fully-actuated UAVs, the Bicopter position dynamics involve lateral force coupling with the attitude dynamics, and the global asymptotic stability (GAS) of the trajectories cannot be proved directly with the state-of-the-art geometric PD controllers on Special Euclidean group SE(3). This paper demonstrates that the Bicopter position trajectories using the geometric controller are ultimately bounded with a certain bound and exhibit a large domain of attraction through the Lyapunov technique. Moreover, when the bound is sufficiently small, the system exhibits almost GAS. The analysis further reveals that ultimate bounded stability is preserved even under external disturbances, yet with an increased bound. The position tracking performance and the robustness of the controller against large initial errors and mild wind disturbances are verified using MATLAB simulations. Further, the performance of the proposed controller is compared with the traditional PD controller, and it is found that the proposed controller requires less control effort to achieve the desired trajectories. A realistic software-in-the-loop (SITL) framework is also developed using the PX4 flight stack and Gazebo, based on an accurate Bicopter model, which is useful for controller analysis and parameter tuning. Finally, a lightweight Bicopter UAV prototype is developed in our laboratory, and the proposed controller is validated through outdoor position stabilization and trajectory tracking experiments. The results demonstrate that the Bicopter with the proposed controller is well-suited for outdoor applications, even under small external disturbances.

title: Agentic AI Workflow for End-to-End Prompt-Based Contextual Virtual Staging
authors: Scott Murray, Haojin Deng, Yimin Yang, Eman Nejad
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Virtual staging has revolutionized the real estate industry by automating the redesign of interior images based on user instructions. This paper introduces an innovative Agentic AI Workflow for end-to-end, prompt-based contextual virtual staging, leveraging multiple specialized AI components. Our framework integrates advanced segmentation models and reinforcement learning-enhanced inpainting models to accurately interpret and execute user instructions, resulting in highly realistic and aesthetically pleasing property visuals. A key innovation is the use of Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) to fine-tune the Stable Diffusion model specifically for inpainting tasks. By employing a reinforcement learning technique tailored for diffusion models, we optimize LoRA parameters to maximize aesthetic quality and adherence to user prompts. This agentic approach enables each AI component to independently refine its specialized function while seamlessly collaborating within the workflow, enhancing overall flexibility and user satisfaction. To rigorously evaluate our methodology, we developed a standardized benchmark workflow to assess our proposed method across various categories, including furniture, functional elements, and decor. Experimental results demonstrate that our Agentic AI Workflow significantly outperforms traditional methods, achieving higher aesthetic scores and greater user preference, particularly in furniture and decor, while exhibiting reduced performance variability for consistent and reliable outcomes. Beyond real estate, the versatility of our Agentic AI Workflow extends its applicability to diverse domains such as architecture, e-commerce, and digital content creation. This research highlights the potential of agent-based AI systems to deliver customizable and high-quality visual transformations, paving the way for innovative applications across multiple industries.

title: A Novel Deep Learning Method to Diagnose Tea Leaf Diseases
authors: Manabendra Nath, Pinaki Mitra, Deepak Kumar
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Tea is one of the major crops in India, holding a significant importance culturally and economically. As tea leaf diseases cause significant crop losses and degrade the quality of tea, accurate diagnosis of tea leaf diseases is necessary to avert crop losses and maintain tea quality. Automated computerbased diagnostic approaches are essential for detection of diseases in large tea-cultivation areas. Existing automated tea disease identification methods left a significant scope to improve identification accuracy and efficiency of the models. This work leverages an efficient Deep Learning architecture with optimized feature extraction layers to detect complex disparity in texture, color, and lesion patterns. The proposed model incorporates depthwise separable convolutions, an effective feature fusion mechanism with a residual learning approach, and an attention mechanism, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy (99.3%) with fewer parameters compared to other state-of-the-art deep learning models.

title: YAM: A Novel Binarization approach for Non-Uniformly Illuminated Document Images
authors: Yash Maheshwari, Dibyasree Guha, Somenath Kuiry, Nibaran Das
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Document image binarization is a crucial preporocessing step in Optical Character Recognition (OCR) systems, but its accuracy is often hindered by non-uniform illumination. This paper introduces YAM, a novel and computationally efficient binarization technique based on a hybrid thresholding strategy. YAM integrate both global image statistics and local neighbourhood analysis to robustly adapt to luminance variations. Experiments conducted on the WEZUT OCR dataset shows YAM demonstrated superior performance over traditional binarization methods, including Sauvola, Niblack, and Otsu, achieving an F-measure of text recognition of $97.54 \%$ and a word accuracy score of $97.74 \%$. YAM incorporates a box filter approach which makes it executes faster than recent binarization techniques like ZigZag. Both quantitative and qualitative results validate YAM offers a compelling balance between performance and efficiency as a practical and high-fidelity solution suitable for resource-constrained environments.

title: Flatness-Based Predictive Control with EKF for UAV Target Tracking
authors: Haidar Ahmad Ali, Abadi Amine, Gabon Aurore, Laligant Olivier
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) require robust perception and control strategies for autonomous tracking of moving targets. This work integrates Extended Kalman Filter (EKF)-based trajectory prediction with a flatness-based Model Predictive Control (MPC) scheme for vision-based tracking. The EKF smooths noisy measurements and predicts short-term target motion, ensuring continuity during occlusions. These predictions serve as references for an MPC controller formulated on the quadrotor’s differentially flat outputs, enabling a simplified linear predictive model while respecting acceleration and input constraints. Real-time simulations demonstrate accurate and smooth tracking of the EKF-predicted trajectories, confirming the effectiveness of the combined EKF-MPC framework for vision-guided UAV target tracking.

title: Energy-Efficient Spike Encoding for Implementing Spiking Neural Networks on FPGA
authors: Armin SalimiKia, Saeed Mozaffari, Majid Ahmadi, Shahpour Alirezaee
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper presents an energy-efficient approach to the implementation of spiking neural networks (SNNs). Various techniques, including clustering, quantization, and pruning, are explored and applied to achieve this goal. Our proposed method focuses on optimizing the flow of data through the neural network. By understanding the relationship between energy consumption and the response of internal hardware components for different data shapes, we were motivated to develop a novel data encoding scheme. The proposed Energy-Efficient Spike Encoding (EESE) minimizes switching activity within the implemented Spiking Neural Network (SNN), resulting in significant 26% energy savings. We achieved a total power consumption of 0.101 W, with 3% of it attributed to dynamic power consumption, while maintaining 97% accuracy.

title: On Secure UAV-aided ISAC System via Sensing
authors: Hongjiang Lei, Heng Jin, Ki-Hong Park, Mohamed A. Aboulhassan, Xiaqing Miao, Gaofeng Pan
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) is a rapidly evolving and highly promising technology for wireless networks, enabling the concurrent execution of communication and sensing functions within constrained spectrum resources. This paper examines a secure ISAC system assisted by an uncrewed aerial vehicle (UAV), in which the extended Kalman filter is incorporated for accurate estimation and prediction of eavesdropper states. Radar signals are transmitted to track and jam potential eavesdroppers while communication services are simultaneously provided to ground users. Under practical constraints—including maximum UAV velocity, transmit power, and propulsion energy consumption—the achievable uplink rate is maximized through joint optimization of the transmit beamforming and UAV trajectory. To address the computationally complex and inherently non-convex optimization problem, an efficient iterative algorithm combining block coordinate descent with successive convex approximation is designed, yielding a high-quality suboptimal solution. Finally, comprehensive simulations are conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme against benchmark methods and to elucidate the inherent trade-off between communication and sensing performance.

title: POKEx: Performance analysis of POKE-key exchange and SIDH-variants
authors: Hyeonhak Kim, Suhri Kim
abstract: In this paper, we present a comparative performance analysis of the POKÉ-based key exchange and SIDH variants. SIDH gained attention for its small key size and efficient performance, and has been selected as an alternate candidate in NIST PQC Round 4. However, following the key recovery attack by Castryck and Decru in 2022, SIDH was shown to be vulnerable to polynomial-time attacks on classical computers, undermining its security and removing it from consideration. Given that SIDH was regarded as the leading isogeny-based algorithm, several countermeasures, such as MSIDH, MD-SIDH, and bin/terSIDH have been proposed. However, these approaches still face performance limitations. Meanwhile, POKÉ, proposed by Basso and Maino at Eurocrypt 2025, is an isogeny-based public key encryption scheme that combines a SIDH-like protocol with higher-dimensional isogenies and has drawn attention for its efficient performance. In this work, we adapt POKÉ into a key exchange algorithm and benchmark it against M-SIDH, terSIDH, and CSIDH. Targeting NIST security level 1, POKÉ-based KEM is approximately 21.21 times faster than terSIDH and 64.97 times faster than CSIDH, showing that the POKÉ-based KEM is currently the most promising isogeny-based key exchange candidate.

title: Fault Isolation with HBG-CNN in a Direct Current Drive of a water solar pumping
authors: Hajer Yaich, Taher Mekki, Slim Triki
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: In remote and rural areas, photovoltaic (PV)powered water pumps have received considerable attention due to major developments in the field of solar cell materials and power electronic systems technology. For DC pumps, the interface with the PV panels is achieved using a DC-DC converter to ensure controlled DC output. In particular, this paper takes the full bridge (FB) inverter as the case of study. However, many researchers have observed that most of the PV-powered water pump system failures are related to inverters. Therefore, an appropriate fault detection and isolation (FDI) mechanism is required. This paper extends the work of a Hybrid Bond Graph (HBG)-based diagnostic for Direct Current drive of a water solar pumping by combining it with the powerful pattern recognition of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) to improve the overall fault isolation performance.

title: Cramér-Rao Bound Optimization for Active RIS Aided Device-Based ISAC System
authors: Peng Zhang, Yang Liu, Qingqing Wu, Xiaodan Shao, Wen Chen, Qingjiang Shi
abstract: This paper considers an active reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) aided device-based uplink integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system. In this context, base station (BS) receives pilot and communication signals transmitted concurrently from mobile users to provision sensing and communication services. For the considered setup, we investigate beamforming design by jointly optimizing RIS configuration, mobile users’ transmit power and linear combiner at the BS to minimize Cramér-Rao bound (CRB) of angle-of-arrival (AoA) estimation for the sensing users while ensuring spectral efficiency of communication users. The considered device-based sensing paradigm raises unique challenge since communication signals contribute to noise covariance in AoA measurements, which leads to a highly complicated CRB expression. To resolve this challenge, we transfer the problem into a quartic form, equivalently represent covariance matrix inverse into an equation condition, decouple the intractable covariance equality constraint by introducing splitting variables followed by penalty dual-decomposition (PDD) methodology, which develops an iterative process updating all variable blocks alternatively. Extensive numerical results verify the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm and demonstrate the significant advantage of device-based sensing scheme over the device-free counterpart when the sensing targets can get connected in the ISAC network.

title: Design and Implementation of Low-Area FIR Filter Using Partial Product Based Methodology
authors: N Siva Naga Malleswari, Bommina Lakshmi Lavanya, Tottaramudi Prasanthi Devi, Polukonda Harshitha
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: A block-based FIR filter architecture using the partial product method has been designed for a filter order of 32 with block size 8. Verilog HDL was used for implementation, and the design was simulated using Xilinx Vivado. The architecture is evaluated using area delay product (ADP) and energy-per-output (EPO) metrics. The proposed filter achieves an ADP of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{1, 1 5 5} \mu \mathrm{m}^{\mathrm{2}} \cdot \text{n s}$</tex>, demonstrating a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{9 5. 9 \%}$</tex> improvement over the reference ASIC-based architecture. However, this gain in speed and area efficiency results in an increase in energy consumption, with EPO reaching <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$132.50 \text{pJ} 911 \%$</tex> higher than the ASIC implementation. These results highlight the effectiveness of design in applications that prioritize speed and resource efficiency over power consumption.

title: Deep Email Analytics: A System for Uncovering Human Values in Unstructured Corporate Communication
authors: G Sujith, H A Sudhanva, M P Darshan, N S Girish, P Priyanga, Prashanth Kannadaguli
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: The increasing volume in the digital communication within organizations presents a unique opportunity to understand the underlying human values that drive corporate culture and decision-making. However, analyzing vast amounts of unstructured text, such as emails, poses significant difficulties, especially when dealing with the nuanced and often imbalanced representation of different values. This research proposes a sophisticated deep learning platform designed for the value-based analysis of business correspondence. Within our research, we used recurrent neural networks to classify a large dataset of emails into a number of categories. What is novel about our approach is the fact that we tackle the class imbalance problem in our data, meaning that we pay special attention to the values that are observed less frequently. This means our model becomes significantly better at identifying those less frequently observed, highly valuable values. Our completed system is a valuable tool in decoding behavior and ethics at a given organization.

title: CAT-Net: A Channel and Self-Attention TCN for Robust Frame-Level Overlapping Speech Detection
authors: Yassin Terraf, Youssef Iraqi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Detecting overlapping speech is essential for improving the performance of speech processing systems such as speaker identification, diarization, and automatic speech recognition. However, existing methods often fail in noisy and reverberant environments, limiting their real-world applicability. To address this challenge, we propose CAT-Net, a novel lightweight architecture for robust frame-level Overlapping Speech Detection (OSD). CAT-Net combines multiscale channel-wise attention, which dynamically weights frequency bins based on their importance using parallel temporal convolutions. The weighted features are fed into a Self-Attention Temporal Convolutional Network (SATCN), which models short- and long-term temporal dependencies via dilated convolutions. To overcome the limitation of uniform weighting across the receptive field, a self-attention mechanism is applied after each dilated layer to adaptively re-weight temporal features based on contextual importance. A final classification module labels each frame as overlapping or single-speaker speech. As part of this work, we construct two comprehensive single-channel OSD datasets: one derived from the GRID corpus for neutral speech, and another from the RAVDESS corpus for emotional speech. For each dataset, we generate multiple versions simulating clean, noisy, reverberant, and combined noise-reverberation conditions across a wide range of Signal-to- Noise Ratio (SNR) levels and noise types. This enables rigorous evaluation of OSD models under realistic acoustic environments. Experimental results demonstrate that CAT-Net outperforms state-of-the-art methods across all conditions while using significantly fewer parameters, underscoring its effectiveness, efficiency, and suitability for deployment in practical speech processing systems. In addition, CAT-Net is evaluated on the real-world AMI Meeting Corpus, demonstrating strong generalization to realistic multi-speaker conversational conditions. Furthermore, integrating CAT-Net into a standard speaker diarization system results in consistent improvements across both clean and noisy conditions.

title: RFM: Refined Feature Modeling for Multimodal Recommendation
authors: Wenxing Ding, Zhida Qin, Wenhao Xue, Pengzhan Zhou, Tianyu Huang
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of multimodal recommendation in consumer-facing e-commerce platforms, where users interact with item information across multiple modalities—such as images, textual descriptions, and specifications. Effectively modeling these items and user preferences requires robust techniques for extracting meaningful multimodal features. To address this, we propose RFM (Refined Feature for E-commerce Multimodal Recommendation), a framework that improves user and item modeling through attention-based cross-layer knowledge distillation. RFM enables a student network to selectively learn from semantically aligned teacher layers, capturing features most relevant to user preferences while avoiding noisy or mismatched signals. These refined features are then used as item embeddings in a dual-graph learning structure, which includes both an item-item similarity graph and a user-item interaction graph. This design enhances the expressive power of item representations while preserving collaborative signals. RFM is particularly applicable to consumer-facing e-commerce platforms like Amazon, where users interact with multimodal content to evaluate a wide range of consumer electronics products. Extensive experiments on five real-world Amazon datasets demonstrate that RFM consistently outperforms strong baselines, achieving an average improvement of 5.8% in Recall@20. These results highlight the practical effectiveness of RFM for enhancing recommendation quality in online retail environments.

title: Transformer No-Load Losses Estimation Using Machine Learning from Measured Data
authors: Miroslav Mrajca, Vladimir Bilek, Jan Barta
abstract: This work introduces an innovative application of established machine learning methods to calculate transformer no-load losses. An accurate estimation of losses is crucial to cost-effective and reliable transformer design. Existing methods often lack precision due to hard-to-predict additional losses or are computationally expensive due to complex finite element models. The proposed method enables fast and accurate prediction of transformer no-load losses using Gaussian process regression, selected for its suitability for the dataset and problem. Building on previous work, an improved surrogate model is developed with enhanced outlier filtration and optimized input selection. The approach is further extended to predict a range of losses, accounting for manufacturing deviations. Its performance is validated through a learning curve. Key findings indicate that outlier removal significantly improves accuracy and the optimal model depends on nine key variables from an extended input set. Modeling ranges of losses is feasible with a sufficiently large dataset, which further enhances accuracy, as confirmed by the learning curve. Overall, the method shows a strong potential for accurate no-load loss estimation and to support more efficient and cost-effective transformer design.

title: Evaluating and Mitigating Relationship Hallucinations in Large Vision-Language Models
authors: Mingrui Wu, Jiale Li, Jiayi Ji, Fei Hao, Xiaoshuai Sun, Rongrong Ji
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: The issue of hallucinations is a prevalent concern in existing Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs). Previous efforts have primarily focused on investigating object hallucinations, which can be easily alleviated by introducing object detectors. However, these efforts neglect hallucinations in inter-object relationships, essential for visual comprehension. In this work, we introduce R-Bench, a novel benchmark specifically designed to evaluate hallucinations in visual relationships. R-Bench includes both image-level questions to assess the existence of relationships and instance-level questions that probe deeper into local visual comprehension. Our analysis reveals that relationship hallucinations arise from three types of co-occurrences: relationship-relationship, subject-relationship, and relationship-object, exacerbated by the long-tail distribution in visual datasets. Moreover, LVLMs often ignore visual content, over-relying on common sense from language models, particularly in spatial reasoning tasks. We further demonstrate that region-level image-text alignment helps mitigate relationship hallucinations and propose a new baseline, Region-Aware Alignment Mitigation (RA<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>M), that enhances model attention to relevant regions, improving alignment between generated text and images.

title: Movable Signals with Dual-Polarized Fixed Intelligent Surfaces: Beyond Diagonal Reflection Matrices
authors: Matteo Nerini, Bruno Clerckx
abstract: This paper investigates wireless systems aided by dual-polarized intelligent surfaces. We compare reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS), which adjust their reflection matrices, with movable signals operating with fixed intelligent surface (FIS), which adjust the signal frequency while the surface properties remain fixed. For both RIS and FIS, we consider surfaces with a diagonal reflection matrix, named diagonal RIS/FIS, and surfaces with a reflection matrix not limited to being diagonal, named beyond-diagonal RIS/FIS. Movable signals with FIS always outperform RIS, achieving at least a fourfold gain. When transmitter and receiver polarizations differ, beyond-diagonal FIS further enhances performance.

title: Design and Implementation of a Microstrip Patch Antenna Array with Displaced Radiation Beam
authors: Ursula Resende, Alexandre Labossiere A Muzzi, Ulysses R. C. Vitor, Lucas D. Coelho
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work presents the complete development process of a microstrip patch antenna array designed to produce a displaced radiation beam at 2.45 GHz. Two linear arrays were designed, simulated, fabricated, and experimentally tested using FR4 as the dielectric substrate. The first array was configured with equal feed lengths to generate a centered main lobe, serving as a reference. The second array introduced a progressive 30 degrees phase shift between adjacent antenna elements by varying the feed line lengths, effectively steering the main beam away from the central axis. All antennas were optimized using CST Studio Suite software to ensure good impedance matching, low S11 parameter value, and stable radiation performance. The prototypes were fabricated through chemical etching and measured using a vector network analyzer and a spectrum analyzer setup. Experimental results confirmed the simulated behavior: the displaced-beam array achieved a main lobe at approximately 15 degrees, with increased gain and a broader beamwidth compared to the centered array. The results validate the proposed approach for implementing directional beam control using passive feed network design, demonstrating its potential for applications in smart antennas, wireless communications, and beam-switching systems.

title: CITRAP: A Configurable Infrastructure Template for Rapid Prototyping on FPGAs
authors: Vitalii Burtsev, Martin Wilhelm, Nandhish Thathanur Rajappa, Ilia Sozutov, Thilo Pionteck
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Despite advances in high-level tool chains, rapid prototyping of FPGA-based accelerators poses significant challenges. First, creating the basic interface infrastructure for the Unit Under Test evaluation, such as PCIe interfaces and DRAM controllers, is a time-consuming process. Second, with each iteration of UUT debugging, the static design requires complete synthesis from scratch. Third, frameworks with a high level of abstraction do not provide direct access to the UUT signals for debugging. In this paper, we introduce an open-source solution called CITRAP, a lightweight and reusable template that supports native debugging tools. It simplifies the process of creating infrastructure through the use of template scripts and standard IP-cores. The hardware design consists of two parts: a static infrastructure partition and a user logic partition. The static partition provides the infrastructure with interfaces, is synthesized only once, and stays untouched in the FPGA throughout debugging iterations. The user logic partition hosts the UUT, supports IP-cores for debugging and can be resynthesized and reconfigured independently by using Xilinx's Dynamic Function Exchange technology. Unlike more complex frameworks such as XRT, TAPASCO and OpenCPI, our approach does not introduce new abstraction overhead, allows for faster design cycles while providing full access to debug signals.

title: Stablecoins and Power: Balancing Banks, Tech Giants, and Government Oversight
authors: Nir Kshetri, Jeffrey Voas
abstract: Stablecoins offer faster, cheaper, and more inclusive financial transactions but carry risks for stability, regulation, and public revenue. This article examines their adoption, economic impact, and the governance challenges for policymakers and private actors.
