title: Measurement and Multi-objective Optimization of Displacement-Force Characteristics of a Proportional Solenoid for Cotton Picker Power-Shift Transmission
authors: Xiangchao Meng, Yiqing Li, Xiangdong Ni, Guangqing Zhang, Huajun Chen, Sihang Li, Wei Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Proportional electromagnet is the key actuator in the shift process of power shift transmission of cotton picker. By adjusting the electromagnetic force of proportional electromagnet, the flow and pressure of shift hydraulic oil can be accurately controlled, and the smoothness and stability of shift can be realized. Taking the proportional electromagnet of power shift transmission of cotton picker as the research object, the static and transient analysis of the proportional electromagnet is carried out by Ansys Maxwell software, and a new method for measurement proportional electromagnet characteristics of power shift transmission of cotton picker is proposed through the built proportional electromagnet test platform, which verifies the correctness of the simulation model. In order to improve the displacement-force response characteristics of proportional electromagnet, the key parameters of proportional electromagnet are parameterized, and the horizontal characteristics of electromagnetic force are measured by the variance index of electromagnetic force of proportional electromagnet. Multi-island genetic algorithm is used to optimize the parameters of proportional electromagnet. The results show that the proportional electromagnet test platform and the proportional electromagnet characteristic measurement method can meet the requirements of proportional electromagnet characteristic measurement of cotton picker power shift transmission, and the average electromagnetic force of the optimized proportional electromagnet is increased by 2.54%, the variance of electromagnetic force is reduced from 2.31 to 0.38, the variance of electromagnetic force is significantly reduced, the dispersion degree is reduced, the horizontal characteristics of displacement-force curve of proportional electromagnet are obviously improved, and the average Joule loss is reduced by 8.65%, which is of great significance to realize the accurate shift control and smooth operation of power shift system of cotton picker.

title: Grid-Forming and BESS: Review of Advances and Challenges
authors: J. Galvez-García, V. Torres-García, J. R. Rodríguez, H. F. Ruíz-Paredes
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: The massive integration of renewable energies has drastically reduced mechanical inertia in power systems, compromising frequency stability. In response to this challenge, Grid-Forming Inverters (GFM) and Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) emerge as key technologies: the former emulate the inertial response of synchronous generators, while the latter provide fast active power adjustments to maintain frequency at nominal values. In this context, this work presents a review of these technologies, focusing on control strategies for GFM and BESS, with an emphasis on active power injection schemes and primary frequency regulation. Proposed approaches in the literature are reviewed to address operational challenges, such as the dynamic coordination between both technologies and harmonic suppression in weak grids. Furthermore, relevant technological gaps are discussed in areas such as standardization, fault resilience, and cybersecurity, among others, identifying key opportunities for future research. Through a comparative analysis of recent studies, this work synthesizes lessons learned and highlights the main opportunities for the effective integration of GFM and BESS in grids with high renewable penetration.

title: GPTViet: An Open-Source Vietnamese Foundation Model from Pretraining to Domain Specialization
authors: Thang Nguyen-Truong, Nhiem Tran, Ngoc Truong, Thanh Le-Hoang, Kien Bui-De, Dong Tran-Manh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: As open-source Large Language Models (LLMs) increasingly rival proprietary counterparts, the need for foundational models tailored to specific linguistic and cultural contexts becomes critical. This paper presents GPTViet, a series of foundational LLMs for the Vietnamese language. Built upon the LLaMA architecture, GPTViet was developed by curating a high-quality Vietnamese corpus and performing extensive finetuning on a range of model sizes (8 B to 70 B parameters). Evaluations demonstrate that GPTViet models significantly outperform their respective base models on Vietnamese-specific tasks, as measured by standard benchmarks and our custombuilt VietExam benchmark. The practical utility of this work is showcased through domain-specific application, VietHealth 70B for medical consultation. Adhering to the principles of open source Llama, GPTViet and all its derivatives are publicly released under an open-source license. This initiative provides the Vietnamese research and development community with a powerful, adaptable foundation to accelerate the creation of diverse intelligent applications. For more information, please visit https://github.com/VietnamAIHub/GPTViet and demo at http://gptviet.ioit.ac.vn/.

title: Digital Twin-Enhanced Communication Architectures for Malaysia's Smart Manufacturing Sector
authors: Wai Yie Leong
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: The integration of digital twins into smart manufacturing has emerged as a transformative approach, revolutionizing the way factories operate, monitor, and optimize performance. In Malaysia's push toward Industry 4.0 and its upcoming transition to Industry 5.0, digital twinenhanced communication architectures play a critical role in ensuring real-time data synchronization, predictive analytics, and intelligent automation. This paper presents a comprehensive investigation into the design, implementation, and optimization of digital twin-augmented communication infrastructures tailored to Malaysia's smart manufacturing context. Leveraging edge computing, industrial IoT, 5G, and semantic interoperability standards, we propose a multilayered communication framework that addresses latency, data reliability, and system scalability challenges. Our research combines simulation modeling, industrial testbeds, and stakeholder interviews across key industrial corridors in Selangor and Penang. Findings indicate that digital twinenabled communication systems improve real-time process visibility by 58%, reduce downtime by 35%, and enhance predictive maintenance accuracy by 62% compared to conventional setups. Through architectural modeling, latency analysis, and digital twin synchronization protocols, the study demonstrates the viability of the proposed framework in small-to-medium enterprises (SMEs) and multinational manufacturing plants alike. The results underscore the necessity of standardized digital twin interfaces (e.g., OPC UA, MQTT, and ISO 23247), edge-driven latency mitigation strategies, and cloud-twin data fusion mechanisms to ensure full-loop control and scalability. This work contributes a technically validated, policy-aligned, and future-proof architecture that supports Malaysia's Smart Manufacturing Blueprint (2021-2030) and aligns with the MyDigital roadmap.

title: Virtual Inertia vs Physical Inertia for Improving the Stability of a Heavily Renewable Driven Power System
authors: Ravi Kiran Reddi, Deepak Kumar Soni, Vaskar Sarkar
abstract: Driven by the global push for net-zero emissions, inverter-based renewable energy sources (RESs) are rapidly replacing traditional synchronous generators. As a consequence of the above mentioned transition, the system exhibits a natural tendency to lose inertia and show weaker performances in resisting large disturbances. The reduced inertia intensifies the risk of high rates of change of frequency, angular instability, and frequency oscillations. Inertia support mechanisms for RESs can enhance the stability of low-inertia power systems. This paper presents a comparative analysis of virtual and physical inertia-based approaches for RESs, focusing on rotor angle stability. The system behavior is examined for three different configurations of RESs integration. In the first configuration, RESs are integrated normally without any inertial support. Second, the virtual inertia functionality is embedded in the RES control mechanism. Finally, the physical inertia of the system is restored with the help of synchronous condensers. The study is conducted on the IEEE 68-bus benchmark system using both modal analysis and non-linear dynamic simulations to evaluate and compare the effectiveness of virtual and physical inertia support mechanisms.

title: Hybrid Grey Wolf-Fuzzy Logic Controlled ZETA Converter for Efficient PV-Battery Energy Management
authors: R Thamizharasan, Krithik Roshan M L, Mohammed Harris J A, Roshan Joshwa J
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: The integration of renewable energy sources with energy storage systems is becoming essential for achieving sustainable and reliable power management. An intelligent photovoltaic (PV) battery hybrid energy management system are to be developed using a ZETA DC-DC converter to ensure efficient power regulation and seamless energy exchange under variable operating conditions. A Hybrid Grey Wolf-Fuzzy Logic Control (HGWFLC) scheme is being implemented to enhance Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) performance by combining the global optimization capability of the Grey Wolf Optimizer (GWO) with the adaptive reasoning of Fuzzy Logic Control (FLC). The ZETA converter is operating in Continuous Conduction Mode (CCM), providing bidirectional voltage regulation with continuous input current and minimal output voltage ripple. A detailed MATLAB/Simulink model is being developed to analyze the interaction between a 600 Wh PV array, a 2.3 kWh, 60 V lithium-ion battery, and a resistive load. Simulation results are demonstrating that the HGW-FLC based MPPT achieves high accuracy, faster transient response, and improved stability compared to conventional Perturb & Observe (P&O) and standalone FLC methods. The proposed configuration enhances energy utilization efficiency, conversion performance, and operational reliability, making it suitable for hybrid renewable energy and smart grid applications.

title: A Physics-Guided Fusion CNN Framework for Bearing Fault Diagnosis under Cross-opereating Conditions
authors: Zhicheng Di, Tao Liu, Tianwei Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Current intelligent bearing fault diagnosis models based on end-to-end learning generally suffer from insufficient interpretability, primarily due to the lack of guidance from physical mechanisms. To address this issue, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis method that integrates physical information. By enhancing features through post-processing and converting one-dimensional signals into two-dimensional images, the method effectively embeds physical knowledge. Experiments on publicly available bearing datasets demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a diagnostic accuracy of 97.40 %, showing significant advantages over baseline models in terms of stability and accuracy. This validates the effectiveness of physics-guided information in enhancing model performance and interpretability.

title: Kisê-Manitow’s Hand in Space: Securing Communication and Connections in Space
authors: Nesrine Benchoubane, Gunes Karabulut Kurt
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: The lunar Gateway is a complex system-of-systems (SoS) requiring secure, resilient integration of all its systems. This paper develops controls for its early systems to secure command and data handling (C&DH) and evaluates their effectiveness through a case study on collision impact propagation originating from Canadarm3. We demonstrate that a baseline security strategy with stringent, standardized controls reduces failure impact by up to 70%, underscoring the importance of consistent security integration across all systems.

title: Predicting Urbanization Trend in Vietnam Based on Machine Learning Models with Geographic Information Features
authors: Nam Hai Le, Son T. Luu, Anh Gia-Tuan Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Recently, Vietnam has witnessed rapid population growth and economic development, especially in urban areas. Urbanization in Vietnam requires rational planning to balance the development of the economy and the sustainable environment. To better investigate and monitor urbanization in Vietnam, we introduce a human-annotated land-use dataset comprising 1,500 high-quality satellite images from 2019 to 2024 over Binh Duong Province, and propose a data-driven method that integrates GIS information from satellite imagery with a machine-learning approach to automatically predict land use and land cover. The empirical results show that the land-use prediction models perform efficiently in predicting land-use types by year, enabling scalable, year-by-year monitoring of urbanization through changes in land-use. Automatic urbanization prediction benefits authorities in urban management, planning, and data-driven decision-making.

title: Study on HMDS-Assisted Plasma Surface Modification of Epoxy Resin and its Flashover Characteristics
authors: Ze Liu, Yan Du, Jiang Wu, Junjie Cui, Jingcheng Bao, Wen Cao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Epoxy resin is a key insulating material for gasinsulated transmission lines (GIL), but it suffers from surface charge accumulation and electric field distortion. To address these issues, this study modifies the epoxy resin surface using an argon dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) assisted with hexamethyldisilazane (HMDS). The study investigates the effects of different modification conditions on the surface flashover characteristics of epoxy resin. Several analytical and testing methods were employed to evaluate the epoxy resin before and after modification. These methods include scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), surface flashover tests, and the isothermal surface potential decay (ISPD) measurements. The evaluation focused on changes in five key aspects: surface morphology, chemical composition, surface conductivity, surface potential decay, and pollution flashover. The results indicate that plasma treatment enhances surface roughness through etching, leading to a significant increase in shallow trap density, surface conductivity, and the charge dissipation rate. Moreover, the pollution flashover voltage of modified samples was significantly higher compared to untreated samples. This work demonstrates that plasma-assisted vapor deposition effectively optimizes the distribution of surface traps, enhances surface conductivity in epoxy resin, accelerates charge dissipation, alleviates electric field distortion. All of these contribute to improving the surface flashover stability of epoxy resin under non-uniform electric fields. Moreover, this modification method is cost-effective and environmentally friendly, exhibiting promising application prospects in the field of high-voltage insulation.

title: Research and Verification of On-Orbit Autonomous Management Strategy for Payloads
authors: Xin Zhao, Chaoyu Wang, Yonghu Cao, Shengwei Pei
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: To address the challenges of diverse payload types, complex in-orbit operational states, cumbersome control operations, and low execution efficiency in satellites, this paper proposes an autonomous payload management strategy that operates without ground station support. Using real-time in-orbit computed orbital data or temporal information as input triggers, the satellite autonomously calculates the operational status of its payloads within defined thresholds. This calculation incorporates parameters such as satellite time, orbital data, and activation statuses of various payloads. Based on this, the satellite independently executes activation commands and software configuration for individual payload units, achieving autonomous in-orbit payload management. Validation demonstrates that this method significantly reduces satellite ground operation and control costs while substantially enhancing the satellite's autonomous management and operational capabilities. Furthermore, for energy-constrained spacecraft, this approach can drastically minimize energy expenditure by aligning operations with mission usage plans.

title: A Lightweight Plug-and-Play Model for Sensor Integration in Resource-Constrained IoT Devices
authors: Nghia Nguyen Dai, Viet Xuan Truong, Vinh Loc Cu, Hoang Thao Le, Hoang Viet Nguyen, Thai Truong Minh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Plug and Play (PnP) technology has demonstrated superior efficacy in modern computing systems by enabling automatic device detection and configuration without manual intervention. Building upon this principle, this research proposes LitePnP, a lightweight Plug-and-Play model specifically designed for resource-constrained IoT devices, which typically lack comprehensive operating systems and are limited in memory capacity, processing power, and storage capabilities. The model focuses on three primary components: (1) a sensor identification mechanism based on active and passive scanning through RS485/Modbus RTU protocols; (2) lightweight JSON-based drivers that enable sensor operation abstraction while reducing memory overhead; and (3) a minimalist PnP process that faciliates seamless driver installation and service deployment. The significant contribution of this research lies not only in proposing the lightweight PnP model but also in comparing it with typical PnP models such as MicroPnP, IEEE 1451, and TEDS. The comparison demonstrates that while current models provide comprehensive functionality or high standardization, they often require specialized hardware or substantial resources. In contrast, LitePnP model offers minimalism and ease of integration, making it particularly suitable for low-cost IoT devices and opening up a viable approach for large-scale applications in smart agriculture, environmental monitoring, and industrial automation.

title: A Low Noise High Gain Amplifier MMIC for Wideband Satellite Application
authors: Zhi-Jian Chen, Yang Li, Feng-Yuan Mao, Bin Li, Zhao-Hui Wu, Quansheng Guan, Xiaoling Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: In this paper, a low-noise amplifier (LNA) monolithic microwave integrated circuit (MMIC) with a four-stage cascade common-source structure is presented which aims at the low noise and high gain performance in the n258 band for 5G commercial and satellite communications. A high-pass filter structure with a resistor was adopted as the interstage matching network, greatly improving the matching bandwidth. A transmission line is applied at the drain of the transistor with RLC parallel feedback, which enhances gain flatness and stability. The LNA has been fabricated by 150-nm GaN-on-SiC high electron mobility transistors (HEMT) technology. The tape-out measurement reveals that the proposed LNA achieves a flat gain of 21.4-22.8 dB with a gain flatness of 1.4 dB. The measured noise figure (NF) is 1.33–1.97 dB with an average in-band NF of 1.69 dB. The implemented LNA also achieves an output-referred intercept point (OIP3) of 23 dBm while consuming 150 mW from a 5-V power supply.

title: Non-Contact Thermal Estimation of Oxide Scale Thickness in Steel via Infrared Imaging and Machine Learning
authors: Oscar D. Prieto-Sánchez, Antony Morales-Cervantes, Gerardo Marx Chávez-Campos, Héctor Javier Vergara-Hernández, Jorge Sergio Téllez-Martínez, Maritza Fabiola León-Bejarano
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This work presents a non-contact methodology for estimating oxide scale thickness on AISI 1045 steel during high-temperature oxidation. Radiometric infrared thermography was used to capture the thermal evolution of steel specimens subjected to a controlled Joule heating process. Each thermal image was flattened and processed via Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to extract low-dimensional thermal features. These features were used to train machine learning regressors, specifically Random Forest and XGBoost, to predict oxiderelated dimensional changes. The methodology was validated using micrometer-based thickness measurements synchronized with the thermal data. Results demonstrated strong predictive performance with mean absolute errors below 0.007 mm. This approach enables real-time tracking of thermally induced surface evolution without invasive sensors, opening possibilities for smart manufacturing applications.

title: Data Acquisition System for Amperometric Estimation of Substance Concentration in Electrochemical Signals
authors: M.A. Mogollán-Jiménez, N. Alvarez-Jarquin, D.J. López-Araujo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Chronoamperometry, an electrochemical technique that quantifies analytes by measuring current-time responses during redox reactions, offers exceptional precision and miniaturization potential for portable analytical devices. However, existing chronoamperometric systems lack integrated real-time processing capabilities and user-friendly interfaces, limiting their deployment in point-of-care diagnostics and field applications where immediate results are critical. This work presents the development and validation of a novel embedded system that automates analyte concentration estimation through real-time chronoamperometric data acquisition and algorithmic processing. The system architecture integrates a real-time data acquisition, signal interpolation, and concentration estimation through a small user-friendly interface, combining embedded hardware and algorithmic processing. Results show the system can reliably process chronoamperometric signals and deliver low-error estimations, demonstrating its robustness and potential for real-time applications.

title: Enhanced Performance of Five-Phase PMSG-based Grid Connected Wind Turbines Conversion System
authors: Edriss Ben Saleh, Ramzi Trabelsi
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This work addresses the modeling and implementation of Field-Oriented Control (FOC) for a five-phase Permanent Magnet Synchronous Generator (PMSG) wind turbine system. The study focuses on enhancing power quality and dynamic performance through coordinated control of the machine-side converter (MSC) and grid-side converter (GSC). The complete wind energy conversion system including the aerodynamic, electrical, and control subsystems was modeled and simulated in MATLAB/Simulink. Results under varying wind conditions demonstrate stable DC-link voltage, smooth torque response, and effective MPPT performance, confirming the suitability of FOC for five-phase PMSG-based wind turbine applications.

title: MYSENTIMENTH: Affective Norms for Malay Sentiment Word Derived from Mental Health Context
authors: Hafizuddin Muhd Adnan, Hamwira Yaacob, Normi Sham Awang Abu Bakar, Abdul Wahab Abdul Rahman
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Recent research trends in sentiment analysis are increasingly focused on understanding and extracting emotions from social media comments from content on various platforms. This study aims to identify emotional cues in language to understand public sentiment and social dynamics better. Word-level sentiment analysis, in particular, plays a crucial role in interpreting human emotions, providing essential insights for anticipating and responding to societal issues. Despite growing research interest in sentiment analysis, there is a noticeable lack of research on emotion-labeled corpora in Malay. To date, no comprehensive studies or publicly available datasets have been published to develop a Malay emotional corpus, which remains underdeveloped. To address this gap, the present study aims to develop MySentiMentH, a lexicon of affective norms for Malay sentiment words within the context of mental health, enabling more targeted analysis of emotional language, especially as it appears in responses to major societal events. The primary objective of this research is to review existing techniques and methodologies for developing emotional corpora and to adapt these approaches to the creation of MySentiMentH. The methodology includes detailed discussions on data collection, the design of the MySentiMentH lexicon, and the materials and procedures used in its development. The findings demonstrate the feasibility of constructing a Malay sentiment lexicon with emotional labels. MySentiMentH is shown to be a valuable resource for future research and applications, as it provides a foundation for the continued development of a comprehensive Malay emotional corpus. This corpus can serve as an effective sentiment-monitoring tool for better understanding human emotions from words used on social media.

title: Limitations and Comparative Evaluation of Statistical and Deep Learning Approaches for Short-Term Household Energy Forecasting
authors: Maissa Taktak, Ahmed Fakhfakh, Faouzi Derbel
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Short-term household energy forecasting at high temporal resolution is essential for smart grid operations. This paper presents a comprehensive empirical evaluation of statistical and deep learning approaches applied to a $\mathbf{1 4}$-month residential consumption dataset from northeastern Mexico. We systematically compare ARIMA and ARIMAX models using global and rolling window strategies against four deep learning architectures: LSTM, BiLSTM, GRU, and CNN-LSTM. Experimental results demonstrate fundamental performance differences between method categories. Statistical approaches demonstrate inadequate performance due to the highly volatile characteristics of residential energy consumption. Deep learning architectures successfully model nonlinear consumption dynamics, with GRU achieving root mean square error of 99.3 W, representing 25% error reduction compared to best statistical methods. Rolling window retraining strategies counterintuitively degrade statistical performance despite increasing computational costs. The moderate absolute performance across all methods reflects fundamental predictability constraints imposed by residential consumption volatility at high temporal resolution, with implications for realistic performance expectations in operational deployments.

title: Actuator Fault Detection and Identication for Boost Converters in Photovoltaic System
authors: Maouadda Ismail, Karim Dahech, Mohamed Chaabane
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Faced with the global energy crisis, the exploitation of photovoltaic energy has emerged as an essential solution in the industrial sectors. To maximize the efficiency of these systems, several Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) techniques have been developed, including the Perturb and Observe (P&O) method, allowing the photovoltaic generator to operate at its optimal power. However, the reliability of DC-DC converters is essential, which explains the growing interest in developing efficient methods for fault detection and identification. My paper is based on an approach for diagnosing open-circuit and short-circuit faults in boost converters of photovoltaic systems. The presented method is distinguished by its simplicity of implementation, requiring only conventional current and voltage sensors, while offering remarkable efficiency as demonstrated by the obtained simulation results.

title: Leveraging In-Context Adversarial Augmentation for Improved Natural Language Inference Performance
authors: Quang-Dung Dang, Ly-Huynh Phan, Van-Tung Bui, Dinh-Dat Nguyen, Chi Minh Hieu Nguyen, Truong-Giang Nguyen, Van-Thuong Vu
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) in Natural Language Inference (NLI) tasks often encounter challenges such as shortcut learning, weak generalization, and high sensitivity to adversarial inputs. To address these issues, we propose a three-phase framework that integrates dataset preprocessing, in-context adversarial augmentation, and supervised fine-tuning with parameter-efficient techniques (LoRA). The approach leverages cosine similarity to generate semantically consistent adversarial samples, enriching training data with more challenging premise-hypothesis-reason pairs. We evaluate the methodology on the ANLI dataset across multiple training regimes (R1, R2, R3, R1+R2, and Full ANLI). Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach substantially improves robustness and reasoning capability. Qwen3 4 B achieves up to 87.2 % accuracy and 87.05 % Macro F1, nearly 8 % higher than its baseline training results, while consistently outperforming LLaMA 3.2 3B under all settings. Hybrid strategies that combine adversarial augmentation with mixed training also show strong gains, reaching 85.4 % accuracy and 85.27 % Macro F1. These findings confirm that adversarial augmentation combined with efficient fine-tuning is an effective way to improve inference performance and can be scaled to broader NLI benchmarks.

title: A Ka-Band CMOS Switchless Low-Noise High-Responsivity Receiver for Sensing Applications
authors: Yu-Chia Su, Yi-Fu Chen, Hong-Yeh Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper presents a Ka-band switchless receiver designed for millimeter-wave (mm-wave) sensing applications, implemented in a 90-nm CMOS 1P9M process. The receiver architecture comprises a two-stage cascaded low-noise amplifier (LNA), an active balun, and a square-law power detector. To eliminate the insertion loss and noise degradation associated with conventional single-pole double-throw (SPDT) switches, a dual-path LNA with RC feedback is introduced. The dual-path LNA achieves a gain of 17.4 dB, a noise figure of 4.5 dB, and a 3-dB bandwidth of 11.6 GHz, while consuming only 18.5 mW of dc power. The proposed switchless receiver demonstrates a minimum noise-equivalent power (NEP) of 1.3 fW/√Hz and a noise-equivalent temperature difference (NETD) of 0.32 K, enabling precise detection of weak thermal emissions. The total chip area is 1.2 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. These results highlight the suitability of the design for scalable and energy-efficient mm-wave sensing systems.

title: CareVision: Real-Time Fall Detection for Elderly Care
authors: Theppasit Tongsrihon, Chanunpat Sattayasansakul, Areerat Songwattana, Poonphon Suesaowaluk
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Falls are a major cause of injuries, increased mortality rates, and reduced quality of life among the elderly, especially those living alone who may not receive timely assistance. This study aims to develop a fall detection system integrating Internet of Things (IoT) and Computer Vision technologies to enhance safety and mitigate fall-related risks. The system operates with smart cameras and IoT devices, utilizing AI-powered image processing techniques, including MediaPipe and You Only Look Once version 8 (YOLOv8), for real-time fall detection. When a fall is detected, the system records the incident images directly onto the device’s local storage, ensuring data privacy and fast access. It then sends an alert via Telegram Bot to caregivers, ensuring rapid and timely intervention. The empirical test demonstrated high accuracy in fall detection using MediaPipe and YOLOv8, minimizing false positives and negatives through confidence thresholding and post-processing, thereby improving reliability and reducing unnecessary alerts. Real-time alerts via Telegram Bot enable prompt caregiver intervention, improving response times. The outcomes result in a secure, reduced risk of injury situation, and allow elderly individuals to live with more faith in their health and a good quality of life.

title: A watermark-based defense mechanism approach against LiDAR point insertion attacks in autonomous vehicles
authors: Sergio Alberto Salguero-Luna, Kelsey Alejandra Ramírez-Gutiérrez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Autonomous vehicles use different sensors to perceive their surroundings and make driving decisions. Among these, Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) is probably the most useful sensor due to its high accuracy and role in supporting various autonomous driving tasks. However, despite significant advances in autonomous driving technology, multiple reports of attacks targeting the sensors of these vehicles have been documented. In particular, LiDAR point insertion attacks have drawn increasing attention from the research community, as they can cause vehicles to brake abruptly or even result in fatal collisions. Although several countermeasures have been proposed, many fail to provide comprehensive protection, often exhibiting vulnerabilities that hinder their effectiveness in real-world scenarios. This work presents a watermarking scheme to address LiDAR point insertion attacks. Our approach segments the LiDAR point cloud into voxels and embeds a watermark message in those enclosing points. The robustness of the proposed method is evaluated against such attacks using points collected from real-world LiDAR readings.

title: Influence of Leakage Impedance on Physical and Economic Parameters of a 2500 kVA Oil-Immersed Transformer
authors: Kamran Dawood, Necati Berkay Çiçek, Semih Tursun
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Transformers are vital components in the transmission and distribution of electrical energy. This paper examines the impact of leakage impedance variations on the design, weight, and cost of a 2500 kVA oil-immersed transformer. Leakage impedance affects voltage regulation, short-circuit currents, and load sharing, influencing key design parameters such as winding configurations, winding dimensions, and magnetic core dimensions. This study compares the effects of leakage impedance values at 6%, 7%, and 8% on transformer weight and cost. As leakage impedance increases, the need for larger winding spacing and expanded magnetic core size results in greater material consumption, leading to higher transformer weight and production expenses. Experimental results reveal a progressive increase in transformer weight corresponding to each increment in leakage impedance, which in turn drives a notable rise in manufacturing cost due to increased copper and other material usage. The findings provide a clear correlation between leakage impedance, physical transformer characteristics, and economic impact, offering valuable insights for optimizing transformer design to balance electrical performance with material costs and weight constraints.

title: DUDU-BLDC: Dataset for Diagnostics of Brushless DC motors with Degrading Magnets
authors: Kacper Jarzyna, Paweł Piątek, Waldemar Bauer, Jerzy Baranowski
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Reliable fault diagnosis of brushless DC (BLDC) motors is critical for ensuring the safety, efficiency, and uptime of modern industrial systems. Yet, the lack of publicly available, high-resolution datasets for BLDC diagnostics has hindered the development and benchmarking of data-driven algorithms. To address this gap, we introduce DUDU-BLDC, the first fully documented repository of synchronous current and non-contact speed recordings from Fein EC48 BLDC motors under healthy, mechanically imbalanced, electrically degraded, and combined-fault conditions. Collected at 50 kHz and packaged according to the TIER 4.0 protocol, the dataset comprises five CSV files with 28 statistical and spectral features per 0.8 s experiment. We demonstrate its utility via a Gaussian Naive Bayes classifier achieving up to 85.8 % mean accuracy on speed features, illustrating how DUDU-BLDC can accelerate research in BLDC fault detection and predictive maintenance. The complete dataset, metadata, and code are openly available on Zenodo under a CC BY 4.0 license.

title: A Cross-Source Domain Contrastive Learning-Guided Invariant Adversarial Network for Mechanical Fault Diagnosis Under Unseen Conditions
authors: Jie Zhang, Kangkang Zhao, Yufan Lv, Leijun Shi, Yun Kong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Although domain adaptation methods are commonly used in mechanical fault diagnosis to mitigate the domain shift problem, they typically rely on target domain data being available during training. To address this issue, this paper proposes a cross-source domain contrastive learning-guided invariant adversarial network (CSDCL-IAN). The model first employs a residual attention network to construct a feature extractor, aiming to enhance discriminative fault information. Subsequently, a cross-source domain contrastive learning mechanism is designed, which extracts common features across multi-source domains by making intra-class features closer and inter-class features more distinct. Finally, unseen-condition data are input into the trained CSDCL-IAN to realize cross-domain fault diagnosis. In transfer diagnosis experiments on a planetary transmission system test rig, CSDCL-IAN yields an average diagnostic accuracy of 98.15% on across six transfer tasks, which significantly verifies its superior domain generalization ability and cross-domain diagnostic performance.

title: Performance of Beamformed Microphone Arrays
authors: Afrooz Haghbin, Rodney Vaughan
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Hearing assistance is to improve sound intelligibility, and takes on many forms, from the traditional earborn hearing aids to cellphone apps for connected earphones. These systems are useful for those with hearing impairment or for those struggling with background noise, such as when the cocktail effect is compromised by the spoken language not being sufficiently familiar. While in-line time-signal processing can help, the best way forward is to use multiple microphones to harness the power of array signal processing. Arrays allow the simultaneous enhancement of the wanted sound and suppression of interfering sounds, as long as the interferers are in different locations from the wanted sound. This paper demonstrates how the performance of the main beamforming algorithms can be explored very conveniently using MATLAB. The algorithms are deployed and evaluated here using a simple representative scenario - the geometric arrangement of wanted and interfering signals and the array elements. Here we use a linear array and a circular array, each of ten elements, that can be mounted on the head; a single wanted signal source, and just a couple of interfering sources. When the number of array elements is greater than the number of sources, there are enough signalprocessing degrees of freedom to strongly improve the wanted signal-to-interference ratio.

title: Encrypted Proximity Recognition (EPR) Framework using Connectionless BLE with Application to Classroom Attendance
authors: Dwaipayan Datta, Nirjhar Debnath, Kousik Dasgupta
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Proximity-based identification faces a fundamental challenge where existing solutions either sacrifice cryptographic authentication for scalability or require dedicated infrastructure. Traditional Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) implementations demand connection establishment, limiting concurrent device support on typical smartphone hardware. This paper presents Encrypted Proximity Recognition (EPR) framework, a connectionless BLE protocol that achieves cryptographic device authentication with concurrent scalability and zero-infrastructure deployment. EPR employs one-way cryptographic key mixing where each device broadcasts values derived from a pre-distributed secret key combined with session-specific one-time parameters through multi-stage cryptographic operations, enabling a verifier device to identify present devices by matching received broadcasts against pre-computed values. The framework supports flexible deployment configurations including deterministic mixing for offline operation, server-assisted mixing to prevent client-side function extraction, and TRNG-based parameterization for enhanced security. Extensions with biometric verification enable multi-factor authentication combining proximity, device possession, and user presence. Real-world validation through classroom attendance deployment demonstrates practical feasibility.

title: An Experimental Study of Walrus Optimization-Based Deep Learning Models for Software Effort Estimation
authors: Duy Khanh Nguyen, Khanh Duy Dao, Thi Kim Ngan Dang, Thi Minh Phuong Ha, Ngoc Tho Huynh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Software Effort Estimation plays a pivotal role in project planning, resource allocation, and cost management within the software development life cycle. This study investigates the integration of deep learning models Convolutional Neural Network, Recurrent Neural Network, Long Short-Term Memory, Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory and Multilayer Perceptron with the Walrus Optimization Algorithm for hyperparameter tuning. By using five standard SEE datasets including China, Kemerer, Kitchenham, Maxwell, Miyazaki94, we assess the model's performance using multiple evaluation metrics: Mean Squared Error, Mean Absolute Error, Coefficient of Determination (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex>), Mean Magnitude of Relative Error, and Prediction Accuracy at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2 5 \%}$</tex> (Pred(25)). Experimental results reveal that LSTM and its variant consistently outperform other models in terms of MSE, MAE, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> in most datasets, demonstrating the advantage of sequence-based learning for SEE. The proposed framework offers a replicable methodology for applying evolutionary optimization to deep learning in SEE.

title: Enhancing Gemini for Mental Health Assessments
authors: Opeyemi Adesina, Yuvraj Gupta, Olutade Olajitan, Christophe Schinckus, Faisal Naeem
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: The demand for psychiatric services due to increasing mental health awareness and a rising prevalence of its disorders shows a huge deficit in the number of practicing psychiatrists relative to patients. A human-centered AI-based conversational system (with the ability to administer intake assessment) for data collection and documentation can reduce consultation time by up to 66.6%, through automation. We formulated a pipeline that utilizes a large-language model to facilitate interview-style intake assessment and answered two research questions: a) how effective is the baseline (Gemini 1.5 Pro) model in diagnosing psychological health disorders? b) what strategies could be employed to improve its diagnostics accuracies? By fine-tuning Gemini 1.5 pro, results show that we can improve diagnostic accuracies of the baseline model from 38% to 70% for the case studies evaluated.

title: Edge AI-Based Fall Detection for an Elderly Care Robot
authors: Sarra Ben Halima, Faten Ben Abdallah, Joseph Haggege
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Falls represent a major safety risk for older adults, motivating reliable and privacy-preserving detection solutions that operate directly on edge devices. This work presents a lightweight fall-detection system based on the YOLOv5 object detector and deployed on an NVIDIA Jetson Nano to recognize three postures: standing, sitting, and falling. When a fall is confirmed, the embedded system generates an alert that can be transmitted to a caregiver. On a separate test set, the detector achieves a mean Average Precision of 95.8 percent at an Intersection-over-Union threshold of 0.5. Real-time measurements on the Jetson Nano show an effective processing speed of around seven frames per second for the baseline configuration and up to twelve frames per second when using NVIDIA’s TensorRT optimization. The software pipeline is configured for compatibility with PyTorch, CUDA, and TensorRT, and is adapted to the constraints of embedded deployment. Current limitations relate to lighting variations, camera viewpoint, and scene complexity. Planned developments will focus on improving robustness, reducing latency, and integrating the system on an elderly-care robot for on-board perception and timely alerts.

title: A Projectile Band Bayonet-Chamber Action Localization Method Based on the ResAttU-Net++
authors: Xingxiao Fan, Manyi Wang, Bin Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Localization of projectile band bayonet-chamber action is of great significance for ensuring the reliability of automatic artillery loading. However, the signals generated by projectile band bayonet-chamber action exhibit strong impact characteristics and sample imbalance, and current conventional detection methods fail to meet the requirements for effective recognition of band bayonet-chamber localization. To address this issue, this paper proposes a Residual Attention Nested U-Net (ResAttU-Net++) model: while retaining the skip connection design of U-Net++, a “residual-attention module” is constructed to enhance the feature extraction effect of transient impact signals during band bayonet-chamber action. Additionally, a class-weighted Lová sz-Softmax loss function is specifically designed to effectively balance sample weights. The proposed method is evaluated through experiments on both laboratory test benches and range test benches. Combining three evaluation criteria, the model's cross-condition performance and localization accuracy are verified, thereby providing an effective solution for band bayonet-chamber action localization in sample imbalance scenarios.

title: Adaptive AI-Based Protection Framework for Relay Coordination and Device Recommendation to Enhance Selectivity in Industrial Smart Grids
authors: Doaa Alghamdi, Fahd Hariri
abstract: This paper presents the AI-based Protection Frame-work for Coordination and Recommendation (APFCR), developed to enhance protection selectivity, reliability, and automation within smart grid environments. The framework intro-duces a novel Overlap-Points Metric (OPM) that quantifies Time-Current Characteristic (TCC) curve intersections into measurable indicators, replacing traditional visual assessment with objective, data-driven evaluation. The proposed hybrid architecture integrates deterministic Auto-Fix algorithms with reinforcement learning (RL), combining rule-based precision with adaptive intelligence to achieve dynamic and self-optimizing coordination across diverse network conditions. Three case studies were conducted to assess the framework's robustness and scalability under varying network complexities. In sim-ple configurations, APFCR achieved complete elimination of curve overlaps, demonstrating 100 % coordination performance. In moderately constrained networks, it sustained 83 % performance with a 28 % decrease in intersection density, whereas in highly constrained systems, it maintained 70 % performance and achieved a 61 % reduction in overlap occurrences. Collectively, these findings confirm APFCR's adaptive capability and effectiveness in minimizing coordination conflicts as system complexity increases. Furthermore, a techno-economic analysis confirms a distinct cost advantage, with the framework reaching break-even after 10–15 projects compared to conventional consulting studies. Collectively, APFCR establishes a scalable, sustainable, and intelligent decision-support framework that advances digital transformation and automation in industrial power protection systems.

title: Measurement and Law Analysis of Soil Dielectric Properties in Frozen Soil Environment
authors: Xiaotao Wang, Wei Shen, Ke Li, Zhibo Xue, Chi Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: The lightning protection performance of transmission lines in frozen soil areas is closely related to soil electrical parameters. Existing studies mostly focus on room temperature soils, and there is a lack of experimental analysis of the frequency-dependent characteristics of permafrost electrical parameters. In this paper, the frequency changes of resistivity and relative dielectric constant in the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{Hz} \sim 10 \text{MHz}$</tex> of soil with an initial moisture content of 12% were measured at different temperatures. The results showed that the decrease of soil temperature led to a significant increase in resistivity and a decrease in relative dielectric constant. Under negative temperature conditions, water freezes into ice, and the dielectric constant is much smaller than that of liquid water, which makes the difference between frozen soil and room temperature soil significant. With the increase of frequency, the soil dielectric constant tends to be stable, and the polarization effect weakens at high frequency. The results reveal the frequency-dependent characteristics of the electrical parameters of permafrost, which provides an experimental basis for further research on the broadband response of permafrost grounding devices.

title: EEG-Based Parkinson's Disease Classification using XGBoost and Explainable AI
authors: Thi-Nhu-Quynh Nguyen, Hoang-Thuy-Tien Vo, Tuan Van Huynh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that impairs motor and cognitive function, and electroencephalography has emerged as a practical modality to support diagnosis. We propose a subjectwise validated framework that couples rigorous preprocessing with explainable machine learning. Signals are denoised using FastICA with ICLabel to remove non-neural components, normalized, and partitioned into delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands. From each band, we extract complementary descriptors spanning statistical measures, entropy indices, and fractal dimensions, and train an XGBoost classifier on the resulting feature vectors. Model interpretability is achieved with SHAP using TreeExplainer, which quantifies the contribution of each descriptor to individual predictions and to the global decision rule. The fused feature set yields balanced, state-of-theart performance, achieving 97.71 % accuracy, 98.13% sensitivity, and 97.29 % specificity for the two-class control versus PD task, and 97.82% accuracy, 97.96 % sensitivity, and 98.87 % specificity for the three-class control, ON, and OFF task. SHAP attributions indicate that band-limited statistics and entropy measures drive the control versus PD contrast, whereas multiscale complexity, as captured by fractal descriptors, is most discriminative for medication state. These findings demonstrate that accurate and transparent EEG-based support for PD diagnosis is feasible within a single, cohesive pipeline.

title: RAG Chatbots for Educational Virtual Field Trips
authors: Suryaprakash Reddy Kalvakolu, Heinrich Söbke, Florian Wehking, Mukesh Chandra Kumar Mamidala, Eckhard Kraft
abstract: Virtual field trips (VFTs) are increasingly recognized as effective educational activities, particularly in technical fields, where they provide remote access to complex locations. However, self-guided VFTs often leave learners with unresolved questions due to the absence of real-time instructional support. While chatbots based on large language models such as ChatGPT might be powerful learning tools, they are prone to inaccuracies due to their reliance on generalized knowledge bases. Thus, this pilot study introduces a retrieval augmented generation (RAG) chatbot specifically designed to generate accurate, contextually relevant responses from a curated set of technical documents related to an VFT environment based on 360° technology. Learners (N=1 0) were exposed to the 3 6 0° VFT environment of a biogas plant, where the chatbot provided real-time assistance. A mixed-methods evaluation was employed to assess the chatbot's impact on learning, including both qualitative user feedback, collected in semi-structured interviews, and quantitative measures. The quantitative measures comprised – based on standardized questionnaires – motivation, emotion, cognitive load, and usability, while learning gains were collected based on a pre-posttest design. The findings demonstrate that the RAG-enabled chatbot supports the accuracy of information retrieval, thereby not overstraining the cognitive load on learners. Participants reported a better understanding of domain-specific information, underlining the potential of RAG-based chatbots in virtual environments.

title: Application of High-Throughput and Low-Latency for Hybrid Edge-Cloud Computing: Advancing Smart City Real-Time Data Processing
authors: V. Saravanan, Gutta Venkateswarlu, G. Sasikala, Hebatullah Awwad, Babitha Lincy, Vemuri Nitin
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: The rise of smart cities has produced an explosion of heterogeneous data sources, from sensors, surveillance systems, traffic controls, healthcare monitors, and environmental monitoring devices. Real-time processing and management of this amount of data is rather challenging, especially when high throughput, low latency and scalability are in consideration. In this paper, we study the use of a novel hybrid edge-cloud computing (HECC) architecture that supports high-throughput and low-latency in smart cities for real-time data processing. By injecting edge computing for local real-time analytics and cloud infrastructure for massive processing, the envisioned framework should be able to achieve the optimal trade-off between the speed and the confidence of the decision informed by collected data. The work proposes and investigates a layered hybrid architecture where edge nodes provide preliminary data filtering, aggregation, and anomaly detection at the edge (close to the data source) - and the cloud layer handles long-term analytics, historical pattern mining, and storage. Several scheduling algorithms, network topologies, and communication protocols are experimented to quantify performance under dynamic urban environments (e.g., traffic congestion prediction, emergency response, pollution level prediction). Experimental results conducted in real urban simulation environments show the hybrid system can significantly reduce processing latency and improve data throughput, by up to 55% and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>70 {\%}$</tex>, respectively, compared to the traditional cloud-only solution. This study presents a scalable, adaptive, and robust computational model as an approach to progress the operational intelligence and responsiveness of the next-generation smart environments.

title: Inferring Low-Voltage Distribution Topology from Trench Footprints: A Deep Learning Framework
authors: Abdulaziz Alobaidi, Mohammed Alsalmi, Meshari Albawardi, Hamad Alowais, Malek Alduhaymi, Faisal Albeladi
abstract: The accurate topology identification of low-voltage distribution networks (LV DNs) is still a key challenge with limited GIS visibility and real-time measurements. This paper introduces a deep learning-based framework that identifies the topology of Saudi Arabia's underground LV networks. This is based on detecting trench patterns and identifying infrastructure elements using the YOLO architecture. The difference between electricity-specific trenches and water trenches is considered through visual features, such as the presence of meter boxes and water boxes during the training. Later, identified electricity trenches are used to build the LV topology through directional connectivity from customer premises to LV transformers, aligning with Saudi Electricity Company (SEC) configurations. The resulting topological graph helps to enhance planning and observability in the absence of conventional measurements.

title: Device Effect on Current Balancing in Parallel Connected IGBTs
authors: Danielle Jaye S. Agron, Patrick Palmer
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: One of the challenges in parallel connected devices is to ensure that current is equally distributed among the system. There are several factors that affect the current balance in each branch like parasitic parameters, devices, and asymmetry in the electrical circuit. In this paper, device dependency is investigated on its influence on current mismatch within the parallel connected insulated gate bipolar transistors (IGBT) devices for high power inverter application. Using three IGBT devices connected in parallel, experimental results reveal the strong correlation in using same production lot (week and year) devices reduce power losses. In addition, applying skewed gate driving overall improved the current distribution in parallel devices.

title: Analyzing the Basics of Share Market Mutual Funds with AI-Driven Portfolio Optimization
authors: S. Dhivya, D. Mahila Vasanthi Thangam, Saravanan S
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: As share market mutual funds become more complicated, adaptive, data-driven portfolio optimization methodologies are required in addition to the classic applications of Modern Portfolio Theory (MPT) and Mean-Variance Optimization. Although these classical systems serve as a foundation, but suffer from backward-looking returns, presuming return distribution follows normal behavior, and being unable to adapt in a volatile market. To address these shortcomings, it provides a unified AI-driven portfolio optimization technique that integrates supervised learning (XGBoost, Temporal Fusion Transformer) and reinforcement learning (Constrained Soft Actor-Critic) for dynamic allocation, as well as robust risk modeling using GARCH and DCCGARCH. It also includes investor profiles, sentiment analysis, and macro aspects to help users make selections. The results demonstrate its superiority, with higher annualized returns of $15.8 \%$, higher Sharpe (1.25) and Sortino ratios (1.95), lower volatility $(12.6 \%)$, and superior downside protection $(-18.2 \%$ drawdown), outperforming the existing system in terms of efficiency, adaptability, and resilience.

title: Liquid Metal Based Soft-Connected Packaging of Press-Pack SiC Power Module for Pressureless Interconnection and Double-Sided Cooling
authors: Huayang Zheng, Liang Wang, Peng Sun, Yuxi Liang, Mingrui Zou, Wentao Sun, Zheng Zeng
abstract: Owing to the advantages in high breakdown voltage and low switching loss, the silicon carbide (SiC) device is promising to integrate with the press-pack (PP) packaging for high-voltage and high-power applications. However, the higher Young's modulus and heat flux of SiC dies, compared to silicon counterparts, pose significant challenges for conventional PP packaging. Rigid PP packaging suffers from uneven contact pressure, while the flexible PP packaging offers only single-sided cooling. To tackle these issues, a soft-connected PP packaging enabled by liquid metal, and a matched structure is proposed to replace the spring structure, thus realizing pressureless interconnection and efficient double-sided cooling. Finite element analysis and experimental assessment for the soft-connected packaging of the PP SiC module and its two counterparts with conventional interconnections are conducted. Experimental results indicate that the contact pressure on the SiC die with the soft interconnection is decoupled from the external clamping force and reduced by 99% compared to both conventional packaging baselines, thus making the module highly suitable for easy series connection. Compared to the conventional rigid and flexible PP SiC modules, the optimal junction-to-fluid thermal resistance of the soft-connected PP SiC module is reduced by 83% and 55%, respectively. The reliability of the power module and the stability of the liquid metal have been preliminarily verified through thermal shock testing. The proposed soft-connected packaging thus facilitates the deployment of SiC technology in advanced PP power modules.

title: Age-Related Visual Attention and Interaction Performance Across Interface Layouts in EV Charging Applications: An Eye-Tracking Study
authors: Dongyue Liu, Tong Wu, Xiyun Li
abstract: This study investigates how different interface layouts affect user interaction efficiency and visual processing mechanisms, with a particular focus on the moderating role of age differences. A total of 40 participants were recruited, including 20 younger adults (aged 22–27) and 20 older adults (aged 52–58), who completed three types of tasks—target localization, status confirmation, and functional operation—across four typical electric vehicle (EV) charging application layouts (L1–L4). Eye-tracking techniques were employed to capture average fixation duration, saccade count, fixation-to-saccade ratio, and gaze heatmaps, while task completion time, accuracy, and subjective preferences were analyzed in parallel. The results show that L1 (Bottom Navigation with Top Functional Area) yielded the best performance in both task efficiency and visual processing, with minimal performance differences across age groups. In contrast, L3 (Bottom Navigation with Two-Level Hierarchical Structure) significantly impaired interaction efficiency and increased cognitive load, particularly for older adults. Eye-tracking metrics aligned closely with behavioral data and user preferences, underscoring the critical role of layout structure in shaping attentional allocation and interaction pathways. These findings highlight the importance of adopting intuitive and flat layout designs to enhance universality and usability in cross-age mobile application interfaces.

title: A Robot-Led Intervention for Emotion Regulation: from Expression to Reappraisal_supp1-3657604.pdf
authors: Guy Laban
abstract: Emotion regulation (ER) is a crucial skill for managing emotions in everyday life, yet finding a constructive and accessible method to practice ER remains challenging due to cognitive demands. In this study, we explore how regular interactions with a social robot, conducted in a structured yet familiar environment within university halls and departments, can provide effective support for practising ER via cognitive reappraisal. Twenty-one students participated in a five-session study at a university hall or department in the U.K., where the robot (QTrobot, LuxAI), powered by a large language model (GPT 3.5) facilitated structured conversations, encouraging the students to reinterpret emotionally charged situations that they shared with the robot. Quantitative and qualitative results indicate significant improvements in ER, with participants reporting better understanding and control of their emotions, significant changes in constructive ER tendencies and positive effects on mood and sentiment after each session. The findings also demonstrate that repeated interactions with the robot encouraged greater emotional expression, including longer speech disclosures, increased use of affective language, and heightened facial arousal. Notably, expression peaked during key reappraisal moments, particularly when participants were prompted to reinterpret negative experiences. The qualitative feedback further highlighted how the robot fostered introspection and provided a supportive space for discussing emotions, enabling participants to confront long-avoided emotional challenges. These findings demonstrate the potential of robots to effectively assist in ER in familiar environments, offering both emotional support and cognitive guidance

title: LLM Enabled Resource Allocation for Knowledge Base Federated-Split Learning in Semantic Communications
authors: Kaixiang Yang, Ruikun Li, Yikai Xu
abstract: With the advancement of 6G and IoT, semantic communication has evolved from ”bit-focused” transmission to ”meaning-centered” delivery, yet faces challenges including limited device resources and privacy risks in multimodal data processing. While semantic knowledge bases enable structured domain guidance for feature extraction, edge computing reduces bandwidth usage through local processing, and federated learning (FL) preserves privacy by aggregating model updates instead of raw data. However, standalone edge computing lacks complex reasoning capability, and FL incurs high communication costs. This paper proposes an LLM-powered resource allocation framework for knowledge base-assisted federated-split learning. First, we design a knowledge-aware federated-split architecture that integrates semantic knowledge bases into model splitting and aggregation. Second, we develop a system model formalizing computation latency, communication rates, and end-to-end latency. Third, we formulate resource allocation as a Constrained Markov Decision Process (CMDP) and adopt a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) framework with a frozen LLM to generate knowledge-aware rewards for policy learning. Experiments on the FLASH dataset demonstrate that our framework outperforms baselines by reducing training latency, accelerating convergence, and improving semantic reconstruction accuracy, effectively addressing resource allocation challenges in privacy-preserving semantic communication.

title: Sensitivity Enhancement and Offset Reduction in the Silicon Cross-Like Hall Device via P-type Implant and Optimized Layout Orientation
authors: Lin Zhou, Chengxin Shen, Yue Xu
abstract: This paper presents a high-sensitivity horizontal Hall-effect device (HHD) implemented in a standard 180 nm BCD (Bipolar-CMOS-DMOS) process for cost-effective magnetic sensing. To overcome the inherent sensitivity limitations of standard processes, key structural innovations are introduced. These include the use of a low-doped N-type diffusion layer and P-type implantation to reduce carrier concentration and effective thickness, respectively, alongside a cross-like device structure (L/W = 0.8) that mitigates the short-circuit effect and optimizes the trade-off between current-related (SI) and voltage-related sensitivity (SV). After fabrication and packaging, it is experimentally shown that a high SI of 586 V/AT and SV of 36.3 mV/VT are simultaneously attained. Furthermore, a theoretical analysis of the mechanical stress-induced offset in cross-like Hall devices is presented. Based on this analysis, a method of reorienting the device's cross-finger layout direction from [010] to [110] is proposed to suppress this offset. Measurement results confirm a drastic reduction in the residual offset from 17.7 μV to 5.4 μV under a bias current of 100 μA. This work provides a competitive solution for developing low-cost, high-performance current and magnetic sensors.

title: Lateralized Learning for Multi-Class Visual Classification Tasks
authors: Abubakar Siddique, Will N. Browne, Gina M. Grimshaw
abstract: The majority of computer vision algorithms fail to find higher-order (abstract) patterns in an image so they are not robust against adversarial attacks. Deep learning considers each input pixel in a homogeneous manner such that different parts of a locality-sensitive hashing table are often not connected, meaning higher-order patterns are not discovered. Hence, these systems are sensitive to noisy, irrelevant, and redundant data, leading to wrong predictions with high confidence. Adversarial attacks exploit this vulnerability by generating deceptive inputs that mislead AI systems. In contrast, human vision is rarely susceptible to adversarial attacks. Vertebrate brains afford heterogeneous knowledge representation through lateralization, enabling modular learning at different levels of abstraction. This work aims to verify the effectiveness, scalability, and robustness of a lateralized approach to real-world problems that contain noisy, irrelevant, and redundant data. Two well-known and widely used adversarial attacks, the Fast Gradient Sign Method and the Iterative Adversarial Technique, are applied to generate corrupted test images. The experimental results on multi-class (200 classes) image classification tasks demonstrate that the proposed system effectively captures hierarchical knowledge representations, enhancing its robustness. Crucially, the lateralized system outperformed four state-of-the-art deep learning-based systems for the classification of normal and adversarial images by 19.05% − 41.02% and 1.36% − 49.22%, respectively.
