title: M2DG-TPV: A Matrix-based Tri-Perspective View 3D Perception Model with 2D Gaussian Recovered Voxels
authors: Fengyufan Yang, Runwei Guan, Ka Lok Man, Erick Purwanto, Jeremy S. Smith, Yutao Yue
abstract: Perceiving and understanding complex 3D environments are paramount for ensuring the safety and efficiency of intelligent transportation systems. 3D occupancy perception provides a comprehensive representation of surroundings by encoding geometric volumes alongside semantic labels. However, existing approaches often face significant challenges in preserving fine-grained geometric details due to the inherent constraints of camera-based image features. Simultaneously, 3D perception sensors such as LiDAR are limited by the sparsity of the resulting point clouds (voxels). To address these limitations, this paper introduces M2DG-TPV, an innovative model that employs a cross-attention-based module to integrate image and voxel features. It lifts the 2D image feature to a simplified 3D representation through an efficient matrix-based view transformation and enhances the voxel feature in occluded regions via a masked 2D Gaussian recovery method. Experimental evaluations on the nuScenes dataset demonstrate that M2DG-TPV achieves an absolute improvement of 2.0 mIoU over state-of-the-art methods and surpasses existing approaches in 9 out of 16 semantic classes, while utilizing fewer model parameters and preserving finer geometric structures. Additional evaluation on the SemanticKITTI dataset further demonstrates the cross-dataset generalization.

title: Analysis of the Energy Efficiency and Dynamic Behavior of a Gorlov-Type Turbine Under Different Wind Speed Profiles and Scales Using CFD
authors: Lopez-Lau Luisa Andrea, Charca-Mojica Lidia Paola Beatriz, Carmona-Arteaga Abel
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This research evaluates the aerodynamic performance of a Gorlov turbine as an alternative for wind microgeneration in rural areas with limited access to electricity. Using transient CFD simulations, wind speeds of 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 m/s were analyzed, revealing a progressive acceleration of the system up to 73 RPM and a direct relationship between flow and performance. Five geometric scales were also assessed at 4 m/s, with Scale 1 standing out for its higher RPM and stability, and Scales 2 and 3 for their balance between efficiency and dynamic behavior. The turbine's helical geometry demonstrated adaptability to turbulent flows, confirming its technical viability for sustainable rural electrification and resilience to climate change.

title: A Novel Image-Based Watermarking Method for Detecting False Data Injection in Line Current Differential Relays
authors: Swati Agarwal, Kondety Tony, Manish Pandit, Ranjana Sodhi
abstract: Line current differential relays (LCDRs) are widely used to protect critical transmission lines from internal faults in power systems via local and remote end measurements. Since LCDRs rely on digital communication channels, which, in turn, are vulnerable to cyberattacks, and thus, can be maloperated, leading to a cascaded failure. This paper proposes a novel image-based dynamic watermarking technique to distinguish between actual faults and false data injection attacks (FDIAs) in LCDR. It dynamically embeds the watermark into the remote-end as well as the local-end current measurement signal. After the extraction of the watermarks from the local and remote end signals, the extracted signals are compared to the original embedded watermark using the Damerau-Levenshtein (DL) distance. The final relay logic is developed based on the DL distance. The working of the proposed scheme is tested on PSCAD using the IEEE 14-bus system model.

title: PCB Coil-end Type Radial Flux PM Motor for Integrated Machine Drives
authors: Masahiro Aoyama, Jumpei Mukaiyama
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: For electric micromobility applications, an axial-length shortening is required for the coil winding area of the distributed winding stator. In addition, an integrated motor drive (IMD) system is desirable to achieve miniaturization, unitization, and improved efficiency of the motor drive systems. In this study, a new IMD system is proposed in which the coil-end of the distributed winding stator is replaced with a printed circuit board (PCB) and the drive circuit is integrated in that area. First, the proposed motor structure and prototype have been revealed. At the current stage, the coil-end PCB and the drive circuit PCB have been designed to be the same for integration, but they are separate boards. The drive characteristics of each individual component were evaluated and have been clarified. Additionally, the evaluation results of system efficiency and losses when these components are placed in spatial proximity have been presented.

title: The Importance of Access to Information and Communication Technologies for Latin American Women Entrepreneurs: A Systematic Review
authors: Sara Fernanda Sánchez Sánchez
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This paper presents a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) under the PRISMA 2020 guidelines to examine why access to technology is essential for Latin American women entrepreneurs. From 234 initial records, 22 empirical studies show that adopting digital platforms, ICTs, and AI tools can increase revenues by up to 25 %, expand international markets by up to 30 %, and reduce operational costs by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8-15 \%$</tex>. Beyond economic impact, digitalization reduces social isolation and strengthens networks. However, persistent barriers like limited digital skills and costly connectivity constrain wider adoption. Promoting affordable access, tailored training, and supportive ecosystems is key to unlocking women's entrepreneurial potential in the region.

title: Negative-Sequence Based Directional Overcurrent Adaptive Protection Scheme for Distributed Generation
authors: N. V. N. Jagadish, Khalid S. Al-Ghamdi
abstract: Due to the concerns for reduction of system losses, providing back-up power during loss of the grid, mitigation of energy security risks and conspicuous perturbation of power outages triggered by severe environmental constraints; the modernized distribution grids elicited grid resiliency and reliability enhancement through pragmatic enforcement of the Microgrid (MG) concept with distributed generation. With the proliferating power ultimatum, several intricate factors prone to MG operation modes, bidirectional power flow complexities, management and control of power transfer, varying fault current contribution, and high impedance faults (HIF) customized the network configuration and imperiled the protection system operation and system stability. The propitious utility framework persuaded the prerequisites to embrace the integration of state-of-the-art affiliated Distributed Energy Resources (DERs), which requires assimilated and coordinated studies to emphasize the outcomes of an efficient, reliable, and fast protection scheme for both the grid-connected and islanded modes of operation. Operating modes of distributed generation (DG) will affect the magnitude and direction of fault currents resulting in failure of protection coordination between directional overcurrent relays (DOCRs). In this paper, the negative-sequence based adaptive directional overcurrent relay (NSADOCR) stratagem is proposed. Protection coordination is accomplished by a new adaptive approach, which alters time dial setting (TDS) of negative-sequence overcurrent relay based on the ratio of the normal mode to operating mode of plug setting multiplier function. Furthermore, the direction of fault is attained using phase change in between the pre-fault and superimposed negative-sequence current components. Performance of the NSADOCR is evaluated on the dSPACE controller board, which is interfaced with Real- Time Digital Simulator (RTDSTM) to perform the hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) tests. Extensive simulation studies and hardware results on DG systems exemplify and indicate that the new adaptive technique results in effective protection coordination over the conventional approach, considering various distribution network (DN) modes of operation.

title: Optimization of an Energy Tuning Assembly for High Explosives Detection
authors: Lance Drouet, Oluwatomi Akindele, Sandra Bogetic, Cameron Salyer
abstract: The Portable Isotopic Neutron Spectroscopy (PINS) system, employs neutron-induced gamma-ray spectroscopy and provides a nondestructive method for high explosives detection. In standard operation it uses Californium-252 as a neutron source. Operating PINS with a deuterium-tritium (DT) neutron generator has some advantages over Cf-252, including lifetime and ability to produce high-energy inelastic scattering gamma rays. However, current systems using DT neutron generators suffer from a high environmental background and reduced ability to induce neutron capture, reducing spectral quality and limiting nitrogen sensitivity. This study presents the development of an energy-tuning assembly (ETA) designed to optimize the DT neutron energy spectrum to increase nitrogen reaction rates in a target, thereby improving high explosive detection capabilities. A metaheuristic optimization framework, MultiGNOWEE, coupled with MCNP, was employed to generate two ETA configurations: a single-objective ETA, which maximizes nitrogen capture reactions, and a multi-objective ETA, which balances neutron capture and inelastic scattering. Simulations demonstrated the optimized configurations achieved up to a 10-fold improvement in nitrogen capture rates compared to the bare configuration. Experimental validation was conducted using a DT neutron generator and a high-purity germanium (HPGe) detector. Two prototype ETAs were constructed and assessed on a melamine simulant. Measurements demonstrated improved nitrogen detection for both prototype ETA configurations when compared to the standard system.

title: Feasibility Analysis of Using POF Sensors for Finger Movement in a Soft Hand Exoskeleton
authors: Juan C. Maldonado-Mejía, Carlos Arturo Narvaéz Delgado, Carlos A. Cifuentes, Marcelo Eduardo Vieira Segatto, Camilo A. R. Díaz
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Measuring finger motion in soft hand exoskeletons remains a challenge due to the nonlinearity and compliance of soft materials. This study evaluates the feasibility of Polymer Optical Fiber (POF) sensors for estimating finger angles in a soft hand exoskeleton. A comparative evaluation was performed against Inertial Measurement Units (IMUs) and a Huskylens camera used as a reference. The test consists of performing repetitions of four movements: depressurized actuator, finger extension, depressurized actuator again, and finger flexion. Two types of analysis were performed: one based on repetitions and another based on the four movements. Results showed that the POF sensor achieved high correlation (r) in both analyses (Repetitions: r>0.98, Movements: r>0.85).

title: Design of a Planar Dual-Band Bandstop Filter with Matryoshka Resonators and Defected Ground Structure
authors: Marcus Estêvão Sousa Lopes, Valdemir Praxedes da Silva Neto
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: In this article, a Planar Dual-Band Bandstop Filter with Matryoshka Resonators and Defected Ground Structure is designed and manufactured. The measured center frequencies of the first and second stopbands are 0.494 GHz and 1.197 GHz, respectively, and the respective fractional bandwidths are 107.49% and 30.16%. The minimum transmission coefficients for the first and second stopband are, respectively, -35.152 dB and -24.959 dB and the maximum reflection coefficients are -0.108 dB and -0.238 dB. The filter has fractional bandwidths higher than the filters of the literature used for comparison, thus indicating its use in applications where this is an advantage.

title: Unlocking the Operational Flexibility of UPS Systems: A Two-Stage Bidding Strategy for Data Centers in Joint Energy and Reserve Markets
authors: Xinru Guan, Yan Sun, Pei Song, Mingjie Yang, Jianyong Gao, Qiong Wang, Xuan Wei, Zhaohao Ding
abstract: With the rapid advancement of artificial intelligence and cloud computing, data centers have become critical infrastructure and are facing persistently rising energy consumption and cost pressure. On the IT side, workload latency tolerance can be exploited through workload execution optimization to reduce costs. On the auxiliary equipment (non-IT) side, uninterruptible power supply (UPS) systems are typically overprovisioned for peak demand and consequently remain underutilized during normal operation. To leverage flexibility from both sides, this paper proposes a two-stage bidding strategy for data centers in joint energy and reserve markets. To capture uncertainties in renewable energy output and workload arrivals in bidding and scheduling, we formulate a two-stage stochastic mixed-integer programming model and solve it via the sample average approximation method. This approach is designed to unlock the operational flexibility of UPS and further balance data center operation reliability with economic efficiency. Numerical experiments verify the proposed method's effectiveness in improving UPS availability and significantly saving energy costs.

title: Design and Optimization Strategies for Streamlined Power Grid Automation Systems
authors: S Chaitrashree, Eleena Mohapatra
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Power grid planning is a crucial stage in System-on-Chip (SoC) physical design, ensuring that voltage is distributed uniformly across logic, memory, and analog regions while minimizing IR-drop, electromigration, and noise issues. Traditional flows rely on manual Tcl scripts, which require repeated customization per block and per technology node. These methods are not scalable, often consume $2-3$ hours of manual effort, and increase susceptibility to human error. This paper presents a Python-driven automation framework for PSDL (Power supply definition Language) based power grid generation. The framework eliminates manual Tcl coding by accepting design specifications such as stripe width, step size, metal layers, offsets, and power domains as input in a structured CSV/XLS file. A Python parser processes this file, dynamically generating PSDL code that defines both pattern specifications and region constraints. The validated script is then executed in Innovus to route the power mesh across multi-layer stacks (M1-M8). Compared with conventional flows, the proposed automation achieved up to a 90% reduction in setup time, cutting power grid creation from 120-180 minutes to under 10 minutes. Additionally, it improved verification reliability by 35%, reduced debugging iterations, and enabled seamless multi-domain support. This structured and reusable approach significantly enhances accuracy, productivity, and scalability in advanced SoC power planning.

title: Comparison of Three Different Antennas Applied to Ka-Band Satellite Communications
authors: Luiza F. Scalão, Maria E. B. dos Santos, Nathani B. dos Santos, Marcos V. T. Heckler, Edson R. Schlosser
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Three different antenna solutions applied to satellite communications (SatCom) in the Ka-Band are proposed in this paper. The design and simulation for all solutions are presented. First, a two-horn array is shown, followed by a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> array of multilayer, circularly polarized microstrip antennas using the sequential rotation technique. Finally, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2} \boldsymbol{\times} \mathbf{1 2}$</tex> circularly polarized reflectarray is demonstrated. The simulated gains of the horn antennas, microstrip array and reflectarray are, respectively, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$23.36 \text{dBi}, 18.8 \text{dBic}$</tex> and 22.8 dBic at 28 GHz. A discussion on the features of each topology is presented at the end of the paper.

title: Benchmarking India’s Agricultural Performance: A Data Visualization Tool for High-Demand Crop Analysis
authors: T.M.N. Vamsi, Aditya Ganti, Lakshmojee Koduru
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: India’s agricultural sector continues to face persistent challenges in meeting global production standards for several highdemand crops. This study aims to identify 25 such crops where India’s output significantly lags behind international benchmarks and to provide actionable insights through an interactive, datadriven visualization tool. Leveraging global datasets, such as data from United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization (UN FAO) spanning 1961 to 2023, the research employs advanced data wrangling and analysis techniques using Excel, Python, and SQL to perform a comprehensive gap analysis between India and leading agricultural nations. The methodology integrates climate, resource availability, and yield potential into a benchmarking framework to assess India’s relative performance. Power BI is used to visualize key findings in the form of dynamic dashboards, enabling stakeholders-such as policymakers, researchers, and agribusinesses-to make informed, evidence-based decisions. By highlighting regional inefficiencies and production deficits, the proposed tool not only fosters long-term agricultural planning but also supports India’s strategic goal of achieving agricultural self-sufficiency and competitiveness in the global market.

title: Lightweight Real-Time Drone Detection and Trajectory Forecasting Using YOLOv8 and LSTM Networks
authors: S V Bhaskar, P Krishna Kowshik Reddy, K Ashraf Ahmed, Levaka Umar Reddy, Nishanth Aluvala
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are becoming increasingly used across civilian and defense sectors, creating a growing demand for systems that can detect and anticipate their movements with minimal delay. In this work, we propose a compact deep learning framework that unites YOLOv8n for drone detection with a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network for trajectory forecasting. The detector identifies drones accurately in each frame, and the LSTM predicts their upcoming positions by learning motion patterns from recent observations. This combination enables early response to aerial intrusions rather than the usual frame-by-frame tracking approach. Our experiments on a drone-specific dataset indicate that the model reaches a mean average precision close to 0.89 and processes around nine frames per second on a standard CPU setup. These outcomes suggest that the system can provide reliable detection and trajectory prediction even on limited hardware, making it practical for field applications like airspace security and surveillance. The lightweight design ensures operational feasibility on low-power platforms, enabling realtime performance without reliance on high-end computing resources

title: Optical System for Identifying the State of Medium Voltage Disconnect Switches
authors: Alex Sandro Ivankio, Juan Camilo Castellanos Rodriguez, Marcos Vinicio Haas Rambo, Uilian José Dreyer
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Electric utility companies have been increasingly investing in technology to enhance the monitoring of assets installed in substations. This monitoring is essential to mitigate failures, avoiding financial and operational losses for consumers. Incorrect operation, for example, incorrect closing, of medium voltage disconnector can result in excessive heating and involuntary shutdowns. This work presents an optical sensing system for the opening of the disconnector, which employs an electronic circuit for signal processing. For the transmission and reception of the laser, a plastic optical fiber sensor was used, connected to a housing where a biconvex lens is coupled. The results demonstrate that the proposed system is efficient in detecting different angular positions of the switch, being able to identify opening angles with contact resistances on the order of micro Ohm. Thus, continuous monitoring of the switch contributes to reducing losses and minimizing maintenance costs.

title: Towards Unified Metaheuristic-Deep Learning Architectures for Cross-Domain Healthcare Diagnostics
authors: G.V. Sriramakrishnan, Balajee Maram
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Healthcare data continues to grow in importance; thus, the need for robust diagnostic tools becomes urgent in multiple fields. Swarm intelligent algorithm with deep learning for cross domain diagnosis in healthcare is the focus of the current study. It proposes an innovative, hybrid approach which interlaces multiple convolutional neural networks with transformers. The model was tested with more than 42,000 patient records across three benchmark datasets in dermatology, cardiology, and neurology. The analysis demonstrated that the system outperformed current methods with an overall 96.8 % diagnostic accuracy, 95.7 % precision, 96.2 % recall, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex>-score of 96.0 %, and 18 % reduced computational load compared to baseline deep learning models. Model convergence time also decreased, by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 1} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex>. Other than deep learning systems, there was robust statistical evidence to suggest the model is transferrable to other systems. The robust, flexible, and computationally efficient framework of the model provides cross-domain clinical decision support that is highly interpretable. The integrated metaheuristic-deep learning approach has proven potential for other domains.

title: Edge Computing with CNN-RNN Hybrids for Autonomous Vehicle Object Detection and Tracking
authors: R. Vani, Manimaran P, Muthumareeswari M, Panparasu P, Rishikanth S
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This paper introduces a CNN-RNN hybrid architecture of edge-optimized system to detect and track real-time objects in self-driving cars. The architecture combines convolutional neural networks with spatial feature detectors and recurrent layers with a temporal sequence detector, which allows it to detect effectively in dynamic settings. KITTI and nuScenes are preprocessed to guarantee that the input is of high quality, and edge deployment is more efficient in the context of limited hardware. The experimental findings show that the suggested model has 96.8% accuracy, has a shorter inference time of 95 ms, and ID switches are 20 percent lower than the current models. Comparison of performance between vehicles and vulnerable road users indicates that there are consistent increases in performance at increased levels of the IOU, which justifies its versatility in the handling of different traffic conditions. Also, model compression algorithm plays a very important role in minimizing deployment overheads, which makes computing edge viable. It is a hybrid solution, which is scalable and practical in terms of intelligent transportation systems, enhancing safety and efficiency in autonomous driving.

title: Cost Allocation Mechanism for Shared Battery Storage Systems: A Game-Theoretic Approach
authors: Anchal Maurya, Harshit Dhiman, Agam Jain, Jeet Vijay Shah, Kartikey Singh Bhadauria, Deep Kiran
abstract: As the cost of battery storage systems (BSS) continues to drop, their efficient utilization in housing and transportation can reduce their operating costs through cooperative sharing among them. Therefore, this paper proposes a cost allocation mechanism to equitably allocate costs among households based on their peak demand by fairly distributing the surplus/deficit of their share in shared BSS at the average/blended price. It presents a method for allocating shares of shared BSS to the households based on their historical peak demand. It is proven that the proposed cost allocation mechanism is subadditive, balanced, and lies in the core of coalition game theory. It also proposes a framework for determining the optimal capacity of a shared BSS based on its amortized investment for a coalition of households and their demand across peak and off-peak periods. Additionally, the amortized investment for which no profit or loss occurs is demonstrated. Overall, the results demonstrate that each household receives a positive and visible profit, transforming economic and social norms that encourage the usage of shared BSS.

title: OTC Platforms in Indian Power Markets – Driving Digitalization and Data Analytics for Economy, Efficiency, and Transparency
authors: Vinod Kumar Agrawal, Sushil Kumr Soonee, Kapil Dev, Ashish Shrivastav, Sahil Kapoor, Nitesh Jha, Gaurav Rupani, Amit Chauhan, Arunima Mishra
abstract: India’s power sector is undergoing a paradigm shift, catalysed by decarbonisation goals and an accelerated push to deepen markets through digitalization. Traditional market mechanisms, centred on long-term PPAs and centralised power exchanges, are now complemented by innovative solutions to offer flexibility, transparency, and efficiency. One such development is ‘Over the Counter (OTC)’ platforms, introduced under CERC Power Market Regulations, 2021, to facilitate customizable, bilateral electricity trading through secure digital infrastructure. This paper shares the experiences towards the launch of India’s first OTC platform, ‘New Age Markets in Electricity (NAME)’, the products operated under it, and the new avenues it is likely to generate. The platform offers tailored market-driven products, operating through a modular, cloud-ready architecture. At the heart of the platform lies an advanced and versatile data repository integrated with powerful analytics. The platform also incorporates a digital financial flow mechanism via a banking system, ensuring secure and automated settlements. By combining market flexibility with digital innovation, OTC platforms bridge key market gaps and support policy objectives in a rapidly evolving market. Going forward, stakeholder collaboration, regulatory alignment, and continued technology-driven enhancements will support towards maximizing platform’s impact on the market.

title: On-Chip vs. Off-Chip FPGA Acceleration for Embedded Neural Networks
authors: Obed K. Allotey Babington, N. Amanquah
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Embedded machine learning systems often struggle to meet real-time requirements because general-purpose micro-controllers lack the computational throughput needed for fast inference. Hardware accelerators offer a solution by boosting inference speed, but in many designs, off-chip accelerators introduce communication overhead that critically degrade system latency. This work examines that bottleneck through a comparative analysis of on-chip versus off-chip FPGA acceleration for embedded neural networks. We evaluate four configurations: baseline inference on both a silicon-based STM32F091RC microcontroller and a MicroBlaze softcore processor, alongside their accelerated variants. Using a Morse code decoding neural network, results demonstrate that on-chip softcore-accelerator integration achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$420 \times$</tex> speedup over its baseline and outperforms the externally accelerated microcontroller by 9362.61 %. This highlights the critical importance of eliminating off-chip communication bottlenecks in embedded machine learning.

title: Anomaly Detection of Telemetry Data Based on Time-Frequency Contrastive Learning
authors: Zhipeng Wang, Weiping Yang, Kankan Wu, Yuchen Song, Yu Peng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Anomaly detection plays a key role in the reliable and efficient operation of the satellite. However, most current algorithms tend to focus more on modeling the data in the time domain or frequency domain for anomaly detection. With the increasing complexity of satellite missions and the extension of satellite lifespans, telemetry data exhibit more intricate timefrequency characteristics. Existing anomaly detection models tend to be insufficient in capturing the correlations between temporal and frequency features, which constrains their overall representation capability and may lead to false alarms or missed detections. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an anomaly detection approach that integrates contrastive learning with time-frequency augmentation into a data-driven reconstruction framework. First, the encoder is pre-trained through time-frequency contrastive learning, where temporal and frequency views of the telemetry sequences are exploited to obtain discriminative feature representations. Then, a decoder is appended to the pre-trained encoder, and the entire autoencoder is retrained by minimizing the reconstruction loss to enhance its representation and reconstruction capability. Finally, anomaly detection is performed by computing the reconstruction error of test samples, where deviations beyond a predefined threshold are identified as anomalies. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed anomaly detection method achieves superior detection performance on the real satellite telemetry data set.

title: Modified Direct Power Control of Photovoltaic to Grid tied Voltage Source Converter with Active Filtering Capability
authors: Praveen Vankadari, Korivi Yogananda Reddy, Sree Hari J B, Akshay Chabukswar, Avinash Naramu, Rupesh Wandhare
abstract: Renewable-based distributed generation (DG) systems have helped ease the growing power demand on the utility grid. However, the proliferation of consumer-side electronic devices, which are increasingly designed for compactness and efficiency, has introduced a large number of nonlinear loads. The presence of such nonlinear loads significantly deteriorates grid power quality through current harmonics, voltage distortions, and non-unity power factor, which cannot be effectively mitigated by simple renewable energy integration. This paper proposes a One-Step Prediction–based Direct Power Control (OSP-DPC) strategy for a photovoltaic (PV) system–integrated Voltage Source Converter (VSC), while enabling simultaneous renewable energy integration and active power filtering. The method maintains constant switching frequency and mitigates drawbacks of variable switching frequency schemes such as EMI/EMC issues and higher switching losses. A perturb-and-observe (P&O)–based MPPT and instantaneous pq-theory–based power extraction is employed to enhance system dynamic performance. Finally, the simulation results presents the effectiveness of the proposed strategy under various irradiance conditions.

title: Prescribed Performance Output Containment of Heterogeneous Multi-Agent Systems With Non-periodic Intermittent Communication
authors: Yanpeng Shi, Jiangping Hu, Baogen Song, Peng Li, Lei Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper investigates the output containment tracking problem in general heterogeneous multi-agent systems facing prescribed performance and intermittent communication. In this case, a novel non-periodic intermittent control framework is introduced to facilitate the intricate nature of the complex network to achieve the containment objective. First, an intermittent communication network is built by introducing a novel intermittent interval condition combining average dwell-time and extreme value theories into the directed graph. Second, a distributed non-periodic intermittent containment control strategy is designed, utilizing an internal system and a modified containment control approach. Subsequently, a distributed prescribed performance hybrid controller is developed to achieve output containment tracking. Additionally, sufficient conditions for the exponential stability are obtained based on the non-periodic intermittent and prescribed performance control methods. This criterion adopts the characterization of the average time interval. The effectiveness of the designed hybrid control strategy is verified by the simulation example, showcasing its advantage to solve the challenges in intermittent communication and prescribed performance.

title: Design and Simulation Analysis of a Synchronous Clamping Device for Banana Pseudo-Stems in Cableway Transportation
authors: Guo J., Xia S., Qiu J.G., Zhang X.R.
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: Cableway transport is a critical step in the post-harvest handling of bananas, and its effectiveness fundamentally relies on the reliable clamping of the banana pseudo-stem. Traditional rope-tying methods suffer from issues such as insecure clamping, susceptibility of banana bunches to falling, fruit damage due to impact, and low automation levels. To address these problems, this paper presents the design and development of an automatic clamping device for banana pseudo-stems used in cableway transport of banana bunches. The device employs an internal ring gear-pinion-clamping rack transmission mechanism, driven by a single electric actuator, to achieve synchronous radial movement of four clamping racks. The device parameters were determined through transmission system design and theoretical strength checks, while 3D modeling and static finite element simulations were completed using SolidWorks software. The results show that the working stress of the key load-bearing component (the clamping rack) under the rated load is 41.5 MPa, resulting in a safety factor of 4.94. Furthermore, under the ultimate load, the structure deforms only elastically, indicating a sufficient strength margin. Furthermore, the maximum strain of the banana pseudo-stem under the rated clamping force is 0.243, effectively avoiding crushing damage. The findings demonstrate that this clamping device achieves secure, stable, and non-damaging clamping of banana pseudo-stems, providing an effective technical solution to the problems of bunch drop and damage during cableway transport.

title: An Integrated Approach for Fault Diagnosis and Localization in DC Microgrid
authors: Anu Bhalla, Bhavesh R. Bhalja
abstract: An accurate fault diagnosis, classification and location estimation are essential for rapid maintenance and restoration of power. To address time-critical DC network faults, this research presents a novel scheme for the protection of low-voltage DC microgrid (LVDCM). Fault diagnosis and classification are achieved by observing the difference of variance in current signals from both ends of the cable. Subsequently, to locate the fault, the cable inductance up to the point of fault occurrence and the total cable inductance are computed using the recursive least square error technique. The presented strategy confirms the fault as an internal fault if the computed fault location is less than 1 p.u. The genuineness of the presented approach is examined through its implementation on multiple fault scenarios under different microgrid operating modes and topologies in a mesh-connected LVDCM using PSCAD/EMTDC. Comparative analysis of the developed scheme with the other existing algorithms clearly highlights the superior performance in terms of better selectivity, rapid fault diagnosis, and consistent performance amid noise.

title: Fuzzy-Based Dynamic Weight Optimization for Handover in SDN-VANET
authors: Do Binh Gia Huy, Chu Thi Phuong Dung, Dinh Thi Thai Mai
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This study presents a fuzzy logic-based method for optimizing handover decisions in SoftwareDefined Networking Vehicular Ad Hoc Network (SDN-VANET). The proposed system dynamically adjusts the weighting factor <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\lambda$</tex> in the Optimal Cluster Head formula, based on Signal-to-Interference and Noise Ratio (SINR) and vehicle density. Unlike static approaches, the proposed algorithm adaptively balances signal quality and load. Via emulation in Mininet-WiFi, the model outperforms SSF and LLF in terms of throughput, delay, and handover failure under dense traffic scenarios.

title: Interval Principal Component Analysis for Fault Detection under Measurement Uncertainty
authors: Anissa Ben Aicha, Raoudha Bel Hadj Ali, Majdi Mansouri, Kamel Belkhiria
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: In this study, we present a novel approach for detecting faults in static systems with uncertain, interval-type data. Unlike traditional methods that treat measurements as exact values, our approach accounts for inherent uncertainties by modeling system variables as intervals. We develop an intervalvalued Principal Component Analysis (PCA) model using the method of Surya et al., which captures the dominant modes of variation while quantifying the uncertainty in both eigenvalues and eigenvectors. To evaluate fault detection, we introduce global interval-based detection indicators that robustly identify deviations caused by faults, even under significant uncertainty. Through a simulated example of a seven-variable system, we demonstrate that our method not only detects faults effectively but also distinguishes between different fault magnitudes and locations. The results show that certain indicators outperform others in clarity and sensitivity, providing practical guidance for real-time monitoring. Overall, this work offers a reliable framework for fault detection in uncertain systems, combining rigorous interval analysis with intuitive, interpretable indicators, and sets the stage for future applications in industrial and safetycritical environments.

title: Multistage 5.75-GHz High-Efficiency and High-Gain Amplifier as DC-RF Power Converter for SSPS
authors: Ryo Ishikawa, Kazuhiko Honjo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: A high-efficiency and high-gain microwave power amplifier to convert DC power from solar power generation to microwave power has been developed for Space Solar Power System (SSPS). The microwave power amplifier is required to have high-gain characteristics, as well as high-efficiency performance, in order to reduce the power consumption at the front signal processing system. In addition, it is also required to be compact, since a huge number of amplifiers are arranged in an array antenna system. The fabricated multistage power amplifier exhibited a maximum power-added efficiency of of 69%, and a gain of 35.1 dB at 5.75 GHz.

title: Analysis of Emotional Evolution for Public Opinion in Sudden Events Based on Big Data
authors: Yizhuo Chen, Chengcheng Yu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: In the context of emergencies, accurately and reasonably analyzing netizens' attention and emotional attitudes in the emergency management of online public opinion is one of the important reference means to control the development of public opinion, guide the development of public opinion, and ensure social stability. Taking the "Typhoon Capricorn" emergency as an example, Python is first used for data collection; secondly, TF-IDF (term frequency–inverse document frequency) is used to eliminate duplicate data of public opinion texts and extract key data; then the sentiment analysis module of the third-party Python library (i.e. SnowNLP) is used to perform sentiment analysis of online comments. By analyzing the public opinion hotspots, public opinion stages, and public opinion emotions of netizens' comments, suggestions for responding to online public opinion are explored from the aspects of public opinion monitoring, precise response to public opinion, netizens' emotional tendencies, public emotional guidance, and media influence, in order to provide the government with a more accurate, detailed, and humanized situation analysis reference in the handling of public opinion emotions in emergencies.

title: MedPredict: A Prototype System for Integrated Machine Learning-Based Disease Prediction
authors: Nur Athirah Mohd Abu Bakar, Hannah Kamillia Hamidi, Nurazlin Zainal Azmi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: The rise in chronic and non-communicable diseases (NCDs) such as diabetes, heart disease, kidney conditions, and breast cancer has underscored the need for early diagnosis and preventive strategies. Traditional diagnostic approaches often involve complex procedures and specialist interpretation, delaying timely intervention. This paper presents MedPredict, a prototype of an intelligent, web-based disease prediction system that leverages machine learning to assist in the early detection of multiple health conditions. Developed with an integrated architecture, the prototype includes modules for diabetes, heart disease, breast cancer, and kidney disease, each employing tailored ML algorithms trained on public datasets. Evaluation through functional, integration, and usability testing demonstrated positive outcomes, with prediction accuracies ranging from 76% to 98% and high user satisfaction in terms of interface usability and clarity of results. MedPredict aims to complement clinical decision-making and support public health efforts by providing an accessible, non-invasive tool for proactive healthcare.

title: Modeling and Analysis of Ferroresonance in Renewable Energy Sources
authors: Mario López Albiter, V. Torres-García, N. Solís-Ramos, S. Ramírez-Zavala
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: Nowadays, the renewable energy networks are designed for transmission and distribution using underground systems. Such systems minimize visual impact, reduce congestion, and increase security and reliability. However, the technology utilized has increased the capacitance effect, which can lead to the system being more susceptible to the occurrence of the ferroresonance phenomenon. Ferroresonance can cause dielectric or thermal damage and consequently makes the system susceptible to faults in the electrical power equipment and installations. This paper analyzes the numerical solution of an RLC circuit considering the nonlinearity of the inductor through a hyperbolic sine function, validating the data obtained with a simulation of voltage, current and magnetic flux. Subsequently, the ferroresonance phenomenon in photovoltaic parks is analyzed to detect possible ferroresonance conditions.

title: Modeling and Simulation of 28 GHz mmWave MIMO Heterogeneous Networks in the Tripoli Urban Area
authors: Sara Fkini, Amer R. Zerek
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Heterogeneous Networks (HetNets) that combine a 3.5 GHz macro-cellular layer with a 28 GHz millimeter-wave (mmWave) small cell layer are a foundational architecture for 5G. While the mmWave layer offers vast bandwidth compatible with massive MIMO, its challenging propagation characteristics in urban environments necessitate detailed system-level analysis. This paper presents a dynamic simulation of a 5G HetNet, geographically anchored to the urban area of Tripoli, Libya. Using a framework based on 3GPP TR 38.901 channel models, the simulation identifies a critical performance bottleneck: “cell dominance,” where the superior propagation of the macro layer leads to congestion, leaving the high-capacity mmWave layer severely underutilized. To solve this, we investigate an aggressive Cell Selection Offsetting (CSO) strategy. Our findings demonstrate that 25 dB CSO effectively offloads users to the mmWave layer, resulting in a 19.9% increase in average user throughput with only a minor 0.89 dB decrease in average Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio (SINR). This study validates CSO as a critical optimization technique for 5G deployments in Tripoli.

title: Tumor Detection Using Reduced Order Modeling in Digital Image Elasto Tomography
authors: Fahiza Fauz, Imran Akhtar, Tahir Zaidi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Digital Image Elasto Tomography (DIET) offers an economical and non-invasive way to identify variations in breast tissue stiffness. This paper presents a framework for reduced-order modelling that uses Fourier-Bessel modal analysis and single-frequency excitation to make tissue characterisation easier. The surface of the breast is modelled as a circular elastic membrane, and the vibration data that were recorded are examined to obtain Fourier-Bessel coefficients that characterise mechanical actions. The corresponding mode shapes are rebuilt to show the patterns of deformation associated with inclusions of tumors. Tests carried out on ten breast phantoms with different depths and sizes of inclusions show notable differences in the spatial mode and coefficient values distributions between healthy and tumorous cases. The proposed approach effectively reduces computational complexity while preserving diagnostic sensitivity. Across ten phantom trials, the method achieved 87% sensitivity, 82% specificity, and 85% overall accuracy, confirming reliable detection of stiffness anomalies using only the dominant Fourier–Bessel coefficients. These results confirm that the method enables reliable tumor localization and provides a promising foundation for scalable, real-time, and low-cost breast cancer screening systems.

title: Development and Application of a Graphical Automatic Programming System for Multi-Groove Shaft CNC Machining
authors: Lili Lin
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: To solve the problems of low programming efficiency and cumbersome parameter verification caused by variable dimensions in the batch processing of multi-groove shafts, a graphical automatic programming system was built based on the Fanuc 31i CNC system and Fanuc Picture development environment, integrating macro program compilation and parametric interface technologies. By extracting variable parameters of multi-groove shafts to design the interface, associating controls with macro variables via read-write functions, compiling and integrating part family macro programs, and importing data files through parameter configuration, the system enables programming and processing of dedicated shaft part families by inputting parameters graphically on the CNC interface. Practical application shows it shortens setup and debugging time, improves efficiency and safety. This technical approach provides a feasible solution for the development of dedicated CNC programming functions and is suitable for batch processing of similar parts.

title: Prompted Vs. Organic Customer Insight: Comparing the Value of Focus Groups and Online Reviews in Product and Service Innovation
authors: Maren Schnieder, Ana Isabel Canhoto, Ramin Behbehani, Ahmad Beltagui, Niraj Kumar, Amirreza Alizamani
abstract: The rapid proliferation and widespread accessibility of electronic word of mouth (eWoM) have sparked a wave of interest in leveraging these sources to guide product and service innovations. While breakthroughs in natural language processing (NLP) are rapidly accelerating, it is important to understand how these data sources themselves differ from more traditional options such as surveys, interviews and focus groups. This paper compares focus groups and online reviews to identify their differences and to highlight how both can complement each other. The study explores both data sources using a thematic analysis and zero-shot text classification, respectively. Results show that prompted (i.e. focus groups) and organic sources (i.e. online reviews) can yield different insights in terms of coverage, granularity, timespan and so forth. Neither one nor the other emerges as a superior data source in this study, as they appear complementary. As online reviews are often written after a delightful or unpleasant experience, their detailed and timely insights may position them as a viable choice for incremental innovation. While focus groups may be the ideal environment for participants to imagine and explore radical innovations, many of the recommendations, as well as concerns, were at least implied in a handful of online reviews. Considering the abundance of online reviews and advances in NLP, even a negligible share may be sufficient to derive insights for radical innovation.

title: From contrast-driven segmentation to central lumbar spinal stenosis grading: a comprehensive multi-view spinal MRI image analysis
authors: Zhengchao Zhou, Pingping Wang, Xinggui Ji, Wanbo Xu, Zhongyi Han, Benzheng Wei
abstract: Central lumbar spinal stenosis, a prevalent degenerative spinal disorder, severely impacts the quality of life for those affected. Axial and sagittal MRI images offer diverse information on tissue structure and lesions, which is crucial for accurate diagnosis. However, MRI-based diagnostic approaches still have poor lesion localization, insufficient cross-view alignment, underutilization of multi-view MRI information, and limited generalization across patient variability. To address these problems, we proposed an Encompassing Lumbar Central Spinal Stenosis Grading Model via Multi-view MRI Image Fusion called ELSG-MF. ELSG-MF consists of three stages: the first stage utilizes the extraction of robust pseudo-labels through a contrast-driven consistency reinforcement technique to guide Med-SAM in localizing and segmenting spinal tissue components. The Sagittal-Axial Pairing (SAP) Algorithm was developed by stage2 to integrate the spatial anatomical relationship between the vertebral body and the intervertebral disc, facilitating the correlation pairing between sagittal and axial images. Stage3 subsequently innovated the multi-view Adaptive Fusion (M²AF) module, which enables adaptive dynamic fusion of anatomical features across views. M²AF enhances the extraction of contextual complementary information, and significantly improves the model’s capacity to detect subtle variations in the degree of narrowness. A series of studies show that our model achieves an overall accuracy of 0.8631, AUC of 0.96, and F1-score of 0.8614. These results indicate that our model substantially outperforms mainstream approaches, attaining superior segmentation and grading accuracy, exhibiting robust generalization and clinical application potential.

title: A 94.8-nW Battery-Free Intelligent Silicon Platform for Distributed Multimodal Sensing With Adaptive and Event-Driven Computing
authors: Haochen Zhang, Wei-Han Yu, Zhongyu Zhao, Zhizhan Yang, Ka-Fai Un, Jun Yin, Rui P. Martins, Pui-In Mak
abstract: This article presents an ultralow-power (ULP), battery-free intelligent silicon platform for distributed, multimodal sensing with adaptive, event-driven computing in edge devices. The proposed silicon platform incorporates hardware–software co-design in the implementation. At the algorithm level, a lightweight forward-forward (Lite-FF) algorithm is proposed to enable: 1) distributed model training with low-bitwidth operation and a small memory footprint and 2) event-driven feature transmission. At the circuit level, the digital compute-in-memory (CIM) architecture is employed to accelerate multiply-and-accumulate (MAC) operations with two key features for computation energy efficiency improvement: 1)a sparsity-adaptive input scheduler (SAIS) to skip redundant activation bit-level computations and 2) a sign-magnitude bit-significance accumulator (SM-BSA) to reduce bitline toggling by leveraging weight sparsity in sign-magnitude format. Fabricated in 65-nm CMOS, the silicon platform consumes 94.8 and 340.4nW in inference and training mode, respectively. Evaluated on a condition-based monitoring (CbM) task, the proposed framework can achieve a classification accuracy of 90.6% with dual-modal sensing while demonstrating the ability of on-chip training. The proposed compute engine can achieve a peak energy efficiency of 10.7 fJ/MAC at a 0.4-V supply voltage, outperforming the state-of-the-art nanowatt-class neural network (NN) accelerators by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.76\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula>.

title: Multi-sensor bearing fault diagnosis based on the improved DIVERSIFY under multiple unknown working conditions
authors: Yichao Li, Yanfang Liu, Xiangyang Xu, Zhongjing Yu, Peng Dong, Shuhan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Existing solutions for bearing fault diagnosis often exhibit a considerable decline in performance when faced with multiple unknown working conditions, a critical out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization challenge. To address this, this paper introduces an improved DIVERSIFY framework with two key enhancements. Firstly, to overcome the critical issue of baseline DIVERSIFY requiring manual tuning for the number of latent domains, we propose a novel identification algorithm underpinned by a unique Kullback-Leibler (KL)-Log metric. This metric’s innovation lies in its ability to transform the continuous KL-divergence value into a discrete, integer-based format, which enables a direct and rule-based determination of the number of domains from the data distribution itself. Secondly, to adapt the DIVERSIFY structure for complex multi-sensor scenarios, a multi-sensor convolution fusion block (MCFB) is designed with a parallel multi-kernel architecture. By simultaneously employing convolutional kernels of varying sizes, the MCFB explicitly captures and fuses both intricate short-term local features and essential long-range temporal dependencies from multi-sensor signals. Comprehensive validation on a series of OOD generalization tasks demonstrates the method’s superiority. The proposed framework achieves average diagnostic accuracies of 97.41%, 95.20%, and 88.63% in challenging scenarios with one, two, and three unknown working conditions, respectively, significantly outperforming the baseline and other state-of-the-art approaches.

title: Revolutionizing C++ Programming Education: A Gamified Interactive Educational Game
authors: Dung Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: C++ is a foundational programming language in university curricula, including in Vietnam, but its abstract concepts and syntax complexity present significant learning challenges, often causing student disengagement, particularly for beginners. To address these issues, this paper introduces a game-based learning (GBL) approach using a structured educational game to improve student engagement and competence in fundamental C++. The game features three progressive levels—from logic puzzles, to interactive code manipulation, and finally writing full code—to gradually build problem-solving and coding skills. Designed for first-year students, this approach focuses on foundational skills, excluding advanced topics like OOP. The method was evaluated with 166 first-year students in a C++ programming course through classroom experiments, learning achievement tests, and learner satisfaction assessments. The results showed that students using the game achieved a significantly higher average performance (mean score of 88.35) compared to peers in traditional settings (mean score of 75.66), and 95.0% expressed high satisfaction with learning C++ through the game. The findings also indicated that learning through games encouraged active participation and improved students' ability to understand programming concepts. This research highlights the efficacy of GBL in software engineering education and offers a practical framework for improving C++ instruction in Vietnamese higher education contexts. Future work may explore expanding the game to include advanced topics and other programming languages.

title: Road Design Optimization to Reduce Pedestrian Delays Validated Through Microsimulation
authors: Iain Antezana, John Nicho, Manuel Silvera, Daniel Palacios
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: Pedestrian accessibility is a critical component of urban sustainability and public safety. In many Latin American cities, inadequate intersection design contributes to delays and heightened risks for pedestrians. This study examines an intersection in Lima, Peru, characterized by poor signage and inefficient geometry. Tools such as AutoCAD, PTV VISSIM, and drones were used to model the current conditions and develop road redesign proposals based on recommendations from the National Association of City Transportation Officials (NACTO). Through microsimulation analysis, the impact of the proposed improvements was evaluated, including geometric optimization and the redistribution of space between pedestrians and vehicles. The results show a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0. 4 \%}$</tex> reduction in pedestrian travel times and an increase in safety, highlighting the effectiveness of interventions focused on sustainable mobility. This work contributes to urban planning by offering a replicable model for improving accessibility in similar areas.

title: Research on the deep feature representation method for digital management of museums
authors: Zheng Li
abstract: This study introduces a symbolic, multi-layered approach that bridges semantic reasoning with dynamic digital environments. Existing solutions for managing structured cultural data often rely on rigid database schemas or brittle machine learning pipelines that struggle with semantic drift, context adaptation, and domain-specific fidelity. These traditional models lack mechanisms to maintain consistent, explainable knowledge evolution, and often fail to integrate heterogeneous inputs such as ontologies, visitor interactions, and metadata constraints. In response, we propose an integrated system architecture that comprises a symbolic repository layer, a formal reasoning engine, a temporal interaction graph, and a consistency controller—jointly orchestrated through a semantic framework named CuratoSynth. This orchestration enables adaptive knowledge alignment by encoding interpretive intentions and synthesizing them with evolving user behavior patterns. Our model ensures contextual integrity through logic-based rule enforcement and supports intelligent curatorial decision-making via automated inference and constraint propagation. Experimental simulations confirm the method’s robustness in sustaining ontological compliance and semantic continuity over time, significantly outperforming baseline approaches in both interpretive accuracy and system transparency. This work offers a scalable, explainable, and domain-grounded framework for the intelligent digital orchestration of cultural knowledge systems.

title: Reconstructing Subsurface Ocean Temperature from Sea Surface Multivariate Remote Sensing Data using CSSP-ConvLSTM
authors: Jie Sun, Jungang Yang, Wei Cui, Ole Baltazar Andersen, Jiawei Xun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: The three-dimensional ocean temperature field plays a critical role in studies of global climate change, carbon cycling, and ocean dynamics. Subsurface temperature reconstruction, particularly within the thermocline, remains insufficient due to limitations in observational coverage and modeling frameworks. To address this challenge, we propose CSSP-ConvLSTM (CNN–Swin Transformer Spatial Parallel ConvLSTM), a subsurface temperature reconstruction model that integrates multi-source sea surface remote-sensing data. The model employs a spatial dual-branch structure and a temporal enhancement mechanism to achieve multi-scale characterization of local details, global dependencies, and nonlinear evolution. When applied to the northwestern Pacific (30–1000 m), reconstruction accuracy is significantly improved compared with single-branch or single-model baselines, with an average R² of 0.9811 and RMSE of 0.4557 °C reconstruction errors are markedly reduced within the thermocline (100–600 m) and deep layers (800–1000 m). Independent evaluations using ARMOR3D and EN4 datasets are conducted, confirming strong temporal generalization, stability, and physical consistency. Interpretability analysis based on SHAP indicates that shallow temperatures are primarily influenced by SST and SSH, whereas subsurface and deep layers are more affected by SSS and SSH. These results demonstrate that CSSP-ConvLSTM provides an effective approach for reconstructing high-resolution three-dimensional (3D) ocean temperature fields, and facilitates improved understanding of thermocline dynamics and their potential climatic implications.

title: Experimental and numerical study on the AC loss of HTS REBCO winding for fully superconducting electrical machine
authors: Jun Ma, Xuezhi Luo, Hanlin Zhu, Bin Feng, Zhixuan Zhang, Finn Sutcliffe, Yameng Zhang, Yingjie Guan, Chao Yuan, Phil Mellor, Nick Simpson
abstract: In superconducting electrical machines, the HTS windings are used to replace traditional copper armature windings to improve the power density. However, the HTS armature windings produce AC loss when carrying AC currents under AC magnetic fields in superconducting electrical machines. It affects the efficiency of the superconducting electrical machines. In this paper, a full-scale HTS REBCO armature winding is wound based on our 10kW superconducting synchronous electrical machine design, and the corresponding finite element model is also built based on T-A formulation. Under different amplitudes and frequencies of the AC currents, the AC transport loss of the HTS REBCO winding is analyzed by simulation and experiment. The results show that the simulation and the experiment have good consistency. Meanwhile, the AC magnetization loss of the HTS REBCO winding is analyzed by simulation under different amplitudes of the AC magnetic fields. We find that the magnetization loss is much higher than the AC transport loss of the HTS REBCO windings. Finally, under different amplitudes of the AC currents and AC magnetic fields, the total AC loss of the HTS REBCO winding is also analyzed. This work is the first step towards R&D of high power density superconducting electrical machines for future electric aircraft.

title: From Keywords to Context: An AI Agent for Natural Language Document Lookup in the Enterprise
authors: Hieu Le Ngoc
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Traditional keyword search fails to unlock knowledge from unstructured enterprise data. This paper introduces an AI agent that improves document lookup using a hybrid Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pipeline, which combines sparse, dense, and reranking techniques for high accuracy. The agent is made extensible with the Model Context Protocol (MCP) for external tool use, such as web searches. Our approach achieves a state-of-the-art nDCG@5 of 0.91, significantly outperforming keyword search (0.62) and standard RAG (0.76), while also enabling conversational queries, multidocument synthesis, and external knowledge integration.

title: Transformer-Based Segmentation of Pituitary-related Structures in T1CE MRI Using Swin-Unet
authors: Woojae Hong, Seong-Min Kim, Joongyeon Choi, So Won Oh, Hyunggun Kim, Yong Hwy Kim
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Accurate segmentation of pituitary adenoma (PA), pituitary gland (PG), and internal carotid artery (ICA) in contrast-enhanced T1-weighted (T1CE) coronal MRI is essential for diagnosis and treatment planning. A transformer-based segmentation model using Swin-Unet was proposed, and the effects of image preprocessing strategies and loss functions were investigated. A retrospective dataset of 255 patients was analyzed, with manual annotations serving as the ground truth. Preprocessing strategies including N4 bias correction, WhiteStrip and Z-score normalization, and resampling/cropping were evaluated. Several loss functions, including combo loss, Dice loss, and focal loss, were systematically compared. Swin-Unet was benchmarked against a classical U-Net baseline. Segmentation results revealed that Swin-Unet with resampling, cropping, and White-Strip normalization achieved the highest Dice similarity coefficients (DSCs) of 0.825 for PA, 0.565 for PG, and 0.716 for ICA. Swin-Unet demonstrated markedly improved segmentation performance, especially for PG, compared to U-Net (mean DSC = 0.613). These findings suggest that transformer-based architecture models, combined with appropriate preprocessing and loss optimization, can provide a promising framework for accurate and reliable segmentation of pituitary-related structures.

title: Advanced Deep Residual Network Architectures for Accurate Liver and Tumor Segmentation in Medical Imaging
authors: Ghada Douzi, Imen Werda, Amna Maraoui
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: In recent years, deep learning architectures have significantly transformed medical image segmentation. This study compares two leading models, U-Net(U-shaped Network) and ResUNet(Residual U-net), for liver and tumor segmentation using the LiTS17(Liver Tumor Segmentation Challenge 2017) dataset. U-Net, known for its symmetric encoder-decoder design and skip connections, has become a standard in medical imaging applications. ResUNet extends U-Net by incorporating residual blocks, which improve gradient flow and promote feature reuse. Experimental results indicate that ResUNet surpasses U-Net in Dice Score, training loss, edge precision, and computational efficiency, highlighting the advantages of residual learning in enhancing segmentation performance for complex anatomical structures.

title: Deep Ensemble Learning for Robust Detection of Lung Cancer Using Multi-modal Imaging Data
authors: P. Loganathan, D Prameen, Bhupesh Goyal, P. Narmatha, Manidipa Roy, J. Noor Ahamed
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Accurate early diagnosis of lung cancer is difficult because of modality-specific high noise, low contrast, and intermodality imaging heterogeneity on Computed Tomography (CT), Positron Emission Tomography (PET), and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI). In this paper, we propose a Deep Ensemble Learning Framework (DELF) that exploits complementary structural, metabolic, and soft-tissue characteristics via adaptive multi-modal fusion. DELF employs a 3D CNN (CT), a convolutional Autoencoder (PET), and a Vision Transformer-based network (MRI) in an attention-mediated probabilistic ensemble. An uncertainty-aware meta-learner adaptively redistributes modality weights to improve robustness in the presence of noise or data scarcity. Experiments on LIDC-IDRI, PET/CT, and BraTS datasets show that DELF achieves AUC is 0.974 and F1-score is 0.950, outperforming the state-of-the-art fusion and stacking ensemble by up to $2.6 \%$. Cross-modal attention maps, when visualised, show interpretable tumour localisation consistent with radiologist annotations. Near-real-time inference (Approx. 0.4 s per scan) and uncertainty-quantified predictions were obtained with the proposed framework, providing a reliable, clinically configurable solution for multimodal lung cancer screening.

title: A Machine Learning-based Comparative Analysis of Feature Ranking Algorithms for Prioritizing In-Silico Pathogenicity Prediction Methods for Somatic Driver Mutation Classification in Breast Cancer
authors: Subrata Das, Arnab Mukherjee, Arnab Ghosh, Nidhan K. Biswas, Anirban Mukhopadhyay
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Feature selection is a critical component of machine learning, especially effective for analyzing high-dimensional biological data with complex, non-linear relationships. A key challenge in cancer genomics is prioritizing mutations, i.e., classifying pathogenic drivers from non-drivers mutations. Existing numerous pathogenic and conservational scoring algorithms (PCSAs) often shows significantly discordant predictions. Therefore, choosing the right set of PCSAs depending on their performance in distinguishing driver mutations is thus of critical importance and essentially a feature selection problem. In this study, we utilize a dataset of missense mutations from $\mathbf{1, 0 0 9}$ breast cancer patients. We annotated these mutations with 41 PCSAs which act as features. To estimates the feature importance, we employed Random Forest classifiers coupled with three different Feature Ranking Methods (FRM) - Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE), SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), and Mean Decrease in Impurity (MDI) and evaluated the performance of each FRM in ranking these PCSAs. While classifiers built using top-ranked PCSAs resulting from all three FRMs performed well, the RFEbased model slightly performed better than others. DEOGEN2 consistently ranked as the top PCSA, along with MVP, MPC, and integrated_fitCons frequently appearing in the top ranks. These findings not only assess the utility of the studied FRMs but yield a robust set of PCSAs that are highly effective in separating pathogenic drivers from non-driver mutations in breast cancer.

title: LL-ViT: Edge Deployable Vision Transformers with Look Up Table Neurons
authors: Shashank Nag, Alan T.L. Bacellar, Zachary Susskind, Anshul Jha, Logan Liberty, Aishwarya Sivakumar, Eugene B. John, Krishnan Kailas, Priscila M.V. Lima, Neeraja J. Yadwadkar, Felipe M.G. França, Lizy K. John
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Vision Transformers have been tremendously successful in computer vision tasks. However, their large computational, memory, and energy demands are a challenge for edge inference on FPGAs - a field that has seen a recent surge in demand. We recognize the benefits of recent works on logic and Look Up Table (LUT) based networks, such as LogicNets, NeuraL Ut,Dwn, among others, in offering models that simultaneously reduce both the memory and compute footprints. However, these models natively do not perform well on common vision tasks, such as CIFAR-10/100. In this work, we propose LL-ViT, a novel edge optimized vision transformer design that integrates layers of LUT neurons within the transformer architecture. Based on our characterization that reveals that a majority of model weights and computations are from the channel mixer (MLP layer), we design an alternate LUT-based channel mixer, and simultaneously develop an FPGA-based accelerator for LL-ViT. Contrary to some attempts to replace each multiplication with a table lookup, our architecture utilizes a neural learning approach which natively learns the LUT functions. This approach allows for reduced model sizes, and a computational and energy-efficient inference solution for vision transformer models. Evaluating on edge-suitable workloads, we achieve accuracies of 95.5% on CIFAR-10, 78.8% on CIFAR-100, and 60.9% on Tiny-ImageNet datasets, comparable to the baseline transformer. LL- ViT eliminates over 60% of the model weights and 50 % of the multiplications in the model, and achieves 1.9× energy efficiency and 1.3 × lower latency over an integer quantized <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$V$</tex>iT accelerator, while also offering superior throughput against prior works at a 10.9W power budget.
