title: Convolutional Block Attention Module for Enhanced Batik Image Synthesis
authors: Agus Eko Minarno, Galih Wasis Wicaksono, Denar Regata Akbi, Hardianto Wibowo
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper presents an innovative approach to digitally recreating batik, an intricate Indonesian textile art form characterized by complex hand-drawn patterns and rich cultural heritage, using an advanced artificial intelligence approach. We enhance Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) with a Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) to better capture and reproduce the sophisticated patterns, color variations, and detailed motifs characteristic of traditional batik designs. The study systematically evaluates three different configurations of CBAM implementation: within residual blocks (Batik GAN CA-R), combined with down-sampling and residual blocks (Batik GAN CA-RD), and integrated into up-sampling and residual blocks (Batik GAN CA-RU). Our innovative approach yielded impressive results in generating authentic-looking batik patterns, with metrics showing high-quality image generation: a Fréchet Inception Distance (FID) score of 13.863, demonstrating strong similarity to real batik patterns, a Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) of 24.859, indicating excellent image quality, and a Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) of 0.901, confirming high structural fidelity. These strong performance indicators demonstrate the model's effectiveness in preserving and reproducing the sophisticated details of traditional batik patterns, contributing significantly to both digital art advancement and cultural preservation efforts. The proposed method shows promise for applications in digital textile design, cultural heritage documentation, and automated batik pattern generation.

title: Designing for Anonymity in Social Networking Platform for Student Mental Health and Well-Being
authors: Hazwani Mohd Mohadis, Muhammad Hadwan Mohd Hisham, Muhammad Danial Mohd Zahri, Mohamad Hidir Mhd Salim, Zulfikar Ahmed Maher
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: The rise of digital communication has transformed how students seek support for their mental health and well-being. However, stigma and fear of judgment continue to hinder open self-expression. This study presents the design and development of BeyondWords, a mobile application that serves as an anonymous social networking platform, providing university students with a safe space to share personal confessions, emotional expressions, life experiences, challenges, and vulnerabilities. The platform was developed based on a user requirements analysis conducted through interviews and questionnaires, which revealed that 80% of respondents considered anonymity crucial for self-expression, while 90% believed it protects privacy and reduces fear of judgment. Participants emphasized that anonymity enables them to express their burdens and emotions freely, fostering a sense of relief and emotional support. To address these needs, BeyondWords incorporates features such as anonymous posting, interactive feedback, content moderation, and community engagement. This work highlights the pivotal role of anonymity in digital social platforms in creating safe spaces that effectively support student mental health and well-being.

title: Robust Control Framework for a Grid-Connected PV/FC Hybrid System
authors: Abdel Aitouche, Dhaker Abbes, Haoping Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper proposes a robust control framework for a grid-connected hybrid energy system integrating photovoltaic (PV) panels and proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFC). A fuzzy logic-based maximum power point tracking (MPPT) algorithm is implemented for the PV subsystem, while a proportional-integral (PI) controller regulates methane flow in the fuel cell reformer. The grid-side converter is managed by a Nonlinear Output Feedback Fuzzy Converter Control (NOFCC) based on a Takagi-Sugeno (TS) fuzzy model, ensuring DClink voltage stability and fault ride-through (FRT) capability. System stability is guaranteed via Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI) conditions. MATLAB/Simulink simulations under grid faults and load variations demonstrate improved voltage stability, reduced overshoot, and enhanced power quality compared to conventional control methods.

title: CNN-Powered AoA Prediction via PyTorch for Uniform Linear Arrays
authors: Luis Alejandro Iturri-Hinojosa, Jorge Alberto Gómez-García, Daniel Rodríguez-Saldaña
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This work proposes a convolutional neural network (CNN) implemented in PyTorch for precise angle of arrival (AoA) estimation using uniform linear arrays (ULA). The architecture processes raw complex-valued antenna array data directly, streamlining the signal processing chain and enabling seamless integration into intelligent beamforming systems for high-frequency and millimeter-wave communications. The model was trained over 118 epochs with early stopping, monitoring training and validation losses to ensure convergence and prevent overfitting. Evaluated on separate training, validation, and test datasets, the estimator demonstrated strong generalization, achieving a mean absolute error (MAE) of approximately 0.60° and a mean squared error (MSE) near 1.01 deg<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">I. 2</sup> on the test set. These metrics reflect an average angular deviation below one degree, indicating high precision competitive for antenna signal processing applications.Representative test examples exhibited pointwise absolute errors under 0.5°, confirming the model’s fine angular resolution. A slight underestimation bias was observed but remained within acceptable limits without significant error spikes, even at the edges of the angular range. A case inference at 25° showed a predicted angle of 25.53°, with an absolute error of 0.53°, demonstrating practical prediction accuracy. Corresponding beamformer phase weights derived from the CNN output validate its applicability for real-time beamforming.Overall, the combination of low error metrics, stable training convergence, and consistent predictions confirms the CNN’s effectiveness for direct AoA regression from raw antenna data, making it suitable for deployment in real-time high-frequency communication and sensing systems where precise directional information is critical.

title: A Novel Energy Management Strategy to Facilitate the Integration of Renewable Energy Hubs into Local Energy Markets
authors: Leila Bagherzadeh, Innocent Kamwa, Atieh Delavari
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Innovative energy management technologies have facilitated the operation of integrated energy systems (IESs), which interconnect different energy carriers essentially electricity, heat, and gas. The evolution of energy hubs (EHs) presents an opportunity for enhanced efficiency, reliability, and adaptability in meeting energy supply and demand. Incorporating EHs within the power system profoundly affects the operations of both transmission and distribution networks. Consequently, bilateral TSO-DSO coordination is necessary to increase effectiveness. Furthermore, by integrating power generation, storage facilities, and flexible loads, EHs have the potential to gain economic advantages by actively engaging in energy market activities. Therefore, this paper introduces a stochastic model for the economic energy management of distribution and transmission networks, incorporating renewable EHs based on TSO-DSO coordination. In the proposed model, the total operation costs of the networks and EHs are minimized, considering optimal power flow constraints of the networks and the operational framework of EHs situated within the distribution network. In addition to the considerable uncertainties linked to loads, renewable energies, and electric vehicles (EVs), the model addresses an integrated demand response program (IDRP). Accordingly, numerical results demonstrate that the proposed scheme is capable of improving the operation and economic status of the proposed structure by utilizing renewable resources as well as storage and flexible loads in the EHs.

title: An IoT-Enabled Real-Time Soil Irrigation System for Smart Agriculture
authors: Ratul Chowdhury, Rupali Banerjee, Prianka Dey, Soumadip Mondal, Jadav Chandra Das, Anupam Ghosh
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Water management in agriculture based on specific crop types is essential for optimizing yield, conserving water, and sustaining soil health. Different crops have varying water requirements, depending on their growth stages, root depth, and specific climatic conditions. For a large-scale cultivation system, a manual pumping system is inefficient with respect to water resource management and increases human dependency. To address the aforementioned issues, this paper proposes a microcontroller-based fully automated irrigation system to maintain the growth of crops and ensure plants are watered only when needed. This proposed system introduces a soil moisture sensors for continuous monitoring of soil conditions in and when the moisture level falls below a predefined threshold and as per the climate features extracted from weather API, the proposed learning framework with the help of ESP32 microcontroller activates a relay-controlled water pump to irrigate the soil till the moisture reaches an optimal level and accordingly the pump is automatically turned off to prevent overwatering. Smart farming systems are increasingly targeted by different types of cyber threats: False data injection attacks, reply attacks, Denial of service attacks, etc. To provide trust, reliability, and integrity, the proposed autonomous system also integrated Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)-256 encryption to provide end-to-end security. Experimental results reveal that the proposed system ensures trust, prevents manipulation, and protects both infrastructure and decision-making processes in automated or intelligent agriculture systems.

title: Channel Correlation Analysis of Distributed Access Links for Reliable Industrial Wireless Connectivity
authors: Dreyelian Morejón, Jesús R. Pérez, Inaki Eizmendi, Marta Fernández, Pablo Angueira, Rafael P. Torres
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: The stringent reliability and latency requirements of industrial networks are challenged by harsh propagation environments. To design effective communication systems, a thorough understanding of the underlying channel characteristics is essential. Deploying multiple, spatially distributed Access Points (APs) is a promising strategy to overcome these challenges by creating resilient communication links through macro-diversity. This paper presents an experimental characterization of a multi-AP radio channel in a representative industrial laboratory environment, focusing on the 6 GHz band (upper FR1), enabling the investigation of frequency-dependent propagation mechanisms beyond traditional sub-6 GHz cellular bands. We analyze key statistical properties, including inter-link correlation, coherence distance, and coherence bandwidth, to assess the potential for both macro- and micro-diversity. The results demonstrate that the channels from distributed APs are largely uncorrelated, highlighting a significant opportunity for macro-diversity. Conversely, the measured coherence distances far exceed typical device dimensions, suggesting limited returns from single-device spatial diversity. An evaluation of selection combining, equal-gain combining, and maximal-ratio combining techniques confirms that distributed APs can provide substantial diversity gains, ranging from 2.6 dB to 23.1 dB. These findings validate the deployment of coordinated, distributed AP architectures as a crucial strategy for achieving robust, low-latency connectivity in future industrial settings.

title: A Highly Sensitive Substrate Integrated Waveguide Rotation Sensor With Embedded Reference Band for Calibration
authors: SK Abdul Alim, Ali-Reza Moznebi, Rashid Mirzavand
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: A novel dual-band half-mode substrate integrated waveguide (SIW) sensor is presented to measure rotation while featuring a reference band for calibration purposes. The sensor has two layers: a stationary bottom layer, which consists of a half-mode SIW structure that incorporates three slots, and a rotatable top layer. The first resonance (f1) appears at 2.4 GHz and remains stable to serve as a reference point, while the second resonance (f2) shifts from 3.42 to 4.24 GHz as the top layer rotates from 0° to 90°, with a sensitivity of 9.1 MHz/°. The difference between these two resonances (Δf = f2 - f1) directly reflects the rotation angle and effectively compensates for influences that cause simultaneous shifts in both resonances. This compensation principle is demonstrated by temperature analysis. The measured results indicate that the frequency difference remains constant over a wide temperature range from −60°C to 60°C, as temperature affects both frequencies in a similar manner. This confirms that the use of the frequency difference effectively suppresses common-mode frequency drifts, rendering Δf insensitive to these effects and allowing for reliable detection. An extensive performance comparison with state-of-the-art rotation sensors confirms that the proposed design offers higher sensitivity and reliable dual-band operation with built-in calibration.

title: Directionally Regularized Two-Stage Calibration for Cross-Shaped MGT Sensor Arrays with Physics-Inspired Error Modeling
authors: Yingzi Zhang, Yali Shen, Yeng Chai SOH, Wei Niu, Fang Xue, Hongliang Wang, Wenyi Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Accurate calibration of magnetic gradient tensor (MGT) sensor arrays requires correcting both the magnitude and directional responses of individual triaxial magnetometers. Conventional scalar-based calibration methods focus solely on fitting the magnitude of the magnetic field vector, lacking control over directional accuracy and thereby compromising the reliability of MGT construction under field conditions. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a directionally regularized two-stage calibration framework specifically for cross-shaped MGT fluxgate sensor arrays. A physically interpretable twelve-parameter error model is formulated to decouple sensor-internal distortions from array-level orientation misalignments. Crucially, a directional regularization term is incorporated into the calibration objective function to enforce vector alignment across the array. Furthermore, a high-precision triaxial fluxgate sensor is employed as an internal reference, enabling fully self-contained calibration without external field generators or scalar magnetometers. For accurate estimation of the calibration parameters, a two-stage optimization strategy based on Differential Evolution (DE) is developed, in which all parameters are coarsely estimated via magnitude consistency in the first stage, followed by refined alignment of array orientations via directional regularization in the second stage. Field experiments conducted over six independent trials validate the effectiveness and reproducibility of the proposed framework, yielding an overall mean magnitude RMSE of approximately 5.92 nT and a mean angular deviation of 0.07°. These results confirm that the proposed framework enables accurate and robust compensation of MGT sensor arrays in practical environments.

title: Study of a Five-Blade Vertical Axis Turbine for Energy Generation Using Autodesk CFD
authors: Arturo Bruno García-Montenegro, Abel Carmona-Arteaga
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: In response to limited energy availability in rural areas of Peru and the environmental impact of conventional sources, this study evaluates the performance of a five-blade vertical-axis wind turbine using Autodesk CFD simulations. The effects of wind speed (1 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>) and geometric scaling were analyzed in a wind-tunnel-like environment, employing the SST k-omega SAS turbulence model with 9000 iterations per simulation. Results show that higher wind speeds increase RPM, reaching up to 123.72 RPM at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>, while scaling up the turbine causes a decrease in RPM. However, torque remains stable due to the larger contact area with the airflow. It is concluded that these turbines are viable for basic domestic applications, such as LED lighting, particularly in contexts with persistent winds and limited resources.

title: Evaluation of the Influence of Vehicular U-Turns on the Number of Vehicle Conflicts at a T-Type Intersection without Signal Lights, with and without a U-Shaped Lane, with Signal Lights, with and without a U-Shaped Lane Using Vissim 9.0 and SSAM
authors: Bazan Rios Fabio Cesar, Condori Cusihuaman Bridson Everly, Campos De La Cruz Fernando José, Daniel Palacios, Manuel Silvera
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: In Lima, U-turns, although prohibited at many urban intersections, are carried out persistently, generating congestion and increasing the number of road conflicts. This study evaluates the influence of these maneuvers on a T-type intersection under four configurations: T-type intersection without traffic lights, without and with an exclusive U-lane, with traffic lights, without and with exclusive U-lane. The research was carried out at the intersection of Av. José Antonio Lavalle with Alameda San Marcos, an area with a high influx of vehicles and pedestrians. Using simulations in VISSIM 9.0 and conflict analysis in SSAM, vehicular conflicts were quantified and evaluated using safety metrics such as Time to Collision (TTC). The results show that the intersection without a traffic light and without an exclusive U-lane has 145 conflicts, the intersection with an exclusive U-lane and without a traffic light reduces that figure to 93, the traffic light configuration without an exclusive U-lane reduces conflicts to 117, and the configuration with a traffic light and exclusive lane for U-turns further reduces conflicts to 79. These figures represent reductions of 35.9 %, 19.3 and 45.5 %, respectively, compared to the configuration without an exclusive U-lane and without traffic lights -initial situation-. Likewise, severe conflicts with TTC=0 maintain a proportion according to the total conflicts of the intersection for each configuration. The study concludes that the proper management of U-turns, combining traffic light control and exclusive U-lanes can significantly reduce vehicular conflicts.

title: Preliminary Assessment and Seismic Vulnerability Study of a 16th-Century Adobe Heritage Building
authors: Sergio Andrès Bèjar Rengifo, Christian Alexander García Reyes, Rick Milton Delgadillo Ayala
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: The Santa Ana Church, built in 1553 in Barrios Altos, Lima, is a paradigmatic example of seismic vulnerability in heritage buildings. Its antiqueness, lack of modern reinforcements, and the natural deterioration of the bricks and masonry considerably increase the risk of damage in an urban environment with high seismic activity. This paper presents a combined methodology to quantify the seismic vulnerability of the Santa Ana Church using: (1) a rapid visual assessment based on FEMA P-154, and (2) a modal spectral analysis implemented in SAP2000. The FEMA 154 format is used to obtain a rapid vulnerability indicator based on visual inspections and construction parameters. The results indicate that the building complies with the Peruvian code's maximum allowable drift (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\leq \mathbf{0. 0 0 5 ~ m}$</tex>); however, the column-dome junction exceeds allowable shear and requires local reinforcement.

title: Emerging Trends in AI-Driven Autonomous Unmanned Aerial Vehicle System for Wildfire Surveillance: A Comprehensive Survey
authors: Varsha Poddar, Sukalyan Goswami, Nidhi Sikder, Anirban Mondal, Mrinmay Das
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Wildfires are increasing exponentially in this era of climate change and scarcity of resources. Recent developments in unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) technology have been explored to create drone systems that can detect and fight wildfires and contribute to other applications. This paper presents an extensive overview of existing trends and a comprehensive study of novel drone technologies, fixed IOT sensor satellite imagery and AI-based decision-making techniques to provide well-informed analytical insights based on the cost, response time, environmental impact, and efficiency. This paper surveys pioneering research done in various areas of application to provide a comparative evaluation of different systems. This survey aims to determine existing research gaps, explore and highlight innovative promising directions like energy-efficient flight coordination, real-time onboard processing, and other possible systems to cater to large-scale and other technologies for small-scale as well as ground sensor networks.

title: Searching to Modulate for Cold-Start Recommendation
authors: Shiguang Wu, Yaqing Wang, Quanming Yao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Making personalized recommendation for cold-start users, who only have a few interaction histories, is a challenging problem in recommendation systems. Recent works leverage hypernetworks to directly map interaction histories to user-specific parameters, which are then used to modulate predictor by certain modulation structure. These works obtain the state-of-the-art performance. However, there lacks a general approach to design the modulation structure. Instead of using a fixed modulation function and deciding modulation position by expertise, we propose to determine proper modulation structure, including function and position, via neural architecture search. We propose two approaches. We first design a symbolic search space which covers broad models and theoretically prove that this search space can be transformed to a much smaller space, enabling an efficient and robust one-shot search algorithm, called ColdNAS. Since recommendation systems are a special case of bipartite matching problems, the proposed methods can be generalized to a wide range of cold-start tasks, such as disease-gene association prediction for emerging diseases. However, diverse scenarios introduce new challenges in both the flexibility of the search algorithm and the search space. To address these limitations, we further propose ColdNAS<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_+$</tex-math></inline-formula>, where we employ neural networks to model modulation functions to extend search space and design a two-stage decoupled stochastic search algorithm to enable non-differentiable targets in continuous spaces. Extensive experimental results on benchmark datasets show that modulation structures obtained by ColdNAS and ColdNAS<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$_+$</tex-math></inline-formula> consistently outperform hand-designed cold-start techniques for recommending items for new users and predicting associated genes for new disease. We observe that different modulation functions lead to the best performance on different datasets or under different metrics, which validates the necessity of designing the modulation structure in a data-driven way.

title: Photonic Lens Based on a Quasi-Periodic Metamaterial with Sixfold Repetition for Advanced Optical Manipulation
authors: João Rafael Costa F. Da Silva, Vitor L. S. T. Catão, Nilson H. O. Cunha, José P. Da Silva, Cosme E. Rubio Mercedes
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Quasi-photonic crystals are structures with long- range order but without perfect periodicity, which grants them unique optical proprieties at the macroscopic scale. In this work, is proposed a photonic lens based on a structure composed of a quasi-periodic distribution of air holes embedded in a metamaterial substrate with a refractive index of 3.6. The photonic lens is designed by replicating a quasi-periodic unit cell six times around his center, using photonic bandgaps, generated by the quasi-periodicity, to control the propagation of light. The optical input signal is focusing perpendicularly along the longitudinal direction of the air holes, which block certain light frequencies and allow others to pass through specific regions, enabling effects such as beam bending control and focusing. This allows light confinement within nanometric waveguides, with the focal length being adjusted through structural control. The study employs the Finite Element Method (FEM) to simulate the energy confinement between the quasi-periodic region and the guiding structure, operating at a wavelength of 1550 nm.

title: LLM-Empowered Cooperative Content Caching in Vehicular Fog Caching-Assisted Platoon Networks
authors: Bowen Tan, Qiong Wu, Pingyi Fan, Kezhi Wang, Nan Cheng, Wen Chen
abstract: This letter proposes a novel three-tier content caching architecture for Vehicular Fog Caching (VFC)-assisted platoon, where the VFC is formed by the vehicles driving near the platoon. The system strategically coordinates storage across local platoon vehicles, dynamic VFC clusters, and cloud server (CS) to minimize content retrieval latency. To efficiently manage distributed storage, we integrate large language models (LLMs) for real-time and intelligent caching decisions. The proposed approach leverages LLMs’ ability to process heterogeneous information, including user profiles, historical data, content characteristics, and dynamic system states.Through a designed prompting framework encoding task objectives and caching constraints, the LLMs formulate caching as a decision-making task, and our hierarchical deterministic caching mapping strategy enables adaptive requests prediction and precise content placement across three tiers without frequent retraining.Simulation results demonstrate the advantages of our proposed caching scheme.

title: Shock-Proofing the Grid: Readiness of Indian Electricity Markets for Futures-Based Hedging Instruments
authors: Ribhu Shankar, Parminder Kaur Bajaj, Naran M. Pindoriya
abstract: India's electricity market, centered around the volatile Day-Ahead Market, presents significant financial risk to participants. The recent introduction of electricity futures offers a potential hedging solution, but adoption is hindered by a nascent market structure and a critical lack of liquidity beyond the front-month contract. This study provides a quantitative, simulation-based evaluation of the efficacy of these new instruments. A synthetic historical futures price series is constructed for a forty-month period based on an analysis of observed market premiums in both contango and backwardation states. The performance of three distinct hedging archetypes, Conservative, Moderate, and Aggressive, is then back-tested against historical spot price data. A bootstrap statistical test is employed to validate the robustness of the findings. The results demonstrate that dynamic hedging strategies yield statistically significant mean monthly savings of approximately one to one-point-five percent. The Moderate, volatility-triggered strategy is identified as optimal from a risk-adjusted perspective, delivering both cost savings and the highest degree of cost stability. This paper provides the first empirical evidence to motivate broader participation from stakeholders, arguing that active, data-driven hedging is a viable strategy to mitigate risk and can help overcome the initial liquidity barriers in the Indian electricity derivatives market.

title: Numerical Analysis of SPR SPCE Sensor with Graphene Applied in the Detection of Markers in Power Transformer Oil
authors: Karlo Q. da Costa, Maikon S. da Costa
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work presents the numerical analysis of an SPR sensor with graphene in the SPCE configuration in THz, using COMSOL, in which the near fields and radiation diagrams are analyzed as a function of the types of samples present on the surface of the sensor, and can be applied in the detection of markers in transformer oil. The basic structure of the sensor is Prism/SiO2/Graphene/Sample/Air. The proposed sensor presented good results, such as good sensitivity and high detection resolution, being able to detect minimal changes in the refractive index of the oil sample, caused by the presence of markers that indicate its insulation quality.

title: Sorghum Leaf Disease Detection Using Vision Transformer
authors: G Pavan Kalyan, Bhukya Chinna, S Senthil, Ramesh Chundi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Sorghum is a key cereal crop cultivated extensively in semi-arid regions, where food security is greatly impacted by it. However, foliar diseases frequently impair its yield and quality, necessitating prompt discovery for efficient control. This study introduces a deep learning-based framework leveraging the Vision Transformer (ViT) architecture to classify various sorghum leaf diseases directly from raw images. In contrast to conventional convolutional neural networks (CNNs), ViT employs self-attention mechanisms to model long-range dependencies within image patches, enabling more robust feature learning. A publicly available sorghum leaf disease dataset was curated, preprocessed, and augmented to improve model generalization. Using the ViT-B/16 variant, The suggested model outperformed many CNN baselines with a classification accuracy of 95.4%. Performance was evaluated across all illness categories using evaluation criteria like precision, recall, and F1-score. The results demonstrate transformer-based models’ promise as a scalable and practical remedy for automated plant disease identification, supporting real-time monitoring in precision agriculture.

title: Dynamic Line Rating Computation and Limit Exchange Methodologies
authors: Pradeep Kumar Manigilla, Mritunjay Aman, Sriker Annangi, Pankaj Prabhat, Anjani Prasad Achanta, Sathyanarayanareddy Nukala
abstract: Digital Dynamic Line rating (DDLR) is an advanced method for determining the real time capacity of transmission lines based on ambient conditions, particularly temperature. Unlike traditional static line ratings which are conservative and based on fixed assumptions, DLR provides more accurate and flexible assessments by incorporating real time environmental factors to compute the line ratings dynamically which enables to optimize power flows without compromising on system safety. This paper explores various methods for calculating Dynamic Line Ratings (DLR) which includes curve fitting, empirical methods and data driven approaches. The discussion highlights the advantages of DLR in optimizing the utilization of existing transmission infrastructure, reducing congestion and improving grid reliability. Additionally, we discuss the limit exchange portal TROLIE which enables the exchange of limits among various entities and enable broader operational aspects and reliability.

title: Impact of High Temperature on Wind Turbine Performance in India and Need for Climate-Resilient Design
authors: Abhijeet Prakash, Priyanka Meena, Lav Kumar Khandelwal, Manas Ranjan Chand, Priyam Jain, Vivek Pandey, Shailendra Verma
abstract: India rapid transition toward renewable energy, especially wind power, necessitates addressing environmental challenges that affect performance. With an installed wind capacity of 50 GW as of March 2025 and a target of 100 GW by 2030, the country's wind energy sector must operate efficiently under extreme climatic conditions, particularly high ambient temperatures. This paper analyses the impact of high temperatures on wind turbine generator (WTG) performance across major wind-rich states. Empirical data from ISTS-connected WTGs reveal significant thermal derating behaviour beginning as low as 38°C, leading to reduced output even under rated wind speed conditions. The study highlights the importance of aligning turbine design with Indian environmental standards, such as those by the Central Electricity Authority and IEC 61400-1. Findings underscore the need to factor temperature-induced derating into generation forecasts, resource adequacy studies, and long-term planning to ensure grid reliability and renewable integration. Recommendations are provided to enhance WTG design verification, improve thermal tolerance, and align operational strategies with evolving climatic conditions. It is hypothesized that WTGs operating in high-temperature regions exhibit measurable power derating above 38°C, and that current IEC-based designs may require adaptation for Indian climatic conditions.

title: A Low-Power Successive Approximation Algorithm for ECG Signals
authors: Hamed Nasiri, Cheng Li, Lihong Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper presents a novel successive approximation (SA) algorithm designed for electrocardiogram (ECG) signals. Instead of digitizing each sample independently, the proposed method encodes the difference between consecutive samples, effectively leveraging the low activity nature of ECG signals. Unlike the conventional successive approximation register (SAR) ADCs, which require a fixed N comparisons for an N-bit conversion, the proposed approach dynamically adjusts the number of comparisons per sample, typically ranging from 2 to N. The algorithm was implemented in MATLAB and tested on ECG signals, demonstrating significant efficiency gains. Results show that the proposed method reduces the number of comparisons by $73.29 \%$ compared to the conventional SAR ADC method and by 13.81 % compared to the LSB-first algorithm, a popular scheme from the literature. Additionally, DAC update operations are minimized by the same percentages, leading to substantial power savings in both DAC and digital logic components of the SAR ADC design. These improvements make the method particularly wellsuited for low-power biomedical applications, especially batteryoperated ECG monitoring devices.

title: Adaptive Differentiator Estimator
authors: Karim Khayati, Aymen Maatki
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: In this article, a new differentiator estimator with adaptively adjusted gains is proposed. The algorithm circumvents some unknown limits of the second derivative of the original signal, and allows the asymptotic stability, also after certain circumstances (compensating the unknown uncertainties that are due) a finite-time convergence of the estimator. The simulation results are carried out using different pure (i.e., chatter-free) signal forms to validate the effectiveness of the proposed technique and compare its performance with existing ones described in the literature.

title: Design of Orthogonal Phase of Arrival Positioning Scheme Based on 5G PRS and Optimization of TOA Performance
authors: Hyejin Shin, Sohee Kim, Ilmu Byun, Juyeop Kim
abstract: This study analyzes the performance of positioning techniques based on configuration changes of 5G New Radio (NR) signals. In 5G networks, a terminal’s position is determined from the Time of Arrival (TOA) of Positioning Reference Signals (PRS) transmitted by base stations. We propose an algorithm that improves TOA accuracy under low sampling-rate constraints and implement 5G PRS for positioning in a software-defined modem. We also examine how flexible time–frequency resource allocation of PRS affects TOA estimation accuracy and discuss optimal PRS configurations for a given signal environment. With the proposed configuration, the terminal can achieve sub-sample TOA accuracy, reaching approximately 0.3 samples.

title: SkeletonHR: Robust Heart Rate Detection under movement conditions using a commodity mmWave radar sensor
authors: Yingxiao Wu, Zhiyuan Zhou, Zhongmin Jiang, Jianping Han, Wenyao Xu
abstract: FMCW mmWave radar has shown promise in vital signs measurement in stationary scenarios. However, its precision for heart rate detection significantly degrades in moving scenarios due to overwhelming action noise. To address this issue, we introduce SkeletonHR, a novel approach for robust human heart rate detection in complex movement scenarios using a commodity mmWave radar. SkeletonHR first leverages an advanced network for human joint points reconstruction and four additional joint points were interpolated to fully extract the phase signals from the upper body. For the purpose of isolating the complete heartbeat signal from the complex composite signal, we propose a HeartWave-VMD algorithm that extracts the heartbeat signal by rigorously evaluating its physiological validity and quality of the heartbeat signal. Furthermore, an adaptive joint-point prioritization strategy is explored to select the most reliable signal across multiple chest joints to enhance the accuracy and robustness of heart rate detection. Ablation experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method. Experimental results show that SkeletonHR can accurately separate heartbeat in the presence of micro and large random body movements. The 80th percentile of the absolute heart rate error per minute is less than 4.51 BPM in the case of micro movement and 10.35 BPM in the case of large movement.

title: Compact 12-Element Circular MIMO Antenna Array with Passive Geometric Isolation for Triple-Band 5G
authors: Nihal Singh, Parth Singh, Aryahi Srivastava, Manish Jaiswal, Raj Gusain, Anurag Vidyarthi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: We demonstrate a design, optimization, and comprehensive performance analysis of a compact 12-element multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) antenna array tailored for fifth-generation millimeter-wave devices. The design is implemented on an FR-4 substrate (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 ~\text{mm} \times 20 ~\text{mm} \times 0.78 ~\text{mm}$</tex>) and simultaneously covers three key 5G bands centred at 24.3 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{GHz}, 28.5 \text{GHz}$</tex>, and 38.3 GHz. Single-port characterization yields deep impedance matching with measured return losses of -22.96 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$d B,-27.27 d B$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-70.73 d B$</tex>, respectively, with fractional bandwidths of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.6 \%, 12.3 \%$</tex>, and 5.8 %. When all twelve ports are active, the MIMO design maintains a total active reflection coefficient (TARC) below -6 dB across each band, confirming robust impedance stability under realistic MIMO excitation. Key diversity metrics further validate the proposed design: envelope correlation coefficient (ECC) < 0.09, mean effective gain (MEG) between 0.75 and 0.95, diversity gain <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(D G) \approx 10 d B$</tex>, and channelcapacity loss <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(C C L) \leq 0.17$</tex> bit <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$/ \mathrm{s} / \text{Hz}$</tex>. Far-field simulations demonstrate per-element gains of 3.69 dBi, 1.9 dBi, and 5.06 dBi, while the symmetric circular layout ensures high inter-element isolation (> <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0}$</tex> dB). Collectively, these results confirm that the proposed antenna offers low correlation, high spectral efficiency, and compact form factor, rendering it a strong candidate for nextgeneration 5G mmWave transceivers in handheld and IoT platforms.

title: A 40 GHz Low-Power Variable-Gain Low Noise Amplifier in $28-\text{nm}$ CMOS Process
authors: Harshith Reddy, Pankaj Arora
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: A Low-Power Variable Gain (VG) mm-Wave Low Noise Amplifier (LNA) is designed and simulated in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28-\text{nm}$</tex> CMOS process. The LNA utilizes a simple, yet novel, technique presented in this paper to vary the small-signal output resistance to provide gain control. The amplifier also utilizes forward body biasing to allow for reducing the supply voltage to 0.7 V and enhancing the power efficiency. A simultaneous noise and input matching (SNIM) technique is used to provide robust input matching and noise performance during gain adjustment. The proposed VG-LNA achieves a peak gain of 21 dB at 40.5 GHz with a noise figure of 2.8 dB and consumes only 4.5 mW. At the highest gain configuration, an input-referred 1-dB compression of -21 dBm and IP3 of -7.8 dBm are achieved, which increase to -14.8 dBm and 1.2 dBm, respectively, at the lowest gain configuration. Regardless of the gain control voltage, the LNA attains a very good FoM as compared to the state-of-the-art.

title: Real Time Digital Simulator (RTDS) Hardware in the Loop (HIL) Testing of Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) Controller
authors: Muhammed Y. Worku, Mahmoud Elhassan, Ahmad Al-Jabr
abstract: This paper presents hardware in the loop (HIL) testing of the Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) controller under different operating scenarios through Real Time Digital Simulator (RTDS). The objective of the HIL testing is to evaluate the performance of the BESS controller when the BESS is utilized as a power conditioning system to provide active and reactive power to the network. A test case containing AC network, BESS, inverter and interfacing transformer is developed in RSCAD. The replica controller which is the device under test (DUT) is interfaced with the RTDS through input/output cards. The RSCAD model sends the status of the system such as the DC link signals (voltage and current), the inverter output parameters and the Point of Interconnection (POI) voltage and current signals to the external replica controller using the Gigabit-Transceiver Analogue Output (GTAO) cards. After receiving these signals, the replica controller generates gating signals for the IGBTs of the inverter through the Gigabit-Transceiver Digital Input (GTDI) cards. Different types of grid conditions and BESS operating modes such as active power control/reactive power control, charge/discharge and, low voltage ride through (LVRT) tests are performed to validate the BESS controller capability and results are provided. The developed test system will help utilities test the BESS controller prior to installation and commissioning.

title: Self Replication Mode for Network Intrusion Detection of Imperative Node Evaluator
authors: B. Sarvesan, R. Elankavi, Potli Harshavardhanreddy, G Jahnavi, Penakalapati Harsha Vardhan, Bayatapalle Jahnavi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Security is now a critical concern for modern systems due to network expansion. Keeping an eye out for anomalies in user behavior is a helpful fraud detection tactic. This is a plan for an intrusion detection system using techniques like self-replication and pattern matching. The system notifies other nodes to be on the lookout for potentially damaging event sequences by identifying potentially dangerous symptoms in the surrounding environment. The suggested model, Imperative Node Evaluator with Self Replication Code and Auto Triggering Mode (INE-SRC-ATM), is made to automatically trigger nodes to secure the network and lessen false alarms, as well as to automatically repair the network in the event of an intrusion. When there is a difference in characteristics that raise the bar for network security, the suggested model reacts instantly. Both the accuracy of self-replication triggering and the degrees of intrusion detection demonstrate good performance of this model in intrusion detection.

title: Fusion-Based Movie Recommender System Combining Genre Similarity, LightFM, and Neural Networks
authors: A K Manjula, H N Champa
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: In this work, we offer a hybrid movie recommendation system [2] that integrates three distinct approaches: content-based filtering using genre similarity, collaborative filtering using LightFM with WARP loss, and a deep learning-based user-item interaction model. The system integrates both numerical ratings and textual metadata using the MovieLens 1M dataset. We intend to improve forecast accuracy and recommendation diversity by merging these algorithms. Each method’s efficacy is evaluated using evaluation criteria such as Precision@K, Recall@K, and NDCG@K. Although further feature engineering could improve deep learning, the results show that collaborative filtering with LightFM performs better than previous approaches [3]. This hybrid strategy [2] demonstrates how combining many recommender systems might result in more thorough customisation.

title: CNN and K-NN Methods for Image-Response Recognition in Surface Plasmon Resonance Sensors
authors: Mateus V.L. Lopes, Leiva C. Oliveira, Antonio M.N. Lima
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Two innovative techniques for detecting aqueous substances using surface plasmon resonance (SPR) imaging are presented. The first technique utilizes a machine learning framework that employs the k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) algorithm, incorporating projection histogram features for image representation. The second technique uses a convolutional neural network (CNN) deep learning model, trained on a comprehensive dataset of SPR images. Both systems were integrated into a custom-designed portable experimental setup and applied to the real-time identification of aqueous solutions. These models achieved an accuracy rate exceeding 96% in the runtime deployment phase, demonstrating the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed solutions for real-time molecular interaction analysis using SPR.

title: Smith Chart-Based Graphical Design of a Two-Section Transmission Line Matching Circuits
authors: Satoshi Tanaka, Takeshi Yoshida, Minoru Fujishima
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: With the advancement of integrated circuits targeting higher frequencies such as the sub-THz band, the application of transmission line (TL) matching circuits— previously considered impractical due to their large area requirements—is becoming increasingly feasible in integrated implementations. Among the well-established TL matching circuit design methods are the binomial type, which offers a flat transmission response, and the Chebyshev type, which allows inband ripple to be used as a design parameter. These circuits are frequently implemented using two or more sections. However, determining the required parameters typically involves solving complex polynomial expressions or referring to precomputed table data under representative conditions. In this paper, we propose a simple and intuitive graphical design method for two-section TL matching circuits using the Smith chart. The differences between the Binomial and Chebyshev methods are clearly visualized on the Smith chart, highlighting how the ripple specification defined in the Chebyshev approach leads to differences in the resulting designs, thereby simplifying the design process.

title: Towards Smarter Healthcare: A Multimodal Sensor Fusion Approach for Heart Disease Prediction with Artificial Intelligence
authors: Probal Ghosh, Ritu Kundu, Sima Ghosh, Sudakshina Dasgupta
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The increasing prevalence of heart disease requires creative methods of early identification and customised treatment. The multimodal sensor fusion method using Artificial Intelligence (AI) to predict cardiac diseases with enhanced reliability and accuracy is presented in this research. To extract comprehensive aspects relevant to cardiovascular health, this methodology combines data from multiple physiological sensors, such as wearable technology, electrocardiograms (ECGs), etc. This method analyses the fused information and finds predicted patterns suggestive of heart disease by utilising deep learning techniques in conjunction with sophisticated machine learning algorithms. The effectiveness of this technique has been demonstrated by evaluation on a diverse patient dataset, which shows notable gains in prediction accuracy as compared to conventional methods. Using the heart disease multimodal dataset, the experimental evaluation of this fusion achieved $90.67 \%$ of overall accuracy with 0.91 F1-score. In addition to facilitating prompt intervention, the suggested solution opens up the opportunity for more intelligent, data-driven healthcare systems. This study advances proactive management of heart disease and public health by integrating multimodal data and artificial intelligence.

title: Individual Action Detection using Yolov9 and Deep Neural Network
authors: Zaryab Shaker, Adnan Ahmed Rafique, Ahmad Jalal
publish: 2025 Horizons of Information Technology and Engineering (HITE)
abstract: The research presents a reliable Action detection system which identifies individual actions in a group. The system specifically addresses computer vision challenges that affect video surveillance systems, together with sports analytics, and healthcare monitoring applications. The work employs a multi-stage pipeline approach for implementation. Image quality improvement starts with Preprocessing before the system performs human detection using YOLOv9. Optical flow estimation generates skeleton data from OpenPose-detected body points as the second stage of the process. The process generates hybrid features through SIFT and Local Binary pattern technique combination. Features undergo concatenation followed by Grey wolf optimization enhancement after the feature extraction process. The DNN classifier operates to recognize activities that stem from the obtained data. The assessment of this method took place through the use of the public Volleyball dataset. This dataset contains 500 video sequences shot under different lighting and occlusion conditions. The detection system of our proposed method showed better performance than various baseline methods which made the system more reliable in difficult situations. The research shows how the combined feature fusion system with optimization methods from SIFT and LBP operates at 25ms frame rate (40ms processing time) for real-time system and extends its scalability to multi-computer systems. Our research shows progress in group activity action recognition through the development of methods which handle multiple person interactions and complex computations and establish fundamental evaluation standards for future work in dynamic environments.

title: A Phased Array of Miniaturized Radiators for 6G
authors: Kalyan Sundar Kola, Rituparna Mondal, Sandip Bhattacharya, Anirban Chatterjee
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: This article reports on developing a beam-forming array of miniature printed radiators for mm -wave applications, particularly 6 G communication. The sole radiator is miniaturized by $10.52 \%$ and offers a unidirectional radiation pattern at 27 GHz. Further, an array with four identical individually excited antennas has been constructed to perform beam-forming operations. The main beam of the array can be controlled by providing an accurate progressive phase to each element during excitation. The inter-element space of the array has been optimized in such a way as to achieve a lower side-lobe level at the desired direction of radiation. Additionally, the array is capable of scanning its main beam in a dual direction simultaneously without any mechanical involvement. The proposed array is compact, miniaturized, and suitable for 6 G applications, like IoT, V2X, and satellite networks.

title: A Switching-Function-Based Average Value Model for Efficient EMT-type Simulation of Solid-State Transformer with Interleaved DAB Modules
authors: Hengyu Li, Walid Hatahet, Liwei Wang, Wei Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Conventional electromagnetic transient (EMT) simulation of solid-state transformer (SST) requires tremendous computational efforts due to the detailed representation of discrete circuit components of the SST. This paper presents a numerically accurate and efficient average value modeling strategy of the SST. Switching-function-based average value model (SFB-AVM) is proposed to simplify the SST equivalent circuit and to accelerate the EMT simulation. Switching interleaving operation of the dualactive bridge (DAB) modules of the SST is accurately modeled in the proposed SFB-AVM. Circuit decoupling and constant network conductance (G)-matrices in the nodal voltage equation are achieved in the proposed SFB-AVM. Furthermore, switching interpolation technique is proposed to capture semiconductor switching events accurately in the proposed SFB-AVM. Significantly improved simulation efficiency of the proposed SFBAVM is demonstrated in the case studies by comparing to the detailed model (DM) and detailed equivalent model (DEM).

title: A Quad-core 32-bit RISC-V CPU Implementation with Design Verification on 130 nm CMOS Process
authors: Le-Thanh-Nhon Nguyen, Khai-Minh Ma, Tran-Bao-Thuong Cao, Duc-Hung Le
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This paper presents implementation of a System-on-Chip consisting of 4 CPU cores, each core contains 32-bit RISC-V architecture. The authors proposed a script to implement a complete back-end flow from Place-and-Route to design verification on Skywater 130 nm process. The system had the core size <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5 \times 3.5 \text{mm}$</tex>, approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. The operation frequency is 100 MHz. The author proposed a digital design and verification design flow with SystemVerilog to verify the functions of the system after back-end design process for improving the correctness of the design.

title: Designing of an Improved Robust Degn-Harrison 2D Chaotic Map for Image Encryption Application
authors: Manish Kumar Thukral
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Chaotic maps (CMs), owing to their sensitivity to initial conditions and complex dynamical behavior, are widely employed in image encryption applications. Recent studies have explored the use of the discretized Degn-Harrison model as a two-dimensional (2D) CM for image encryption; however, its practical applicability is limited by a narrow chaotic region containing periodic windows. In this paper, a novel modification of the classical Degn-Harrison map is proposed to overcome this limitation. The proposed approach embeds a one-dimensional chaotic map into the Degn-Harrison system and employs a modulo operation, resulting in a significantly enhanced dynamical structure. Numerical investigations demonstrate that the modified map exhibits chaotic behavior across the entire bifurcation parameter range and generates hyperchaotic dynamics characterized by two positive Lyapunov exponents.

title: Passive Adaptive Foot-Ankle for Quadruped Robots: Design and Analysis
authors: Yongxiang Cheng, Dongyue Hua, Zisen Hua, Guojia Min
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: This study innovatively integrated a heterogeneous parallel mechanism with a passive pneumatic control system featuring reciprocating drive characteristics, and proposed a three-degree-of-freedom passive foot-ankle mechanism suitable for quadruped robots. Based on the new structure, the kinematic model of the ankle and mathematic model of the elastic element, comprising mechanical and pneumatic model, were established by using appropriate theory. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed structure in actual limb motion was validated using a single-leg experimental platform. The results indicate that the novel structure not only enables reverse regulation of limb movement through changes in footplate posture, but also significantly optimizes the driving torque characteristics of leg joints.

title: Hybrid ANN-FLC Based Fault Detection in PV Systems
authors: Salem Idham Ewad, Mohammed Taha Yunis, Basima Taresh Dawood, Hayder DAkhil Atiyah
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper proposes an intelligent control system built on a hybrid ANN-FLC architecture control to optimize fault diagnosis and protection function in grid-tied photovoltaic (PV) systems. The implemented model employs the adaptive the learning ability of the ANN combined with the rule-based inference mechanism of FLC inferential process of FLC that enhance decision fault diagnosis and hybrid ANN-FLC systems facilitates autonomous tuning and context-sensitive control ensuring adaptive fault detection under fluctuating irradiance and thermal conditions. Real-time voltage and current signals are processed and examined through feature extraction techniques to form a ten-dimensional input vector that characterizes the transient behavior of the PV array. A ANN module identifies seven fault categories such as LL, GF, OC, SC, and sensor deviation states, reaching a mean detection accuracy of 98.2%. Fuzzy decision layer fine-tunes all results through four fuzzy linguistic from change fault likelihood normalized power variance current ripple ratio and DC-bus voltage. This improvement guarantees stable and transparent fault diagnosis. Method verification via measurement show oscilloscope and infrared thermography verifies early fault detection capability reduse false positive rate by approximately 35% and reestablish steady voltage levels in $\mathbf{3 5 - 4 0 ~ m s}$. In conclusion the formulated ANN-FLC such a hybrid protection approach provides a dependable and selfadaptive control scheme that mitigates heat stress enhances system protection and improves dynamic stability of photovoltaic networks in contemporary smart grids.

title: Design of Ground Fault Detector for Current Disturbances on Distribution System
authors: Wisnu Prawira Triatmaja, Prayoga Nanda Oktafiama, Reza Pandu Wijaya, Octarina Nur Samijayani
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: In electricity distribution, disturbances frequently occur, including both symmetrical and asymmetrical faults. Case in year 2023, PLN UP3 Bulungan as one of the state company responsible for electricity generation and distribution in Indonesia, recorded 104 occurred medium-voltage disturbances, 85% of which were caused by phase-to-ground short circuits. Such faults may result in phase angle imbalances and induce fault currents in the grounding conductors of the medium-voltage network. To detect these faults, Ground Fault Detectors (GFDs) have been deployed across all distribution substations. The GFD detects fault currents caused by phase-to-ground faults using a current transformer (CT). The CT then transmits signals to the control circuit, triggering a fault indication. This study analyzes the GFD current setting calculation on the distribution system at PLN UP3 Bulungan, which has a length of 11.4 km. The results show that the single-phase short-circuit current at 1% distance from the source is 953.53 A, while at 100% distance from the source, it is 805.85 A. Therefore, the recommended GFD current setting Distribution system is 80 A. This result is expected to improve fault detection accuracy and distribution system reliability at specifically at PLN UP3 Bulungan.

title: Broadband Measurement of Dielectric Properties of 3D-Printed Plastics
authors: Tess Doherty, Rodney Vaughan, Chris Hynes
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Obtaining broadband measurements of dielectric properties is a challenge, particularly at high frequencies. An established approach is to use an open coaxial probe resting on a sample of the material under test (MUT) that has a known thickness. We describe the application of this technique using Speag’s DAK-TL2 system to characterize several 3D-printed plastics. 3D-printed materials have very little published data about their electrical properties, and plastics are very convenient for making microwave components from coil formers to antennas. Low-loss materials are of particular interest, exacerbating the measurement challenge. Ideally, the MUT samples are homogenous, have uniform thickness, and the surfaces are very smooth [1]. None of these properties can be attained with most plastics, particularly with 3D-printed plastics, with the most challenging property being surface smoothness. For low-loss materials, the loss tangents are close to or less than the measurement uncertainty of the system. Much of this uncertainty is due to the losses in the probe and the detail of the interface between the probe and the MUT. The procedure, measurements, and repeatability behaviour of the complex dielectric constants of a variety of 3D-printed plastics are presented for frequencies up to 20 GHz.

title: Federated Learning-Driven Cyber-Physical Security Framework for AI- Powered Smart Grids in Renewable-Integrated Urban Infrastructures
authors: Muhammad Inam Ul Haq, Shehryar Qamar Paracha, Sayyed Daniyal Qamar, Sayyed Talha Gohar Naqvi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: The transition to AI-powered smart grids particularly in renewable-integrated urban environments has introduced critical cyber-physical vulnerabilities due to distributed architectures and heterogeneous edge devices. While centralized machine learning offers high detection accuracy, it suffers from privacy risks, high latency, and limited scalability. This paper proposes a Federated Learning (FL)-based cybersecurity framework designed for hybrid anomaly detection in smart grid infrastructures. The approach enables edge devices to locally train time-series models without raw data exchange, thereby preserving privacy and minimizing communication overhead. The framework addresses key challenges including non-IID data distributions and edge node dropout. Experimental results on an extended IEEE 33-bus system with integrated PV/wind resources and cyber-physical fault injection modules confirm near-centralized accuracy (~94.8%), 20% latency reduction, and a significant reduction of raw data exposure risks. Additionally, the system achieves 75% bandwidth savings and improved energy efficiency, while scalability, real-time feasibility, and adversarial robustness are explicitly considered. This work advances the deployment of privacy-preserving, edge-intelligent AI for secure, resilient urban infrastructure.

title: Enhancing M2M 5G Communications through SVR-Based Angle of Arrival Estimation
authors: Luis Alejandro Iturri-Hinojosa, Gabriela Leija-Hernández, Alexis Cruz-Vargas
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: The integration of Machine-to-Machine (M2M) communications with fifth-generation (5G) networks has enabled a new era of intelligent, low-latency, and high-reliability applications across diverse domains, particularly in connected healthcare and autonomous medical systems. This work presents a Support Vector Regression (SVR)-based approach for estimating the Angle of Arrival (AoA) in 5G M2M environments, aiming to enhance spatial awareness, dynamic beamforming, and interference suppression in dense deployments. The proposed model is validated using synthetic array data and benchmarked against traditional regression techniques. Results show that the SVR method significantly reduces angular estimation errors under low-noise conditions, particularly for a half-wavelength interelement spacing, while highlighting that grating lobes degrade accuracy at angles above 30°, which can be alleviated by reducing the spacing between antenna elements. Moreover, its relevance is underscored through recent clinical use cases of 5G-powered medical platforms—such as capsule endoscopy and telesurgery—where accurate beam control and signal direction estimation are critical. These findings position SVR-based AoA estimation as a key enabler for next-generation M2M medical systems operating in latency-sensitive and spatially constrained environments.

title: Coverage Analysis for FR3 Spectrum Based on Throughput Performance
authors: Stephanie M. Soares, Iran Mesquita Braga, Bárbara Regina Xavier Ribeiro Faria, Dércio M. Mate
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents a coverage analysis based on throughput performance evaluation for the new frequency range 3 (FR3) spectrum, also denominated as the cmWave spectrum, envisioned for sixth generation (6G) of wireless networks deployments. The study focuses on channel measurements and performance analysis under different antenna configurations using a laboratory setup. Measurements were carried out to assess the achievable throughput by varying the reference signal received power (RSRP) at the User Equipment (UE). We assumed large-scale path loss models under Line-of-Sight (LOS) and Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) scenarios to estimate the maximum distance coverage range for FR3 frequency bands. Furthermore, we analysed the impact of different antenna configuration, Single-input Single-output (SISO) and Multiple-input Multiple-output (MIMO), on achievable throughput and distance coverage range. Results indicate significant degradation in throughput as frequency and number of antenna increase, especially in NLOS scenarios. The study offers critical insights into FR3 practical coverage limits, which are essential for guiding 6G deployment strategies in urban scenarios.

title: Enhancing Geo-Transferability in Building Function Classification through Similar Place Knowledge Retrieval_supp1-3659015.docx
authors: Haosheng Huang
abstract: Understanding the use of buildings (i.e., building functions) is crucial for effective urban management and policy making. Recently, many deep learning-based models have been developed to identify building functions. However, their high performance depends on a large labeled dataset, which is a significant challenge for cities with limited labeled data. To close this gap, we propose a similar-place knowledge-retrieval-based framework for building function identification that enables a trained model to be directly applied/transferred to other cities without additional training needed. Our approach combines remote sensing imagery, POI data, and building footprints to capture the macro and micro built environment. Specifically, this framework includes two different modules: 1) a geo-aware transformer-based model to capture fine-grained spatial interactions between buildings; 2) a hierarchical node clustering algorithm with a similar-place knowledge-retrieval layer for portraying the coarse-grained features. This combination clusters all neighbors of a target building into a ’place’ and then conducts a coarse-grained knowledge transfer based on the similarity match. The evaluation conducted across nine cities demonstrates that the proposed model outperforms all state-of-the-art baselines, achieving an average improvement of 21.98% in cross-city predictions, as measured by Cohen’s kappa coefficient. More importantly, the ablation study shows that integrating our knowledge-retrieval layer into other deep-learning baselines significantly improves their cross-city prediction performance. Additionally, the transferability performance analysis indicates that greater similarity between the sample distributions in the source and target cities contributes to the proposed model’s higher transferability. In summary, the proposed knowledge-retrieval layer is an effective and reliable component for enhancing cross-city prediction and has strong potentials for application in cities without labeled data to support city management and sustainable urban planning.

title: Utilizing Large Language Models for Alzheimer's and Bipolar Disorder Prediction
authors: Vikas Kamra, Siddhii Jain, Vansh Puri, Nikhil Dhaila
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Bipolar disorder and Alzheimer disease are the two serious mental illnesses that impact millions of people globally. Current diagnostic tools are often slow and not scalable, leaving both patients and caregivers in a difficult position. Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT-4, BERT and RoBERTa show promise in predicting and counselling through natural conversation. This paper presents the progress of an ongoing project where nearly half of development work is complete. So far, datasets have been collected and preprocessed, baseline models have been built, and early finetuning experiments are conducted. Results indicate that LLMs can recognize linguistic markers with better accuracy than traditional models, though ethical challenges and technical issues remain unresolved. The final stages will involve full finetuning, system integration, and real-world validation.

title: Dynamic Adaptive Aggregation and Feature Pyramid Network Enhanced GraphSAGE for Advanced Persistent Threat Detection in Next-Generation Communication Networks
authors: Liang Kou, Xiaochen Pan, Guozhong Dong, Meiyu Wang, Chunyu Miao, Jilin Zhang, Pingxia Duan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs) pose severe challenges to Next-Generation Communication Networks (NGCNs) due to their stealthiness and NGCNs’ dynamic topology, while conventional GNN-based intrusion detection systems suffer from static aggregation and poor adaptability to unseen nodes. To address these issues, this paper proposes DAA-FPN-SAGE, a lightweight graph-based detection framework integrating Dynamic Adaptive Aggregation (DAA) and Multi-Scale Feature Pyramid Network (MSFPM). Leveraging GraphSAGE’s inductive learning capability, the framework effectively models unseen nodes or subgraphs and adapts to NGCN’s dynamic changes (e.g., elastic network slicing, online AI model updates)—a key advantage for handling NGCN’s real-time topological variations. The DAA module employs multi-hop attention to dynamically assign weights to neighbors at different hop distances, enhancing capture of hierarchical dependencies in multi-stage APT attack chains. The MSFPM module fuses local-global structural information via a gated feature selection mechanism, resolving dimensional inconsistency and enriching attack behavior representation. Extensive experiments on StreamSpot, Unicorn, and DARPA TC#3 datasets demonstrate superior performance, meeting detection requirements of large-scale NGCNs.

title: Hysup-V: Quality-Aware 3D Vietnamese Sign Language Reconstruction With Anchor-Guided Kinematic Fusion
authors: Quang Nguyen Viet, Diep Nguyen Hoang, Hai-Anh Bui-Vu, Le Cong Thuong, Thanh Ha Le
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Reconstructing expressive 3D signing motion from in-the-wild monocular video remains difficult due to motion blur, compression artifacts, frequent hand and face occlusions. These degradations make standard pipelines temporally unstable and prone to losing fine articulator detail. We introduce HySUP-V, a reliability-aware framework that assesses and manages visual evidence quality across sequences. In Stage I (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$E Q A$</tex>), we score part-level image quality to select high-fidelity anchor frames as references. In Stage II (AKF), we enforce shape consistency by fusing specialized hand (MANO) and face (FLAME) estimates into a unified SMPL-X model and use geodesic pose transport to bridge degraded frames. Applying HySUP-V, we curate VSL-3D, a public dataset of 1,540 Vietnamese Sign Language clips with expressive SMPL-X parameters. Human evaluations yield a Mean Opinion Score of 3.47/5, plausible reconstructions with strong semantic preservation and hand accuracy, while highlighting remaining challenges in facial detail and motion naturalness.
