title: TBGA: Tripartite and Bipartite Graph Attention for Multi-modal Video Question Answering
authors: Junyeong Kim
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Multi-modal Video Question Answering (MVQA) is a complex and emerging task at the intersection of computer vision and natural language processing, which requires models to comprehend and reason over multiple synchronized information streams including video, audio, and textual transcripts to correctly answer natural language questions. Despite recent progress, many existing approaches rely on late-stage fusion mechanisms or learn shallow co-occurrence patterns between modalities and questions. These limitations hinder their ability to capture nuanced, fine-grained semantic interactions, especially in challenging benchmarks such as Social-IQ, which focus on social reasoning and subtle contextual understanding. In this work, we propose Tripartite and Bipartite Graph Attention (TBGA), a novel graph-based architecture specifically designed to address the semantic alignment challenges inherent in MVQA. TVGA employs a dual-graph strategy: a tripartite graph is used to explicitly model inter-modal relationships among video, audio, and transcript representations, while bipartite graphs are constructed between question tokens and each modality to enable question-aware semantic encoding. This design facilitates structured reasoning across heterogeneous modalities and ensures that information is integrated in a semantically coherent and interpretable manner. We validate the effectiveness of our approach through experiments on Social-IQ dataset, a benchmark designed to test high-level social and emotional reasoning in videos. Our model achieves state-of-the-art performance, significantly outperforming prior methods. These results demonstrate the potential of structured graph-based reasoning in advancing multi-modal understanding and highlight the benefits of explicit cross-modal alignment in complex video reasoning tasks.

title: A Delay Compensation for Adaptive Bandwidth Hysteresis Current Control
authors: Noritaka Kinjo, Shin Kawai, Triet Nguyen-Van
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: The adaptive bandwidth hysteresis current control (ABHCC) method proposed in previous work successfully addressed the challenge of maintaining a constant switching frequency, a known limitation of conventional hysteresis current control. ABHCC also offered low computational cost and enabled high-speed current regulation through FPGA implementation. However, it was observed that switching delays in power electronic devices caused the actual switching frequency to fall below the target. To address this issue, this study propose a novel control method that integrates ABHCC with state prediction control (SPC), explicitly accounting for switching delays. The proposed approach preserves the low online computational cost characteristic of ABHCC, thereby retaining its suitability for high-speed current control. Simulation and experimental results confirm that the proposed method effectively compensates for switching delay and brings the inverter’s switching frequency closer to the desired value.

title: Improving ocean color atmospheric correction near clouds with neural network
authors: Jilin Men, Wenkai Li, Xi Chen, Lian Feng, Liqiao Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Atmospheric correction is a prerequisite for deriving accurate ocean color products from satellite observations. However, current atmospheric correction algorithms directly mask clouds and around area to avoid the influence of cloud adjacency effects (CAEs), which degrade the quality of satellite observations, limiting the spatial-temporal continuity of water quality monitoring. In this study, we introduce the CAEs-effected Atmospheric correction for Polar-orbit satellites (CAP) algorithm, demonstrated using MODerate resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer-Aqua (MODISA) as an example. CAP is a physically constrained data-driven approach designed to enhance atmospheric correction performance in the presence of CAEs. The algorithm integrates the physical foundation of the standard atmospheric correction scheme implemented in SeaDAS with the cloud-adjacency correction information extracted from GOCI data. The GOCI-based CAE features are transferred to MODISA spectral bands and jointly used for model training. Validation using independent testing datasets shows that CAP achieves band-averaged correlation coefficients (R) of 0.97 with minimal bias and significantly reduces relative percentage differences near cloud edges. CAP improves signal-to-noise ratios by up to 53.7%, particularly in the red bands, and increases the number of valid observations by ~40%. Global-scale composites confirm that CAP can generate Rrs fields consistent with the results of the standard atmospheric correction in SeaDAS without applying straylight masks, thereby recovering valuable observations previously discarded. By mitigating CAE-induced biases while maintaining accuracy in cloud-free conditions, CAP enhances the reliability of bio-optical retrievals and expands observational coverage for ocean color applications. The methodology of integrating geostationary and polar-orbit sensor data provides a transferable framework for future satellite missions and can be extended to other challenging atmospheric correction scenarios.

title: A Transmission Line-Based Approach for Material Identification
authors: Ursula Resende, Jennifer Bento Vieira, Ulysses R. C. Vitor, Lucas D. Coelho
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: The accurate identification of materials is a fundamental requirement in several technological fields, including electrical engineering, telecommunications, and materials science. This study proposes a methodology for identifying non-magnetic materials based on the electromagnetic response of a transmission line. The material under investigation is inserted into the transmission line structure, functioning as the dielectric medium. Material identification is performed by comparing the measured input impedance with analytically calculated values derived from known dielectric permittivities. The methodology was validated through computational simulations and experimental tests using both microstrip and coaxial transmission line prototypes. The results confirm the feasibility of the proposed approach and highlight its potential for further refinement and broader applicability.

title: Learning Multi-view Anomaly Detection with Efficient Adaptive Selection
authors: Haoyang He, Jiangning Zhang, Guanzhong Tian, Chengjie Wang, Lei Xie
abstract: This study explores the recently proposed and challenging multi-view Anomaly Detection (AD) task. Single-view tasks will encounter blind spots from other perspectives, resulting in inaccuracies in sample-level prediction. Therefore, we introduce the Multi-View Anomaly Detection (MVAD) approach, which learns and integrates features from multi-views. Specifically, we propose a Multi-View Adaptive Selection (MVAS) algorithm for feature learning and fusion across multiple views. The feature maps are divided into neighbourhood attention windows to calculate a semantic correlation matrix between single-view windows and all other views, which is an attention mechanism conducted for each single-view window and the top-$k$ most correlated multi-view windows. Adjusting the window sizes and top-$k$ can minimise the complexity to $O((hw)^\frac{4}{3})$. Extensive experiments on the Real-IAD dataset under the multi-class setting validate the effectiveness of our approach, achieving state-of-the-art performance with an average improvement of +2.5$\uparrow$ across 10 metrics at the sample/image/pixel levels, using only 18M parameters and requiring fewer FLOPs and training time. The codes are available at https://github.com/lewandofskee/MVAD.

title: IF Estimation in Multi-Component Signals via Hough-Viterbi Algorithm with HGA-ADTFD
authors: Yaqin Zhao, Yuchen Liu, Longwen Wu
abstract: Instantaneous frequency estimation is significant in signal processing for non-stationary multi-component signals in dense time-frequency environments. Researchers studied different algorithms for instantaneous frequency to suppress frequency switching errors. However, many classical algorithms are susceptible to errors in the time-frequency distribution (TFD) and noise at instantaneous frequencies, which often degrades their performance for multi-component frequency estimation. We propose a hybrid genetic algorithm-optimized adaptive directional time-frequency distribution (HGA-ADTFD) to improve the efficiency of multi-signal processing in TFD. The proposed HGA-ADTFD algorithm optimizes TFD using genetic parameter optimization. Crucially, the algorithm implements a joint calibration strategy that fuses local linear segments from the Hough transform with continuous paths from the Viterbi algorithm to determine the final instantaneous frequency. The proposed HGA-ADTFD algorithm achieves a minimum root mean square error for the final instantaneous frequency value, which is reduced to 0.5 MHz (the sampling frequency is 100 MHz).

title: Maximizing Edge Throughput in Collaborative Multi-Task Inference With Shareable Model Structures_supp1-3658130.pdf
authors: Jigang Wu
abstract: Recent studies in collaborative edge computing fail to take advantage of shareable structures in multi-task learning (MTL) models and the potential of MTL models sharing at the edge. This leads to resource under-utilization at the edge. Thus, this paper focuses on shareable-structure-aware model deployment and task scheduling in collaborative multi-task inference, so as to fully utilize the low-latency potential of edge computing. Specifically, we formally define the problem with an objective to maximize edge throughput under multiple constraints (e.g., resource constraint, model integrity, etc.), and prove that it is NP-hard. To solve the problem, we first propose an approximation algorithm based on randomized rounding to generate sub-optimal solutions. We then present an adjustment strategy that generates a feasible solution when the approximation algorithm violates any of the given constraints. To evaluate the proposed algorithms, we conduct comprehensive simulations based on state-of-the-art MTL models, Google cluster-usage trace, and four kinds of computing units. Extensive experiments show that the proposed approximation algorithm coupled with the adjustment strategy, outperforms state-of-the-art methods for all cases, in terms of edge throughput.

title: A novel subtraction-based algorithm for finding d -MCs for all possible d
authors: Yi-Feng Niu, Yi-Fan Yan, Xiu-Zhen Xu, Deng-Guo Zhang
abstract: Reliability serves as a fundamental indicator for evaluating the performance of multi-state flow networks (MFNs). d-minimal cuts (d-MCs) are recognized as one of the most efficient tools for MFN reliability assessment. Finding d-MCs for all possible d plays a vital role in capturing the whole picture of MFN reliability. The existing method is grounded on the addition of (d−1)-MCs and a unit vector to generate d-MCs for all possible d. In contrast, this article proposes a novel method based on the subtraction of (d+1) MCs and a unit vector to obtain d-MCs for all possible d with enhanced computational performance. To date, this study is the first to explore the subtraction-based method for the d MCs for all possible d problem. Numerical experiments confirm that the proposed subtraction-based method is more efficient in comparison with the well-known addition-based method.

title: Ensemble Workload Prediction with Fluctuation Division Control in the Computing Power Network
authors: Shuaishuai Liu, Jin Wang, Ruwang Jiao, Benyuan Yang, Jingya Zhou, Kejie Lu
abstract: The Computing Power Network (CPN) is a distributed system that integrates computing resources to optimize utilization, but ensuring Quality of Service (QoS) is challenging due to high demand and complex heterogeneous connections. Accurate workload prediction is essential for maintaining QoS, yet the diverse and complex user requirements in CPN make prediction difficult. To address this challenge, we propose an ensemble workload prediction model with fluctuation division control for workload prediction in CPN, comprising three key components. First, we use the Three-Way Decision (3WD) approach to partition workload fluctuations, controlling granularity thickness and applying clustering to capture dynamic workload characteristics. Second, we develop tailored prediction methods for each of the three partitioned regions and ensembles them to enhance overall prediction performance. Third, the ensemble prediction method is applied to each region to obtain the final predicted values. The proposed method introduces an innovative fluctuation division control strategy for characteristic mining to capture dynamic workload fluctuation patterns and designs the effective ensemble workload prediction model deal with the problem of non-stationary workload prediction in CPN. Experimental results on trace datasets from Alibaba and Dinda demonstrate that the proposed model improves the higher average prediction accuracy by up to 26.06%$\sim$66.4% than the comparison methods.

title: Accelerating Belief Propagation with Task-Based Hardware Parallelism
authors: Balaji Venkatesh, Leo Han, Mark Jeffrey
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This project is the convergence of two directions, the first being innovations in belief propagation (BP), an inference algorithm for probabilistic graphical models. These are graphs where random variables form nodes, and a probability mass function forms edges. BP computes the marginal distributions of the nodes. Applications include workplace safety, cancer detection, and healthcare patient experience [1]–[3]. Existing implementations of BP fail to achieve acceptable convergence coverage, convergence rate, and linear scaling with hardware resources [4]–[7]. The second direction is hardware support for priority-ordered algorithms through task-based parallelism. Speculative hardware parallel execution of BP has been simulated and implemented in software, but no cost-effective pure hardware implementation exists [8]–[11]. This work implements BP on an FPGA-based speculative parallel accelerator and demonstrates the possibility of increased performance.

title: Digital Twin Modeling Method Based on the Dynamic Characteristics of Mobile Robots
authors: Binhao Ren, Shuting Wang, Xin Zhang, Yuanlong Xie
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: Current mobile robot navigation validation faces challenges with limited real-world testing and safety concerns. Digital twin technology offers a cost-effective and safe solution to accelerate algorithm validation and optimization. However, existing digital twin approaches often neglect the dynamic characteristics of mobile robots, resulting in significant discrepancies between the virtual model and the physical counterpart. To address this gap, this paper proposes a dynamics-integrated digital twin modeling method based on a two-wheel differential-drive mobile robot platform. Firstly, a complete dynamic model accounting for dynamic uncertainties is established. On one hand, a data-driven methodology is employed for offline identification of dynamic parameters, enabling high-fidelity modeling. On the other hand, for real-time model calibration, an adaptive theory-based online parameter identification method is designed. Coupled with establishing a real-time heterogeneous data communication link, this completes the construction of a comprehensive digital twin system. Experimental results demonstrate a high consistency between the model-predicted displacement and the actual motion state. Comparisons based on error metrics among three schemes—offline identification, online identification, and uncertainty consideration-validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in enhancing model fidelity. This research provides both theoretical support and practical insights for achieving highfidelity digital twin modeling of mobile robots.

title: Digital Twin-Enhanced Multimodal Learning for Robust Fault Detection in Photovoltaic Energy Systems
authors: Imen Nakti, Majdi Mansouri, Atef Khedher
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents a modality-specific artificial intelligence (AI) framework for fault diagnosis in photovoltaic (PV) systems, combining real sensor measurements with Digital Twin-augmented data. Electrical, thermal, and mechanical features from PV modules are treated as separate modalities, each analyzed by dedicated AI models that capture unique fault patterns. Their predictions are then integrated through an optimized late-fusion strategy, producing a unified and robust representation. The inclusion of Digital Twin simulations enhances class balance and improves robustness against noise. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed multimodal approach significantly outperforms single-modality models, achieving higher accuracy and reliability in PV fault detection. The study highlights the potential of combining real and synthetic PV data to support effective predictive maintenance strategies.

title: Energy Valley Optimizer Approach for Controlling Switched Nonlinear Systems
authors: Sabrine Ben Tekaya, Marwen Kermani, Ahmed Jaballi, Anis Sakly
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents an optimal control approach specifically designed for switched nonlinear systems. Based on a recently developed metaheuristic optimization technique called the Energy Valley Optimizer (EVO) algorithm, a hybrid control strategy is proposed to minimize a given performance criterion. The proposed method simultaneously determines the optimal switching instants and the optimal control schemes using the EVO algorithm. To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, a hydraulic two-tank system is considered as a case study.

title: 1-bit DAC for Image Enhancement of Q-band Direct Digital RF Transmitter
authors: Yuki Fujiya, Koki Furuuchi, Junhao Zhang, Tomoyuki Furuichi, Satoshi Tsukamoto, Noriharu Suematsu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper presents a 1-bit digital-to-analog converter (DAC) with high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and large output voltage amplitude, implemented using a cascode FETs configuration. The gate bias of the proposed 1-bit DAC is designed to be externally supplied, and enabling very short rise/fall times suitable for Q-band transmitters. A Q-band (40 GHz) direct digital RF transmitter that utilizes the image components of a 1-bit band-pass (BP) ΔΣ modulator, incorporating the proposed DAC, is evaluated. Measurement results show that the 3rd-order image signal at 40 GHz is enhanced, and the SNR and adjacent channel leakage ratio (ACLR) is improved by around 11 dB for CW and 16 dB for QPSK signal by using the proposed 1-bit DAC.

title: Testing Data Pipeline Limits for Stock Market Forecasting with Machine Learning Integration
authors: Joshua Padron-Uy, Keona Gagnier, Ajitesh Parihar, Albert Wong, Gaétan Hains
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This research aims to investigate the performance of a data pipeline system implemented using an extract, transform, load (ETL) tool under increased data volume. The system utilizes a data warehouse (DW) for an XGBoost machine learning model to forecast closing stock prices. The data source comes from the Financial Modelling Prep (FMP) API, which provides large amounts of real-time and historical data from the stock market.

title: A Parallel UE/gNB Emulator for Large-Scale Validation of 5G Core Networks
authors: Vu-Dung Luong, Kieu-Ha Phung
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: The evolution of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> and the transition to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 G}$</tex> demand advanced tools for testing complex network architectures, particularly UE and gNB interactions with the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> Core. This paper introduces an ue-gnb emulator modelling massive populations of UEs and gNBs as parallel state machines. By generating large-scale, programmable signaling storms, our emulator enables tremendous stress testing of core networks while remaining lightweight and configurable. Our emulator also supports conformance, performance, and robustness evaluation of open-source <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G}$</tex> Core implementations like Free5GC and Open5GS. It can validate the compliance with 3GPP specifications, measure platforms' key performance indicators under heavy load, and assess the robustness when controlled abnormal messages, information occur. The critical meaning of the emulator are shown in the uncovers of several hidden vulnerabilities in Free5GC and Open5GS.

title: A Hierarchical Autonomous Parking Method Based on Complexity-Adaptive Hybrid-Action Constrained Reinforcement Learning
authors: Muguang Ma, Chao Li, Ye Li
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: Autonomous parking in narrow, irregular urban environments is challenging, as current planning methods often yield non-smooth trajectories and low success rates in constrained scenarios. This paper proposes Complexity-Aware Hybrid-Action Constrained Reinforcement Learning (CHCRL), a hierarchical method to address these issues. CHCRL first quantifies scenario difficulty via a fuzzy complexity model and uses a Fuzzy Inference System for target pose estimation in unstructured areas. Second, it employs a Constrained Markov Decision Process with a hybrid action space (discrete intentions, continuous parameters) for smooth path generation. Crucially, a complexity-driven adaptive constraint mechanism dynamically adjusts safety thresholds based on the environmental score. Experimental results in parallel and perpendicular scenarios demonstrate that CHCRL significantly outperforms baselines (PPO, SAC), exhibiting superior robustness, safety, and efficiency, especially in complex parking tasks.

title: Optimizing Transaction Classification through Hybrid Feature Engineering and Advanced Machine Learning Algorithms
authors: Adel Rajab
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: The accelerated adoption of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies has facilities swift, decentralized transfer of value while simultaneously opening venues for illicit behavior such as money laundering, fraud, and the financing of terrorism. Because block chain records are pseudonymous and generate high dimensional data, effective detection demands sophisticated machine-learning (ML) models combined with network and graph-analysis methods to achieve reliable classification. This study offers a comparative assessment of ML classifiers to identify illegal activity in cryptocurrency transactions based on the Elliptic Bitcoin Transaction dataset. A two-stage feature selection approach including variance threshold method and random forest based feature ranking method was utilized to extract most informative features. Six ML classifiers, namely Random Forest (RF), K-Nearest Neighbor (KNN), Logistic Regression (LR), Support Vector Classifier (SVC), Gradient Boosting (GB), and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), were chosen and compared on a stratified train-test split based on accuracy, precision, recall, f1 score, confusion matrix, and ROCU-AUC score. The performance results illustrate how RF, GB, and the rest of the methods consistently produced the best 98% accuracy rate with almost flawless classification scores of (0.997, 0.994, and 0.982, respectively). However, the KNN achieved an AUC value of 0.963, and the margin-based SVC achieved an AUC value of 0.981. The results shows that using ensemble methods can greatly improve how intrusions are detection in cryptocurrency network, these models are able to spot subtle patterns in blockchain transactions, which has practical value for making Bitcoin networks more secure.

title: Computer Vision in Agriculture: Cacao Bean Sorting Using Deep Learning
authors: Marife A. Rosales, Angelita M. Pagcaliwagan
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This study presents the development of a cacao bean classification system that employs deep learning algorithms and computer vision. The objective of the study is to accurately and efficiently categorize the cacao beans into seven distinct classes, including good beans, bean clusters, fractured beans, flat beans, germinated beans, insect-damaged beans, and moldy beans. To ensure the gathering of consistent and high-quality image datasets, the authors developed an image acquisition setup that included a C920 Logitech camera and LED light strips. To identify the most effective algorithm, the proponents used different pre-trained convolutional neural network (CNN) models, including DenseNet201, ResNet50, VGG16, Googlenet, and others. The results indicate that DenseNet201 achieved the highest performance with 91.83% when the default parameters were employed during model development. The learning rate, mini-batch size, and solver were the optimized hyperparameters to further improve the performance of the model. The optimized trained model attained a training accuracy of 99.38 %, a validation accuracy of 99.6 %, and a testing accuracy of 100 %. The robustness of the model was evidenced by evaluation metrics such as precision of 99.59 %, recall of 99.54 %, and F1-score of 99.57 %. This research shows a promising application of computer vision and artificial intelligence in the agricultural sector.

title: Optimization of Photovoltaic-Based Distributed Generation, Battery Energy Storage Systems, and Controllable Loads in Smart Grids Using Manta-Ray Foraging Optimization Algorithm
authors: Joseph Usman, Sotdhipong Phichaisawat
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper presents a coordinated optimization approach for the integration of photovoltaic-based distributed generation (PV-DG), battery energy storage systems (BESS), and electric vehicle charging stations (EVCS) in the IEEE 33-bus distribution feeder. A full Newton-Raphson power-flow model implemented in MATPOWER is employed to accurately access voltage and system losses under various distributed energy resources (DER) configurations. The performance of two metaheuristic algorithms; the Manta Ray Foraging Optimization Algorithm (MRFOA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is compared for minimizing a weighted sum of active power loss, voltage deviation, and unmet peak load across four scenarios: baseline (no DER), PV-only, PV+EVCS, and PV+BESS+EVCS. Simulation results validate that MRFOA consistently achieves faster convergence than PSO and always satisfies operational constraints. In the PV-only scenario, MRFOA improves the minimum bus voltage from 0.913 p.u. (baseline) to 0.953p.u. and reduces active losses by 40 %. With the inclusion of EVCS and BESS, MRFOA further reduces losses to under 1 kW and maintains all voltages within ±3% of nominal, as confirmed by detailed quantitative metrics. These results demonstrate the effectiveness and practical applicability of MRFOA for multi-objective DER planning in smart distribution networks.

title: GAM Antenna Arrays for B5G Systems
authors: Gustavo F. Vicentine, Pei Xiao, Evandro Conforti, Arismar Cerqueira S.
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper investigates and compares irregular antenna arrays based on Golden Angle Modulation (GAM) with conventional Uniform Rectangular Arrays (URA) for 5G millimeter-wave (mmWave) applications, with a focus on mitigating grating lobes. A half-wave dipole antenna operating at 26 GHz is designed and integrated into various array configurations: URAs <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0.5\lambda,\ 5\lambda)$</tex> and GAM arrays <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(1.45\lambda,\ 2.91\lambda)$</tex>. Simulations are performed to evaluate key performance metrics, including peak gain, half-power beamwidth (HPBW), and sidelobe level (SLL). Results show that while URAs with large spacing suffer from severe grating lobes (e.g., SLL of -0.29 dB for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5\lambda$</tex> spacing), while the aperiodic structure of GAM arrays effectively suppresses them. The GAM <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.45\lambda$</tex> array with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.45\lambda$</tex> spacing achieves a high peak gain of 22.16 dBi, a narrow HPBW of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.5^{\circ}$</tex>, and an improved SLL of -16.71 dB. Beamforming analysis for this GAM array demonstrates robust steering capabilities for moderate angles (e.g., 20.50 dBi at 30°), with a typical gradual gain degradation at wider angles (e.g., 8.91 dBi at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$75^{\circ}$</tex>). This work highlights the superior performance of GAM arrays in mitigating grating lobes and providing effective beam steering, making them a promising solution for future wireless communication systems.

title: Extended Input Range Multi-inverter System Based On Novel Supercapacitor Assisted Ultra Low Frequency Switching Converter Technique
authors: Chamila Naligama, Nihal Kularatna, Alistair Steyn-Ross, Kosala Gunawardane
abstract: Supercapacitor-assisted loss management (SCALoM) concept has laid the theoretical foundation for developing high-efficiency power converters for renewable energy systems, using supercapacitors (SC) as lossless voltage droppers and energy buffers. The analytical study in this paper demonstrates how SCALoM is applied to reduce losses in renewable energy inverters. It is shown that the losses in input DC loop can be reduced by utilizing an even number of small inverters to deliver the overall load in combination with identical supercapacitor modules, instead of a stand-alone large inverter. Loss reduction occurs in the static transistor losses, copper losses, and DC bus capacitor series resistance, while adding DC-UPS capability to the inverter system. The proof of concept four-SCA-inverter system is composed of a four identical inverter combination coupled with four 250F supercapacitor modules, extends the input range of the inverter system by a factor of two. This reduces the voltage stress on the inverter components and the input loop rms current by a factor of two. The experimental four-SCA-inverter system, built with unmodified commercial inverters and 250F SC modules (switched at frequencies below frequency of 0.02Hz), indicates efficiency improvements upto 2.5% compared to parallel inverter arrangements. The central SPWM driven, optimized four-SCA-inverter arrangement indicates significant efficiency gains, at higher load levels compared to a single central inverter arrangement. As per the experimental observations the SCA-inverter design approach eliminates the load balancing and synchronisation issues associated with multi-inverter systems.

title: Robust Fault-Tolerant Control of Four-Phase Interleaved DC-DC Converter Under Switch Fault for Fuel Cell Application
authors: Shengrong Zhuo, Xinyu Liu, Yigeng Huangfu, Hao Bai, Ruiqing Ma, Shaoshuai Wang, Fei Gao
abstract: The multi-phase converter has been widely used for fuel cell (FC) applications. However, despite the continuous operation of the converter, the switch fault would deteriorate the control performance of the closed-loop controller, and cause increased input current ripple. To this end, in this paper, a robust fault-tolerant control based on the framework of active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) is proposed for a four-phase interleaved converter. In particular, the system control gain is updated based on the duty cycles, so that the control performance under switch fault can be maintained. On the other hand, the method of phase shift reconfiguration is proposed to suppress the input current ripple of multi-phase converters under switch fault, in which the optimal phase shift is calculated by optimizing the object function derived from the input current ripple model. The experimental results are provided to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Projection-Based Fusion of 2D LiDAR and Camera Data for Real-Time: Architecture and Experimental Evaluation : *Note: Sub-titles are not captured in Xplore and should not be used
authors: Walid Benayed, Mohamed Slim Masmoudi, Imen Mabrouk, Mounir Ben Nasr
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Perception is a fundamental requirement for mobile robots operating in dynamic and unstructured environments. While 3D LiDAR sensors provide accurate depth information, they remain costly and resource intensive. Cameras, on the other hand, offer rich semantic understanding but lack precise distance estimation. This paper introduces a lightweight perception framework that combines 2D LiDAR and RGB camera data within the ROS2 ecosystem. The approach leverages YOLOv9 for object detection and a projection-based method for associating LiDAR measurements with visual detections. The system has been validated experimentally, showing that it can provide reliable and real-time multi-modal perception suitable for a wide range of mobile robotic applications.

title: A Detection Strategy for False Data Injection Attack in Automatic Generation Control System
authors: Fanidhar Dewangan, Monalisa Biswal
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Controlling system frequency is critical for operational reliability and stability of power systems. Automatic generation control (AGC) plays a key role in controlling the deviation in frequency and tie-line power flow within the defined limits as they may lead to operational interference or infrastructure damage. AGC relies on communication networks for the transmission of system measurements and control signals. Unfortunately, this dependence creates vulnerabilities to cyber-physical false data injection (FDI) attacks which are difficult to identify and pose a threat to the stability of the system. In multi-area power systems, the frequency control is complemented by the minimization of tie-line power flows. The prevalence of smart grid technologies incorporating digital communication infrastructure poses an increased risk for cyber-attacks aimed at AGC. This work introduces a method to detect FDI attacks targeting to AGC in a two-area power network. It works by first calculating a clean area control error (ACE) under normal conditions and then comparing that baseline with an ACE recalculated from attack-driven data. In this study, various types of attacks such as step, ramp, random, scaling, and sinusoidal, are injected into frequency and tie-line power information. A threshold limit is set based on the statistical relation between the mean and standard deviation of change in ACE value. The attack is detected when the change in ACE value exceeds the threshold value. The proposed method is applied and validated on the data obtained from the simulation of Indian Eastern Regional Grid model, developed in PSCAD.

title: Efficient Object Detection in Remote Sensing Images Based on Feature Weaving and Redundancy Suppression
authors: Yunze Bai, Changming Song, Yun Wang, Peiyan Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing object detection faces significant challenges in handling scale variations, complex backgrounds and dense target distributions. Existing models often struggle with high computational costs and massive number of parameters, hindering deployment on resource-limited devices. To address these issues, we propose an efficient object detection network based on feature weaving and redundancy suppression called EWS-YOLO, featuring two components: (1) The Weave-Gated Parallel (WGP) module employs grouped convolution with interlaced cascading and gating mechanisms to achieve implicit multi-scale feature extraction and adaptive fusion, significantly enhancing multi-scale target detection capability. (2) The Redundancy-Suppressed Feature Pyramid Network (RFS-FPN) integrates an Progressive Shuffle Upsampling mechanism coupled with Dynamic Feature Fusion, enabling intelligent fusion of low-level spatial details and high-level semantic features while effectively suppressing redundant information through adaptive channel-wise feature recalibration. Experimental results on VisDrone, DIOR and UAVDT datasets demonstrate EWS-YOLO's superior performance, achieving 42.4%, 95.2%, 98.7% mAP@.50 respectively while reducing parameters by 41% compared to YOLOv8s, making it particularly suitable for resource-constrained applications.

title: Learning to Optimize RIS-RSMA for Multi-Robot Communication with Max-Min Fairness
authors: Zhuoran Chen, Yang Ding, Keyu Jia, Nina Zhang, Zongkai Tian
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: This paper proposes an automated control framework for multi-robot communication systems. In this framework, a base station (BS) coordinates a team of robots through dynamically optimized wireless links. We develop a Graph Neural Network (GNN) based approach to achieve automated control of BS power allocation, beamforming, and reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) phase shifts. By modeling the communication environment as a graph, our method enables fully automated control. This control dynamically adapts to real-time channel conditions and robot mobility patterns. The control objective is to achieve max-min rate fairness through autonomous resource allocation, thereby ensuring reliable connectivity for all robotic agents. Simulation results demonstrate that our automated controller achieves superior performance in convergence speed and adaptation capability. Consequently, it provides an effective solution for autonomous multi-robot operations in complex environments.

title: Region-Level Vision-Language Model for Detecting Distraction Behavior and Mobility Attributes of Vulnerable Road Users
authors: Dai Quoc Tran, Mohamed Abdel-Aty, Younggun Kim, Ahmed S. Abdelrahman, Zubayer Islam
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Vulnerable road users (VRUs) such as pedestrians and cyclists frequently engage in distracted behaviors (e.g., phone or headphone use) that elevate crash risk. General-purpose vision–language models (VLMs) struggle to capture these subtle, small, and context-dependent cues, and most camera pipelines still rely on frame-based analyses that ignore temporal context. We present IntersectionPAR, a lightweight vision–language framework that couples an Interactive Attribute Encoder with region-level captioning to recover safety-relevant semantic attributes (gender, phone/headphone use, mobility mode and aids) together with kinematic cues in a bird’s-eye view. We further introduce a temporal risk module that computes a continuous Situational Awareness Score (from phone, pose, and gaze proxies) and a Dynamic Risk Score that fuses awareness with spatial context (safe vs. unsafe zones), aligning system output with the specific moments practitioners need to act. Our dataset contains 12,273 annotated images drawn from~200 intersection-crossing scenarios under varied lighting and weather. Under a standardized zero-shot protocol against a broad suite of modern VLMs, IntersectionPAR attains keyword-based accuracy of 0.6123 with balanced precision/recall (0.7936/0.7864) and an F1-score of 0.7719 while requiring only ~9 GB of VRAM(>40 GB for several baselines). Qualitative analyses show strong behavior on safety-critical cues (e.g., cane and mobility-aid detection) and illustrate how the temporal risk module elevates risk precisely when low-awareness VRUs enter the roadway. Statistical analyses of 200 crossing events further reveal behavioral impacts of phone use (e.g., longer waiting time and increased path deviation). By pairing accurate, attribute-aware perception with low computational cost and an actionable temporal risk signal, IntersectionPAR supports real-time intersection safety monitoring and proactive interventions to mitigate VRU risk.

title: One Size Doesn't Fit All: Age-Aware Gamification Mechanics for Multimedia Learning Environments
authors: Sarah Kaißer, Markus Kleffmann, Kristina Schaaff
abstract: Gamification is widely used in digital learning. However, most systems neglect age-related differences. This paper investigates how gamification can be designed in an age-aware way to address learners' diverse motivational and cognitive needs. Based on a targeted literature review, we present a mapping of age groups, mechanics, and effects. Furthermore, we derive five design principles for age-specific gamification and identify three technical patterns for implementation in multimedia learning environments. The results indicate that gamification is not universally effective, but rather requires a differentiated design to support engagement and inclusivity across the lifespan.

title: Hierarchical Synergistic Fusion Network for Multi-sensor Fault Diagnosis of Harmonic Drives with Small Samples
authors: Yong Xu, Jiaxian Chen, Kairu Wen, Ruyi Huang, Guolin He, Weihua Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Harmonic drives are a key component in many high-end systems and a potential weak point affecting operational stability. Thus, studying fault diagnosis methods for harmonic drives is of significant importance. In recent studies, the use of multi-sensor data for joint diagnosis has gained increasing attention, though most existing models still rely heavily on fault data. To address this challenge, this paper proposes a diagnostic model named Hierarchical Synergistic Fusion Network (HSFNet), which achieves accurate identification of harmonic drive faults under small-sample conditions. First, the model maps multi-sensor data into the time-frequency domain and dynamically recalibrates input weights to emphasize different sensor signals. Then, a multi-source features fusion module is designed to capture fault characteristics from receptive fields of different scales, enhancing interactions and fusion of both same-scale and cross-scale features to strengthen the model's representational capacity. Finally, a classification projection head compresses features and outputs diagnostic results. Validation and comparative analysis on the collected dataset demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method.

title: Hybrid Centrality and Temporal Dynamics Framework for Identifying Influential Nodes and Predicting Links in Complex Networks
authors: S Venkata Rao, DVH Venu Kumar
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: For applications like recommendation systems, information diffusion, and epidemic control, it is essential to identify influential nodes in complex networks. Conventional centrality measures use global structures, which are more computationally expensive, or local structures, which are less accurate. For link prediction, recent developments have suggested ensemble learning techniques, mixed and global isolating centralities, and more. Three essential elements are integrated in the Hybrid Centrality Temporal Dynamics (HCTD) framework. Initially, it presents a Hybrid Centrality Score (HCS) that blends Global Isolating Centrality (ISCD2) and Mixed Centrality (MC). Second, it uses modeling of temporal dynamics to monitor the evolution of influence over time. Third, it uses link prediction based on machine learning to foresee upcoming significant interactions. A variety of datasets, such as social media, transportation, and biological networks, are used to validate the framework. Experiments with SIR simulations and ensemble prediction models demonstrate that HCTD consistently outperforms existing methods in identifying both current and emerging influential nodes.

title: A Wideband Bi-Directional Variable-Gain Amplifier with Low Phase Variation for Phased Array System
authors: Chun-Hsiang Yang, Tzyh-Ghuang Ma, Kun-You Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper presents a wideband bi-directional variable-gain amplifier (VGA) for millimeter-wave (mmW) communication, implemented in 90 nm CMOS technology. The amplifier employs a two-stage differential structure to achieve bidirectional wideband performance with minimal phase variation. In the forward path, the measured 3-dB bandwidth is from 23.13 GHz to 44.69 GHz, with an insertion loss of 1.48 dB. The gain control range (GCR) is 17.3 dB, with a maximum root mean square (RMS) phase variation of 1.73°. In the backward path, the measured 3-dB bandwidth is from 23.32 GHz to 45.83 GHz, with an insertion loss of 1.87 dB. The GCR is 16.5 dB, with a maximum RMS phase variation of 5.48°. The chip consumes 28.5 mW of DC power from a 1.2-V supply, occupying a core area of 0.37 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title: Cybersecure Line Differential Relay Based on Transient Signatures and Decision Tree Classification
authors: Suryanarayana Gangolu, Rakesh Kumar Panda, Suman M, CH. Venkateswarlu
abstract: This paper presents a novel cybersecurity-enhanced complementary method to the line current differential protection scheme, addressing the vulnerability of current measurements to cyberattacks during data exchange. A hybrid protection framework combining the Transient Fault Signature Method (TFSM) and a Decision Tree Classifier (DTC) is proposed for detecting normal conditions, physical faults, and cyberattacks in transmission lines. TFSM extracts transient features such as signal energy, peak, and harmonic content, while the DTC enables fast and interpretable classification. Unlike conventional approaches that rely on fixed thresholds, the proposed TFSM–DTC method detects both physical faults and cyber anomalies at the signal level using lightweight computations. The proposed technique was validated using the WSCC 9-bus system modeled in PSCAD/EMTDC, achieving an overall classification accuracy of 99.37%, with recall of 0.9938. These results confirm the method’s robustness, computational efficiency, and suitability for real-time implementation in smart grid protection relays.

title: Adaptive Spatial Filtering and Linear Discriminant Learning for Robust Motor Imagery EEG Classification
authors: Sricheta Parui, Ayush Das, Sayan Banerjee, Mahendra Kumar Gourisaria, Rakesh Kumar Rai
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: This study explores the use of electroencephalography (EEG) signals for classifying motor imagery (MI) tasks involving imagined left- and right-hand movements. To achieve accurate discrimination, we integrate Common Spatial Patterns (CSP) for spatial feature extraction along with Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) for classification. EEG recordings were obtained from 59 scalp electrodes positioned to capture neural activity in motor-related cortical regions. The signals were preprocessed using an $\mathbf{8 - 1 5 ~ H z}$ band-pass filter to suppress noise and emphasize the sensorimotor rhythms relevant to movement imagination. Experimental evaluations on MI data demonstrate that the proposed CSP-LDA pipeline effectively distinguishes between different hand-imagery classes, suggesting its potential use in developing reliable and user-adaptive Brain-Computer Interface (BCI) systems for neurorehabilitation and assistive technology applications.

title: Characterization of HW-SW configurations in FPGA-based adaptive AI Imaging Systems
authors: Wadie Ben Abdallah, Wassim Ghiloufi, Nader Ben Amor
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: An adaptive edge-computing system can adjust its computing resources to different constraints, such as remaining energy, workload requirements or available computing resources. The system has different hardware (HW) software (SW) configurations. The different configurations are generated and characterized offline using the metrics: “ consumed power” and “execution time”. The adaptation controller ensures optimal configuration selection through continuous evaluation of system constraints and the diferent operating scenarios. In this article, we focus on the offline characterization of different HW-SW configurations for two applications: Sobel filtering and facial recognizing. We present the design and characterization of two specific HW accelerators used in each application configuration. The different architectures were tested on the FPGA ZedBoard.

title: A Case Study With Concurrency and Data-Tensor Parallelism Scenarios in vLLM
authors: Tuan-Duc Chu, Tien-Son Pham, Hong-Quan Tran, Van-Sang Pham, Anh-Tuan Mai, Xuan Truong Nguyen, Thanh-Tuan Dao
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have gained widespread adoption across a variety of applications, but serving them efficiently in production remains a nontrivial challenge. Optimal deployment requires a deep understanding of model scalability and throughput behavior under different configurations. In this work, we conduct an in-depth benchmarking study to characterize the scalability and throughput patterns of LLMs, with a particular focus on the vLLM inference engine. Our evaluation includes two representative LLM architectures: dense and Mixture-of-Experts (MoE). By analyzing throughput at both the system and architectural levels, we uncover how factors such as model structure and inference scheduling interact to influence performance. Our findings provide actionable insights for configuring vLLM to achieve high efficiency across diverse LLM workloads.

title: A Framework for Real-Time Semantic Duplicate Detection in Q&A Platforms using a Serverless Autonomous Agent
authors: Poorvi Srikanth, K G Deeksha, Pooja Sharma, Charulatha Reddy, L Suresh, Prashanth Kannadaguli
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: The rapid growth of community-driven platforms, such as Stack Overflow, has resulted in vast amounts of unstructured and often redundant question-answer pairs, making it difficult for users to efficiently retrieve high-quality solutions. To address this challenge, we propose SO-Janitor-Agent, an intelligent system designed to automate the cleaning, organization, and retrieval of Stack Overflow content. In the first phase, raw data is collected through web scraping and processed into a curated golden data set by removing noise, duplicates, and inconsistencies. In the second phase, we develop a semantic search engine powered by natural language processing techniques to provide context-aware retrieval of relevant answers rather than simple keyword matches. To ensure scalability, portability, and ease of deployment, the third phase involves containerizing the application with Docker and deploying it to Google Cloud Run, enabling serverless and costefficient execution. In the next stage, the system is extended to a fully automated AI agent using the n8n workflow, allowing continuous monitoring, intelligent decision-making, and dynamic interaction with Stack Overflow data. The proposed system demonstrates how data cleaning, semantic search, and agentdriven cloud-native deployment can be combined to improve developer productivity and accessibility to high-quality technical knowledge.

title: Effective Graph Resistance Based Vulnerability Assessment Framework for Cyber Resilient CPPS
authors: Jigyasa Singhai, K Shanti Swarup
abstract: Cyber-Physical Power Systems (CPPS) integrate traditional power infrastructure with information technology, creating new opportunities for smarter and more adaptive grid operation. At the same time, this interconnection increases the system’s exposure to cyber risks. To address this challenge, we present a graph-theoretic framework that uses Effective Graph Resistance (EGR) to identify structurally vulnerable elements in the cyber layer of CPPS. Unlike conventional centrality measures, EGR captures the overall connectivity and redundancy of the network, making it well-suited for resilience assessment. The developed approach is applied to standard IEEE 9-bus (WSCC 9-bus), 14-bus, and 39-bus systems. The results show that the proposed methodology identifies both vulnerable nodes and links whose removal significantly increases the network’s EGR, hence identified as critical elements in systems. Protecting and prioritising these components can significantly enhance system resilience.

title: Comparative Analysis of Flywheel and Battery Energy Storage Systems for Smoothing Photovoltaic Power Output
authors: Anil Bhatt, Bipin Subedi, Nita Kumari Phuyal, Aashish Yakami, Gaurav Tamrakar
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) power generation fluctuates due to the intermittent behavior of irradiance, which in turn results in voltage fluctuations and power quality degradation. These issues need to be mitigated for stable power output, which can be done by employing PV power smoothing techniques. Use of Energy Storage Systems (ESSs) in this application is one of the ways of mitigating the intermittency issue. This study aims to analyze and compare the performance of Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) and Flywheel Energy Storage System (FESS) for PV power smoothing. Mathematical models of PV, BESS and FESS were developed in MATLAB and evaluated using 300 seconds of varying irradiance data. A power management strategy was formulated to regulate power flow between the PV and ESSs. Three test cases with different capacities of FESS and BESS separately were simulated to examine the impact of ESS sizing. Results show a significant reduction in PV power fluctuations after using ESSs. However, FESS shows better performance in smoothing the PV power of up to 91% due to its rapid response towards power fluctuations for a short period of time.

title: Efficient Wide Area Data Compression - A Ramanujan's Sum-Based Approach
authors: Manish Pandit, Ranjana Sodhi
abstract: Phasor Measurement Unit (PMU) forms the major building block for the enhanced situational awareness in the Wide Area Monitoring System (WAMS). However, due to higher reporting rates of PMU (50-60 frames per second), the requirements of bandwidth as well as storage are increasing rapidly. To alleviate this issue, this paper proposes a two-stage scheme for efficient compression of such a vast amount of PMU data. Stage-1 applies Ramanujan's Sum-based Fault Window Detection (RSFD) algorithm on the multi-PMU data to extract the disturbance window from PMU data buffer. Stage-2 implements Ramanujan's Sum-based transforms on simplified windows to exploit temporal redundancies. Moreover, the Principal Component Analysis (PCA) scheme is employed to exploit the spatial redundancies resulting in the efficient compression of the data. The proposed scheme is validated on the benchmark IEEE 14-bus system by utilizing the Real-Time Digital Simulator (RTDS) that mimics the real-world performance of the simulated system. The results validate that the proposed method outperforms the traditional Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) based method.

title: Explainable Brain Tumor Segmentation With Attention-Guided Variational Autoencoder
authors: Avinash Gusain, Parveen Kumar
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Accurate delineation of brain tumors in MRI is central to modern neuro-oncology, because treatment decisions and prognosis strongly depend on the exact tumor extent. The task remains difficult in practice due to large variations in tumor appearance, irregular and fuzzy borders, and often subtle contrast between lesions and normal brain tissue. This work introduces a unified deep-learning pipeline in which dual attention blocks are coupled with a variational autoencoder branch, and the resulting segmentation network is augmented with gradient-based visualization to provide interpretable outputs. The framework was trained on BraTS 2023 dataset [?] using Adam optimizer ($\mathbf{r}=\mathbf{1 e}-\mathbf{4}$, batch size 8) on NVIDIA RTX 3090, achieving Dice scores of $\mathbf{8 9. 2 \%}$ (ET), $\mathbf{9 2. 1 \%}$ (NCR/NET), $\mathbf{9 1. 5 \%}$ (WT) with mean 90.9%, alongside sensitivity 97.36%, specificity $\mathbf{9 7. 4 8 \%}$, and accuracy $\mathbf{9 7. 4 2 \%}$. Grad-CAM visualizations confirm focus on clinically relevant tumor regions. By combining attention-driven localization, VAE uncertainty modeling, and explainability, this approach advances robust, interpretable segmentation for neuro-oncology applications.
