title: Healthcare Seeking Behavior of Tuberculosis Using Logistic Regression Model
authors: Achinta Saikia, Deba Kumar Baruah, Diganta Kalita
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Background: India has been known as a developing country in the world and has to face several developmental challenges. One of the major challenges is the disease problem which impacts both quantity and quality of human resources that are available for the growth of the nation. Objective: Study on health seeking behavior of tuberculosis in rural and urban area of Jonai, Dhemaji, Assam. Methods: It followed a descriptive, nonexperimental research design with a quantitative measure to investigate health seeking behaviour of tuberculosis among rural and urban population of Dhemaji district, Assam. Conclusion: In this study, a logistic regression model was developed to predict tuberculosis (TB) based on three key risk factors related to health-seeking behavior. The model classifies on individuals into healthy or patient groups, with sensitivity of 40% and specificity of 79%. These results suggest that the model is effective at identifying TB cases, although there is potential for improvement in sensitivity. Thus, the logistic regression model is a valuable tool for early detection and can be instrumental in guiding TB prevention efforts in these communities.

title: LlamaIDS: Real-Time Detection Model of Zero-Day Intrusions Using Large Language Models
authors: Faqiang Wang, Qun Weng, Manman Zhang, Yunlong Shao, Zakaria Alomari, Adetokunbo Makanju, Zhida Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Zero-day intrusions, which exploit previously unknown vulnerabilities, present a significant challenge in cybersecurity. To address this, the LlamaIDS architecture is proposed to leverage the fine-tuned Llama 3.2 large language model, alongside Wireshark, Snort rules, and network data from the UNSW-NB15 dataset for advanced real-time detection. This system includes two primary phases: fine-tuning and detection, significantly enhancing accuracy and reducing false positive rate compared to the original Llama model, thus providing a robust and adaptive solution for real-time zero-day intrusion detection.

title: A Hybrid Machine Learning Framework for Improving Delayed Graduation Prediction Accuracy in Employed Postgraduate Students
authors: Dong Li, Mengyao Sui
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: With the continuous expansion of China's graduate student enrollment, the contradiction between cultivation quality and cultivation scale has been highlighted, and the phenomenon of delayed graduation has become more and more common, among which the problem of delayed graduation of employed graduate students is particularly prominent. In order to identify students facing the risk of delayed graduation in advance, this paper firstly analyzes the influence of two features, "gender" and "job type", on the accuracy of delayed graduation prediction through experiments, so as to determine the feature set for delayed graduation prediction. Subsequently, this paper designs a prediction framework based on multiple prediction algorithms, which can realize the optimal matching of prediction methods, key parameters and prediction data. Through experimental validation on the MBA dataset of a western university, this framework significantly outperforms other methods in terms of accuracy, recall, precision, and F1 scores, which are improved by 9.68%, 76.99%, 26.05%, and 73.81%, respectively. The Friedman mean rank test and the significance level test further confirm the superiority of this framework.

title: Design and Performance of Grid-Forming Controls for Power Electronic Transformer with Photovoltaic Integration on Low-Voltage DC Link
authors: Luis Diego Piseno-Estrada, Edgar Lenymirko
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This paper presents the design of a three-stage Solid-State Transformer (SST) with a photovoltaic (PV) array connected at the low-voltage DC (LVDC) link and the evaluation of its performance. The PV system supplies a fraction of the load demand, while the rest is drawn from the medium-voltage AC (MVAC) grid. Grid-forming strategies—droop control and Virtual Synchronous Machine (VSM)—are implemented in the rectifier and inverter to enhance system flexibility. The SST is evaluated under MVAC voltage sags, PV generation loss, and abrupt load changes to compare the control responses. The simulation results show that both methods maintain system stability. VSM offers smoother dynamic behavior during voltage sags, while droop control supports modular operation by allowing independent stage control. In contrast, VSM requires synchronization between stages, which may reduce modular flexibility.

title: Robust Multimodel Ho Control Design for Nonlinear Systems: Disturbance Rejection
authors: Rihab Abdelkrim
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: Nonlinear systems are central to modern engineering applications but remain difficult to regulate due to their complex dynamics and sensitivity to external disturbances. Robust control methods, particularly $\mathrm{H} \infty$ techniques, provide systematic tools to guarantee stability and performance under uncertainty. This paper presents a design approach that integrates $\mathrm{H} \infty$ loop-shaping with multimodel representations to achieve resilient control of nonlinear systems. The loop-shaping scheme is employed to attenuate disturbances in real operating environments while shaping open-loop dynamics to meet robustness and performance specifications. Two architectures are proposed that incorporate these methods, ensuring improved transient responses and practical applicability. Simulation studies confirm the effectiveness of the multimodel $\mathrm{H}_{\infty}$ design in rejecting disturbances, underscoring its potential as a robust solution for complex nonlinear applications.

title: A Comparative Performance Analysis of Deep Learning-Based Motorcycle Tracking Models at Urban Intersections: A Vietnamese Case Study
authors: Vinh Nguyen Dang The, Thu Huynh De, Huy Truong Dinh
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Monitoring motorcycle traffic at urban intersections presents a significant challenge in intelligent transportation systems, especially in Vietnam, where motorcycles account for a large proportion of vehicle flow. This study evaluates the performance of various combinations of object detection and tracking models under real Vietnamese context. Specifically, we compare two detection models RT-DETR-L and YOLOv11-L paired with three popular tracking algorithms: ByteTrack, BoT-SORT, and DeepSORT. The dataset is created using traffic videos recorded at an actual Vietnamese intersection with heavy traffic during both daytime and nighttime conditions. For evaluation purposes, we generate two high-quality ground truth files using CVAT software, combining automated tools with manual annotation. Numerical results show that the RT-DETRL combined with ByteTrack achieved the highest identity preservation performance, with an IDF1 score of 83.2 % during the daytime and 69.5 % at nighttime. Meanwhile, the RT-DETR-L with BoT-SORT demonstrated greater stability in localization, achieving a MOTA score of 65.1 % during the daytime and 62.1 % at nighttime. DeepSORT exhibited the lowest performance under both lighting conditions. Combinations using YOLOv11-L generally performed worse than those using RT-DETRL. Further analysis revealed that ByteTrack is more effective in handling object occlusion, while BoT-SORT is better suited for scenarios involving directional changes. These findings provide critical empirical insights for selecting optimal configurations in traffic surveillance applications in Vietnam.

title: New PSO based algorithm for ARX Laguerre model parameters optimization
authors: Marwa Yousfi, Chakib Ben Njima, Tarek Garna
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: The present work focuses on optimizing the parameters of the ARX-Laguerre SISO (single input single output) model using a Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) approach. The efficiency of the ARX-Laguerre model is highly sensitive to the selection of its Laguerre poles, making their optimal tuning essential. To address this, we employ a metaheuristic optimization technique, namely the PSO algorithm, to determine the best pole values. The performances of the presented algorithm is shown through validation on a CSTR benchmark.

title: Analyzing the Impact of DMSO Treatment on Biofilms: A Textural Description and Unsupervised Approach
authors: Diego G. Cano-Rodríguez, Jonás Grande-Barreto, David I. Loaiza-Toscuento, Elizabeth Perez-Corona, Julio C. Ramírez-San-Juan, Teresita Spezzia-Mazzocco, Hayde Peregrina-Barreto
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: The study of microbial behavior helps us understand how microorganisms grow and how they can be effectively treated. While standard techniques can evaluate the effectiveness of treatments on microorganisms, these methods often require the destruction of samples, which limits ongoing research. Alternative techniques, such as Laser Speckle Imaging (LSI), provide a non-invasive and rapid way to analyze the viability of biological samples. This work examines whether information from LSI images can be utilized to differentiate the impact of treatments on biofilms of Candida tropicalis, a species that is part of the normal human microbiota but can also act as an opportunistic pathogen, commonly found in hospital patients and medical instruments. To achieve this, a Time History representation was processed, and features were extracted from the Gray Level Run Length Matrix. Finally, samples were clustered using K-means, demonstrating that it is possible to differentiate the effects of various treatment doses based on the dynamic description provided by LSI.

title: Controller design based on passivity for a power factor correction regulator three-phase AC-DC converter
authors: Cuauhtémoc Guerrero, Rodrigo Loera-Palomo, César A. Hernández-Jacobo, Víctor Santibañez, José Luis Meza-Medina
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: In this work, a controller is developed to manipulate the modulation rates for the generation of Pulse Width Modulation (PWM) signals for the power semiconductor devices in a three-phase AC-DC converter. These modulation rates are used to regulate the voltage of an RL load, simultaneously achieving a unity power factor in the three-phase supply. The control law is designed based on a model of an average circuit in a two-phase synchronous reference frame. The control contains two loops; the inner loop takes advantage of the properties of the model to utilize passivity-based techniques, and the outer loop is a PI control. The proposed controller is tested in a computer simulation, showing its physical implementation.

title: Strategic Edge Cloud Placement via Clustering of Telecommunication Infrastructure
authors: Rohan Singh Takhi, Sudhakar Kumar, Sunil K. Singh, Saksham Dargan, Varsha Arya, Kwok Tai Chui, Brij B. Gupta
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: With the imminent increase in Internet users in Australia, where the average annual growth rate is 2.97%, this article addresses the growing demand for low-latency connectivity by optimizing mobile edge computing (MEC) placement using unsupervised clustering on Australian telecommunication site data. So, low-latency Internet is available to the maximum number of users as fast as possible. This paper explores finding the best locations to setup Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) servers, with the goal of improving internet speed and reducing response time for users across the country. Four clustering models-Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM), DBSCAN, Spectral Clustering, and a graph-based approach were applied to identify spatial patterns in infrastructure distribution. GMM revealed a well-balanced structure in ten clusters, the largest containing more than 17,000 sites. DBSCAN exposed a single dominant cluster of 95,404 sites, along with small dense pockets and noise points, indicating urban concentration and rural sparsity. Spectral clustering produced nuanced segmentation, capturing metropolitan and regional variations, with top clusters ranging from 19,985 to a few dozen sites. Cluster centroids were used to propose optimal edge server locations, balancing latency reduction with infrastructural feasibility. The results demonstrate strong clustering in both metropolitan areas and regional areas, reflecting diverse demands and deployment needs of the network. The findings provide a strategic framework for cost-effective MEC rollouts, enhancing service accessibility and responsiveness in dynamic telecom ecosystems.

title: Cyclo-AMC: Automatic Modulation Classification on Versal utilising Cyclostationary Features
authors: Ruilin Wu, Carol Jingyi Li, Wei Zhang, Xueyuan Liu, Philip H.W. Leong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Field Programmable Technology (ICFPT)
abstract: Recently, it has been shown that cyclostationary features can greatly improve generalization of deep neural network (DNN) automatic modulation classification (AMC) systems. Unfortunately, its computation has a high computational cost, limiting its application in real-time settings. To address these issues, we present Cyclo-AMC, the first field-programmable gate array (FPGA)-based custom AMC accelerator that combines cyclostationary features with a DNN. Cyclo-AMC runs entirely on an AMD Versal VEK280 AI Engine-Machine Learning (AIE-ML) device and integrates an area-efficient implementation of the FFT accumulation method (FAM) algorithm to extract cyclostationary features, with a compact ResNet-18 model. Cyclo-AMC achieves a 32× reduction in energy consumption over an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3090 graphics processing unit (GPU). On the CSPB.ML.2022 dataset, Cyclo-AMC achieves 93.8% classification accuracy compared to 81.7% for FINN-A.

title: Group-Aware DDQN with Markovian Reward Adjustment for Vehicular Spectrum Access Under Intermittent Jamming
authors: Danh Le, Thanh-Dat Le, Tri-Hai Nguyen
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Vehicular networks rely on stable and low-latency spectrum access to support safety, infotainment, and cooperative driving applications. However, intermittent jamming poses a persistent threat to reliable communications. Recent advances in deep reinforcement learning (DRL) have demonstrated promise in spectrum access by capturing temporal dependencies in partially observable environments. Yet, most existing approaches treat jamming as either static or memoryless, overlooking its temporal correlation. In this paper, we extend prior work on Double Deep Q-Networks (DDQN) with history stacking-based vehicular spectrum access by introducing a group-aware Markovian reward adjustment framework. Vehicles are partitioned into groups targeted by jammers with correlated activity patterns, modeled as two-state Markov chains. Transition probabilities are estimated online and incorporated into both the state representation and reward design, enabling proactive avoidance of high-risk channels and unnecessary handoffs. Simulation results show that the proposed approach accelerates convergence, increases deadline satisfaction, and improves data completion rates compared to standard DQN and ALOHA baselines.

title: Intelligent Control with Artificial Neural Network and Double-Integral SMC for Nonlinear Pathophysiological Model
authors: Didar Murad, Omar Zeb, Atif Rehman, Iftikhar Ahmad, Muhammad Tariq Saeed, Rehan Zafar Paracha
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: The intense inflammatory complications of COVID-19 are substantially fueled by an imbalanced kallikrein-kinin system (KKS), resulting in a toxic bradykinin (BK) storm. This work responds to the pressing need to modulate this multifaceted pathophysiology by developing a ten-state nonlinear mathematical model of the SARS-CoV-2 activated KKS. We proposed an intelligent control with an artificial neural network (ANN) and a double-integral sliding mode controller (DISMC). The two control schemes reveal an inherent trade-off. Although the ANN controller is adaptive, model-free, and smooth, it can be sensitive to changes in model parameters. In contrast, the DISMC ensures robustness, accuracy, and stability but generates control signals with undesired oscillatory behavior. The simulation results reveal that pathological entities including the BK-B2 receptor complex, the pro-inflammatory cytokine interleukin-6 (IL-6), and the therapeutic drug Icatibant show restorative trends. This study provides a strong ground for the development of smart, auto-regulated drug infusion devices and tailored treatment strategies for acute COVID-19 and other nonlinear pathophysiological states.

title: Towards a Smart University through the Development of an AI-Integrated Examination Management ecoSystem (SEMS)
authors: Mohd Khairul Azmi Hassan, Amir’Aatieff Amir Hussin, Nurazlin Zainal Azmi, Ahmad Anwar Zainuddin, Adlin Hafidz, Adam Othman
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Smart university transition makes way for incorporating sophisticated technologies into optimizing educational administration. In presenting the conceptualization and deployment of the Smart Examination Management System (SEMS), an AI-empowered, web-centric platform to automate and enrich the end-to-end examination management lifecycle of higher learning campuses, the research draws upon iterative and incremental software engineering philosophies. SEMS bundles together question construction, reviewing, and approval life cycles into a single, unified digital realm. The system leverages role-based security, template standardization, and entrenched data treatment protocols to enhance the quality, consistency, and security of examination materials. A comparison of SEMS against currently prevalent platforms such as Moodle, Canvas LMS, and Questionmark illustrates the former’s superiority in collaboration features, workflow insight, and intelligent guidance. The incorporation of AI features ensures automated comments, clarity of contents, and originality verification, thus enriching academic rigor. The platform promotes green practice through eliminating dependency on papers and administrative duplication. Through structural modeling (UML, ER, and sequence diagrams), proto- type creation, and usability testing, SEMS illustrates its capability to revolutionize institutional assessment regimes and lend itself to the larger mission of intelligent academic administration.

title: Dynamic MPPT Strategy for PV Systems via NARX Neural Network Prediction and Robust Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Control
authors: Omar Zeb, Didar Murad, Atif Rehman, Iftikhar Ahmad, Muhammad Tariq Saeed
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Digital Futures and Transformative Technologies (ICoDT2)
abstract: Continuing to expand the importance of solar energy within the scope of global renewable energy, there is a surge of interest in the global marketplace to capitalise on the development of clean energy and the need to mitigate reliance on fossil fuels. Considering the unpredictability of environmental and load factors and the resultant impact on photovoltaic system effectiveness, estimating the efficiency of output power is a challenging task. This complexity necessitates both urgency and accuracy in the execution of the tactics required for the implementation of the algorithms for maximised power point tracking needed for optimal energy harvesting. Due to the nonlinear dynamics inherent in photovoltaic systems, more sophisticated control techniques that are nonlinear in nature and favors artificial intelligence are considered more preferable as opposed to traditional methods like Perturb and Observe (P&O). This work proposes a dynamic MPPT framework through the establishment of a Nonlinear Auto-Regressive (NARX) neural network, which utilises time series prediction capabilities of the neural network to extrapolate the behaviour of the PV system with respect to changing irradiance and temperature conditions. In order to enhance stability and resilience, a NARX-based predictor is integrated with a Robust Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Controller (RSTSMC), which in particular is designed to suppress nonlinearities and enhance robustness against environmental uncertainties. The suggested hybrid design is verified with HIL testing and then compared with standard MPP tracking strategies. The proposed model highlights that the NARX-RSTSMC approach is able to outperform others in the most important metrics in real-time PV optimisation during dynamic operating conditions in regards to accuracy, speed of convergence, and overall reliability.

title: Optimizing Power System Stabilizers: A State-Space Approach Enhanced by Genetic Algorithm
authors: Luis Portugal-Montaño, A. Zamora, Jose Ortiz-Bejar, Reynaldo Dominguez-Navarrete
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: In this paper, we present a practical approach for designing multiple Power System Stabilizers (PSSs) that combines state-space modeling with Genetic Algorithm (GA) optimization. Instead of relying only on heuristic search, our method first derives an ideal phase lead from the system’s state-space representation. This ideal phase acts as a guide for the GA, which adjusts the PSS parameters T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>, T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>, T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>, and T<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">w</inf> to closely match the desired behavior. of the generators, aiming to place the system poles at a point ensuring optimal damping. This approach seeks to enhance the stability and performance of the power system by achieving effective synchronization between the PSS and generators, thereby optimizing the dynamic response of the system. The obtained results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy in improving the dynamic response and stability of generators within an electric power system environment.

title: IF4FD: Multiscale Information Fusion for Zero-Shot Industrial Fault Diagnosis
authors: Chenwei Tang, Ying Wang, Weijia Wang, Wangyang Ying, Jie Liu, Yong Wang, Nanxu Gong, Wei Ju, Rong Xiao, Jiancheng Lv
abstract: Fault diagnosis aims to identify faults occurring in industrial production processes to prevent personnel injuries and economic losses. However, there are two main challenges in solving fault diagnosis, i.e., extracting discriminative features from limited sensor data and recognizing new classes of faults. To fill these research gaps, we propose a zero-shot fault diagnosis framework, called IF4FD, based on multiscale information fusion. First, we enhanced raw data from the perspectives of category knowledge, attribute knowledge, and feature knowledge. Then, by drawing on zero-shot learning (ZSL), we can transfer knowledge of trained faults to new classes of faults, enabling the classification of previously unknown faults. The multiscale informative knowledge effectively facilitates knowledge transfer and fault classification, thereby enhancing the accuracy of zero-shot fault diagnosis. Extensive experiments on two industrial fault diagnosis datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, which consistently achieves superior performance compared to representative zero-shot fault diagnosis methods, general ZSL baselines, and several supervised classifiers. A case study on real industrial data from the Cranfield Multiphase Flow Facility also confirms the method’s effectiveness in practical applications.

title: 3GPP PDU Set Framework: Release 19 Updates
authors: Serhan Gül, Igor D.D. Curcio
abstract: Extended Reality (XR) applications demand substantial bandwidth, ultra-low latency and high refresh rates, challenging network performance. While 3GPP Release 18 introduced the Protocol Data Unit (PDU) Set based Quality of Service (QoS) framework to enable application-aware packet handling for XR traffic, Release 19 advances this by addressing dynamic traffic characteristics with enhanced burst signaling, expedited transfer mechanisms for latency-critical content, and refined guidelines for PDU Set Importance (PSI). These updates improve power management, scheduling, and resource allocation, strengthening the foundation for intelligent network handling and seamless immersive XR experiences using 3GPP networks.

title: Design and Simulation of SSSR and CSRR Loaded Array Antenna for 6G Applications
authors: Smrity Dwivedi
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: This article presents and reviews the design and simulation of advanced 5 G and 6 G antennas. 5 G and other new ways will help to connect most of the existing devices and create a balance between systems and users based on technology, needs and requirements. It should be broadband and reliable. So for beyond 5 G and 6 G, 1 to 10 THz frequencies are analyzed, so the potential of both can be obtained from here. Polyamide is used as a low-frequency, high-performance material, PEC is used as the material for antenna ground construction and Graphene is used to construct sssr and csrr structure for radiating plane for good results. Model simulations were performed using CST Microwave Studio. At 3.5 THz, the S 11 parameter is -36.4 dB. Gain of the antenna is 11.2 dBi. Many research articles talk about technology upgrades beyond 5 G and 6 G. The pros and cons of the design are also discussed. The bandwidth is 2 THz. As with many of the models discussed in sections 1 and 2, the innovation of this paper is simplicity of design, ease of fabrication, reduced loss due to lack of clearance, and availability of operating and basic equipment.

title: Edge-Enabled High-Resolution State Estimation for Distribution Networks Based on Micro-PMU Data
authors: Zhiqi Xu, Wei Jiang, Junbo Zhao
abstract: The increasing penetration of renewable energy into distribution networks necessitates high-resolution, real-time monitoring of system states. However, the low sampling frequency of conventional smart meters and the heavy computational workload of centralized estimation frameworks hinder the deployment of high-frequency state estimation. This paper proposes an edge-enabled framework that leverages micro-phasor measurement unit (micro-PMU) data to achieve high-resolution state estimation in distribution networks. The framework adopts a zonal architecture in which each edge node locally processes micro-PMU and smart meter data, reducing the computational workload of the control center and ensuring real-time performance. In each zone, an edge node detects and localizes abrupt changes in power consumption and performs iterative estimation with optimal initialization when an abrupt change is detected, whereas it executes a non-iterative linearized tracking method during steady periods to minimize computational workload. Validation on large-scale unbalanced three-phase distribution systems demonstrates that the proposed framework achieves high estimation accuracy and significantly reduces computation time compared with conventional decentralized state estimation methods.

title: Advancing Engineering Education in the Age of AI Through Innovative Methods
authors: Yasin Mamatjan, Ehesan Maimaitijiang, Maihemuti Dilimulati
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Integrating artificial intelligence (AI) into engineering education presents both opportunities and challenges as educators seek to apply cutting-edge AI-driven tools and online platforms to enhance learning outcomes. The field is beginning to explore how AI-driven personalized tutoring, on-demand adaptive learning, and innovative assessment strategies can reshape traditional pedagogical models, though broad adaptation and seamless integration remain ongoing challenges. However, this integration brings challenges such as ensuring academic integrity, preventing over-reliance on AI for solution generation, and balancing personalized assistance with deep, hands-on learning experiences. This paper presents a framework for incorporating AI, online platforms, project-based methods, and new assessment strategies to improve engineering education. It addresses academic integrity challenges, promotes deeper engagement through real-world competitions, and aligns projects with industry objectives via guest lectures and research-driven collaborative work. Creative case studies on real-world Health Monitoring and collaborative Smart Assistant projects equip students with practical skillsets that illustrate the effectiveness of this framework, while a SWOT analysis (Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities and Threats) supports student research to be more practical and creative. Finally, the successful student competitions such as ‘Pandora’s Box’, won the first prize at the Acres Design Competition, demonstrate how these pedagogical methods can lead to award-winning and real-world relevant results that eventually equip them with practical problemsolving skills.

title: A realistic stochastic model considering the multipath effects based on C/N0 for GNSS positioning in harsh environments
authors: Zhen Li, Jun Tao, Jing Guo, Yihao Jiang, Qile Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The presence of unmodeled errors such as multipath and non-line-of-sight (NLOS) significantly degrades the positioning performance of global navigation satellite systems (GNSS), especially in harsh environments. We propose a novel stochastic model that considers multipath effects based on carrier-to-noise-density ratio (C/N0). This model utilizes C/N0 observations and their nominal function to construct a five-segment variance shrinking factor to enable a more accurate characterization of observation precision and yields reliable posterior residuals. Subsequently, the Institute of Geodesy and Geophysics 3 (IGG3) scheme based on posterior residuals is applied for quality control to enhance the performance of the results. Three sets of real-time kinematic (RTK) positioning experiments were conducted in harsh environments such as urban canyons and shaded areas to validate the effectiveness of the proposed method. For single-epoch static RTK positioning, the proposed method improves the horizontal accuracy of the Trimble Alloy from decimeter to centimeter level and the u-blox F9P from approximately 1.5 m to 1.0 m, with improvements of 2-13% in the ambiguity success rate compared to traditional equal-weight, C/N0, and elevation models. In kinematic positioning, the proposed method significantly improves positioning accuracy by more than 20% and increases the ambiguity success rate. The Trimble Alloy achieves decimeter-level horizontal positioning accuracy in deep urban canyons, while the u-blox F9P achieves an accuracy of around 1 m.

title: Backflash Mitigation via Scheduling in FSO Systems With Quantum Key Distribution
authors: Maria Dimitropoulou, Constantinos Psomas, Ioannis Krikidis
abstract: Quantum key distribution (QKD) is a potential technology suitable for fulfiling the stringent requirements of upcoming 6G wireless networks in terms of privacy and security. Nevertheless, QKD systems have several practical limitations in terms of hardware design and implementation, making them vulnerable to malicious attacks. Specifically, we adopt a detection scheme using a single-photon avalanche diode and due to the avalanche effect, a secondary photon is emitted, called backflash, which can be captured by an eavesdropper. To mitigate this security loophole and enhance the secrecy performance, we consider a selection mechanism which schedules a single user for secret key exchange purposes. In particular, we propose an intelligent two-stage selection scheme in a multiuser free-space optical QKD deployment. We derive closed-form expressions for the secrecy success probability by considering a generalized pointing error model. Our results confirm that the proposed scheme yields significant secrecy gains over conventional methods.

title: ISSCC: Integrated Service for Full-process Delivery in Secure Cloud Computing
authors: Ping Wang, Fei Tang, Jiang Yu, Huihui Zhu, Shiyue Kang, Chao Zhang
abstract: Secure cloud computing offers a range of services including storage, search, and computation, all of which have experienced ongoing performance advancements. However, seamlessly integrating these services into a unified “storage–search–computation” workflow remains challenging due to heterogeneous security mechanisms. For instance, searchable encryption, while effective for secure search, does not natively support computation over ciphertext. To address this gap, we propose ISSCC, an integrated service framework that seamlessly bridges storage, search, and computation in secure cloud environments. ISSCC employs searchable encryption to ensure secure data storage and search. To support post-search computation on retrieved results, ISSCC utilizes trusted execution environments instead of purely cryptographic approaches. We implement ISSCC on a real TEE-enabled cloud platform and conduct a comprehensive performance evaluation and security analysis. Experimental results demonstrate that ISSCC is both feasible and practical, delivering effective end-to-end services across the full “storage–search–computation” pipeline in secure cloud computing.

title: Impact of Receiver Coil Displacement and Orientation on the Efficiency of Resonant WPT Systems
authors: Maurício D Almeida, Ursula Resende, Silvia C Albuquerque
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work presents a comprehensive simulation-based analysis of a wireless power transfer system employing resonant magnetic coupling between coils. A circuit-based model was developed to evaluate the behavior of the system, incorporating lumped parameters to represent the transmitting and receiving coils. This model was validated through comparison with simulations performed using Advanced Design System (ADS) software, showing strong agreement in input resistance, scattering parameters, and load current. Once validated, the circuit model was used for all subsequent analyses. The study investigates how the spatial positioning of the receiver coil—specifically alignment, lateral misalignment, and angular tilt—affects key performance metrics such as input resistance, scattering parameters (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}_{11}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{S}_{21}$</tex>), load current, mutual inductance, and overall system efficiency. Parametric sweeps were conducted for distance (0–100 mm), lateral offset (0–100 mm), and tilt angle <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(0^{\circ}-180^{\circ})$</tex>, with simulation results revealing the sensitivity of energy transfer to coil positioning. Notably, lateral misalignment caused significant impedance mismatch and efficiency reduction, while angular tilt led to symmetric efficiency behavior around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$90^{\circ}$</tex>, where mutual inductance approached zero. The results identify operational windows outside ideal alignment and emphasize the substantial impact of mutual inductance variations due to spatial factors.

title: Study and Evaluation of Hybrid System for the Isolated Jannah Island in Saudi Arabia
authors: Abdallah Bilal Dhaydil, N.V.N. Jagadish
abstract: Hybrid energy systems that integrate solar panels, batteries, and diesel generators offer a practical and efficient method for supplying electricity to remote locations. Numerous isolated areas in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia are disconnected from the central electricity grid and rely on mobile diesel generators for power delivery. This study addresses the critical challenge of providing a reliable, cost-effective, and sustainable energy supply by investigating the development of a hybrid system for Jannah Island, located in the Eastern Province of the Kingdom. The island's current power infrastructure, which relies solely on diesel generators, has proven to be an economically and environmentally unsustainable model. The Saudi Electricity Company (SEC) incurs an annual loss of approximately SAR 150,000, which is the difference between the annual cost of SAR 186,889 and the revenue of SAR 36,000 from customer bills. This deficit is projected to accumulate to SAR 3.75 million over a 25-year period if the existing system remains in use. To address this challenge, a techno-economic optimization model was developed using HOMER Pro simulation software to determine the optimal capacity and operational strategy for a hybrid system. The proposed architecture consists of a 200-kW peak solar PV array, a 1 MWh battery storage system, and the existing diesel generators as a backup. This approach is designed to enhance power reliability and economic viability by reducing dependence on a single fossil fuel source. The simulation results provide a comprehensive validation of the hybrid system's performance. The financial analysis projects a substantial reduction in operational expenses, with fuel consumption and transportation costs decreasing by 65% compared to the diesel-only system. The Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE) for the hybrid system is estimated at $0.15/kWh, a dramatic improvement over the $0.32/kWh of the conventional diesel solution. Furthermore, the system enhances energy supply reliability by 98% and contributes to a 75% reduction in carbon emissions, directly aligning with Saudi Arabia's environmental sustainability goals. The anticipated financial savings over 25 years are SAR 1.55 million based on 2024 fuel prices, and this figure could increase to over SAR 6.18 million if fuel prices rise by 500%. These findings demonstrate that the hybrid system is a practical and effective strategy for meeting the energy needs of isolated communities. Especially since diesel fuel prices have increased by 44% since the beginning of 2025.

title: Design and Evaluation of a Multi-View Multispectral Photometric Stereo Instrument for Online Surface Defect Detection of Hot Continuous Casting Slabs
authors: Xiangyu Cao, Shun Wang, Hongjie Li, Dongdong Zhou, Ke Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: To address the technical challenges in online surface defects detection of hot continuous casting slab (HCCS), this paper presents the design, development, and validation of a novel vision-based instrumentation system based on Multi-View Multispectral Photometric Stereo (MVMSPS). The system integrates four cameras with specific spectral illuminators to intrinsically eliminate spectral crosstalk at inspection speeds up to 0.5 m/s. The core innovations are twofold: 1) A Generalized Homography Transformation (GHT) method is proposed for precise multi-view image matching, reducing geometric alignment errors by over 87.8% compared to conventional methods. 2) The optimal illumination zenith angle under the Lambertian model is theoretically deduced to guide the lighting design and maximize the signal-to-noise ratio. Enabled by these innovations, the MVMSPS algorithm effectively fuses multi-view and multispectral data to effectively estimate the surface normal and capture the high-frequency information of surface depth variations. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed MVMSPS system can accurately, reliably, and efficiently detect surface defects (e.g., scars, cracks, and indentations) on HCCS in high-temperature and dynamic environments, with a complete processing time of under 3.6s per image set, satisfying the real-time requirements for online inspection and offering a promising instrument solution for intelligent production and quality control in the steel industry. Additionally, this paper explores potential future research directions, including combining fast two-dimensional detection with three-dimensional photometric stereo and integrating multimodal information, to further enhance detection performance.

title: Explainable Transfer Learning for Rare Genetic Disorders: Leveraging Limited Data in Resource-Constrained Healthcare
authors: G.Uma Devi, Balajee Maram
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: The absence of them, heterogeneity, and low level of medical care also cause numerous complications in the clinical diagnosis of rare genetic diseases. This is because such models have a history of failure in such cases because it consumes a lot of annotated data to operate. The paper presents a describeable transfer learning system adapted in rare genetic illnesses and led to a sound generalization in the underrepresented groups as a result of label-sharing with gigantic-populated genomic examinations. The plan incorporates model interpretability methods to improve clinical assurances in instances of medical conditions with resource constraints whereby there is deficiency of computational resources and expertise. Using experimental data it was shown that using pre-trained genomic embeddings, classification errors are made to be smaller by 21.4 without damaging the interpretability of resultant feature attributions on SHAP feature attribution. The system also had the potential to increase the efficiency of the diagnostic system by 32 percent in a simulated environment with low resources, which meant that the system could be successfully transported to rural and underserved clinical environments. This publication presents an open pipeline at scales that allows the strategies to the precision medicine of the rare diseases with a trade-off between the performance and ethical responsibility. Such findings confirm the need to integrate the data-efficient AI techniques and explainability to assist clinicians in high-stakes low-data setting.

title: Adaptive Obfuscation for Reusing RGB Datasets for Privacy-Preserving Human Pose Estimation
authors: Francesco Pistolesi, Matteo Mugnai, Beatrice Lazzerini
abstract: For decades, RGB data has been central in human-pose estimation (HPE). The growing legislative pressure now limits their use during deployment, as RGB frames reveal sensitive personal information (SPI). Recent work often designs and trains new anonymization models, at a high computational cost. We ask instead whether adaptive filtering is sufficient. We introduce an adaptive obfuscation pipeline that converts RGB datasets into privacy-aware counterparts without training new networks. For each image, we detect the largest face, estimate a re-identification risk from its relative area, and raise blur or pixelation until an InsightFace recognizer fails to match the original embedding; that intensity is then applied to the whole image. Applied to MS-COCO, the pipeline generates two new sets, COCO-BLUR and COCO-PIX. On COCO-BLUR, three off-the-shelf HPE models retain more than 87% of their baseline AP. We release our code at this link (GitHub repository) offering a sustainable way to anonymize RGB data.

title: Subscriber-Level Churn Prediction from CDR/OCS Data: A Comprehensive Machine Learning Approach with Feature Engineering Analysis for Telecommunications Marketing
authors: Trung-Tru Huynh, Toan Phuc Nguyen, Hung Ho-Dac
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Customer churn prediction is a critical challenge in telecommunications, directly impacting revenue and customer lifetime value. This paper presents a comprehensive machine learning approach for predicting subscriber churn using Call Detail Records (CDR) and Online Charging System (OCS) data. We develop and evaluate multiple prediction models including Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting classifiers on real telecommunications data with synthetic churn labels. Our methodology focuses on marketing-oriented metrics including Precision@k (5%, 10%, 20 %) and PR-AUC to support targeted retention campaigns. Novel contributions include comparing full versus minimal feature engineering approaches, evaluating computational efficiency against predictive performance. Results show ensemble methods achieve superior performance, with Gradient Boosting reaching PR-AUC of 0.205 and precision@10% of 0.217. Minimal features on full datasets achieve comparable performance (PR-AUC of 0.199) to complex features on sampled data, offering practical guidance for telecommunications operators implementing churn prediction under computational constraints.

title: A Phase Adaptive Approach to Self-Data-Driven Online Remaining Useful Life Prediction
authors: Runzhong Fang, Bin Yang, Yaguo Lei, Yang Gao, Xiang Li, Naipeng Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Self-data-driven methods for Remaining Useful Life (RUL) prediction are promising where failure data is scarce. However, conventional batch-update approaches are computationally inefficient for online scenarios and their fixed models fail to capture multi-stage degradation. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a novel two-stage framework. The first, offline stage uses a Phase Adaptive Expectation Maximization (PAEM) algorithm, which identifies degradation phases to achieve robust parameter initialization for a library of candidate models. The second, online stage employs an Entropy-Driven Particle Filter (EDPF) to adaptively fuse these models in real-time, tracking time-varying dynamics without reusing historical data. Validation on the XJTU-SY bearing dataset demonstrates that the framework significantly improves prediction accuracy and stability over traditional methods, providing a computationally efficient and robust solution for online RUL prediction.

title: TFD-Video: Threshold-Aware Federated Deepfake Detection for Video Forensics
authors: Maryam Al-Fehani, Abdullatif Al-Baseer, Saif Al-Kuwari
abstract: Deepfakes and other AI-based manipulated and synthesized videos pose a rising threat, yet training robust detectors under federated settings is challenging, where data is siloed and communication is limited. Existing compression strategies for Federated Learning (FL) can reduce detection accuracy for forensics, and standard federated averaging (FedAvg) may weaken client-specific adaptations that are important in practice. To this end, we propose Threshold-Aware Federated Deepfake Detection (TFD), a framework that combines communication-efficient structured sparsification with client-side optimization. Each client augments a shared video backbone with learnable per-filter thresholds that gate computations and induce structured sparsity. During training, clients update local weights and thresholds but transmit only compact threshold vectors. The server aggregates these vectors to establish a common sparsity pattern, while dense model parameters and data remain local. This efficient threshold-sharing scheme dramatically reduces communication overhead by several orders of magnitude while enabling each client to maintain a model tailored to its local data. We evaluate TFD on deepfake video benchmarks (FaceForensics++ and Celeb-DF), reporting detection metrics (accuracy, AUROC/AUPRC) and efficiency indicators (per-round payload size and costs). The results indicate that TFD can significantly reduce costs and latency while maintaining competitive detection performance relative to state-of-the-art approaches.

title: A Streaming Big Data Pipeline for Real-Time Vehicle Re-Identification in Chaotic Urban Traffic
authors: Vinh-Ha X. Pham, Trong-Hop Do
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: We present a deployment-ready, real-time vehicle re-identification (Re-ID) pipeline designed for motorcycle-dominated, non-lane urban traffic. The system integrates Apache Kafka and Spark Structured Streaming with modern detection, tracking, and embedding models, enabling city-scale streaming operation with temporalgated FAISS retrieval and persistent metadata for analysis. To support evaluation under realistic conditions, we release a new multi-camera dataset from Ho Chi Minh City that captures dense occlusions and irregular flows often missing in existing benchmarks. Our work contributes (i) a scalable big-data Re-ID pipeline, (ii) a motorcycle-centric dataset with reproducible evaluation, and (iii) a foundation for practical intelligent transportation and urban security applications in developing cities. The source code and dataset are publicly available at: https://github.com/HaPXV/A-Streaming-Big-Data-pipeline-for-Real-Time-Vehicle-Re-Identification-in-Chaotic-Urban-Traffic.

title: A Robot-Led Intervention for Emotion Regulation: from Expression to Reappraisal_supp2-3657604.pdf
authors: Guy Laban
abstract: Emotion regulation (ER) is a crucial skill for managing emotions in everyday life, yet finding a constructive and accessible method to practice ER remains challenging due to cognitive demands. In this study, we explore how regular interactions with a social robot, conducted in a structured yet familiar environment within university halls and departments, can provide effective support for practising ER via cognitive reappraisal. Twenty-one students participated in a five-session study at a university hall or department in the U.K., where the robot (QTrobot, LuxAI), powered by a large language model (GPT 3.5) facilitated structured conversations, encouraging the students to reinterpret emotionally charged situations that they shared with the robot. Quantitative and qualitative results indicate significant improvements in ER, with participants reporting better understanding and control of their emotions, significant changes in constructive ER tendencies and positive effects on mood and sentiment after each session. The findings also demonstrate that repeated interactions with the robot encouraged greater emotional expression, including longer speech disclosures, increased use of affective language, and heightened facial arousal. Notably, expression peaked during key reappraisal moments, particularly when participants were prompted to reinterpret negative experiences. The qualitative feedback further highlighted how the robot fostered introspection and provided a supportive space for discussing emotions, enabling participants to confront long-avoided emotional challenges. These findings demonstrate the potential of robots to effectively assist in ER in familiar environments, offering both emotional support and cognitive guidance

title: BioDeepHash: Generating Consistent Templates for Secure Biometric Recognition
authors: Baogang Song, Dongdong Zhao, Jiang Yan, Huanhuan Li, Hao Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Given the immutability of biometric data, it is imperative to develop a biometric template protection method that guarantees the complete non-disclosure of any original biometric information while ensuring high recognition performance. Two mainstream approaches in biometric template protection—cancelable biometrics and biometric cryptosystems—have been widely adopted; however, the protected templates produced by these methods still contain some of the original biometric data, which can lead to privacy leakage. To address these challenges, we propose a novel framework named BioDeepHash that integrates deep hashing with cryptographic hash functions. In our approach, a deep hashing model generates consistent templates for similar biometric data from the same user, thereby eliminating intra-class variations. An application-specific XOR string is then used to achieve revocability, and finally these consistent templates are processed by cryptographic hash functions to produce protected templates that meet strict security standards. Our experimental results show that, compared with existing methods, BioDeepHash increases the average Genuine Acceptance Rate by 10.12% on the iris dataset and by 3.12% on the facial dataset, while achieving an extremely low False Acceptance Rate—0% for the iris dataset and only 0.0002% for the facial dataset.

title: A Battery-Powered Current-Driven JK Hybrid Boost Converter with Reconfigurable 28–110 V Output and Reduced Voltage–Ampere Metrics for Portable Electrical Stimulators
authors: Yi-Ching Chiu, Tai-Hung Wu, Rui-Jun Ng, Shu-Heng Jiang, Ke-Horng Chen, Xi Zhu, Ying-Hsi Lin, Shian-Ru Lin, Tsung-Yen Tsai
abstract: This paper presents a current-driven JK reconfigurable hybrid boost converter that achieves a wide voltage conversion ratio (VCR) range of 7×–30× and delivers 11W output power at 110V / 100mA, targeting electrical stimulator applications. Compared to a conventional boost converter (CBC), the proposed design utilizes series-parallel flying-capacitor (SPFC) stages and a negative-coupled inductor to reduce the inductor current ripple by over 60% and 15% for VCRs ranges of 7×–20× and 20×–30×, respectively. Furthermore, the JK-Controller and current-driven technique dynamically adjust the converter operation based on the stimulus strength setting, leading to a significant reduction in the voltage·ampere (V·A) metric and achieving a stimulation efficiency of 87.3%.

title: Distributed Diffusion Policy for Cooperative Resource Orchestration in IIoT Edge Networks
authors: Jiayi Meng, Lanlan Rui, Zixuan Chen, Yang Yang, Shaoyong Guo, Xuesong Qiu
abstract: With the rapid proliferation of Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) devices, massive Delay Sensitive and Computation Intensive (DSCI) tasks are generated. Traditional Mobile Edge Computing (MEC) systems face limitations like inter-cell interference at cell edges, degrading Quality of Service (QoS). To address this, Cooperative Access Edge Networks (CAEN) enable dynamic Access Point (AP) clusters for enhanced transmission reliability in IIoT. However, challenges arise from multi-user interference, bandwidth contention, dynamic environments, and heterogeneous resources, complicating joint resource orchestration. This paper proposes EdgeDiffuse, a diffusion-enhanced distributed resource orchestration algorithm, which optimizes task offloading selection, transmission power control, and computational resource allocation to minimize long term task completion time while promoting system load balancing. EdgeDiffuse enables adaptive and hierarchical coordination between user agents and edge servers. It integrates diffusion models under a Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning (MADRL) framework for improved policy exploration in high dimensional offloading decision spaces, and further uses convex optimization for server side resource allocation. Experimental results demonstrate that EdgeDiffuse achieves 28.17% reduction in task completion time, 7.40% improvement in task transmission rates, and 15.71% enhancement in load balancing compared to advanced baselines, showcasing superior performance in multi-user and resource constrained scenarios.

title: Multi-Satellite Cooperative Communications for 6G: Fundamentals, System Design, and Applications
authors: Bodong Shang, Xinyi Huang, Huayuan Wang, Xiangyu Li, Meixia Tao, Haijun Zhang, Pingzhi Fan
abstract: Recent advances in satellite technologies and non-terrestrial networks have made multi-satellite cooperative communications a promising approach for enhancing quality of service in satellite networks. To meet the ever-increasing demands for global coverage, ultra-reliable connectivity, and low-latency services, cooperation among multiple satellites is a key enabler for overcoming the limitations of single-satellite service systems. With its growing importance, both applications and opportunities are simultaneously manifesting. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of research on multi-satellite cooperative communications. In particular, we first introduce architectures for multi-satellite cooperative networks, including intralayer, inter-layer, and cross-layer architectures. Subsequently, we comprehensively analyze and discuss their operating modes, including cooperative relaying, coordinated joint transmission, cooperative reception, beamforming, and cooperative interference management. Additionally, optical inter-satellite links are being considered for cooperative communications to enhance satellite interoperability. We then introduce the challenges and corresponding solutions for implementing multi-satellite cooperative communications. Furthermore, we explore enabling technologies for multi-satellite networks, including multi-connectivity, cooperative satellite beam-hopping, multi-satellite beamforming, traffic offloading, and management of satellite topology and constellation graphs. To further enhance the evaluation of the multi-satellite network, we discuss performance metrics, analysis tools, optimization methods, and validation. Finally, we outline several compelling research directions for future multi-satellite cooperative communication networks.

title: Development of a Ground-Based Atmospheric Detector Based on Hyperspectral Technology
authors: Chunying Zhang, Xiaohu Yang, Xiaoxi Li, Zhanfeng Li, Yue Li, Yu Huang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Atmospheric hyperspectral detection technology plays a critical role in environmental monitoring, weather forecasting, and climate change research, and has attracted widespread attention globally in recent years. To address the limitations of existing atmospheric sounding instruments-such as limited resolution, narrow spectral range, and moderate stability-this study aims to achieve high-precision acquisition of atmospheric spectral data. Utilizing the mechatronic coupling method to achieve sky detection through a single channel, excluding direct solar irradiation. The results demonstrate that the independently developed hyperspectral detector achieves a spectral resolution of up to 0.5 nm, allowing precise detection of atmospheric constituents within the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 6 0 - 1 0 0 0} \mathbf{ n m}$</tex> wavelength range. This provides fundamental data support for studying near-space atmospheric dynamics and constructing accurate atmospheric models. Furthermore, performance tests demonstrated excellent agreement between MODTRAN simulations and actual atmospheric measurements, with the visual comparison confirming a close match that meets all design requirements.

title: Entity Linking in Real-World News Streams: An End-to-End Deep Learning Approach for Disambiguating Named Entities Across Heterogeneous Sources
authors: Vivek Ghatala, Monil Shah, Vishal Diyora
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: The process of disambiguating named entities in the varied and unstructured news text is a major challenge in natural language understanding. EL is a daunting task due to the constantly changing content, the mixed-language source of real-world news streams, and the contextual ambiguity of realworld news streams. This paper proposes a novel end-to-end DL framework, SA-ESF (Symmetrical Attention-based Entity Linking using Structural Features), designed specifically to address these complexities. The model exploits symmetrical BiLSTM networks with two attention mechanisms to learn bidirectional semantic relevance between mentions and candidate entities. In addition, it has dense structural features (such as entity descriptions and contextual embeddings) and uses prior link probabilities estimated on Wikipedia to improve disambiguation accuracy. SA-ESF is trained with contrastive learning and positive and hard negative samples, which makes it robust to cross-source and cross-language evaluation. For benchmark datasets, experiments demonstrate that SA-ESF outperforms the state-of-the-art models with the average F1score of 89.7, accuracy of 91.2%, and precision of 90.3%. The results indicate the superior performance, strength and scale of the model in resolving complicated entity disambiguation problems in dynamic, multilingual and heterogeneous news settings.

title: Effect of Contact Force on Reflective Photoplethysmography and Peripheral Oxygen Saturation Prediction *
authors: Zifei He, Jiaxin Ma, Yiqing Yao, Zhipeng Cai, Lulu Zhao, Yongxin Chou, Qun Wei, Jianqing Li, Chengyu Liu, Chenxi Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Reflective photoplethysmography (PPG) signals are widely applied on many wearable devices to detect physiological signs, such as heart rate, blood pressure and peripheral oxygen saturation (SpO2). Current research shows that the contact force between sensors and skin can effectively influence PPG signals. This work mainly focuses on identifying the major aspects affected by contact forces. Based on an opensource database, WF-PPG, the signal qualities under different contact force were compared to evaluate the influence on highfrequency noise, baseline wandering, and motion artifacts. Additionally, the datasets were used to train a linear regression model and a support vector regression (SVR) model for SpO2 prediction. The results of signal quality analysis show that as contact force increases the reflective PPG will have increased high-frequency noise and be more affected by motion artifacts. Moreover, the parameters of trained linear model indicate that the optimal gain and offset will change with variations in contact force. When contact force is include, the SVR model outperforms the model without contact force. In conclusion, the contact force can affect the waveform of reflective PPG and further influence the measurement of SpO2. Thus, detecting contact force simultaneously can actually improve the accuracy of SpO2 measurement.

title: Hybrid Machine Learning-Based Optimization of SVC Firing Angles: A CatBoost-LightGBM Approach for Enhanced Grid Stability
authors: Mahmoud Mohammadnezhad Kiasari, Hamed H. Aly
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Flexible AC Transmission Systems (FACTS) have become indispensable tools for enhancing power grid reliability, stability, and efficiency in the modern power grid. Static Var Compensators (SVCs), one of the most useful classes of FACTS devices, play a critical role in compensating reactive power that can adjust voltage levels dynamically. However, this performance is highly related to the SVC’s firing angle unit, which determines the amount of reactive power injection/absorption. Any suboptimal firing angle can lead to grid instability, like voltage collapse and excessive current fluctuations. This paper presents a Simulink model with a hybrid Machine Learning approach combining CatBoost and LightGBM with lagged features to improve firing angle prediction across various scenarios. Despite the usage of single methods, this hybrid one benefits from the strength of previous models that, in the end, demonstrates better performance, faster coverage, and enhanced real-time adaptability among traditional models.

title: Adaptive Electric Vehicle EMS with Secure V2G Energy Transactions using Blockchain
authors: C Shri Varshini, Nidhi Gummaraju, K Shanti Swarup
abstract: An energy management system(EMS) is essential in Electrical Vehicle(EV) as they completely rely on stored electrical energy. This ensures efficient drivetrain operation and helps in optimization of power consumption, extending battery life. The EMS adapts dynamically to the Eco, Normal and Sport driving modes, presents real-time decision making to control torque and regenerative braking. This EMS can also perform energy transactions between vehicle and grid in V2G deployments, thus improving the total efficiency of electric transportation and bridges the gap between simulation and deployable control strategies. The system includes fuzzy logic controller and energy trading. EV modeled using MATLAB Simulink Software, also has the ability to detect the driving mode. The Fuzzy Logic Controllers analyze the situational parameters of the vehicle to provide baseline torque limits, to reduce energy loss, and improve performance. Blockchain-based energy trade logic is integrated with the MATLAB using a custom code providing security-aware EMS that helps in real-time tracking of V2G and G2V transactions which are safe and counterfeit-proof. FTP-75 driving cycle is used to test this intelligent adaptive electric vehicle, which exhibits smoother control responses and better SOC retention.

title: 10 kW High-Power Undersea Wireless Power Transfer System for Autonomous Underwater Vehicles
authors: Lei Yang, Jiahua Sun, Zhixue Bu, Xuena Chen, Xin Dai, Shihao Guo, Ruiqi Guo, Chenyu Liu, Haibing Wen, Yaopeng Zhao, Yunjie Sun, Aimin Zhang, Xiangqian Tong
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: Targeting the high-power charging requirements of medium-to-large Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs), this paper proposes a 10 kW undersea wireless power transfer (UWPT) system design methodology. By adopting an LCC-S compensation topology and circular magnetic coupling mechanism, the synergistic optimization of electromagnetic stability and power transfer efficiency in seawater environments is achieved. The system significantly suppresses high-frequency losses through high-frequency inversion technology and film-insulated Litz wire construction. Parametric simulation optimization determines the optimal matching relationship for coil parameters. A coupling mechanism achieving a coupling coefficient of 0.61 at a 60 mm transmission distance is developed. Experimental results demonstrate that the system achieves stable 10 kW power output in air medium with a peak efficiency of 96.4%. In saline environments, the efficiency reaches 93.9%. During load transients, the output voltage fluctuation remains below 2.3%, validating constant-voltage output characteristics and load fluctuation adaptability. This research provides theoretical and technical foundations for the engineering application of high-power undersea wireless power transfer systems.

title: 10000-Cycle/10-μs Short Circuit Operation in 650-V E-Mode p-GaN Gate HEMT With Schottky Source Extension
authors: Yunhong Lao, Jingjing Yu, Qian Zheng, Junjie Yang, Youyi Yin, Teng Li, Qimeng Jiang, Gaofei Tang, Maojun Wang, Jin Wei
