title: BTC-Net V2: Spatial-Priority Hierarchical Reconstruction for Hyperspectral Image Compression
authors: Xichuan Zhou, Mingyang Wan, Hang Yu, Tao Chen, Rulong He, Xiangfei Shen, Lihui Chen, Haijun Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: In recent years, lossy compression of hyperspectral images (HSIs) for spaceborne applications has garnered significant attention. The limited storage capacity and constrained transmission bandwidth of spaceborne equipment make it challenging to simultaneously balance the compression rate of transmitted data and the quality of locally reconstructed images. To address this challenge, we propose BTC-Net V2—an advanced iteration of BTC-Net—that substantially enhances the performance of its predecessor. Specifically, in the encoder stage, we adopt a large-kernel convolution to replace the three-layer convolutional network used in the previous version, enabling a more lightweight encoder design that aligns with the resource constraints of spaceborne HSI compression. Moreover, in the decoder stage, we replace the “feature enhancement followed by upsampling” paradigm of the previous version with a spatial-priority hierarchical architecture that prioritizes spatial dimension upsampling. This design ensures the subsequent feature enhancement backbone operates on a larger spatial scale—directly mitigating the loss of spatial correlations in BTC-Net and ultimately yielding higher reconstruction quality. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that our proposed BTC-Net V2 outperforms BTC-Net by 3.35 dB in PSNR—achieving 40.78 dB versus BTC-Net’s 37.43 dB—while operating at an even lower bit rate (0.054 bpppb compared to BTC-Net’s 0.060 bpppb). Our code is available at https://github.com/MWan-deeplearner/ BTC-Net-V2.

title: A Fault Diagnosis Method for Rolling Bearings Based on Adaptive Wavelet Transform and SE Attention-Enhanced MobileNetV3
authors: Bohui Zhang, Xinyu Yang, Siyu Shao, Tianlin Niu, Wenxiu Zheng, Yuxin Lu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Vibration signals of rolling bearings exhibit the characteristics of a mixture of transient impacts and nonstationarity. Although traditional continuous wavelet transform is able to provide time-frequency localization analysis, it has insufficient time-frequency focus on transient impacts, which easily leads to aliasing of non-stationary signal components and makes it difficult to accurately extract fault features. To address this issue, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis method that integrates adaptive wavelet transform and improved MobileNetV3. To resolve the problem of insufficient frequency coverage caused by the fixed scale of traditional CWT, an adaptive wavelet scale optimization strategy is adopted to dynamically calculate the optimal scale range of the Morlet wavelet, thereby achieving accurate coverage of the characteristic frequencies of bearings. Meanwhile, through harmonic enhancement and multimodal feature fusion, the fault features are improved. Aiming at the problems of high computational cost and significant time consumption in the training of traditional convolutional neural networks, an improved MobileNetV3 model is constructed: SE attention modules are embedded in specific layers to enhance the ability of fault feature extraction; stochastic depth technology is introduced to improve the model's generalization performance; and Bayesian search is combined to optimize hyperparameters. Experimental results based on the dataset show that this method is capable to effectively process complex vibration signals, and realize model lightweighting while ensuring diagnostic accuracy, providing a new solution for the effective and efficient diagnosis for rolling bearings in engineering application scenarios.

title: Mixed-Timescale Service Caching, Computing, and Communication Optimization for Low-Latency High-Reliability Edge-Cloud Networks_supp1-3587713.pdf
authors: Ming-Chun Lee
abstract: This paper studies the mixed-timescale joint optimization of service caching, computing, and communication for edge-cloud networks. By jointly considering the caching update, user association, task offloading, and computing and communication resource allocation in different timescales with queueing dynamics, we first formulate a long-term optimization problem whose goal is to minimize the network energy consumption while stabilizing the edge-cloud network. By exploiting the Lyapunov optimization techniques, we decompose the overall problem into large-, medium-, and small-timescale problems, and their individual solution approaches are provided. To further improve the latency and reliability, an end-to-end latency measure is proposed along with the use of extreme value theory to derive an enhancement approach. Performance analysis of our approaches is provided and computer simulations are conducted to evaluate the proposed approaches. Results show that our approaches have better latency performance as compared to reference schemes. Furthermore, results also show that our proposed enhancement approach can effectively improve the latency and reliability.

title: Adaptive Virtual Admittance Based Current Harmonic Suppression Strategy for Totem-pole Bridgeless PFC Converter
authors: Binxing Li, Yujia Zhu, Gaolin Wang, Jing Wang, Xuhui Duan, Yanfeng Gu, Dianguo Xu
abstract: In GaN totem-pole bridgeless power factor correction (PFC) converters, LC resonance from the electromagnetic interference (EMI) filter transforms grid voltage distortion into current harmonics, degrading power quality. A novel adaptive virtual admittance based current harmonic suppression method is proposed to improve the grid current quality across a wide load range. The input impedance model, accounting for the EMI filter and digital control delay, is established to reveal impedance variation patterns. The virtual admittance vector is decoupled in the polar coordinate system and optimized under different load conditions. Furthermore, a load-power-adaptive virtual admittance mechanism based on the piecewise cubic Hermite interpolation method is presented to suppress specific grid current harmonics. To ensure the robustness of the proposed method, the sensitivity of the virtual admittance and the influence of the system delay are analyzed. The experimental results show that the proposed method exhibits a better harmonic current suppression effect compared with conventional methods.

title: Continual Learning for Automotive Radar Semantic Segmentation
authors: Yipeng Chen, Ziwei Zhang, Jun Liu
abstract: The robustness of perception systems in adverse weather is critical for the safety of autonomous vehicles, with millimeter-wave radar being an indispensable sensor. However, current radar-based segmentation models are trained offline on static datasets and suffer from catastrophic forgetting when encountering unseen object classes in dynamic real-world environments. To address this limitation, we introduce a class-incremental continual learning framework specifically designed for automotive radar point cloud semantic segmentation. Our approach employs a model-agnostic student-teacher architecture, where a frozen model from a previous task provides supervisory signals to the current model via knowledge distillation. This is combined with a focal loss to handle the inherent class imbalance of radar data. Our framework is comprehensively evaluated on the RadarScenes dataset across several state-of-the-art segmentation architectures, including both point-based and transformer-based models, to demonstrate its general applicability. Our experiments demonstrate that the proposed strategy effectively mitigates catastrophic forgetting. This work establishes a benchmark for continual learning on radar point clouds, paving the way for more adaptive and long-term autonomous perception systems.

title: Multimodal Deep Learning for Cryptocurrency Trend Prediction via Candlestick Charts and Technical Indicators
authors: Tin Trung Truong, Van Hai Ho, Hai Ho
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: The growth of Bitcoin cryptocurrency with large fluctuations has aroused the interest of large investors, leading to the need for institutional investors to be at the forefront of short-term cryptocurrency trend prediction technology. To address the complexities caused by nonlinearity, this paper proposes a fusion model combining the MobileNetV2 model to capture candlestick chart morphology, OHLCV series with technical indicators modeled by GRU for short-term dependencies, and nonautoregressive encoder (NAR) to extract long-term context. Then, the features of each model are merged into the XGBoost model for classification (Bull/Bear/Neutral), which is mapped into trading signals while integrating the Uncertainty gating decision mechanism to increase reliability. Using the 15minute BTC/USDT dataset from Binance, divided into 70%/15%/15% ensembles, the merged model achieved an accuracy of 74.3 %, macro-F1 of 0.7429, and MCC of 0.4867, outperforming the single-method and baseline methods. The trust-aware gating results further improved the reliability, raising the accuracy and F1 to over 81% with a coverage of 67.74%, with a high threshold exceeding 98% accuracy for selective predictions. The above results demonstrate that the combination of multi-methods with the Uncertainty gating decision mechanism provides a reliable and practical forecasting tool for the volatile cryptocurrency market.

title: Deep Learning-Based Recognition of Selected Filipino Sign Language Phrases
authors: Robert G. de Luna, Kriztel Anne R. Girang, Jan Earl Laurenz D. Lucido, Leigh Francis E. Marasigan, Cindy Nicole D. Santos, Marie Louise C. Sebidos
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: As communication bridges gaps between individuals, sign language emerges as a crucial medium for the deaf community, fostering social inclusivity and accessibility. To address the need for effective sign language recognition, this study utilized a custom dataset of 40 selected Filipino Sign Language phrases collected from 25 signers and employed four neural network models: Long-Short Term Memory (LSTM), Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU), Artificial Neural Network (ANN), and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). The dataset underwent preprocessing phases, including the extraction of frame sequences and hand key points, which were then used to train and evaluate the models. Results indicated that the GRU model outperformed other architectures, achieving 99.98% accuracy in classifying FSL phrases. The study also developed a hardware prototype integrating the optimal model, demonstrating its potential for real-world applications. Overall, the findings suggest that deep learning techniques, particularly GRU-based models, can effectively capture the temporal dynamics of sign language, paving the way for more inclusive communication technologies.

title: TaK-Fuzz: Transaction-aware Knowledge Smart Contract Fuzzing with Retrieval-Augmented Generation and Language Models
authors: Nguyen Ho Nhat Khoa, Nguyen Thanh Kiet, Vo Truong Trung Hieu, Truong Thi Hoang Hao, Phan The Duy
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Ensuring smart contract security remains a major challenge in the blockchain ecosystem, and automated fuzzing is vital for detecting vulnerabilities. Traditional fuzzing methods often lack sufficient code coverage and resource efficiency, especially in complex contracts. In this work, we introduce TaK-Fuzz, a transaction-aware fuzzing framework that leverages RetrievalAugmented Generation and expert knowledge extracted from audit reports to guide intelligent creation of testcases. TaK-Fuzz has a vector database of vulnerability patterns from audited contracts and, for each fuzzing target, retrieves relevant entries based on semantic similarity. These insights are then used as context for a large language model, which applies Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning to generate focused and effective test cases for smart contract fuzzing. Experimental evaluation shows that TaK-Fuzz consistently outperforms the baseline MuFuzz across code coverage, vulnerability detection, and efficiency. For instance, on the Soli-Audit dataset, TaK-Fuzz achieves nearly complete branch coverage (99.43 %) while requiring only a fraction of the testcases compared to MuFuzz. Overall, it not only improves recall in detecting critical vulnerabilities but also reduces resource consumption by orders of magnitude. These results confirm that by combining knowledge retrieval with reasoning-driven test generation, TaK-Fuzz maximizes vulnerability discovery while maintaining high efficiency, establishing itself as a robust solution for smart contract fuzzing.

title: EtherFineChain: A Blockchain-Based Framework for Secure Traffic Violation Logging and Cryptocurrency Penalty Enforcement Using Ethereum Smart Contracts
authors: Jhuma Dutta, Mainak Pal, Subhas Barman, Matangini Chattopadhyay, Samiran Chattopadhyay
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: New-generation traffic violation systems are often plagued by issues related to data tampering, transparency, and poor record-keeping. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes EtherFineChain, a blockchain-based framework for traffic violation logging and cryptocurrency penalty enforcement utilizing smart contracts. The system records decentralized, tamper-proof and verifiable storage of key violations data like vehicle number, evidence references for legitimate stakeholders. A working prototype has built and deployed on the simulated environment - Ganache, enabling automated fine deduction and immutable record keeping. Experimental evaluation shows that the average transaction latency is 134.48 ms and transaction throughput is 7.43 transactions/sec(approx.), and handles over 500 records per hour under simulation. Although the current version is founded on pre-processed inputs, the architecture is designed to support real-time detection and automated pipelines in upcoming versions. EtherFineChain provides a scalable and independent foundation for digital traffic management, laying the groundwork for secure integration into smart-city infrastructures.

title: AI-Driven Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Short-Term Renewable Energy Forecasting under Extreme Weather Events
authors: Sajib Debnath, Md Robiul Islam, Md Abubakkar, Md Zahidul Islam, Md Shafiqul Islam Mridul, Arindam Kishor Biswas
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: As wind and solar grow on the grid, operators need short-term forecasts that remain dependable precisely when weather turns extreme. However, the coupling between meteorology and demand/renewable output is highly nonlinear and nonstationary, which limits the accuracy of standard statistical and machine-learning baselines. We introduce a hybrid deep learning framework that pairs an attention-guided convolutional network used to extract spatial signals from meteorological and renewable features with a bidirectional LSTM that models temporal dependencies in load and generation. The model produces probabilistic outputs, yielding point forecasts together with calibrated prediction intervals so that uncertainty can be factored into operations. We evaluated the approach on hourly ERCOT demand, NREL wind integration data, and NOAA weather records, and stress-tested it on periods flagged as extreme using a robust outlier detector. Across multiple horizons, the proposed method reduces the error by approximately 15–20% relative to the ARIMA, SVR, and vanilla LSTM baselines, while maintaining strong interval coverage. In volatile conditions, the attention layer consistently elevates the meteorological drivers most responsible for forecast shifts, and the uncertainty head indicates the confidence to place in each estimate, both of which are directly useful for reserve sizing and dispatch decisions. Overall, combining attention-based spatial weighting with bidirectional sequence modeling yields a practical and resilient forecaster for short-term renewable and load predictions under extreme weather conditions.

title: Microwave Characterization CPW Lines Using Copper Ink Based Printed Electronics
authors: Shin Yokomura, Daisuke Yasunobu, Hiroto Sakaki, Kenjiro Nishikawa
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: This paper evaluates coplanar waveguides (CPWs) on polyimide substrates fabricated using production-level printed electronics (PE) technology with copper powders. Printed electronics technology involves printing metal powders onto substrates and forming metal patterns on the substrate, enabling the low-cost mass production of electronic circuits. However, there are few reported demonstrations of microwave circuits using printed electronics substrates. Therefore, in this study, measurements and evaluations of CPW were conducted up to 20 GHz. As a result, the transmission loss per millimeter at 20 GHz was found to be comparable to that of CPW lines formed on conventional substrates, such as Alumina, and those formed using inkjet-based manufacturing processes with silver particles.

title: Practical Implementation of a Hybrid ANN-SMC for Photovoltaic MPPT Control
authors: Youssef Dhieb, Kais Jamoussi, Larbi Chrifi-Alaoui, Moez Ghariani
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents the practical implementation of a hybrid Maximum Power Point Tracking (MPPT) controller that combines Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and First-Order Sliding Mode Control (SMC) for photovoltaic (PV) systems. The hybrid ANN-SMC approach exploits the robustness of sliding mode control combined with the adaptive learning capability of neural networks to ensure optimal energy extraction under dynamic irradiance and temperature variations. The experimental validation is performed on a Phaesun Sun Plus 20 W photovoltaic panel connected to a DC-DC boost converter. The control algorithm is executed in real time on microcontroller-based platform interfaced with voltage and current sensors. The ANN module adaptively tunes the SMC parameters, thereby minimizing chattering and improving tracking accuracy. Experimental results confirm the feasibility and efficiency of the proposed hybrid controller. The ANN-SMC controller ensures fast convergence to the maximum power point (MPP), high MPPT efficiency, and strong robustness under rapidly changing outdoor conditions. The study demonstrates that the proposed approach provides a reliable and cost-effective MPPT solution for small-scale photovoltaic systems.

title: Scalable Leader-Follower Formation for Nonholonomic Robots: Applications in Autonomous Navigation and Environmental Sensing
authors: Andres Erazo, Andres Morocho, Brayan Caizaluisa, Andrés Arcentales, Ana V. Guamán, Seok-Bum Ko
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper presents a robust leader-follower formation strategy and a specialized circuitry design for a scalable multi-robot system using three tracked chassis robots. Each robot dynamically shifts between follower and leader roles, enabling flexible scalability without the need for inter-robot communication. The proposed method leverages advanced image processing techniques for accurate, indirect distance measurement, ensuring robust coordination and reducing reliance on complex communication protocols. The study also provides an evaluation procedure of sensor performance across various distances and timing conditions, offering valuable insights into the system’s real-time operation and environmental sensing capabilities. These findings open the door to a range of applications, from autonomous navigation to environmental monitoring.

title: Coconut Maturity Level Classification using Image Preprocessing and Deep Transfer Learning
authors: Robert G. de Luna, Jhea Camille M. Alegre, Rhose Anne P. Martinez, Monica Rose N. Ramos, Hannah Micah A. Sadian, Oswald Godwin G. Villanueva
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This research addresses the difficulty of precisely identifying coconut maturity, which is essential for the Philippine agricultural sector and currently relies on unreliable techniques such as tapping guided by skilled judgment. To provide a more dependable solution, this study employs convolutional neural networks (CNNs) particularly transfer learning models for categorizing coconuts into three groups: mature, pre-mature, and young. A collection of 3,000 coconut images was collected and augmented, with an equal number at each of the three stages of ripeness and then enhanced to increase variation. Before training, the images were preprocessed by resizing and normalizing before applying three pre-trained models (EfficientNet, MobileNetV2, and VGG16). The assessment involved measurements such as accuracy, rate of errors, sensitivity, specificity, false positive rate, precision, and F1-score. Results showed that the VGG16 model achieved the highest accuracy of 96.17 %, followed by EfficientNet at 80.17 %, and MobileNetV2 at 65.33 %. This demonstrates how CNNs are more reliable than traditional methods for categorizing coconut ripeness. The device was made by incorporating the high-performing VGG16 model into the Jetson Nano microprocessor. This offers a feasible and scalable answer for enhancing farming practices and production methods within the coconut industry. This development could greatly enhance efficiency and standards in coconut farming, which would help farmers and the overall agricultural industry, ultimately promoting economic growth and sustainability.

title: Diagram Annotation and Classification for Visually Impaired People in Higher Education
authors: Ajitesh Parihar, Gaéetan Hains, Manpreet Kour, Kristina Cormier, Karine Gros, Mohamed Saber
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Despite the improvements in accessibility for visually impaired people in higher education, non-text material from books still poses a challenge. This paper discusses the purpose of creating an accessible system for understanding diagram features and using machine learning models that can classify and extract the topology of those diagrams. We will introduce the steps required for diagram processing and the development of tools to help generate data sets for training machine learning models.

title: On the Investigation of Hybrid Excited PM Machines with Emphasis on the Air Gap Flux Density
authors: Ahmed Asmi, Imen Abdhennader, Amal Souissi
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper aims to investigate the electromagnetic features of hybrid excited permanent magnet machines (HEPMMs), with an emphasis on the flux density distribution along the air gap. First, the proposed model is applied to a slotless topology. To do so, two magnetomotive forces (MMF) that constitute the machine’s dual excitation are presented: The first considers a PMs excitation component, while the second takes into account the current excitation field component. The slotting effect is then taken into consideration by incorporating a stator permeance function. The air gap flux density distribution of the slotted HEPMM is therefore estimated and compared to a predicted 2D finite element analysis (FEA) results. The investigation shows that the proposed formulation has good accuracy. Finally, the FEA model is used to forecast the no-load characteristics of the proposed concept, including back EMFs and phase flux linkages.

title: DeeprankCDM: A Deep learning Based Rank Aggregation Method for Ranking Mutations in Cancer Driver Gene based on Pathogenicity
authors: Subrata Das, Shouvik Chakravarty, Animesh Kumar Singh, Arnab Mukherjee, Anirban Mukhopadhyay, Nidhan K. Biswas
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Prioritizing missense mutations with respect to their functional impact, especially those found in well-known cancer-associated genes within tumor tissue, remains a major task that is still not fully characterized. Even though a large number of bioinformatic algorithms exist that computationally estimate mutational pathogenicity, they showed significant inconsistency in their predictions. Only a few of these tools demonstrate better accuracy in separating drivers from nondriver mutations in cancer. The objective of this study is to rank cancer driver gene mutations based on their in-silico predictive pathogenicity by employing a deep learning method. We developed DeeprankCDM, a deep learning method to identify consensus ranking by aggregating different ranks. Our model is implemented based on pairwise learn-to-rank, an approach designed to determine preferences between items and aggregate multiple individual ranks into a single, consensus ranking. The method shows good consistency during training, with an accuracy of 0.7802, ranging tightly between 0.7791 and 0.7804. Notably, along with well-known gene PTEN, missense mutations in the well-established and frequently mutated gene TP53 emerged as top-rankers in the final aggregated list, indicating the good and reliable performance of our developed method.

title: Study on Thermal Environment Response Characteristics of Micro-Initiator
authors: Ruizhen Xie, Yuan Qiao, Yanyan Wang, Yanxiang Luo, Chenggang Ao, Penghui Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: In order to solve the problem that the performance degradation of micro-initiator under thermal load is unclear, this paper tests the ignition sensitivity and initiation ability of micro-initiator under high and low temperature environment conditions, and tests the ignition and action time of micro-initiator after high and low temperature storage. The results show that the ignition sensitivity, action time and initiation ability of micro-initiator have no significant changes at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-54^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> and 71° C compared with room temperature. After storage at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-54{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> and 71° C for 30 days, the ignition performance of the micro-initiator has no significant change, indicating that the micro-initiator has good adaptability to the thermal environment from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-54^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to 71° C. After storage at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5 0}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 h}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$130^{\circ} \mathrm{C}, 4 ~\mathrm{h}, 110^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> and 96 h, the micro-initiator failed to ignite, indicating that the thermal safety problem of the micro-initiator will not occur when the ambient temperature is less than 150° C. When the ambient temperature is greater than 110° C, the ignition performance of the micro-initiator will be unreliable according to the different storage time.

title: Developing a RAG-Based LLaMA Chatbot for Restaurant Customer Service
authors: Viet Thanh Huynh, Trung Thanh Ho, Nguyet Minh Nguyen, Nhi Yen Bui, Nhan Hoai Dao, Quyen To Nguyen, Hung Thanh Ngo
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: This study presents the development of a customer service chatbot. A dataset collected from a restaurant covers various aspects, including menu and dish consultation, service incidents, practical usage scenarios, operational information, and general customer inquiries. Using this dataset, the LLaMA 3.2-1B-Instruct model was fine-tuned on domain-specific conversation pairs to tailor the language model to the target application. To improve accuracy and flexibility, the system integrates Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) with Qdrant vector search and BM25 keyword search in a hybrid retrieval framework. We evaluated the performance using automated metrics (ROUGE, BERT-Score) on the baseline and fine-tuned models, and LLM-based evaluation (RAGAS) on the RAG system. Evaluations were conducted on both the original and quantized versions (8-bit and 4-bit). The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed RAG-based chatbot system generates natural and contextually appropriate responses, and further confirm the feasibility of using quantized versions for deployment on resourceconstrained hardware.

title: Assessing Methods to Categorize Questions According to Cognitive Level based on Blooms Taxonomy: Constraints and Future Direction
authors: Pranit Das, Dhriti Chakraborty, Prasenjit Choudhury
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Automated systems that classify questions according to Bloom’s Taxonomy (BT) levels often struggle to accurately capture the underlying cognitive complexity. Existing supervised learning approaches frequently fail to distinguish between factual, analytical, and creative queries, as a result, chatbots and various educational platforms generate generic and one-size-fitsall responses. The objective of this study is to evaluate machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) approaches for BTbased question classification using 2,532 questions from multiple datasets and compare it with prompt based approaches. Crossdataset evaluation reveal a significant decline in performance in ML and DL approaches, highlighting the limitations of supervised learning techniques. Further analysis of out-of-vocabulary (OOV) terms uncovers gaps in the coverage of BT action verbs, which hinders accurate classification. These findings demonstrate that ML and DL approaches fail to reliably classify questions, revealing substantial limitations in identifying learning intent and information need, that significantly hinders the ability to deliver personalized content. To mitigate these issues, promptbased generative classification approaches using instructiontuned Large Language Model (LLM) is tested. Without relying on fixed vocabularies, the method nullifies OOV errors and better handles verb overlap by using LLM’s contextual knowledge trained on vast natural language.

title: Data-Driven Energy-Efficient Residential HVAC Control via PSO-Tuned PID Optimization
authors: Amar Bitouh, Lokman Sboui
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Model Predictive Control (MPC) is gaining popularity for real-time applications in various fields, particularly in embedded technologies. However, it requires high computational power and costly resources. This work explores the possibility of tuning the gains of a PID controller using the PSO (Particle Swarm Optimization) algorithm to minimize energy consumption while maintaining an acceptable heating rate. First, a thermal model of a residential building was created using Simscape, serving as a data source. Then, a PSO algorithm was implemented to determine the optimal gains of the PID controller. Index Terms-PID optimization (PID-PSO), Energy efficiency, Thermal systems.

title: Towards a Digital Twin of Medium-Voltage Circuit Breakers Using Quantum Algorithms and Deep Learning
authors: Arianne Lemo, Mactar Thiam, Karl-Igor Pierre, Christian Cossette, Adam W. Skorek
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: This paper proposes an approach that takes advantage of quantum computing combined with deep learning methods to design the digital twin of a medium-voltage circuit breaker. The method put forward in this study optimizes the search for an alternative to Sulfur hexafluoride, SF6 gas insulation in the fight against global warming, by replacing the use of SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> with a gas that is less harmful to the environment. The implementation of the QAOA quantum algorithm maximizes performance in calculating the dielectric strength of a gas mixture, while the integration of the deep learning method identifies the pattern of gas behavior in operation and predicts failures. The aim of creating the digital twin of a medium-voltage circuit breaker is to provide the electrical industry with a platform for virtual experimental testing with increased precision, saving time and resources - an important innovation in the world of electrical engineering.

title: Performance Comparison of 1st and 2nd Order Sliding Mode MPPT Controllers in Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Walid Ouled Amor, Rachid Benbey, Youssef Dhieb, Moez Ghariani
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Sciences and Techniques of Automatic Control and Computer Engineering (STA)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative evaluation of firstand second-order sliding mode control (SMC1 and SMC2) strategies for maximum power point tracking (MPPT) in photovoltaic (PV) systems. Both controllers are implemented on a boost DC-DC converter connected to a PV array. Their performance is assessed under both constant and variable irradiance conditions through MATLAB/Simulink simulations. The results demonstrate that SMC1 achieves faster dynamics, with a rise time of 44.55 ms and a response time of 64 ms, making it suitable for applications requiring rapid convergence. However, it suffers from chattering, which may accelerate component degradation and increase switching losses. In contrast, SMC2 achieves smoother regulation with reduced oscillations and a lower ITAE value (7.456 vs. 13.58), improving long-term stability and robustness under irradiance variations. Both controllers reach identical steady-state MPPT efficiency of $96.95 \%$, but their suitability depends on system constraints: SMC1 for cost-effective embedded systems, and SMC2 for grid-connected or highly dynamic environments.

title: Comparative Analysis of Linear Quadratic Regulator, Linear and Robust Model Predictive Control on a Two-Wheeled Inverted Pendulum
authors: Lorenzo Fici, Dalim Wahby, Alvaro Detailleur, Guillaume Ducard
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Robotics and Automation Engineering (ICRAE)
abstract: This work investigates and compares control strategies for the stabilization of a two-wheeled inverted pendulum robot. The study focuses on three model-based approaches: 1) linear quadratic regulator (LQR), 2) linear model predictive control (MPC), and 3) constraint tightening MPC (CTMPC). The study, conducted entirely in simulation using a nonlinear model of the robot, consists of two parts, namely 1) trajectory simulations for two known initial conditions, and 2) the estimation of the region of attraction (RoA) using a Monte Carlo-based approach. In simulation, all designed controllers perform comparably on a set of nonzero initial conditions and the estimated RoA is identical. Overall, the CTMPC achieved smaller deviations in position and a slightly faster settling time compared to the other controllers, at the cost of a marginally higher mean-squared error of the pitch angle. These results indicate that while all controllers regulate the system, CTMPC offers slightly improved transient performance.

title: Tea Leaf Diseases Detection using YOLOv8-CBAM by enhancing Channel and Spatial Features
authors: Samual Halder, Sourav De, Pratima Sarkar, Sandipan Pasari, Somnath Mukherjee, Bitan Misra
publish: 2025 Seventh International Conference on Research in Computational Intelligence and Communication Networks (ICRCICN)
abstract: Agricultural productivity in tea cultivation faces substantial threats from foliar pathologies that significantly diminish harvest outputs and economic returns. Contemporary diagnostic approaches dependent upon human expertise demonstrates inherent limitations including temporal inefficiency, subjective variability, and diagnostic inaccuracy. This investigation presents an autonomous recognition framework employing computational vision and deep neural architectures. We augment the YOLOv8 detection paradigm through incorporation of Convolutional Block Attention Modules, facilitating dynamic channel and spatial feature prioritization. This enhancement amplifies discriminative capability for pathology-specific morphological characteristics while minimizing extraneous environmental interference, demonstrating elevated precision and sensitivity particularly for incipient symptomatic manifestations. Experimental validation against conventional methodologies and unmodified YOLOv8 reveals marked improvements in accuracy, resilience, and operational efficiency under authentic field deployment scenarios. The proposed architecture maintains minimal computational overhead, rendering it appropriate for resourceconstrained agricultural implementations and enabling proactive intervention strategies with reduced dependence on agrochemical applications.

title: Detecting “Nine-Dash Line” Images in Digital Content via Faster R-CNN and DINOv2-Based Knowledge Distillation
authors: Tu Do Tran, Hieu Mai Danh, Long Dang Hoang
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: The “nine-dash line” image represents an illegal maritime claim that frequently appears in digital content, posing significant risks of distorting Vietnam's territorial sovereignty. Manual moderation cannot keep pace with the rapidly growing volume of data, especially as such infringing images are often small, thin, and subtly embedded. In this study, we employ an enhanced Faster R-CNN model, incorporating knowledge distillation (KD) from the vision-language model DINOv2 to detect “nine-dash line” imagery. A KD loss function is utilized to align embeddings between predicted and ground-truth regions, thereby improving the detection of small and occluded objects. The model is trained on a specialized dataset of 836 images and achieves a mean Average Precision (mAP) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 8. 4 \%}$</tex>, representing an improvement of 6.2 % over the baseline Faster R-CNN with a ResNet-50 backbone. In addition, the employed approach achieves an Average Recall (AR) of 66.2 %, compared to 58.8 % for the baseline model. This system demonstrates strong potential for integration into automated digital content moderation workflows, supporting the protection of national sovereignty in cyberspace.

title: Ultra-Low Frequency Micro-Thrust Drifting Compensation Using Pre-and Post-Measurement Signals Based on DWT and Seg-Mamba
authors: Wenwen Hou, Xingyu Chen, Libin Huang, Jiawen Xu, Liye Zhao, Ruqiang Yan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Drift compensation is pivotal for micro-thrust measurement equipment to detect gravitational waves as ultra-low frequency drift poses a significant challenge. This study proposes a drift compensation method taking advantages of predictions using pre- and post-instrument heating signals. We decompose the signals into baseline drifts and alternating noise. It is demonstrated that the baseline drift could be fitted through improved weighted least squares fitting. Besides, the alternating noise can be de-composited using wavelet method and predicted using a novel Seg-Mamba model. The results illustrated that the proposed method can reduce power spectral density (PSD) of background signal drift from 49930 µN/Hz<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1/2</sup> to 0.08 µN/Hz<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1/2</sup> at 0.1 mHz for microthrust measurement. The proposed method is capable of effective drift compensation for thrust measurement in complex and dynamic environments.

title: Deep Learning Model for Invasive Ductal Carcinoma Detection in Histopathology Images
authors: Dylan Jayabahu
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: Breast cancer, with Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (IDC) as its most prevalent subtype, presents substantial challenges in early detection and diagnosis. This study introduces a novel computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) system designed to detect IDC in histopathology images with high precision. Leveraging a convolutional neural network (CNN), the system incorporates advanced methodologies such as sliding window-based heatmaps and a unique oversampling technique that extracts patches from homogenous regions in stitched whole-slide images. This approach enhances minority class representation while maintaining biological integrity, addressing class imbalance effectively. The system achieved a balanced accuracy of 89.06% and an F1-score of 86.68%, outperforming existing models in the literature. The implementation of sliding heatmaps further improves interpretability, enabling pathologists to visualize model predictions seamlessly. This research demonstrates the potential of combining innovative deep learning techniques with domainspecific insights to enhance IDC detection, offering a reliable tool for clinical practice and contributing to improved patient outcomes.

title: Local Coordination of Distributed PV-BESS for Grid Voltage Regulation
authors: Zhanqiang Zhang, Wenbin Yue, Chuan Sun, Xiaodong Li
abstract: To mitigate bus voltage violations in active distribution networks, this article proposes a local coordinated voltage regulation (VR) algorithm involving distributed photovoltaic (PV) and battery energy storage system (BESS). First, a sequential coordination mechanism of reactive power compensation (RPC) of PV followed by active power compensation (APC) of BESS is designed. Then, the available maximum RPC capacity and the required minimum APC capacity are computed in turn based on the exact VR requirement of a selected crucial bus. Afterward, a capacity-based proportional RPC-APC control is adopted to keep each PV or BESS in a consistent controllable state, thereby preventing repeated parameter updates and extensive iterations. The algorithm only requires control of local PV and BESS on the buses experiencing voltage issues, which leads to a fairer sharing of the VR burden. Finally, the effectiveness is validated through the case study in a real grid scenario.

title: Optimizing Fully Fuzzy Linear Systems Using the Average Uniform Algorithm: A Fuzzy Data Modeling Approach
authors: Azmi Alazzam, Ghassan Malkawi, Ahmed Abdelaziz Elsayed, Asem Omari, Said Badreddine
abstract: This paper presents an Enhanced Average Uniform Algorithm (E-AUA) for solving Fully Fuzzy Matrix Equations (FFME), addressing critical limitations in existing fuzzy optimization methods. Our approach combines sophisticated dual exploration-exploitation mechanisms with adaptive parameter management and fuzzy-specific operators to achieve superior performance in handling uncertain linear systems. Through comprehensive evaluation on systems ranging from 3×3 to 20×20 dimensions, E-AUA consistently outperforms established meta-heuristic algorithms including genetic algorithms, particle swarm optimization, simulated annealing, and differential evolution, achieving solution accuracies below 10-6 with 100% success rates. The algorithm demonstrates exceptional scalability with rigorously proven O(TKn3) computational complexity and maintains robust convergence across diverse problem types including wellconditioned, ill-conditioned, and mixed-sign systems. Rigorous theoretical analysis establishes formal convergence guarantees under explicitly stated conditions, while ablation studies confirm the contribution of each algorithmic component. Practical validation through two real-world applications-supply chain optimization and energy system management-confirms applicability across domains, achieving 15% cost improvements over deterministic approaches and demonstrating superior performance on systems with up to 150 decision variables. Statistical validation through 50 independent runs with Wilcoxon signed-rank tests confirms significance at p < 0.001 levels, while comprehensive comparative analysis against recent optimization algorithms, including Honey Badger and Grey Wolf optimizers establishes E-AUA’s state-of-the-art performance.

title: Enhanced Wireless Readout near Gain–Loss Detuned Non-Hermitian Exceptional Points
authors: Huacheng Zhu, Lu Tan, Yang Yang, Ke Yin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Wireless sensing systems have significant applications in environmental monitoring and medical diagnostics. Although exceptional point (EP) in non-Hermitian parity-time (PT) symmetric system can significantly enhance perturbation sensitivity, making them highly promising for ultrasensitive wireless sensing, their practical implementation is hindered by the stringent requirement for precise gain-loss matching between the reader and the sensor. Furthermore, the resolution of such systems deteriorates markedly under asymmetric perturbations. Here, we develop a PT-symmetric wireless sensing system with gain–loss detuning that maintains high-resolution frequency shifts despite slight gain-loss mismatches between components. Through theoretical analysis, we demonstrate that this system achieves sensitivity comparable to that of PT-symmetric systems while overcoming their inherent limitations. Experimental validation through pressure sensing demonstrates that the detuned PT-symmetric system achieves high-resolution detection under tiny capacitive pressure perturbations while attaining a sensitivity of 1.85 MHz/N. Our work indicates potential implications for practical applications of ultra-sensitive sensors.

title: Beyond Speculation: Measuring the Growing Presence of Large Language Model-Generated Texts in Multilingual Disinformation
authors: Dominik Macko, Aashish Anantha Ramakrishnan, Jason S. Lucas, Robert Moro, Ivan Srba, Adaku Uchendu, Dongwon Lee
abstract: Increased sophistication of large language models (LLMs) and the consequent quality of generated multilingual text raises concerns about potential disinformation misuse. Our study provides the first empirical evidence of LLM presence in real-world disinformation data sets.

title: Fringe Effect-Induced Artifact Suppression via Reconstruction Discrepancy-Based Measurement Correction in Dual-Plane ERT
authors: Ran Pang, Chao Wang, Xiao Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Electrical Resistance Tomography (ERT) is widely used for multiphase flow monitoring due to its non-invasiveness and high temporal resolution. However, the fringe effect induces artifacts in the reconstructed images from conductivity perturbations beyond the measurement plane, compromising tomographic imaging accuracy. Existing mitigation strategies, such as sensor structural optimization or multi-plane auxiliary imaging, face limitations like extended sensing ranges or the requirement for prior object knowledge. In this paper, a boundary measurement correction method based on reconstruction discrepancies in dual-plane ERT is proposed to suppress the fringe effect-induced artifacts. The distinct sensitivity responses of dual planes to identical spatial perturbations can be manifested as discrepancies in dual-plane reconstructed images. Based on these discrepancies, it is able to extract the measurement components corresponding to the perturbations within the measurement plane. Independent reconstruction of these components eliminates the artifacts induced by the perturbations outside the measurement plane. The results demonstrate substantial improvement in reconstruction quality after correction, significantly outperforming the grounded-guard single-plane tomography and dual-plane 3D tomography. The correction method also shows robust suppression capability for perturbations at arbitrary off-plane locations and superiority in handling severe fringe effect induced by axially longer perturbations.

title: AI-Powered Neurofeedback Systems for Bipolar Disorder
authors: Muhammad Danial Mutalib Mohd Shah, Zainatul Shima Abdullah
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Information and Communication Technology for the Muslim World (ICT4M)
abstract: Bipolar disorder (BD) frequently erupts during late adolescence, precisely when the brain’s structural scaffolding is being remodelled through synaptic pruning, myelination and reward circuit fine tuning. Conventional clinical tools—mood charts, rating scales and episodic interviews—capture only the visible tip of a much deeper neuro developmental iceberg. Recent strides in artificial intelligence (AI) and high throughput computing raise the prospect of monitoring that iceberg in real time by fusing multi scale neuro data (MRI, diffusion MRI, EEG), behavioural exhaust (keyboard metadata, actigraphy, speech prosody) and longitudinal developmental markers. This paper delivers a 360 degree review of state of the art pipelines, then proposes Brain DEV BD, an end to end, student friendly blueprint that (i) aligns data acquisition with critical neuro developmental windows, (ii) deploys explainable transformer ensembles for multimodal fusion, and (iii) outputs a dual report which comprise developmental risk trajectory and 30 day episode onset probability. A prospective validation plan on 200 Malaysian and international youths (14–24 years) is laid out, together with ethical guard rails around privacy, bias and participatory design. By zooming out from static diagnosis to dynamic brain growth, Brain DEV BD seeks to convert BD care from reactive firefighting to proactive, just in time intervention.

title: Improving On-Time Delivery in a Metalworking SME Using Demand-Driven MRP and Simulation-Based Validation
authors: Gabriel Alejandro Rivera-Vargas, Andres Tamayo-Corazao, Juan Carlos Quiroz-Flores, José Antonio Taquía-Gutierrez
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: Peruvian metalworking SMEs struggle to meet the 87.5 % on-time delivery (OTD) benchmark, largely because existing material requirements planning systems fail under intermittent demand. This study closed that gap by integrating Demand-Driven Material Requirements Planning (DDMRP) with Croston-based forecasting and validating the approach through discrete-event simulation. After mapping the current value stream, strategic inventory buffers were dimensioned from a 31-month demand series for chassis tanks and embedded in an Arena model of the line. Compared with the baseline, the proposed system raised simulated OTD from 41.6 % to 94.0 % and cut average production lead time from 55.4 to 18.3 days, delivering an estimated annual net profit of US <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$73,894$</tex> against an investment of US <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4,533$</tex>. The work provides the first quantitative evidence of DDMRP's effectiveness in the Peruvian metal-mechanic sector, demonstrates its transferability to settings with high demand variability, and contributes a replicable procedure for practitioners seeking sustainable, low-capital performance gains.

title: A Critical Look at Ethics of Facebook on Litigation & Misinformation
authors: V Lakshmi Narasimhan, Cole A Kenna, Naresh Kumar Sharma, B M Bharath
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Over the years social networking sites have exploded in popularity, of which Facebook stands as the most popular with nearly three billion monthly users. However, for all its popularity, it is also a hotbed of ethical concerns. Experts criticize Facebook for lying about how they use the data they gather from consumers, the spread of misinformation on their platform, ignoring harmful groups that utilize the website such as terrorist groups, and allowing minors to post sensitive information. Studies have shown that, while Facebook can have a positive effect on the world wide web, the ethical issues caused by it can outweigh the good. Care should be taken by anyone who wishes to use Facebook, especially younger users. Facebook doesn’t always have the user’s best interests in mind. Instead, it skirts the line of what could be considered ethical and has repeatedly shown it cares more about profit than its users. While an earlier paper dealt with Facebook’s issues relating to Child Education and Employment, this paper provides a critical look at misinformation issues that plague Facebook.

title: Simultaneous Power and Data Transmission Using a Single Hybrid Optical Cable Towards B5G Systems
authors: F. B. F. Pinto, S. B. Vasconcellos, E. S. Lima, E. L. Anderson, Arismar Cerqueira S.
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work presents a proof of concept (PoC) of an optically powered communication system for Beyond 5G (B5G) networks. The proposed configuration features a hybrid optical cable that enables simultaneous data and power transmission through single-mode fiber (SMF) and multimode fiber (MMF) links, respectively. A 5G New Radio (NR) signal at 26 GHz is generated, transmitted over a 200 m Radio-over-Fiber (RoF) link, and radiated through a 5 m wireless link. The implemented Power-over-Fiber (PoF) system is capable of transmitting more than 8 W of optical power to supply all the active components of the Remote Radio Unit (RRU). Efficiency metrics indicate excellent PoF performance, achieving a power transmission efficiency (PTE) above 36%. The optically powered B5G network is capable of delivering up to 623 Mbit/s with a 200 MHz bandwidth using a 64-quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) scheme. Finally, a performance comparison based on the root mean square error vector magnitude <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{EVM}_{\text{RMS}})$</tex> highlights the feasibility of PoF implementations for future mobile communication networks.

title: Playing with Attention: Design and Implementation of an Interactive Prototype for Children with Attention Deficit
authors: Kevin Castro, Fredy Pardo
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This project focused on creating an interactive educational game prototype designed to strengthen cognitive and attention skills in children exhibiting symptoms of attention deficit, particularly during their critical developmental stagespreschool and early school years. Aware of the essential role these skills play in learning and overall development, the project sought to provide an effective tool that not only entertains but also educates and supports the enhancement of cognitive areas. To achieve this goal, a review of scientific literature related to child cognitive development and educational technologies was conducted. Key cognitive development theories and teaching methods were then identified and selected as the foundation for the game's design framework. These guided the selection of activities, strategies, and challenges to be incorporated into the game, ensuring alignment with the individual needs of the children. The game's design is based on a usability and accessibility approach tailored to children's cognitive and attention capacities. Through a set of engaging activities and challenges, and by leveraging the benefits of gamification, the game aims to maintain a high level of user engagement. To assess the effectiveness of the prototype, pilot tests were conducted with children, evaluating their attention and problem-solving skills. Preliminary results showed that the prototype was effective in improving children's concentration and problem-solving abilities, indicating its potential as a meaningful educational tool to address the causes of attention deficit. Ultimately, this project not only facilitated the development of innovative learning tools for schools but also had a significant impact on the cognitive and attentional development of the children who used them. It offered flexible and enjoyable learning experiences and laid the groundwork for balanced cognitive growth, enabling children to successfully face the challenges of today's world and make the most of modern technology.

title: Integrated Climate and Water Analysis: Forecasting Floods and Droughts with Machine Learning
authors: Subhadra Bhattacharyya, Sudip Bhattacharya, Amit Kumar Das
publish: 2025 13th International Conference on Intelligent Embedded, MicroElectronics, Communication and Optical Networks (IEMECON)
abstract: Water is the most important thing in our life, and this paper focuses on monitoring and predicting water resources. The prediction is for flood and drought using rainfall forecasting. This forecasting was done by using monthly Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) and temperature, rainfall datasets. It is helpful for construction and agricultural activity. The prediction can be visualized in a graph of rainfall vs NDWI monthly. And for predicting this, we have used a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model. For accomplishing such a thing, we have organized the data set accordingly for LSTM model and we have use prophet for advance climate forecasting and by using various plot like heat map, box plot, plotting Histogram to understand the Distribution the different Features NDWI + Rainfall Distribution Together to understand points with high NDWI and high rainfall as well as identify the flood thresholds.

title: User Admission Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning in Mobile Networks with Network Slicing and Different Numerologies
authors: Hudson Henrique de Souza Lopes, Flávio Henrique Teles Vieira
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: Slicing techniques in 5G networks make it possible to divide a physical network into virtual slices, each adapted with a bandwidth part (BWP) and a specific numerology so that radio resources can be allocated in an efficient manner, meeting the various requirements of each slice. In addition, combining device-to-device communication (D2D) with network slicing (NS) improves spectrum utilization, providing better performance for the wireless network. In this article, we propose an approach that uses Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) in mobile networks with NS, D2D and flexible numerology. The results show that the proposed approach achieves superior performance in terms of both throughput and delay compared to the scenario without using DRL.

title: Photonic Spatial Switching Techniques Using Semiconductor Optical Amplifiers
authors: Pedro A. B. Leao, Jonathan A. Soares, Tiago Sutili, Arismar Cerqueira S., Evandro Conforti
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work presents a detailed analysis of the key switching parameters of semiconductor optical amplifiers (SOAs). Based on a numerical model of an InPhenix SOA, a dataset was generated, enabling a rigorous examination of the principal parameters of the PISIC and MISIC techniques. Furthermore, a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) was employed to solve the inverse SOA problem, achieving a low mean squared error.

title: Deep Learning-Based Detection of Cracks in Concrete Pavement Using Simulated UWB Horn Antenna GPR Signals
authors: Grigório Ribeiro Soares Neto, Vinicius Uchoa Oliveira, Simona Fontul, Francisco Manuel Carvalho Pinto Fernandes, Jorge Carvalho Pais
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper investigates whether time-domain Ground Penetrating Radar (GPR) signals, synthetically generated with ultra-wideband (UWB) horn antennas modeled in CST Studio, can train a convolutional neural network (CNN) to detect internal cracks in concrete pavements. A full-wave simulation workflow produced A-scan signals for intact and cracked slabs; six signal-level augmentation techniques (time shifting, amplitude offset, mixup, spectral perturbation, Gaussian noise, and segment rearrangement) were mathematically formalized and applied. A light image-level augmentation further expanded the dataset. In total, 2,100 labeled samples (1,050 per class) were used to train and validate a binary CNN classifier. The model achieved 97% validation accuracy and a stable loss profile, indicating reliable discrimination between crack and no-crack conditions using synthetic GPR data. The results support simulation-driven training as a viable path for AI-based non-destructive crack detection and provide a reproducible baseline for future validation with field measurements.

title: Assessment of the Implementation of an Intelligent Irrigation System in Bogotá
authors: Santiago Alejandro Alvarez Garzón, Cristian Felipe Garcia Quinche, Juan Sebastian Rios Vega, Sara Fernanda Sánchez Sánchez, Oscar Fernando Penagos Espinel
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: The Smart Agriculture project focuses on the creation of an automated and efficient garden. This garden will be equipped with a monitoring system that will use electronic components such as temperature and humidity sensors to ensure optimal growing conditions for the plants. Additionally, an irrigation system will be implemented to utilize rainwater, promoting sustainable water use. To enhance the plant growth process, artificial light will be incorporated, complemented by sound, to stimulate their development in a controlled manner.

title: Extending Visual Dialog Beyond English: An Analysis of Monolingual and Multilingual Models
authors: Milena Menezes Adão, Silvio Jamil F. Guimarães, Zenilton K. G. Patrocínio
abstract: Visual Dialog is a challenging multimodal task requiring models to answer questions about images through multi-turn conversations. Despite significant progress, research has predominantly focused on English, limiting applicability to the 850+ million speakers of Portuguese and Spanish worldwide. We present the first comprehensive study of monolingual and multilingual Visual Dialog models for Portuguese and Spanish, introducing novel insights into cross-lingual visual grounding mechanisms. Through extensive experiments on newly translated VisDial datasets, we compare language-specific encoders (BERTimbau for Portuguese, BETO for Spanish) against multilingual BERT, achieving competitive performance with monolingual models while revealing distinct cross-modal attention patterns. Our mechanistic interpretability analysis demonstrates that despite different tokenization strategies and pretraining objectives, both approaches converge to similar attention distributions in deeper layers, with divergence decreasing from 0.000832 (Layer 0) to 0.000490 (Layer 11). We find that monolingual models exhibit holistic attention strategies while multilingual models show more selective, fine-grained visual grounding. These findings have important implications for developing inclusive vision-language technologies and understanding cross-lingual transfer in multimodal contexts.

title: Joint Power Control and Beam Steering for NGSO-to-GSO Interference Mitigation in Ku Band
authors: Luciana R. N. Ferreira, Higo T. P. Silva, Hugerles S. Silva, Paulo Henrique Portela de Carvalho
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work investigates the jointly use of power control and beam steering techniques to mitigate interference between non-geostationary satellite orbit (NGSO) and geostationary satellite orbit (GSO) systems operating in the Ku band. Our approach is a low complexity solution, which does not require strict synchronization between systems and depends only on geometric parameters known a priori by the GSO and NGSO systems. Simulation results, which consider real-world constellation characteristics and follow International Telecommunication Union (ITU) recommendations, are presented under various system parameters. The analyses presented here are unprecedented in the literature, thus constituting a practical approach to mitigate interference, ensuring that the equivalent power flux-density (EPFD) of the satellite constellation meets the ITU regulatory limits.

title: A Perspective on Non-Invasive Blood Pressure Monitoring: Bridging Emerging Principles, Enabling Technologies and Extended Applications
authors: Chentao Du, Ting Xiang, Guangyao Zhao, Mengkang Deng, Zijun Liu, Zexu Yang, Jiayuan Fang, Ningxu Yuan, Siyuan Zhou, Jian Li, Nan Ji, Jing-Song Ou, Alberto Avolio, Xinge Yu, Yuan-Ting Zhang, Tingrui Pan
abstract: Cardiovascular disease (CVD), the leading global cause of death, highlights the critical need for effective blood pressure management. Non-invasive blood pressure (NIBP) monitoring, compared with invasive methods, enables home-based and long-term use, supporting early detection and continuous care. Despite significant progress, challenges remain, including accuracy issues, insufficient validation in real-world settings, limited application-specific sensor designs, and inadequate calibration standards and validation platforms. These gaps call for a systematic review to clarify the unmet needs and future research directions. This article reviews current advances in four key areas: (1) novel NIBP estimation principles designed to minimize user intervention; (2) flexible and wearable electronics that improve accuracy and comfort; (3) integration with theranostic applications and broader healthcare scenarios enabled by NIBP technologies; (4) calibration and validation strategies that enhance reliability and accuracy. With the rapid growth of home healthcare and AI-enabled wearable systems, addressing these challenges is essential to advance personalized, precise and stable cardiovascular medicine.

title: Toward Dolphin-Inspired Frictional Drag Reduction: A Novel Actuator Device for Boundary Layer Modulation_supp1-3617982.mp4
authors: Silvia Matt
abstract: Drag reduction is of significant interest in the design of marine vehicles. Viscoelastic boundary materials and compliant surfaces, such as those found in dolphin skin, have the potential to reduce frictional drag by delaying the transition from laminar to turbulent flow and minimizing turbulence. To investigate the effect of boundary modulation on turbulence, we developed and tested a novel device that generates wave-like deformations on a flow boundary. This device, enabled by a 5×5 voice coil motor array, was embedded in the wall of a flow channel and overlaid with a flexible membrane in direct contact with the water. The boundary displacement was quantified using a computer vision approach. The deformable membrane system was tested across a range of flow tank speeds and boundary actuation patterns, and the impact on near-boundary velocity was assessed. The resulting data indicate that boundary actuation alters the boundary layer velocity and turbulent stresses both under the region of actuation and in its wake. The effect was most pronounced in regions with boundary layer coherent structures, and certain actuation parameters were consistent with a reduction in frictional drag. A numerical model of the flow tank showed a 10% reduction in average shear stress over the actuated boundary and one actuation wave period, supporting the laboratory experiments and corroborating the findings. This work supports efforts to develop dolphin-inspired methods to reduce near-boundary turbulence and drag, which, if successfully applied in a natural environment, can lead to more energy-efficient platforms and underwater vehicles.

title: Dual Visual Prompting with Context-Modulated Diffusion Prompts
authors: Huan Wang, Haoran Li, Huaming Chen, Jun Yan, Jiahua Shi, Jun Shen
abstract: Prompt learning has emerged as an efficient tuning paradigm for fine-tuning powerful pre-trained models on downstream tasks in specific domains. Existing efforts mainly focus on dataset-level implicit embeddings by introducing extra learnable parameters instead of fully fine-tuning large-scale visual models. However, we find that these static post-training prompts are not flexible enough to adapt various input instances within the same dataset, which might lead to the loss of the model's generalization capability. To leverage the meaningful contextual information of each input instance, in this paper, we propose a straightforward yet effective method, termed CoMoDP, to enhance visual prompt learning with Context-Modulated Diffusion Prompts. Specifically, CoMoDP is a dual-visual prompting scheme that comprises two key components: (i) a unified visual prompt designer, producing dataset-level implicit embedding as unified prompts for efficient adaptation without corrupting the underlying information of the original image; and (ii) a diffusion prompt simulator, leveraging diffusion model's meticulous understanding of semantic structure and texture edges in the images to dynamically generate instance-level implicit embedding as diffusion prompts for input samples. Moreover, to reduce the overfitting of prompts, we also introduce momentum alignment, a self-regulating strategy that restricts the optimization region of prompts in both feature and logit spaces. Extensive experiments on various standard and few-shot datasets demonstrate that our method brings substantial improvements and yields strong domain generalization performance, compared to the state-of-the-art methods. We also demonstrate both zero-shot and out-of-distribution performance to establish the utility of our dual-visual prompting scheme CoMoDP and the efficiency of each component, without involving excessive parameters.

title: Quantum Computing–Driven Digital Twin Architecture for Optimized Load Distribution in IoT Networks
authors: Ankush Manocha, Munish Bhatia, Prashant Pandey
abstract: The growing demand for reliable service delivery and real-time data processing has intensified challenges in efficiently distributing workloads across geographically distributed server nodes in Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled Digital Twin (DT) environments. To address this issue, this study proposes a quantum computing–inspired (QCi) optimization–based framework to enhance load balancing in IoT–DT systems. The approach integrates a novel QCi optimization strategy with a QCi-based predictive neural network to estimate optimal server node allocation by considering real-time server availability and workload dynamics. Extensive evaluations show that the proposed method outperforms Bayesian Belief Networks, conventional Artificial Neural Networks, and Support Vector Machines, achieving a sensitivity of 87.36%, specificity of 94.38%, precision of 91.25%, and coverage of 97.51%. The results demonstrate that combining QCi optimization with DT technology significantly improves processing efficiency, prediction accuracy, and adaptability for real-time IoT workloads.

title: A Multi-Modal Deep Learning Framework For IVF Outcome Prediction Using Clinical, Demographic and Embryo Imaging Data
authors: R Haripriya, K. Sumangala, Priyanka D Rukesh, S G Sumana, K Astalakshmi
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: In-Vitro Fertilization (IVF) has revolutionized reproductive medicine. However, due to a variety of clinical, demographic and embryological factors, the prediction of outcomes after the use of IVF remains difficult. Conventional models typically rely on only a limited set of clinical inputs, such as maternal age, hormone levels, or embryo grading, without considering a broader range of data or imaging insights. To address these limitations, we propose a novel multi-modal deep learning framework for the improved prediction of IVF outcome in a transparent manner. The proposed framework uses a combination of structured data (including clinical, demographic and procedural information) with unstructured image data of embryos. The key elements of this framework include: (i) structured health records representing hormone profiles, treatment history, lifestyle and ethnicity. (ii) static and time-lapse embryo imaging enhanced by segmentation using U-Net and features extracted using ResNet-50 [12] and (iii) deep learning models. We have developed a hybrid architecture by combining LNGLMD-Net for modeling clinical data, CSPCSGAN for generating high-resolution synthetic images to balance the dataset and ensemble fusion methods such as Generalized Joint Optimization (GJO), OEOP and Condorcet’s Jury Theorem for outcome prediction. Models trained on the datasets produced higher accuracy, sensitivity, F1-score and AUC-ROC values, than customary machine learning approaches. SHAP analysis identified the most important features in the embryo development prediction models, which included the hormone Anti-Mullerian Hormone test, embryo fragmentation rates and the day of embryo transfer. Our model exhibits good generalizability and is practically useable despite being ill-posed due to high computation load and limited quality embryo data. As such, this work provides the AI-augmented reproductive health domain with a clinically interpretable data-driven decision support system for improved IVF protocols and personalized treatment pathways, which are highly sought after by clinicians. Future work includes using video data of embryo development using CNN-LSTM models, producing more realistic GAN-generated images and implementing privacy-preserving federated learning models across multiple fertility clinics.

title: SPECK Algorithm Implementation in VLSI: A Verilog-Based Approach for Efficient Simulation, Synthesis and Cryptographic Enhancement
authors: S.R. Arun Raj, G. Ramana Murthy, Pravin A. Dwaramwar, C. Thangamani, Dilip I. Sangotra, T.C. Manjunath
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Communication, Computing &amp; Industry 6.0 (C2I6)
abstract: Cryptography plays a key role in ensuring data security in resources, such as IoT devices, built -in systems and wireless sensor networks. Speck algorithm is a light encryption block designed by the NSA in 2013, which offers a balance between security and efficiency. This project focuses on the design, simulation and implementation of the RTL algorithm with the Verilog. The primary objectives of this work include designing the effective Verilog code to verify its correctness through simulation. The design includes the implementation of key expansion, encryption and decryption processes in optimization for area, performance and performance. The verilog -based design is simulated and verified by testing shots to ensure that correctness is correct. This work contributes to ongoing hardware security research by providing an efficient and scalable implementation of Speck -based verilog, suitable for IoT and built -in systems. Index expressions Performance analysis, verilog, design RTL, encryption, key spot, expansion, simulation, light cryptography, decryption…

title: Frequency-Reconfigurable Cylindrical Dielectric Resonator Antenna Using PIN Diode
authors: Gabriel P. Paulena, Juner M. Vieira, Edson R. Schlosser, Marcos V.T. Heckler
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This paper presents a frequency-reconfigurable cylindrical dielectric resonator antenna (DRA) designed to operate across three different GNSS services: GLONASS G3, Galileo E5b and GPS L2. Frequency reconfiguration is achieved by using a PIN diode to change the stub length, enabling the antenna to switch between these bands. The antenna presents a compact size and is composed of a cylindrical DRA with two stacked layers of CER-10 laminate. Parametric simulations of the feeding mechanism are presented and discussed. The antenna exhibits good performance achieving a radiation efficiency of 83.37% and gain of 5.2 dBi.

title: PrivProt: A Privacy-Aware Application Layer Protocol for Mobile Environments
authors: David Cevallos-Salas, José Estrada-Jiménez, Danny S. Guamán
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: Undoubtedly, mobile applications are essential in daily life, simplifying various tasks and saving time. However, they collect and transmit vast amounts of users' personal data to remote servers for providing their services. Despite the sensitivity of these operations, mobile environments commonly rely on the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) for the transmission of personal data, which does not protect against advanced threats that run on mobile devices and are capable of intercepting and exfiltrating personal data in use by authorized mobile applications. HTTP over secure Transport layer protocols, commonly known as HTTP Secure (HTTPS), is also ineffective against these threats as it only protects personal data in transit. In this paper, we present PrivProt, a lightweight protocol designed to preserve the privacy of personal data in use by mobile applications through the establishment of a secure end-to-end session with a remote server at the Application layer and the inclusion of privacy claims within an OAuth 2.0 token. Our results demonstrate that PrivProt outperforms HTTP in transmitting identical payloads while introducing missing privacy safeguards for mobile environments.

title: Improving puncture accuracy based on the estimation and compensation of the rotation of the flexible needle tip
authors: Longfeng Yu, Zhaoru Dong, Yu Wang, Zhenwan Peng, Feifan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Needle puncture serves as the foundation for a broad range of minimally invasive surgical diagnostic and therapeutic procedures. Flexible needles have the potential to overcome the limitations of traditional rigid needles, particularly their inability to bypass obstacles and correct needle tip deviations, making them a promising alternative. However, when the needle hub rotates during insertion, torsional interactions between the needle shaft and surrounding tissue result in a discrepancy between the rotation angles of the needle hub and the needle tip. This discrepancy can lead to needle tip misalignment, thereby affecting patient prognosis and compromising diagnostic reliability.
