Furthermore, accurately measuring the orientation of the needle tip remains a challenge. To address these issues, we propose a method for estimating and compensating for orientation discrepancies, which improves puncture accuracy, enhances patient prognosis, and boosts diagnostic reliability. Specifically, based on puncture images, we introduce a projection-based approach to estimate the actual rotation angle of the needle tip, and construct a dataset containing the corresponding rotation angles of the needle hub and tip. We then utilize a neural network to estimate the true orientation of the needle tip from a specific needle hub rotation angle. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can effectively estimate and compensate for the discrepancy between the orientations of the needle tip and hub, reducing the average rotation error from 9.6° to 0.6°. Additionally, puncture experiments conducted using paths planned via the particle swarm optimization algorithm verify that the method improves puncture precision, decreasing the error from 2.42±0.65 mm to 0.96±0.65 mm. These results indicate that the method is feasible and effective for enhancing patient prognosis and diagnostic reliability.

title: Optimizing Saudi Arabia's Power Grid: The Role of AC/DC Hybrid OHTL Systems and BESS Integration for Energy Efficiency and Net-Zero Targets Using GNDO
authors: Razan Khalid, Sarah Alyafeai, Abdullah Almehizia, Fahad Al-Ismail
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive 36-year deployment roadmap for transforming Saudi Arabia's power grid into a resilient, low-carbon system aligned with Vision 2030, and net-zero by 2060 target. Utilizing a detailed model of the national grid based on IEEE 18-bus system, where long-term technical and economic viability of HVAC, HVDC, and Hybrid AC/DC configuration was evaluated by optimization framework driven by the Generalized Normal Distribution Optimization (GNDO) algorithm, minimizes CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions, energy losses, and costs while adhering to strict power flow and stability constraints. The results demonstrates that deploying a Hybrid AC/DC system is the backbone of a sustainable transition, reducing annual energy losses by 52.2% (950 GWh) and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions by 52.4% (20.2 Mt) compared to conventional grid. This configurations unlocks annual savings of 234 million dollars and, critically, reduces the size of needed Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) capacity by 30%, while improving frequency stability by 66%. This analysis projects the operational performance and cost escalation of each scenario through 2060, providing a clear policy blueprint for strategic infrastructure investments and phased implementation.

title: Model to Increase Process Flow Efficiency Through the Use of TPM, SW, SLP Tools in a Furniture Company
authors: Juan Infantes-Arrunategui, Luis Medina-Pisconte, José Alvarez, Iliana Macassi, Orkun Yildiz
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: The Peruvian furniture manufacturing industry has faced a sustained decline in operational productivity and competitiveness, a trend that has been intensified by growing market demands, supply chain disruptions, and technological lag. This study addresses the performance gap observed at Huarcaya Group, a medium-sized enterprise dedicated to customized furniture production. The firm exhibits a suboptimal operational efficiency level of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 1 \%}$</tex>, below the national industry benchmark of 67 %. The root causes identified through technical, spatial, and economic analysis include poor facility layout, nonexistent preventive maintenance protocols, and the lack of standardized work methods. Drawing from methodologies broadly endorsed in the industrial engineering domain, the study proposes a strategic intervention integrating Systematic Layout Planning (SLP), Total Productive Maintenance (TPM), and Standardized Work (SW). These tools are applied synergistically to reconfigure the physical workspace, enhance asset reliability, and stabilize task execution across operations. Comparative literature demonstrates these methods' effectiveness in similar manufacturing contexts, including automotive, agro-industrial, and light assembly sectors. The proposal aims to elevate the efficiency index to a minimum of 67 %, thereby restoring competitive parity and setting a precedent for replicability within similar Peruvian enterprises. The findings are expected to provide empirical insights that reinforce the strategic role of industrial engineering in systemic performance recovery.

title: SE-Net: Symmetry-Enhanced Deep Learning for Advanced Stroke-Lesion Segmentation Using Multi-level Brain-Symmetry Priors
authors: Rawan Saad Alshehri, Eman Alqaissi, Emna Ellouz, Ghassen Suissi, Ahmed AlMokhtar Ben Hmida
abstract: Acute ischemic stroke is a leading cause of death and disability worldwide, and accurate lesion segmentation is important for diagnosis and treatment planning. Current deep learning approaches for stroke-lesion segmentation often fail to use the inherent bilateral symmetry of the human brain and are thus missing a valuable anatomical prior that clinicians routinely use for lesion detection. This paper introduces SE-Net, a novel symmetry-enhanced neural network that systematically incorporates brain-symmetry priors at multiple levels within a deep learning framework. Our approach extends the 3D U-Net architecture with four specialized components: a symmetry-aware encoder with dual-stream processing, a symmetry difference module for highlighting pathological asymmetries, a perfusion-diffusion mismatch attention mechanism, and enhanced skip connections that preserve symmetry information throughout the network. Comprehensive evaluation using the Ischemic Stroke Lesion Segmentation (ISLES) 2022 dataset demonstrates exceptional performance with a Dice similarity coefficient of 96.72%, which represents an improvement of 13–39 percentage points over state-of-the-art methods. The Hausdorff distance was 14.21 mm, which indicates improved boundary precision by 35–66% improvement compared to previous approaches. Statistical analysis confirmed that highly significant performance gains were achieved (p < 0.001, Cohen’s d > 1.7). Qualitative analysis was performed using representative segmentation results, small lesion detection examples, and symmetry difference visualizations, and the results validated the clinical applicability of our approach. Cross-dataset evaluation demonstrates robust generalization with 86-89% zero-shot performance across different imaging protocols. Clinical validation through expert evaluation confirmed the method’s potential for practical translation with an inference time of 3.4 seconds, which is suitable for acute stroke protocols. SE-Net addresses critical challenges in stroke diagnosis while establishing a framework for incorporating domain-specific anatomical knowledge into deep learning architectures for medical imaging applications.

title: Research on Oil and Gas Pipeline Defect and Stress Concentration Identification Method Based on Metal Magnetism
authors: Liansheng Qin, Xianzhu Dai, Mingjiang Shi, Yanbing Liang, Haonan Li
abstract: Defects and stress concentrations in oil and gas pipelines often occur at welds and elbows. In order to effectively distinguish between different types of defects and stress concentrations, a method for identifying defects and stress concentrations in oil and gas pipelines based on metal magnetic memory is proposed. Firstly, numerical simulations of defects and stress concentrations are conducted using the principle of metal magnetic memory detection. Then, an experimental plan is designed and an experimental platform is constructed based on the results of the numerical simulations. Magnetic memory signals from 224 sets of defects and 256 sets of stress concentrations were collected, and analysis found that the magnetic memory signals for defects and stress concentrations are similar and susceptible to environmental interference. Traditional methods of feature extraction are difficult and challenging to achieve high-precision discrimination. To address the issue of difficulty in feature extraction, a deep learning approach is adopted, proposing a hybrid model that integrates the multi-universe optimization algorithm, convolutional neural network, and bidirectional long short-term memory network. The experimental dataset is then validated. The results show that the recognition accuracy of this method can reach 94.8%, proving its effectiveness and high recognition rate in identifying defects and stress concentrations in oil and gas pipelines, and providing new ideas for intelligent recognition of pipeline defects.

title: Co-attention Autoencoder for Reinforcement Learning in High-Dimensional Environments
authors: Ruo-Ze Liu, Si-Yao Xing, Shuang Liu, Qifan Yu, Meng-Xuan Chen, Tong Lu
publish: 2025 4th International Conference on Automation, Robotics and Computer Engineering (ICARCE)
abstract: We propose a framework, termed Co-attention Autoencoder for Reinforcement Learning (CARL), which exploits temporal dynamics among consecutive observations while mitigating information redundancy. As an unsupervised and model-agnostic module, CARL can be seamlessly integrated into existing RL algorithms, improving both training stability and performance. Extensive experiments demonstrate that CARL outperforms baselines in all environments, achieving an average improvement rate of 10.68%, which highlight its potential as a general framework in high-dimensional decision-making tasks.

title: Time-Delay Induced Dynamics and Stability of CAV Platoons: A Numerical Framework Using Nonlinear DDEs
authors: Mahbub Hassan, Md. Emtiaz Kabir, Touhid Bhuiyan, Md Maruf Hassan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive numerical modeling framework for analyzing the string stability of Connected and Autonomous Vehicle (CAV) platoons under the influence of communication delays. Leveraging nonlinear Delay Differential Equations (DDEs), we simulate a ten-vehicle CAV platoon incorporating realistic controller dynamics with position and velocity feedback. A novel energy-based string stability metric is proposed, wherein the total energy dissipation ΔE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf> for each follower vehicle is computed using a combination of spacing error and its temporal derivative. This approach provides a physically interpretable measure of disturbance attenuation and convergence behavior.Through a series of parameter sweeps, we investigate the effects of varying time delay τ, position gain k<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>, and velocity gain k<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">v</inf> across 27 configurations. The results demonstrate that all configurations satisfying ΔE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf> > 0 exhibit asymptotically decaying spacing errors, confirming their string stability. Notably, increased delay tends to reduce energy dissipation, but this can be counteracted by appropriately tuning controller gains. Three-dimensional surface plots further reveal that higher k<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf> and k<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">v</inf> enhance stability margins under moderate to high delays.This study validates the use of ΔE<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">i</inf> as a robust stability proxy and offers practical guidelines for controller tuning in delay-prone vehicular environments. The proposed framework avoids reliance on linearization assumptions and can be extended to heterogeneous or mixed traffic scenarios. These findings contribute to the development of scalable, delay-resilient CACC systems with provable stability guarantees.

title: Third-Order Super Twisting SMC for Dynamic Response Improvement of IPMSM Drive Systems
authors: Hyun-Gyu Koh, Irfan Sami, Hee-Jeong Seon, Tae-Seok Kang, YoungGyu Jin, Yeong-Jun Choi
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: This paper proposed a Third-Order Super-Twisting Sliding Mode Control (TO-STSMC) strategy for robust speed regulation of Interior Permanent Magnet Synchronous Motor (IPMSM) drives under uncertain load conditions. Conventional PI, first-order SMC, and second-order STSMC controllers often suffer from overshoot, chattering, and limited transient performance. The proposed TO-STSMC introduces a third-order dynamic structure with correction terms to ensure finite-time convergence, strong disturbance rejection, and smooth control effort. The simulation results under the step load torque profiles demonstrated that the proposed method achieves faster settling, reduced overshoot, and accurate speed tracking compared to existing approaches. Furthermore, current responses confirmed reduced chattering, while bounded control signals indicated improved efficiency. These results demonstrate that TO-STSMC is a promising control strategy for high-performance IPMSM drives with potential applications in industrial automation, electric vehicles, and renewable energy systems.

title: Sub-6GHz Band Frequency Synthesizer with Automatic Frequency Calibration Technique
authors: Xin-Yu Chang, Yue-Fang Kuo
publish: 2025 IEEE International Symposium on Radio-Frequency Integration Technology (RFIT)
abstract: A sub-6GHz band frequency synthesizer with automatic frequency calibration (AFC) is presented. This proposed AFC architecture with a lock detector can be synchronized with the logic control unit to avoid frequency-switching errors during the phase-locking state. The proposed synthesizer is fabricated in a TSMC 180nm CMOS process. It occupied 1mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and dissipated 15.6mW at a supply voltage of 1.8V. The operating frequency ranges from 4.96GHz to 6.16GHz with a channel spacing of 10MHz. The calibration process needs to go through two phase-locked states whose duration is less than 7.2μs.

title: Improving the Performance of the Lightweight Detector Through Effective Collaboration with Visibility Enhancement Technique
authors: Quoc-Viet Hoang, Trung-Hieu Le
publish: 2025 RIVF International Conference on Computing and Communication Technologies (RIVF)
abstract: Detecting underwater fish presents numerous challenges due to factors such as complex backgrounds, image blur, and especially low illumination conditions. In this study, we propose a robust approach for elevating the fish detection accuracy of lightweight detectors, abbreviated as VcO-Net. Our network achieves the desired performance by closely incorporating the visibility enhancement technique and object detection model. The VcO-Net involves two components: a feature upgrade subnetwork and a small detection subnetwork. The feature upgrade subnetwork is developed based on the GAN architecture for effective learning of fish features. Extensive results on published datasets demonstrate that our VcO-Net surpasses current small object detection models.

title: Dual Active Bridge Switching Modes for Interfacing Supercapacitors
authors: Henar Mike O. Canilang, Shuai Wang, Ning Zhu, Patrick Palmer, Jiacheng Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Canadian Conference on Electrical and Computer Engineering (CCECE)
abstract: The dual active bridge (DAB) converter, known for its capability to handle wide voltage conversion ratios and ease in control for bidirectional power flow, is an attractive dc-dc topology for interfacing supercapacitor (SC) energy storage systems. Single phase shift modulation is commonly used to control DAB which conventionally realizes continuous conduction switching mode operation. Alternatively, this paper highlights the other DAB switching modes, namely discontinuous conduction mode and critical mode, for its operation with SCs. These unconventional switching modes can be beneficial in terms of maximizing the power utilization of SCs given their high-power density characteristic and thereby enhance the performance cost ratio of SC energy storage in many applications. A theoretical derivation is presented together with simulation validation.

title: Order Picker Path Optimization Using Traveling Salesman Problem Heuristics: A Comprehensive Analysis for Modern Warehouse Operations
authors: Prashanth Cecil
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Electrical, Control and Instrumentation Engineering (ICECIE)
abstract: Order picking represents the most labor-intensive and costly operation in warehouse management, accounting for approximately 50-65% of total operational costs. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of order picker path optimization using Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) heuristics in modern warehouse environments. We develop and evaluate multiple heuristic algorithms including nearest neighbor, 2-opt, 3-opt, and hybrid genetic algorithms for optimizing picker routes in various warehouse configurations. Our approach incorporates real-world constraints such as item weight, congestion factors, and pick frequency distributions. Experimental results from simulations on warehouse layouts ranging from 5,000 to 50,000 square meters demonstrate that the proposed hybrid genetic algorithm with 2-opt local search refinement achieves an average path reduction of 23.7% compared to traditional S-shape routing, with computational times suitable for real-time implementation. The framework has been validated using data from multiple distribution centers, showing consistent improvements in picker productivity and overall warehouse throughput.

title: Multimodal Urban Traffic Monitoring Using Artificial Vision and Crowdsourced Data
authors: Bernando Hernández-Sánchez, Ilse Cervantes, Juan Terven, Cesar J. Montiel Moctezuma
publish: 2025 IEEE International Autumn Meeting on Power, Electronics and Computing (ROPEC)
abstract: This study presents the design, implementation, and evaluation of an autonomous urban-traffic monitoring system that integrates computer vision with crowdsourced data. Deployed in the municipality of Corregidora, Querétaro, Mexico, the system supports mobility research in mid-sized cities. High-definition cameras at strategic locations capture continuous video streams that are processed in real time for vehicle detection, speed estimation, lane-change recognition, and traffic-density estimation. Edge nodes execute the vision pipeline and publish events to the analytics platform. In parallel, real-time alerts from the Waze platform are integrated to enhance situational awareness and validate visual observations. The resulting multimodal dataset is analyzed using time-series models, multivariate statistical methods, and geospatial visualization.

title: Top-$k$ Feature Selection in Sparse Learning via Accelerated Coordinate Descent Method
authors: Han Zhang, Yannian Gu, Feiping Nie, Xuelong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Top-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math></inline-formula> feature selection in sparse learning is a fundamental problem in machine learning. It is difficult to conquer due to the rigid <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\ell _{2,0}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-norm constraint. Existing literature mostly relaxes the constraint and seeks the approximation of the selection matrix, degenerating primitive models and missing the genuine solutions. This research tackles the primitive top-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math></inline-formula> feature selection model in sparse learning. From the perspective of universality, we investigate both supervised and semi-supervised models of top-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math></inline-formula> feature selection in sparse learning. By disassembling the feature selection matrix, it is revealed that two different objectives could be unified into one general ratio-trace problem, which is a non-convex optimization problem. The accelerated coordinate descent method is raised to efficiently solve the non-convex objective, through which the local optimal solution of top-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math></inline-formula> feature indices is obtained with a competitive time cost. To verify the proposed algorithm, we design toy experiments that could visualize the advantages of the selected features. Meanwhile, experimental results on nine normal datasets and the large-scale ImageNet dataset comprehensively show the superiority of our methods compared to representative and state-of-the-art supervised and semi-supervised algorithms.

title: An Interpretable Diagnosis Method for Wind Turbine Gearbox Based on Causal-Aware Neural Network
authors: Zhenpeng Lao, Gang Chen, Junlin Yuan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: Due to the complexity and variability of the operating environment, robust and interpretable fault diagnosis is essential to ensure the safe operation of the wind turbine gearbox. In recent years, causal learning has offered promising application prospects for uncovering the internal causal relationships of equipment and the interpretability of intelligent diagnostic models. However, the existing methods still have limitations, including difficulty in coping with the distribution offset caused by environmental changes and insufficient interpretability, which result in unreliable diagnoses. Aiming to address the above problems, an interpretable fault diagnosis method based on a causal-aware neural network (CANN) is proposed, which improves the diagnostic accuracy and interpretability of the model in complex environments. Firstly, a new structural causal model is proposed to analyze the causal relationship between fault-related variables. Then, a causal decoupling enhancement module is proposed to separate the effective causal part from the complex graph data. Finally, a robustness enhancement strategy based on causal intervention is proposed to extract stable and invariant features, which can effectively mitigate the influence of spurious correlations and distribution deviations. The experimental results show that the CANN model not only shows robust results in complex industrial environment diagnosis tasks, but also provides an interpretable explanation for model decision-making.

title: An IoT-Enabled Framework for Real-Time Smart Metering with Dynamic Tariff Pricing
authors: Gayathri S, Monisha M, Anant Kumar, K Shanti Swarup
abstract: In the era of intelligent power system, the present work pioneers, a next generation of reshaping the power systems. As energy landscape evolves synergy of AI and IoT redefines the smart metering and intelligent techniques in grid operation. The transition to smarter and more sustainable power system is increasing driven by digital technology that enhances the monitoring, control and automation. This work presents a practical approach to IoT enabled energy management using proposed Cyber Physical System – Digital Twin framework built on the smart meter network. This is designed to enable real time intelligence, tracking predictive decision-making grid analysis at grid edge by reducing latency and enhancing efficiency and security. By embedding these techniques, we transform raw data to actionable insights by optimizing the forecast and dynamically adjust electricity tariff based on real time conditions which offers visual feedback. The validation of simulation in LabVIEW software and the hardware centric innovation serves as the foundation of envisioned architecture that revolutionize power system network. The fusion of physical and digital intelligence marks a transformative leap by unlocking the unprecedented level of efficiency and resiliency and adaptive energy system capable of secured generation and responsive behaviour that leads to more future sustainable network.

title: Weighted Sum-Rate Maximization for RIS-BD Assisted Multi-User Symbiotic Radio System Based on Parasitic Mode
authors: Yujie Qiu, Lei Feng, Fanqin Zhou, Zhixiang Yang, Wenjing Li, Shaoyong Guo
abstract: Symbiotic radio (SR) garners significant attention for its potential to enhance spectrum efficiency and energy efficiency. This paper proposes a RIS-BD assisted multi-user symbiotic radio system based on parasitic mode, where primary users (PUs) and secondary users (SUs) achieve symmetric resource sharing through limited competition for transmission resources. To achieve the pareto optimum balancing system-wide transmission performance with user fairness, we address the optimization of the weighted sum-rate (WSR) under the condition of multiple constraints, including heterogeneous user transmission demands and the base station's maximum transmission power. To tackle this complex problem with coupled variables, we decompose it into three subproblems and design an alternating optimization-based algorithm to jointly optimize time slot access, user association, and active-passive beamforming. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to conventional commensal mode, parasitic mode achieves more orderly resource sharing, supports high-quality transmission for differentiated users, and delivers significantly improved overall transmission performance.

title: Microstrip Quadrature Coupler with Virtual Grounding for 2-4 GHz Applications
authors: F. C. Andrade, R. D. Ferreira J., R. J. Velásquez G., C. G. Rego, J. C. Ramirez, G. Medeiros-Ribeiro, Diego Tami
publish: 2025 SBMO/IEEE MTT-S International Microwave and Optoelectronics Conference (IMOC)
abstract: This work presents the design, optimization, and computational analysis of a quadrature hybrid coupler using microstrip technology on an FR4 substrate. The original layout was reconfigured to replace the physical ground connection with a virtual grounding technique based on a distributed resonator, thereby eliminating the need for metallic vias. The structure employs multi-section coupled lines and phase-compensation stubs, and it was simulated using Ansys HFSS. Simulation results demonstrate effective operation within the 2 - 4 ~ G H z range, maintaining a phase shift of 9 0° ± 5° and isolation better than −15 dB. Removing the physical via required extensive geometric optimization, including adjustments to critical elements and dimensions. Comparative analysis between the physical and virtual grounding models showed similar electromagnetic behavior with minor differences attributed to limitations of the preliminary virtual ground model, especially at lower frequencies. This study highlights the potential of virtual grounding to simplify manufacturing processes and enable the development of costeffective RF devices without significant performance degradation.

title: Analysis of the Evolution and Characteristics of the Collective Interest and Benefit Companies (BIC) in Ecuador, Year 2020-2024
authors: Jorge Luis Garcia Bacuilima, Mohammed Hafidh Mohammed Alkuhlani, Daisy Dayanna Salazar Guaman, Cristian Favia Calle Wilchis
publish: 2025 Congreso Internacional de Innovación y Tendencias en Ingeniería (CONIITI)
abstract: This paper examines the evolution and characteristics of Benefit and Collective Interest (BIC) companies in Ecuador during the 2020–2024 period, within a legal framework that promotes the triple bottom line: economic, social, and environmental impact. Based on official data from the Superintendency of Companies, Securities, and Insurance, the study applies a descriptive and quantitative methodology supported by statistical and visualization tools. The analysis explores the annual growth rate of BIC companies, their geographic distribution, and their economic activities, considering a total of 1,697 registered firms. Results reveal a rapid initial adoption in 2021, followed by a phase of progressive stabilization, with a strong concentration in the Sierra region, especially in Pichincha, and predominance in professional services, commerce, and construction. A comparative perspective with Colombia highlights similarities in the adoption patterns and underscores the importance of regulatory incentives to sustain long-term growth. The findings show that the BIC model represents a promising mechanism for promoting corporate responsibility and sustainability in Ecuador. However, its consolidation requires stronger policy frameworks, measurable impact indicators, and broader sectoral and territorial integration to ensure equitable and sustainable development.

title: Impact of Energy Storage Systems into the Electrical Grid Decarbonization
authors: Ahmed Al Sager, Enrique Marco Kirch
abstract: The integration of a not negligible amount of Renewable Energy Power Plants (RE Plants) is a challenge for any power system, including the one of the KSA. Following the actual tendency towards higher penetration of the renewable energy generation can lead to higher fluctuations in the Renewable Energy System (RES) outputs, that need to be addressed to guarantee efficient grid operation. A VRES (variable renewable energy sources) is a non-dispatchable RES. Due to its fluctuating nature, a VRES cannot behave as a controllable RES such as hydro Energy. Storage is considered as one of the key enablers of the ongoing transition towards more efficient and sustainable energy systems. It depends on the capacity to redirect all or part of the energy flows to a suitable storage system, so that this stored energy can later be released when there is an excess of demand with respect to the generation available at that moment. This Paper analyzes the potential application of TES (Thermal Energy storage), in combination with Combined Power and Heat plants (CHP) and the market conditions where replacing Gas fired Boilers with TES for the generation of Industrial Grade Steam within the CHP is a feasible alternative.

title: Emotion Detection and Classification of Different Saudi Dialects
authors: Rehab K Qarout, Joud Y Samkari, Rahaf M ALFudhayl, Ruba H ALSulami, Shada M Basudan, Ghadi K AlJuhani, Nuha Zamzami
abstract: Detecting emotion refers to identifying the emotion expressed in a given text and is considered a fundamental task in the domain of natural language processing. With the rise of social media, it has become essential to analyze the emotions expressed in these texts and their dialects to understand from which region the users originate and their emotional responses. The Arabic language has faced challenges due to its complexity and the numerous dialects it encompasses, including the Saudi dialect. The data were collected from several sources, and some were manually classified. Moreover, data consists of 3,504 posts (55.7%) that were collected, in addition to 2,783 posts (44.3%) that are available on GitHub. Recently, with the rise of deep learning algorithms, Transformer-based pre-trained models have emerged. This research builds a system using two such models to detect emotion and classify dialects in Saudi texts. MarBERT was used to detect emotions, and SaudiBERT was used to detect dialects, with accuracies of 0.85 and 0.84, respectively. The two models were compared to other pre-trained models (AraBERTv0.2-Twitter, AraRoBERTa-SA, ArabicBert). The SaudiBERT model outperformed in dialect classification, and the MarBERT outperformed in emotion detection.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Deep Learning Methods for Wood Surface Defect Detection: A Comprehensive Study of Semantic Segmentation Approaches
authors: Yuki Yanai, Tomokazu Ishikawa
abstract: Early detection and accurate classification of surface defects are essential for preserving wooden cultural heritage buildings. This study presents a comprehensive comparative evaluation of six state-of-the-art semantic segmentation methods (FCN, PSPNet, DeepLabv3+, DANet, SegFormer, Swin Transformer) for wood surface defect detection. Using a dataset of 2,000 images containing ten defect categories, we evaluated each method's performance under unified experimental conditions. SegFormer achieved the highest performance with 68.83% mIoU and 74.27% mAcc, demonstrating the effectiveness of its hierarchical encoder design for complex wood texture patterns. FCN and DeepLabv3+ achieved competitive performance with shorter training times, making them promising practical options.

title: DS-Evidence-Theory-Based Order Spectrum Sparse Representation Classification for Drivetrain Fault Diagnosis Under Variable Working Conditions
authors: Junhui Qi, Yufan Lv, Yun Kong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Sensing, Measurement &amp; Data Analytics in the era of Artificial Intelligence (ICSMD)
abstract: To address the challenges of fault diagnosis in wind turbine drivetrains under variable speed conditions, this paper proposes a novel method called Dempster-Shafer (DS) evidence theory-based order spectrum sparse representation classification (DS-OSSRC). By integrating multi-sensor data, the proposed approach combines order spectrum analysis and sparse representation classification to extract discriminative speed-invariant features for classifier-free intelligent diagnosis. A decision-level fusion strategy based on DS evidence theory is proposed to effectively resolve the conflicts among individual channel outputs, enhancing diagnostic accuracy and robustness. Experimental validation on a wind turbine drivetrain dataset demonstrates that the proposed method achieves 99.52% accuracy under varying working conditions and significantly outperforms single-sensor-based models and two other fusion strategies, especially in noisy environments. The proposed DS-OSSRC method offers a computationally efficient and reliable solution for cross-condition transfer fault diagnosis.

title: Optimizing Wind Farm Development With Geospatial Analysis in Eastern Saudi Arabia
authors: Mohamed R. Elkadeem, Ali Younes, Jakub Jurasz, Atif S. Alzahrani, Mohammad A. Abido
abstract: This paper presents an integrated geospatial-assisted decision-making framework for evaluating land suitability and energy potential for utility-scale onshore wind turbine installations. By combining geographic information systems and multi-criteria decision-making techniques, the study evaluates site suitability based on climatological, environmental, locational, and topographical factors. Application in Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province reveals that 81.5% of the region is unsuitable due to restrictions like grid remoteness, infrastructure gaps, and prohibited zones such as oil and gas facilities, land use, bird paths, and flood-prone areas) while 18.5% (96.,806 km<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) is moderately suitable. Additionally, capacity factor analysis identifies northwest zones (0.37-0.40) as key areas for maximizing wind energy efficiency. This framework supports Vision 2030 by providing a scalable tool for renewable energy planning and policy development.

title: A Hybrid Symmetrical Optimum-Pattern Search tunned PI Based Three-Phase SRF PLL Synchronization System Under Grid Irregularities
authors: Bibhuti Prasad Sahoo, Adityansu Pati, Raseswari Pradhan
abstract: The rising incorporation of renewable energy sources (RES) is the main factor driving the significance of synchronization of grid in recent years. The synchronous reference frame phase locked loop (SRF PLL) is currently a crucial component of grid-connected power electronic converters (PECs) and is at the heart of synchronization functioning. A loop filter (LF) relied on proportional integral (PI), which is typically included in PLL, is essential for guaranteeing exact frequency and phase angle alignment between PEC and grid. This work suggests a unique PI tuning method relied on the pattern Search (PS) algorithm that fine-tunes the symmetrical optimum (SO)-tuned PI values for the SRF PLL grid synchronization scheme to improve performance. The suggested approach is evaluated in the presence of difficult grid anomalies including abrupt frequency jumps and step amplitude variability. When the proposed SO-PS tuned LF strategy for SRF PLL is contrasted to the current classical SO tuning approach, the MATLAB simulation results show increased dynamic performance and accuracy.
